Ottawa, November 4, 1924.

Sir:

I should be grateful if you would inform me what arrangements can be made to place the magazine known as "The Red Cross Junior" in the larger and better Indian schools of Ontario and other provinces in Canada. Is there an organizer of the Junior Red Cross for the Dominion? I believe that your publication could be used to advantage in approximately 225 Indian schools in Canada and it may be that the Department of Indian Affairs can arrange a special rate.

I have to thank you for your cooperation in the past.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Russell T. Perrier,
Sup't. of Indian Education.

B. B. McGrady, Esq., B. A.,
Canadian Red Cross Society,
410 Harbourne St.,
Toronto, Ont.

INSTRUCTIONS

Note 1.—For country schools please give the number of the School Sections and the name of the Township and County (or District).

Note 2.—For country schools please give the name of the nearest railway station or town and the distance and direction from the same.

Note 3.—As a rule, Junior Red Cross is carried on as a 4-H Club, with officers corresponding to those of the 4-H Club. It is recommended that teachers of primary classes prefer to work with monitors.

Note 4.—All communications regarding the club are sent to the Secretary and not to the Director unless otherwise arranged.

Note 5.—The Secretary also acts as Treasurer in case of clubs.

Note 6.—The Secretary also acts as Trustee in case of Clubs.

Note 7.—Clubs should re-enroll each year in September. Old Clubs will get a form to sign and return to headquarters. New Clubs will be requested. Clones that change of mid-winter promotions may again re-enroll.

Note 8.—New Auxiliaries are supplied with a button for each member and the Secretary should keep a record of members and buttons. Old Auxiliaries that have preserved their last year buttons will, in case of re-enrollment, be supplied with different colored buttons of different years will add interest to the work.

Note 9.—If requested, new Auxiliaries will be supplied with one half as many badges as there are members. Additional supplies may be bought at a nominal cost. Many teachers use the membership buttons also as awards in the Health Game.

Note 10.—Auxiliaries are free to use any money raised for any deserving cause. Contributions for the Canadian National Tuberculosis Association, Orphaned Children's Fund are always welcomed. There is no membership fee.

Note 11.—For the school-year 1924-25, one copy of the Junior Magazine is sent free to each club that requests it regularly. Additional subscriptions are 50 cents a year. Many clubs get more copies.

Note 12.—Committees or Monitors are usually appointed for the following: (1) Personal Hygiene; (2) Room; (3) Programs; (4) Games and Songs; (5) Nurses; (6) First Aid; (7) Minute Books; (8) News; (9) Library; (10) First Aid Cabinet, etc. The responsibilities should be shared by all pupils taking part.

Note 13.—Clubs desiring a good Minute Book and unable to purchase one locally can be supplied at cost price, including postage, 65 cents. Portfolios to hold magazines and news letters, etc., can be furnished at a cost of $1.00.
**ENROLLMENT AND PLEDGE**

In signing our names to this Roll and applying for membership in the Canadian Red Cross Society as a Junior Auxiliary we promise, so far as our ability and our opportunity will enable us, to help the Society in its great mission on behalf of Canada and the World, viz.—The Improvement of Health, the Prevention of Disease, and the Mitigation of Suffering throughout the World.

November 7th, 1924

Russell S. Ferris, M.A.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Bldgs., Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Ferris,

I am pleased to have yours of November 6th, inquiring about the placing of our Junior Red Cross magazine in your Indian schools. I am pleased this inquiry in the hands of Miss Jean Browne, Director of Junior Red Cross for Canada.

You will be interested to know, I am sure, that we now have four Indian Schools enrolled in our membership, viz:-

Bruce Co. No. 1 Cape Croker Reserve, Harry Kolpens, Miss M. Moffitt, Director.

Algoma Bia. Niboni Indian School, Niboni Braves, Miss Florence Kelly, Director.

Algoma Bia. Whitefish Lake School, 4-H Club, Miss A. Toner Director, Naughton.

Bruce Co. Sidney Bay Indian School, Cape Croker Reserve, 4-H Club, Miss M. McGarvey, Director, R.R. #5, Warton.

All of these receive the magazine free each month along with a copy of our newsletter. We will be glad to have all the other Indian Schools in Ontario enroll with us. Even if the classes are not capable of conducting a 4-H Club, they will benefit by enrollment. The enclosed Application Form shows how this is arranged. If you are writing the teachers you might encourage them in this direction. I am sure we can help to stir active wholesome interest in health and good citizenship.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Organizer, Junior Red Cross.
NATIONAL OFFICE,
410 SHERBOURNE ST.,
TORONTO, CANADA

November 8th, 1924.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Parliament Bldgs.,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Mr. McGrady, the Organizer of Junior Red Cross for Ontario, has passed on to me your letter of November 4th. I am greatly delighted with your query regarding the placing of the "Red Cross Junior" in each of the Indian schools in Canada. Some of the Indian schools in Ontario and Saskatchewan are enrolled in the Junior Red Cross, and are engaging in our scheme of inter-school correspondence with Indian schools which are enlisted under the Junior Red Cross in the United States. Some of these portfolios that have come from the United States to our Canadian Indian schools are of great interest.

The "Red Cross Junior" is 50¢ a year or 5¢ a copy. We should be greatly pleased indeed if you will place an order with us for an annual subscription to each of your schools.

I am sending you a few sample copies of the "Red Cross Junior".

Sincerely yours,

Jean E. Browne

National Director, Junior Red Cross, and Editor, "Red Cross Junior".

Ottawa, November 21, 1934.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to placing the "Red Cross Junior" in Indian schools in Canada. I am preparing a list of residential and day schools, to which it is advisable to send the publication. You will be further advised.

I should be grateful if you, in the meantime, would consider offering this Department a club rate. Our business would be very easily handled, considering that there would be but one letter covering the addresses, one letter relative to renewals per annum and one cheque in payment per annum.

My suggestion is that Indian schools generally each receive a copy of "Red Cross Junior." You could send a list of the schools in each province to your provincial organisers. I shall send a circular letter to principals and teachers, explaining about the magazine and informing them that the Department would be glad to learn that they have enrolled with the provincial organisation. I shall also instruct our schools to requisition to the Department if additional copies of the magazine can be used to advantage.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier

Miss Jean E. Browne,
National Director, Junior Red Cross,
410 Sherbourne St.,
Toronto, Ont.

November 28th, 1924.

Russell R. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have your letter of November 21st, and I am delighted that you propose to subscribe for the "Red Cross Junior" for your Indian schools, and that you will write to all your principals and teachers encouraging them to organize Junior Red Cross in their classes.

I discussed the question of club rates for the magazine with the Chairman of the Junior Red Cross Committee as this has not before been considered by the Committee. The Chairman appreciates your proposal very much indeed, but asked me to point out to you that we are now selling the magazine at cost; in fact, last year we had a deficit of approximately $400.00. The best we can do, therefore, is to offer the rate of 40¢ a year as a club rate for an order of 200 or more.

Sincerely yours,

Jean E. Brome
Director, Junior Red Cross, and Editor, "Red Cross Junior".

Ottawa, December 16, 1924.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to placing the "Red Cross Junior" in Indian schools. I have today sent a requisition to the King's Printer for 578 subscriptions for the calendar year 1925. All stationery, books, etc., for government departments must be ordered through the offices of the King's Printer. They will give you a list of the schools to which the magazine should be directed. You will note that there is one subscription for each of the day schools and three for each of the residential schools.

I have informed the King's Printer that we have arranged a club rate of 40¢ a subscription. I have to thank you for your help in this connection and I believe your publication will be of great value to the youth of our Indian wards.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Jean E. Browne,
National Director, Junior Red Cross,

Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,-

I have your letter of December 16th, with the good news that you have requisitioned 372 subscriptions for the "Red Cross Junior". I appreciate your co-operation in the work of Junior Red Cross very much indeed. Your subscriptions will bring our monthly issue up to over 12,000. I am writing at once to our Provincial Division. Your list from the King's Prizes came just now.

Sincerely yours,

Jean E. Binnie

JEB/EC.
Director, Junior Red Cross, and Editor, "Red Cross Junior".
Ottawa, February 20th, 1925.

To Indian Schools,

This Department has arranged with the King's Printer for you to receive during the current year the "Red Cross Junior", a magazine issued monthly by the Canadian Red Cross Society. I believe this magazine will provide interesting reading matter for the pupils of your school and will encourage the development of healthful habits amongst the children.

The Department trusts that you will make general use of the magazine and will utilize the "Health Games" which are promoted by the Red Cross Society through the medium of this publication.

As beneficial results will, no doubt, follow the carrying out of the suggestions furnished monthly in this magazine, it is expected that you will give this new activity the attention it deserves. If additional copies can be used to advantage, you may forward a requisition to the Department. Further, any school that wishes may enroll with the provincial organization of the Red Cross Society.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, February 20, 1925.

Paris,

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Among other interesting things at the League Offices, I find a collection of material art from several of the European countries. The exhibits have been prepared entirely by members of the Junior Red Cross. It occurred to me that we should have here an exhibit of similar work, and it would be all the better if we could secure some samples, made by members of the Junior Red Cross. I think it better to send this request through you than through the provincial organizers, as you will know the schools that could be counted on to produce the best work. I should like to have the exhibit in duplicate so that one part could be sent here, and the other shipped...
in Canada for explicit purposes.

As I shall be here until the middle of July, I shall be glad to hear from you in this connection.

With many thanks in advance,

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Yours sincerely,

John E. Binnie
Director General Red Cross in Canada.
Ottawa, May 8, 1925.

Dear Madam:

I have your letter of the 17th ultimo, with reference to an Indian Exhibit for the Junior Red Cross League Headquarters. It would be difficult to secure samples of children's work that would be a credit to them and to us at the end of the academic year. If you will make suggestions as to what type of work would be suitable for the purpose you mention, I shall be glad to cooperate with you in the fall, with a view to securing something for both Canadian and League Headquarters.

I trust that you are enjoying your stay overseas and that you will have a pleasant journey home.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

THE LEAGUE
OF RED CROSS SOCIETIES

ORIGIN, ACTIVITIES, PURPOSES

Origin and primary Purpose of the Red Cross Movement.

The Red Cross is the symbol of human compassion. A Genevese citizen named Henry Dunant, who had been profoundly moved by the sufferings of the wounded whom he had seen on the battlefield of Solferino in June 1859, embarked on a campaign which led to the formation in 1863 of a Genevese Committee for the mitigation of the sufferings of wounded soldiers in time of war. This committee, which later took the name of Comité International de la Croix-Rouge, secured the signature by the principal States of the world to the Geneva Convention of 1864, which, revised in 1906, constitutes the basis of the code of civilized warfare to-day.

The primary purpose of the National Red Cross Societies which have arisen since 1864 in nearly all civilized countries has been, until 1919, to care for the sick, wounded and prisoners of armies and navies in times of war.

The Comité International de la Croix-Rouge has, since its foundation, continued to act as the custodian of the principles of the Red Cross and of the Geneva Convention. The International Red Cross Conferences, of which eleven have met in the past 60 years, are summoned by this Committee, and new Red Cross Societies receive official recognition from it.
Peace Programme and Foundation of the League of Red Cross Societies.

In 1919, on the initiative of Mr. Henry P. Davison, Chairman of the War Council of the American Red Cross, the Red Cross Societies of the United States, France, Great Britain, Italy and Japan founded the League of Red Cross Societies. The purpose of the League, which today comprises fifty-one national Red Cross Societies, is to maintain in time of peace the enthusiasm and devotion displayed during the war by the National Red Cross Societies in the relief of human suffering, and to utilize this great force for the purposes stated as follows in Article 2 of the Articles of Association of the League:

1. "To encourage and promote in every country in the world the establishment and development of a duly authorized voluntary national Red Cross organization having as purposes the improvement of health, the prevention of disease and the mitigation of suffering throughout the world, and to secure the co-operation of such organizations for these purposes."

2. "To promote the welfare of mankind by furnishing a medium for bringing within the reach of all the peoples the benefits to be derived from present known facts and new contributions to science and medical knowledge and their application."

3. "To furnish a medium for co-ordinating relief work in case of great national or international calamities."

The present programme of the League.

The League had been in existence for three years, during which time experiments and investigations of every kind were pursued by its Secretariat, before the General Council, at its second meeting in March, 1922, was able to formulate a specific programme in conformity with these general purposes. The General Council then urged upon the National Red Cross Societies the development of their organization on the basis of popular membership in order to assure to the Red Cross the greatest possible influence, especially invited their attention to "the pressing need which exists at the present time to create among all classes an intelligent demand for better health conditions and an increasing knowledge of the means of securing them", and recommended to them "the adoption of peacetime programmes aimed specially at meeting this need through the development, with the cooperation of the League Secretariat, of Popular Health Instruction, Public Health Nursing and Junior Red Cross Organization; the latter constituting in the judgment of the Council a specially valuable means of securing the education of the coming generation in health matters, as part of its general purpose of instilling into children at the most impressionable age the spirit of service which lies at the basis of the Red Cross ideal."

The resolutions adopted by the General Council at its third meeting, in April 1924, endorsed and amplified this programme, laying additional stress on the relief functions of the Red Cross, and on "the great importance of the role which the Secretariat of the League can exercise in regard to international relief activities."

Special attention was also drawn by the resolutions of this meeting to the desirability of action being undertaken by the Red Cross for the improvement of health conditions in the Merchant Marine. Red Cross Societies were also urged to continue and amplify their activities in the direction of training volunteer personnel for work in the health and social fields, and organizing the services of the personnel so trained, besides extending the facilities they offer to the public in the form of elementary courses in First Aid, Home Nursing, Personal Hygiene, etc.

The Organization of the League.

The control of the affairs of the League is vested in a General Council and a Board of Governors.

*The Board of Governors, which is the competent authority to revise the Constitution of the League, elected May 1924 to defer until December 31, 1925, the coming into force of a number of amendments to the Articles of Association and By-laws, which have been approved by the Board. The general effect of these amendments is:
(1) to place the control of the affairs of the League in the hands of the Board of Governors;
(2) to enlarge the Board of Governors so as to comprise
The General Council meets at least once every two years, and consists of not more than five delegates of each National Red Cross Society belonging to the League. Each Red Cross Society's delegation has one vote at the General Council. All Red Cross Societies organized in accordance with the principles laid down by the Comité International de la Croix-Rouge and subscribing to the programme indicated in the League's statutes are eligible for membership in the League. The Board of Governors, which meets at least once every year, consists of representatives of each of the five founder Societies and ten nominees of Societies designated by the General Council, with the Director General and Secretary General of the League as ex-officio members. The Board elects its own Chairman. The Director General is the chief executive officer of the League, and is nominated by the Board of Governors, as is also the Secretary General. The Secretariat, of which the Director General is the head, comprises a staff of about 70 persons of various nationalities. Besides the Central Secretariat, which handles questions of information, liaison and organization, as well as the publications of the League, and the financial services and the Treasurer General, it includes specialists in Health, Nursing, Junior Red Cross and Relief. The Secretariat, which was originally established at Geneva, was transferred to Paris in 1922 by decision of the General Council, Paris affording a more convenient centre for extensive international activities.

The expenses of the activities of the Secretariat are met by contributions from National Red Cross Societies belonging to the League. Up to the present time, the greater part of these expenses has been borne by the American Red Cross, which in 1919 voted a substantial sum to constitute a guarantee fund during the first years of the League's existence. The other national Societies were first asked to contribute to the League's budget in 1922. During the year 1922-23 eighteen of these Societies voted contributions. For the year 1923-24 a total of 35 national Societies have contributed. Duly audited accounts are published annually.

The Activities of the Secretariat.

The prime function of the Secretariat lies in assisting National Red Cross Societies to develop their organization and membership, and the peacetime activities best calculated to improve health, prevent disease and mitigate suffering in their respective countries, by means not at variance with their several national traditions, and in co-operation so far as possible with governments and other agencies. As a natural corollary to the efforts made by the different National Red Crosses to further the coordination of national health and welfare activities in their respective countries, the League Secretariat seeks to secure greater co-ordination of these activities internationally. With this end in view, the Secretariat, besides constituting an instrument for facilitating joint action, when opportunity arises, on the part of the Red Cross Societies of different countries, has also established close co-operative relations with the other international organizations which are concerned with health and welfare problems. It works in close touch with the Office International d'Hygiène Publique in Paris, the Health Organization of the League of Nations and the Industrial Health Service of the International Labour Office, as well as with the Pan-American Sanitary Bureau and the Rockefeller Foundation. The Chairman of the International Council of Nurses is also Chairman of the Nursing Advisory Board of the League. The headquarters of the League affords accommodation and secretarial facilities to the International Unions against Tuberculosis and Venereal Disease, and to the provisional Committee of the nascent International Union against Cancer. The Secretariat is also in close touch with other organizations engaged in combating the evils of alcoholism and slum conditions, and in promoting mental hygiene.

Relations with the Comité International de la Croix-Rouge in Geneva are maintained by the intermediary...
of a Joint Council constituted in April, 1921*, in which members of the Committee and of the League's Secretariat meet periodically to consider questions which affect both bodies, and to ensure that any duplication of work shall be avoided. The Joint Council gives special attention to disasters the magnitude of which demands international relief measures.

The Secretariat maintains contact with National Red Cross Societies by means of correspondence and by constant visits of members of the League staff to National Societies and of officers of these Societies to the Secretariat of the League. In addition to the biennial meetings of the General Council, group conferences are periodically organized by the Secretariat to secure the exchange of views and experiences between representatives of National Societies with similar geographical, economic and social conditions and problems, and to facilitate their cooperation in meeting them.

The First Oriental Red Cross Conference brought together representatives of seven Red Cross Societies of the Far East at Bangkok in November 1922; the Eastern European Societies sent delegates to the Warsaw Conference in April 1923, and representatives of fifteen American societies met at Buenos Aires in November 1923.

The Secretariat publishes a monthly review entitled "The World's Health" in three editions, English, French and Spanish, with a total circulation of 15,000 copies, and also issues to member Societies and to such persons as are directly interested, a fortnightly Information Circular containing notes regarding its activities and those of member Societies, and detailed studies of specific problems based on Red Cross experience in different countries. With this circular are included popular articles on subjects connected with health and with other features of the Red Cross programme, which are available for reproduction by Red Cross Societies in their own publications or in the press. Articles published by the League Secretariat have been quoted or reproduced in other publications more than 8,000 times. The League also helps to subsidize a scientific monthly journal, entitled "Matriaux pour l'Etude des Calamités," published by the Geographical Society of Geneva under the joint auspices of the League and the Comité International de la Croix-Rouge. This publication was started in the summer of 1924 with a view to stimulating interest and research in the scientific world as to the causes of natural disasters and their prevention.

In addition to its periodical publications, the Secretariat prepares and issues special pamphlets when requested to do so by any member Society, or when a specific need arises. Eight such pamphlets, some of them in nine languages, have so far appeared. It also prepares for National Red Cross Societies, whenever called upon to do so, special documentary studies regarding the organization of specific types of activities.

A small library of standard works dealing with Red Cross questions, Public Health and related topics, has been collected in the offices of the Secretariat, which also maintains collections of health propaganda material of all kinds, cinematograph films (about 100), posters, pamphlets (2,200 in 17 different languages), etc.

These collections are at the disposal of National Red Cross Societies belonging to the League. From April 1922 to October 1924 the pamphlets sent out on request from these collections numbered over 7,500, in addition to 800 posters. League films have been lent for use in 26 different countries. The average number of films sent out in reply to requests is six each month. Each film comprises 5 to 10 reels.

A permanent exhibition of Red Cross material has been assembled at the League headquarters for the benefit of visitors. Travelling exhibits for propaganda purposes and for loan to member Societies are prepared by the Secretariat as required.

Some Results achieved by the League.

The League has been directly instrumental in securing the organization or recognition of National Red Cross Societies in twenty-two countries where no recognized independent Red Cross Societies previously existed. The membership of existing Societies has been increased and the Secretariat has been called upon at different times

---

* The Board of Governors decided in April 1924 to renew the 1921 agreement until December 31, 1925, and to abrogate it as from that date.
to assist nearly all the Societies belonging to the League in formulating and launching their peacetime programme. Almost all National Red Cross Societies have now assumed responsibility for extensive activities in the Public Health field in time of peace. In almost every case these activities are of a markedly educational character, aimed at affording to the masses of the people the opportunity of appreciating the advantages of hygienic habits, at teaching them what hygiene is, and at preparing them to use the hygienic equipment already at their disposal and to demand more. The Health Division has given special attention to the question of mobile health propaganda units. One such unit, launched in Czecho-Slovakia in 1921, enabled 400 lectures to be given to a total of 160,000 persons. The demonstration led to the establishment of two such units on a permanent basis by the Czecho-Slovak Red Cross. A similar unit was set up in Poland in 1922 with no less satisfactory results. The Nursing Division of the Secretariat has organized an International Course in London for teachers of Public Health Nursing, at which 66 nurses from 34 different countries have been or are being trained in nursing and Public Health work; in at least six of these countries Public Health Nursing was previously unknown. This course, started in 1921, has been repeated every year since. A similar course in the administration of schools for nurses has been arranged to start in 1924. In three countries, Red Cross nursing schools have been organized or reorganized with the help of this Division.

The League Secretariat organized in 1921 three conferences at which experts from Eastern, Western, and Northern European countries respectively were enabled to exchange views and formulate principles of anti-venereal work. In 1923 the League was instrumental in securing the constitution of the Union Internationale contre le Pévil Vénérien, and members of the League staff constitute the secretariat of this organization, as well as (since 1922) the secretariat of the International Union for Combating Tuberculosis. The development of Child Welfare work in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and particularly in Czecho-Slovakia and Roumania has been fostered by the League Secretariat, which has worked in close co-operation with the various agencies, both national and foreign, engaged in Child Welfare work throughout Eastern Europe.

Thirty-seven Red Cross Societies, with the assistance of the Junior Red Cross Division in the League's Secretariat, have organized, or are now organizing, Junior Sections for the purpose of "inculcating in the school children of their several countries the ideal of peace and the practice of service, especially in relation to the care of their own health and that of others, the understanding and acceptance of human and civic responsibility, and the cultivation of a spirit of friendly helpfulness toward other children in all countries." Co-operative relations have been established with organizations interested in other children's movements.

In July 1923 the American Junior Red Cross incorporated its European office with the Junior Red Cross Division of the League Secretariat, the latter accepting responsibility for the administration of the funds allocated by American Juniors for the purpose of furthering Junior organization in European countries.

In the relief field, the League Secretariat has hitherto devoted its main efforts to assembling documentation with a view to the compilation of an international code of disaster relief problems and methods. The League played an important part in assisting the Red Cross Societies of Eastern Europe — notably the Polish, Czecho-Slovak and Serbo-Croato-Slovene Societies — to meet the epidemic crisis in 1920, when the possibility of a general extension of typhus fever throughout Europe gave rise to grave apprehensions; and, in connection with the Comité International de la Croix-Rouge, the League has assisted in co-ordinating the dispatch of relief to the victims of the famines in Russia in 1921 and in Germany and Albania in 1924, and of the earthquakes in Chili, Colombia, Costa-Rica, Ecuador, Japan and Persia in 1923. The Secretariat has also placed personnel at the disposal of the Mixed Commission for the exchange of populations between Greece and Turkey under the Treaty of Lausanne.

The Mobilization of the Red Cross for Peacetime Work.

The purposes of the League of Red Cross Societies are incontestably worth attaining. If the results already
secured appear to give reasonable promise of future success, the essential means to this end is the enrolment under the banner of the Red Cross of all those who want a healthier and a better world, and are prepared to devote time, money or service to this purpose. The power of the great educational movement, for which the League of Red Cross Societies is working, represents the sum total of the strength of National Red Cross Societies, and the strength of National Red Cross Societies depends upon the support which local Red Cross sections can command. A Red Cross Society can attain its maximum effectiveness only when every citizen is a member of the local section of his National Red Cross Society, taking an enlightened interest in the humanitarian purposes for which the Red Cross exists, and ready to give personal assistance in their realization.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg leave to make a brief report regarding the contact made with your Indian schools in Ontario and our Junior Red Cross. You will remember that your Department subscribed for our junior magazine to be sent to each school. Besides this, seven of your schools have formally enrolled to "play the health game" as Auxiliaries of our Society. I have had reports from a number of the teachers who have had this experience. These go to show that it has been of much benefit to the pupils and community. I am enclosing these reports for your perusal. Please let us have them back before long as I wish to make further use of them.

This experience has led me to think that we might be able to help your schools in a larger way in association with our organization. If all your teachers could be induced to link their pupils with our Society (there is no charge for this whatever) we might be able to develop a sort of "Indian School Pride" amongst these isolated groups. Once a month for example, in connection with our News Letter which is sent with every magazine, we might have a special page dealing with the work in the Indian Schools. In addition we might be able to arrange for interchange of school portfolios and letters of friendship between the schools.

Shall be pleased to have your consideration of these matters and comments. There can be no doubt that the training of Indian children in good health habits would be of inestimable value.

Yours very truly,

Director, Ontario Junior Red Cross.

Dear Mr. McCready:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, relative to Junior Red Cross activity in Ontario Indian schools. I am delighted that there has been some response to this effort and it was with considerable interest that I examined the papers which you enclosed.

A few months ago, when the Department arranged for some 70 Indian schools in Ontario to receive the "Red Cross Junior," a circular letter was directed to the teachers. This letter read in part as follows:

"The Department trusts that you will make general use of the magazine and will utilize the "Health Games" which are promoted by the Red Cross Society through the medium of this publication.

"As beneficial results will, no doubt, follow the carrying out of the suggestions furnished monthly in this magazine, it is expected that you will give this new activity the attention it deserves. If additional copies can be used to advantage, you may forward a requisition to the Department. Further, any school that wishes may enroll with the provincial organization of the Red Cross Society."

I feel that the incentive to organize a formal Red Cross Auxiliary in an Indian school should come from within the school itself, if we desire to have real and permanent usefulness. The movement is now in the missionary stage and I believe it would be better for it to develop as interest is awakened. Indian schools which have not formally enrolled will learn from time to time from your News Letter that other Indian schools are profiting by enrolment and, I hope, will correspond with you yourselves.

I wish to thank you for your cooperation and for your interest and I trust that much good will result from your efforts. The papers which you directed to me are enclosed herewith.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Miss Browne:

I have been intending for some time to write you with reference to the Indian Schools in New Brunswick. I understood from correspondence received from you last winter that Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Schools, was anxious to have these schools enrolled in Junior Red Cross, and that that was one of his main reasons for sending them the "Red Cross Junior".

With this idea in mind I wrote to each of these schools last Spring, and sent some of our New Brunswick literature. I had replies from two. The Teacher at Kingsclear, Miss Elizabeth Toner, was most interested, and wanted to start the branch at once. I sent her complete information, and as I was visiting Fredericton, my annual visit to the Normal School, at that time, I thought it worthwhile, as she seemed anxious for me to do so, to hire a taxi and drive out to her school. It cost six dollars, but I felt it was quite worthwhile as it meant the enrolling of that branch. I spent about an hour in her school, and found the children and teacher most interested. Miss Toner told me that their Parish Priest had been planning to come to the school, as he was very much interested. But he had a sick call and was unable to be present. I left with Miss Toner the Enrollment Form, and she promised to send it in the following week. It did not arrive so in June I wrote to her, and received this reply:

"I received your letter today, sorry to have put you to the inconvenience, but I will not be able to send in the Enrollment Form, until I hear from the Inspector, Reverend F.C Ryan, as he said he would take the matter up with Mr. Ferrier."

The other teacher who replied to my letter was Sister Mary Isidore of the Maliseet Reservation. Sister wrote me:

"Our fifty little Indian children are anxious to start a branch, and we would like to fill out the Enrollment Form as soon as possible. No doubt it will be rather difficult for them to keep all the rules, but with encouragement on our part, which we are very desirous to give, we hope to make this a success."
I immediately sent her the literature and Enrollment Form, but did not hear from her again. I suppose the difficulty is the same as in the other case.

The question has been bothering me for some time, but has been neglected, as there seem to have been so many other teachers anxious to take up the work, who required immediate attention.

Now that I have a chance to check up a few of these cases, I am wondering just what to do about these Indian Schools, in as much as they do not come under our Provincial School System. So I thought I would refer the matter to you.

Very sincerely yours,

(sgd) Jessie I Lawson.

**Grandmother Frog and the Crab**

There was once an old Frog and she had a daughter who went by the name of Cinderella Frog because she was very grey. When Spring came Mother Frog spun some green yarn, damped it and wound it up. Then she called the Crab to help her to thread the yarn on her loom in order to weave it into a coat. The Crab was in love with Cinderella, the daughter, and when it grew dark he mounted a grey horse, took a freshly baked cake under his arm and rode off. Mother Frog tried to ask the hand of her daughter. Mother Frog seized the shuttle and began to beat him with it, shrieking: "Be off with you, he off! My daughter Cinderella is not for you. She sits the whole day beside me, threading pearls and gems for me." And as Mother Frog lifted up the shuttle, the yarn slipped out of her hands and got all unravelled.

So in Spring a green thread swims in the river like a weft. This is the broken loom of the Frog. And this is also why frogs are still go unclad up to this day. And the Crab, as the Frog pursued him, retired backwards defending himself till he could escape her. From that day the Crab began to go backwards and has walked that way ever since.

—from the Bulgarian Collection of Folklore and Literature. Published in the Czechoslovakian Junior Red Cross Magazine.

The Indians of Canada

An Indian acting as guide to a fisherman. Courtesy of the Canadian Pacific Railways.

WE ARE accustomed to think of the Indian as a semi-wild man roaming through the northern wilds of Canada. This is far from the truth. Of the 100,000 Indians now in Canada the majority live on Government reservations and are looked after as the children of the Government. Our Indians wear the same kind of clothing as we do, except on festive occasions, when they don the very picturesque costumes seen in the photograph of Stony Indian Chiefs of Alberta.

Many of the Indians nowadays are farmers and ranchers. Their children are educated in schools just as the white children are, while orphaned Indian children are looked after in special residential schools. Last year nearly $2,000,000 was set aside by the Dominion Government for educational purposes among the Indians. Their health also is carefully safeguarded, and as a result, the Indians, who had been dying off from the ravages of tuberculosis and other diseases, are now increasing in numbers.

The Indian, as a rule, is a good citizen. He is patient, honest, and fairly industrious. During the war he showed his citizenship in a striking way. Over 35 per cent. of the male Indians of fighting age enlisted voluntarily in the Canadian army. This number is as large as it is possible to get from any population. The Indian had no obligation in this war, for, as a ward of the Government, he could not be called upon for active service. He rapidly became a smart, well disciplined, first class soldier. About 4,000 Indians volunteered for active service and a large number of these received decorations and medals for conspicuous bravery. They served mostly in fighting units, including the air force. One Indian travelled 3,000 miles to enlist, and many swamged from the shores of the Arctic Ocean to serve "The Great White Mother." On their return many of them were given public receptions. Quite a number died from tuberculosis contracted as a result of service in the field.

In the Sagkeeng group of the city of Indians there were only eight able-bodied men and these all volunteered for service and went overseas. In other tribes over 50 per cent. volunteered, in some cases only two or three able-bodied men being left in each reserve. The pictures shown are Indians from one of the Plain Tribes. Most of these Plain Indians were great fighters. The Indian head...
Canadian Order of Foresters, until he died, was a veritable business man. The Indian and others have shown that the Indian has great possibilities and capacity in all fields when he receives suitable training. J. J. Oke, an outstanding Iroquois preacher, who lives near Montreal, is a universal genius. He looks like a looking man with the dark brown eyes of his race. In truth, through civilization, the Indian is rapidly becoming very similar to the white man. As the years go by the Indian in Canada is being held in ever higher esteem by the white man.

The total estimated value of real and personal property of Indians in Canada is $72,000,000, and the Government has Trust Funds on deposit for them to the amount of $12,000,000. Their estimated total annual income is $10,300,000.

The Government is systematically improving conditions among the Indians by inducing them to build better houses and learn more about farming and raising cattle and improving their stock. Ploughing and seed competitions are held among the Indian tribes to stimulate improvements in their agricultural methods. Schools and churches are doing a great deal to steady the Indian and make him capable of competing with the white man. Though he is a ward of the Government, he can now become a regular citizen by agreeing to take his share of the prosperity that belongs to him and become independent like other citizens. Of course, it is difficult to induce some of the older Indians to give up all of their ancient customs. Many of them still act as guides and fishermen in the summer and as hunters in the winter time. But women and men are excellent at handicrafts such as bead work and basket weaving, and earn money in this way. For years it has been against the law to sell liquor to an Indian, one of the best regulations ever suggested for helping to make him a successful citizen.

On the Pacific Coast of British Columbia one often sees Indians, Japanese, and Chinese together, and it is sometimes difficult to tell which is which. Their features are so similar, one is almost forced to believe from their appearance alone that the Indians were derived from Asiatic stock which crossed the Pacific centuries ago. It has been recently proved that a large proportion of the Indians of Canada came originally from the heart of Asia and are related from the language point of view with the Tibetan Chinese races. Probably five thousand years or more ago they left the cradle of their race and came across the Behring Strait in migrant waves by way of Siberia and Alaska.

—G. G. Neumith.

A Five Year Old Member

A little Syrian girl living in Montreal has wanted to become a member of the Junior Red Cross for the last year. Recently she reached the tremendous age of five years old, and her birthday had been 99 cents out of money which had been given her for candy. This she gave to the Junior Red Cross, was made a member and received a pin. She can barely understand English, but her leader says that she has certainly grasped the idea of service for others.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

Your letters to hand, contents well noted, I fail to see what good could come from the linking up of our Indian schools to Provincial organizations of any kind.

As for the "Red Cross Junior," if I understand it rightly, it would be absurd to undertake to ask the Indian children to observe the health rules so required by this society, their living, housing, & financial condition render such impossible. Morally speaking, it would be very unwise to lay down a set of rules to INDIANS when we realize from the start that not one half of same could be respected.

I feel that our Domestic Science is nothing other than the Junior Red Cross made workable for the Indians, and as we advance, we can draw nearer to perfection, year by year.

Our Domestic teachers could form both a "JUNIOR & Senior League" with further rules workable to the INDIAN, and The Dept. could offer prizes for the ones who would better observe said regulations on each Reserve, then a general one to the Reserve that (ONLY) would in general lead, -The Dept. being the Judge.

I feel I have covered the case in question in justice to both the Dept. & Indians, so I trust my letter will not be considered merely as a DIPLOMATIC ONE.

I trust the boys are all well in the Dept. Do remember me to all, and in a special way to Mr. Scott. I will be in Ottawa about the 15th or 16th of June. I will be on my way to Chicago. I will visit the Indian schools a little earlier this TERM.

Dear Mrs. Speechly,

Both the children and I were pleased to receive your letter of the twenty-third of February along with the roll of posters and the package of buttons. We were sworn in members of the Junior Red Cross yesterday. You may be sure the ceremony was fitting. Today the children proudly display their buttons. The wall posters attract considerable attention. I have told them of the charter to follow and they impatiently await its arrival.

No doubt you will be curious to know the attending ceremony of swearing in. I thought it would add dignity and impressiveness to the proceedings if a little ritual was introduced. We spent yesterday morning doing that.

First, I told them that "the lady in Winnipeg" had answered their letter. This answer I read to them, having it interpreted by the one pupil who understands enough English to do that. The children were highly pleased.

Then, I explained to them each poster, showing how it was possible for them to follow each health rule; except maybe the matter of vegetables in winter. (The Indians are too nomadic to be gardeners. Though they plant spring seed, there are but few who attend to their gardens in summer and they become choked with weeds.) When you show them results by producing yourself they say: "Oh, but you're different! You're a white man, not an Indian!"

With the concluding explanation of the posters the children became members of the Junior Red Cross. This was done as follows:

Each child came to my desk and with his hand on the Bible said:

"I promise to keep my body clean."
"I promise to keep my mind clean."
"I promise to help others and be kind to animals."

With these promises he was declared a member and a button presented.
The remainder of the morning was spent in enlarging on the three promises, especially the latter, for they are inclined to be thoughtless of others and regard animals as if without feeling. Numerous stories and illustrations to show how more fun and benefit could be had from spying on a squirrel to learn some of his habits than shooting him with a bow and arrow; how it would be more jolly to watch a nest of eggs hatch and later feed the young, than it would be to dash the little eggs against some tree; how it would be pleasanter to build houses for the song birds, than to use them as targets.

Various penalties were decided on should any promises be broken.

We shall anticipate the arrival of the charter, for the framing of which we all send you our hearty thanks. We have already decided on the place where we shall hang it; beside the flag.

For all your trouble I am most grateful and feel sure a deal of good will come of it.

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) Charles Clay.
North Temiskaming,
April 11 - 1928.

Mrs. Ruth B. Shaw,
45 Belmont Park,
Montreal, Que.

Dear Mrs. Shaw,

This letter will seem like an echo from the grave, it is so long since we corresponded, but, just now, I have a particular object in writing.

Last winter the Minawasis undertook to send a box of home-made valentines to the Children's Hospital for Valentine Day, but, storms and bad roads prevented us from getting material from Liskeard so they abandoned the idea when their supply of material was exhausted. They intended keeping the few they made till next Valentine Day, but I am leaving in June, so we decided to forward the valentines. I think there are sufficient for a small group of sick children. I am donating the moccasins and the enclosed is for a fruit treat for the little group.

We have had an awful winter, but, the little Minawasis have been comparatively healthy. I assure you the Red Cross literature has benefitted them immensely. They knew enough now to take sanitary precautions - something they never did before.

I have no idea where I shall be next year. I intend to rest till next spring and then take a Summer School if I can get one from the Indian Department.

I thank you for all you have done for the Indian children that have been in my charge for the last six years and appreciate very much the weight you have taken off my shoulders. Before we established the Red Cross Club, it was nothing unusual for me to have to send the children home to wash and comb - now they understand better.

Wishing you every success,

I remain,

Yours gratefully,

(signed) Catherine Henan.
SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT ON
INDIAN SCHOOLS
ORGANIZED FOR JUNIOR RED CROSS.

There are 14 Indian Schools in Canada enrolled as Junior Red Cross branches with a membership of 350.

"The Canadian Red Cross Junior" goes to every Indian School in Canada. It is subscribed for by Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Schools, Indian Department, Ottawa.

According to reports received from the provincial divisions, the Indian Juniors are quite active, in selling Christmas Seals, Junior Magazines, home-made candy and sweet-hay baskets. Their contributions to the Crippled Children's fund through these activities have been considerable. A few have prepared portfolios for exchange and others have made excellent exhibit material, such as sweet-hay baskets, bead-work, miniature canoes and wigwams. These examples of native art have been much appreciated wherever they have been exhibited.

Undoubtedly through Junior Red Cross good health habits have been established. The wife of one of the Principals of an Indian residential school in Alberta writes, "Until we tried Junior Red Cross we could not get the children to see any reason why they should clean their teeth and brush their hair, etc., but now we have no more trouble for each child now feels his own responsibility in these things.

The following is a letter written by Mr. MacDonald, Principal of the Whycocomagh Indian School, Nova Scotia,
which explains what Junior Red Cross has done for his school.

Received your letter of the 13th and I now gladly attempt to give you the required information. I am pleased to state that I consider the organization and existence of this branch of the Junior Red Cross, a real success, not only to my pupils; but likewise to the parents and home folks who are quick to practise the health habits of the children, when same are seen to be of advantage.

As may be generally and truthfully understood, the rules of sanitation were not strictly followed and carried out by the Indians, living as they did in wigwams and feasting on whatever the day's hunting and fishing produced. The error was partly through ignorance and partly through neglect and even to this day, some are inclined to consider the ancient manner of living superior to the present; but these ideas are rapidly diminishing and without doubt the Junior Red Cross is partly responsible.

Many of our "white people" consider the average Indian to be dull and stupid and devoid of the intelligence of modern life. This idea is false and without foundation or proof. The Indian of today cannot be compared with the
Indian of yesterday and to consider them inferior to the average human being is nothing short of degraded ignorance. They have their classes good and bad, like the "white people" and in many cases they could teach us lessons well worth learning. The noted Canadian writer, George Pearson, while describing a visit to Nova Scotia, for the Regina Leader, commented on the snow white and clean appearance of the homes of the Whyocomagh Indians.

The school children are examined by the Health Nurse of the Indian Department, quarterly, and are always found as followers of the "Rules of the Health Game" and from experience, I can truthfully say that the Junior Red Cross is largely responsible for the existing conditions.

A visit to our school will convince anyone that the Red Cross badge is not worn for its ornamental purpose only. You may not find the pupils attired in the height of fashion and the clothing of the rich; but you will find, boys and girls with clean bodies, who had a good breakfast of porridge and milk, who walked knee-deep in snow while coming to school after sleeping last night by open windows. In
bringing these conditions about, I give due and just credit to the Junior Red Cross and feel confident that in after school days, the health habits will not be forgotten."
May 3rd, 1928.

Mr. Ferrier,
Superintendent of Indian Schools,
Indian Department,
Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

This morning I received an account of a visit of one of our Junior Red Cross workers in the province of Quebec to a Junior Red Cross meeting in the Indian Day School in St. Regis village, and I thought you would be interested in hearing her account of it:

"It was the occasion of the presentation of the Red Cross Flag to the Wa-ka-tas-kat Juniors who had won it for this year, tying with the Juniors of the Huntingdon High School, this being the Flag competed for by all the Groups in the counties of Beauharnois, Chateauguay and Huntingdon. The teachers, Miss MacNulty and Miss Morris, knew I was arriving some time during the week but owing to the fact that there are only two mails per week only had a two hours' notice of my arrival. There are 50 Juniors in the school, all in Grades 1 to 5. The meeting was presided over by the President, a small boy, who called the meeting to order, announced the various items and asked for all the different reports from each officer and committee head in a most businesslike manner. These reports were clearly and well read. The Secretary called the roll and each Junior answered promptly and distinctly. I ought to say that the meeting opened with the Juniors' Pledge, and closed with God Save the King and the presentation to me of some pretty Indian baskets. REQ. No. 7865
WA-KA-TAS-KAT JUNIORS HAVE ACTIVE YEAR

The Wa-Ka-Tas-Kat Juniors of the Indian Day School at St. Regis, Quebec, have had a very active year as their excellent annual report shows.

The teacher says that the gains in personal hygiene have been remarkable, especially in regard to cleanliness and ventilation. She reports that all the members look much healthier since they have established the habit of sleeping with open windows. Their idea of cleanliness has extended to their school and school grounds.

On Arbor Day, the Wa-Ka-Tas-Kat Juniors cleaned their school and school grounds, sprayed the wet spots with oil to keep down the mosquitoes, sowed flower seeds in garden plots and window boxes and planted 25 maple trees.

This year they have started a campaign for protecting birds' nests and nestlings.

The teacher writes that the Juniors were devoted to their sick this year. They took all sorts of dainties to the shut-ins in the village and sent boxes to hospital patients in Cornwall. They made themselves very helpful in homes where the mothers were sick by minding children, washing dishes, sweeping, carrying water and wood, making fires and other useful jobs.

In addition to all these splendid acts of service, these Indian Juniors made 30 Halloween cards, 12 Christmas cards,
30 Easter cards, 6 scarves and 29 wash-cloths which they sent to the office of the Quebec Division to be distributed to children in hospitals.

We shall have to find out what the Indian word "Wa-Ka-Tay-Kat" means. I am sure it must be something very fine.
June 14, 1929.

Superintendent of Indian Education,

Secretaries, Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

Referring to your inquiry as to the possibility of forming a branch of the Junior Red Cross League in connection with the above school, I have come to the conclusion that it is not yet ripe enough to undertake such a movement. The children are mostly young and primitive in their knowledge of spoken English, and their parents suffer from chronic unemployment when anything but their own immediate wants are concerned. The executors are not always of a type to form leaders in a matter of this kind, whether male or female. On the whole, after much careful thought, I think it will be best just to go on promoting a deeper interest in the Junior Red Cross League till the time favours something more advanced.

I myself shall be glad to give a regular donation to the funds of the league, with the hopes of actual sympathy.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

During the past couple of months we have had with us at the Head of the Lakes a Doctor Loretto O'Connor, the Directress of the Junior Red Cross for Ontario.

She came to Fort Arthur with a letter from the Department of Education to the Public School Inspector, but, after she had been around all his schools, I took care to have her go around the separate schools also.

And, it seemed to me, anything worth while talking about to ordinary school children in regard to health should be doubly worth while in the case of our Indian children; I therefore asked the Doctor to visit Fort William Residential School, and we would have gone to Mission Bay had it been possible to secure a conveyance capable of manoeuvring the roads.

The Doctor was due to speak to the pupils in the public school at Nipigon last Thursday. I suggested, half jokingly, that she might like to go out to Lake Helen, never supposing that she would face the long tramp through the snow. But, to my surprise, she jumped at the idea. And so we went up last Wednesday, taking Miss Leusch unexpectedly, since she would never have thought anyone would go over that trail without having to, especially with the chilling wind that was blowing. However the Doctor tramped it out, (I believe she got her ship frozen) and spoke to the children. In the afternoon the mothers came down and she spoke to them also.

I had invited Dr. O'Connor to make the rounds of the schools on Manitoulin Island in the spring, something she seemed quite keen on doing, but, before taking her around, I thought I had better find out what your views were on the matter.

If, as I suspect, you would be only too glad to have her interest herself in the Indian Schools as well as in the Provincial ones, I thought of making this suggestion. She visits all the Normal schools regularly, and will soon be visiting Ottawa Normal. Would you like to drop her a line inviting her to call upon you when she is in Ottawa? I have sounded her out, and I feel confident that there are few things that she would appreciate more. And, as all her expenses are borne by the Red Cross, there will be no expense incurred by your Department.

The Doctor's address is: c/o Junior Red Cross,
Ontario Division.
410 Sherbourne Street.
Toronto, 5.

With kindest regards & Yours sincerely,

The Florence Nightingale Of The Anahim Lake District

Jane Bryant, known as "The Florence Nightingale of the Anahim Lake District," is the Government Field Nurse in charge of the Indians in this district of Northern British Columbia. Jane, a native born daughter of this very district, is a graduate of Kamloops General Hospital. Her uniform is the chaps and spurs and revolver of the cowboy. Mounted on her horse, with her medicine and other needs on a pack horse, this courageous young nurse rides the range tending to the needs of the sick Indians. Her work is dangerous, difficult and full of hardships. On the Indian reserves she has to accept what shelter and food they offer her. On the trail she may be forced to spend the night underneath the shelter of a tree. In the winter she has to face deep snow and very cold weather. Only recently she battled a blinding blizzard for many hours in order to bring a sick man to the hospital. Once her life was threatened when she was pursued by a pack of hungry timber wolves. It was only the threat of her revolver that kept these savage killers from attacking her and her horse. Working up here in the very outposts of civilization, Jane has to do without many of the medical aids and helps that are to be had in great city hospitals. Despite this handicap, this young nurse has shown a great presence of mind and ability to meet any occasion. A few years ago a young man, in jumping from a mowing machine when the horses bolted, had his leg completely cut off by the blade of the machine, just above the ankle. Jane was sent for, while a call was sent out for the doctor some 100 miles away. The doctor on getting the call immediately set out on saddle horse over the mountain to the scene of the accident. In the meantime, Jane, equipped with only a pair of pliers, some old wire, and a few horse hairs, patched up the wounded leg as well as possible. The doctor arrived some twelve hours later. Today the young man, despite the loss of his leg, is alive and well, due to the quick thinking of this brave young nurse. Truly Jane Bryant, for her courage and zeal and devotedness, deserves the title of "The Florence Nightingale of the Anahim Lake District."

J. Hennebery
Catholic Indian Residential School
150 Mile House, B.C.

Dear Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist,

We were very touched at the kind offer made by you on behalf of the Indian girls of your Convent and certainly hope that something can be arranged. In order to help and to obtain materials from us it will be necessary for you to enroll as a Junior Red Cross Branch. Over 50,000 boys and girls attending schools throughout the Province are already enrolled. They have however first obtained the permission to do so from their educational authorities. If the Provincial Department of Education and the Church give permission we will be so glad to have your help.

We have supplies ready to send to our members and as you say in your letter such things are desperately needed for the people of the bombed areas of England.

We certainly hope that we will hear from you soon again and with sincere thanks for a most thoughtful and kindly offer,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

February 14, 1941.

Mr. R. A. Hoey Supt of Welfare & Training,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

By the Junior Red Cross magazine which is forwarded to the Restigouche Indian Day School monthly, the pupils and their teachers admired the work performed by the boys and girls of the Junior Red Cross Society. To satisfy our zeal on behalf of the homeless children of England, the principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School wrote to the Supervisor of the said Society, and inquired if the Indian girls of the Restigouche School would not be allowed to do something for the needy children still exposed in the war section. She explained however that the twenty Indian girls of our Senior Class were penniless but ready to busy their hands in sewing, knitting, or loom-weaving, on behalf of their Society.

Enclosed you will find the answer to my inquiry. By it you will see kind Mr. Hoey, that your approval is necessary before enrolling the said pupils in the Red Cross Society. I humbly ask the honourable Staff to kindly tell me your opinion on the matter, and I am ever ready to sanction your final decision.
This would not prevent us to provide for the needy ones of our Reservation first, as all the heavy winter coats for girls, windbreakers for boys, stockings, bonnets, mittens, have been cleverly confectioned by our girls with the material forwarded.

About 25 yards of heavy material for dresses are still to be made. The members of the Senior Class could consecrate many hours weekly for the welfare work of the homeless children of England.

Leaving this subject to your kind consideration, I remain

Truly yours,

Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist, etc.
Ottawa,

Dear Friend,

"JOURNEY FOR MARGARET."

We would like to recommend that as many as possible of our friends and co-workers throughout Canada see the motion picture "JOURNEY FOR MARGARET." We are recommending this because, besides being one of the highest rated entertainment pictures of the Season, it has a particular message and interest to Red Cross people.

This picture is based on the popular novel by the well-known war correspondent, W.L. White, showing the conditions in Britain arising from the war and particularly the effect on the children.

Our Canadian Junior Red Cross, as you know, is maintaining 14 War Nurseries in Britain at the present time. This picture depicts in a very wonderful and tender way, what these nurseries mean to children tragically deprived of fathers and mothers, often bomb-shocked, requiring deep human understanding of mind and spirit wounds as well as physical needs.

This is no propaganda picture but if it has the same reaction on you as it had on us, you will want to place it among your treasured memories and you will find it of help to you in better realization of the present and post-war problems facing the Red Cross.

H.J. Mackie,
Campaign Chairman, Ottawa Branch,
Canadian Red Cross Society.

Dear Sir:

The St. John Ambulance Association has Branches in various parts of Canada. As you know, the purpose of our organization is to train the citizens of Canada in the art of First Aid and Home Nursing particularly to prepare them to meet any emergency. At a recent meeting of our British Columbia Branch it was suggested that we draw this to your attention.

We are in a position to teach First Aid and Home Nursing in a great number of cases and we feel that we are in a specially good position to pass this information on to the pupils of Indian schools in various parts of the Dominion. Under an arrangement of the St. John-Red Cross Joint Board, we are prepared to teach those under sixteen years of age First Aid and Home Nursing at no cost to them. We would be very pleased to give any assistance possible in carrying out this work, and would be very glad to discuss this with your officers if you so desire.

Yours very truly,

W. J. Bennett,
Director of Ambulance.

CIRCULAR LETTER TO ALL SECRETARIES AND COMMISSIONERS

Dear Sir:

There appears to be some misunderstanding regarding the charges to be made for public classes in First Aid and Home Nursing. The following are the regulations now effective:

JUNIORS

Age Limit

When an examination is held and certificates awarded, the junior age limit will be under sixteen years of age whether attending school or not.

Fees, etc.

Free courses will be given juniors. Each person taking the course will be given, free of charge, a junior textbook in the subject being taken, one triangular or one 2" roller bandage and certificate if the examination is passed. Efforts should be made to conduct the classes and examinations as economically as possible by using volunteer instructors and examiners. No charge shall be made for use of equipment, such as charts and splints. Any expense incurred must be taken care of from War Service funds, this to include instructors' and examiners' fees if any.

SENIORS

Age Limit

(a) Under seventeen years of age.

Where a person is over sixteen years of age, but under seventeen years and has been awarded a junior certificate, the senior course may be taken and senior awards given on successfully passing the required examination. (Junior certificate numbers must be inserted on examination form in all cases.)

(b) Over seventeen years of age.

In all cases, other than the one given in the above paragraph, the minimum age limit for senior awards will be over seventeen years of age.
Fees, etc.

(a) Under seventeen years of age.

Free courses will be given all seniors under seventeen years of age whether attending school or not.

(b) Over seventeen years of age.

Persons over seventeen years of age pay a fee of $1.00 for each course taken.

Each person taking the senior certificate course will be given, free of charge, a senior textbook in the subject being taken, one triangular or one 2" roller bandage and certificate, if the examination is passed.

Books and bandages will not be given free of charge to persons taking voucher, medallion, label or pendant courses but a voucher or award card will be given if the examination is passed.

Efforts should be made to conduct the classes and examinations as economically as possible. Any expense incurred must be taken care of from War Service funds, this to include instructors' and examiners' fees if any. The $1.00 fee is retained to assist in offsetting the expenses of the course.

When medallions, labels and pendants are available they will be supplied on order and at the current price at the time of application.

GENERAL

(a) Requisite Qualifications for Instructors.

(1) A person holding a senior or higher certificate of St. John, obtained within five years prior to the date of commencing teaching First Aid, will be permitted to instruct juniors. Examinations must be conducted by either a certificated instructor or a medical doctor.

(2) A school teacher holding a senior certificate or higher award of St. John will be permitted to teach First Aid (as outlined in regulation 1) and also permitted to instruct pupils attending the senior classes in the school in the senior work. In the latter case pupils taking the senior course in First Aid must be examined by a medical doctor.

(3) Non-commissioned officers of the rank of sergeant or higher and commissioned officers holding a senior or higher certificate of St. John, obtained within five years prior to the date of commencing teaching First Aid will be permitted to instruct enlisted members of the Armed Forces. Examinations must be conducted by a medical doctor.

(4) In all other cases instruction in First Aid must be given by certificated instructors or medical doctors, and the examination conducted by a medical doctor.

(b) Note:

Persons instructing under qualifications outlined in items
1, 2 and 3 above must give full Christian Names and record of awards on examination report of class instructed.

Yours very truly,

W. J. Bennett,
Director of Ambulance and Commandery Commissioner.
June 5th, 1945.
