Ottawa, 7th Dec., 1894.
AT GOVERNMENT HOUSE, OTTAWA.

SATURDAY, 10TH NOVEMBER, 1894.

PRESENT:

HIS EXCELLENCY THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

His Excellency, in virtue of the powers conferred upon him by sections 137 and 138, which are added to the Indian Act by section eleven of chapter 32 of the Acts 57-58 Victoria, and by and with the advice of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada, is pleased to make the following regulations:

1. All Indian children between the ages of seven and sixteen shall attend a day school on the reserve on which they reside for the full term during which the school is open each year, unless excused for the reasons hereinafter mentioned.

2. Any person who receives into his house a child of any other person between the aforesaid ages, and which child is resident with him, or in his care or employment, shall be deemed thereby to be subject to the same duty with respect to the education of such child during such residence,
as a parent, and shall be liable to be proceeded against as in the case of a parent, if he should fail to cause such child to be educated to the extent required of a parent under these regulations; but the duty of the parent under these regulations shall not thereby be affected or diminished, and shall continue in full force.

3. No parent, guardian or other person shall be liable to any of the penalties of these regulations in respect of any child—

(a) If the child is under efficient instruction;

(b) If the child is unable to attend school by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause;

(c) If there is no school within two miles, measured by the nearest road from such child's residence, if such child is under ten years of age, or within three miles, if over this age;

(d) If the child has been excused, as hereinafter provided, from attending school;

(e) If the child has passed the entrance examination for high schools.

4. Where, in the opinion of any Indian Agent, or of any teacher authorized by such agent to issue such certificate as is hereinafter referred to, the services of such child are required in husbandry or in urgent and necessary household duties, or for the necessary maintenance of such child, or of some person dependent upon such child, such Indian Agent or teacher may, by certificate setting forth the reasons therefor, relieve such child from attendance at school for any period not exceeding two weeks, during each of the four school terms or quarters.

5. Indian Agents may appoint one or more persons to act as truant officers on each reserve for the enforcement of these regulations, and such truant officers shall, for the purposes of these regulations, be vested with police powers, and shall perform such services as shall be deemed necessary by the Indian Agents by whom they are appointed for the enforcement of these regulations.

6. It shall be the duty of truant officers appointed under these regulations to examine into all cases of non-attendance at school which may be brought to their notice, to notify the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of any child between seven and sixteen years of age when such child is not attending school, and to require such parent, guardian or other person to cause the child to attend some school within three days.

7. If the parent, guardian or other person having the legal charge or control of any child, shall neglect or refuse to cause such child to attend some school after being notified as herein required (unless such child has been excused from such attendance as provided by these regulations) the truant officer shall make, or cause to be made, a complaint against such parent, guardian or other person, before any Justice of the Peace having jurisdiction in the county or district in which the offence occurred, or before the Indian Agent for the locality; and upon convic-
tion of such refusal or neglect, such parent, guardian or other person, shall be liable to a fine of not more than two dollars, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ten days, or both.

8. For the purposes of section 138, which is added to the Indian Act by section 11 of chapter 32, 57 & 58 Victoria, the following schools are declared to be industrials schools:—Mount Elgin Institute; Muncey; Mohawk Institute, at Brantford; Shingwauk and Wawanosh Homes, at Sault Ste. Marie; Wikwemikong Industrial School, at Wikwemikong—all in the Province of Ontario; Brandon Industrial School, at Brandon; St. Boniface Industrial School, at St. Boniface; Rupert's Land Industrial School, at Middle Church; Washakada Home, at Elkhorn—all in the Province of Manitoba; McDougall Orphanage, at Morley; Battleford Industrial School, at Battleford; St. Joseph's Industrial School, at High River; Regina Industrial School, at Regina; Otterville Industrial School, at Otterville; Red Deer Industrial School, at Red Deer; St. Albert Industrial School, in the Edmonton Agency; Emmanuel Training School, at Prince Albert—all in the North-west Territories; Kuper Island Industrial School, at Kuper Island; Kamloops Industrial School, at Kamloops; Kootenay Industrial School, at Kootenay; Alert Bay Industrial School, at Alert Bay; Metlakatla Industrial School, at Metlakatla; William's Lake Industrial School, at William's Lake; Coqualeetza Home, at Chilliwack—all in the Province of British Columbia. And for the aforesaid purposes the following schools are declared to be boarding schools:—Portage la Prairie Boarding School, at Portage la Prairie; Pine Creek Boarding School, at Pine Creek; Birtle Boarding School, at Birtle—all in the Province of Manitoba; Onion Lake Boarding Schools, in the Onion Lake Agency; Blackfoot Boarding Schools, on the Blackfoot Reserve; Blood Boarding School, in the Blood Agency; Creesland Boarding School, in the Red River Agency; File Hills Boarding School, in the File Hills Agency; Gordon's Boarding School, on George Gordon's Reserve; Touchwood Hills Agency; Muscowequan's Boarding School, on Muscowequan's Reserve, in the Touchwood Hills Agency; Lac la Biche Boarding School, in the Saddle Lake Agency; Piegan Boarding School, on the Piegan Reserve; Round Lake Boarding School, at Round Lake, in the Crooked Lakes Agency; Sarcee Boarding School, on the Sarcee Reserve; Stony Plain Boarding School, on Enoch la Potac's Reserve, in the Edmonton Agency; Duck Lake Boarding School, at Duck Lake—all in the North-west Territories; Port Simpson's Home, at Port Simpson; All Hallows Boarding School, at Yale—both in the Province of British Columbia.

9. An Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace, on being satisfied that any Indian child between six and sixteen years of age is not being properly cared for or educated, and that the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child is unfit or unwilling to provide for the child's education, may issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child and place it in an industrial or boarding school, in which there may be a vacancy for such child, and a child so
placed in an industrial or boarding school may be retained until the age of eighteen years is reached; but no child shall be committed to any industrial or boarding school before the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child, is notified orally, or in writing, by a Justice of the Peace, Indian Agent or truant officer, of the intention to commit the child, and four days shall be allowed to elapse between the giving of such notice and the committal of the child, except in the Province of Manitoba and the North-west Territories, where an Indian child may be committed by an Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace, as aforesaid, without notice.

10. If any such parent, guardian or other person who has been notified as aforesaid objects within the aforesaid four days to the placement of the child in an industrial or boarding school, the Indian Agent, or Justice of the Peace, shall appoint a day for a formal inquiry into the case, and may take evidence under oath as to the manner in which the child is being cared for and educated; and, if it be shown that adequate provision is being made or will be made for the child's care and education, the child shall be left in the custody of such parent, guardian or other person.

11. The share of annuity or interest money, or other hand revenue, belonging to a child committed to an industrial or boarding school, may be retained by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and may be expended by the Superintendent General for the maintenance and education of such child or funded for its benefit.

12. If any child placed under these regulations in an industrial or boarding school should leave such school without permission of the Superintendent General, the Assistant Indian Commissioner, or of the Principal of the School, or should any child who has been allowed off, fail to return at the stipulated time, any Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace shall, on information made to that effect by any officer of such school, issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child back to the school in which it had been previously placed as aforesaid. But notwithstanding anything in this section it shall be competent for any employee of the Indian Department, or any constable, to arrest without a warrant any child found in the act of escaping from any industrial or boarding school, and to convey such child to the school from which it escaped.

13. Any person authorized by warrant under these regulations to search for and take any child to an industrial or boarding school may enter (if need be by force) any house, building or other place specified in the warrant, and may remove the child therefrom. (a) The warrant may be addressed to any policeman or constable, or to any truant officer appointed under these regulations, or to the Principal of any industrial or boarding school, or to any employee of the Department of Indian Affairs.

14. Notwithstanding anything in these regulations contained, no Protestant child shall be placed in a Roman Catholic school, or in a school conducted under Roman Catholic aus.
placed in an industrial or boarding school may be retained until the age of eighteen years is reached; but no child shall be committed to any industrial or boarding school before the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child, is notified orally, or in writing, by a Justice of the Peace, Indian Agent or truant officer of the intention to commit the child, and four days shall be allowed to elapse between the giving of such notice and the committal of the child, except in the Province of Manitoba and the North-west Territories, where an Indian child may be committed by an Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace, as aforesaid, without notice.

10. If any such parent, guardian or other person who has been notified as aforesaid objects within the aforesaid four days to the placing of the child in an industrial or boarding school, the Indian Agent, or Justice of the Peace, shall appoint a day for a formal inquiry into the case, and may take evidence under oath as to the manner in which the child is being cared for and educated; and, if it be shown that adequate provision is being made or will be made for the child's care and education, the child shall be left in the custody of such parent, guardian or other person.

11. The share of annuity or interest money, or other hand revenue, belonging to a child committed to an industrial or boarding school, may be retained by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and may be expended by the Superintendent General for the maintenance and education of such child or funded for its benefit.

12. If any child placed under these regulations in an industrial or boarding school should leave such school without permission of the Superintendent General, the Assistant Indian Commissioner, or of the Principal of the School, or should any child who has been allowed out fail to return at the stipulated time, any Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace shall, on information made to that effect by any officer of such school, issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child back to the school in which it had been previously placed as aforesaid. But notwithstanding anything in this section it shall be competent for any employee of the Indian Department, or any constable to arrest without a warrant any child found in the act of escaping from any industrial or boarding school, and to convey such child to the school from which it escaped.

13. Any person authorized by warrant under these regulations to search for and take any child to an industrial or boarding school may enter (if need be by force) any house, building or other place specified in the warrant, and may remove the child therefrom. (a) The warrant may be addressed to any policeman or constable, or to any truant officer appointed under these regulations, or to the Principal of any industrial or boarding school, or to any employee of the Department of Indian Affairs.

14. Notwithstanding anything in these regulations contained, no Protestant child shall be placed in a Roman Catholic school, or in a school conducted under Roman Catholic aus-
pices; and no Roman Catholic child shall be placed in a Protestant school, or in a school conducted under Protestant auspices.

15. The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs shall have the right, notwithstanding anything in these regulations contained, to return to the custody of its parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control thereof, any child placed in an industrial or boarding school under these regulations.

JOHN J. McGEE,
Clerk, Privy Council.

OTTAWA, 21st January, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Supt. Vowell forwards a copy of a letter from Mr Agent Neill asking for three copies of the Regulations relating to the education of Indian children. The Agent states that he has been interpreting Sections 5, 6 and 7 as referring to day schools and that Indians cannot be compelled by the truant officer to send their children unless there is a day school within two miles from their home. I consider that he is correct in his views as regards these clauses in the Regulations but I am not aware that any instructions have been issued to put these Regulations in force in British Columbia. He also refers to Section 9 of the Regulations, which provides for the committing of a child to an Industrial or Boarding school and says that he takes it that the power conferred by this clause is only to be exercised by the Agent with discretion and is permissive and not obligatory, and cannot be put in force by any missionary who likes to instruct the truant officer under rules 1 and 6. I think he has grasped the intention of the Act under which the Regulations were passed, although Section 9 confers powers on a Justice of the Peace which are too great and are liable to cause serious trouble. If a Principal of a boarding school should get him to act without the authority of
the Department.

The printed supply of the Regulations is about exhausted and before any more are issued it would be well to have them amended. The question of this amendment has been under the Department's consideration for nearly three years.

OTTAWA, 9th May, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Martineau writes under date the 22nd ultimo, asking the Department to enforce the Regulations relating to the education of Indian children. He states that the boarding school on Gordon's reserve is short of six pupils and that the Principal and he have used all their powers of persuasion to induce the parents to send their children, but without avail.

It is a question to my mind whether under Sections 137 and 138, 57-58 Vic. Cap. 32, under which the Regulations were passed, the Department has the power to comply with his request. Section 1 of the Regulations provides that all Indian children between the ages of 7 and 16 shall attend a day school on the reserve on which they reside for the full term during which the school is open each year, unless excused for the reasons thereafter mentioned. There is no day school on this reserve and parents can hardly be said to prevent their children from attending a school which does not exist, and I do not consider that the Act ever contemplated removing the children from their parents, save when they prevent them from attending a day school.

If the education of certain children on this reserve is not being attended to, where a boarding school is established, the only way I see to overcome
the difficulty is to establish a day school in connection with the boarding school and pay a tuition grant for day pupils. Then, if the parents refuse to send their children to a day school, the regulations could be enforced.

"Whereas the Indian Department is expending a large sum annually on the maintenance of day schools on the Indian Reserves;

"And Whereas, the reports show a very small attendance at these schools compared to the money expended;

"And Whereas, the teachers complain that there are many children who might attend, but that they cannot persuade the parents to send them at all regularly; and that they believe the attendance might be much increased."
"If the Indian Agents and Farm Instructors would use their influence and the power they have in this direction.

1. That the Agents and Farm Instructors have much more power and influence over the parents, in this respect, than the teachers, and that they be instructed by the Indian Department, to be sure to use this power.

3. That the giving or withholding of rations, and if possible of a portion of the Treaty money, be connected in some wise way with the attendance of children.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that the Regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children made by Your Excellency in Council on the 10th day of November, 1894, and the amendment thereto of the 1st day of April, 1895, be repealed and the following substituted therefor in virtue of the powers conferred upon Your Excellency by Sections 9, 10 and 11 of the Indian Act Chap. 81 of the Revised Statutes 1906:

1. All Indian children between the ages of six and fifteen shall attend a day school on the reserve on which they reside for the full term during which the school is open each year, unless excused for the reasons hereinafter mentioned.

2. Any person who receives into his house a child between the ages mentioned, and which child is resident with him, or in his care or employment, shall be deemed thereby to be subject to the same duty with respect to the education of such child during such residence as a Parent, and shall be liable to be proceeded against as in the case of a parent, if he should fail to cause such child to be educated to the extent required of a Parent under these regulations;
but the duty of the parent under these regulations shall not thereby be affected or diminished, and shall continue in full force.

3. No parent, guardian or other person shall be liable to any of the penalties of these regulations in respect of any child—

(a) If the child is under efficient instruction;

(b) If the child is unable to attend school by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause;

(c) If there is no school within two miles, measured by the nearest road from such child's residence, if such child is under ten years of age, or within three miles, if over this age;

(d) If the child has been excused, as hereinafter provided, from attending school;

(e) If the child has passed the entrance examination for high schools.

4. Where, in the opinion of any Indian Agent or of any teacher authorized by such agent to issue such certificate as is hereinafter referred to, the services of such child are required in husbandry or in urgent and necessary household duties, or for the necessary maintenance of such child, or of some Indian dependent upon such child, such Indian Agent or teacher may, by certificate setting forth the reasons therefor, relieve such child from attendance at school for any period not exceeding
two weeks during each of the four school terms or quarters.

5. Indian Agents may appoint one or more persons or Indians to act as truant officers on each reserve for the enforcement of these regulations, and such truant officers shall, for the purposes of these regulations, be vested with police powers, and shall perform such services as shall be deemed necessary by the Indian Agents by whom they are appointed for the enforcement of these regulations.

6. It shall be the duty of truant officers appointed under these regulations to examine into all cases of non-attendance at school which may be brought to their notice, to notify the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of any child between six and fifteen years of age when such child is not attending school, and to require such parent, guardian or other person or Indian to cause the child to attend some school within three days.

7. If the parent, guardian or other person having the legal charge or control of any child, shall neglect or refuse to cause such child to attend some school after being notified as herein required (unless such child has been excused from such attendance as provided by these regulations) the truant officer shall make an entry in his book, and cause to be made, a complaint against such parent, guardian or other person or Indian before any Justice of the Peace having jurisdiction in the county or district in which the offence occurred, or before the Indian Agent for the locality; and upon conviction of such
refusal or neglect, such parent, guardian or other person
or Indian shall be liable to a fine of not more than
two dollars, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding
ten days, or both.

8. For the purposes of section 10 of chapter
61 of the act above quoted all industrial and boarding
schools receiving a per capita grant or other grant from
the Government for the education of Indian children are
declared to be industrial and boarding schools for the
purposes of section 9 of the Act.

9. An Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace on
request from the Department of Indian Affairs or one
of its authorized officers on being satisfied that any
Indian child between six and fifteen years of age is not
being properly cared for or educated, and that the parent,
guardian or other person having the charge or
control of such child, is unfit or unwilling to provide
for the child's education, may issue a warrant authorizing
the person named therein to search for and take such
child and place it in an industrial or boarding school,
in which there may be a vacancy for such child, and a
child so placed in an industrial or boarding school may
be retained until the age of eighteen years is reached,
provided that the Superintendent General of Indian Af-
fairs may for special reasons permit a pupil to be re-
tained until the age of twenty years; but no child shall
be committed to any industrial or boarding school before
the parent, guardian or other person having the
charge or control of such child, is notified orally, or in writing, by a Justice of the Peace, Indian Agent or Truant Officer, of the intention to commit the child, and four days shall be allowed to elapse between the giving of such notice and the committal of the child.

10. If any such parent, guardian, or other person or Indian who has been notified as aforesaid, objects within the aforesaid four days to the placing of the child in an industrial or boarding school, the Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace who issued the warrant shall appoint a day for a formal enquiry into the case, and may take evidence under oath as to the manner in which the child is being cared for and educated; and, if it be shown that adequate provision is being made or will be made for the child's care and education, the child shall be left in the custody of such parent, guardian or other person or Indian.

11. The share of annuity or interest money, or other band revenue, belonging to a child committed to an industrial or boarding school, may be retained by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and may be expended by the Superintendent General for the maintenance and education of such child or funded for its benefit.

12. If any child in an industrial or boarding school should leave such school without permission of the Superintendent General or other authorized officer of the Department of Indian Affairs, or of the Principal of the school, or should any child who has been allowed out, fail to return at the stipulated time, any Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace shall, on information made to that effect by any authorized officer of the Department, issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein
to search for and take such child back to the school in which it had been previously placed as aforesaid. But notwithstanding anything in this section it shall be competent for any employee of the school or of the Indian Department or any constable, to arrest without a warrant any child found in the act of escaping from such school and to convey such child to the school from which it escaped.

13. Any person authorized by warrant under these regulations to search for and take any child to an industrial or boarding school may enter (if need be by force) any house, building or other place specified in the warrant, and may remove the child therefrom.

(2) The warrant may be addressed to any policeman or constable, or to any truant officer appointed under these regulations, or to any employee of the Department of Indian Affairs.

14. Notwithstanding anything in these regulations contained, no Protestant child shall be committed to a Roman Catholic school or to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices; and no Roman Catholic child shall be committed to a Protestant school or to a school conducted under Protestant auspices.

15. The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs shall have the right, notwithstanding anything in these regulations contained, to return to the custody of its parents, guardian or other person having the charge or control thereof, any child placed in an industrial or boarding school under these regulations.

Memorandum

for Mr. Oliver

The memorandum to council herewith relating to the education of Indian children has been prepared for the following reasons.

The printed supply of the regulations now in force is exhausted and the regulations need amendment in the following sections:

(1) Where it is stated that all Indian children between the ages of 7 and 16 shall attend a day school is changed to 6 and 15 to agree with the ages fixed in sub-section F of sections 98 and 104 of the Indian Act.

(2) The words "Indian or other" and "an Indian" have been inserted in the first and second lines for the sake of clearness.

(3) This section relates to the appointment of truant officers. In the old regulations there is provision that truant officers should be invested with police powers. This provision is very indefinite and probably ultra vires. For this reason the duties of the truant officer have been clearly defined in the amended regulations.

(4) Age limit changed from 7 to 16 to 6 to 15, the reason given in section 1.

(5) The word "illegal" has been struck out before the words "charge or control" as it would possibly occasion difficulty in administering the regulations.
(8) In this section all boarding and industrial schools in operation in 1894 were mentioned seriatim. As constant changes were taking place in the schools, new ones being established and old ones closed, the section has been changed to read "all industrial and boarding schools receiving a per capita or other grant from the Government for the education of Indian children are declared to be industrial and boarding schools for the purposes of Sections 10 and 11 of the said Act."

(9) After the words "Justice of the Peace" in the first line of this section the following has been inserted "on requisition from the Department of Indian Affairs or from one of its authorized officers" and the age 7 to 16 has been changed to 8 to 15 to correspond with the other sections. The statute fixes the age at which children may be kept in these schools at 16 and this age limit can not legally be extended.

(10) The words "Assistant Indian Commissioner" have been struck out and the words "or other authorized officer of the Department of Indian Affairs" inserted and the words "officer of such school" are changed to read "authorized officer of the Department." After "employee" the words "of the school or" are placed for the purpose intercepting deserters.

(13) The words "or to the principal of any industrial or boarding school" in sub-section 2 have been eliminated as they place too much power in the principal's hands.

(14) The words "placed in" before a Roman Catholic school have been changed to "committed to" as Section 11 of the Act provides for the committal not the placing of Indian children in industrial and boarding schools. The word "in" has been changed to "to" and "committed to" is
again inserted before a Protestant school instead of "placed in".

These amended regulations were sent to the Department of Justice for examination and revision and have been passed on by that Department as being in proper form for submission to His Excellency the Governor General in Council.

THURSDAY, the 6th day of August, 1908.

PRESENT:

HIS EXCELLENCY THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

His Excellency the Governor General in Council in pursuance of the powers conferred upon him by Sections 9, 10 and 11 of the Indian Act, Chapter 81 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1906, is pleased to order that the Regulations relating to the Education of Indian children established by the Order in Council of the 10th November, 1894, and the amendment thereto of the 1st April, 1895, shall be and the same are hereby repealed and the following Regulations substituted therefor:

1. All Indian children between the ages of six and fifteen shall attend a day school on the reserve on which they reside for the full term during which the school is open each year, unless excused for the reasons hereinafter mentioned.

2. Any Indian or other person who receives into his house an Indian child between the aforesaid ages, and whom child is resident with him, or in his care or custody shall be deemed thereafter to be subject to the same duty with respect to the education of such child during such residence as a parent, and shall be liable to be proceeded against as in the case of a parent, if he should fail to cause such child to be educated to the extent required of a parent under these Regulations; but the duty of the parent under these Regu-
lations shall not thereby be affected or diminished and shall continue in full force.

3. No parent, guardian or other person shall be liable to any of the penalties of these Regulations in respect of any child—

(a) If the child is under efficient instruction;

(b) If the child is unable to attend school by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause;

(c) If there is a school within two miles, measured by the nearest road from such child's residence, if such child is under ten years of age, or within three miles, if over this age;

(d) If the child has been excused, as hereinafter provided, from attending school;

(e) If the child has passed the entrance examination for high schools.

4. Where, in the opinion of any Indian Agent or of any teacher authorized by such Agent to issue such certificate as is hereinafter referred to, the services of such child are required in husbandry or in work and necessary to enable him to earn the necessary maintenance of such child, or of some Indian dependent upon such child, such Indian Agent or teacher may, by certificate setting forth the reasons thereof, declare such child to be attending school for any period not exceeding two weeks during each of the four school terms or quarters.

5. Indian Agents may appoint one or more persons to act as Truant Officers on each reserve for the enforcement of these Regulations and such Truant Officers shall perform such services as the Indian Agents by whom they are appointed shall deem necessary for the enforcement of these Regulations.

6. It shall be the duty of Truant Officers appointed under these Regulations to examine into all cases of non-attendance at school which may be brought to their notice, to notify the parent, guardian or other person having the child or control of the child between six and fifteen years of age whose child is not attending school, and to require such parent, guardian or other person to cause the child to attend some school within three days. If such child does not do so, the Truant Officer is to make every effort to see that the children attend school regularly and to arrest and convey to school any child not sick or otherwise lawfully excused from attending school that they may find absent from school during school hours.

7. If the parent, guardian or other person having the care or control of any child shall neglect or refuse to cause such child to attend some school after being notified as herein required (unless such child has been excused from such attendance as provided by these Regulations), the Truant Officer shall make, or cause to be made, a complaint against such parent, guardian or other person before any Justice of the Peace having jurisdiction in the county or district in which the offense occurred, or before the Indian Agent for the locality; and upon conviction such parent, guardian or other person shall be liable to a fine of not more than two dollars or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ten days, or both.

8. Under the provisions of Section 10 of Chapter 81 of the said Act all industrial and
boarding schools receiving a per capita or other grant from the Government for the education of Indian children are declared to be industrial and boarding schools for the purposes of Sections 10 and 11 of the said Act.

9. An Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace on requisition from the Department of Indian Affairs or from one of its authorized officers on being satisfied that any Indian child between six and fifteen years of age is not being properly cared for or educated, and that the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child is unfit or unable to provide for the child's education, may issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child and place it in an industrial or boarding school which there may be a vacancy for such child, and a child so placed in an industrial or boarding school may be retained until the age of eighteen years is reached; but no child shall be committed to any industrial or boarding school without the consent of the parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control of such child is notified orally, or in writing, by a Justice of the Peace, Indian Agent or Trust Officer of the intention to commit the child, and such day shall be allowed to lapse between the giving of such notice and the committal of the child.

10. If any such parent, guardian or other person who has been notified as aforesaid, objects within the aforesaid four days to the placing of the child in an industrial or boarding school, the Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace who issued the warrant shall appoint a day for the formal inquiry into the case, and may take evidence under oath as to the manner in which the child is being cared for and educated; and, if it be shewn that adequate provision is being made or will be made for the child's care and education, the child shall be left in the custody of such parent, guardian or other person.

11. The share of annuity or interest money, or other band revenue belonging to a child committed to an industrial or boarding school, may be retained by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and may be expended by the Superintendent General for the maintenance and education of such child or funded for its benefit.

12. If any child in an industrial or boarding school should leave such school without permission of the Superintendent General or other authorized officer of the Department of Indian Affairs, or of the Principal of the school, or should any child who has been allowed or taken away at the aforesaid times by an Indian Agent or Justice of the Peace shall, on information made to that effect by an authorized officer of the Department, issue a warrant authorizing the person named therein to search for and take such child back to the school in which it had been previously placed as aforesaid.

But notwithstanding anything in this section it shall be competent for any employee of the school, or of the Indian Department, or any constable to arrest without a warrant any child who commits the act of escaping from such school and to convey such child to the school from which it escaped.

13. Any person authorized by warrant under these Regulations to search for and take any child to an industrial or boarding
school may enter (if need be by force) any house, building or other place, specified in the warrant and may remove the child therefrom.

(2) The warrant may be addressed to any policeman or constable, or to any Truant Officer appointed under these Regulations, or to any employee of the Department of Indian Affairs.

14. Notwithstanding anything in these Regulations contained, no Truant child shall be committed to a Roman Catholic school or to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices; and no Roman Catholic child shall be committed to a Protestant school or to a school conducted under Protestant auspices.

15. The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs shall have the right notwithstanding anything in these Regulations contained, to return to the custody of its parent, guardian or other person having the charge or control thereof any child placed in an industrial or boarding school under these Regulations.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS,

Number of teaching days in year.

All Indian Schools shall be kept open for no less than 200 days in each year.

Duration of terms.

Schools shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 1, unless this date should be Labour Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 25.

The winter term will commence on January 3, and end on June 30 in each year.

The following holidays will be allowed during the year:- All Saturdays, Labour Day, all local, municipal, Dominion or Provincial public fast or thanksgiving days, the King's Birthday, Good Friday, Easter Monday, the remainder of the week following Easter Monday and Victoria Day.

In addition to the above, the Roman Catholic schools will be allowed as holidays a limited number of holy days of obligation, not exceeding five (5) in all, which will be accounted as teaching days and for which payment of salary will be allowed.

Where in the interest of the school work such action may be desirable, the holidays allowed during the summer (two months) may, upon the recommendation of the local Agent, be taken at some other time of the year; but no change is to be made without the express approval of the Department.

Length of sessions.

(From March to October, inclusive,) the morning session shall be from 9 a.m. to 12 noon, and the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 5:30 p.m., with a recess during each session of not less than 15 and not more than 20 minutes.

(And from November to February, inclusive, from 9:30 a.m. till 12 noon, and from 1 to 5 p.m., with 15 minutes recess in the morning, only.)

Payment of salaries for broken periods, etc.

In computing salaries for broken periods, teachers will be paid in the proportion that the number of days they taught bears to the total number of teaching days in the year.

Salaries of teachers will be payable quarterly upon receipt of returns; but where a teacher is engaged to take charge of a school, either to commence after the summer holidays, payment for the September quarter will be made as provided for in the case of broken periods in the previous paragraph; and at the end of the year, or when services expire before the end of a year, the necessary adjustment will be made and all the arrears, if any, paid.

Notice of resignation.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

Frank Padley,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

EDUCATION NEED AMONG INDIANS

SARNIA, March 26.—The Indians, to preserve their identity and to promote their welfare, should be educated. This is the statement made by Lieut. Loftus, chief of the Mohawks. During the time Lieut. Loftus was engaged in the recruiting campaign he laid bare facts which have been hidden from view for many years.

The Indians inhabiting the Sarnia Reserve and the surrounding district are the Wyandotte, the Potawatomies, all that remains of the ancient Iroquois, and the Mississaugas. They are very attached to their ancient habits, and, although they have been told many times that they must show more interest in education, they have not listened to the appeals, the old methods have been tried out without putting forth an effort to get it still.

It has been brought to the attention of the Indians by the government, that they are keeping their offspring in ignorance. Lieut. Loftus visited the Indians, and although he was met with hostility, he went on with his work. He explained to them that if they are to keep up with the times, they must send their children to school. A letter from the Government agent states that if the Indians do not send their children to school, the Government will hold back the money due them. This, however, is a drastic measure. The average annual income of the Indian is between $150 and $200. In very hard times it may fall as low as $50 to $75. This means there is no other source of income except the land, and it is very often the case, his year's rent is paid before the end of the year. If the family has a large number of members, the amount paid to every member of the family is less than it should be.

When the first announcement of this new system was made, the Indians were hostile and sullen, but after it had been explained to them, they became more understanding. The government also made laws to bring past to him, and that he is required to pay taxes, and that he is required to pay school fees. The Indians have now more reasonable view of the question. Lieut. Loftus has been very generous in his efforts to help the Indians. He has been thanked for what he had done, and the Indians have said that betterment of this system would be greatly appreciated. The question has been more fully solved in the council house.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant with reference to an overture from the Synod of British Columbia requesting that the regulations relating to the attendance of Indian children be enforced where day schools are established.

In reply I beg to say that the question of the attendance of Indian children at the day schools has received the earnest attention of the Department. In a number of instances in British Columbia truant officers have been appointed to see that the children attend the day schools regularly. The main difficulty is to overcome the indifference of the parents regarding the education of their children. Our Agents have been instructed on each occasion on which they visit & receive to impress on the parents the benefits their children will acquire by regular attendance and to endeavour by every persuasion in their power, to induce the parents to see that their children attend the day schools on the reserves regularly.

Your obedient servant,

Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sir -

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of copy of resolution No. 46, passed by the General Board of Missions of the Methodist Church at its meeting on October 6th, having reference to the question of compulsory education among the Indians of Canada.

I wish first to refer to the figures quoted in the resolution with respect to enrolment and attendance. Leaving out of consideration the most remote portions of the Provinces of Quebec, Manitoba, Alberta, Saskatchewan and British Columbia, as well as the North West Territories, inhabited only by the Indians who follow the hunt exclusively for a livelihood, our last statistics (1915) show a population of school age, 6 to 15 years of age, of approximately 16,547; of these 11,804 pupils are enrolled either at day or residential schools, and the average attendance for the past fiscal year was 7,474. This constitutes 65.32% of the enrolment, which is a better showing than the average attendance in the rural schools of the Province of Ontario as shown by their returns for the year 1916. Of course, I am aware that the steady attendance at the residential schools is a factor in effecting this very favourable comparison. We have provision for the enforced attendance of Indian children at our day schools and an honest effort is made by the Department, through its officials, to make these regulations effective. There are reserves, however, where, owing to the scattered location of the

Rev. G. W. Barker,
Secretary of the General Board of Missions of the Methodist Church,
Toronto, Ont.
Indians, it is almost impossible to enforce anything like regular attendance at schools, especially during the winter months. Where, however, conditions are at all favourable, the Department is anxious and willing to make a special endeavour to produce better results.

So far as the residential schools are concerned, the statutes give us no power to enforce the compulsory enrolment of Indian children; even if the system were considered to be in the best interests of the Indian children, it is doubtful whether Parliament would grant to the Department the absolute power of taking children from their parents without their consent. As you are aware, the Department now has the power to place in industrial or boarding schools children living in an unwholesome environment, or those whose parents neglect to send them to school when such facilities are in existence.

I also think this an opportune time to make reference to the teacher himself as a factor of the greatest importance in attaining the end your committee has in view. So far as day schools are concerned, I have observed that the best attendance and ultimate results are secured only by those teachers who are competent to arouse and retain the interests of parents and pupils. I realize the difficulty of obtaining the service of persons of the required temperament and adaptability to take charge of schools in districts so isolated as our reserves in many cases unfortunately are. It will be admitted, however, that the efforts of officials of this Department would be of little avail unless the teachers are able to hold the interest of the children. Any system which depends solely upon the enforcement of stringent legislation for results must of necessity eventually fail.
I have in mind individual schools in the Province of Ontario which are second to no white schools in their respective districts, and in each instance I attribute the success of these schools primarily to the personality of the teachers. This type of teacher is unfortunately very rare.

At the same time I appreciate the necessity of the co-operation of our Indian Agents and other officials, and will be pleased to do what I can to increase their interest in the education of the children under their immediate care.

With this end in view I shall be pleased if you will furnish me with the information apparently placed before your committee with reference to Agencies in which our officials are not making such effort as they should to enforce the attendance of Indian pupils. I am seeking for this information with a view to taking the matter up with these delinquents.

I may add that this information will be treated as confidential.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) D.A. Scott

Ottawa, December 16, 1918.

Sir,

It has been brought to the attention of the Department that there is great room for improvement with regard to school attendance of Indian children. It would appear that in many cases Indian parents neglect to send their children to school, and that in some cases they even wilfully detain them at home. Such conduct constitutes an offence under the regulations relating to the education of Indian children, and I would refer you to section 7 of these regulations, which reads as follows:

"7. If the parent, guardian or other person having charge or control of any child shall neglect or refuse to cause such child to attend some school after being notified as herein required (unless such child has been excused from such attendance as provided by these regulations) the school officer shall make, or cause to be made, a complaint against such parent, guardian or other person before any Justice of the Peace having jurisdiction in the county or district in which the offence occurred, or before the Indian Agent for the locality; and upon conviction, such parent, guardian or other person shall be liable to a fine of not more than two dollars or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ten days, or both."

The Department takes a very serious view of the failure on the part of the Indians to comply with the regulations in these respects, and it has accordingly been decided that henceforward Indians whose conduct is remiss in this matter shall not be regarded as being eligible for relief or other assistance from the Department.

I would ask you, therefore, to kindly bring the attitude of the Department in connection with the subject to the attention of the Indians of your agency and to endeavour to make them fully understand the inevitable consequence of failure on their part to comply with the ruling of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:-

Hon. Mr. Meighen:-

Memorandum of conversation between the Hon. the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Rt. Rev. Bishop McNally and the undersigned on Wednesday morning, December 10th.

The possibility for carrying out the scheme for Indian education in southern Alberta for the Blood and Peigan Indians outlined below is contingent upon Parliament making the education of Indians at residential schools compulsory. If the statutory authority be not given it would not be possible to successfully conduct the system of schools outlined below.

At present the educational establishment for these Indians consists of the following schools:

Roman Catholic Church of England.

Boarding school, Blood Reserve. Boarding school, Blood Reserve. This property belongs to the Church.

Boarding school, Peigan Reserve. Boarding school, Peigan Reserve. Buildings belong to the Church.

Industrial school, High River.

It is proposed to close the High River school and to dispose of the property; to erect a new industrial school for the Roman Catholic Indians in a locality where agriculture and stock-raising can be properly carried on. When this building is provided it is proposed to close the Peigan boarding school. The boarding school on the Blood reserve shall be maintained for the present as the building, with small expenditure, can be kept in a good state of repair. It is desired as soon as possible to erect for the Church of England children an industrial school where agriculture and stock-raising can be taught, and to then close the two boarding schools.
The reasons underlying these recommendations are as follows. The Department considers it good policy to endeavour to arrange amalgamation between the Blood and Peigan Indians to sell the reserve of the latter band and remove them to the Blood reserve. A school cannot be successfully operated on the Peigan reserve owing to the nature of the soil, the same applies to the Blood reserve. As the number of schools will be diminished advantage will accrue to the Church, as at present they find it difficult to provide a competent staff, and large schools can be run more economically than small ones.

As for compulsory education we find it is difficult to recruit for the schools under the present voluntary system. There is no lack of children of school age, but the apathy or hostility of the Indians defeat the object of the Department. The compulsory system needs some defense, but as the sanitary standard of our school buildings improves, and the health of the children is carefully safeguarded, the strong arguments which might arise from that source disappear. It is proposed by legislation to provide for adequate holidays throughout the year, in order that the parents may not be entirely separated from their children.

Duncan. C. Scott.

Section 9 of the Indian Act, Chapter 61 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1906, Section 10 of the said Act as enacted by Section 1, Chap. 35, 4-5 George V, 1914, and Section II of the said Act and any regulations made in pursuance of the said sections, are hereby repealed and the following sections substituted therefor:

"(2). The Governor in Council may establish day schools on an Indian reserve for the children of such reserve or in lieu of day schools may establish industrial schools or boarding schools for the attendance, maintenance and education of the children of such reserve, reserves, or parts of reserves as may be designated by the Superintendent General.

(3). All pupils shall be provided by the Superintendent General with transportation to and from the industrial or boarding schools to which they have been assigned including transportation from such schools to their respective homes for the regular summer vacation and their return to such schools after such vacation.

(4). All schools shall comply with the standards established by the Department in respect of buildings, equipment, teaching and discipline and shall be regularly inspected by qualified officers, and shall be open to inspection by the Chief and Council of a band at such reasonable times as may be agreed upon by the Agent and Principal of the school.

(5). The Superintendent General may apply the annuities and interest moneys of children attending an industrial or boarding school to the maintenance of such schools or to the maintenance of the children themselves.

10. Every Indian child over the age of seven and under the age of fifteen who is physically able shall attend such day school on a reserve or such industrial school or boarding school as may be designated by the Superintendent General, for the full term during which such day school, industrial school or boarding school is open each year.

(2). No Protestant child shall attend a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices; and
no Roman Catholic child shall attend a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices.

11. The Superintendent General may appoint a truant officer for the enforcement of attendance of children at school and such officer shall, for the purpose of such enforcement, have the powers of a peace officer and shall examine into all cases of truancy within his knowledge or when requested to do so by the Indian Agent, a teacher or a chief of the band, and shall warn the truants and their parents or guardians of the consequences of truancy; and shall notify the parent or guardian in writing to cause the child to attend school forthwith.

Any parent or person with whom any Indian child is resident on a reserve who fails to cause his or her child, as such child between the ages aforesaid, to attend school as required by this section after having received three days' notice so to do by a truant officer, shall, on the complaint of the truant officer, be liable on summary conviction before a justice of the peace or Indian Agent to a fine of not more than two dollars and costs or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ten days or both, and such child may be arrested without warrant and conveyed to school by the truant officer; provided that no parent or other person shall be liable to such penalties if such child is unable to attend school by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause, has passed the entrance examination for high schools or has been excused by the Indian Agent or Teacher for temporary absence to assist in husbandry or urgent and necessary household duties."
The amendment provides for the repeal of Sections 9, 10 and 11 of the Act, and of the Regulations made in pursuance of the Sections. I have extracted the clauses which we propose to repeal, and send a copy of the Regulations which were passed by His Excellency in Council on the 6th day of August, 1908. These clauses empower the Governor in Council to make regulations to secure the compulsory education of children at day schools, and their commitment to residential schools in certain circumstances.

A short time ago I attempted to re-draft the Regulations for the purpose of carrying out the purpose of the new amendment, namely, a true system of compulsory education for every Indian child at both classes of schools, day and residential, but it was found that, under the Act, the Governor in Council would not have the power to pass them. I would, therefore, propose to cancel the clauses of the Act and of the Regulations, and to obtain legislative authority for a true system of compulsory education, affecting every Indian child, and both classes of schools.

You may not think it necessary or advisable to cancel the Regulations by statute, as they may quite as effectively be cancelled by Order in Council. The Justice Department say that the proposed course is unusual, but not improper. I am inclined to favour the omission of any reference to the Regulations in the Bill, and to cancel them by Order in Council when the statute becomes operative.
It is self-evident that there is little use in having schools without pupils, and, except in so far as the Regulations provide otherwise, it rests, at present, with the Indians whether their children shall be sent to school or not. Indian educators and the officials of the Department have been under the necessity of securing attendance by various methods, by moral suasion, by veiled compulsion, which has no force back of it, even by special inducements, which were in the nature of payments or favours shown to the parents.

Each Indian child who is new in residence at a boarding or industrial school is placed there with the consent of the parents, given in writing, and, after having once obtained a child, it has been a constant struggle to retain it for the required term, as the parents are largely governed by whim, and attempt, for all sorts of specious reasons, to withdraw their children, and interrupt the course of their education. There is a continuous effort to keep our schools full, but they are not now filled, and there is at present no way of overcoming the indifference of the parents.

While the proposed legislation is drastic, it gives the Department control, removes from the Indian parent the responsibility for the care and education of his child, and the best interests of the Indians are promoted and fully protected. The clauses apply to every Indian child over the age of 7 and under the age of 15.

If a day school is in effective operation, as is the case on many of the reserves in the Eastern provinces, there will be no interruption of such parental sway as exists. Where a day school cannot be properly operated, the child must be taken to an industrial or boarding school. All such schools are open to inspection.
and must be conducted according to a standard already in existence; they must be conducted under contract. A regular summer vacation is provided for, and the transportation expenses of the children are paid by the Department, which latter clause will, I think, go far to remove the present objection to education at residential schools. It has always been advanced as a hardship that parents and children are separated for years without the possibility of any reunion, and that the child grows away from the life of the reserve, and the observation and affection of the parent, and that, when he is discharged from the school, he is an alien in his own home.

There are objections to an annual summer vacation from our point of view, but, with the power given us by the proposed amendment to control the movements of pupils, it will be relatively easy to provide for their return, and I think the proposal will do much to popularize education at residential schools.

Consideration is shown by the proposed changes, and, I think, rightly so, to the various religious denominations, who have, since the earliest days, devoted themselves to the cause of Indian education. All our residential schools are conducted by these denominations, and the evangelization and education of the Indian are carried on side by side.

A fair proportion of the expenditure on the maintenance of these schools is provided by the Churches, and, in the past, the greater share of the responsibility for recruiting pupils has fallen upon their shoulders; it is found to be enormous. Their zealous co-operation with the Department, and the generosity which is shown in the provision of funds, entitle them to the support and assistance which a compulsory system of education will provide.
As our Indian boarding schools in the province of Ontario are well filled, and, for the most part, have waiting lists, we shall not require to invoke the clauses frequently in these parts. In the three Western provinces, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, day schools are a failure, and it is proposed to close them, and to substitute education at residential schools. This will involve the establishment of some new institutions, but it is proposed to use the Trust Funds of the Indians, as far as possible, for Capital expenditure, as we are enabled to do under the present statute without the consent of the Indians. These remarks apply to British Columbia. The Indians of this province are not in possession of large Trust Funds, and cannot, therefore, contribute, but the obligation to provide buildings is not heavy, and can be gradually assumed and discharged.

As an answer to an argument which might be raised against the invasion of the rights of the parents over the children, it should be pointed out that All Indians are wards of the Crown, and the western treaties all provide for education as part of the compensation for the cession of the Indian title. As this proviso was inserted at the request of the Indians, and altogether in their interests, it follows that they have certain responsibilities, and must produce their children to be educated.
Before the war broke out we had a most progressive policy with reference to the re-building of schools which had become dilapidated and the building of new schools throughout the country. Unfortunately we were stopped in that because we could not get the money. We are limited in every way and are confined within the limit set by Parliament to the appropriation for Indian Affairs. If we have a little more interest in the House of Commons, I am not criticizing it at all, because it has a lot of work to do, but if we could have a standing committee or some committee so that we would have a body of men in the House who would become better acquainted with Indian affairs it would be of advantage.

MR LABOINTRE: Are you in favour of a special committee?

MR SCOTT: I am very much in favour of it. I said to the Minister yesterday, "Had you done nothing except to get the committee you have appointed you have done a great deal".

THE ACTING CHAIRMAN: Mr. Lepoint suggests a standing committee. I understand, would you favour that?

MR SCOTT: Yes, I would. Of course it would have to be very carefully guarded in regard to the summoning of witness and everything of that kind, because every standing committee has standing regulations for its guidance. This is by way of preamble and I hope you will not consider it out of place. As I said I have had to contend in my official life with difficulties, because a civil servant never gets away from obstacles. Our obstacle in regard to Indian education is the lack of a compulsory system, the same as the white people have under the present Act the Governor in Council is
empowered to pass regulations, and he has passed regulations and we are now conducting our Indian Schools under a regulation passed in 1908, and under the Act these regulations permit us to commit to an industrial school the child who will not or who is not attending the day school on the reserve. That is as far as it permits us to go. Not having any other powers to commit except the child who is not attending the school on the reserve the object of this Bill is to give us power not only to compel children to attend day school on the reserve, but we can take the child, place it in the industrial school without the parents consent. That, of course seems going very far, but I may say that the Bill hardly applies to Eastern Canada at all in any of its provisions, although it extends to all parts of Canada, to Eastern Canada, as well as in the West. But our residential schools in the East are practically full, we have waiting lists, none of them can accommodate any more pupils, and the compulsory clause almost entirely affects the Western part of the Dominion, although it may affect certain cases in the East when at least we have an Indian abusing or neglecting his child.

In the West we have a great deal of difficulty in getting children to school. I may say that our school system is somewhat peculiar in that the churches cooperate with us in the work of education, and I have always been in favour of that because of the success which has attended the work and which is due in a great measure to the cooperation of the churches. In 1910, when Mr. Oliver was Minister, he took a very enlightened view of education and he called all heads of different denominations the Anglicans, the Roman Catholic, the Methodist and the Presbyterians, to Ottawa, and they had a conference and there has been a decided improvement as a result. The churches are conducting boarding schools, under a
Contract system, the Government consenting to an increase in the per capita grant which I may say is not now sufficient; the cost of living has so increased, but the churches loyally made up the deficiency out of their own pockets. That is the church is a partner to a very great extent, and I should say that about one third of the funds for required for Indian education are provided by the churches. At that time Mr. Oliver agreed to spend a certain amount every year in the erection of new buildings, as well as increasing the per capita grant, and this policy was continued by the Borden Government and Parliament was very generous in its appropriations until the war broke out. The difficulty in the West is with the almost savage people we have there, to get them to realize the benefit of education and to send their children voluntarily. Now the educators who are conducting these schools have resorted to all sorts of means to get these children to attend. I will not say that they have resorted to bribery, that is not the proper term to use, but they have really paid to have the children brought to school, and the difficulty is to keep them there/they get there, because just as soon as the child enters the school the parents want to take it out for some reason or other, either because of supposed sickness or somebody has died, and they want to get the children out of school. The Bill is to give us control of that and we have endeavoured to take the sting out of the separation of the child from its parents and the breaking up of the home life; the Indians' parents are very fond of their children. There has always been every effort made and opportunity taken to study their character - I am speaking of the Tribes in the West now, not of those in the East, because they deal with their children the same as we do. I have
endeavoured to mitigate the separation as much as possible by providing that there shall be a holiday every year, and that the Department shall pay the expenses of sending their children home and bringing them back so that the Indian parents will be assured of seeing their children running around the Tepee for a month or six weeks every summer at least. I am very doubtful whether that is a benefit to the children because if we take the children from the vermin ridden shack with lice, bed-bugs and vermin of all kinds, and bring them to the schools, clean them and clothe them, and give them the benefit of nourishing food and then sent them back to the place whence they came - that does not apply or course to all cases - it does not tend to improve them in regard to the education of the children. To point to the benefit of the policy of the Department I may say that not more than 25 years ago we were practically feeding the Indians of the West, after the disappearance of the buffalo. Canada took up the obligation of feeding these people and keeping them alive. To-day we see hardly one-tenth of the gratuitous feeding in the Northwest Territories, the Indians are practically self-supporting on account of our policy. I have brought pictures here of schools. When I took charge of the schools I made up my mind that they would be considered only from the point of view of the public interest and not from the standpoint that anything was good enough for the Indians. That was the trouble in the old days, the Department put up cheap places which very soon became dilapidated and filled with tuberculosis germs so that they were unfit for the purposes for which they were erected. The institutions we have erected in recent years have been such that any member of the community can go into them and be proud of them, and the plans we have drawn and the schools we have
put up since that time for the Indian children are such as we have put up in Portage La Prairie. I have brought these pictures for your inspection in order to let you understand that we are not taking these people and putting them into institutions that we cannot be proud of.

(Pictures distributed and examined by the Committee)

These schools are conducted under control of the Government, the Government have a contract, a copy of which I have here, and I will leave it for the information of the Committee. The contract is with the Bishop of the Diocese or with the Head of the Presbyterian or Methodist churches conducting the schools and they are expected to keep the schools up to a certain standard, the schools are under inspection of our own officers, by our agents and inspectors, and in some cases also, particularly day schools, they are inspected by the provincial inspectors. I do not think that I can say very much more about the educational clauses. The purpose of the Bill is to give us control over the attendance at the day schools.

THE ACTING CHAIRMAN: Under the present regulations you have simply control of the schools on the reserve?

MR. SCOTT: Yes.

THE ACTING CHAIRMAN: Now you extend it to the other schools?

MR. SCOTT: Yes, where the Indian pupil fails to attend we can issue a warrant and take him to the Industrial school. In the West we have found that the reserve day schools are an absolute failure, we have tried to stimulate attendance in every way, by a warm mid-day meal, sometimes by conveying the children to the school, the distance over which the Indians are
scattered in the West renders it almost impossible to get any effectual education at the Indian day schools.

All the Indian educators, I may say, are in favour of this Bill; If I had wished to issue a circular and asked them for their opinions in order to bombard the Committee I could have got replies from all of them, but I did not do that. Dear Sir:

I have been absent on a visit to the Pacific Coast, or I should have written to you at an earlier date on a matter which I consider of vital importance to the future of the Indian wards of the Dominion Government.

I have followed with the greatest interest the proposed amendments to the Indian Act now before Parliament, and have noticed with great regret various reports in the daily press which seem to indicate the development of considerable opposition to the same.

This opposition I believe to be largely "manufactured" and to be of a nature which, if allowed to prevail, will hamper or frustrate the most far-reaching and promising scheme of reform for the benefit of the Indians which has ever been presented for the consideration of Parliament.
I refer, especially, to the proposal to make compulsory the education of Indian children, and to secure the same through the agencies of boarding schools.

As you are aware I have been carrying on, personally, for some years a series of wide investigations into the whole subject. In these investigations I have gone as far North as Fort MacPherson, Peel River, Mackenzie River Delta.

I began those investigations as a doubter in, if not an opponent of, the boarding school system. The facts I have encountered have converted me into an earnest adherent of that system, as the only system which holds within it the possibility of a solution, within reasonable limits of time, of the whole problem of Indian education and, therefore, of the solution of the ultimate problem of Indian enfranchisement and citizenship.

I may mention one fact as indicative of the type of evidence which has weighed with me in producing in my mind the change from the position of a "doubter" to that of a convinced supporter of the boarding school system: everywhere I went I found a consensus of opinion to the effect that the children of ex-pupils, taken as a whole, were of a distinctly higher type in mental and moral receptivity and capacities, than were the children of Indian parents who had not received the benefits of such education.

The boarding school system, I repeat, presents in my judgement the only satisfactory solution of the problem.
Coupled with compulsory education that system should be, and can be I believe, made the efficient instrument for the bringing about of the great end which every well-wisher of the Indian wards of the nation must have at heart, i.e., the progressive raising of the whole Indian people from the depressed position of wards, to the higher position of self-respecting, self-supporting, intelligent, well-educated citizens of the Dominion.

Please pardon this free expression of my convictions on the subject,

And believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

General Secretary.

P.S. I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Mr. B. Nicholson, M.P., a member of our Indian Committee.

Reasons which led the Department to recommend Amendments to the Statutes with reference to Indian Education, and objects to be attained by the Amendments.

The present educational clauses of the Indian Act provide that the Governor General in Council may pass regulations for compulsory attendance at schools, and regulations were passed by the Governor General in Council in 1908 which now govern. The powers conferred by the Act have been held by the law officers to deal simply with day schools, and it is held that there is no power to provide for the compulsory attendance of Indians at boarding or industrial schools. The regulations provide for the commitment of an Indian child to an industrial or boarding school when the child is not attending the local day school.

The provisions of the amendment give the Superintendent General power to compel the attendance of Indian children at day schools and at residential schools, and their residence at the latter for definite periods. The provisions for compulsory attendance at day schools will be operative generally throughout the Dominion wherever day schools are conducted. The provisions with reference to compulsory attendance at residential schools will be almost wholly confined to the provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia. The clauses may occasionally be invoked in Ontario and the eastern provinces for the protection of neglected children or children who require restraint.

The experience of the Department and those interested in Indian education, extending over a period of thirty years, has convinced them that in the prairie provinces and British Columbia day schools have failed to be a successful factor in educating and civilising the Indians. The causes contributory to this failure are the difficulties of securing a constant attendance of the pupils. The reserves in the west
are usually large, and the Indian habitations are scattered far and wide within the boundaries of the reserves. The Indians are not collected into village communities. The children, therefore, have to come fairly long distances to school. In many of the localities, the Indians are still hunting Indians, and when they leave for the hunting grounds in the late summer, they have of necessity to take with them their families. The Department endeavoured for a time to overcome these difficulties by providing conveyance to and from the school, and attempted also to increase the attendance by providing a warm mid-day meal for the pupils. The result of these efforts was merely to increase the cost of the schools without materially increasing their efficiency.

The attached statement will give some idea of the unsatisfactory nature of the service at Indian day schools.

The difficulties of maintaining a constant number of pupils in residence in boarding and industrial schools has been equally great. The difficulty has arisen from different causes, but has been in our experience equal to the obstacles described in dealing with the day school attendance. Owing to the apathy of Indians who have not progressed very far from the aboriginal state, it has been difficult to get their support for this class of school, and the Principals of the schools and the Indian Agents, without any compulsory power, find it difficult to maintain constant attendance. Uniform and constant attendance is the very life-blood of the school, because the financial aid conferred by the Government depends on the number of pupils in residence. We are subject to the expense of the Indian parents.

It has been proved conclusively after thirty years' experience that the only real progress is made by the Indians who have been educated in residential schools, where they have the benefit of agricultural training and training in domestic
employments.

It is, therefore, proposed to consider the class of residential schools as the best system for the prairie provinces and British Columbia, and to develop that system as far as possible consistent with the funds from time to time placed at the disposal of the Department by Parliament. It is proposed also to use the available funds of the Indians for their own education. It is proposed to close day schools whose usefulness is nil, and to gradually establish a residential school system which will accommodate the healthy children of school age throughout these provinces.
