INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

FOR THE GUIDANCE OF INSPECTORS, INDIAN AGENTS, AND TEACHERS

Number of teaching days in year.

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 200 days in each year.

Duration of terms.

Schools shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 1, unless this date should be Labour Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 22.

The winter term will commence on January 3, and end on June 30 in each year.

Number of holidays.

The following holidays will be allowed during the year:—All Saturdays, Labour Day, all local, municipal, Dominion or Provincial, public fast or thanksgiving days, the King's Birthday, Good Friday, Easter Monday, the remainder of the week following Easter Monday and Victoria Day.

In addition to the above, the Roman Catholic schools will be allowed as holidays a limited number of holy days of obligation, not exceeding five in all, which will be accounted as teaching days and for which payment of salary will be allowed.

Where in the interest of the school work such action may be desirable, the holidays allowed during the summer (two months) may, upon the recommendation of the local Agent, be taken at some other time of the year; but no change is to be made without the express approval of the Department.

Length of sessions.

The morning session shall be from 9 a.m. to 12 noon, and the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., with a recess during each session of not less than 15 and not more than 20 minutes.

Payment of salaries for broken periods, etc.

In computing salaries for broken periods, teachers will be paid in the proportion that the number of days they taught bears to the total number of teaching days in the year.

Salaries of teachers will be payable quarterly upon receipt of returns; but where a teacher is engaged to take charge of a school, duties to commence after the summer holidays, payment for the September quarter will be made as provided for in the case of broken periods in the previous paragraph; and at the end of the year, or when services expire if before the end of a year, the necessary adjustment will be made and all arrears, if any, paid.

Notice of resignation.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

DUNCAN C. SCOTT,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. SCOTT,

With reference to the proposed changes in the educational sections of the Indian Act, I wish to recommend that

1. Section 10 (1) be amended to include children in their 15th year, i.e., compulsion from the 7th to the 16th birthday.

2. Section 98 (1) (F) be amended to conform.

3. Section 104 (2) (F) be amended to conform.

4. A subsection (4) be added to Section 10, so that the provisions of the section may apply to the 15th birthday in the case of any particular Indian child who, in the opinion of the Superintendent General, would be granted a decided disservice if discharged from industrial or boarding school at an earlier age.

In explanation of my 4th recommendation, I wish to state that, in a few cases, the Department has found it advisable to bend every energy towards keeping in a residential school a pupil who should not be placed in the custody of the parent or parents at the ages of 14 or 15. I might mention two instances as examples. The Department refused to discharge Kathleen Clancey from the Chapleau School, even after repeated requests from the father. The mother was dead and the father was a Six Nation Indian, who eked out an existence, begging, etc., in the streets of Hamilton. In another case, the Department refused to send Aggie and Christie Olson, two attractive and accomplished 14-year-old pupils at Brandon, to the mother, a Brokenhead woman, who wanted her daughters to join her in a life of prostitution. In these cases, the Department and the churches managing the schools had a moral obligation to thwart the efforts of an irresponsible parent. The proposed section would give power to keep such children in school until they had reached their 15th birthday. At this age, they would be better able to choose wisely for themselves.

5. The words "to the maintenance of such school or" be deleted from Section 9 (6).

Dear Sirs:

There is a small matter which often comes up in the North country, a matter on which I would like an authoritative decision. It has not until now concerned me particularly, but now that I am interested I cannot get a clear definition of the law.

In Pelican Narrows, for example, the Catholic Indians are told it is compulsory they send their children to the Indian Boarding School at Sturgeon Landing, about a hundred miles distant. The Indians would send their children by command of their priests, for reasons of religious obedience, but they are also told that it is a matter of law, and that they have no choice in the matter in any event. We all know that school attendance is compulsory, but also know that a white person in an isolated district cannot (or at least is not) be forced to send his children a hundred miles away from home to attend school. We also know that there are certain laws respecting Indians which differ from laws governing other individuals.

But on the other hand, the protestant preachers tell the protestant Indians at Pelican Narrows that sending their children to Lac La Ronge, Indian Boarding School for Protestants, also a hundred miles removed, is not compulsory, either by law nor by religious compulsion. As a result, only three or four, to my knowledge, attend, the balance of the children being without any schooling. (And better off)

I should be very pleased to get this matter straight: IS IT COMPULSORY INDIANS SEND THEIR CHILDREN TO SCHOOLS A HUNDRED MILES REMOVED FROM THEIR HOMES AND SOMETIMES THREE HUNDRED MILES, and if not, can the parents, once informed of this, call at these schools at will and bring their children home?

I want you to understand that I am determined to find out about this; that in appealing to you direct I am saving expense and trouble in making a test case, and that is the reason I do not want to commit myself until I am sure of my ground. Common sense would argue that a couple, whether Indian or what as long as they are classified as human, could hardly be expected to surrender their children between ages of eight and eighteen except in clear cases where neglect, non-support, or any other delinquency on their part was properly proved. But laws are not always dictated by common sense.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, with reference to changes in the compulsory education clauses of the Indian Act. Subsection 1 of Section 10 was repealed in April last, and the following substituted therefor:

"Every Indian child between the full ages of seven and sixteen years who is physically able shall attend such day, industrial or boarding school as may be designated by the Superintendent General for the full periods during which such school is open each year; provided that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to have it discharged from school on attaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General may direct that such child be retained at school for such further period as may seem to be advisable, but not beyond the full age of eighteen years, and in such case the provisions of this section with respect to truancy shall apply to such child and its parents, guardians or persons with whom such child resides during such further period of school attendance".

You will note that the Statute is now quite clear that Indian children may be compelled to attend until their 16th birthday. In certain instances, the Department can also compel attendance to the 18th birthday. It is not intended that compulsion to the 18th birthday be applied to all Indian children or even to a large number. This clause was added to the section so that the Department could postpone discharge for an added two years, when home conditions strongly suggested such action.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

EXTRACT from Separate School Inspector Greening's Report regarding his visit to the LAKE HELEN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on November 10, 1931.

Original on File 9-4-6.

After having thought over the situation carefully and discussed it with other inspectors visiting Indian schools, it is my considered opinion that there can be little hope of Indian day schools ever being anything like as efficient and useful as the expenditure and care lavished upon them by the Department would seem to merit, unless there is a complete change in policy in regard to the enforcing of attendance.

It was something of a shock to me to be told by a missionary (one who had done much for Indian schools) that, in his experience, Indian children or young people getting into trouble were almost invariably the product of the Indian school. Since then I have spoken to many different kinds of people, trappers, teachers of experience, railway men, store-keepers and missionaries (both priests and nuns) and find it a generally prevalent opinion that there is a growing disregard for law on the part of the Indian, very much like the contempt for law said to have arisen in the United States from non-enforcing of the liquor laws, and that this disregard for the law has much the same kind of foundation, viz., the ability of the Indian to "get away" with things.

One of these things, undoubtedly, is the keeping of children from school. The Indian parent knows that he is expected to send his child to school, but he keeps him at home or takes him away fishing -------- and nothing happens. The child knows that he should be at school, but he stays away, with the same result. One Indian Agent told me that a parent had told him that his boy did not want to go to school and that he was not going to send him, and that the agent could do just whatever he felt good and pleased to do. I asked the agent what he had done about it and was told... NOTHING. The child was not at school when I visited it and occupied his time in coaxing other boys to play truant.

What he needed in the worst way was a sound whipping in order to show him that the law was not to be trifled with. (I hope that I shall not be asked for further particulars re this case. The Inspector would not want to be a spy and even less an informer. Moreover the incident is by no means an isolated one.) It cannot be denied, I think, that education increases one's potentialities either for good or bad and that the educated "crook" is the one concerning whom the police are most apprehensive. If we are going to increase the Indians' scope of action without seeing that he has a wholesome respect for authority, are we doing him a kindness or are we doing more harm than good? May I also repeat what I have said often before, that the use of double-seats in Indian schools is tending to make of the Indian child an accomplished cheat. There are many obstacles to be met with in the administration of Indian schools that are really difficult to overcome, but surely these two are not in that category.
The Compulsory Education Act was introduced in 1936. The government was concerned about the welfare of the children and the future of the community. The Act required all children between the ages of 7 and 14 to attend school. This was seen as a way to improve the education system and provide better opportunities for the children.

The Act was met with resistance from some parents who believed that their children should be allowed to work and earn a living. However, the government argued that education was essential for the children's future.

In response to the Act, the government established a number of schools across the country. These schools were designed to provide a quality education to all children, regardless of their background or circumstances.

The Compulsory Education Act was a significant step forward in the education system. It ensured that all children had access to a quality education and provided them with the tools they needed to succeed in life.
Therefore, to be fair with us, you should get after such reserves as Belle Lake, Little Long Lake, all and Beaver Lake etc., all these reserves have numerous children of school age.

Another important question is do you think you could find time to come up with the coming summer and meet with some of the Indians in the two Western provinces, Saskatchewan and Alberta, and try to bring this whole question could be brought thoroughly with you personally and then we could arrive at some decision that would be satisfactory to all concerned.

(Mark E. Steinhauser)

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, with reference to the compulsory education clause of the Indian Act. If there are any eligible children who should be in school, the Department has full authority to place them there. Any children that you consider should be compelled should form the subject of a special communication to the Department, and our answering letter, specifically naming the children and the school, will give you authority for taking action.

When the Department has authorized compulsion, when you have given written notice to a parent and the child in question has not been placed in school within three days, he or she may be arrested without warrant and conveyed to the school by the Indian agent or truant officer or any member of the R. C. M. P. In addition—see Section 10 (4)—the parent or guardian may be proceeded against.

Most Indian agents have found, however, that if they tell the parents that they are prepared to compel, the formal notice or subsequent arrests are unnecessary.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to the status of Indian children in regard to school attendance.

In reply I beg to say that we have our own regulations pertaining to the attendance of children at school embodied in the Indian Act, but these apply only to Indians living on their reserves. Indians living off their reserves are subject to the provincial laws, just as any other resident. Where Indian children, not resident on a reserve, attend white schools, the provincial compulsory attendance law would be applicable in their case.

Dear Mr. Philam,

Having got the matter of prescribed and supplementary reading well in hand, I am turning my attention to the library titles—in an effort to have the whole thing ready for you by Christmas.

Fully half the titles on the tentative list which Mr. Bennett knew were, in his opinion, fairly graded. The same may, and likely does, apply to those he did not know. I am, and never have been, satisfied with the grading and, the list was but tentative. Something must be done. I have thought of the following:

I enclose a list of all the library titles on the tentative list—on regular acquisition forms. If you will order these for me I shall read them all and grade them. I shall then turn my children loose on them, watch them carefully, and listen to their comments. With this information in hand, I shall revise the list. In the case of any book which they do not appear to like, and which I think they should, I shall enlist the aid of other teachers and so on until I am satisfied. I shall then submit
the list is an authority on children's reading (I think at the moment of Dr. Wain, president of Teachers College, University of B.C. — who has a reputation for this work). While I shall not be able to give you the complete list by January I shall be able to give you a tentative one and the church authorities will be so much concerned with grading as with titles. The list, will, however, be ready by Easter I hope. I have checked the titles which you have in the office. These could come direct; the others will have to be ordered.

All will be returned as your copies to be kept in Ottawa. This will be most desirable in the end and so no extra expense will be involved. In many cases these books are handled by several publishers, that is, kindness can be called for your quotations.

I am not at all satisfied with the number of books for Catholic schools. I suggest that you write me a list Catholic firms and ask them to submit say ten books which they consider suitable for each grade. Then I can carefully go through and they can have them back if necessary.

If there is anything you can do expeditiously, it will be an enormous help. It has taken just a month for my last acquisition to through and in the case of the library books it is a month wasted.

Yours truly,

Dear Phil:

The Christmas vacation will give me ten clear days to get the standardization of texts off to you. I think it was understood that if you had them by the New Year it would be soon enough. However, before that, I do want the criticisms of the various books that were sent out for testing purposes. It is on these, largely, that my final decisions will be based. I append a list of the schools which should send in reports, and if they have not been received by the first of December, for instance, I would appreciate if you would drop them a line and jog them along.

I should also like to know exactly what you want me to do in connection with the Library titles. As I told you at the time I did them, and as Mr. Scott's comments show, they are poorly graded. I also proposed later that you should let me have the books, that I would go through them carefully and decide them. After that I had planned to turn my children loose on them, model their readings, listen to their comments—and then re-grade them. In the case of doubtful selections I had thought that they might be tried in other schools around me so I knew all the teachers, including those at Spanish. Then, when I was satisfied I thought it might be wise to turn the list over to a grading critic for approval. There are any number of them both in the East and the West, and I know several of them personally.

Obviously, this could not be finished before Christmas, as in the ordinary course of events I would not receive them from the Bureau for at least three weeks from the time a requisition was put through. I had thought that on the list sent out to the Church authorities the titles could be given without any reference to grading. It would be titles that would require their approval rather than grading. I should have the grading ready to send to you by Easter.

Also, there are a number of titles not on the requisition which I sent to you that I should like to have a look at. While this may appear to be the expenditure of a large sum, I have pointed out that they could be returned to the Department and could be used to fill a requisition for Library books to one of the Schools.

Yours truly,

THE WONDERFUL FISHING OF PETERKIN SPRAY

A fisherman bold was Peterkin Spray,
And he sailed and he sailed and he sailed away.
And when he got there, he embarked once more
Down the path that leads to the Sun's back door.
"Ho, Ho," said the Sun, "here is Fisherman Spray,
but the cook doesn't need any salmon today."

"Too bad, Mr. Sun," said Peterkin Spray,
And he sailed and he sailed and he sailed away,
But the wind was so light that 'twas half past eight
When he called his wires at the Moon-man's gate.
"Frosh fish!" he cried, but the Moon-man said,
"I never eat fish when I'm going to bed."

"What a fussy old Moon!" sighed Peterkin Spray,
And he sailed and he sailed and he sailed away,
And when he got there, he exclaimed "My Stars!"
I had almost forgotten to call on Mars."
"Fine fish," cried Mars and he smacked his lips,
"Charge a dozen or so to my next eclipse!"

"O dear, O dear!" sighed Peterkin Spray,
And he sailed and he sailed and he sailed away,
And when he got there, he declared "I wish
I never, never had learned to fish.
For some won't buy and others won't pay,
And I'm tired, and tired of sailing away!"

"I know what I'll do!" said Peterkin Spray,
And he turned his boat down the Milky Way.
He opened the Dipper (yes, honest, he did!),
He popped in his cargo, and slapped down the lid.
"There's a kettle of fish!" laughed Peterkin Spray,
And he sailed and he sailed and he sailed away.

Dear Phil,

I am attaching the Library List.

I have split it up amongst Publishers as well as I could using those which have the best editions in a case where the one book is sold by several firms.

On three of the Dent books there is a 50% discount for orders of twenty five or more. On their other two there may be the same, although I have nothing in writing to that effect. I should send the order directly to Mr. Button to make certain that you get the full discount.

The following is an extract from a letter from Mr. Watson & Thos. Nelson & Sons. "The prices listed in the books (those above) are the retail list price subject to the usual trade discounts. The Government would be able to buy them less 25% in the case of school books, and about 35% in the case of trade books." I imagine that the majority of those on my list are Trade books.

The Blackie quotations are the ones marked in the books sent to me by Mr. Morgan.

The Macmillan books are subject to the usual discount of 20% and no more for quantity.

I have included some Bible stories, for I feel that they are necessary. Until you have the opinion of some Catholic authority I should confine their use to Protestant schools. While there is nothing doctrinally wrong with them, they are by Protestant authors.

I have re-read everything which I have recommended, and have not relied upon my memory of prior readings. Also, where possible, I have checked the grading of the books with some standard list. Unfortunately these are all American, but I have let my own experience guide me largely.

While they are not all inexpensive books, yet I think that everyone which I have recommended is worth the
I think that you share my opinion that one good book is worth several inferior ones. I also feel that a well bound book is much better in the long run than a poorly bound one.

You will see, also, that, acting on my oft repeated statement, I have picked Blackie books for the higher grades, choosing the ones for the lower grades from more modern ones. This is essential enough for any beginner, but still more so when they have as limited a background as the average Indian child.

Depending on your finances, I should buy fifty of each of these. That should solve your supplementary reading problem for the ensuing year, and you are assured of having material which is of the best, and most satisfactory for your needs.

The only thing which I have not considered is the required supplementary reading for Grades VIII and IX. Each province has a definite list, and to list them all would extend this list beyond the bounds you wished.

I have asked you in a prior letter if I may tell those publishers who have given me specimen copies which of their books I have recommended to you. May I? I think it is but common courtesy. They are unlikely to see orders going through.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

George [Last Name]

Dear Phil,

Re: THE MARYWOOD READERS - MacMillan
Pre-Primer
Primer
Readers I - VI

I can truthfully say that this is the best series of Catholic Readers that I have seen. I really didn't know that such a set was on the market. While they are of American origin, they are handled by the MacMillan Co. of Canada.

The books are well graded. The material is well within the experience of children of the different grades. The vocabulary is well chosen, or at least as well chosen as possible considering the amount of religious knowledge and training concerned. In so far as they are used by Catholic children I imagine the vocabulary difficulties would be of no consequence.

A valuable part of the work is the amount of activity suggested. Rousseau aptly said, "Reflect that the student will learn more by one hour of manual labour than he will retain by a whole day's verbal instruction." While I believe that such things as comprehension tests, and correlated work belong to the sphere of the Work Book, yet in the case of supplementary readers it is well that such things be included.

I have no hesitation in recommending these as suitable Readers for the Catholic schools.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Phil,

You will likely have heard of CRY HAVOC by Beverley Nichols, even if you have not had the opportunity to read it. I read it sometime ago with considerable interest and respect. It is, as far as I am concerned, the correct approach to the subject of future wars.

The book appealed so much to the Ontario Department of Education that they have had a special edition printed—revised to suit the needs of children—and have had copies placed in all the schools in the Province. I have just had an opportunity to go through this new edition, and can thoroughly recommend it for use in our schools.

I think that it might be placed—to great advantage—in the residential schools, and in such schools as have first year high school pupils, or a strong entrance class.

The book sells for .75¢, and may be obtained from the publishers, George Doubleday, Toronto and Company, University Ave., Toronto. If you wished to review it, I am certain that they would be glad to send you a copy for that purpose. There would be no use in my offering you my copy, as mine is the adult one.

If you are at all interested, I should advise you to act promptly, as the edition is not large. Personally, I cannot recommend it too highly for your consideration.

Yours,

November 26th, 1934.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Thank you for your letter of November 22nd. We shall be very glad to receive an order for 100 copies for SAINTS FOR HOME AND SCHOOL and to allow you a 20% discount off the published price of $1.00. We are sorry not to be able to do better on this book but we think it is good value for the price, and between ourselves we make a very minute margin on the edition.

Regarding the History Work Books by Mrs. Gowan, we shall be willing to supply you with copies of these, providing that a minimum of 100 copies is ordered, at a price of 9¢ net, carriage charges extra. We are sorry that we cannot do better than this but you know we like to give you the best possible price although we are not always able to do so. We wish to thank you very kindly for your consideration in all these matters, and we shall look forward to receiving the order only when it is convenient for you to place it.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

J. M. DENT & SONS LTD.

CJE/DM
Ottawa, November 28th, 1934.

Dear Mr. Bustace:

With reference to your letter of the 26th instant, I am arranging with the Government Stationery Office to purchase from your firm 125 copies of "Saints for Home and School".

I am keeping in mind your offer regarding the History Work Books and we will see what we can do about them early in the new year.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

C. J. Bustace, Esq.,
a/c J. M. Dent & Sons,
224 Bloor St. West,
Toronto 5, Ont.
Ottawa, November 28th, 1934.

Sir,-

The Department would appreciate if you would place in stock 125 copies of "Saints for Home and School". These can be secured from J. M. Dent & Sons, Toronto, at a net cost of eighty cents (80¢) each.

A requisition covering approximately 114 copies of this book will be forwarded to you early next week and the remainder will be ordered from time to time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The King's Printer,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 8, 1934.

Dear Mr. McLean:

I enclose accounts which we have just received from the Canadian National Railways. In this connection I would refer you to my letters of October 30th and November 15th. The account for the freight on the books sent to Ottawa should be forwarded by you to the Government Stationery Office, if you quoted them a price on the books f.o.b. place of shipment. I would appreciate your communication with the Canadian National Railways and explaining to them that you will handle the accounts, and, as intimated above, if refund is due you, you should take up the matter with the Department of Public Printing and Stationery.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

McLean Merchandise Sales,
29 Melinda Street,
Toronto 5,
Ontario.
Ottawa, December 10th, 1934.

Dear Mr. McLean,

The enclosed has reached our office this morning. In view of my previous letter, I cannot understand why Donohue & Company persist in writing to us. As you are aware, the accounts for the books purchased from you should come from your office to the Department of Public Printing & Stationery and the accounts of Donohue & Company should be paid by you.

I sincerely hope that you will get this matter straightened out immediately as this order has caused us more trouble than any other order that we have placed in years. If Donohue & Company follow out their intention of sending a draft on us, they will just be out the cost of the draft as it will be returned.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

M. J. McLean, Esq.,
c/o McLean Merchandise Sales

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I should like to thank you for your kindness in giving me so much time recently out of a busy morning. You told me many interesting things about your work that I shall be long in forgetting.

Sample copies of some of the publications of both Oxford and Longman-Green have been sent to you, and I hope you may find among them something that will be of use. I am assuming that Mr. Phein will be able to examine them there, and that it will not be necessary to send him a separate lot.

We are entirely at your service. If you have special need of any particular kind of book, at any time, we shall be glad to give you such information as we have, or to send material to be examined. Our library and records are here to be used, and nothing would please us better than that you should put us to work.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Men Officer,
EDUCATIONAL DEPARTMENT.

INTRODUCTION

The library of every school or class-room should contain a variety of books sufficient to enable pupils in each Form to find there something of interest. It should also have a supply of interesting books new to him. The courses of study require that the subject of supplementary reading receive attention in class, and at seats in all the grades. "The material in the School Readers should be supplemented in each Form by a wide range of good books which will meet the interests and capacities of the pupils. Such books, sufficient in number for class use should, if possible, be provided in the school library,"—Courses of Study, 1924, page 5.

A test of many of our libraries in rural schools indicates that many of the books are not suitable for pupils of elementary grades, and few of the libraries contain an adequate supply of good reading material for Primer, First Reader, and Second Reader classes. Since the most elementary books may be easily read with interest by senior pupils, it is true that a library should have a larger supply for the junior classes than that which the material should be for seniors only.

Teachers and boards are urged to see to it that the library is made a very important part of the school equipment, and that it is fully used by the pupils for seat work and for home reading.

The pupils of the lowest classes should have good stories read to them in school and at home, so that their curiosity and interest in books should be aroused sufficiently to urge them to read for pleasure. Then their own reading, with proper guidance, will develop a reader for whom is good, and they will, without much direction, become very excellent readers. This wider reading will result in improving the pupils in composition, both oral and written.

For the beginners, nursery rhyme and other picture books with a small amount of text are the best. Those which are best liked by the children in the school should be selected. For example, Old Mother Hubbard, with a picture for each stanza, is a fine book for children before they are able to read very well. Illustrated books should be chosen wherever possible.

Each school library should receive an annual addition in order that it may contain copies of the more recent good books. A careful inventory should be made by the teacher and inspector each year, so that worn out and useless material may be discarded. One copy of this list should be filed in each school.

by G. C. Goldring, B. Ed.,

Superintendent of Toronto Schools

For Grades 7, 8 and 9

WE ARE CANADIAN CITIZENS is a Civics Reader designed for the use of pupils of ages thirteen and fourteen years. The subject is treated from the community standpoint, and the aim is to explain some of the basic principles of community life.

In the first few chapters, common experiences within the range of comprehension of the pupils are used to explain some of these principles. Then, following a chapter on "Home and Home Life", several chapters are devoted to definite features of community life, such as police, fire protection, public libraries, health, recreation, safety, and provision for the handicapped and unfortunate. After a chapter on "Rural Life", the next few chapters deal particularly with matters of interest to the individual, such as preparation for work and a healthy personality. Formal government is explained in the last half dozen chapters; municipal government, the government of a province, of our country and of the British Empire, and the League of Nations being taken up in that order. The final chapter emphasizes the importance of democracy, and is entitled "Citizenship in a Democracy".

Dear Phil:

We have received an order from the Department of Public Printing for 50 copies of *Net* and *Patay* at 10 cents each. I don't know how they got the price, except through you. Did we ever quote 10 cents per copy? There was a time - two or three years ago - when we would have been glad to have cleared the 50,000 old copies that we had at that time at ten cents each, but that time has passed and in the interim it has taken on a new lease of life. As you know, we reduced the list price from 25 cents to 15 cents a copy, so that even at the net price as it has appeared in our catalogue for two or three years, it is a bargain.

However naturally, if you have any record of us having quoted your Department 10 cents each in any quantity, we shall stand by that quotation, without hesitation. Otherwise, what would you say if we invoiced them at the catalogue net price of 15 cents per copy, less 20%, carriage extra? As you know, the word "net" means that such books are not subject to discount. However, your Department has been so kind to us that we feel that every possible consideration should be given to it.

I would have written direct to the Department of Public Printing but for the belief that you possibly provided them with the price and if so, our letter would seem rather strange to them. In other words, we shall continue to "play cricket" under any or all circumstances.

With kindest regards, I am

Yours very sincerely,

HB/LB

Dear madam:-

I have completed my Canadian history Work-Books for Grade Five, and enjoyed and found them very interesting. I feel that I have learned many interesting and valuable things from them. I find that they help me in remembering my history, and they help me take notice of some things which I may not pay particular attention to, if it were not for the questions asked in the work books.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Ruby Jean Foster.
Grade V correspondence student.
Dublin Shore,
Lunenburg Co., N.S.
May 25th, 1939.

Dear Madam:

As I am coming to the end of the term, I feel very sorry indeed to say "Good Bye" to my History Work-books. I really cannot explain how much I enjoyed this work, and those I have numbered on the list are the different kinds of work I enjoyed most.

It was a pleasure to study about those old settlers and early pioneers, their methods of working, etc. I am quite sure, History is one subject all boys and girls surely enjoy to study.

I sincerely hope all Canadian boys and girls will get as much enjoyment out of these books as I have.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Anson L. Wolfe.
Pupil of the Correspondence Study Division.

Dear Mrs. Cowan:

I was very pleased to learn your exciting history work-books. I should have liked to have more of painting and drawing and pictures.

Your books had such lovely things in them that there is nothing more left to give boys and girls for interest.

I live in a very lonesome place, and you shall be very interested to hear that my favourite subjects are Arithmetic and History, and always make high marks on them.

Well I hope you shall be able to make more books, also for Grade VI, for next year I shall not have any.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sirs:

During the summer and autumn months I have had an agency for books. These books are indeed educational, and I have had a great many orders for Public Schools; the said orders to be delivered about the last of September.

I visited the Indian Residential School in Shubenacadie this afternoon, but Father Mackie was away. However, I talked with the sister in charge and she suggested that I write to this Department and ask for an order. She told me that all books were supplied by your Department.

My first book is Winston's Dictionary and Reference Library. This is a dictionary, plus sections of Signs & Symbols, Tables of Weights Measure and Standards, Words & Phrases, Names of Persons and Places, Christian Names of Men & Women, Chronological Table (1000 B.C. to 1937 A.D.), Gazetteer,
and Atlas of the World. The complete volume contains more than 1350 pages, including 300 illustrations. The complete book is 9½ inches long, 7 inches wide, and more than 2 inches thick. It is attractively bound in waterproof cloth that will not finger mark, that is vermin proof, stamped in gold and ink with Patent Thumb Index—Price $4.50.

The second book I have suitable for schools is "The New Wonder Book of Knowledge" and it is one volume complete in itself. This book is 7½ x 9 inches containing 624 pages with 72 illustrations to describe the text and impress upon the mind the world's wonders in nature and history. This book is intended for the large class of men women and children who wish to gain some fair idea about the subjects that arise either in ordinary conversation or in reading, and about which they desire some definite information. Every chapter is "The Story of ——" For instance: Salt Making, Pair of Shoes Making, Teaspoon, the Big Redwood Tree, in a Watch, in a Fire Extinguisher in a Case of Chewing Gum Telephone, Newspapers, Submarine, Oil Well, Suit of Clothes, Bridges and dozens of others. Price $1.98
The last book I'd like to mention is "The House of Windsor" by Eric Roland, Canadian author. It includes the life of George V, founding the House of Windsor and is certainly a permanent record of the Empire and the Crown including the Coronation of George VI and special sections of the Royal Tour. The book measures 6 x 8 1/2 in., comprises nearly 500 pages lavishly illustrated with 64 photographs, 34 of which are on the Royal Tour. It is bound in durable rich cloth, maroon with gold stamping for only $2.00.

I do feel that these books would be of great value in the Indian Residential School in Shubenacadie. I sell all kinds of books but the 3 I've described are the ones I've sold to a great many School Boards, and many teachers.

I believe there are 8 grades in the School. Could I hope to have an order for several of these books? I do not hesitate in recommending them. I am a teacher of 12 years experience, and feel that the books are all that I've described them to be.
May I have a favorable reply as soon as possible, so that I may include an order with the one I'm delivering Sept. 31st. The payments may be divided - part when ordering and the remainder on delivery - or full payment on delivery.

Thanking you, and awaiting your reply,

I am,
Respectfully,
Hazel R. MacPhee.

Dear Mr. Rogers:

I am anxious to secure, if I can, a catalogue and price list of the books available for sale and distribution at the Manitoba Book Bureau.

I would have written to Mr. Brown but I am not sure that he is still in charge.

All textbooks for use in Indian day and residential schools and all school supplies are provided through the Government Stationery Office, a branch of the Public Service which comes directly under the King's Printer. This year, however, owing to the war conditions and the additional work for which the Stationery Office is now responsible, we have experienced difficulty in securing delivery of our textbooks and school supplies on time. It has been the practice in the past to make a distribution of these books and supplies annually.

I should like to know what proportion of the textbooks for use in Manitoba schools are sent out during the holiday period (July and August). It is just possible that I may have to work out a system whereby residential school books will be provided one season of the year and Indian day school books at another. HOME-MADE FROZEN DESSERTS

What is more appetizing on a warm summer day than a dish of good ice cream? More and more of this dairy product is now being used and it has virtually passed out of the luxury class of foods, being served as a dessert at hotels, restaurants and homes at all seasons of the year. Like all dairy products, ice cream is a well-balanced, easily digested, palatable food containing all the nutritive elements essential to body building and good health—fat, protein, carbohydrates and vitamins, especially Fat Soluble A. When made from fresh, clean-flavoured cream, it has a delicacy of flavour which appeals to young and old. Ice cream is altogether an ideal food.

The attractiveness of ice cream is one of the reasons for its popularity, though it has many other advantages which place it among the more important foods. It is a general favourite, even among those who do not relish milk and cream in the fluid state and it contains all the nourishment of these foods, as the milk constituents are not evaporated in the freezing process. Ice cream is a valuable source of fat, the lack of which may be serious in fever in the ordinary diet, protein of excellent quality for growth and the maintenance of health, fat in one of its most easily digested forms, sugar and all three vitamins. The comparatively high proportion of sugar and the low temperature make ice cream less desirable than milk for children, but it has much to recommend it as an article of diet.

Dr. McCollum, an eminent authority on nutrition, calls attention to at least one point in favour of the custom of selling ice cream in cones. In this way, many children are induced to buy ice cream instead of candy and thus supplement a diet sometimes seriously lacking in milk and other dairy products. Undoubtedly, an increase in the daily milk order would be a wiser and more economical method, but in homes where the value of milk is not fully understood, this "casual purchase" or "treat" by poor children is a matter of much greater importance than it might at first thought appear to be.

Ice cream is of particular importance in the sick room, as it provides nourishment in an easily digested form. It is usually allowed even when the patient's diet is limited to liquids and is often especially valuable in cases of fever.

CARE OF THE CREAM

Cream which is about 24 hours old is more satisfactory for ice cream making than fresh cream. It should, however, be perfectly sweet and it is necessary, therefore, that the cream be kept in a cool place. If cream is aged (24 hours) and kept cool before freezing, the texture of the ice cream will be smooth and free from ice crystals which are so objectionable.

EQUIPMENT NECESSARY

It is possible to make frozen desserts with utensils to be found in any kitchen. Good ice cream may be made according to the following directions by using some vessel such as a small tin or granite pail and another vessel similar in shape, but several sizes larger.

After pouring the ice cream mixture into the smaller pail, cover tightly and place in the larger one, leaving the handle erect. Pack with ice and salt, or with snow and salt, then, using the handle of the pail, turn back and forth to keep the contents in motion. After 5 or 10 minutes, remove the cover, being careful to prevent any salt getting into the mixture and, with a broad bladed knife, scrape the frozen portion from the inside edge into the centre. Cover tightly and repeat until the mixture is frozen, scraping from the inside edge frequently.
Ice cream for a small family, or individual amounts for an invalid, may be made in this way by using a small vessel such as a baking powder can and a bowl or small pail. This is not so convenient a method of making ice cream as when a freezer is used. A longer time is required but a delicious dessert can be made in this way.

Various sizes of ice cream freezers are on the market. For the average home, a quarter-size is suitable and can be purchased at almost any hardware store for $5.00, or less. A freezer is a convenient addition to the kitchen equipment and, when properly cared for, will last a long time.

Ice can be secured at all seasons of the year in towns and cities, while the modern dairy farm usually has a well-filled ice house. Snow can be used, when available, as a substitute for ice with very satisfactory results. Salt is also necessary for the freezing process. Crushed rock salt is preferable, but ordinary coarse salt or even table salt will serve the purpose.

**Classification of Ice Cream**

**Plain Ice Creams.**

The plain ice creams are made from table cream (12 to 18 per cent butterfat), sugar and flavouring material. Vanilla is the most common flavouring, but other flavours such as chocolate, maple, coffee or caramel, are suitable and appetizing.

**Fruit Ice Creams.**

The fruit ice creams consist of cream, sugar and fresh fruits. Almost any kind of fresh fruit such as strawberries, raspberries, cranberries, peaches, cherries, grapes or currants can be used. The fruit should be fresh and well ripened.

**Nut Ice Creams.**

Nut ice creams consist of cream, sugar and nuts. Any of the common nuts—walnuts, filberts, etc., can be used. Vanilla, chocolate or caramel are suitable flavourings for nut ice creams.

**Bisque Ice Creams.**

Bisque ice creams are made of cream, sugar and bread products such as macaroons, grapenuts, marshmallows, etc.

**Parfaits.**

Parfaits belong to the richer and fancier ice creams. They consist of cream of about 25 or 30 per cent butterfat, sugar, yolks of eggs and flavouring material. Nuts or fresh fruit may be added.

**Mousses.**

Mousse is probably the richest and fanciest of the ice creams and consists of frozen whipped cream to which sugar and natural flavouring have been added. Fresh fruits are necessary for mousse and a small amount of lemon juice should be added to bring out the fresh fruit flavour.

**Puddings.**

Ice cream puddings are made from the parfait mixture with the addition of candied fruits and nuts. They are generally highly seasoned. These puddings are suitable for Thanksgiving, Christmas and other holiday festivities.

**Ices.**

The most common ices are the water and milk sherbets which consist of milk, skimmilk, or water, sugar, flavouring and the whites of eggs, if desired. Sherbets are characterized by their tart flavour, as lemon juice is usually added in addition to any other flavouring used.

Frappes consist of the same materials as sherbets, but are frozen only to a soft, semi-frozen consistency.

Souffles differ from sherbets in that they contain the whole egg.

Any of the above ice creams can be made easily in the home. The cost and richness of the plain ice creams will depend on the richness of the cream used. Ordinary table cream (about 18 per cent butterfat) will make a very smooth and tasty ice cream, but this cream may be thinned with milk in equal proportions, which will reduce the cost and still make an acceptable product. Parfaits, puddings, mousses and bisques are fancy products which are more expensive, but are suitable for special occasions. In the country and small towns and even in large cities fancy ice creams cannot be purchased readily. They can be made in the home, however, at any season of the year, as all the materials necessary can be obtained separately at any time.

**Some Recipes for Ice Cream.**

Only a few recipes are given as illustrations of the different types of frozen dishes, but a great variety of frozen desserts can be made by the use of different flavouring materials. In the making of ice creams, much scope is given for the imagination and ingenuity of the housekeeper in attractive and palatable combinations of food materials.

The cream in each of the following recipes, except for that of the mousse, is table cream (16 to 18 per cent butterfat), but the cost of the ice cream can be reduced considerably by using half cream and half milk; or about two-thirds cream and one-third milk. Thinner cream, however, will not give as smooth an ice cream and it will probably require a longer time to freeze.

The amounts given in these recipes are for one quart of ice cream.

**Vanilla Ice Cream, No. 1.**

- 1 pint table cream
- 2 tsp. vanilla
- 1 cup sugar

Mix the ingredients, stir to dissolve the sugar, and freeze.

**Vanilla Ice Cream, No. 2.**

- 1 cup scalded milk
- 1 egg yolk
- 1 tsp. flour
- ½ cup sugar
- 1 tsp. vanilla
- 1 cup cream

Mix the flour and sugar together, add the slightly beaten egg yolk and stir in the milk gradually. Cook over hot water about 15 minutes, strain and cool. Add the cream and flavouring. Freeze and serve.

**Chocolate Ice Cream.**

- 1 pint cream
- ¼ cup sugar
- ¼ cup chocolate or cocoa
- 1 tsp. vanilla
- few grains salt

Put the chocolate or cocoa, half the sugar and a little water or milk in a pan. Heat over hot water and stir until a smooth syrup is formed. Cool the syrup and add with the remaining sugar to the cream. Add flavouring and freeze.

**Oatmeal Ice Cream.**

- ½ cup rolled oats
- 1 cup milk
- ¼ tsp. vanilla
- ¼ cup sugar
- 1 cup cream

Soak the rolled oats in the milk one hour. Strain. Cook the strained liquid in a double boiler about 45 minutes, stirring frequently. When cool, add cream and flavouring. Freeze.
FROZEN RICE PUDDING.

2 cups rice
1 cup sugar
1 cup cream
1 tsp. vanilla

Wash the rice thoroughly in boiling, salted water until tender. Drain; then add the milk and cook in double boiler about 30 minutes. Press through a sieve and pour over the egg yolks and sugar beaten together. Return to the double boiler and stir until it thickens. Remove from the fire, cool, add the flavouring and freeze. Whip the cream and add when the ice cream is nearly frozen. Leftover cooked rice may be used (about 6 tbsp.).

STRAWBERRY ICE CREAM.

1 pint cream
1 tsp. vanilla
1 cup sugar
1 cup crushed strawberries

Crush the fruit and sprinkle with the 1/4 cup sugar. Mix the remaining ingredients and freeze. Add the crushed fruit when the mixture is nearly frozen.

Any fruit may be used in the same way, the amount of sugar being varied according to the sweetness of the fruit. Before adding the sugar to seedy fruits such as raspberries, crush through a sieve to remove the seeds.

NUT ICE CREAM.

1 pint cream
2 tsp. vanilla
1 cup sugar
1 cup chopped nuts

Add the vanilla and sugar to the cream. Freeze. When nearly frozen, add the chopped nuts. Nuts used in chocolate or maple ice cream make a very palatable frozen product.

MACAROON BISQUE.

1 pint cream
2 tsp. vanilla
1 cup sugar
1 cup ground macaroons

Dry the macaroons in a hot oven. Roll or grind in a meat grinder and add to the ice cream when nearly frozen. Grapefruit ice cream can be made by substituting grapefruit for macaroons.

LEMON MILK SHERBET.

1 pint whole milk or skimmilk
1 cup sugar
2 cups lemon juice
2 egg whites (if desired)

Whip the egg whites and mix with other ingredients; freeze. If fresh fruit flavours are desired, add only one-third the amount of lemon juice and less sugar with sweeter fruits. Egg whites may be omitted, but the sherbet will not be as smooth in texture.

Milk, eggs and sugar will be the same in other sherbets, only the flavouring material will change.

The following recipes are for the richer ice creams and are more expensive. The cream used should not be thinned and to get the best results should contain about 25 to 30 per cent butterfat. Table cream, however, will suffice.

GOLDEN PARFAIT.

1 pint cream
2 egg yolks
1/2 cup sugar
2 tsp. vanilla

Add one-quarter of the cream to the egg yolks and beat a few moments over hot water, stirring constantly. Remove from the fire, cool, add the other ingredients and freeze.

A nut parfait can be made by adding one-half cup of chopped nuts to this recipe. For fruit parfait, add three-quarters of a cup of crushed fruit.

NESSERODE PUDDING.

1 pint cream
2 tsp. vanilla
1 cup maraschino cherries
1/4 oz. candied fruits
1 cup sugar
2 egg yolks
1 cup chopped walnuts
1 slice chopped pineapple

Add one-quarter of the cream to the egg yolks and heat a few moments over hot water, stirring constantly. Add sugar, remove from fire, cool and add vanilla. Grind and mix the fruit and nuts and add when the cream is nearly frozen. All puddings are made from the golden parfait mixture with fruits and nuts added.

MOUSSE.

1 pint whipping cream
1/2 cup crushed fruit (strawberries, peaches, etc.)
1/2 cup sugar
Juice of one lemon

Whip the cream. Then add sugar, lemon juice and crushed fruit and freeze. Turn the freezer very slowly and just enough to insure even freezing of the whole mixture. Although not necessary, the cream may be coloured to correspond with the colour of the fruit.

SAUCES FOR PLAIN ICE CREAMS

MARSHMALLOW SAUCE.

1/2 lb. marshmallows
1 cup boiling water
1 cup pulverized sugar

Cut marshmallows in pieces and melt in double boiler. Dissolve sugar in the boiling water. Add to marshmallows and stir until thoroughly blended. Turn into bowl and cool before serving.

CHOCOLATE SAUCE.

1 square chocolate (unsweetened)
2 tsp. butter
1/2 tsp. vanilla
1 cup sugar
1/2 cup boiling water

Melt chocolate, add the butter, then the water, gradually. Add the sugar and boil about 5 minutes. Then add vanilla.

COFFEE SAUCE.

1/2 cups milk
1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup ground coffee
1 tsp. cornstarch
few grains of salt

Scald the milk with the coffee and let stand about 20 minutes. Then strain. Mix the sugar, cornstarch and salt together, and into this stir the hot coffee infusion. Cook 5 minutes and serve hot.

This sauce may be made using one cup of milk and 1/2 cup of left-over coffee.

FREEZING THE ICE CREAM MIXTURE

It is a common impression that it takes a great deal of time and hard work to make ice cream. Such is not the case. It is a simple matter to mix the ingredients and, if the cream is at least 24 hours old, and if ice and salt is used in proper proportions, it is a matter of only 15 or 20 minutes before the freezing process is completed. The freezing process, however, is important to give the ice cream the proper body and texture as this has a great effect on the palatability.

POINTS TO REMEMBER WHEN FREEZING ICE CREAM.

1. Cream when frozen increases considerably in volume and, on this account, the freezer should never be filled more than half full. The increase in volume is due to the incorporation of air during the freezing process and the more evenly this is incorporated in the ice cream mixture, the smoother the ice cream will be.

2. The can containing the ice cream mixture should be adjusted in the freezer, then packed with alternate layers of finely crushed ice and salt. About eight to twelve parts of ice to one part of salt will give an efficient freezing mixture. As the freezer is turned, the salt will gradually work down and come in contact with all the ice.

3. Snow may be used instead of ice. If the ice or snow does not melt quickly enough, a small amount of water poured over it will help in the formation of the brine and hasten the freezing process.

4. If the cream has been previously cooled to a low temperature, the handle of the freezer may be turned fairly quickly from the start; if the mixture in the can is at ordinary room temperature, the handle should be turned slowly for a few minutes to cool the cream to about freezing point. Too rapid turning of the can before the cream is quite cold tends to churn the cream and will result in the ice cream containing particles of butterfat which are objectionable.
5. After the cream has started to freeze, the handle may be turned more quickly until the freezing process is complete. This should require from fifteen to twenty minutes.

6. When the ice cream is frozen to a semi-solid condition and will hold its shape, remove the dasher from the freezer and, with a spoon, pack the ice cream solidly in the can.

7. Cover the can, placing a cork in the opening in the cover.

8. Draw off the brine and repack the freezer with alternate layers of ice and salt, using about eight measures of ice to one of salt. If only a short time can be allowed for the ice cream to stand use a higher proportion of salt.

9. Cover the freezer with a damp sack or piece of carpet and allow to stand at least one hour for the ice cream to harden. Large quantities require several hours.

10. After about an hour, draw off the brine and add more ice and salt. Repeat whenever necessary until the ice cream is used.

SCENE—An ordinary well-appointed kitchen—stove at centre back of stage, shelf at right, higher shelf at left back, refrigerator at left, table at right, door at upper left, armchair about centre front.

The curtain rises on the kitchen folk—Mrs. Porridge Pot and Mr. Soup Kettle beside stove; Mrs. Teapot, Miss Salt and Mr. Pepper together at right in front of shelf; Kitchen Clock on higher shelf; Mrs. Candy Box and Mrs. Sugar Bowl at right near table; Mr. Pickle Jar upstage.

NOTE.—The above suggestions are given for use when real furniture is used.

(Voices off stage)

BETTY—Mother, may I have a cup of coffee instead of milk with my lunch today? Susie Smith who sits behind me in school drinks coffee every day. She said this morning that only babies drink milk.

MOTHER—But you remember how I told me last week that Susie is one of those little girls who are so much underweight. I want my little girl to be well and strong and that's why I want you to drink milk and follow all those health rules teacher tells you about.

BETTY—But could I have coffee just this once?

MOTHER—No, Betty. Coffee's not good for children—not even a taste. Now you've finished your lunch, you have time for a rest before starting back to school.
Betty—All right, Mother. I'll sit in the big chair in the kitchen.

(Betty comes into kitchen and sits in chair—settles comfortably.)

Betty—(Drowsily) My! It's so nice and warm here—I'm sleepy as can be.

Mother—Well, take a little nap, dear. Sweet dreams!

Mr. Kitchen Clock (peeking out from behind clock)—Well, Betty is asleep already. I hope she dreams of the Kitchen People for a change. I wonder if these Human Beings ever realize how interested we are in them?

Mr. Pickle Jar—Are they indeed, Mr. Kitchen Clock? You see, my name is Mr. Pickle Jar and I do not visit in the kitchen very often so I do not know the kitchen people very well.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Why, yes, we are all very fond of the family and we all try very hard to please them. Some of us are very jealous of what Betty's Mother thinks of us, and Mrs. Milk Bottle and Mrs. Coffee Pot are forever arguing as to which one does the most good.

Mr. Pickle Jar—Mrs. Milk Bottle and Mrs. Coffee Pot! I don't know those ladies. They have not come in yet? Perhaps they are together somewhere.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Oh, dear me, no! Mrs. Milk Bottle and Mrs. Coffee Pot are not very good friends. They do not meet very often for they live in different localities. Mrs. Milk Bottle lives on Refrigerator Street. She prefers that neighbourhood to any other for the climate suits her better. Mrs. Milk Bottle says it is very bad for her to live anywhere but the coldest spot she can find.

Mr. Pickle Jar—Who is this Mrs. Milk Bottle?

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Mrs. Milk Bottle is quite an important personage here. I am very fond of her, but like everybody else she has her peculiarities. For one thing, she always wears a hat in the house. If she has her way, she changes her travelling hat of cardboard as soon as she comes into the house and puts on one of those glass or aluminium ones. She takes a lot of pride in her appearance.

Mr. Pickle Jar—And what about Mrs. Coffee Pot? Where does she live?

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Mrs. Coffee Pot is particular about her looks, too. She lives on Pantry Row, near her neighbours Miss Salt and Mr. Pepper, who Mrs. Matchbox says are seen together a good deal.

(Mrs. Milk Bottle and Mrs. Coffee Pot enter from opposite sides.)

Mrs. Porridge Pot—Here's Mrs. Coffee Pot now—and here's Mrs. Milk Bottle.

Mrs. Coffee Pot—Good morning, Kitchen People. My, this is a cold place.

Mrs. Milk Bottle—Oh, you are so particular! You always like such a warm place.

Mrs. Coffee Pot—Well, I'm not like you, turn sour when I'm left in a warm place for a little while. Warmth improves my disposition. You always talk about being kept "Clean, cold and covered."

Mrs. Milk Bottle—You are rather particular yourself about being kept clean and shiny.

Mrs. Coffee Pot—Well, anyway, I am satisfied with that. You like to be dressed up with a glass or aluminium head-dress; I suppose you think the cardboard one is not becoming to you.

Mrs. Milk Bottle—Well, I've very important work to do and I can do my work better when people keep me clean and cold, and—

Mrs. Steam Bowl (interrupting)—Yes, but sometimes Betty seems to like Mrs. Coffee Pot best. Do you remember this morning, she asked for coffee instead of milk?

Mrs. Milk Bottle—But her mother said coffee was not good for children.

Mrs. Coffee Pot (angry at what Betty's mother said about her)—I am just as good as some other folks I know here.

Mrs. Milk Bottle—Oh, you are, are you? Well, perhaps you will tell what good you do.

Mrs. Coffee Pot—I am very fond of the family.

Mrs. Milk Bottle—Oh, yes, you pretend to be fond of the family. Dear knows, you should be, for you are kept shiny and clean and are well looked after, but I don't believe you repay the kindness shown you except by giving to grown-up people a drink of good flavour.

Mrs. Coffee Pot—I suppose you have been listening to that cousin of yours, Mrs. Cream Jug. She always thinks she is so necessary. It's true she is a great help to me, but many people prefer not to have her accompany me.

Mr. Kitchen Clock (stepping out from behind clock)—Now, now, my friends, do not let us squabble. Let us hold a Court and decide this question once and for all. Lend your ear, good people, and let us hear the statements of the parties to the suit. We will now see which of them gives most to little Betty.

Mr. Kitchen Clock (continuing)—Now, Mrs. Milk Bottle, what have you to say?
Mrs. Milk Bottle—Judge Kitchen Clock, I claim I am the best friend of babies, boys and girls and even grown-up people, too; especially when they are sick. I put roses in children's cheeks and make them healthy and happy. The Good Health Fairies have blessed what I have to give them.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—We will hear what the Good Health Fairies have to say.

(Enter Butterfat Fairy, who takes Mrs. Milk Bottle by the hand.)

Butterfat Fairy—I am Fairy Butterfat of the Tribe of Good Health Fairies and I help Mrs. Milk Bottle.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Oh yes—I have heard of you. They say you are Mrs. Milk Bottle's favourite fairy.

Butterfat Fairy—Why no! She is just as fond of the other fairies. Folks always see me first, though, because I am so hard to keep down.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Do you bless the milk which Mrs. Milk Bottle gives boys and girls?

Butterfat Fairy—Why, of course. I make milk taste better, and more than that, I keep boys and girls warm and make them grow.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Have you any little sisters or brothers who help Mrs. Milk Bottle?

Butterfat Fairy—Oh, yes, little Sugar Fairy helps Mrs. Milk Bottle and she loves little children. She is so sweet almost everybody loves her.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Call Sugar Fairy.

(Butterfat calls Sugar Fairy.)

Sugar Fairy (entering)—I'm not very big but I love little children. They love me, too. I help folks keep warm; and milk, which Mrs. Milk Bottle gives, is a food I have blessed.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—And what else do you do, little maid?

Sugar Fairy—I also bless Mrs. Sugar Bowl and Mrs. Candy Box, too (pointing to each in turn); but if I could write, I'd hang a sign on both—"Take in Small Doses."

Mrs. Sugar Bowl and Mrs. Candy Box (both together)—Oh, that would not be nice. Little children just love us and always want us.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Order! Sugar Fairy is giving evidence.

Sugar Fairy—You know, Judge Kitchen Clock, when little children want too much of my company, I begin to spoil their teeth and sometimes even make them sick. I don't do it to be mean, I just can't help it.

(Sugar Fairy takes signs and hangs them on Mrs. Sugar Bowl and Mrs. Candy Box. Mrs. Sugar Bowl and Mrs. Candy Box hang heads and look rather ashamed.)

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Is there any other little fairy wishing to speak?

Protein Fairy (entering)—Yes, I'm Protein Fairy. I build muscle to make people strong. Boys who eat what I bless can play football—and baseball—and hockey.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—And little girls—what can they do when they eat the food you bless?

Protein Fairy—Little girls can run fast and jump far. They can also do a great deal to help Mother. I can work best when boys and girls drink about three glasses of milk every day.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Call the next witness.

Mrs. Milk Bottle—Come, Lime Fairy.

Lime Fairy (entering)—I help Mrs. Milk Bottle, too. I make teeth—good, white, firm teeth—and children can have the teeth I make "for keeps" if they take good care of them. I build bones, too.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—And what foods have you blessed, little builder?

Lime Fairy—Milk is my favourite. I put into milk more of the material to build teeth and bones than I put in any other food. Children who drink it can depend on me.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Are there any more witnesses?

Vitamin Fairies (entering all together, hands clasped)—We are called Vitamins. We always go along with milk which Mrs. Milk Bottle gives and we love it best of all the foods because we're not all together in any other. We love Mrs. Milk Bottle. We are not very well known but we do a great deal of good and no boy or girl could grow or be well and strong without us.

(All the fairies join hands and dance in ring, singing to the tune of "London Bridge is Falling down":)

We're the Good Health Fairies, Fairies, Fairies,
We're the Good Health Fairies, we work for children.
We make good food for boys and girls, boys and girls, boys and girls.
We make good food for boys and girls and make them happy.

We love one food the best of all, best of all, best of all,
We won't tell you that food's name, we'll spell it for you.

(Fairies form the word M-I-L-K.) See footnotes 1 and 2; also illustration on page 16.

Kitchen People (all together)—Milk!

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Has anyone else here anything to say in favour of Mrs. Milk Bottle? Have you, Mrs. Porridge Pot?

Mrs. Porridge Pot—Yes, indeed, Judge. I have something especially good for children but I always have to depend on my friend, Mrs. Milk Bottle, to help me.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—And you, Mr. Soup Kettle—what have you to say?

Mr. Soup Kettle—I give something good too, and I always know that if Mrs. Milk Bottle helps me with a soup for the family, it is a food I can be proud to give.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Yes, I guess Mrs. Milk Bottle does give a good deal to little Betty. All these witnesses are great friends of mine. Now, Mrs. Coffee Pot, let us hear what you have to say. Please tell the kitchen folk here what you can do for boys and girls.

(Mrs. Coffee Pot hangs head, looking ashamed—sulks.)

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Come, come! Haven't you any fairies to speak for you?

Caffeine (coming from behind Mrs. Coffee Pot)—I'm not a fairy. I'm a mischievous sprite called Caffeine. I make coffee harmful for children. None of the Good Health Fairies will have anything to do with me. My best friend is Cousin Tannin who does the same to tea as I do to coffee.

(Tannin peers from behind Mrs. Teapot on hearing his name mentioned by Caffeine.)

Mr. Kitchen Clock—Has anyone something to say in favour of Mrs. Coffee Pot? (Deep silence.) Now what is the decision?

(All kitchen people with exception of Mr. Kitchen Clock, Mrs. Coffee Pot and Mrs. Milk Bottle consult together.)

Mr. Pickle Jar—Well, I guess this is no place for me. What I give isn't good for children.

(Mr. Pickle Jar tiptoes around the group and when he gets near the door makes a dash through it and away.)

Mrs. Porridge Pot (announcing verdict to Mr. Kitchen Clock)—The decision of this assembly is that Mrs. Milk Bottle is by far the more valuable of the two parties to the suit.

Mr. Kitchen Clock—You have heard the verdict. (Pointing to Mrs. Coffee Pot)—For punishment, I am going to forbid you to have anything to do with Miss Betty and all other growing girls and boys.

(Fairies clap their hands. Mrs. Porridge Pot and Mr. Soup Kettle say "hear, hear," and nod approvingly.)

(Mrs. Coffee Pot stamps her foot and cries in anger.)

(Mr. Kitchen Clock returns to place behind clock, points one hand of clock to one, the other to twelve and beats once on small drum or pan.)

Mother (coming into kitchen)—One o'clock! (Wakens Betty.) Time to go back to school, dear.

Betty (Stretches and yawns, then wakes up suddenly)—Oh, Mother, I had the funniest dream. All the pots and pans were people. They talked. Mother! And Mrs. Milk Bottle and Mrs. Coffee Pot were quarrelling about what they did for me. . . . And they had a Court and there were fairies. . . . And Mrs. Milk Bottle was so nice and so kind and all the fairies belonged to her. . . . Mrs. Coffee Pot didn't have any fairies—just a horrid sprite who makes coffee bad for girls and boys. I'm not going to taste coffee—or tea—till I'm grown up anyway. I'm going to drink Milk every day.

Mother—I'm glad of that, Betty. We're going to have hot milk soup for supper.

Betty—Oh, goody, goody! Make a lot, please, Mother—I'll have a good appetite.

(Betty dances out of kitchen to go to school.)

Mother (laughs and says to herself)—It's fortunate Betty had that dream. There's nothing like Milk for growing children.

(Curtain falls.)

Arrangement

The playlet may be staged with a background similar to the one used by the Dairy Branch, shown in the photograph. This allows for an easy and natural grouping of the characters. In this case, Betty and her Mother are not seen in the opening dialogue. Another arrangement is to make use of two curtains, the usual one at the front, behind which Betty and her Mother sit at the table, and a second curtain which hides the other characters until after Betty falls asleep. The playlet, however, can be put on in a schoolroom or elsewhere by arranging real furniture conveniently and placing an ordinary kitchen clock on a shelf from which a curtain is suspended to hide the character "Kitchen Clock."

While the costumes and setting are of very great importance in the effective staging of this play, it can be put on in the schoolroom very interestingly for children, by dressing the characters in plain white aprons such as are used in Home Economics classes and using cardboard labels with the names of the characters. One teacher made use of it in this way, even improvising furniture—a large black cloth covered a small table and did duty as a kitchen stove. As has been said, however, the costumes add a great deal to the attractiveness of the play and they can be made at home or in the classroom without much trouble and with little expense.

It is sometimes possible to secure the equipment used by the Dairy Branch, Department of Agriculture, Ottawa. Anyone wishing particulars, or further suggestions as to staging the playlet, may write to this office.
