Mrs. Mouse Entertains

A CHOCOLATE STORY

By

Helen G. Campbell,

DAIRY AND GOLD STORAGE BRANCH,
DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, OTTAWA.

The mice were giving a party—a wonderful party. It was Father Mouse's birthday and most of the relations were invited.

All day long Mrs. Mouse had scurried here and scurried there putting things "to rights" and getting ready for company. There was such a lot to be done—the house to be "tidied up", spoons and forks and knives to polish, frocks to wash for all the Missy Mice, suits to press for all the Easter Bunnies—and all without letting Father Mouse know; it was to be a surprise.

Always everybody else knew about it. Barker the dog knew, too—ow the cat was pretty certain and even the lady-butterfly suspected it. Scratchily-scratch, scratchily-scratch, Mrs. Mouse ran hither and thither—to market and home again, to market and home again, with all the supplies for a wonderful supper.

She hadn't very far to go; Father Mouse had been to this when they built their house. "Dear me!" It made Mrs. Mouse tired just to think what a time they'd had choosing a site for their new home. She used to tell how she and Father Mouse tramped miles and only decided to build there after they'd taken a good look at Mo-Cow the cat and had seen that he ate too much over to run fast. "We'll be quite safe here," Father Mouse had said, "will Mo-Cow start reducing exercises."
But even though they were near the market, it took a long time for Mother Mouse and the Missy Mice, coming home with their aprons filled, to bring everything, for Mrs. Mouse was to have something special for supper — she wanted the relations to see what a good cook she was.

What a time she'd had to decide! She and all the Missy Mice had talked and talked about it. They knew Father Mouse would want his cheese. He was particular about having it every day; he thought there was nothing like it to make mousie. He no did it, he said, to make him strong to provide for his family. "Let's have bread and cheese," said the Missy Mice, who never tired of it. But Mrs. Mouse wanted something "extraordinary."

All of a sudden, she squeaked delightedly, "I know, I'll have a cheese soup."

"A cheese soup, Mother?" said the Missy Mice. "How could you make cheese soup?"

"I can" said Mother Mouse, "I know all about it; only last week when I went out for my afternoon walk I overheard Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door tell The-Lady-Upstairs exactly how it was done. 'It was delicious,' she said 'and good for the children too — when well made.'"

Mrs. Mouse went on to say she had been just walking through, not paying the slightest attention to the ladies' talk when she heard someone mention cheese. She stopped right away, of course; she was always interested in that subject, but she'd never heard of a cheese soup before. "You take some milk," Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door was saying, "you heat it just so — in a double boiler, of course."

Mrs. Mouse had run for pencil and paper — she'd had an "awful" job to keep the paper from rattling but she'd managed to write down most of the directions and to make a special note not to let the cheese get too hot or cook too long.

"If you do" Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door had said, "it will be tough and the children can't digest it properly."

You see, Mrs. Mouse liked to walk around the rooms occasionally though she wasn't on speaking terms with The-Lady-Upstairs — in fact, she wasn't even sure they'd like each other.
Sometimes she overlooked the funniest things — about HEALTH — and FOOD — and SUNSHINE — and FRESH AIR. It seems that Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door was very particular about her children's health. She tucked them in bed very early and Mrs. House had heard her say she opened the windows wide every night.

And their food was just so — about a quart of milk every day for each of the children, some fresh fruit and some green vegetables, lots of butter and brown bread and glasses and glasses of water.

Mrs. House knew, of course, that everybody should have plenty of sleep, eat plain nourishing food, drink lots of milk, wash their faces, comb their hair, brush their teeth, and make themselves tidy. But Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door seemed to know all this and just why too; she often talked about it with Th-Lady-Upstairs.

Mrs. House stopped her work to talk of all these Health Rules and the little pigs thought it so interesting you could have heard a pin drop till the clock struck. "Gnats!" said Mrs. House, "there is just time to go for the cheese before I should begin to make the soup." It would take a big piece and how could they get it home without Father House to help them? You see, he'd gone down to the City Hall to attend a meeting of the House's Improvement Society.

It was quite a job but the Missy Pigs and the Master Pig pushed and tugged and puffed and there it was at last, as fine a piece of cheese as Mrs. House had ever laid her eyes on.

Then, such a sorry for pan! The milk was put to heat just like Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door had said. Mrs. House measured the flour very carefully — while the butter melted in a saucepan. Then she stirred it in — just so — for she'd heard it must be smooth, creamy pasto. She didn't forget the salt and pepper either — not too much, she didn't believe in highly-spiced, highly-seasoned foods, especially for the children.

Then she must add the milk and stir and stir.

"Poor dear, what if it should be lumpy!" Mrs. House thought she'd die if it wasn't smooth, particularly when she expected Mrs. Farm House who set such a good table and Mrs. Grocery House who was trained to put on airs and Mrs. Church House who lived in such an aristocratic community.
But the soup didn't get lumpy; it was smooth as smooth. There was nothing to do now but wait till the company came and at the last minute put in the cheese which the Missy Mice were having such a time to grate. The grater was big, even Eldest-Hasty-Mouse could hardly reach the handle, and Youngest-Hasty-Mouse would be up to mischief and pull the tails of his brothers and sisters.

Then the egg—how were they going to break it? Mrs. Mouse thought she'd leave it out—you can't have cheese soup—let Eldest-Hasty-Mouse hold the prettiest hand. She put it near the edge of the table and hid Mother Mouse behind a curtain away down near the floor, then the Missy Mice gave a quick little shove. Snack! went the egg in Mother Mouse's curtsy.

There was just a minute to change their dresses, just a minute for Mother Mouse to put on a clean apron and polish her nose. Everything was ready! Mrs. Mouse had just made sure all the little mice's finger nails were clean and that they'd washed behind their ears, when the doorbell "ding-a-ling!"

"There!" exclaimed Mrs. Mouse. "Oh-ee" said the little mice.

In scampered the visitors and everybody had presents for Father Mouse—apples and carrots and lettuce and cabbage, and all the things he liked.

Can you imagine when Father Mouse came home? Such a surprise! Such a sensation! "Happy Birthday, Happy Birthday!" squealed all the relations and Mrs. Mouse left him shaking hands with everybody when she went out to finish the soup.
In went the cheese! In a minute it was melted; then in went the yolk of the egg! One last minute to beat it — now it was ready to serve. Everybody helped to carry it to the table and Mother Mouse was so proud of her big surprise. The relations smacked their lips and said "delicious" and "scrumptious" and "tasty" and other words which meant the soup was over so good.

"How did you make it, Mother Mouse?" And Mrs. Mouse told them how she had learned it from Mrs. Neighbour-Next-Door, how she'd said it was so good and so economical — and fine for the children, too, if properly prepared.

You can imagine the chatter at the table, the clatter of dishwashing afterwards, the games next, the laughing and running and sliding down the banisters. There was such a noise that Nee-Cry the cat awakened and said "My, my, if I hadn't eaten too much for dinner, I'd chase those mice here." Nobody else heard and the mice had such fun it seemed no time till they heard the alarm clock call The-Lady-Upstairs it was time to get up. "We must be going" the visitors said, "we've had a lovely time."

When the last guest had said "Good-bye" Mrs. Mouse sighed happily, "Well the party was a great success and everybody liked my cheese soup."

Cost of Food Primary Factor.

The committee appointed consisted of Dr. E. Bianche Smith of the Public Health Service, Dr. Frances Rother of the Children's Bureau and Dr. Edith Hawley of the Bureau of Home Economics. All three women are nutrition experts. Dr. Sterling, who served as chairman, also was an authority in hygiene, and Dr. Rother in infant hygiene and Dr. Hawley is a food economist.

The committee, after doing by scientific methods the food values which must be represented in an ideal minimum diet, arranged the menu on the basis of economy as possible. Indian children need and should have about the same foods, but the new ration has been proven to be the best for any child food, in view of the tendency to tuberculosis and other communicable diseases among the Indians. Cost was a primary factor in the problem.

The suggestions were submitted to Dr. Henry W. Sherman of the Bureau of Chemistry, Dr. J. McCollum of Johns Hopkins. Both men approved the plan with a few suggestions and Dr. McCollum added a few recommendations. In this form they were returned to the committee whose report was approved by Dr. Marshall C. Guthrie, chief medical director of the agency.

These modifications came from the recommendation that the standard to be achieved, where and when possible, should be to provide for a quart of milk per pupil daily, two ounces of meat or fish, five eggs, which may be used as an alternative to meat, and a small quantity of sugar and small quantities of jam.

Cost of New Ration.

The cost of the new ration is 39 cents per day as against 34, the estimated cost of the old ration. But officials of the Indian Bureau say it is impossible to provide even the present approved ration in all schools at all times. The actual ration program must keep within cost limits of 20 cents, usually within from 16 to 18 cents. The cost of the army ration is about 50 cents.

"We have estimated an average expenditure of $250 per pupil per year in the large schools, $200 for the medium schools and $175 for the smaller schools," states H. B. Peairs. "The average school year is 270 days, and the cost of the new ration would be 25 cents a day to $67.50. That is more, sometimes than we have."

The committee estimates that it would bring the cost to $100.30. And we could only be pleased to see it provided. But the present standard is not provided for under any circumstances. No Indian child goes hungry. They may not have the best food, but they have as good fare as we would like to give them.

Emphasis is being placed on improving the food served in our schools and on the substitution of either fresh canned or dried products whenever it is impossible to provide an adequate supply of fresh milk."

At a Conference of Missionaries and Teachers engaged in the Indian work in the Diocese of Saskatchewan on August 21st and 22nd, the following resolution was passed:

It was felt that during last winter, when many of the Indians were in want and short of food, that the children were lowered in strength and stamina owing to insufficient nutrition.

THE CANADIAN RED CROSS SOCIETY

REPORT ON FOOD SURVEY

ST. JOHN'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, CHAPLEAU, ONTARIO

OCTOBER 1-8, 1944

Early last year the National Nutrition Committee of the Canadian Red Cross Society learned of the bad malnutrition conditions which had been found among Indians by Group Captain P. F. Tisdall when he made a survey. Group Captain Tisdall suggested that the Red Cross could render assistance and that the Society might offer its cooperation to the Department of Indian Affairs. This was done, and at the request of the Department a survey at St. John's Indian Residential School at Chapleau was undertaken. Canon Vale, principal of the school readily gave his consent and was most helpful in furnishing information to the National Director of Nutrition during the time the survey was being conducted. Mention should be made, as well, of the excellent cooperation given by the matron and all members of the staff.

In the following report we would like to emphasize that any criticisms are made with the knowledge that the existing conditions are not due to lack of interest in the children's welfare, but rather to (a) lack of facilities, (b) lack of money, (c) insufficient knowledge of the nutritional needs of children, (d) insufficient training of the staff who are in charge of the meals.

1. Procedure for Sampling of Food.

The first step was to establish what could be considered a representative or average serving, since the ages of the children varied and since the servings of food usually were not uniform. A preliminary study of amounts of food served was made, and a series of weighings done to determine the average.
A chart of the dining tables was made, and the age of each child entered. It was found that the most representative amounts were those given to the boys and girls 11 to 18, so samples were based on amounts served to this group. At each meal it was necessary to make a number of weighings of the bread as it was not cut in uniform slices.

Servings of all foods on the daily menu were placed in bottle I with 15 cc. glacial acetic acid. This food was used for assaying the thiamine, riboflavin, niacin, calcium, iron and phosphorus.

In bottle II were placed average servings of all raw, preserved or cooked fruits and vegetables, jams, fruit sauces, ketchup, pickles, dishes such as stew containing vegetables or fruit, fruit pies, etc., except tomatoes, grapefruit or grapefruit juice, orange or orange juice or fortified apple juice. This food was used for the assay of ascorbic acid from sources other than those rich in ascorbic acid and commonly used as supplements. An equal volume of 5% metaphosphoric acid was added to the food in this bottle.

Tomatoes, citrus fruits and citrus fruit juices were placed in bottle III for the assay of excellent sources of ascorbic acid. An equal volume of 5% metaphosphoric acid was also added to the food in this bottle.

Arrangements were made with the railway, so that the food reached the laboratory on a schedule which permitted the determination of the ascorbic acid content within 24 hours from completion of the collections.

2. Observations on Preparation of Food in the School.

The kitchen was visited daily and some of the following observations will be of interest in comparing the calculated value of the diet with the results of the assays.
1. The turnips were peeled and cut at 9 o'clock in the morning and left lying exposed on the kitchen table until they were put on the tables at noon.

2. Cabbage which was used in the vegetable soup at night was on cooking before 9 A.M.

3. The cooking of most of the vegetables, including potatoes was started early in the morning and they were then left standing on the back of the stove until served.

4. The standard of all food preparation was very low and the meals were distinctly unpalatable. Since the girls resident in the school are supposedly being trained to act as domestics, and to set up a better standard in their own future homes, it is doubly important that they acquire the highest possible standards for the preparation of simple every-day foods. The best illustration of the need for this is the bread made in the school. This is heavy, solid, tough and tasteless except for an unpleasant flavour, which will be mentioned later. The kitchen matron mentioned difficulty in using Canada Approved flour, so the Director of Nutrition sent to the Department of Agriculture for special recipes for the use of this flour in bread-making. The Director and Miss Hinton then tried one of these recipes and taught one of the Indian girls to make the bread according to these directions. The resulting product was excellent and the staff expressed the wish that they could have bread like that all the time. It is interesting to note that careful washing and rinsing of all the utensils before starting, resulted in bread free from any of the unpleasant flavour which had previously characterized all the bread made at the school.
Special short courses in the handling and preparation of food and in simple nutrition are necessary for all members of kitchen staffs in the schools if the Indian girls in turn are to receive adequate instruction to fit them for the work they will do later.

3. Cleanliness

One of the noticeable features was the lack of cleanliness and sanitary care in the handling of the food, the washing of dishes and in the care of the kitchen and dining rooms. There was no adequate protection from flies and it was not uncommon to see the food on the tables practically black with them. One day about 40 or 50 flies were counted on one slice of bread. Cockroaches were everywhere in large numbers—particularly in the kitchen and dining rooms.

As nearly as could be determined, the unpleasant flavour which permeated all the food came from improperly washed dishes and utensils.

It is important to note that this survey was done at the peak of the year when the supply of vegetables was most plentiful and their vitamin content at a high level. For example potatoes, which are one of the chief sources of ascorbic acid in the school dietary, average 50-55 mg per cent in September, but by April they average below 10 mg per cent. The matron also reported that by January the amount of other vegetables in the menus would be much less since the quantity grown does not last throughout the winter.

Therefore the value of the diet shown by the assays in Table II is higher than it would be during a large part of the year, and this is a factor to be considered in comparing the assay values with the recommended allowances.

The diets were assayed for calories, calcium, phosphorus, iron, thiamine, riboflavin and niacin on a composite sample for a week. The dietary may be compared with the allowances for all the different age groups, but for the purpose of this discussion only three of the latter have been included in Table II.

The calorie content of the diet is satisfactory for a large proportion of the children, but is 25% below the requirement of the 15 older boys. The calcium content is also low for the adolescent boys and girls. The assays show a high iron content and the riboflavin may also be considered satisfactory for all the children. However special attention should be drawn to the low thiamine level in relation to the recommendations for adolescence. But most serious of all is the deficiency of vitamin A and ascorbic acid. At the peak of the season, with the ascorbic acid content of the foods at a high level, the amount of ascorbic acid in the diet did not meet the suggested level for the youngest child, and was only 31-35% of the recommended allowance for children 10 years of age or over. This group of children represents 8% of the school.
The calculated value for vitamin A is probably high because no butter and very few eggs were used in the school cooking, and the figures used in calculating were for recipes which probably contained these foods. However even the calculated value shows a deficiency of this vitamin for all the children over 6 years of age—in other words practically the whole school, as Table III reveals. The niacin content is also low for the adolescent group 15-16 years of age.

In general it may be noted that during the period of stress when the demand of the body for these nutrients is greatest, the school dietary is startlingly low in ascorbic acid and vitamin A, and to a lesser degree is deficient in thiamine, calcium and niacin, and in calories for the boys 15-16 years of age.

By midwinter the value of the dietary will drop still lower because (a) the supply of home-grown vegetables other than potatoes will be nearly exhausted, (b) the commission lists from which all other food is ordered does not include any canned vegetables or tomatoes, (c) the ascorbic acid (vitamin C) content of potatoes or other vegetables on hand will be much lower.

Milk Supply

Some mention should be made of the handling of the milk. No apparent effort was made to keep the milk in properly cleansed containers, since it also had the predominantly bad flavour of all food prepared in the school. Also, sufficient care was not taken to keep the milk at the proper temperature, with the result that it was frequently served when showing signs of sourness. Since the milk came from a tested
Lord the staff seemed to consider that it was safe and the need for adequate sanitary precautions in its handling had not occurred to them. In addition, the danger of undulant fever from any raw milk supply is one factor of which many people are in complete ignorance.

Suggested Remedial Measures

The above situation calls for a careful study of ways and means to improve the nutrition of the children in the school. It is realised that any nutrition program for Indian residential schools must be practical in nature, and adaptable to the individual school. Accordingly the following tentative suggestions in brief form are put before the Department for their consideration:

1. Increased Supply of Food Sources of Vitamins and Minerals.

The first and perhaps most important step in the nutrition program is to see that an adequate supply of the essential food nutrients is made available. This can be accomplished by the following measures:

(a) An increased production of vegetables and eggs, and in those districts where it is economically sound, also of milk. This production program could be developed with the assistance and advice of the Department of Agriculture through their local representatives. A preliminary study of the nutritional needs of the children could then be translated into the number of bushels of vegetables or quantities of other foods required for the school.

(b) Revision of the School Commission Food List would be desirable. The present lists, from which all food other than that produced by the school is ordered, include no canned vegetables or tomato juice. Additions to the list would be made with careful consideration of food values in relation to
Expenditure. Tomato juice or canned tomatoes is a much-needed addition at the present time.

II. Education of Staff

As was pointed out earlier in this report, the survey revealed the necessity of short courses in simple nutrition for all members of kitchen staffs in the schools if the Indian girls in turn are to receive adequate instruction to fit them for the work they are to do later. Under present conditions it is not practical to suggest centralized courses, but a start could be made by having trained Home Economics graduates spend a period of time in each school developing with the staff the best possible methods of food preparation. Constant follow-up work would be necessary in connection with this undertaking.

III. Education in the Schools

Periodic short courses in food preparation, nutrition and household management held in the schools for the Indian girls would do much to stimulate their interest and would offer an opportunity to present homemaking as an interesting and worthwhile vocation.

Summary

In respectfully submitting this report the Nutrition Service of the Canadian Red Cross Society extends its appreciation to all those who cooperated in the survey, and wishes to offer its continued cooperation to the Department of Indian Affairs.

REPORT ON FOOD SURVEY

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, SPANISH, ONTARIO

March 11 - 15, 1946

The National Nutrition Committee of the Canadian Red Cross, in cooperation with the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, undertook a second food survey at the Indian Residential School at Spanish, Ontario, during the five-day period from March 11th to 15th, 1946.

The Principal and all members of staff extended the fullest possible cooperation, and were appreciative of any suggestions made regarding methods for conserving food value during the preparation of meals, and in connection with the menus.

We would like to emphasize that any suggestions in the following report are made with the knowledge that existing conditions are due primarily to (a) lack of money, (b) lack of facilities, (c) the unavailability of certain foods, and (d) insufficient knowledge of the nutritional needs of children.

On arrival at Spanish we discovered that the boys and girls were in separate schools, with completely separate management of the commissariat. Because it was impossible to have the food in both schools assayed, we decided to collect the food samples in the Girls' School only. The rest of this report will therefore be presented under two headings - (1) Survey in St. Joseph's Girls School, and (2) Survey in St. Peter's Boys School.

Survey in St. Joseph's Girls School

1. Procedure for Sampling Food

Representative servings of all foods served were collected at the three meals each day, weighed and placed in bottles with 15 c.c. glacial acetic acid. This food was used for assaying the thiamine, riboflavin, niacin,
calcium, iron and phosphorus. The results of this assay will be forwarded in a supplementary report. The diet was calculated and the details of these calculations are shown in Tables VI - XII, attached to this report.

2. Observations on Preparation of Food in the School

The kitchen was visited nearly every day and the methods of food preparation noted.

(a) Vegetables were prepared some time ahead and left soaking, sometimes overnight.

(b) Potatoes were never cooked in their jackets.

(c) All food was handled and prepared in a very cleanly manner.

(d) The food was appetising, and carefully served.

(e) The girls all receive instruction in methods of food preparation, but it was not determined whether these methods are in accord with the more recent scientific findings. However they were all taught standard procedures in following recipes, with the result that the food tasted good when served and the quality was always the same.

3. Cleanliness

Among the most noticeable features in the school were the immaculate conditions maintained in every part of the building - particularly in the food cupboards, storerooms and dining rooms.

The children's tables had attractive serviceable coverings and these were carefully set before each meal with the necessary cutlery and table napkins. We considered this was an important factor in the training of girls for domestic work as well as for their own homes. It was also conducive to the well-ordered, happy meal hours observed in the school.

It is important to note, in studying Table V-A, how in this particular case greater improvement in the all-round value of the dietary may be gained by some modifications in the additions suggested in Table IV-A.

(1) The addition of cheese and butter to the diet may be omitted and the money used instead to increase the tomatoes or tomato juice from 4 oz. to 6 oz. daily. This would increase the vitamin A to a greater extent and would raise the level of the ascorbic acid to cover the needs of the boys 15-15 years of age.

(2) If the tomato juice were increased to 8 oz. daily, the additional eggs would not be necessary because the iron and protein in the diet is already adequate, due to the large quantities of navy beans in the diet. This is an important consideration from the standpoint of cost.

The conclusions reached in (1) and (2) indicate that any general recommendations for changes in the Indian school dietsaries might result in unnecessary expense and at the same time there might not be the maximum return in food value for the expenditure involved. Therefore a careful analysis of the dietary in each school should form the basis for suggested nutrition program.

General Observations

The sympathetic and understanding approach of the staff to the children was a striking feature of the schools. As a result there was an unusually happy atmosphere during both work and play.

Recreation for the children, such as skating parties, swimming and boating, was carefully planned and supervised and it was apparent that every effort was being made to promote normal healthy relationships.
The genuine desire of all members of staff to co-operate in making any possible improvements made this survey both pleasant and profitable to all concerned.

While doing the survey we had the opportunity to speak to the staff and to the students of the Girls School and to three groups of boys in St. Peter's School. These talks were informal and from them we were able to gain valuable information regarding the food likes and dislikes of the children.

Suggested Remedial Measures

The outline of the two dietaries and the additions necessary to bring them to a level of adequacy, calls for a careful study of ways and means by which any improvements may be made. It is realized that any nutrition program must be practical in nature and adapted to the individual Indian school. Accordingly the following tentative suggestions are submitted to the Department for their consideration.

1. Increased Supply of Protective Foods

The first and most important step is to see that an adequate supply of the essential food nutrients is made available. This could be accomplished by an increased production of milk, vegetables and eggs. Plans for the increases might be developed with the assistance of the Department of Agriculture through their local representatives. Prior to this a study of the nutritional needs of the children should be made, and these needs translated into terms of food would form the basis of the production program.

II. Staff Education

Courses in basic nutrition for all members of staff would create an awareness of the importance of adequate nutrition for children and would
lead to greater interest and co-operation in any nutrition program which might be undertaken. In addition, courses in food preparation and home management are necessary for all kitchen staffs.

III. Nutrition in the Schools

Periodic short courses in nutrition would do much to stimulate the interest of the Indian girls in their present course in food preparation.

Summary

The Nutrition Service of the Canadian Red Cross Society extends its appreciation to all those who assisted in the survey, and wishes to express its continued interest in a nutrition program for the Indian schools. The Society hereby offers its support to the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In reply to your letter of September 15th may I say that we will be glad to undertake a survey at the Mount Elgin Institute at Bancroft, from October 6th to 18th, and will make definite plans accordingly if you will be kind enough to communicate with the Principal of the school. We would appreciate hearing from him regarding the best means of transportation to the school, and also if you would make arrangements for accommodation for myself and an assistant.

On Thursday Dr. Alderwood came to see me and we had a long talk about the Indian schools which I found very valuable. Dr. Alderwood seems genuinely interested in improving conditions and is particularly interested in the possibility of training courses for the staffs. He is anxious that the five people who are at present taking their training for the Home Mission field receive courses in nutrition, food preparation and household and institutional management, because most of their trainees enter Indian work and he hopes that some of the present ones will go to Indian residential schools.

I suggested to Dr. Alderwood that he write to you, making the request for such training and that you in turn might be able to relay the request to Red Cross, since we had offered our co-operation.

Since there are several training schools in Toronto it is possible that the United Church Training School would be able to combine with the Church of England if the above-mentioned courses were offered by Red Cross. This would be at least a start toward the goal which we are all interested in reaching, namely, better preparation and service of foods in the schools, with resulting improvement in nutrition.

If you consider that it would be valuable to start this work I believe our Executive would be more inclined to grant permission if the matter was presented as an independent request from your Department.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I sometimes regret very much that I am just one person in the Department and therefore cannot accomplish work as rapidly as I would like to do. We are now completing the report on the survey at the Indian School at Duncan, and I may say that I consider the health conditions in this school simply appalling. Apparently, from my observations, no one on the staff had even elementary knowledge of sanitation and hygiene. Since there was no matron many phases of the school activities were not being handled efficiently or adequately. I have gone into this in slightly more detail in the report, but thought you would like to have this information right now.

Miss Macleod, Nutritionist of the British Columbia Division, and I spent a very interesting two days at the school in Kamloops in December. I can assure you that it was a pleasure from beginning to end. The authorities were extremely cooperative and Dr. Tennant was very kind in taking us out to the school and back to our hotel. Our impression was that the children were very well cared for and that every effort was being made to give them the best food available. We were particularly interested in the broad viewpoint of Father O'Grady regarding the necessity of providing the students with some means of carrying out the things they had learned, after they left the school.

Recently, through our Red Cross worker at Brantford, I heard that there was some difficulty raised by the Local Council of Women in connection with the food at the Indian School. In the opinion of the Red Cross worker the interference was ill-timed, since she understood the new principal had just taken over his new duties recently. As you know, both the Sault Ste. Marie and the
Brantford schools were on the list of those you wished me to visit. It would be possible to visit one of these schools for a five-day period beginning March 50th. For many reasons it would be more convenient to go to Brantford at this time, since I could take one of the Community Nutrition students as an assistant on the survey. I realize that there might be two sides to the question of going to Brantford at this time. It has occurred to me that if we did a survey now we would have some effectual information for your Department if the Local Council of Women are not satisfied. Also, we might be able to give the new principal some assistance in planning food supplies for the school, and that would put him in a position to say that he had had professional advice.

On the other hand I can realize that since this difficulty has arisen the principal might fear that this was more interference. However, if you could assure him that we were going in with a sympathetic approach and with the object of helping in mind, would it be possible to arrange this survey for the date mentioned above? I would appreciate very much hearing from you in regard to this matter by return air mail if possible.

I only wish that circumstances permitted me to plan further ahead in this work in the Indian schools. However we have to take advantage of the opportunities when we see a spare moment immediately ahead of us.

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

As a result of our meeting with you and Colonel Neary last Friday, I feel that a satisfactory decision has been reached whereby this Division can now proceed to ascertain the feeding problems of Indian Residential Schools and develop a continuous dietary Service for them designed to aid their health and education.

The nutritional status of the Indian School children is of concern since it constitutes a part of the Canadian health problem. And, with regard to remedial action I would like to review the main considerations.

1. Suggested menus, adapted to circumstances
2. Shopping Lists adapted to these menus and therefore to the possibilities of the locality
3. Recipes for cooking and instruction of cooks
4. Assistance with budgeting and cost accounting so as to give maximum health benefit for the money spent
5. Assistance in coordinating health education (including nutrition) with the actual menus, such as by providing explanatory posters in simple terms

In order to offer direct assistance to individual schools and to evolve a standardized service it will be necessary for one or two of my Nutritionists to visit most of these schools. It is understood that you will explain such visits to the church authorities concerned, and that the actual visits will be arranged with the Provincial Inspector or Commissioner concerned. I understand that it will be easiest to begin in Ontario and this will suit us very well. We would like to begin as soon after opening on September 9th, as can be arranged. Miss A.M. McCready, local phone 3103 will be ready to proceed at that time assisted by Miss D. Tripp.

I am enclosing a copy of the inspection report form which we propose to use. Any comments or additions you wish to make will be welcome. I might mention that only rarely do we get information on all these points, but it is almost essential as a reminder if inspections are to be uniform. Also, I am sending along copies of a weekly Food Record and a Daily Menu Form which are basically suitable to record the kind and amount of food served and eaten during a week.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Dietary Service for Residential Schools

I have your letter of August 19th, which I have read carefully.

I cannot give you much help for the obvious reason that I am not competent to pass on such matters.

Your letter refers to the "survey of the feeding problems of our schools" carried on by the Red Cross. I was quite interested in that, desiring to know what opinion the Red Cross had of the efficiency of the schools. We have not been afforded the privilege of any information either as to whether the feeding of the children was satisfactorily carried out nor whether improvements were suggested or criticisms made.

I had almost come to the conclusion that this survey had not been made, in view of the fact that the contract for operating the schools is between the Department and the Church. One would imagine that any report on the way in which that part of the contract relating to the feeding of the pupils is carried out by the Principal, who is the agent of the Church, would eventually come to this office.

However, it does seem to me that the service which is contemplated is desirable and even necessary. We shall do what we can to secure the co-operation of the Principals. We should appreciate hearing how this offer is received by the Principals and what comments they make.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Neary,

It is pleasant to make your acquaintance, even by letter. This is in reply to your 15-44-(W.T.), Oct. 22.

My activities in respect to school diets has not passed the stage of early thought. I did not know about your dietitians and had it in mind to ask school principals to let me have the weights of the various foods used in their schools in one week, later on in the year when their pupils should all be in and the schools on a routine running basis. From this point I had hoped to set on to some assistance to them.

Now that you have more expert advice available I shall not follow up my idea, at least until one of the dietitians reaches this Province.

Over the 20 years I have been visiting residential schools I have seen a great improvement in diet. I think many schools now feed their pupils better than children in white families are fed on the average and probably better than the pupils in white boarding schools. I have inquired of several Principals whether they could keep up their present dietary standards in the face of increasing food costs. They have assured me that they could, but I think they will find it hard to do so.

In the circumstances, I would like to have the dietitian come here before visiting any schools in Alberta. It so happens that in this Province there are several schools in remote areas where much local produce, fish, game, etc., form part of the diets. I think schools of this kind in Alberta may be more accessible than similar schools in some other Provinces and I should be very pleased to help the dietitian see some of them.

Please be assured that I shall welcome the dietitian. I am concerned over what she deals with and not too sure what I can do by myself to contribute anything useful.

P.S. A week's notice would ensure my being at Edmonton.

E.L. Stone

HEALTH ASPECTS IN RELATION TO FOOD SERVICE

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

Nutrition Division, Dept. of National Health and Welfare, November, 1946.

Indian Residential Schools located at Kenora, Fort Frances, Sioux Lookout and McIntosh, Ontario, Portage la Prairie, Brandon and Elkhorn, Manitoba and Lebret, Saskatchewan were visited. Reports on inspection of Food Service at each school are attached (and copies have been forwarded to Indian Affairs Branch). From a health standpoint, there are certain aspects which deserve additional consideration.

1. Staff:

In each of the schools operated by the Protestant churches, the kitchen staff constituted a problem. The Principals could not compete with the local salaries offered by industry, hotels, restaurants, etc., to obtain an efficient staff. Consequently, unqualified staff (often elderly) were paid a mediocre salary to carry out the work in a careless and uninterested fashion. The result was that the food quality was not good, cleanliness was neglected, the Indian girls were not receiving proper training and there was lack of coordination of efforts.

In each of the schools operated by the Roman Catholic church, nuns comprised the kitchen staff. They had received training and gained experience through their respective orders. Their salaries were of no consequence and therefore they were genuinely interested in their work. The result was that the food quality was good, cleanliness was evident, the Indian girls were receiving training and there was coordination of efforts. And, they were receptive to further assistance.

In the case of the schools operated by the Protestant churches, salaries and sources of suitable and flexible cooks are primary concerns. As long as unqualified and disinterested staff are employed the introduction of assistance (i.e., menus, recipes, etc.) will not greatly improve the situation.

2. Facilities:

Dishwashing: The use of several small dishpans is a most inadequate method of dishwashing in any institution. This is particularly true in the case of Indian Residential Schools since the Indian children are highly susceptible to tuberculosis. The most effective method observed was the use of a double compartment galvanized metal sink for washing and rinsing. It seemed evident that most schools strictly curtailed the use of soap, for dishwashing, as an economical factor. These schools must be made to realize that sufficient soap is a necessity and not a luxury. If necessary, the extra cost should be provided in some way by the Dominion Government.

A satisfactory sink method requires the use of a three compartment sink for washing, rinsing and chlorinating the dishes. From the standpoint of durability stainless steel sinks are preferable to galvanized metal sinks; the end cost is actually less.

The installation of dishwashing machines would be feasible at any of these schools and would constitute a labour saving device. Consideration might be given to providing schools with such machines, although this might interfere with training in cookery since they are not likely to encounter them later in life.

Potato Peeling: The girls, as part of their training, should know how to peel potatoes by hand. But to do this, it is not necessary to peel potatoes for 100 or more each day. In fact, other phases of training are thus neglected.

Potato Peelers were observed at St. Mary's School, Kenora and Qu'Appelle School, Lebret. The installation of a potato peeler at the
other schools would be advisable.

Ventilation and Lighting: The presence of stale cooking odours and a dark, dingy appearance are contributing factors to poor and unhealthy working conditions in any kitchen. A hood with installed fan over the range would increase the ventilation in the kitchens at Fort Frances and Sioux Lookout Schools. Additional electric light facilities would be an advantage in the kitchens at Fort Frances, Sioux Lookout and Cecilia Jeffrey (Kenora) Schools.

Refrigeration:

Adequate refrigeration is a requisite in an institution for the proper storage of current supplies of meat, dairy products, other perishables and daily left-overs. Otherwise, food spoilage and loss are very likely to occur. At Sioux Lookout and Portage la Prairie, the family-sized icebox and refrigerator, respectively, were very inadequate and inconvenient. A walk-in refrigerator, in each case, seems necessary.

Cooking Utensils and Dishes: Many old and worn cooking utensils and chipped and cracked dishes were observed in use at Cecilia Jeffrey, Sioux Lookout, Brandon and Elkhorn schools. Many of these items were unfit for use and should be condemned.

It has been difficult to replace them and, in many cases, the utensils were worn beyond a state of additional repair. As the present situation constitutes a health menace some arrangement should be made for these schools to be able to obtain immediate replacements.

Storage: It is essential to store dry staple supplies in bins or covered containers rather than opened bags, from the standpoint of cleanliness and insect control. At Sioux Lookout school, the bins were insufficient and in a neglected state of repair.

The hot water pipes passed through the storerooms at Fort Frances and Brandon Schools, and the temperature was too high for the storage of food supplies.

3. Pasteurization of Milk:

As an initial precautionary measure against Tuberculosis to which Indians appear highly susceptible the cattle should be tested often and regularly. At McIntosh school it was stated that it was difficult to get an inspector to test the cattle. At Fort Frances School the cattle were only tested every two years. There is little assurance of a herd being free from tuberculosis by such irregular tests.

Since milk is a medium for the transmission of Tuberculosis, undulant fever, a system for the pasteurization of all milk for consumption should be in effect at these schools.

4. Nutritional Aspects:

The nutritional inadequacy of the children's diet can be attributed to the following reasons:

(1) Financial Limitations -

The food cost per child per day ranged from twenty to thirty cents according to our calculations which were based on the average monthly figures for the value of farm produce and other food expenditures. These figures were obtained from available data at the schools and should be a good estimate.

Extensive work had been done at the Nutrition Division on inexpensive diets. An expenditure of thirty-six cents per person per day under different circumstances, is a likely amount to spend to provide adequate food for children 6 to 15 years old.

Therefore, none of the schools was spending enough on food.
(2) School Farms:

The kind and amounts of supplies realized from the school farms varied according to climate, soil, cultivated acreage, organization and management. Due to rock, bush and swamps at Cecilia Jeffrey, St. Mary's McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Schools it was necessary to purchase a large percentage of the feed for cattle. Consequently sufficient cattle were not kept to provide enough milk and beef. Similarly sufficient potatoes and vegetables for a full year's supply were not grown.

The organization and management of the different school farms indicated individual preferences for raising certain animals or growing certain vegetables to the exclusion of other important products (e.g., eggs). The more of all foods needed that can be produced locally, the more adequate can be the diet at low cost.

(3) Food Purchasing -

The important nutritive value of certain foods were not fully appreciated by the food purchasers at each school. Canada Approved Vitamin B flour or bread was used only at Sioux Lookout and Qu'Appelle Schools. Refined prepared cereals (e.g., puffed wheat) were used once or twice a week and rolled oats the rest of the week. Where prepared cereals are used, the puffed cereals and corn flakes should be avoided since other flakes etc. provide more nutrients. Iodized salt was not always purchased for cooking purposes.

(4) Nutritional Losses in Cooking:

In some cases, the antiquated cooking facilities necessitated prolonged cooking periods which would result in considerable nutritive losses. Also most of the cooks were not acutely aware of the retention or loss of nutrients in relation to food preparation and cookery. Potatoes, cabbage and turnips, properly prepared, cooked and served are economical sources of Vitamin C. But, by slow or prolonged cooking and long standing periods after cooking the Vitamin C content of these is mostly destroyed.

Since the children far from realize the recommended daily servings of citrus fruit or tomatoes, they are most dependent on such sources as potatoes etc. for some Vitamin C and therefore, cooking methods employed are extremely important. Actual and potential cooks can usually be educated in this phase of their responsibilities. But the inefficient and careless type of substitute cook will disregard such measures.

RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Milk: The children (except at Qu'Appelle and Fort Frances Schools) receive \( \frac{1}{2} \) to 1 pint per day whereas \( \frac{1}{2} \) pints to 1 quart is recommended. Whenever it is possible, sufficient cows should be kept to provide at least \( \frac{1}{2} \) pints of milk per child per day. If the required number of cows cannot be kept, then it would be advisable to supplement the possible supply with whole milk powder.

2. Citrus Fruit or Tomatoes: The children receive none to 2 servings per week (except St. Mary's School - 4 servings) whereas 1 serving per day is recommended. The present budget could not possibly provide the recommended servings. Although some of the children buy oranges this procedure is no assurance for all of the children. An annual shipment of canned tomatoes, tomato juice, vitaminized apple juice or citrus fruit juice by the Dominion Department concerned would be a help. Greater expenditure on food, made possible by financial grant might also serve this need.
3. Other Fruit: One serving of other fruit, (Fresh, canned or dried) is recommended per day and received by the children (except at Elkhorn and Qu'Appelle Schools). However, the size of serving is seldom average. This is, again, the reflection of budget restrictions.

4. Potatoes: The children receive 1 to 2 servings of potatoes per day, (except at Sioux Lookout School-3 servings per week). Since potatoes are an economical source of calories, Vitamin C and other nutrients it is important to provide at least one adequate serving per day. Therefore, if sufficient potatoes cannot be grown at Sioux Lookout, additional requirements should be purchased.

5. Other Vegetables: At least two servings of other vegetables, preferably leafy, green or yellow, served frequently raw are recommended per day. The children seldom receive two servings per day, since they do not like and will not eat most vegetables. However, every attempt should be made to serve the vegetables they will eat in the most acceptable ways. And they should be gradually educated to the importance of the other vegetables.

6. Whole Grain Breakfast Cereals & Bread: One Serving of a whole grain breakfast cereal and at least four slices of Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread (whole wheat, brown or white) with butter are recommended per day. The children receive 5 to 7 servings of whole grain breakfast cereal (i.e., rolled oats) per week. In most schools they serve a refined prepared cereal 1 or 2 times a week. It is recommended that whole grain cooked or prepared (occasionally) cereal should be served every day. Canada Approved Vitamin B bread or flour wherever it is obtainable, should be used as it is a real contribution to the diet.

At the most, butter was served to the children once a day or 2 to 3 times a week. In some cases it was not served at all, because of the expense. Butter is a good daily source of Vitamin A.

7. Meat: One serving of meat, fish, poultry or meat alternates such as beans, peas, nuts, eggs, or cheese should be served daily. Eggs and cheese should be served at least three times a week and liver frequently. The children receive one serving of meat daily, but often in the case of stew the serving is very small.

Eggs are served "none" to 2 times a week. Cheese (when available) is served "none" to once a week. It should be possible to keep enough hens to have a good supply of eggs.

For growth the children should obtain the number of recommended servings per week of meat or alternate, eggs and cheese.

Liver is seldom served as the children do not like it. However, it can be cooked, ground and mixed with apple, fat and spice and they will accept it as a spread. This was done at McIntosh and Qu'Appelle schools.

8. Iodized Salt: Should be used for cooking as well as tables.

9. Cod Liver Oil is provided by the Department and should be used.
5. Nutrition Education:

An effective nutrition education programme cannot be directed to the Indians without relation to certain influencing factors. Nutrition cannot be isolated from other health aspects i.e., medical services, proper housing and sanitation.

It is known that the basic diet of the Indians consists primarily of meat, lard, sugar, flour and tea, subject to certain tribal and environmental influences, distinct likes and dislikes, etc. The children from 6 to 16 years who attend the Residential Schools, learn about and accept other foods. But at the age of 16 years they return to the reserves and revert to their original eating habits, many of which indicate that their diet is nutritionally inadequate.

The school is the most suitable medium for the introduction of nutrition education because it can and would have to be coordinated with the food served, cleanliness and meal-time atmosphere, etc. If the children are to be taught to eat certain foods for health, this should be reflected in the school meals. Otherwise, the teaching is in vain. For example: at McIntosh and Elkhorn Schools it would seem futile to teach the children to care for their teeth since they have not obtained dental services for three years.

Some incentive can be promoted at the schools but is lacking on the reserves. Continued interest, organization of groups and practical approach in the homes, seem necessary to stimulate desire to apply certain knowledge. Perhaps a system could be worked out to select and pay Indian girls showing an aptitude to carry out educational work amongst the women on the reserves.

Miss Alice McCready of the Nutrition Branch,
Department of National Health and Welfare, was in Alberta
from January 24th, to the end of February, 1947. During
this time she visited six Indian Residential Schools, viz:
Edmonton, Mt. Albert, Wabasca (2), Ermineskin (Hobbema),
and Stony.

It will be noted that her original plan to visit
the Blackfoot Schools was changed to permit her to go to
the two northern bush schools at Wabasca instead. This was
done at my suggestion.

Miss McCready recommended herself to everyone.
While a first visit of three or four days cannot be expected
to bring about any very great improvements, her knowledge and
interest made a very desirable impression. The general
impressions gained from her visit are:

(1) That at the better schools, the pupils are reasonably
adequately nourished, so far as quantity of food goes.

(2) That at no school does the variety of diet meet the
requirements in respect to Vitamin content, and that
no school principal has sufficient revenue to enable
him to provide a wholly satisfactory diet, especially
in fresh fruit or fruit juices.

(3) That some schools could do better than they are doing
with their current resources.

(4) That the goodness or badness of feeding corresponds
to the quality of management of the several schools
in other respects.

Leaving the revenue consideration aside, there
was no difference as regards location. The schools at
Wabasca were better fed than some in more favoured and
less costly places.

Detailed comment would only anticipate Miss
McCready's reports to her own Branch.
I agree with her recommendation that a school for cooks be organized in summer; suggest Libret as a suitably central place for the Prairie Provinces, and hope strongly that some senior Indian School pupils be included among the students.

The only way I can think of by which residential school feeding can be made really satisfactory is by the Department laying down scales of food issues, providing the schools with menus, carrying out effective inspection, and paying the cost of the food. This, I believe, would be welcomed by every school principal.

E. L. Stone

Report on Inspection of Food Service

Morley Indian Residential School, Morley, Alberta

February 24 to 28th, 1947.

I. Staffs

(1) Cook - 5 years at school - fairly good.

The kitchen was not completely supervised by anyone. The assistant matron assisted the cook sometimes and relieved her on off-duty days. The cook was 55 years old. She was a disorderly worker and very temperamental. As a result it would be difficult for the present matron or anyone to assume the supervision of the food service or institute changes. Since cooks have been non-available good attempts have been made to make the best of the present situation.

(2) The school girls assisted with food preparation, dishwashing, table service and cleaning duties. They carried out mostly routine jobs connected with cookery, since the present cook was unsuitable to supervise them. They work on the half-day system and rotate monthly.

II. Facilities:

The kitchen, diningroom and storeroom were located on the main floor. Working conditions were awkward and congested because the kitchen was too narrow. It is recommended that the kitchen be extended on the North side and the new kitchen plans be referred to the Nutrition Division for approval.

The diningroom space was adequate. It had been painted recently and was very attractive.

III. Storage:

The bulk food supplies storeroom was adequate. There were no facilities in or near the kitchen for proper storage of current food supplies or utensils. The refrigeration consisted merely of a 4-door reach-in refrigerator, located in a pantry adjacent to the kitchen. Due to lack of space in the kitchen, this pantry was also used (in a makeshift fashion) for vegetable preparation, utensils and improper storage of perishable goods. This space could be suitably used for the installation of a walk-in refrigerator. There were no cupboards for bread which was improperly stored in cardboard boxes.

As the structure of the root house was poor it was difficult to keep root vegetables. Suitable specifications for construction of root houses are available from the Provincial Department of Agriculture.
(2) Ventilation and Lighting:

There was no means of ventilation outside of opening windows in the kitchen. A hood with exhaust fan over the stove would remove excess heat and cooking odours. The lighting facilities were adequate.

(3) Equipment:

Flooring— Battleship linoleum in kitchen and diningroom (newly laid) - good condition.
Wooden in storeroom - good condition.

Meat Grinder— old and worn;
Hand Slicer— both should be replaced.

Kitchen Work Tables (wooden top)— small and badly warped; should be replaced.

Cooking Kettles and other Utensils— Lack of some; many worn out.
Enamel Dishes— Some replaced; many chipped.

Sink— 1 only single unit galvanized metal (in kitchen) with one small drainboard.

It would seem that, for efficient operation, a scale of equipment (large and small) should be established for the different sized schools.

III. Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions:

The kitchen and adjacent pantry were not clean and tidy due to the overcrowded conditions and the careless working habits of the cook. These conditions were made even worse by the dishes being washed in the kitchen. The diningroom and storeroom were clean and tidy.

The dishes were washed and rinsed in several dishpans. Soap was used, the dishwater was fairly hot but the method employed was unsatisfactory for 100 people. A jacket heater would be necessary to provide sufficient hot water for a proper dishwashing set-up.

The cook wore a hairnet and a coloured apron. The girls wore blue aprons but no caps or hairnets. White aprons would improve the appearance of the food handlers but this seems to be part of the clothing problem. There were no facilities in the kitchen for hand-washing. Food handling habits should be improved here.
Garbage disposal was satisfactory but wet garbage containers in the kitchen were uncovered. The water supply is not chlorinated or tested. The cattle have not been T.B. tested for approximately eight years. The milk utensils were washed in the kitchen, where there were no facilities for adequate washing and sterilizing.

IV. Food Supplies:

The produce from the school farm included milk, butter, cream and vegetables. The school farm (300 acres) is mostly rock and bush (approximately 50 acres cultivated, chiefly for garden). Since frost occurs practically every month in the year the school has found it impossible to grow potatoes, tomatoes and some seasonal vegetables. It is suggested that the school contact the Provincial Department of Agriculture or one of the Agricultural schools in the province for information on varieties suitable to the climate and soil conditions. Pigs and range cattle were sold and the full meat supply was purchased. There was no suitable hen house (hens killed by stray Indian dogs). All of the feed for the dairy herd was purchased. No fruits and vegetables were canned except small quantities for the staff due to lack of help.

Bread is purchased from Calgary. Other supplies are purchased by the Principal from wholesalers in Calgary. The freight charge is approximately 40¢/cwt, and the supplies are trucked from Morley by the school.

During the past months it has been impossible to obtain lard, cheese and dried fruits (other than prunes). It would be advisable to serve some 'standard' quality canned fruits, which are cheaper than most dried fruits.

On the basis of the average monthly food expenditure and value of farm produce the approximate food cost per person per day is thirty cents, according to our calculations.

V. Menus:

The menus were planned a week ahead of time by the cook. The children's and staff menus differed and extras were allowed for the staff. The children's menu offered fair variety and suitable attempts were made to serve foods acceptable to their likes.

VI. Nutritional Aspects:

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was evaluated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings of each important food group as recommended by Canada's Food Rules. The servings fall short in respect to milk, citrus fruit and tomatoes, other vegetables.
the use of whole wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B bread, eggs, cheese, and liver. This will reduce the intake of protein, iron and Vitamins A, B and C.

The present fresh milk supply is too low and if fresh milk supplies are unavailable powdered whole or skimmed milk should be supplemented. This was the only school visited to date where any citrus fruit was actually served as a part of the regular menu. The children in this area were very reluctant to eat vegetables or whole wheat bread. Improved hen housing facilities would be necessary to provide eggs.

| Meat and Fish | 1 serving of meat or alternates daily | 2 servings daily (one of which is small serving) |
| Also—Eggs | At least 3 times weekly | Once weekly |
| Cheese | At least 3 times weekly | None |
| Liver | Frequently | None |
| Iodized Salt | Recommended | Used occasionally for tables but not for cooking |
| Fish Liver Oil | Recommended | Given from October to April (inclusive) |

During the visit sample copies of materials, suitable for the food service and nutrition classes were discussed with the Principal and other staff concerned. Adequate quantities of the above publications have already been purchased by the schools.
After school plain bread (one slice) is served to the children. It was suggested that a piece of raw vegetable could be given too. The children frequently visit the local store at this time and purchase large quantities of refined foods (i.e., cake, cookies, etc.). An education programme to encourage the purchase of fruit would be worthwhile.

VII. Food Preparation, Cookery and Service:

The kitchen matron possessed a fair knowledge of food standards and the food quality was fairly good. Recipes were not used consistently. The working techniques were unsatisfactory.

The food was served on plates prior to the meal hour, consequently it was cold. Family service at each table would be advisable. The tables were neatly set and the food was carefully arranged on the plates. The diningroom was supervised at mealtime by a staff member. The diningroom was attractive and offered a suitable mealtime atmosphere.

Cookery and Nutrition Education:

Once a week an organized cookery class is conducted by the cook (for a few girls). But due to the lack of proper supervision the present training which the girls are receiving in cookery is of little value. A suitable cook, capable of teaching the girls, day by day, as necessary.

Nutrition education was not in effect in the classrooms.

IX. Interest:

The Principal and matron expressed interest in obtaining assistance for the food service and nutrition education.

It is known that prior to the visit at this school, the Indians complained severely about the food. From the standpoint of nutritional adequacy and the quality of the food served, the diet at this school was comparable to most and superior to some schools visited. It was evident that the newly appointed staff members were interested in the welfare of the children and have made some improvements.

X. Assistance:

During the visit sample copies of material, published by the Nutrition Division, suitable for the food service and Nutrition education were discussed with the Principal and other staff concerned. Appropriate quantities of the above publications have already been forwarded to the school.
This division is planning to send additional assistance as follows:

1. Menu Patterns (plus variations and substitutions) based on Canada's Food Rules.
2. Food Purchasing Lists adapted to menu patterns.
3. Work Schedules based on daily menus.
4. Nutrition education material suitably designed for the Indians - i.e., posters, illustrated pamphlets, and literature.

Vegetables, other than potatoes, should be included in the menus.

Use of cheese, eggs, and milk.

Use of iodized salt for cooking.

Need for food preparation and storage equipment:

(a) Refrigeration of kitchens.
(b) Installation of a dispensary with ice and refrigerator units.
(c) Installation of a milk-cooling system.
(d) Pantry for current food supplies (except for vitamin).
(e) Equipment for bread storage.
(f) Cupboards for storage of utensils.
(g) Storage of old and worn equipment, dishes, and eating utensils.
(h) Careful dress and hygiene of food handlers, thus insuring that food served is clean.
(i) Pasteurization of milk.

Need for better use of facilities, better training of pupils:

(a) Equipment - a potato peeler is needed to replace the box cutter.
(b) Ventilation - a hood with fan over the stove.
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Needed for Health:
   (a) Food - 1 pint more milk per child per day.
   Tomatoes or Citrus Fruit - 4 to 5 more servings weekly.
   Other Fruit - 1 more serving weekly.
   Vegetables, other than potatoes - at least 2 servings daily.
   Use of cheese, eggs and liver.
   Use of iodized salt for cooking and tables.

2. Needed for Food Preparation and Improved Sanitation:
   (b) Enlargement of kitchen.
   (c) Installation of a dishwashing unit (2 or 3 compartment sinks).
   (d) Installation of a walk-in refrigerator.
   (e) Pantry for current food supplies (adjacent to kitchen).
   (f) Cupboard for bread storage.
   (g) Cupboards for storage of utensils (kitchen).
   (h) Replacement of old and worn equipment, cooking and eating utensils.
   (i) Careful dress and hygiene of food handlers. (See booklet "If You Served Food").
   (j) Pasteurization of milk.

3. Needed for better use of facilities, better training of pupils:
   (k) Equipment - a potato peeler is needed to release time for better training and other duties.
   (l) Ventilation - A hood with fan over the stove.

The Director,

Miss Alice McCready of the Nutrition Branch,
Department of National Health and Welfare, was in Alberta
from January 24th, to the end of February, 1947. During
this time she visited six Indian Residential Schools, viz:
Edmonton, St. Albert, Wabasca (2), Erminskin (Robbema),
and Stony.

It will be noted that her original plan to visit
the Blackfoot Schools was changed to permit her to go to
the two northern bush schools at Wabasca instead. This was
done at my suggestion.

Miss McCready recommended herself to everyone.
While a first visit of three or four days cannot be expected
to bring about any very great improvements, her knowledge and
interest made a very desirable impression. The general
impressions gained from her visit are:

(1) That at the better schools, the pupils are reasonably
adequately nourished, so far as quantity of food goes.

(2) That at no school does the variety of diet meet the
requirements in respect to Vitamin content, and that
no school principal has sufficient revenue to enable
him to provide a wholly satisfactory diet, especially
in fresh fruit or fruit juices.

(3) That some schools could do better than they are doing
with their current resources.

(4) That the goodness or badness of feeding corresponds
to the quality of management of the several schools
in other respects.

Leaving the revenue consideration aside, there
was no difference as regards location. The schools at
Wabasca were better fed than some in more favoured and
less costly places.

Detailed comment would only anticipate Miss
McCready's reports to her own Branch.
I agree with her recommendation that a school for cooks be organized in summer, suggest Libret as a suitably central place for the Prairie Provinces, and hope strongly that some senior Indian School pupils be included among the students.

The only way I can think of by which residential school feeding can be made really satisfactory is by the department laying down scales of food issues, providing the schools with menus, carrying out effective inspection, and paying the cost of the food. This, I believe, would be welcomed by every school principal.

E. L. Stone

Report on Inspection of Food Service

Ermineskin Indian Residential School, Hobbema, Alberta.

February 19 to 23, 1947.

I. Staff:

(1) Kitchen Matron (cook) - Experienced (12 years), self-trained; middle-aged.

(2) Cook's Assistant - Experience received during past 3 years; training required; interested in cooking.

The kitchen was fully supervised by the kitchen matron. Efficient organization was impossible due to the poorly planned (old) food service set-up and inadequate facilities. The kitchen matron and cook's assistant were hard-working.

(3) The school girls assisted with food preparation and cookery, dishwashing and cleaning duties. Some of the senior girls indicated interest and ability. They might be considered for a cook's course at a later date. They work on the half-day system and rotate every month.

II. Facilities:

The kitchen was large enough but facilities were definitely inadequate. The boys' diningrooms (2) were dark, dingy, damp and unhealthy rooms in the basement. The root house was unsuitably located in the basement; other food supplies were improperly stored in one corner of root house. The walk-in refrigerator was too small and awkwardly remote from the kitchen.

The building was very old (over 50 years), antiquated and over-crowded (166 children). In view of these factors, an attempt to remodel the food service set-up would be difficult and the expense would be unjustified. Replacement of the school was indicated (this has been mentioned since the visit to Col. R. P. Neary, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, Indian Affairs Branch). The Nutrition Division would be glad to advise upon and approve plans for the food service units in a new building.

Equipment:

Coal and wood stove - good condition; inadequate (one firebox plus 3 ovens) to cook for over 200 people.

Meat Grinder - old model; satisfactory condition.

Bread Slicer - old and worn; should be replaced.
Hand Slicer—Old and worn; should be replaced.

Kitchen work tables—Metal top; very old, worn and small; should be replaced by suitable metal or wooden top tables for food preparation.

Diningroom tables and benches—Old and worn; should be replaced.

Sink—1 only single porcelain (in kitchen) with small drainboards.

Eating utensils—Enamel; many were badly chipped; should be replaced.

Provision should be made for sufficient large and small equipment in a new setup.

Attempts have been made to keep the equipment and units maintained and repaired as well as possible.

III. Sanitation and Hygiene Conditions:

The kitchen, diningroom, storage and refrigeration spaces were kept clean and tidy. This was difficult due to old and worn structures; consequently good results were not always evident.

The dishes were washed in several small dishpans in the diningrooms. Soap was not always used; the water was not hot enough and the dishes were not rinsed. Proper dishwashing facilities should be installed in a new building and recommended method used. See "Suggested Dishwashing Equipment for Indian Residential Schools" and "Suggested Dishwashing Methods for Indian Residential Schools".

The garbage disposal was satisfactory.

The water supply has been tested (not regularly). The cows are tested yearly for TB. There were no proper facilities for washing and sterilizing dairy utensils.

The food handling habits were satisfactory. It was good to see that the school girls wore white aprons and hairnets during food preparation. The girls were regularly checked for cleanliness.

IV. Supplies:

The produce from the school farm consisted of milk, pork, eggs, potatoes, other vegetables, rhubarb, berries and honey. The school farm (60 acres) has a cultivated acreage of 50 acres; consequently some 240 acres of land are rented and extra food is purchased for livestock. This is still a very small acreage for such a large school. Cattle are purchased and butchered at the school.
Last year there was no gardener at the school; an Indian was paid $4.00 per day for farm work which was not well done. Last year large quantities of wild fruits were gathered and canned by the staff. Next year the Principal intends to freeze seasonal vegetables (i.e., peas, corn, etc.) for winter months.

Bread is purchased from Wetaskiwin; other supplies are purchased from Edmonton. The rail freight charge from Edmonton to Robbena is approximately 30¢/cwt. At Robbena the supplies are picked up by the school truck.

On the basis of the average monthly food expenditure and value of farm produce, the approximate food cost per person per day is twenty-three cents, according to our calculations.

V. Menus:

The menus were planned from day to day by the kitchen matron. Variety was lacking, since large amounts of dishes were prepared for the noon meal and the left-overs were served (as such) for the evening meal. A planned weekly menu is important to ensure a balanced diet, variety and efficient organization.

Nutritional Aspects:

At this school cases of different skin disorders, scrofula, etc., were observed. Many of the children were pale, expressionless and thin, probably from inadequate preschool diets as well as poor feeding at the schools. A nutrition survey would reveal the true nutritional status of the children in this area.

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was evaluated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings of each important food group as recommended by Canada's Food Rules. The servings fall very short in respect to milk, citrus fruit or tomatoes, other vegetables, the use of whole wheat or Canada Approved white or brown bread, butter, eggs, cheese (non-available) and iodized salt. This will reduce the intake of protein and vitamins A, B and C and iodine. It was stated that fish liver oil was given to the children daily; this was not observed.

The Principal intends to purchase a percentage of whole wheat bread in future. The servings of fruit were small. Sometimes left-over cooked vegetables (from noon meal) served for the evening meals; the servings were small and the nutrient loss would be great due to the long standing period after cooking. Occasionally fresh fruit was sold (at cost) to the children who had money. A mid-afternoon lunch (slice of bread) was served daily.
