VII. Food Preparation, Cookery and Service:

The food quality was fair. Recipes were used, but not consistently. Working techniques were not always satisfactory (often due to lack of facilities). Principles of food preparation and cookery for best retention of nutrients were not well-known (i.e., vegetables prepared far ahead of time, standing for long periods after cooking, etc.). The use of noon leftovers for supper, each day, lent a great deal of repetition. It would be better to prepare and cook only the amounts of food required for dinner and...
serve supper dishes (i.e., meat or alternate and vegetables) freshly cooked and in a different way.

VIII. Cookery and Nutritional Education:

The girls assisted with food preparation and some cookery. But they carried out many routine tasks necessitated by the existent working conditions; an additional kitchen staff member (e.g., Indian girl) would help this situation.

Some nutrition education was in effect in the classrooms. Improved facilities and staff education are necessary prior to a nutrition education programme.

IX. Interests:

The Principal and staff expressed interest in the visit. The limitations of the building and farm were strongly indicated. The Principal is anxious to increase the farm production of milk, vegetables and eggs.

The District Nurse at Hobbs has made many efforts to promote good eating habits amongst the Indians. She was very interested in nutrition education and was well aware of the important foods for health. It is felt that she could offer considerable continuous assistance to this Residential School which is nearby.

The location of the school on this particular reserve was a problem and interferences by the Indians were noticeable.

X. Assistance:

During the visit sample copies of already available and relatively suitable material, for the food service and nutrition education, was discussed with the Principal, matron and cooks. Appropriate quantities have already been forwarded. This Division is planning to send additional material by way of menu patterns, recipes, food purchasing lists, work schedules, nutrition education material, etc.
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Needed for Health:
   (a) Food - Milk: ½ pint more milk per child daily.
      Tomatoes or Citrus Fruit: 7 servings weekly.
      Other Fruit: 1 serving daily.
      Vegetables Other than Potatoes: At least 2 servings daily.
      Use of Whole Wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread.
      Increased Use of Eggs, Cheese, Liver and Iodized Salt.

   (b) Pasteurisation of Milk.

2. Needed for Food Preparation and Sanitation:
   (c) A suitably designed food service set-up, in a new building,
      to include kitchen, dining-room, storage facilities, refrigeration,
      dishwashing facilities and necessary equipment
      (large and small).

   (d) Root House (outside main building).
Report on Inspection of Food Service

Edmonton Indian Residential School, Edmonton, Alberta.

January 27 to 31st, 1947.

I. Staff:

(1) Cook - position vacant at time of visit.

(2) A Cook's Assistant - fairly young - lacked experience and training in quantity cookery, but competent. She was doing a good job under the direction of the matron.

There was far too much work for one cook (approximately 140 people). The regular cook had left prior to visit (four cooks had been employed and had left since September).

(3) The School girls assisted with food preparation, cookery, dishwashing, table service and cleaning duties. There were several senior girls at this school who indicated special ability and interest in cooking. They work on the half-day system and rotate every week. A monthly rotation system would be better.

II. Facilities:

The kitchen, diningroom, storage and refrigeration spaces were adequate.

(1) Storage:

Additional shelves for supplies and a larger rack for bags of flour are required in the main storeroom.

(2) Ventilation and Lighting:

A hood with fan over the stove would help to remove excess heat and cooking odours. Otherwise, the ventilation and lighting were good.

(3) Equipments:

Mechanized equipment - hand slicer - Good condition.
Wooden top Kitchen Work Tables - one badly warped. Should be replaced.
Cooking and Eating Utensils - good condition. Many new.
Flooring - Terrazzo in kitchen, good condition. Surface of milso mastic flooring in diningroom, storeroom and vegetable preparation room was badly worn. Should be replaced.
Sink - 1 only single porcelain (in kitchen) with small drainboards.

The units and equipment appeared to have been well maintained and repaired.

III. Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions:

The kitchen, diningroom, storerooms and refrigeration units were clean and tidy. With a very worn surface, however, it was impossible to make the floor appear clean.

The method used in washing dishes was not satisfactory for 150. A suitable dishwashing unit of 2 or 3 compartment sinks instead of several dish pans could be installed in the main kitchen which offers the only available space. See paper on "Suggested Equipment for Dishwashing in Indian Residential Schools" and "Suggested Methods for Dishwashing in Indian Residential Schools".

The garbage disposal was satisfactory. The water supply has been tested. This should be done regularly. The cows have not been tested for T.B. for one or two years. They should be tested every year.

The cook wore a white cap and apron. The girls wore blue striped aprons, but no caps or hairnets. They were checked by the Matron for short hair and clean hands before commencing work in the kitchen.

IV. Food Supplies:

The produce from the school farm consisted of milk, potatoes, other vegetables and rhubarb. The school farm (600 acres) has a cultivated acreage of 400 acres. The pigs are sold and the full meat supply is purchased. Few fruits and vegetables are canned due to lack of help during summer months. Local fish, which could be used to advantage, is very expensive.

Bread and other supplies are purchased from Edmonton. The school truck picks up the supplies.

Figures were unobtainable to calculate the approximate food cost per person per day.

V. Menus:

A weekly menu pattern had been planned by the Matron.
and was suitably placed in the kitchen. The actual daily menu was based on this and decided upon by the Matron and the cook. Some extras were served to the staff, but very often their menu was similar to that of the children. The children's menu offered fair variety and the supper menu provided more food than had been observed in some schools.

VI. Nutritional Aspects:

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was evaluated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings of each important food group as recommended by Canada's Food Rules. It will be seen that the servings fall short in respect to Citrus Fruit or Tomatoes, Other Fruit, Vegetables, the use of Whole Wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread, Butter, Eggs, Cheese and the use of Iodized Salt. This will reduce the intake of protein, Vitamins A, B and C and Iodine.

Fresh fruit is sold to the children (at cost) at the school. Vegetables are served raw most often. Liver is served regularly once a week. It is the future intention to keep more hens for eggs and cattle for butchering. Also, the principal intends to purchase a percentage of Whole Wheat Bread and to use iodized salt.

VII. Food Preparation, Cookery and Service:

The food quality was fairly good. Recipes were not in use, but working techniques were satisfactory. The cook, unknowingly, applied principles for the retention of nutrients (e.g., use of vegetable water in gravy, etc.).

The food was served on plates and arranged at the tables prior to the meal hour; consequently it was cold. The introduction of family service at each table would be advisable. The diningroom was supervised at mealtime by a staff member, but the table etiquette of the children could be improved. A pleasant mealtime atmosphere was created by an attractive diningroom.

VIII. Cookery and Nutritional Education:

Once a week an organized cookery class is held, but the cook's assistant is unqualified to conduct such a class. Due to lack of staff, the girls performed many routine tasks rather than learning new work.

Nutrition education was not in effect in the classrooms. It was observed at this school that the Indian children indicated very few food dislikes (e.g., vegetables).

IX. Interest:

The Principal and staff members expressed keen interest in the visit and in obtaining assistance for the food service and nutrition education.

There was a lengthy discussion with Dr. E.L. Stone and the Principal about prospective cooks' courses. It was concluded that outstanding Indian girls should be considered as a source of cooks for training. This school had some girls that might be qualified for such a course.

X. Assistance:

REPORT ON INSPECTION OF FOOD SERVICE

CHAPLEAU INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, CHAPLEAU, ONTARIO.

JANUARY 18 TO 21, 1947.

I. Staff:

(1) Cook's position vacant, head matron acting cook.
(2) A cook's assistant— (Indian girl).

The regular cook had left prior to the visit. This school was definitely handicapped by the lack of staff. The head matron, in addition to her regular duties, supervised the kitchen and acted as cook. She had spent five years as a kitchen supervisor in the North. She was a capable organizer and aware of most of the important aspects of food service. Such a person, with added training, would be of value as a regional supervisor to spend a certain length of time (i.e., a month or more) at various schools to organize and supervise the food service.

The cook's assistant was a former graduate of the school (16 years old). She was a capable and interested girl but required further training. Since a source of cooks is a real problem it is recommended that such girls be considered for cooks' courses. These girls could do a better job at some school other than where they have attended.

The school girls assisted with food preparation, dishwashing, table service and cleaning duties. They only carried out routine jobs connected with cookery, since direction and supervision was impossible due to staff limitations. They work on the half-day system and rotate each month.

II. Facilities:

The kitchen space was adequate. The diningroom was small and further congested by tables (12' long and unnecessarily wide). By the use of smaller tables, so children could be more comfortably seated.

(1) Storage:

The main storeroom (for quarterly food supplies) was dark and dingy. It was sufficiently large but too remote from the kitchen. The shelves were narrow, unpainted and inadequate. The elevated rack for flour was too small. This room could be more
conveniently located near the kitchen (space is available). The former bakeshop (off the kitchen) could be suitably converted to a storeroom for current food supplies, or for a vegetable preparation room if sinks were installed, since the bread is now purchased. There were no ventilated cupboards for bread (stored in boxes).

The refrigeration was very inadequate and consisted merely of two small reach-in iceboxes. They were located in a room off the kitchen where a walk-in refrigerator could be installed.

(2) Ventilation and Lighting:

There was no means of ventilation other than windows in the kitchen. A hood with exhaust fan over the stove would remove excess heat and cooking odours. The electric light facilities of the kitchen and diningroom were inadequate.

(3) Equipment:

Coal and Wood Stove (new) - satisfactory
Potato Peeler - old and unserviceable, (not used) should be replaced.
Wooden Top Kitchen Sink Tables - old and worn; should be replaced.
Cooking Kettles and other utensils - were lacking; many old and worn. Additions and replacements should be made.
Diningroom Tables and Benches - old and badly worn; should be replaced.
Lack of Cupboards - in kitchen for utensils and supplies - in diningroom for dishes.
Sink - only single porcelain (in kitchen) no drainboard.
Flooring - concrete with badly worn mule stucco finish in kitchen and diningroom; should be replaced.

III. Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions:

Good attempts were made to keep the food service units clean. But due to lack of help, poor facilities and worn equipment and floors the results were not always obvious.

The dishes were washed and rinsed in dishpans in the diningroom. A poor quality powdered soap (little suds obtained) was used. This method was unsatisfactory for 90 people. A suitable dishwashing unit (2 or 3 compartment sinks) could be installed in a room adjacent to the kitchen (there is a pigeon hole from this room into the diningroom). See "Suggested..."
Dishwashing Equipment for Indian Residential Schools" and "Suggested Dishwashing Methods for Indian Residential Schools".

The garbage disposal was satisfactory.

The water supply is tested regularly. The cows are tested periodically for T.B. (this should be regularly done). There were no proper facilities for washing and sterilizing the dairy utensils.

The girls wore kerchiefs over their hair and colored aprons. The matron checked the girls for clean hands. The children were X-rayed for T.B. on entrance to the school, otherwise on request. There was no complete assurance that the food handlers did not have T.B., which, in some cases, can be transmitted through food.

There were many mice throughout the building. An exterminator should be engaged to rid the building of such pests.

IV. Food Supplies:

The produce from the school farm consisted of milk, potatoes, tomatoes, other vegetables and rhubarb. The school farm (2,000 acres) is mostly rock and bush (35 acres cultivated). Feed for cattle and poultry is purchased. The meat supply and a large part of the year's requirement of vegetables are purchased. Few fruits and vegetables are canned due to lack of staff.

Bread is purchased from Chapleau. Other supplies are purchased from Toronto (freight $1.35/cwt.) and Sudbury (freight $1.10/cwt.).

On the basis of the average monthly food expenditure and value of farm produce, the approximate food cost per person per day is twenty cents, according to our figures. This is a low figure.

V. Menus:

The menus were planned from day to day (and recorded) by the Matron. The children's and staff's menus differed, with extras allowed for the staff. The Matron had a good combination of food combinations and variety but the children's menu did not offer sufficient variety and their supper menu did not always provide enough food (which seemed to be a direct result of financial limitations).
VI. Nutritional Aspects

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was evaluated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings of each important food group as recommended by Canada's Food Rules. The servings fall very short in respect to eggs, cheese, liver, citrus fruit or tomatoes, other vegetables, the use of whole wheat or Canada Approved bread, butter and iodized salt. This will reduce the intake of protein, iron, Vitamins A, B and C and iodine.

Prior to the visit, the Church of England Residential School Commission had notified this school to supplement the fresh milk supply with powdered whole milk so that each child would receive at least one pint of milk per day. The milk consumption was still low. However, this step indicated ready willingness to increase certain foods if financially possible. Fresh fruit was sometimes sold to the children (at cost) through the school. In view of the limitations of farm production some arrangements should be made to provide the important foods.

| FOOD GROUPS | AMOUNTS RECOMMENDED BY CANADA'S FOOD RULES | AMOUNTS SERVED TO CHILDREN |
|-------------|--------------------------------------------|---------------------------|
| Milk        | 1½ pts. to 1 qt. daily                     | 1 pt. daily (½ of which is powdered) |
| Fruit: Citrus Fruit or Tomatoes | 1 serving daily | 1 serving weekly |
| Other Fruit | 1 serving daily | 1 serving daily (usually dried) |
| Vegetables: Potatoes | 1 serving daily | 1 serving daily |
| Other Vegetables | At least 2 servings daily | 1 serving daily |
| Cereals and Bread: Whole Grain cereal | 1 serving daily | 1 serving daily |
| Whole Wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread or White Bread with butter | At least 4 slices daily | At least 6 slices daily (ordinary white). No butter. |
| Meat and Fish | 1 serving of meat or alternates daily | 1 serving daily |
| Also Eggs: Cheese | At least 3 times weekly | None (non-available) |
| Liver | Frequently | None |
| Iodized Salt | Recommended | Not used for cooking or table |
| Fish Liver Oil | Recommended | Given from October to April (incl.) |
VII. Food Preparation, Cookery and Service:

The food quality was fairly good. Recipes were used and working techniques were satisfactory. Best results were not always obtained due to lack of supplies (economical factor) and insufficient help.

The food was served on plates and arranged on the tables prior to the meal hour, consequently the food was cold. The introduction of family service at each table would be advisable. The diningroom was supervised at mealtime by a staff member. The diningroom did not lend a suitable meal-time atmosphere because it was crowded and unattractive.

VIII. Cookery and Nutritional Education:

At the present time, the girls are not receiving actual training in cookery, but carry out routine tasks of preparation and cookery, due to the staff shortages, to get the necessary work done.

Prior to the introduction of Nutrition education many improvements should be made in supplies, facilities and staff.

IX. Interests:

The Principal and Matron expressed interest in obtaining assistance for the food service and nutrition education. In spite of the many handicaps faced by the staff of this school, a good coordinated effort was reflected.

X. Assistance:

During the visit sample copies of already available and relatively suitable material for the food service and nutrition education, was discussed with the Principal and other staff. This Division is planning to send additional material by way of menu patterns, food purchasing lists, work schedules, and nutrition education materials.

However, such literature will be of little or no use in Indian Residential Schools unless the limitations resulting from lack of proper staff, poor facilities and insufficient money allotment for food can in some way be remedied.
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Needed for health:
   (a) Food - 1 pint more milk per child daily
       Tomatoes or Citrus Fruits - 6 more servings weekly
       Vegetables other than potatoes - an extra serving daily
       Use of whole wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread
       Use of Eggs, Cheese, Liver and Iodized Salt.
   (b) Pasteurization of milk.

2. Needed for Food Preparation and Sanitations:
   (a) A qualified cook.
   (b) Installation of a walk-in refrigerator.
   (c) Installation of a proper dishwashing set-up (2 or 3 compartment sinks).
   (d) Replacement of wooden top kitchen work tables.
   (e) Suitable cupboards for bread storage, dishes, kitchen utensils and current food supplies.
   (f) Replacement of old and worn cooking and eating utensils (and additions).
   (g) New flooring in kitchen and diningroom.
   (h) Replacement of diningroom tables and benches.

3. Needed for better use of facilities:
   (a) Equipment - A potato peeler is needed to release time for better training and other duties.
   (b) Lighting - More ceiling fixtures and larger lights are needed in the kitchen and diningroom.
   (c) Ventilation - A hood with fan over the stove.
   (d) Consideration should be given to moving the main storeroom to available space, adjacent to the kitchen.
Report on Inspection of Food Service

Koville Indian Residential School, St. Albert, Alberta.

February 1 to 6, 1947.

This school was owned and operated by the Order of the Grey Nuns. Since 130 old people, as well as 154 Indian children, were looked after it was an entirely different set-up from other Indian Residential Schools. Although the old people occupied a separate section of the building, the environment seemed unsuitable for children.

I. Staff:

(1) Kitchen Matron (cook) - Middle-aged-experienced - fairly good cook. Spoke French only.

(2) Cooks Assistants (2) - Inexperienced and lacked training in quantity cookery.

(3) Baker - male - elderly - experienced and a good bread baker.

(4) Butcher - male.

(5) Vegetable Preparation Helper (1)

(6) Dishwasher (1)

The food preparation and cookery for the children and the old people was done by the same staff. The kitchen matron, although experienced in quantity cookery, lacked knowledge of principles of cookery for the retention of nutrients. The kitchen was well organized.

The school girls assisted with food preparation, dishwashing and cleaning duties. They work on the half-day system and rotate every week. A monthly rotation system would be better.

II. Facilities:

The kitchen, diningroom, storage and refrigeration spaces were adequate. The boys' diningroom required painting.

Ventilation and Lighting - The dark and dingy appearance of the kitchen would be improved by better electric light facilities (more windows impossible) and painting.
Equipment - Mechanized equipment:
- Electric Oven - good condition
- Vegetable Steamer - (1), new
- Steam Kettle (40 gals) - (1), new
- Steamers, Old Style - (3), old and worn
- Potato Peeler - good condition
- Mixing Machine, Old Style - (1), old and worn

Sinks - located in room adjacent to kitchen
- 2 compartment galvanized metal sink, with drainboards.
- Used for pots and pans.
- 6 compartment porcelain sinks, no drainboards. Used for vegetable preparation.

Cooking and Eating Utensils - good condition.

Flooring - Battleship linoleum flooring in kitchen was worn in some areas. The hardwood flooring in diningroom and concrete flooring in other units were in good condition.

The units and equipment appeared to have been well maintained and repaired.

III. Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions:

The kitchen, girls' diningrooms, storerooms and refrigeration units were clean and tidy. The supplies were very suitably stored. The boys' diningroom did not reflect a standard of cleanliness equal to the other units.

The dishes were washed in several small dishpans, at the tables, in the diningrooms. Although soap was used, the water was not hot enough and the dishes were not rinsed. This method was very unsatisfactory. The Principal expressed interest in the purchase of a dishwashing machine to service the whole building.

The garbage disposal was satisfactory.

The water supply is tested (due to high sodium content, it is the intention of the school to dig another well). The cows are tested yearly for T.B.

The food handling habits of the nuns were satisfactory. The other kitchen employees (female) and the school girls did not wear caps or hairnets.

IV. Supplies:

The produce from the school farm consisted of milk, beef, pork, eggs, potatoes, other vegetables and rhubarb. The school farm (1150 acres) has a cultivated acreage of 750 acres. It was stated that the farm buildings were inadequate to keep sufficient dairy herd. A percentage of the milk is sold daily.
Most of the pork is sold. A gardener was unavailable last year, consequently the year's supply of vegetables was insufficient. It was said that a large percentage of the farm produce was sold to meet overseas expenses of this institution. Available fruits and vegetables are canned.

Other supplies are purchased from Edmonton, and picked up by the school truck. It has been difficult or impossible to purchase rice, shortening or lard, raisins, canned tomatoes and beans during the past months.

On the basis of the average monthly food expenditure and value of farm produce, the approximate food cost per person per day is twenty-seven cents, according to our calculations. Separate accounts for the children and old people were not kept.

V. Menus

The menus were planned from day to day by the kitchen matron. She seemed quite aware of food combinations, variety and an adequate diet, but these factors were not always reflected in the food served.

VI. Nutritional Aspects

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was evaluated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings of each important food group as recommended by Canada's Food Rules. The servings fall short in respect to milk (for older children particularly), citrus fruit or tomatoes, other vegetables, the use of whole wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread, butter and cheese (non-available). This will reduce the intake of protein and vitamins A, B and C.

The milk consumption could be increased by discontinuing the sale of it. The Principal expressed the intention of introducing a percentage of whole wheat bread and the use of Canada Approved Vitamin B flour (if available). Fresh fruit could be sold to the children (at cost) at the school. Liver is regularly served once a week. A mid-afternoon lunch (1 slice of bread) is served.

The food quality was fairly good. There was a tendency to rely on food standards for the Indian children. Vegetables were often overcooked which would result in a high loss of nutrients. Recipes were in use and working techniques were satisfactory.

| **Fruits:** | Citrus Fruit or Tomatoes: 1 serving daily | None (except fresh tomatoes in early autumn)<br>1 serving daily |
|            | Other Fruit: 1 serving daily              |                           |
| **Vegetables:** | Potatoes: 1 serving daily | 1 serving daily |
|            | Other Vegetables: At least 2 servings daily | 10 servings weekly |
| **Cereals and Bread:** | Whole Grain Cereal: 1 serving daily | 6 servings weekly |
|            | Whole Wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Brown or White Bread with Butter: At least 4 slices daily | At least 6 slices daily (ordinary white). Butter served twice a week only. |

| **Iodized Salt** | Recommended | Used for cooking and table |

**VII. Food Preparation, Cookery and Service:**

The food quality was fair. There was a tendency to relax on food standards for the Indian children. Vegetables were often overcooked which would result in a high loss of nutrients. Recipes were in use and working techniques were satisfactory.
The food was served (cafeteria style) by the staff in the diningrooms. Family service at each table would be preferable. The girls' diningrooms were bright and attractive. The service in the boys' diningroom was careless and the meal-time atmosphere was unsuitable.

VIII. Cookery and Nutritional Education:

The girls performed mostly routine tasks in the kitchen. Since the kitchen is well-staffed the girls could receive more training in cookery. The Principal indicated the desire to set up a household unit for regular cookery classes.

Some nutrition education was in effect in the classroom, but further education of the staff is necessary for such teachings to be effective.

IX. Interest:

The Principal expressed interest in the visit but strongly indicated their present financial limitations to improve farm facilities and hire suitable help for the farm. Since the nuns receive no salary at this school, they are even more handicapped as this money is most often allocated to improvements.

X. Assistance:

During the visit sample copies of already available and relatively suitable material for the food service and nutrition education was discussed with the Principal. Appropriate quantities have already been forwarded. This Division is planning to send additional material by way of menu patterns, recipes, food purchasing lists, work schedules, nutrition education material, etc.
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Needed for Health:
   (a) Food - Milk: ½ pint more daily for young children
      ¼ to 1 pint more daily for older children
      Tomatoes or citrus fruit - 7 servings weekly
      Vegetables other than potatoes - at least 2 servings daily
      Use of whole wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B bread.
   (b) Pasteurization of milk.

2. Needed for food preparation and Sanitation:
   (a) Improved dishwashing facilities
   (b) Replacement of old steamers (3) and mixing machine.
   (c) Repair of battleship linoleum in kitchen.
   (d) Cleanliness of boys diningroom.
   (e) Painting of boys diningroom and kitchen.

3. Needed for better use of facilities:
   Improved electric light facilities in kitchen.
Report on Inspection of Food Service

St. John's Indian Residential School, Mahasso, Alberta.

February 11 to 14th, 1947.

In addition to the handicaps of isolation (100 miles by trail from Lesser Slave Lake) the staff have had to operate under very crowded and temporary quarters since the school was burned in 1945. The good attempts and coordinated efforts of the whole staff, under such circumstances, deserve special mention.

I. Staff:

(1) A cook - 1 year at this school; previously a cook in R.C.A.F. for 3 years; young, fairly capable.

The kitchen was supervised by the cook, under direction of the head matron. Efficient organization was impossible due to the poor facilities.

(2) The school girls assisted with food preparation and cookery, table service and cleaning duties. They work on the half-day system and rotate each month.

II. Facilities:

The kitchens, diningroom and storage units were temporary and unsatisfactory. There was no refrigeration unit for the storage of dairy products, leftovers, etc. In view of the intention to build a new school the Nutrition Division is willing to approve plans for the food service units.

Equipment - Large equipment was inadequate; small cooking equipment was lacking. Provision should be made for sufficient equipment (large and small) in the new school.

It was evident that attempts had been made to improve the appearance of the temporary set-up (e.g., curtains on windows in children's diningroom, painting, etc.)

III. Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions:

The diningroom was kept clean and tidy. The kitchen, because it was very small and congested, did not appear tidy. The wooden floors were unfinished and although efforts were made, they did not always appear clean.

The dishes were not properly scraped and stacked, and were washed in dishpans in the diningroom. Although soap was used, the
water was not hot enough (difficult to heat on small stove) and
the dishes were not rinsed. Proper dishwashing facilities should
be installed in the new building and recommended methods used (see
"Suggested Dishwashing Equipment for Indian Residential Schools"
and "Suggested Dishwashing Methods for Indian Residential Schools").

The garbage disposal although temporary was satisfactory.
The wet garbage containers in the kitchen should be covered.

The water for all of the buildings was hauled from the
lake every other day. This required a lot of time and was a real
hardship. The water was kept in steel barrels, which should be
covered in the kitchen. The water has been tested in the past
(not regularly tested). The school has never been tested for T.B.
In view of isolation, the Principal intends to find out if this
can be done by the school farm instructor. There were no proper
facilities for washing and sterilizing the dairy utensils.

There was no assurance that the food handlers did not
have T.B. X-rays have only been carried out when T.B. suspects
have been sent to Edmonton (head matron was concerned about one
girl at time of visit).

The cook and school girls wore aprons but no hairnets
or caps. There were no facilities for handwashing. Food handling
habits could be improved at this school (better facilities
would help).

IV. Supplies:

The produce from the school farm consisted of milk (small
amount), potatoes, other vegetables and tomatoes. The school
farm (60 acres) has a cultivated acreage of 25 acres, the remain-
der is swamp and bush. Feed for a few cattle is purchased, mostly
canned and smoked meats used (beef is seldom slaughtered). Last
year the chickens were killed by stray Indian dogs, but Principal
intends to purchase pullets this year. It was impossible to
obtain farm implements with the grant allowed for such last year.

Fish is used extensively. This year fish has been caught
as needed. This has been unsatisfactory and in the future the
Principal plans to store fish for winter months. Some wild fruits
are purchased from the Indians. Some fruits and vegetables are
canned (not large quantities due to lack of staff).

Other supplies are purchased from Edmonton. The rail
freight charge from Edmonton to Lesser Slave Lake is 40 to 50¢/cwt.
(Plus 10¢/cwt. handling charge at the warehouse). The team freight
charge from Lesser Slave Lake to Wabasso (4 to 5 days) is $1.50/
cwt. in winter and $5.00/cwt. in summer. Consequently supplies
for the year are brought in during the winter, if possible.

On the basis of the average monthly food expenditure and
value of farm produce the food cost per person per day was cal-
culated to be thirty-three cents. This is a low figure for this
area (freight expense is included).

V. Menus

The menus were planned a week in advance by the cook
and the kitchen matron. The weekly menu was suitably posted in
the kitchen. Good attempts were made to offer sufficient variety
and an adequate diet. The financial and farm limitations made
this effort difficult. The children's supper meal did not always
provide enough food. Few extras were allowed for the staff.

VI. Nutritional Aspects:

There seemed to be outstanding indications of the effects
of an inadequate diet of the preschool child, in this area. At
the school, cases of different skin diseases, scrofula, granulated
eyelids, etc., were observed. The children's appetites were poor
in comparison with other areas. The staff commented on the un-
healthy state of the children on first entry to the school and
after holidays each year. A nutrition survey would reveal the true
nutritional status of the children in this area.

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was eva-
luated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings
of each important food group recommended by Canada's Food Rules.
The servings fall very short in respect to eggs, cheese, liver,
citrus fruit or tomatoes, other vegetables, the use of whole wheat
or Canada Approved Vitamin B bread and butter.

Prior to the visit, the Church of England Residential
School Commission had supplemented the fresh milk supply with powder-
ed whole milk so that each child would receive at least one pint
of milk per day. The milk consumption was still low. But, this
step indicated ready willingness to increase certain foods if
financially possible. In view of the limitations of farm pro-
duction some arrangements should be made to provide the important
foods.

In autumn fresh tomatoes are served 2 to 3 times a week.
Dried egg powder is used for cooking only. Liver is served whenever
beef is slaughtered (seldom). A mid-morning lunch (slice of bread
with lard and jam spread) was served daily. Vegetables were served in soup often, but the amount did not constitute a serving.

| FOOD GROUPS | AMOUNTS RECOMMENDED BY CANADA'S FOOD RULES | AMOUNTS SERVED TO CHILDREN |
|-------------|--------------------------------------------|---------------------------|
| Milk       | 1½ pts. to 1 qt. daily                     | 1 pint daily (mostly powdered) |
| Fruit: Citrus Fruit or Tomatoes | 1 serving daily | None (except in early autumn 2 to 3 servings weekly) |
| Other Fruit | 1 serving daily | 1 serving daily (mostly dried) |
| Vegetables: Potatoes | 1 serving daily | 1 serving daily |
| Other Vegetables | At least 2 servings daily | 1 serving daily |
| Cereals and Bread: Whole Grain Cereal Whole Wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B Bread, brown or white, with butter | 1 serving daily | At least 6 slices daily (ordinary white). Butter not served (small amount of lard served at each meal). |
| Meat and Fish | 1 serving of meat or alternate daily | 1 serving daily |
| Eggs | At least 3 times weekly | None |
| Cheese | At least 3 times weekly | None |
| Liver | Frequently | Seldom |
| Iodized Salt | Recommended | Used for tables; but not for cooking. |
| Fish Liver Oil | Recommended | Given from October to April (inclusive) |

VII. Food Preparation, Cookery and Service:

The food quality was fairly good. Recipes were used. Working techniques were unsatisfactory (mostly due to poor working conditions). Best results were not always obtained due to lack of supplies (economical factor) and improper methods necessitated...
by poor facilities.

The food was served on plates and arranged on the tables prior to the meal hour; consequently the food was cold. The introduction of family service at each table would be advisable. The dining-room was supervised at mealtime by a staff member. The mealtime atmosphere was pleasant.

VIII. Cookery and Nutritional Education:

The girls assisted with food preparation and cookery, but the training was not effective because proper organization and supervision was impossible under the existant working conditions.

Prior to the introduction of nutrition education many improvements should be made by way of increased supplies and better facilities.

IX. Interest:

The Principal and staff expressed keen interest in the visit. Many worthwhile questions about food and nutrition were asked. The Principal wondered if Canada Approved Vitamin B flour could be contracted for by the Church of England Residential School Commission. Also, he was anxious to obtain information on the use of dried eggs and powdered milk (this will be forwarded by the Nutrition Division).

X. Assistance:

Sample copies of already available posters, pamphlets, etc., were not taken to Wabasso, as it was previously thought that such material would be unsuitable for such isolated schools. It was realized, later, that this material could be used. The use of the publications was explained and appropriate quantities have already been forwarded. This Division is planning to send additional material by way of menu patterns, recipes, food purchasing lists, work schedules, nutrition education material, etc.
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS

1. Needed for Health:

(a) Food - Milk: 1 pint more milk (fresh or powdered) per child daily
   Tomatoes or Citrus Fruit: 7 servings weekly
   Other Vegetables: At least 2 servings daily.
   Use of whole Wheat or Canada Approved Vitamin B flour
   Increased use of eggs (fresh or dried), cheese, liver
   (whenever possible) and iodized salt.

(b) Regular T.B. testing of cows; Pasteurization of milk.

(c) Assurance that food handlers are free from T.B.

(d) Careful dress and personal hygiene of food handlers. See booklet "If You Serve Food".

2. Needed for Food Preparation and Sanitation:

A suitably designed food service set-up in the new building, to include kitchen, diningroom, storage facilities, refrigeration, dishwashing facilities and necessary equipment (large and small).
Report on Inspection of Food Service

Wabasecon Roman Catholic Indian Residential School, Wabasecon, Alta.

February 7 to 10, 1947.

This school was owned and operated by the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Ground. In spite of the handicaps of isolation (100 miles by trail from Lesser Slave Lake) many worthwhile improvements have been made and the whole staff deserves recognition for their efforts. No salaries are received by the Missionary staff.

I. Staff:

(1) Kitchen Matron (cook) - 5 years at the school - Experienced, capable and efficient.

(2) Bread Baker - previously cooked for 20 years - good bread baker; as well, she made butter and looked after the chickens.

(3) Cook's Assistant - 2½ years at school. She has received training under direction of the kitchen matron.

(4) Indian Girls (5) - employed as Assistants; rotate between kitchen and bakery. They indicated interest and ability. Further training is necessary and these girls might be considered for a cooks' course. The kitchen was well organized under the good supervision of the kitchen matron.

(5) The school girls assisted with vegetable preparation, dishwashing and cleaning duties. They work on the half day system and rotate every month.

II. Facilities:

The kitchen, dining room and storage (warehouse outside and storeroom inside) spaces were adequate. A new root house had been built last autumn.

(a) Refrigeration:

Although there was an ice house and fish house outside, dairy products and left-overs were unsuitably stored in an unrefrigerated room. This space could be made into a walk-in refrigerator.

(b) Ventilation and Lighting:

Cross ventilation (windows) was possible in the kitchen, but excess cooking odours remained. A fan could be installed in a window recess, but with the present arrangement of furnace pipes it would be impossible to install a hood and fan over the stove. An electric generator had been installed; the lighting facilities were satisfactory.

(c) Equipments:

Mechanized Equipment - Cooking Machine. Cooking and Eating Utensils - good condition. Flooring - Wooden in all units; good condition. Sink - 1 only single porcelain (in kitchens) with galvanized metal drainboards.

The units and equipment have been well maintained and repaired.
III. Sanitation and Hygienic Conditions

The kitchen, dining-rooms and storeroom were clean and tidy.

The dishes were washed in several small dishpans at the tables, in the dining-rooms. Soap was not used; the water was not hot enough and the dishes were not rinsed. This method was very unsatisfactory. A suitable dishwashing unit (2 or 3 compartment sinks) could be installed in the main kitchen. Dumb waiters serviced the dining-rooms (second floor) from the kitchen (first floor).

The garbage disposal was satisfactory. The water supply has been tested (not regularly). The cows have never been tested for T.B.

There was no assurance that the food handlers did not have T.B. X-Rays have only been carried out when T.B. suspects have been sent to Edmonton.

The food handling habits of the nuns were satisfactory. The girls wore dark blue aprons but no caps or hair nets. They were checked frequently by the kitchen matron for short hair and clean hands.

IV. (a) Supplies

The produce from the school farm consisted of milk, butter, beef, pork, eggs, flour (milled), potatoes, other vegetables, tomatoes, berries and rhubarb. The farm has a cultivated average of 175 acres (some land broken recently). The Principal stated that if a milking machine could be obtained, a larger dairy herd could be kept.

Fish is used extensively. Indian help is hired to fish from November to January, for the winter months (approx. 15,000 lbs. frozen). Wild fruits are gathered by the staff. Large quantities of fruits and vegetables are canned. A great deal of ingenuity was exercised by the staff to make the maximum use of all local supplies, (e.g., green onion tops stored in brine for seasoning, pumpkin used for jam, etc.).

Other supplies are purchased from Edmonton. The rail freight charge from Edmonton to Lesser Slave Lake is 40 to 50¢/cwt (plus 10¢/cwt handling charge at the ware house). The team freight charge from Lesser Slave Lake to Wabasca (4 to 5 days) is $1.50/cwt in Winter and $5.00/cwt in Summer. Consequently supplies for the year are brought in during the winter if possible.

On the basis of the average monthly food expenditure and value of farm produce the food cost per person per day was calculated to be sixty to seventy cents. This is a high figure (freight and some overhead expenses are included).

V. Menus

The menus were planned 4 to 6 days in advance by the kitchen matron.
VI. Nutritional Aspects

There seemed to be outstanding indications of the effects of an inadequate diet of the pre-school child in this area. At the school, cases of different skin diseases, sore lips, granulated eye lids etc., were observed. The children's appetites were poor in comparison with other areas. Many were given rest periods and mid meal feedings. The staff commented on the unhealthy state of the children on first entry to the school and after holidays each year. A nutrition survey would reveal the true nutritional status of the children in the area.

The nutritional adequacy of the children's diet was evaluated by comparison with the number of daily and weekly servings of each important food group as recommended by Canada's Food Rules. The servings fall short in respect to citrus fruit or tomatoes, other fruits, the use of whole wheat or Canada Approved vitamin B Bread, butter and cheese. The milk consumption was somewhat low. This may reduce the intake of vitamin A, B and C.

In Autumn fresh tomatoes are served daily. In the past, fruit jam or jelly has been served as fruit, but it does not provide sufficient fruit to constitute a serving. Raw vegetables is served daily at recess period. A sample of the flour milled at the school was brought back for vitamin B assay since 75% of this flour to 85% ordinary white flour is used regularly for bread. Cottage cheese is served often during autumn and spring. The Principal stated that attempts have been made to increase the variety of foods served to children. This was obvious. Previous to this principal's appointment, fish was served twice a day but now due to increased farm production meat is served frequently.

VII. Food Preparations, Cookery and Service:

The food quality was good. Recipes were used and working techniques were very satisfactory. Principles for the retention of nutrients were applied in the preparation and cookery methods.

The food was served (cafeteria style) by the staff in the dining-rooms. Family service at each table would be preferable. The dining-rooms were bright and the meal time atmosphere was pleasant.

VIII. Cookery and Nutritional Education:

Weekly organized cookery classes are held. The girls record and keep (for future use) basic recipes. This is a good idea and could be introduced at other schools. However, the girls should assist with more food preparation and cookery, day by day, since the kitchen is well-staffed.

Some nutrition education was in effect in the classrooms. The booklet "Your Food and Health in the North" was used. The staff expressed the difficulty of teaching the children the important foods for health. They want to know "why" and yet cannot conceive nutrients. This emphasized the need for especially designed posters etc.

IX. Interest:

The principal and staff expressed keen interest in the visit. Many worthwhile questions about food and nutrition were asked. The concern for the health of the children was reflected by other measures (e.g., organized physical training classes, steam baths etc.)

X. Assistance:

Sample copies of already available posters, pamphlets etc., were not taken to Wahasee, as it was previously thought that such material would be unsuitable for such isolated schools. It was realized, later, that this material could be used. The use of the publications was explained and appropriate quantities have already been forwarded. This Division is planning to send additional material by way of menu patterns, recipes, food purchasing lists, work schedules, nutrition education material etc.

1. Needed for Health:

       Use of whole wheat or Canada Approved vitamin B flour (if assay
       of vitamin B content of flour milled at school does not show com-
       parable value),
       Increased use of cheese.
   (b) Regular T.B. testing of cows; Pasteurisation of milk.

2. Needed for food preparation and sanitation:
   (a) Improved dishwashing facilities
   (b) Installation of a walk-in refrigerator.

3. Needed for better use of facilities:
   (a) Equipment - potato peeler
       bread mixer
       meat grinder
       slicing machine
       To release time for training

Dear Mr. Neary:

Thank you for your letter of March 17th concerning Miss McCready's recent visit in Alberta. I am returning herewith the copy of a letter signed by Dr. Stone which was inadvertently enclosed with your letter.

In order that plans may be brought forward rapidly, I would like to suggest that we have a meeting with Dr. Moore concerning a summer course for cooks, around the 15th April, if this would be convenient. Since I shall be away next week, would you be kind enough to enquire from Dr. Moore what time would suit him and set a date during that week in April. You could then notify my office for my information as soon as I return.

I should like to bring to this meeting Miss Margaret Leck who would take charge of such a cook's course.

In view of the interest in the Prairie Provinces, I think that serious consideration should be given to Dr. Stone's suggestion that a course be held in Edmonton. We would suggest a one-week course, beginning with registration on a Wednesday of a week-end ending on a Friday, confined to cooks or assistant cooks. Not more than 30 should be enrolled for this course and every precaution should be taken to assure their attendance.

Immediately following this week's course, one or two of the cooks would be invited to study an additional week and we would hold a special course for Indian girls from the same school, on how to be useful in the kitchen.

Dr. P.E. Moore, Director, Indian Health Services.
My proposal is that next winter would then be devoted to concentrating our attention on the 15 or 20 schools represented by the students attending these two courses. When finished this short amount of basic instruction, they should be in a position to follow the menus, recipes and other advice that we would like to have represented in a completely coordinated manner by late September. I believe that this procedure will be much better than attempting to send menus and recipes to all the residential schools, since we will not only be training the cooks, but will be able to follow through with all the advice that they need next winter. If this procedure proves effective, we might continue our cook's courses over a longer period of time next summer according to the number of pupils you could guarantee.

May I repeat what has been said before that a system must be available for paying these cooks their transportation and their room and board while attending the course and the registration must be adhered to fairly strictly. It is no use putting on a course for five or six students, nor yet is it possible to give suitable training to a group of thirty.

Sir:

Miss Alice McCready has finished her second visit to residential schools in Alberta. It is hard to judge from one visit to each school, but reports indicate that she has made an excellent personal impression and that the school authorities are receptive to the service she represents.

Re: Dietary Service and Visits of Miss McCready

The Regional Medical Superintendent, Dr. Stone, in his letter of the 29th ultimo has stated that Miss McCready's visits were undoubtedly beneficial to the services, and that she made an excellent impression everywhere.

This has stimulated an interest in dietary, and there should be a good representation from the province at the cooking school which will be held in July. Special endeavours are being made by our agents to have young Indian girls attend it.

As to the future, Dr. Stone has recommended that a nutritionist be assigned to duty over such an area as to provide one annual visit to each of the 19 residential schools in this province. That appears to be a move in the right direction, but it is doubted if it would require the full time services of a dietitian. It is our contention that the visits must be confined to a very short stay, when local problems are discussed, and suggestions, if any, made for improvements. Should the nutritionist intend to stay for some weeks at an institution, the impression would certainly be given that this party intended to take over certain duties; this could cause dissatisfaction and unpleasantness. The principals of all schools will welcome advice, but they will not welcome the presence of somebody who intends to run their show.

I guess we should let Dr. Pett know - you can send him my copy if you want.
Thank you very much for sending me with your letter of June 6th a copy of a letter from Mr. Gooderham, Inspector of Indian Agencies in Alberta.

I note the suggestion of Dr. Stone which meets with some favour by Mr. Gooderham that every one of the 19 residential schools in the Province should receive an annual visit. Mr. Gooderham has interpreted this as meaning someone stationed in the Province who would be able to spend some time at each school and he does not view this with much favour. I would agree with him that it would be a difficult job.

The idea of a travelling dietitian staying a few days or up to a week in an institution is developing in other fields, for example, small hospitals. I am quite sure that when suitable personnel can be obtained some of the Provincial Health Departments will find it advantageous to establish several such positions in their Provinces so as to supervise more adequately the food service in various small hospitals that could not employ a dietitian. From our preliminary studies in this matter on behalf of various Provinces, it would appear that a supervising dietitian actually responsible for such work could not operate on more than about five institutions. Such a person would be, of course, in charge of menu planning, buying, and cost accounting of foods. This is a possible hope for small hospitals, but appears to me to be out of the question for Indian residential schools. So far as we are concerned, the present inspections of residential schools are for the dual purpose of finding out whether further trained supervision and assistance can profitably be used by these schools under their present operation and whether the present operation of food services can be used to improve the education and training being given in the schools. In other words, it is more of an inspection service than a continuing supervisory service at the present time. I am not yet prepared to say whether the general set-up is suitable to take proper advantage of the service that we can provide in this respect. One of our earliest observations was the lack of training by cooks and we are attempting to correct that this summer and will evaluate the success of that phase of our work by further contacts with these cooks next winter. This is, however, only one aspect of many that...
are in need of correction before our inspection report can be completed, and certainly before I could recommend a continuous supervisory service being established regionally.

In other words, we are trying to see what good actually can be done under present circumstances and any improved circumstances that we can reasonably achieve in a short time such as training cooks or getting better equipment in schools.

If a travelling dietitian can be recommended for various regions stationed in those regions, I believe that such a service would have to be financed and administered by some branch of Indian Affairs and not by us. In view of the dual nature of the problem, that is the health aspect, plus the educational aspect, I would not venture to say exactly how this staff of dietitians should be administered. If desired, we could continue to act in a somewhat independent manner as inspectors of what was being achieved in this regard by making a visit somewhat similar to those now being made and by maintaining a service in regard to preparation of materials uniform for all regions. This is obviously a matter for some time in the future.

L. B. Pett, Ph.D., M.D.,
Chief, Nutrition Division.

Section 47 (1) (d) of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, 1931, directs that the Auditor General shall, from time to time, examine the accounts and records in respect to equipment, supplies, provisions or stores the property of His Majesty and, by such tests as he may deem necessary, satisfy himself that such accounts are in order.

The second column should be headed "Total Receipts-1935". There should be included under this item whatever articles have been obtained and paid for by the Department between the period April 1st, 1934, and March 31st, 1935.

The third column should read "Total Issues - 1935". Included under this heading will be the articles of government property, if any, which have become useless during the period April 1st, 1934, to March 31st, 1935.

Section 47 (1) (d) of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, 1931, directs that the Auditor General shall, from time to time, examine the accounts and records in respect to equipment, supplies, provisions or stores the property of His Majesty and, by such tests as he may deem necessary, satisfy himself that such accounts are in order.

Pursuant to this provision of the Act, I have to request that you supply me, not later than June 30th, next, with a complete inventory of all government property at your school. The necessary forms for this purpose are enclosed, and you should list on these forms all the property owned by this Department. It is not necessary to make any mention of food or clothing or other articles owned by the school management.

Three copies of the Inventory should be prepared - two copies should be returned to the Department and one copy retained at the school.

The form which we are using this year is the same as used by the Indian Agent, consequently, where the word "Agency" appears, you should place the name of your school. Page 18 - the Recapitulation - should be completed insofar as it affects your school and you should sign at the bottom of this page.

You will remember that, last year, you prepared and forwarded to the Department an inventory of the government property on hand in your school. You retained a copy of this and, in preparing this year's Inventory, you should use last year's as a basis.

For instance, the first column should be headed "On hand 1st April, 1934". The figures for this column should be obtained from the inventory that you prepared last year.

The second column should be headed "Total Receipts - 1935". There should be included under this item whatever articles have been obtained and paid for by the Department between the period April 1st, 1934, and March 31st, 1935.

The third column should read "Total Issues - 1935". Included under this heading will be the articles of government property, if any, which have become useless during the period April 1st, 1934, to March 31st, 1935.

The Department trusts that you will follow the instructions contained in this letter and give every possible attention to the preparation of this Inventory, in order that it may meet the requirements of the Auditor General.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Re: - Government Property.

The Auditor General has written the Department requesting the inventories of stores and equipment on hand in the various Indian residential schools. You have been forwarded three copies of the necessary form for this purpose - two copies should be completed and returned to the Department at the earliest possible date and one copy retained at the school.

Only Government property should be recorded on this inventory. It is not necessary to make any mention of Food or Clothing or other articles owned by the school management.

As it is desired to place these inventories on a calendar year basis, the inventory you are now completing should cover the period April 1, 1935, to December 31, 1935.

The first column on the inventory should be headed "On hand April 1, 1935". The information for this column can be obtained from the copy of last year's inventory which you have on file.

The second column should be headed "Total Receipts". In this column should be included any articles which have been obtained and paid for by the Department between the period April 1, 1935, and December 31, 1935.

The third column should read "Total Issues". Under this heading will be listed the articles of Government property, if any, which have become useless during the period April 1, 1935, to December 31, 1935.

The total value should be recorded at the end of the inventory for each group opposite the word "Total". Where an individual group covers more than one page, the total should be carried forward from page to page to the end of the inventory for that particular group.

It is important that the name of the school should be written on the top of each page of the inventory.

RECAPITULATION:

(c) The total value of Articles "In Use" and "In Store" for each group should be extended to the outside columns headed "Total Value".

(d) The "Recapitulation" sheet should be totalled to show the "Grand Total" for the school and certified correct by the Principal.

A. F. MacKenzie,

Ottawa, November 15th, 1937.

To Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

RE: Government Property

Enclosed are four copies of a form used for inventory of Government property on hand at Indian residential schools. Three copies of this form should be completed at the earliest possible date and returned to the Department. One copy should be retained at the school.

You will note that the form covers the Government property on hand on December 31st. Consequently, the inventory you are now requested to complete covers the period January 1st to December 31st, 1937. The first column should, therefore, be completed "on hand Jan. 1st, 1938" and the last column should be completed as "on hand 31st Dec., 1937".

It is important that the name of the school should be written on the top of each page of the inventory. You should, also, note that, in preparing the inventory, only the articles and property owned by the Department should be recorded. It is not necessary to make any mention of food, clothing or other articles in the school that have been purchased and are owned by the school management.

It is expected that the three copies of this form will be properly completed and returned to the Department promptly.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.
Lejac Indian Residential School
Under Direction of The Oblate Fathers
LEJAC, B.C.

Nov. 23, 1937

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Department,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Some weeks ago we received inventory forms dealing with Government property at Lejac Indian Residential School.

Last year when we filled in the same forms considerable discussion took place as to what should be included in this inventory. The difficulty arises from the fact that much of our property is purchased out of the per capita Grant or from profits accruing from farm operations or, in the case of animals, from the natural increase.

Some contend that all these things should be listed as Government property, others contend that only such articles as have been purchased directly by the Indian Department should be included.

I will be glad therefore if you would give me definite directions on this question.

Yours truly,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.

Circular Memorandum.- All Directors

Inventory at Annual Stocktaking,
December 31st, 1938

Regarding the usual annual inventory required by
the Auditor General, showing all departmental equipment, supplies,
provisions and stores on hand on the 31st instant, I am enclosing
several copies of his Circular No. 5, 1938.

The following should be brought to the attention
of the various branch and division officers whose duty it is to
check the equipment and prepare the inventory:

1. The return should be submitted on form h01 -
Property Return - copies of which may be obtained on
requisition in the usual way from the Departmental
Stationery Office, Vimy Building, Ottawa.

2. Each branch return is to be completed and
submitted, with a properly certified branch summary,
showing the equipment, value, etc., for the Branch
Head Office, and its various Divisions, Services, etc.,
if any. The Branch return should reach this office
before March 31st, 1939, in order that it may then
be included in the Departmental Reappraisal.

3. The inventory should include all typewriters,
adding machines and other office appliances, and only
such stationery supplies as are in excess of six months'
requirements.

4. All sales or transfers of government-owned
equipment will be reported in Column 6 of the inventory
form - No.h01 - with a notation in the Remarks Column
as to the Salvage Minute number authorizing the sale.
5. Articles considered as worn-out, obsolete, or unserviceable, will continue to be reported in the inventory until authority is given by this office to write-off the article in the branch inventory.

6. Test audits have revealed that there are often numerous discrepancies between the branch records, the inventory, and the stores and equipment actually on hand. Steps should be taken to ensure that the inventory includes all government-purchased equipment in possession of the branch.

7. Any equipment properly authorized to be loaned to other Federal Departments, individuals, etc., should be so reported, with the date of loan, in the Remarks Column of Form 401, together with information as to the present location of any articles not actually in the place covered by the inventory. Receipts for all issues, loans, etc., as well as storage receipts, should be readily available.

8. Equipment, stores, etc., surplus to requirements should be shown in the Remarks Column. No surplus stores will be transferred without the concurrence of the Director, etc., concerned.

9. Furniture, etc., supplied by the Department of Public Works should not be included in the inventory for the Auditor General.

10. Buildings, whether or not erected by the Department of Public Works, should not be included in the inventory, which is primarily for stores and equipment.

Deputy Minister.

OFFICE OF THE AUDITOR GENERAL

Ottawa, Canada. November 10, 1938.

Circular No. 5 - 1938

Dear Sir:

Re: Inventory at Annual Stocktaking.

Pursuant to Section 47 of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, please supply me, not later than March 31st next, with a complete inventory of equipment, supplies, provisions or stores, the property of His Majesty, under the control of your department, as at the 31st of December, 1938.

The inventory should include stationery supplies, travelling accessories such as trunks, bags, cases, etc., and motor vehicles. The actual cost of each item of stores and equipment on hand should be given but, where such information cannot readily be obtained, the estimated value should be stated. In either case, the inventory should be prepared to show the total value of such property on hand.

As the policy of the Government, respecting the value of public property in general, is not to consider depreciation, I suggest that property values, once established, either on a cost or an estimated value basis, should be maintained unchanged in your records from year to year until such property is finally disposed of, subject to any modifications as a result of separations, additions or betterments.

The inventory should be signed by the officer directly responsible for the property listed therein, certified by the senior official of the district concerned, and also by the head office official charged with the administration of the property. A general departmental recapitulation should be prepared showing the total value of the stores and equipment maintained at the various locations. This recapitulation should be certified correct by the official by whom it is compiled and approved by the deputy head of the department. The official title of each officer signing should be given.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Geo. Gonthier
Auditor General.

The Deputy Minister,
Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

CIRCULAR MEMORANDUM

Inventory at annual Stocktaking,
December 31st, 1939.

Regarding the annual inventory of all Departmental equipment, supplies, provisions, and stores on hand as at December 31st, only one copy of this inventory for the past year should be furnished this office. As usual adequate stores and equipment accounting records are to be maintained in all Departmental offices and made readily available for examination, as may be deemed necessary from time to time, by officers of the Auditor General's Department. If it is found that the Branch inventory as submitted for 1939, represents an accurate account of all Departmental equipment on charge to, and in possession of the Branch or Division thereof, arrangements may be made during 1940 when the last inventory has been checked by the Administrative Branch that in such cases only a supplementary return of equipment, etc., received and disposed of during the year may be furnished for the year ending December 31st, 1940.

In preparing the inventory for the past year it is thought that the following points might again be emphasized so that further steps may be taken in arranging for uniformity in the preparation of the inventory.

1. The return should be submitted on form 401 - Property Return - copies of which may be obtained on requisition in the usual way from the Departmental Stationery Office, Vimy Building, Ottawa.

2. Each Branch return is to be completed and submitted, with a properly certified Branch summary, showing the equipment, value, etc., for the Branch Head Office, and its various Divisions, Services, etc., if any. The Branch return should reach this office before March 31st, 1940, in order that it may then be included in the Departmental Recapitulation.
3. The inventory should include all typewriters adding machines and other office appliances, and only such stationery supplies as are in excess of six months' requirements. The serial numbers of all typewriters etc., should be furnished in the inventory.

4. All sales or transfers of government-owned equipment will be reported in Column 6 of the inventory form - No. 401 - with a notation in the Remarks Column as to the Salvage Minute number authorizing the sale.

5. Articles considered as worn-out, obsolete, or unserviceable, will continue to be reported in the inventory until authority is given by this office to write-off the article in the branch inventory.

6. In the past test audits have revealed that there are often numerous discrepancies between the branch records, the inventory, and the stores and equipment actually on hand. Steps should be taken to ensure that the inventory includes all government-purchased equipment in possession of the branch. It is assumed that wherever possible a physical check will be made of the equipment on hand at the close of the year.

7. Any equipment properly authorized to be loaned to other Federal Departments, individuals, etc., should be so reported, with the date of loan, in the Remarks Column of Form 401, together with information as to the present location of any articles not actually in the place covered by the inventory. Receipts for all issues, loans, etc., as well as storage receipts, should be readily available.

8. Equipment, stores, etc., surplus to requirements should be so shown in the Remarks Column. No surplus stores will be transferred without the concurrence of the Director, etc., concerned.

9. Furniture, etc., supplied by the Department of Public Works need not be reported to this office this year, but each Branch should maintain a record of furniture in its possession.

10. Buildings, whether or not erected by the Department of Public Works, should not be included in the inventory, which is primarily for stores and equipment.

Deputy Minister.
January 24th, 1940.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill,
Indian Affairs.

Re: Inventory at Annual Stocktaking.

Reference is made to your memorandum of the 4th instant, your file 150-50, relative to the Kelvinator refrigeration unit at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario. It is noted that, as you consider this unit is a permanent fixture in the school, there is no reason why it should be included in the inventory as you do not include the heating plant or similar permanent furnishings.

I understand that, prior to the passing of the Consolidated and Revenue Audit Act, your Branch furnished the Auditor General with statements of supplies on hand in the various Agencies, Schools, etc., as at March 31st. However, subsequent to the passing of the Act, Departments were required to furnish complete inventories of all Government-owned equipment, supplies and material in their possession. You will note the requirements in the Auditor General's circular letter on this subject, forwarded about November of each year, and embodied in recent years in the Deputy Minister's circular memorandum relative to inventories. The various Branches of the Department are now required to submit an inventory which includes all non-expendable Government-owned property. This might be defined as including all articles such as agricultural implements and farm machinery, automobiles and accessories, transport equipment (including wagons, horses, boats, outboard motors), camp equipment (bedding, cots, tents, tarpaulins) surveying and drafting instruments, tools and fire-fighting etc., equipment and under miscellaneous - trunks, travelling accessories, office appliances such as typewriters, adding machines, etc.

The items to be included in the inventory might be classified as those which may be used continuously and which do not enter into the construction of some structure, etc.; articles of food which are consumed soon after purchase; and lumber, hardware, etc., which are used in the construction of a building or other structure, would not come within the category of non-expendable property. Articles of comparatively small value, the length of service of which is usually short and which require replacement frequently are termed 'expendable' property.
By referring to the Auditor General's letter of August 28th, 1932, 'non-expendable' property was generally outlined. In the Deputy Minister's circular memorandum of December 6th, 1936, furniture, etc., supplied by the Department of Public Works need not be included in the inventory which was primarily for stores and equipment. However, where Branches had rendered this information and required it for their records, it might still be submitted.

It would, therefore, seem that such items as the Kelvinator refrigeration unit should be included in your Branch inventory. By referring to the 1938 inventory of the Residential Schools at Alert Bay, B.C., you will note that such units are now reported, so that there seems to be some lack of uniformity in the preparation of the inventories.

May I be advised please if the information contained in the Deputy Minister's circular memoranda forwarded to you annually before the close of the year respecting the inventory to be prepared at annual stocktaking, is transmitted to all Indian Agencies, Residential Schools and Hospitals. I would also ask that you advise me what steps are taken by your Inspectors to see that equipment is duly reported in the inventory submitted by the Agency, etc. Are complete physical checks, or test checks made from time to time? The return of each of the Divisions is certified to by the Head of the Division. In so doing no doubt some internal check is made by the Division to ensure that all non-expendable equipment is duly reported.

C.W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.
Ottawa, January 29, 1940.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Inventory, government-owned property at Indian Residential Schools.

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Jackson's memorandum of January 24, in which additional information is sought with respect to the procedure followed by this Branch in securing inventories of government property at Indian residential schools.

It is noted that in the penultimate paragraph of this memorandum the view is expressed that large refrigeration storage rooms such as the storage room at Kenora should be included in the inventory. The officials here can see no serious objection to including such equipment, provided that such is your desire. The last paragraph of the memorandum, however, seems to be based on the assumption that Indian agents and Indian inspectors are in close touch with all our Indian residential schools and consequently in a position to make a check of the equipment reported in the inventories requested by the Department from year to year. May I point out that a large number of our Indian residential schools are not now, nor have they been at any time, attached to Indian agencies and consequently do not come under the direct or even indirect supervision of Indian agents and Indian inspectors. Despite this fact, however, we are extremely anxious to have this annual inventory as satisfactory and as exact as possible. It has occurred -
occurred to me the best ways and means of securing a worthwhile inventory might be discussed by the officials of this Branch and any officials you may care to select, at a conference called for this purpose.

The information contained in your circular memorandum relating to the taking of the annual inventory is, together with a printed form and a letter of instructions, sent out from year to year to our Indian agents, principals of residential schools and superintendents of hospitals.
