DEPARTMENT OF MINES & RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH
CANADA

Ottawa, January 15, 1937.

I regret that the limited time at my disposal has not enabled me to write in a personal or introductory sense, until now, to the teachers in charge of our Indian schools.

I have had an opportunity to make a brief study of inspectors' and other departmental reports relating to the welfare of our Indian population and relating particularly to the work accomplished in our schools. This study has convinced me that the teachers in charge of our institutions have rendered, and are still rendering, conscientious and devoted service. Missionary zeal and the spirit of self-sacrifice have been very much in evidence.

I can state that the reorganization of the Department does not necessarily mean a drastic change in educational policy. If changes are found to be necessary from time to time, these changes will be worked out in cooperation with representatives of the churches and with their approval.

My personal opinion is that in our educational programme provision should be made for a course of study that would enable the pupils to spend at least one third of their time at manual training or vocational instruction. The general public have an impression that the instruction given in our Indian schools is altogether too abstract and academic. They feel that there should be a more direct relationship between this instruction and the tasks that confront the pupil after his departure from school. This criticism, I feel, applies with equal force to the instruction provided for our white children throughout the Dominion.

I am deeply interested, also, in a "follow-up System". I mean by this a systematic method of supplying the Department, from year to year, with information that will enable us to know exactly what becomes of our pupils after they leave school. This work should be undertaken at once by the principals of our residential schools and by the teachers in charge of our day schools. We shall welcome any suggestions as to how this work can be simply and effectively accomplished.

I have been placed in my present position to help and encourage you. I am anxious to do this, in cooperation with the officials here, to the best of my ability. I want you to feel perfectly free to communicate with me at any time. I feel confident our relationships are going to be cordial and helpful throughout the period that may lie ahead of us.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.
Hon. P. A. Hoey
Ottawa

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I thank you for the kind and encouraging message you have sent to me. It's a great comfort for a principal to know that he will be listened to with a sympathetic understanding.

In regard to the manual training you mention in your letter, I am anxious to give it as much and as early as I can. The smallest boys receive it and those in grades 6, 7, 8 are half-day workers i.e., that half the day is spent in class and half in manual work. This is further regulated by the rule that they go to class in the morning and then go to class in the afternoon. They are trained...
in farming, pottery, carpentry work, shoe making, tailoring, kitchen work and the mechanical work connected with running the light and water system of the schools.

In order to meet with your desire of a "Follow-up System", I shall keep a record of our ex-pupils' occupations. Unfortunately our ex-pupils have still to face the problem of unemployment.

I am most anxious to cooperate with the Department in the good work done for the Indians in our country.

Dear Sir,

My appreciation of the circular letter of above date and number, and your mention in the last paragraph of your desire for freedom and confidence, prompts me to remark on one or two of the suggestions (if they have not gone beyond that stage).

Does it imply that the Manual or Vocational instruction would be given at each I.R. EDUCATION

Integration with community life - During the past year a strong effort has been made to integrate Indian education more deeply with the actual living experiences and the environment of Indian children. With increased emphasis on community life, the school is becoming more and more the focal point for community interests and activities. No longer are classes held for the school children alone. The basic new is that of a parent-child cooperative program.

The school or community shop is becoming a popular place for the men to repair their tools; men and women come in to the school to sew, to bathe and wash their hair and clothes, for help on house problems, to attend clinics, and, in some cases, at night to learn to read and write. Nursery schools have been established in a number of the older boarding schools. Child care is part of every older girl's training.

Parents contribute a wealth of information on spinning, weaving, and dyeing materials, in curing foods, and in making pottery, basketry, and leather goods, in conjunction with the general curriculum which is being encouraged in all of the Indian schools and communities. An increased effort is being made to preserve the rich contribution which Indian arts and crafts have to make to the culture of future generations.

One concrete example of community interest is the Red Lake day school, near Leupp, Ariz., where a group of several Indian families, interested in home gardens, built and paid for an irrigation dam, by means of which
an ample food supply was provided for their school and community.

This changed emphasis on the interrelationship of school and community life is true not only of the day school but of many of the boarding schools as well. Greater emphasis is being placed on more practical work, such as special agricultural and home-making courses. At one school, 3-week short courses were provided throughout the year for mothers and girls in outlying communities. School and home gardens have been made by children and teachers. School hothouses and hotbeds provide tomatoes, cabbage, beets, and flower plants for the homes. Factory classes and part of many homemaking courses and furnishing increasingly is taught in the homes from which pupils come. The furniture and furnishings are simple, but of a practical and durable type that can be made and paid for by an energetic homemaker.
Ottawa, January 28, 1937.

Dear Mr. Freyling:

Please accept my most sincere thanks for your letter of the 25th instant and for the suggestions contained therein.

I may state, by way of comment, that one or two thoughts I expressed in my letter of the 15th instant were submitted wholly by way of suggestion and designed to obtain from the Principals and Teachers in charge of our schools any views they might have in mind in respect to changes that should be made in educational policy.

The suggestion you make, in respect to the promotion of manual or vocational instruction, is pretty much in accord with my own views on the matter. It is my hope that, some day, the Department will be in a position to establish senior vocational schools and in this way prepare our Indian boys and girls for the tasks that lie ahead of them in life. In view of the economic depression in which we find ourselves, however, it is not at all likely that we can make provision for the establishment of such schools at any time in the immediate future. The demands for more liberal relief allowances and for additional health services are steadily multiplying. I am convinced, however, that, in the meantime, our residential schools can make a

R. W. Freyling, Esq.,
Principal,
Gordon's Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Sask.
real contribution by making provision for manual training, even in the junior grades. I have in mind carpentry work, blacksmithing, auto mechanics, shoe repairing, and, in the case of girls, house work, dress making, crochet work and, in fact, anything that will contribute to the development of certain schools.

At the moment, I am interested most of all in the cultivation and care of gardens. I have been simply amazed, since I entered the Department, at the inability of our Indian population to grow sufficient vegetables to maintain themselves even in the summer months. I am not medical man but I am inclined to think there is a vital and direct relationship between this failure on the part of the Indian to grow and consume vegetables and his very unsatisfactory physical condition.

It is not my intention, of course, that you should attempt the impossible; but I have long since reached the conclusion that it is just a waste of time and effort to provide academic instruction for the average pupil who has no mental aptitude for such study. This applies to our Indian pupils, and it applies with equal force to the white pupils in attendance at our public schools.

I note, with interest, your comments on the "follow-up system". Your suggestion, that we obtain the cooperation of our agents and farm instructors, is one that I shall be glad to follow up. Is it your present practice to send to the Agents a list of the senior boys and girls who leave your school from year to year? It seems to me that, if a list such as this were sent, with comments on certain pupils who may require additional supervision and care, it would be well worth while. A suggestion has been made that a placement officer be employed and put in charge of this work, and this suggestion is now under consideration.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your letter of Jan 15th, addressed to Rev. Father McGrath reached our school yesterday and as the new Principal, it is my pleasure to acknowledge its reception and to assure you of my hearty co-operation in your work on behalf of the Indian children in our schools.

It will be three weeks tomorrow since I took charge of the school here and this is my first experience in this line of work. It will therefore take a little while before I get a thorough grasp of the conditions and needs of the School.

I was discussing your letter with Mr. Moore the Indian Agent and he explained to me that the problem of vocational and manual instruction is more difficult here than in most of the schools. The parents of many, if not most, of our children are engaged in trapping and much of the farm work which the boys learn at the school will not be used.

This is true also of the girls. They will go back to their camps, where there are no cows, no poultry and therefore no question of butter-making etc., of course the training in cooking, sewing, mending etc will be invaluable to them and they receive very thorough training common to these subjects.

The Sister Superior has already called my attention to one problem which is a constant source of worry. The baking is done at the school. Bread is made five times a week, at each baking 200 lbs of flour are used. This is apparently a large quantity of dough and although mixed by hand with a stick, this is such heavy work that the boys and girls are obliged to take turns and even at that I am told that it is too heavy for them. Using the boys for this work has many inconveniences. We only have about twelve boys who are physically able to do this work. They are needed for the chores connected with the farm. There is the inconvenience of bringing the boys into the part of the school reserved for the girls and there is also the disadvantage of compelling the boys to do work which they think is fit only for women and work which...

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your circular letter of the 15th inst
and am very glad to hear from you and make your acquaintance, even
if only through the medium of a letter.

Referring to the third paragraph of your letter; I am also
of the opinion, and have been for some considerable time, that some
provision should be made in our educational programme for greater
scope in vocational training, particularly as it applies to the boys,
there is little doubt that the majority of the Girls in our Resident-
ial Schools get a thorough training in domestic science though some-
times this is carried out on a large or "Institutional" scale and much
of the benefits to be derived from such training is then lost, it has
been our policy for the past number of years to have the girls carry
out part of their training in the Kitchen and under the supervision
of a member of Staff prepare meals, mix and bake bread etc in small
quantities such as would be used by the average family say of from
two to five, this has been a great help to the girls when they have
graduated and returned to the Reserves.

I am also of the opinion that the academic training of the
Indian child in our Schools needs to be revised, there is much in the
Curriculum as carried out to-day that can very well be eliminated
insofar as it applies to the Indian Schools, an elementary education
properly administered, the children thoroughly grounded in these
elementary subjects so that they may go back to the Reserves and
carry on all that is required, I cannot convince myself that the
average Indian Boy or Girl is ready to enter the competitive labour
market just yet, there are the odd ones of course who have the ability
to prepare themselves and to make the most of the opportunities
given them to go out and make their way in the world, but my experi-
ence is that the average Indian Boy or Girl will gravitate to the
Reserves when they leave the Schools no matter how well they have
been trained, this is the reason why I am not in favour of an extended
academic training unless facilities were provided whereby students
would be prepared to meet and to do the tasks which will face them
when they return to the Reserves we will be meeting a long felt
want, in this Indian question, in this connection we have made a
start here and at the present time the older boys are learning
simple carpentry with tools such as they would be in a position to
purchase if living on the Reserve, it is planned that they will
also be divided into classes during the Spring & Summer months to
take up the study of Farm Mechanics, Animal Husbandry etc., I do not
think we should revert to the old type of Industrial School and
attempt to train the boys as Carpenters, Blacksmiths etc with the
idea that they will be trained to compete in the open labour market,
it has, I think, been definitely proved that they have not those
qualities of "stick-to-it-timeliness" and are soon discouraged, but
rather we should aim to prepare them to meet those ordinary emergen-
cies encountered daily by the ordinary working man.
Regarding the "Follow-up system" your plan could I think be followed with the co-operation of the Indian Agency staff and the Staffs of the Schools, in our case, we have several children attending this School who come from Agencies rather remote from the School, such as The Pelly Agency at Kamsack, The Qu'Appelle Agency at Moose Jaw, the Carlton Agency at Leask and The Duck Lake Agency at Duck Lake, it would be somewhat difficult for the Principal of this School to give accurate reports of his ex-pupils living on these Agencies but with the co-operation of the various staffs on these Agencies who are, or should be, thoroughly conversant with the ex-pupil the Department could have information which would keep them up-to-date, as far as the File Hills Agency is concerned I could obtain the information without a great deal of difficulty, in this respect I will appreciate it if you will advise me how far back you wish these reports to extend, the Pupils who have graduated in the past five or six years have had some very difficult times to contend with as you having lived in the West are fully aware, the Indian has been no exception and with the necessary curtailment of finances the younger people in many cases have found it impossible to even get a start, however if you will give me some idea of the period you wish to have covered I will endeavour to supply the necessary information.

If you are in the vicinity of File Hills at any time in the future I shall be pleased to have you visit us and become personally acquainted with us and with our work here, I feel that relationships are more closely cemented with the handgrip of friendship and a discussion of the problems one is meeting with.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

Having all this in mind, your letter came to me as a pleasant surprise and also as an encouragement of a high order, for now, myself and my co-workers, are assured of heartfelt cooperation, something which has been, in the past, rather sadly lacking.

Dear Sir;

I take great pleasure in acknowledging your circular letter of the 15th instant addressed to all the principals of Indian Residential Schools.

May I be permitted to say that I greatly appreciate its very sympathetic tone. It does look as if we were last to have in the Department a man who will appreciate the work done by Indian missionaries and teachers regardless of their religious affiliation and who can acknowledge that the work of these same missionaries and teachers has been one replete with a great deal of devotedness and a vast amount of self sacrifice. Speaking for all my co-workers in this field I can say without fear of contradiction that their motives have always been of the highest order and that they have always sought in the first place and foremost the welfare of their charges.

Their work has not always been appreciated, the results obtained have often been criticised by those who know nothing or very little about the Indians, who never had sufficient moral courage to devote their lives to their welfare and who have too often classed Indian missionaries among the simple of this world, who though well intentioned, can only be classed among the poorly equipped intellectually.

Dear Mr. Rhodes:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo and to state, by way of comment, that I appreciate very fully indeed your courteous and prompt reply to my circular of January 15th.

You will be interested to learn that the views you express in respect to educational policy are wholly in accord with my own views. I have not had an opportunity, of course, to make an extensive study of the subject, but I do feel that the policies you express are very much in accord with the needs of our Indian population. My personal opinion is that each residential school should be almost wholly autonomous in so far as educational policy and the arrangement of a curriculum are concerned. I make this comment because the needs of our Indian people are in no sense uniform throughout the Dominion, nor are they uniform even considered in a provincial sense. It is not at all likely, however, that I shall be permitted to suggest anything quite so radical in my attempts to change the policy now in force. I do feel, though, that we must move steadily in this direction.

Cher Monsieur,

Mes sincères félicitations pour l'intérêt que vous portez aux élèves des Écoles indiennes ainsi qu'au travail des institutrices.

Le développement et le bien-être que vous voulez procurer à nos écoles est en tout point louable, et je me fais un plaisir d'y collaborer en vous faisant connaître les obstacles qui empêchent le bon fonctionnement et d'avancement des élèves d'après expérience personnelle.

L'idéal serait la séparation des sexes, afin de pouvoir donner à chacun un enseignement approprié, garçons, branches principales en une...
de leur admission au collège. Aux filles,
enseignement ménager en vue d'en faire des habiles femmes de ménage, ce qui leur permettrait de faire honorablement leur chemin dans la vie.

Pour nous, à Lorette-Indienne, la réalisation de cet idéal est irréalisable pour les raisons suivantes :

1° Le local est trop restreint,
2° Les divisions trop nombreuses.

Nous n'avons que deux classes pour six divisions. Dans des classes de 24x26 pts loger 35 élèves indolents de nature, emmêlés de l'étude, pendant 6 hrs de classe avec trois divisions, il est impossible de rendre les élèves capables de changer de cours chaque année. Dear Sir,

Permit me to offer my thanks for the interest you have shown in the pupils of the Indian schools, as well as in the work of the school teachers. The progress and the well-being that you were trying to create in our school is very commendable.

I take great pleasure in collaborating with you to this end by bringing to your attention the obstacles which I know from personal experience to be opposed to the best interest of the school children.

The ideal would consist in keeping the sexes apart to this end that the boys might receive an education which would prepare them for college, and, on the other hand, the girls might be taught to become especially good housekeepers.

Now for us, at Indian Lorette, the realization of this ideal is impossible for the following reasons: Firstly, the school is too small; Secondly, the grades are much too numerous.

We have only two classrooms for six grades. It is practically impossible to educate the children when there are 35 of them of three different grades living for six hours a day in classrooms 24'x26'. That is why we have asked our Agent, Mr. Maurice Bastien, to request that you make provisions for the enlargement of the school, in order that we may have at least another classroom. Mr. Armstrong judged this enlargement to be very necessary during his visit here, last October.
Therefore, we ask you to kindly see to this matter, if you are really interested in the good education of these children, and we are sure that you will take the necessary measures to have this enlargement made.

Thirdly, a school library would be a great help for the education of the children.

As we only teach English for an hour a day, these books would have to be bilingual in order to make up for the little time we can give to each grade.

We hope you will understand this and grant our request. We will be glad to furnish you with any other information on request.

Dear Sir,

It is a matter of considerable thought as to what steps can be most usefully and economically worked out for the Indian Boy or Girl to be taught what to do to maintain themselves in their future and take their part with the rest of the Community.

(1) The age set by the Indian Act is 16 years for leaving School. Still quite children, at present where or what can they do other than go home. The Parents all too eager for them to leave the School, the father becomes less energetic than ever, sends the boy out to cut hay or wood (at present practically the only source of income) soon the lad is back to the old state of life and becomes satisfied. There is no further aim, because he has never had the opportunity to reach out for something fresh or more appealing.

(2) My idea is something of this nature:
That a piece of land be set apart for a given number of boys as they leave School - on each Reserve or Agency - purchase of Horses, Cows, Brood Sows and Equipment. Every Boy to take part in Raising Stock, the Breaking up and Conditioning of the land, Seeding, Harvesting etc. etc. The land to be cropped with various grains, grasses and roots, marketed and the monies kept in trust.

This outlay for equipment, seed etc. could be repaid under similar conditions such as the Hudson's Bay or C. P. R. (not the land) or interest only paid, from the Crops and increasing Stock after the first year or two, and as the Boys leave to take up land for
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Ottawa, Ont.

themselves, the surplus — apportioned — would help toward the purchase of their own equipment.

Buildings needed for the accommodation of living would be kept clean and in good order by the Boys, (they being taught this in the School), so be erected near the Farm Instructor for Supervision and restriction of visitors. The Barns etc., to be built from logs cut from the nearby woods, by these boys; teaching them how to set about such work for themselves later. This breaking up and cultivation would also make the land a greater asset to the Department, whilst proving to the older Indians what can be accomplished by a little perseverance — with a possible inducement to improve their own conditions.

Trades could be taught; among those most needful — Wheelwright and Blacksmithing — Harness Making; Repairs for implements, wagons, sleighs, harness etc. are daily needs. Repayment for such work being made by the trading of pickets, wood, hay, etc. which would be allowed to accumulate in shipping quantities and for which there is always a ready demand.

There are many callings that could be named, but until there is a far greater advancement from the old regime than at present shown, it would be waste of money to venture on same. So that there seems little outlet other than those I have mentioned, which are both needful and beneficial.

To equip the boys leaving School with horses, harness, wagons etc. would be useless to 90%, as the great majority of the Indians will not provide for Winter care, and as in the past, turn the horses out to shift for themselves and die from exposure and lack of food. This I feel sure can be verified by figures you will have on file, by taking the number of Families, and what each family has in the way of Live Stock — Horses etc. and until they realize the value of these animals the provision for same would be ruinous.
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Ottawa, Ont.

Trapping doubtless could be successful if conserved for a period, and the pelts shipped or sold by a responsible representative of the Department as in the case of the Grain at present.

Indian lumber camps under trained Supervision could be lucrative in time.

My endeavour is to try to suggest something that seems useful and practical. If there is any part in it that may lead to a further thought of someone else, I should feel gratified by this small contribution. As to the future of the Girls it is far more difficult than the Boys, more especially through the lack of interest by those who have given them a short trial when positions have been procured for them.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Gordon's School.

Dear Sir,-

I thank you very much for considering the suggestions of mine regarding a more useful future for our Indian Children.

Prior to receiving your letter dated the 29th of January, I had just finished an outline of what could be considered in this nature, without a very great expenditure and am attaching same to this reply.

This School, for instance, has not an employee who could give the elementary tuition for any trade, or room for the accommodation of an extra help in residence and we are situated 7 miles from a town.

The Girls are now taught General House Work, Bread making by hand, Cooking, Sewing - in the School Sewing Room, Cutting out and making Garments, as well as by the Officers of the School's Junior W. A. in which there are 35 girl members.

Gardening - preparation of Soil for Seeding, Cultivating etc. is in full swing by the Boys, from seeding time to the gathering in of same - equally so in the grain and root fields. Few Gardens are seen on Reserves, either Flower or Vegetable.
Mr. R. A. Hoey,

I am attaching a monthly chore list - it may be interesting - which conveys the daily work of the Boys; the inside work includes making beds, cleaning the Dormitories, Wash Rooms, polishing floors etc. etc.

Two are sent to the Indian Agent for approval, one of which is for the Department in Ottawa, the other for the Agent's Office files. Re "Washington Report" - Conditions in the U.S. are so totally different that comparison is impossible, though to know what is being accomplished is most praiseworthy and interesting. May I further suggest that firstly our Canadian Indians be brought into line with the object, or better still be compelled to live under a more healthy condition with improved surroundings, which would eventually lead them up to the standards of their U.S. brothers.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the above date and file. In reply may I first assure you of our earnest desire to co-operate to the fullest extent with yourself and the members of your staff in providing and carrying out an adequate program of education for our pupils.

I have read your letter carefully and beg to offer the following suggestions:

1. Visits should be made at intervals by a member of your staff for the purpose of inspecting the residential school and discussing matters affecting the discipline and general atmosphere of the school, also possible improvements in methods and administration.

2. Regional conferences of principals should be called at five year intervals for the purpose of discussing programs and methods. The meetings could be held at the residential schools in rotation during the pupils' vacation periods and the expenses of the principals not cut off their own school's budget.

3. Provision should be made for removing pupils from the public school classes who demonstrate their inability to make satisfactory progress at age 15 or attainment of grade 6. These pupils should be given intensive training in a trade, farming or dairying for the boys and domestic science and gardening for the girls. Such pupils should not be discharged until properly trained or at 18 years of age.

4. Residential schools should not be permitted to become a 'Dumping Ground' for children who are 'Non Band Members' or who may be problem children on the reservations. Non band members upon discharge from the school are faced with the fact that they have no legal right to hold land upon the reservation nor to even live there. If they are able to find employment at a distance from the reservation they are acceptable as workers but are barred from the social life of the community. The result is that they are dis-satisfied and unhappy and it is not long before they begin to drift to and fro between the reservation and the white communities, and as an economic unit cease to be of value and instead become a burden. The problem children constitute a real menace to the welfare and safety of all the pupils in residence.

Dear Mr. Crerar,

I have recently received a memorandum with regard to game depletion by drought as one of the causes of dissension among the Indians.

My informant points out that although this may make matters worse, that for years other causes more fundamental in character have been at work. Among these, one of the most serious is the unscrupulousness of the traders in exploiting the Indians. I feel sure, from my own knowledge, that there is a good deal in this charge.

My informant states that "In 1923 the Steamer Montgomery took out the supply for the Hudson Bay Company and charged them 50 cents per 100 lbs. from Winnipeg to Poplar River Landing.

| 1 lbs. tea                    | .25                                     |

| Muskrat averaged    | $35                           |

"I have given the prices only on a few items just to show the difference. All commodities sold to the Indians are all on the same basis, and the same with the fur they have for sale. The lowest price for a red fox received by an Indian was 25 cents that winter."

My informant gives a further instance:

"One of the traders had fifty-four fox skins stored in the basement of the missionary's place. Of these seven were cross foxes, this was all 2nd, 3rd and 4th grade fur valued by my son and I at $360.00. The trader informed me that he had paid for the 54 foxes fifty dollars in trade to the Indians, which would approximately come to $20.00 to $25.00 by Winnipes prices in groceries."

I understand that large territories have been set aside especially for the Indians to trap; but unless there is some control over the trading, it is obvious that the benefit goes not to the Indian, but to the trader.

Further, with regard to health matters - Tuberculosis has, of course, been prevalent among the Indians ever since I was a child, and the government has done a good deal in the way of sending in medicines, but it is surely obvious that tuberculosis is due in part at least to the low standards of living. So far, very little has been done in a practical way to improve these standards."
The Indian schools have done something to train the younger people in sanitation, and to accustom them to higher standards. Unfortunately, however, these young people go back to the reserves or to villages where they have no opportunity of practicing what they have learned. Indeed, in many cases, their education would seem to be a handicap rather than an advantage. As an illustration I turn to the West coast where young people, after they leave the schools, are sent to live with their parents many of whom are living in villages in very wretched conditions. The result, especially upon the girls, has been disastrous—many of the graduates of the schools preferring a life of prostitution in the cities to that of the very bad conditions in the villages.

These are matters that cannot be taken up with advantage on the floor of the House, but I would urge that your Department give more careful consideration to these questions than has been the case in the past. May I ask particularly with regard to the charges of exploitation referred to in the earlier part of this letter.

Yours very truly,

J. S Woodsworth, M.P.

Memorandum:

Dr. McMillan,

I have given careful consideration to the complaint sent forward to you by Mr. J. B. Woodsworth, M.P., in respect to waywardness and immorality amongst the younger people of our Indian population on the Pacific coast.

I may state, by way of comment, that the problem to which Mr. Woodsworth directs your attention is not an educational problem in any basic sense. His contention is that living conditions in certain Indian villages lend themselves to immorality amongst school graduates who return there to reside. In as much, however, as we are responsible, not only for the education of Indian children, but their general welfare as well, the criticism, if well founded, should be given consideration.

I regret to state that we never have had, nor have we now, an effective "follow-up system" that would enable us to know exactly from time to time what progress, if any, the graduates of our schools are making. In this connection you will be interested to learn that, this month, I have sent out a circular letter to the Principals of our Residential Schools and the Teachers in charge of our Day Schools, containing the following paragraph:

"I am deeply interested, also, in a "follow-up system". I mean by this a systematic method of supplying the Department, from year to year, with information that will enable us to know exactly what becomes of our pupils after they leave school. This work should be undertaken at once by the Principals of our residential schools and by the teachers in charge of our day schools. We shall welcome any suggestions as to how this work can be simply and effectively accomplished."

In addition to this, we have undertaken an experiment at the Kispiox reserve, Babine agency, northern British Columbia. On this reserve, arrangements have been completed for the organization of classes in the school twice each week. Instruction will be given to teen-age boys and girls and to adults, in sewing, dressmaking, nursing and other subjects. If this experiment, which is very inexpensive, is successful, it is our intention to extend it to other districts.

The assumption that economic conditions

- contribute
contribute to immorality may or may not be valid. It is significant that the Deputy Minister of Health for the province of Manitoba, in his report of this year, refers to the alarming increase in delinquency and immorality amongst the school population. It would appear from the report that this tendency is not peculiar to any particular district. If such conditions exist amongst the white population, the task of correcting them amongst primitive or semi-primitive people, such as our Indians, is going to be exceedingly difficult work. It is my intention to give the whole matter careful consideration, just as soon as the time at my disposal will enable me to do so.

February 8, 1937.

Dear Mr. Woodsworth,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of January 26 last, dealing with several matters pertaining to the administration of Indian Affairs, particularly in the Lake Winnipeg district and in Indian Villages on the Pacific coast.

Concerning exploitation of Indians of the Poplar River Reserve by traders, this matter was brought to the attention of the department some time ago and was referred to Mr. A. G. Hamilton to express his views as to the adoption of some procedure other than that now in vogue of disposing of Indians' furs for them, provided any recommended change would benefit them.

Mr. Hamilton in reply stated that he would like to give the matter further consideration and would later submit a report. He has not as yet done so, however, and has been again written to on the subject.

I am sure that you will readily recognize that this is a somewhat difficult matter to deal with in a manner that will assure equity as between the Indians and the traders in transactions which take place personally between these two parties. We have already made a step in advance in the Pan-Indian scheme the Indians agent is endeavoring to some extent the sales of the furs collected by his Indians and it is hoped that we may be able to extend the system where it is practicable to do so. We trust that our inspector will be able to submit some proposal that will be acceptable and feasible.

Your remarks with regard to ...............

J. S. Woodsworth, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.
Your remarks with regard to the prevalence of tuberculosis among the Indians are noted. We are doing what we can to combat this disease with the limited funds at our disposal, and we quite subscribe to your remarks that tuberculosis is in part at least due to the low standards of living among these native people.

I was quite disturbed to note, from your letter of recent date, that you had learned of a marked tendency toward delinquency and immorality on the part of certain girl graduates of our Indian schools, who reside in villages on the Pacific coast. May I express the hope that this tendency is local and in no sense general amongst the Indian population of British Columbia. I should state, in fairness to the officials here, that we have received no reports from our Indian agents, indicating that such conditions exist.

You will be interested to learn that, this month, we have circularized the principals of our residential schools and the teachers of our day schools, asking them to cooperate with us in the organization of an effective "follow-up system," which system should enable us to follow intelligently the progress made by the graduates of our schools during the years immediately following their departure from our institutions. This month, also, we have undertaken an experiment in adult education at the Nicola reserve, designed to encourage teen age boys and girls to take up courses in sewing, dressmaking, nursing, auto mechanics, boat building, etc. If this experiment is measurably successful, it is our intention to extend it to other districts.

It is our intention to communicate with the newly appointed Commissioner of Indian Affairs in British Columbia, Mr. Hesley, asking him to make a careful investigation of the prevailing economic conditions on the reserves, particularly the social and economic conditions in the Indian villages, and to report to us just as soon as he can conveniently do so.

I am sure that Doctor McMillan, Director of Indian Affairs, and Mr. R. A. Hesley, the Superintendent of Welfare and Training would be glad to discuss these matters with you personally should you find it convenient to visit them in their offices in the Booth Building.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received your letter of the 3rd inst. No. 150-60 enclosing copy of your circular letter of the 15th, also embodying certain proposals in connection with that sphere of the Department's activities over which you have been called to preside. If there is any way in which our Commission can assist you in the discharge of your responsible duties, you may be well assured that this assistance will gladly and freely be given.

In your circular letter reference is made to further manual training in the Indian Residential Schools, and also to the very important question of a "follow-up system" in connection with the graduate pupils. Our Commission has already given very considerable attention to both of these questions, but only at one of our schools, namely, at Alert Bay, has anything worthy of the name of manual training been undertaken. Even here, this would have been quite impossible without the help provided by the Department in meeting half of the Instructor's salary. The development of this branch of education has seemed to our Commission to be very important, if the Indian peoples of this country are to be fitted to take their place as citizens of the same.

With regard to the system of follow-up work, our Commission are convinced that no system will succeed without the co-operation of your Department's representatives, namely, the Indian Agent and the missionaries of the different churches who are engaged in purely missionary work. After the pupils
leave the school they require guidance and encouragement, and these may best be given by Indian Agents and Missionaries. The Woman's Auxiliary of our Missionary Society has a special Committee which is doing quite a good work amongst the girl graduates, and their one regret is that they have not sufficient funds at present to provide "Field Matrons" or "Deaconesses" to carry on this work as they feel it should be done.

It has been the policy of our Commission to place the health of the Indian children in the schools in a position of primary importance. Registered Nurses have been given the Head Matronships and other staff positions. Instructions were issued to the various school management to keep careful record of the weights and measurements of children from the time of their admission until the time of their discharge. The Alert Bay School adopted a record sheet sample of which is enclosed herewith, and it was the intention of our Commission to have a sheet of this kind prepared for all of our Society's Schools; also it had been in use for a year or two at Alert Bay with a view to ascertaining whether it required further revision or not. As you will, no doubt, receive replies from many of our Principals to your circular letter, I will not write further at present, but will be very glad indeed to confer with you at any time I may be able with regard to the proposals set forth in your circular letter.

With very good wishes,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 15th inst. re the educational system carried out in the Indian Schools. I agree with your personal opinion that some provision should be made for a course of manual training for the boys, and a course of dressmaking and domestic science for the girls.

Early in the fall I took up the matter of dressmaking etc., with the chief of this Reserve explaining to him that I had taken a course in these branches and that I was sure that the taking up of this work by the school children and other young ladies of the Reserve would be very beneficial to them. Owing to lack of funds and material we let the matter drop. Re vocational training for the boys, probably some provision could be made at the Manual Training Classes in the City of Sydney.
I'd be only too glad and willing to cooperate in the "Follow-up System" as it would not only keep a check on pupils who leave school having attained the required age, but also on those who leave before attaining it. I would suggest that stricter methods in compulsory attendance be used in such cases. For the young people over 15 years of age a census of such could be taken by the teacher, and necessary information concerning their occupation at the present time.

Respectfully Yours,
Catherine Gallagher

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter 150-60 dated February 3rd, together with the enclosed circular.

A large percentage of the teachers in our day schools are women and I am afraid they will have only a vague idea of the difficulties encountered in establishing school graduates. I am sure the Indian Agents could offer helpful suggestions and letters from our Farming Instructors would at least be interesting.

First, I would like to discuss the boarding school graduate. The boys know how to farm, garden, and care for stock. They have been accustomed to the most up-to-date implements, tractors, good horses, and a Farming Instructor always at their call. They get up in the morning when called, eat when told, and work as instructed. When the work is finished, they amuse themselves until told to do something definite. If sick, they receive care and attention. It is a life where everything is planned and provided. After eight or ten years in this environment, the boy is turned back on the reserve and expected to make good.

In some cases, he has been provided with a team, harness, wagon, and plough. He is expected to go to work and make a living. The close supervision is gone - the boy knows he cannot be made to work a definite number of hours each day. Then there is the question of food and his desire to attend all Fairs and Sports Days within a seventy-five mile radius of his home. The result usually is a failure and yet I am not prepared to altogether blame the Indian. The parents usually have little, if any, control as the child has been away from home influence too long. He has been educated and is not willing to take advice from his old father. I agree that at least one-third of the boy's time, while at school, should be devoted to manual training. He should graduate qualified to do ordinary carpentering, blacksmith work, and painting. He could then build his own house and do the ordinary repair work necessary in operating machinery. The bush Indian should be educated in the north and not taken from that environment. They will never be able to farm in those parts and, while away, lose the early home training in regard to

regard to hunting, trapping, and fishing, which training is most essential.

The day school pupils receive less academic training, but are better fitted to make a living in their particular district because of home training. They face with their parents the problems of providing food, clothing, and shelter, and I believe appreciate more any assistance granted.

In many cases, I think it much better to make the graduate prove his worth before assistance is given. I have suggested supplying the Agents with an accountable advance (not large) in order that they might start a community farm. The best boys could be sorted out and, as the scheme enlarged, they could be given 50 acres of cultivated land and some equipment. I find the Indian rarely has enough horse power and, by the time he gets 20 to 40 acres broken, he has ruined a horse or one is dead and the work stops. We cannot expect Indians to greatly exceed the white man's ability in this respect and one has only to make a few enquiries to find out how much it cost to start one man on the "Back to the Land" plan. The expense does not end when he is placed, but seed, food, and clothing is often provided for some time, and in many cases exemption is made in interest and taxes.

Assistance granted in a haphazard way, without being followed up, does not amount to much. These grants of horses and machinery do not bring the desired results, only in a few exceptional cases. The community farm would try the boys out, give them a chance to find their own feet and see for themselves what is required of a good farmer. I think, after the first two years, these farms would pay their way and the scheme could be carried on by the Agent without assistance.

If this plan were adopted or tried out, we might further encourage the graduates by giving the girl some house equipment when she marries. This would not involve much expense and would be something to look forward to. I believe, if this matter were handled carefully and under close supervision, we could gradually settle a large percentage of the graduates and at small cost. However, with the Agents having very little authority and no funds with which to start such plans, it is impossible to get anywhere. This is a big problem and one deserving much careful thought and study. It constitutes our most important problem - "The establishing of home life".

It is impossible to do anywhere near justice to the subject by writing and I hope soon to have the privilege of discussing thoroughly this matter with you.

Sincerely yours,

A. G. Hamilton

Dear Mr. Hey,

I have received your letter of January 15th, and the excellent ideas it contains concerning work in the Indian schools have me very much impressed and encouraged.

I believe the Indian Department's aim is to prepare the children for the problems of their adult life, at work and at home; to give them a fine standard of health, cleanliness, and general living conditions; to make them self-supporting and upright. The present course of study ignores an important means of reaching this goal; and that is, sufficient manual training. All Indian children in the range of my short experience form habits through their hands, and I am convinced that only a well-planned manual course can succeed in instilling life-long habits in their minds.

The change to an improved system will probably be slow, and any practical suggestions I might make have doubtless been thoroughly considered by your department. Each school should devote at least two hours a day to manual training. Those children who, at the age of eleven or twelve years, show a particular aptitude in any direction, whether it be woodworking,
serving, etc., or in academic study, could be sent to a special training school, established by the Department at chosen points in the Dominion. At these schools the children could be trained individually for that vocation to which they are best suited.

The disadvantage of such a plan is the expense of building and operating special schools—or even one experimental school. The advantages are that all the children obtain the practical and moral benefits of the manual training, while those particularly adept ones are not held back by the others.

I hope I may be forgiven for writing at such length on the subject. My only excuse is that since accepting a position in an Indian school I have given a great deal of thought to the matter.

Before closing, I should like to inquire regarding seed for our school garden. Should I address my application for government seed to your department or to the Department of Agriculture?

I should like to speak again of the encouragement your letter brought to me. I am sure that with the added gift of your advice and assistance, the work in our schools will be happier and more progressive.

Yours very sincerely,

Norman Van Hattum.
Walpole Island, Ont.,
Feb 12, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Your letter dated January fifteenth received and have been debating since whether an answer was expected or not. I finally decided I would write anyway, hoping that in the rush of your new duties it will not take too much of your time.

Your opinion as to changing our system and giving the pupils one third of their time at manual training and other forms of Vocational training I think is a splendid idea. So much seems to depend on this early Vocational training. We have several men here, around the age of forty, who received that training at the old Boarding school and are today the outstanding men of our island. This appears to be putting our day school on a lower plane of education, but of course at that time our day school here was not getting really qualified teachers which accounts for this fact.

I have felt for the past few years that manual training was necessary so last year...
we rigged up a bench across the back of the room and bought a few tools, which I personally financed, and made a start. The children were, and are, happier because of it. I have never felt like taking much time for this however, as the entrance examinations are a black cloud always on the horizon and I have felt that we are expected to pass pupils through these exams.

In regard to these entrance pupils, it might be interesting to you to know what happens to them after they reach High School. I think in the past five years, we have had eight who went on to High School and without any exception they were a disappointment. They had the ability to learn in fact some beat their forms but quit after two, three or four years, right when the goal was in sight.

To me it is obvious that it is a mistake to send on the majority of these pupils.

If the length of time they stayed in this school was increased by two or three years and the work more of a hand nature it would be better. But they would pile up here so that another two-room school would have to be built, because we already have approximately sixty.
As to the "follow-up system," suggested; it would be a simple matter for me to give names and occupations of all pupils who have passed through Mrs. Daley's room and my own since we have been here. We could also furnish if necessary, their general outlook on life and moral tendencies. And believe me, Sir, that is the heart breaking part of this teaching Indian children. We teach a child, who has every indication of growing into a man or woman who will be a credit to any community and he gets out of school and in one or two years is no better than the rest. We feel of course, that in time this will be overcome or it would all be a farce, this work being carried on year in and year out.

We have been hoping that a change would be made, a drastic change if necessary, and believe me if Mrs. Daley or myself can be of any assistance, we will be only too glad to help.

Sincerely yours,

James W. Daley
Principal - No. 1 School
Whitefish Lake School
Naughton, Ont.,

Dear Mr. Hay,

I would heartily welcome any provision made on our educational programme concerning manual training. I too have the opinion that our pupils would benefit more from that training than they are from our present course of study.

For instance take the boys and girls that left this school a few years ago. What are they doing now and what are their living standards up to? You will find most of them living in a small, one-room shack very peacefully and contentedly. Their houses are sadly in need of soap and water, clean household articles and well cooked meals. This is because they have never been taught the value of good housekeeping and how to improve and beautify their homes. They spend their money buying ready-made clothes for all the family.
The women do not sew, mend or knit. They have no gardens of any kind on this reserve with the result that they are very often short of food. They seldom ever have any vegetables.

Now this has led me to wish for a school garden this summer. I have been planning for one but I don't know whom I should ask for that. Can you or are you in a position to give me any help?

Last fall when I began teaching I gave the girls a few lessons on sewing and they were very delighted and eager to learn. Of course I couldn't keep it up because I couldn't stand the expense as I was supplying all the necessary material.

There is one other reason why I would like to have manual training here. It would be an incentive for the children to attend school regularly. They are very poor in attendance.

I would be very glad to receive any helpful suggestions you may have to offer me.

Yours sincerely,

Miss M. Kincaid
Ottawa, February 16, 1937.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Many thanks for your friendly and interesting letter of January 15th. I have read this letter very carefully and find it a pleasure in answering same. One of the criticisms often voiced here in the Yukon is that our ex-pupils are unfitted to adapt themselves to a home environment so different from what they have been used to at the school. It seems that the best word that can be used to describe their attitude of mind on reaching home is - DISSATISFACTION. Not only are they dissatisfied with home conditions so different from what they have been used to for so many years at the school but they find it extremely difficult to earn a living.

At the school here the boys are taught farming and gardening. Well, whilst gardening can be undertaken on a small scale in the Yukon, early frosts and a very limited market, would make it a precarious way of earning a living. As far as farming is concerned it is my personal opinion that such is out of the question, for the Indians in such a mountainous country as this. The obtaining of hay to feed stock is very difficult. Hay shipped in from 'outside' costs over a $100.00 per Ton landed in Carcross and local hay, only found in a very few places, costs from $40.00 to $50.00 per Ton.

The price of lumber in the Yukon which ranges from $60.00 per M. up would be a decided obstacle to any boys learning carpentrying with a view to adopting the trade of a carpenter after leaving school.

I have just been talking with the Classroom Teacher about the mentality of the pupils now enrolled here. Her opinion is that of one who has
had many years experience teaching in residential schools in various parts of Canada. It is her opinion that they are of a very low mentality compared with Indian children she has taught in other schools. If a child reached Grade VIII or even Grade VII they would be outstanding. This alone would tend to bar them from following any profession or trade after leaving school.

About the only pursuit that the Indians in the Southern Yukon follow and I believe the same is true of the Northern Part, is hunting and trapping. In this connection I feel that a residential school could help them. During past years both the boys and girls here have spent considerable time during the winter in snaring rabbits. These rabbits have been purchased from them not only by the school but by those in Carcross and vicinity who engage in Mink and Fox Farming. There is no doubt in my mind but that this form of activity should be encouraged and occupy a prominent place on the curriculum and if the Department could supply the boys and girls with snare wire and traps they would be rendering the pupils assistance well worthwhile.

It might be of interest for you to know that a dog - team is kept at this school, not so much with the idea of using it for school work but to give the boys an opportunity of handling a dog team a thing that they will most certainly have to do after leaving school.

In connection with that paragraph of your letter in which you mention the "Follow-up System" I would like to make the following suggestion. The missionaries in the various settlements who are or should be in close touch with ex-pupils could make an annual report at the close of each year to the Principals as to the activities, conduct etc. of those who have left the school. This information could then be passed on to your Department and I am sure would also be of value to the school management. Such a system would of course have to be arranged through the Bishops of the various Dioceses or other Church Leaders.

Yours respectfully,

H.C.M. Grant,
Principal.
Indian Residential School

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your letter of January 15th to hand. Since then I have been very busy with our "FLU" epidemic, which has fortunately passed without any very serious aftermath.

I must thank you for your letter. It was very refreshing and heartening. It means much to me because of its understanding and spirit of cooperation. I have been nearly twenty five years in Indian Educational work and I am still anxious to see progressive movements. I appreciate your letter for its spirit and suggestions.

While still retaining our church relations, I have been impressed for some time with the need of our Indian Schools, with all their equipment, becoming more an integral part of the life of the reserve. This applies more particularly to follow-up work. Too much of the work of the school is lost with the discharge of a pupil. I believe that with the backing of the Department, much can be accomplished by a larger cooperation between school management and Agency officials. This is just one suggestion to start with.

I trust before long that we may have the pleasure of a visit from you. The function of this particular school in the whole scheme of Indian Education can then be discussed at greater length.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I received your letter some time ago and I intended answering sooner but I have been very busy.

I noted the contents of your letter and I am very much interested.

Our educational programme is a bit stiff. It would be rather hard to change our course of study owing to the very few Indian children that are really interested in continuing their education in High Schools and Colleges.

Your idea of spending about 1/3 of the time in manual training and vocational work is very good. One third of the time is
a whole lot though. I presume you mean to have this sort of work related to the other subjects—that is manual training would necessitate certain amount of work in arithmetic, spelling, etc. Then '3 of the time wouldn't be too much.

Just what kind of work do you mean by "vocational work"? I have a fair idea but I would like to know what you have in mind.

To get the school children really interested in manual training etc. we must show them how they will be able to make money out of this kind of work. My idea is that we should try and locate a market for little trinkets that can be made.

I have been assisting some Indians in disposing of hand-made lacrosse sticks and I am getting along very nicely in this line.
There are a few other items I have in mind but I am a little bit hesitant a bit about going ahead with it as I haven't enough capital (money) to finish the thing ahead in case some trouble turns up.

If we get the adults working on something they can make money out of then we have the children interested in this sort of work too. Co-operation means a whole lot in anything.

The Department was good enough to supply me with some tools and lumber for a work bench for my school and when I get things working properly I believe it will be a big aid to my children.

It would be a good idea to send out some very simple blue print plans to some of the teachers. I mean, very simple ones at first because most teachers know nothing about blue prints. I must admit that I know nothing about
them myself. But, teacher and pupil could both learn at the same time.

If there are any other things I can think of at a later date I shall be only too glad to write you.

I trust that you will overlook errors in this letter as I am writing in a hurry.

Yours very truly,

Colin J. Chisholm, teacher,
Cornwall Island East Indian Day School.

P.S.

Miss Moody has no doubt spoken to you about certain things I mentioned to her and I trust you will understand why I told her to speak to you.

C.J. Chisholm.

some disappointment, as they are a hapless lot. Fifty percent of whom do not even try to practice the forest craft of their fathers. It is amazing to learn that some do not even know how to hunt or trap. This Reserve is extremely unfitted for agriculture in any form. The only profession open to the Indian youth in this area is to be a successful trapper and hunter. I believe that wood-craft and other Indian Arts (e.g., basketry, etc.) would be a great improvement to the course of study if included. Also, trapping methods could be taught in conjunction with Nature Study, thus giving them a more humane idea of the profession.

As for the girls who graduate, their one ambition is matrimony, and yet they cannot cook, other than for the bare necessities of a livelihood. A model kitchen and lessons in preparing wholesome yet plain dishes would help them greatly in their
after life.

I have been on Indian Reserves before but never have I witnessed such shiftlessness and poverty as I find here. A course of study, which is less academic, and more vocational would certainly help rectify conditions for the future at least.

In due course, I shall prepare a list of ex-pupils of this school, ones who graduated before my appointment here, and I shall endeavour to also list their present occupations if any. I shall also note any suggestion which might add to the pupils efficiency in after life, that might aid in any reconstruction of the course of study.

Now might I draw your attention in a literary aspect to the course of study and in connection with suitable books. I find it difficult to obtain suitable text books from the Dept. The supplementary reading books, should I think, take in
stories, in connection with the Indian child's environment. The authorized Ontario History and Geography texts are printed in a vocabulary much above the average intelligence of the Indian. Yet the Dept. does not supply such books as "Dent's Geography & History Readers" which are less costly and more suited for the purpose. The Indian child is always attracted to things of a colorful nature, and certainly cannot interest himself in text books which would tax the intelligence of a senior pupil from our white schools.

If you could assure me of shipping us books that I could list, I'm sure you would be doing the Indians here a favour. When a lesson is taught, it is a great source of satisfaction for a teacher to interest the class in a book, which the class can further their knowledge, not above their comprehension.

So in closing, I hope
that you can understand things as I have explained, and I thank you for the opportunity you have afforded me; I assure you I shall communicate with you often as I find the necessity to do so.

Yours very sincerely,

J.R. Douglas,
Teacher, Indian Day School.
9 Doyle St. Truro
Nova Scotia.
Feb 14th 1937.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your letter of Jan. 15th was received and greatly appreciated. I feel that in view of your statements, our relationships are going to be cordial and, to me at least, helpful. I thank you for it, and you may depend that I will enjoy co-operating in any way with the Indian Affairs Branch.

From the records you will see that this is my first year in gov't service. In fact my first year of teaching and as yet, I am loathe to make any suggestions other than concerning those things with which I have daily contact. Some times I feel very much in the need of suggestions and would appreciate them myself.

Speaking of the N. Scotian Indian [Writer]
I think that the "follow-up system" you mentioned would, in a few short years, tell even a far off Australian all he would want to know concerning the work and life of our Indians. The lot of the father seems the accepted lot of the son; likewise the mother and daughter. Baskets, blankets, etc., seem to be their only resource outside of their "order." All of it can not be attributed to them alone. Our "colored friends" will get the preference every time when there is any work to be done. This serves to shove the Indian down further. From lords of this country, they have, in the eyes of the men in the street, sunk to the level where they are beneath our African brothers. The Indian scowled with T.B. "peddling" his wares is an abject figure. I would here like to mention the uphill fight the local Indian Agent is waging continually to instill some feeling of self-respect and honest pride in his charges. But it seems to be of no avail. The morale seems to be gone and little wonder. His hope is in the school. The present system of school has failed. Will there be any changes? Will there be vocational schools for boys? And home
Training for girls? Shouldn't Indian boys be taught cobblering, masonry, carpentry, plumbing, blacksmithing, mechanics etc., and installed as helpers or given half a chance to rise? Or girls taught sewing, knitting, sanitary homekeeping, dressmaking? These things are taught in reform schools, in prisons, in various institutions for blind, deaf, mentally deficient, and why not the neglected Indians?

Now I'm sorry to say this missal has taken form other than what I intended. But I must mention to someone in authority the most important needs of my school and from all the letters I certainly select you. I probably took too much advantage of your generousness when you said "I want you to feel perfectly free to write me any time" so now in conclusion I'll confine myself to my school. The building itself is in very good shape, the grounds are meager and being on a hill (slight) are damp; however drains have been dug and help considerably.

But first on my list I would like a little school library and supplementary reading matter. I had quite a siege bringing the children up to where
they are now, clamoring for Silent Reading. They thoroughly disliked it at first and it was almost considered punishment to have them read. But now they ask for it daily and are eager for any new reading matter. The only outside reading they have is the occasional book I can buy and on my salary minus board, and travelling expenses and a large family of brothers and sisters these books are of a necessity quite occasional. If any grant is possible I would like to select the books myself as these children grasp remarkably little of what they read and only the simplest stories and reading matter could be chosen.

The next case on the docket is the need of a jacket for the stove which throws off a scorching heat to the comfort of children seated nearby.

The third item is mentioned, not expecting to throw the Ind. Affairs Br. into confusion but to call attention to the fact in case repeated demands come from inspectors or doctors, the present desks have been service since somewhere in the eighteen hundreds. Over fifty years
"in his majesty's service." Now I feel that anything in Gov't service that long should be retired on a pension. They are too worn to be repaired and like all things doing fifty years uninterrupted service are beginning to bend under the strain and are beginning to look something like this seat. The children touch about where the X's are, which may possibly result in curvature of the spine. Any Doctor or inspector would advise new desks and seats. If there should be any action taken I would like to select the type of desk or at least would want them individual types and movable. For classroom activities, drill, projects etc., the movable desk is invaluable.

The last but not least I think you will find is in line with your suggestions. Namely, a start on some manual training equipment. You see, Our Agent has arranged with the Town of Truro for me to instruct nine of their children in close proximity to my school in return for the privilege of sending our bigger boys to their manual training school. With this start we hope to have those boys
help our younger ones in the school. Besides, though being no artist myself in that line I have friends who specialized in that work and I feel I could call on them for a start. Later on these boys may take their course in town quite well prepared.

I might mention that the Agent's wife and her sister are starting a sewing and knitting class on the reserve for only two women of them can knit and, to all appearances, less than that can sew. Those boys who are attending them are doing very well and are mixing in quite easily.

Now that is all I want to say concerning school. I want to ask a few questions and wind this missal up. Are Indian school teachers (that is phrased wrongly)—I mean we teachers of Ind. schools—in the habit of getting passes or reduced fares travelling to and from our schools? I heard we were but nobody seems to know definitely. And don't you think it
Would be a good idea to have teachers' institutes or get-togethers where we can all exchange our difficulties and have some experienced teachers—Indian teaching—help us by their experiences? This is the accepted thing, regularly, in provincial schools and young teachers look forward to an opening to air their difficulties. The Indian school teachers are more or less isolated.

Another device which I think is admirable for experience of some travelling and stimulates teaching is the exchange of teachers. It is quite possible for teachers to get into a rut, roughly speaking, by teaching year after year facing the same problems, personalities in the same school. But no teacher likes to be moving continually because he soon acquires a name and faces the risk of not getting a school for next year. And sometimes I think it's not fair to have one cooped up in one place. He has no raise in pay and so he doesn't advance himself in any way. He doesn't meet new situations, or sees nothing new and I think
he suffers by it. In the Indian Schools things would be different. They don't have temperamental parents who if they didn't like the teacher because of some little difference would demand his release, etc., etc.

As far as I can see things are quite different on Reserves. They don't take it in their heads to tell the teacher how this should be taught, etc., and consequently teachers could move without fear of being idle.

Now Mr. Hoey, I thank you for your time—if you have reached this page. I wish too that you don't refrain from commenting on anything I've said. As I said earlier, I'm only a beginner and am likely wrong, and some older, wiser person could convince me, which I would be glad for. I hope to hear from you soon, in regards to those things for my school, at least.

Yours very sincerely,

F.B. McKinnon.
Teacher Millbrook Reserve
Truro, N. Scotia.
Ottawa, February 19, 1937.

Dear Mr. Chisholm:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant and to thank you very heartily for the information contained therein.

When I expressed the view in my circular letter that approximately one third of the regular school period should be devoted to manual training, my intention was to suggest this as an objective toward which our schools should move gradually. A great deal, of course, will depend upon local conditions, the facilities at your disposal, etc. It is somewhat difficult to define vocational instruction. I like to think of it as a philosophy of education. In practice, however, it should result in provision for instruction in carpentry work, auto mechanics, blacksmithing, handicraft work, elementary agriculture, and, in the case of girls, sewing, crochet work, elementary domestic science and, in fact, any subjects which will enable them to become better home makers. It should be comparatively easy to convince the Indian pupil that his chance of success in modern society will depend largely upon the development of certain skills, the acquisition of which must, of necessity, make him more useful to society.

Miss Moodie, when she called upon me a few days ago, intimated that you were anxious to be excused from taking a summer school course at one of the training colleges. If you have this in mind, you should send in a formal request for this exemption, giving in detail your reasons.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir,

First of all let me thank you for your letter of Jan. 15th. May I wish you all success in your work. I wish also to pledge my support to you in our work.

Your "Follow-up System" is a good idea. I have thought that this should be done and have taken pleasure in keeping "tabs" on the pupils who have graduated from this school during my work as teacher here since 1920. There would, however, have to be a limit of let us say five years. The best way would be to supply every teacher with a form on which he would note the progress of pupils who have left school during the past five years. Another form could be forwarded showing the work and the progress of those who left school ten years ago. That means that once a pupil was off the five year list he would not appear on the records until he had been out for ten years. Of course each pupil would have to have a permanent number. Or each pupil could have a sheet of his own and it could be in the possession of the teacher until the end of the five years. I am very much interested in this work and would like to see it under way in the future.

I am more interested and gratified to see that you favour Manual Training and Vocational work among the pupils. This certainly is badly needed and is, I think, of more importance than years of memorizing dates in History and wrestling with analysis of sentences, etc. It is my wish that my pupils will know how to read intelligently, work problems in their grade in Arithmetic and above all be good spellers. Health and P.T. are important as is also study of the Scriptures but for the other subjects I try to make them as interesting as I can by projects. Work that the children can do. I wish you could call some time and see the relief maps that my pupils are working at now in Geography. They enjoy this kind of work too.
I make a specialty of the teaching of Agriculture. I feel that this is one of the ways in which we can instil the lesson of independence in later life. I like the subject and as I have a special certificate for it I find that I can get more from the pupils in this than in anything else except the bit of manual work I can sneak in. I say "Sneak in". I have had to do just that because there were a couple of the parents objected to it and the agent asked me to discontinue it. We have made some very nice little raffia baskets and some picture frames from thin wood.

I should like to take a course this summer in Toronto in Auxiliary class work at the Junior Vocational school. There is, however, not much use in my taking this course if I am to continue on here. I would be willing to go ahead with it if you could see your way clear to giving me a transfer from here to a reserve near London or Brantford. If I were over there near other schools I could be of help to the other teachers in the same part of the country and give them hints and helps if they wanted it, on Saturdays. I feel that this work should come to the fore in our schools and I think that I could do more in a place where the people were a little more broad-minded than they are here. If I were in a place where I could contact the other teachers I would be in a position to let them have the benefit of my experience and the special training which I should have after taking the course referred to.

Please accept this letter as I have written it. For the sole purpose of letting you know that I am with you in all you try to do and also to ask your advice along the lines mentioned above. Again let me thank you for your kind letter.

Yours very sincerely,

Albert E. Smith.
Ottawa, February 19, 1937.
