Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of January 15th, which I was very interested in getting from you. I must apologize for not acknowledging it before.

I thoroughly concur with you that our educational program with the Indian children might be made much more practical to them when they get back on the reserve if we were able to give more technical and manual training.

Chiefly I should suggest carpentry work which would enable them to build themselves decent shacks or houses to live in, and then as much general knowledge as we could given them in cultivating the land for garden products.

We have always been very much handicapped in that respect here in the lack of material to work with.

These two things I think will be primary in starting them to be able to support themselves.

Of course these things I mention only refer to the boys. It has always been the custom in these schools to do all that could be done in instructing the girls in housekeeping, cooking, mending, sewing, and such like. They are not very much use to them unless they have somewhere to do it in.

It has been my experience to see that Indian children, both boys and girls, are much more clever working with their hands than with their heads.
If at any future time you are able to pay us a personal visit it will be very much appreciated. You will be able to see things for yourself first hand.

I remain,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been longer than I expected in replying to your letter of January 15th, #150-60.

In the first place, let me express again my great appreciation of the action of the Minister in placing you in this position of responsibility and opportunity. Many fine expressions of appreciation have come to me, especially from officials of our Home Mission Board.

I thoroughly agree with the personal opinion you express in regard to the educational programme which should be adopted stressing manual training, all kinds of handwork and vocational instruction. I feel, however, that a certain percentage of our brighter pupils, who are free from that inferiority complex which is so characteristic of many of them and who are in every way as well qualified as the best of our white children to make their way in the world in teaching, nursing or other professions, should be given the regular academic training and all opportunity and encouragement possible to go ahead and make good.

about the wisdom of employing placement officers to carry on this work but I think it must be done by the very diligent application and co-operation of everyone concerned in the development and safeguarding of these young lives. Dear Sir,-

I have received your letter No. 150-60, dated January 15th, and in accepting your kind offer to communicate with you, I now take the liberty and pleasure of writing this personal letter regarding this school and educational matters, here.

I have taught in this school for over thirteen years and during that time, although I have experienced some difficulties, I feel confident that progress has been as satisfactory as could be expected under existing circumstances. None of my former pupils have achieved any high educational degree but I feel satisfied that all who have left school had a common school education.

During the first few years I was here, nearly all the reading and writing of letters etc. was done by me as only a very few Indians were able to either read or write. Now, it is only on very rare occasions that I am called upon to either read or write for the Indians as the younger generation can do that themselves. A few years ago, newspapers were unknown in Indian homes, but now the majority of the families are receiving them either daily or weekly.

In making these statements I do not mean to belittle the teaching ability of my predecessors or to have you imagine that I, and I alone, have resurrected the Indians of this Reserve from a grave of total ignorance and placed them above the standard of others but I will frankly and truthfully say that each and every one of the younger generation, who have completed this school's course of studies, have what is considered a fair education and are capable of teaching their parents.

A teacher here is confronted with many difficulties unknown to teachers in white schools, the first and foremost
being that the children cannot speak or understand any English when they first come to school on account of there being no other language but Micmac spoken in their homes. This being so, the average child has attended school for a year or more before he or she is on a parallel with a "white" child on the first day of attendance. I must admit that I have found it impossible to have the children use English in ordinary conversations, outside of the school. That this is a handicap has been proven to me by the early advancement of the children of a family who live near my home, play and talk English with my own children. I now have a limited knowledge of their language and I often wonder how I ever taught the junior children during the first few years I was here, when I could not understand them and they could not understand me.

Another difficulty I experienced was the lack of home study as the children did not, and could not, get any assistance from their parents. The children of today are not so handicapped in this regard as every home has at least a few members who are educated enough to help them.

As regarding suggestions for improvement, I have very little offer as I consider that everything possible is now being done by the Indian Department and all concerned. However, I am of the firm opinion that this school-building should be enlarged, divided into two rooms and a second teacher employed. I do not say this with the idea of lessening my own work and duty but with the firm belief that it is next to impossible for any one teacher to give sufficient time and attention to such a large number of pupils as are attending this school. At present there is an enrollment of forty-three pupils and within the next few months I expect to have eight or nine more. My earnest suggestion is that one teacher have charge of the beginners and Grade 1 and after they have learned to speak and understand English, as well as being able to do some reading, writing etc., that they be transferred to the other teacher, in another classroom, for general studies. In this manner each teacher would have about twenty-five pupils (the average in local white schools), there would be sufficient time for the teaching of vocational training etc., in addition to regular school duties and I feel assured that each and every child would leave school far in advance of the present standard. Visiting school officials and Indian Agents have often remarked that I had too many pupils to teach in a proper manner and that the schoolroom was overcrowded. In bringing this matter to your attention, I am not doing so as a complaint but as a suggestion for the improvement of educational conditions, knowing that same will have the support of the Indian Agent and School Inspector.

However, it would be impossible to have a second teacher without having the school building enlarged by the addition
of another classroom. The building has a floor area of 875 sq.ft. (35 by 25 ft.) and that includes space for a stove, two cupboards; a lunch-table, four aisles and a platform 25 by 5 ft., leaving a very limited space for the twenty-two seats and desks now in use.

Regarding the "Follow-up System" referred to in your letter, I can supply you with particulars regarding each one of my former pupils if separate individual reports are required. Generally, they are married at an early age, especially the girls, and carry on with household duties and the making of baskets etc. as they have learned at their homes when very young. A few leave home to do common labour and household work in nearby towns but as a general rule, they soon return to this or some nearby Reserve, are married and thereby a new home is established.

Before bringing this letter to an end, I wish to say that I have always found the Indian children to be as bright and intelligent as the average white ones and I like my position as their teacher. I welcome this opportunity of writing to you in a personal manner and thank you for your kind invitation to have me communicate with you at any time, an offer I will be only too glad to take advantage of when I have an occasion to do so. I wish to assure you that I will always be glad to carry out any instructions you may give or give you any information you may require and that I can supply.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Jan. 25th. I am very interested in the proposed introduction of manual training and vocational instruction into the educational programme of Indian Schools.

Dear Mr. Hey:

I appreciate the letter which I have just received from you. It is a satisfaction to me to know that you are Supt.of our work. Manual training has a great future as an educative art. It has a special appeal and worth to Indians. In introducing it I hope you will give their own crafts precedence.

Indian handicraft has a very strong appeal. A few years ago our Junior Red Cross sent a small present of this work to Winnipeg. On its merits it found its way to Toronto and thence to the International Red Cross Conference at Tokyo. The Japanese requested to keep it and sent us a present in return.

A year ago we prepared our first portfolio for exchange under the Junior Red Cross. Again we had the joy of seeing it approved very well. It went to New Zealand. Some months ago special portfolio was received at Toronto for exchange. Miss Brown, the National Director, surprised us by asking us to accept it under the condition that we send a return. In her letter she said that she had chosen our school from all the schools in Canada that she had special knowledge of. Our Church later commended us that we had been selected from about 800 schools, many being city schools. Last October we sent our return via Winnipeg. It was held there and displayed at the Bay for some days. Our work has mostly been: bead-work, silk-work, knitting, painting, mocassins, and snow-shoes.

I believe that this work has a special place to fill. It is this work which should be followed if manual work is to be stressed. There are Indian women who cannot make a pair of mocassins because their lives in youth were spent in schools away from home where these crafts were not practised. The best snow-shoe makers are the most illiterate. Ask a young graduate from a boarding school to make a moccasin and watch him blush.

The three most valuable sidelines we have followed apart from the above are: stamp-collecting, scrap-book work, and typewriting. All these are appealing to Indians and are assets in themselves.

We must not expect the Indians to make their gifts through us. They will make them when following their own instincts. Inert efforts to conform them by our visions, impulses and anecdotes will always bring the wrong results. The Follow-Up system may reveal this.

Wishing you the very best success in your great work.

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

Honourable Sir,

Your circular letter to the teachers in charge of the Indian schools was received on the 16th Inst. I am anxious to get at once, on your request, also as a proof that I am much interested in the welfare of our poor Indian pupils.

I made a careful perusal of the content of this highly important letter. Sincerely I felt much encouraged because I noticed that our highest official wished to cooperate efficiently with us. Something was being done in the right direction before, but there is much to do yet in the reorganization of this Board.
You are right in stating that most of the teachers in charge of Indian institutions have rendered conscientious and devoted service. That their missionary zeal and self-sacrifice have been much in evidence.

To my humble knowledge I ought to state sincerely that your success will depend pretty nearly entirely on what you say plainly in your lettering:

"Changes will be worked out in cooperation with representatives of the Church and with their approval."

You could not say better. There should be no room for bigotry and fanaticism who are causing hindrances to good work in this said Branch. The missionaries are working steadily without counting their pains for the welfare of the Indians do certainly know what should be done for their welfare. If not much result was obtained in raising the Indians to a satisfactory standard of life, considering the length of time that the Government formed an Indian Dept. is due largely to the lack of co-operation.
of the Officials with the representatives of the Churches and I will add up with the representatives among themselves.

I am very well aware that you have a gigantic task in your hands and it will take much courage and strength of character in order not to be discouraged easily in working for the Indians. We have to work for their welfare often against their own will.

You are entirely right in stating this: "in educational programme provision should be made for a course of study that would enable the pupils to spend at least one third of their time at manual training or vocational instruction." It will require expenses in order to equip schools with necessary material for such manual work, but it should be done anyhow. The right way to go at it is to begin slowly in each school and progress little by little; for example supplying, one year, garden tools, the
tools for woodwork etc. For girls, supply knitting needles, yarn, print etc so that they can knit stockings, mittens and make their dresses, aprons etc. A hand sewing machine should be supplied to each school etc etc. I might state that if you have not married teachers you will have hard job in your Day school to have manual training done for both boys and girls. It is very important that teachers have their residence on the Reserve otherwise they cannot follow up their pupils. They should have access to the farm stables, shop of the Farm instructor. For the school curriculum it is ridiculous to follow up the course of the Province we live in as the needs of the Indians are not the same as those of the White People. A summary course of studies should be planned by the experts of your dept of Education. Although lots should be left to the initiative and judgment of the teacher. As you state correctly you cannot make lists.
changes. It would not be wise neither.

Some of your Indian agents should be trained not to only reduce expenses but to supply promptly the necessary things for the good operation of the schools and reserves. There should be more supervision in order to find out if schools are equipped properly and promptly. I do not here want to accuse anybody in particular.

It is in the mind of some of your officials that the teachers should be just confined to their school rooms, not to have any other work to perform on the Reserve. This is false. Teachers should be the very soul of the Reserve. Thus the necessity to hire only teachers well recommended by the Church Representatives and well qualified for this important employment.

Regarding your "Follow-up System" I might say that it is of the greatest importance for your Indian Affairs Board to do this "Follow-up" as it will enable
you to see where the mistakes are made either in the Boarding schools or the Day schools so that they may be corrected. What I will suggest is to have a "questionnaire" not too complicated and short once in a while sent to the teachers of the Day schools regarding the best means to obtain the maximum success in such a purpose. Also to the Principals of Boarding Schools in order to find out the best means to accomplish a certain work. Questions can be sent also to the Representatives of the Church for the same purpose. By having the ideas of many you can pick up the best and suitable in order to put them in function.

I think that the teachers on the Indian Reserve could keep you posted on the conduct and the work done by the children after they left school both of the Boarding and Day school pupils as well. A blank could be supplied by the "Indian Affairs Branch" to that effect so that the teachers would fill it in at
least once a year.

The both Boarding and Day schools should operate and are necessary, regulations should be made to define which children should attend the Boarding School in the Agency or the Day School on the Reserve. In small places the Boarding School is ruining the Day School as it is making a huge campaign, a mad run after pupils for the said Boarding School. In my opinion children under 12 years of age who are not orphan, feeble, abandoned should assist to the Day School on their Reserve. For this point also you can get in touch with the Church Representative who could give you suggestions on the matter. Something very serious must be done in order to have Day School pupils attend school more regularly. That is a great proposition.

I have over twenty years experience in teaching and have also been in business
for over fifteen years trading with Indians of the North West Territories, Alberta and Saskatchewan. I understand the character and the needs of the Indians very well. It is a sad thing to see how the Indians have been abused by some traders and merchants robbing them of their work, cattle, horses etc. Now the Dept. hope to give relief to them who should be very well off. This is another thing that the Dept. shall see to in a wise manner.

In the medical branch of your Dept., something must be done in order that the enormous sum of money spent each year for the sanitary and health condition of the Indians, produce a better result. Since about 70% of the Indian children do not reach the age of going to school, dying before being 15 years old, there is surely a very great reform to work out. Medicines that are sent to the agents shall not be retained at the Agency but distributed right off when they are needed.
I am living here with my family on the Big Island Lake Indian Reserve in north-western Saskatchewan, right in the bush. Indians are full-blooded Indians. Some wearing their long hair and quite a few are still going keeping their old traditions. The Day School is open since 2 years. Everything here is at a beginning. The Reserve is about 42 square miles. If you wish to make a trial test of some kind for a Day School I will be pleased to co-operate with you very heartily.

One thing I like to bring to your attention is not to try to make White People with the Indians but just lift them up to a better standard of living mentally and physically and this in remaining Indians.

Of course I am writing all this on the strength of your letter stating: "I want you to feel perfectly free to communicate with me at any time." I hope that this
Letter in order! Your field of action is so vast comprising the whole Dominion and the needs of our Agency is sometimes contrary of another making things very complicated to settle up. The wants of the agencies and reserves are not always alike. Pretty much every agency has their own particularities.

Wishing you success in your new field of action and hoping to have the pleasure to read you soon again,

I am,
Yours Respectfully,

This is why we have made it our duty since several years to train the girls of this school in household science, as much as circumstances allowed; this explains also why we lately solicited, and "easily obtained" from the Department, the means of purchasing a few tools and a little wood to

If it were suitable in size and had more accommodations the Indian girls could be invited to come several times a week, after they have left school, and under the direction of a special teacher devoted merely to post-school work, they could continue their course in domestic science: viz. cooking, sewing, gardening, etc. and be incited to good behavior in their respective employments; their "postschool" teacher could see by herself, either by visits to their homes or skilful inquiries, how they profit by the lessons received, and search means of improving their ways if necessary.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your communication No-150-60, received, inviting my ideas on an educational system of welfare and training for Indians. Although having lived many years with the Indian and having labored educationally and otherwise for some thirty years among them, I feel my knowledge is nevertheless rather provincial which no doubt gave rise to our present educational system, still I feel that it is not impossible to have some kind of a standardized system for the Dominion of Canada as a whole.

Our present system logically has no other end in view, then the ultimate absorbing in time of the Indian within the ranks of the Whites which today is being done; naturally therefore a system of education had to be inaugurated partly on the same base as our Provincial white schools, yet flanked by a strong domestic training, with the whole firmly bound together by sound religious principles thus bringing out everything and developing every part of the soul so that one faculty, or power, may not be developed at the expense of the other, with, of course, due attention given to the education of the heart, the affections and the will.

Such an education, I feel, far surpasses, in the end that of the intellect, since no amount of knowledge can, in so, make a man good, pure, honest or obedient,-this is too often demonstrated by the all too many moral derelicts that have through life menaced sound society by not a few of the world's intellectual "RIGHTS."

If to the above system were added manual training which the Ind Dept., at Ottawa, to date, has refused, if also the system of dole, to our Indians that has so undermined our teaching of thrift, were checked, again if proper supervision by Ind. agents were given to the Ind. home in general,-Eg.-seeing that seed given by the Dept. was really planted, not eaten nor sold, that crops so planted were properly cared for and harvested, likewise inducements held out for tidy thrifty homes, etc., etc., etc.,-if finally a few of the very small reserves could be moved to larger ones, then we would have a system that would open a better road on which the Indian here could more surely walk side by side with his neighbor the white man thus tending to the end I had in view when I inaugurated our present system. Even now under present conditions many of our young Indian boys and girls, in work, thrift, style, dress, habits, etc., etc., far surpass the average whites.

It would here require many pages to explain in detail our present educational system, however a glance over my biannual reports that should be found in the Dept. of Ind. affairs would quickly give you a good insight into this system. Inclosed you will please find a few of our teacher's monthly reports that may explain matters somewhat ----There could be another system based on the fact that it was the intention of the Government to ever keep the Indian as an Indian yet in a somewhat civilized form. In this case I feel apominien standard could be utilized. All Indians of the Maritime provinces might be placed on one Reserve, or for that matter, from four or five provinces, or grouped together by denomination, or tribes, etc., etc., etc.,-then upon these large Reserves churches, schools, hospitals, could be constructed, mills, machineries, woodworking factories, etc., could be erected, farm machinery supplied, etc., thus while carrying out their own craft, they could also become somewhat acquainted with that of the whiteman. In this case a limited academic education, sufficient to carry on their affairs, would be quite enough, since they would have apart their common life while greater attention could then be given to manual training in all kinds of craft work.

Respectfully and humbly submitted for your kind interest,

Yours devoutly,

R.A. HOEY,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Ind. Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Re: Mr. Hoey Esq.,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Your letter January 15th just received, it had been addressed via Barrens River hence the delay we have absolutely no communication with Barrens River in the winter months, via Winnipeg ensures quicker service during winter.

I am very thankful to know that You are deeply interested in regards to our Pupils, this gives me a chance to lay before You our problems here.

First - I am of the same opinion namely that the Indian children ought to have Instructions in Gardening Carpentry and Mechanics the Girls in Sewing Knitting and other Household Duties.

Secondly - The pupils that leave School ought to be helped and encouraged.

But our big problem is this - Our people here are hunters and Trappers, we have helped a few in building of homes and the making of gardens but the majority are still leading a very nomadic life, never home very long they move about continually trying to make a living. This does not give their Children a chance to attend School hence very poor progress, I do not know how long a School has been established here but at least several decades yet there is not one Indian here that speaks or understands English.

This is our tenth year here and we have tried hard, we have tried to get a Truant Officer (as the Parents of Indian Children do not seem to have any control over them) for whenever a child does not wish to go to School it just wont go but without Success. A lot of our Pupils do understand English, yet You cannot get them to talk it outside of School.

I feel that the money spent here could be used to a much better Advantage than it is at present re Education.

There are two Schools here yet a third of the Children belonging to this Reserve never receive any Education as their parents settled about 9 miles northeast from here.
After being ten years on this ground I have come to the conclusion that the only remedy to ensure better education here is this—

To have only One School here and a good One in fact a Boarding School where the Children would stay when the Parents go hunting, there are about one hundred Children here all told, the most of whom receive hardly any education and are dreadfully neglected.

There should never be two Schools of different faiths especially Protestant and Catholic allowed on one Reserve as there is continual friction; for instance here, we are very tolerant and never say anything re the Reds here, yet they tell our people that their religion is wrong those that are married by us are told they are not married at all pictures are given to the people showing them that the only way to heaven is past the pope that Martin Luther with Buddha and others are on their way to hell which is very confusing to the Indian people to say the least.

As the Methodist School was here first and has the most Adherents and as the best way for all concerned would be one School in which all the Children would receive proper attention and care I move that the Charge over this School would be given to the United Church of Canada who would supply about eighty children from their people.

Another item in favor of a Boarding School here would be that the Parents could see their Children be satisfied of their welfare; they never consent to have their children sent out to another Boarding School further by spending their Summer holidays at home they would not be taken out of their environment and could keep in touch with their surroundings, we have seen pupils return from Industrial Schools on to the Reserve (the only place where they could go) absolutely helpless and useless.

Financially it would not cost much more as the two Schools combined now cost as a lot of the food could be grown here quite successfully also fish and quite a bit of meat. Today we are giving our School children for their Midday meal Potatoes (grown) in our garden and Whitefish of which I caught a thousand last fall, we also have about twenty goats half of them milking and some poultry all of these do quite well here.

Pupils graduating from these Schools here would have a good chance to secure work in the different mines here not far from their homes.

I am writing this in haste but would be very glad to furnish You with any particulars that You may be interested in,

Yours very truly

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter with reference to the Educational Programme—Although the general public think the education given to the Indians too abstract and too academic, personally I feel that time spent on the academic portion of the studies, especially English, is very necessary. My reason for this is the English language is essential. With my own pupils, I have found them reluctant to converse with strangers visiting the school, even though I know they understand everything that is said to them. I have struggled to overcome this difficulty by encouraging them to ask questions. I use pictures to illustrate happenings, sport, and scenes in other countries, thus trying to show them how other people live. Most of my pupils have never been farther than 25 miles from the Reserve. I may say here the reluctance to converse is not confined to the pupils of this day school. I have found pupils here on holiday from the Residential Schools have the same handicap, and I feel this is a drawback, for as they grow older they lose their English, instead of becoming more proficient, and so cannot express their thoughts clearly when conversing or making deals with white people—the result, the Indian becomes suspicious even though there is no reason for it.

If the pupils ask questions it shows their minds are working—they are not taking things for granted, and their English is not "parrot fashion."

I have had experience in several New Canadian schools and most decidedly more repetition is needed with Indian scholars—this delays progress.

The Manual Training and Vocational Instruction should help with English as well, if the pupils are encouraged to ask questions and give their ideas.

Manual Training for boys, say from Grade IV onward would be splendid, serving perhaps as an incentive to more regular attendance and advanced study.

I have given much thought to the results of the Residential and Day schools. The Residential School is fine but I do feel it must be quite a hardship for a pupil to return from a school that has every modern convenience to a one room house on the Reserve—this one room housing the whole family—with the most necessary utensils and conveniences lacking. It means the ex-pupil has to completely readjust himself or herself—and in some cases the readjustment results in going back further than if he or she had never left the Reserve.
Would it be advantageous to have pupils attend the Day School until they reach Grade IV? (I do not mean orphan or those who have lost their mother.) I have often thought this might have a stabilizing and disciplinary effect on the parents, causing them to realize their responsibilities toward their children. Some of them think that once a child has reached school age, the responsibility for food, clothing, and shelter lies with the Residential School (and not with the parent) until the child has graduated. If they found their children had to attend the Day School until they reach Grade IV, the Indians would make an effort to see their children were punctual, regular and hardworking at lessons.

I find the Indians are not able to act on their own initiative—they seem to want a guiding hand—but even here their prejudices are aroused, though the guiding hand is all for the good of the Indians.

The Follow-up system should tend to give the ex-pupils the idea the Indian Department is interested in their doing and watching to see if they make good. At present dancing is their chief recreation and the morals of some of the younger generation are not all they should be by a wide margin. If they knew morals were included in the Follow-up report surely this fact would be a great help. The Follow-up system could easily be filled in by the Teacher on the Reserve, using various headings as to number of cattle, horses etc.; acres in crop, married or single, general behaviour, work carried on in summer, in winter etc., forwarded to Ottawa.

It must be taken into consideration that at the present time boys leaving school have nothing to start out with—no horses, no cattle, no implement of any kind, no money, and a very small chance of earning any, so no wonder their morals are at fault—they have nothing to occupy their minds.

If a lantern were placed at the schools, education could be carried on among the older people in the winter by means of slides. These slides can be obtained from the Provincial Govt. at Regina. The lantern could be used for the school children to help in their study of Geography and History.

I trust what I have written may be of some little help to you in your future plans. I have tried my best to get the pupils to be open, straightforward, and honest. The children are not as energetic as other races. I often think this is due to poor living conditions with scarcity of food, as my pupils always seem more alert after their noon meal.

I remain, Sir,

Yours obediently,

Henry Reynolds
Anglican Ind. Day School,
Garden River, Ont.,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your letter of Jan. 15th. to all teachers in
the Indian work was received by me this week, and was read
with great interest, more particularly as it was in entire
opposition to what we had been given to understand would be
the result of the change over in this agency at least.

The school here is a day school and at present
is in a very primary stage the highest grade being Gr. 2.
One of the greatest difficulties on the reserves is with
regard to attendance. Just as soon as a boy or a girl is
beginning to show some progress he or she is so often taken
out of school, and there seems to be no way of making
attendance compulsory. In addition to this the parents on
so many of the reserves are naturally nomads, and pack
up and go on the least excuse. This reserve subsists entirely
by hunting and fishing so there is very little to hold them
within school distance.

This is only the second year that I have had
charge of this particular school, and I was fortunate in
that I followed a man who had been unsuccessful. Though
this meant starting at the beginning with the pupils it also
meant that it was easier to get the interest, and so I have
felt that to a great extent I have the parents behind me, with
exceptions of course, and have had a fairly regular attendance
throughout the year, except for sickness. This year we have
averaged 18 for the whole year.

With regard to manual or vocational training, I
should be greatly interested in any scheme put forward to
encourage this. So far as my girls are concerned I have given
as much time as possible to needlework; all of them except
this year's beginners having mitts, socks, and underwear of
their own making. As I have provided quite a lot of their
clothing through various friends, I have been able to insist
too that this is kept in good repair, by either parents or
pupils. Even the boys have mitts of their own making. In
addition the girls get lessons in dish-washing, sweeping and
cleaning, in connection with the school dinners, besides the
washing of towels and dishtowels. I have always felt that
the day schools have the advantage in this respect, as it is possible to teach using practically the same tools which they would have to use at home, the wash-board for instance. I have applied to the W.A., asking them to provide two suits of underwear such as would be provided for the same children if they attended a boarding school undertaking to supervise the washing and repair of the same, as a regular part of the school-work. However nothing has been forth-coming as yet, and there are not the facilities in the present school building for further laundry experiments.

When I first came to Canada I started a manual instruction class in my school on the prairie, and the boys there were very interested in making quite a number of articles. We had two quite neat little cupboards, one as a museum with glass doors which the boys had made, and every boy contrived to have something, varying from a knife-and-fork-box to a radio table for his parents at Christmas. I was very fortunate there in that the trustees provided all the tools I asked for and made me a very solid work-bench. Naturally I should not think of comparing the work with that of an expert carpenter, but the boys and the parents were very proud of the results.

Again with the present building such work would not be practical, but as the school is in such dangerous condition that the agent advised dismissing the pupils in the event of a high wind, lest it should collapse on them, I feel sure that plans must be afoot for a new one, which will I hope have a basement.

So far as is possible I can assure you of cooperation in any schemes for improving the education in the Indian schools. At the same time I agree with you that in the day schools at least, the instruction given compares very favourably with that given in the rural schools of the Dominion.

With many thanks for your letter and its note of encouragement,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Gora Merritt.

Dear Mr. Schuetze:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant and to state, by way of comment, that I appreciate very fully your prompt and courteous reply to my circular letter of January 15th.

I am writing at this time to state that the suggestions contained in your communication will be very carefully and sympathetically considered. I should state, however, that it is not at all likely that we can seriously consider the desirability of building a residential school in your district or in any other district, at any time in the immediate future. You will readily appreciate that the money at our disposal these days is somewhat limited, and, in addition to this, of course, the Indian Act definitely prevents us from grouping pupils of different denominations in the same institution.

I was glad to notice your reference to the midday meal, for which provision is made in your school. I am particularly interested in your reference to goats. I have been suggesting to a number of Indian agents, since I came to the Department, the desirability of having goats on the reserve.

Dear Sir,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter, which was delivered February 18. I appreciate its common sense and gentleness.

My two years' experience with the Indians cannot be of great help to you. Too bad you sent us word to the Reverend Father in charge; you would have suggestions this time, and up to date.

However, I'll write:

1. Our teaching is too academic. I think so, for the class we teach. Such was our training, every one of us; but it is very different to be in contact with the Indian mind.

2. One-third devoted to manual training. I cordially approve. That is what we do.

3. Some change in the Program. It is already on a low standard, in the primary grades. I think at least compared to the East. Children of the East, both Americans and Canadians have had some training.
before school age; they have ideas, notions already, they speak our language; they are interested, and so are their parents; they attend regularly, they have ambition, they memorize easily, just the opposite for the Indian child. Dullness, poor health, illiterate parents, no ambition, irregular attendance. What can we do especially with the day scholars? The inmates have more chance, and they get ahead. Dear Sir,

Your kind letter of January 25th was received. Your interest in our work and in the welfare of the Indian population is appreciated and encouraging.

In the work on the Reservation I find vocational instruction of great importance. Records show that no pupil has gone beyond the sixth grade at about the age of thirteen the children become restless and difficult to instruct. They marry early or do whatever work can be found so that the academic work during school life seems unimportant in comparison with the fundamental rules of health, sanitation and a knowledge of the
native handicrafts. They are eager to read while at school but I see no evidence of this interest prompting the ownership of books in the home.

Our equipment for manual training and sewing is limited. We bought some tools and materials with prize money from the local fair, where the children marched in the parade and had an exhibit of school work.

Your suggestion of a "Follow-up system" is very interesting. It should be a wonderful help in the community life which is at a standstill here.

Recently I wrote to the Department of Indian Affairs asking for a residence in connection with the school so that I can take a more active part in the welfare of the Reservation. I drive ten miles daily to school so I have little opportunity to cultivate a community club or any welfare work at all.
Your Department has been very kind to me during my six years in the Stoney Point School. I will welcome any plan or opportunity to help the young people of the Reservation for there is a great work to be done here among people who haven't even a weekly church service.

Hoping that I may be of service to you and your Department.

Yours sincerely,

Mary E. Anderson,
Forest, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I was greatly pleased to be asked for suggestions regarding the improvement in the welfare of our Indians.

We try to follow as closely as possible the programme set down for the white schools as well as imparting Christian Doctrine and spending three hours per week in Domestic Science work. Our Domestic Science instruction comes under the following headings:
knitting, making mats and quilts, patching, visiting homes and lectures. We are supplied fifteen dollars' worth of material yearly which is too small to cover a year's work. The Department will not supply the day schools with sewing machines. This means the pupil has to take the article to some home to be sewn and when not supervised is often unsatisfactory.

The boys follow the same course as the girls and this work does not appeal to them, and I might say is of little use to them in after life as the women on this Reserve take care of it. The Indian boy loves hard work and some of my pupils
have made rough but very good imitations of snow-shovels, steam-shovels, animals, Indian heads, boats, violins, aeroplanes, a gun (that really shoots) etc.

Some of the older Indians on my Reserve do lovely work now. What could they do with proper training?

I think that a more thorough course of Manual Training and Domestic Science should be carried out in our schools. This could be accomplished by employing a teacher to give three lessons per week. In this way the same teachers could take the classes in the three schools in this section, namely - Oromocto, St. Mary's and Kingsclear.

Dear Sir:

I received your circular letter and am very glad that there is an increasing interest on the part of the Dept. of Indian Affairs in the educational welfare of the Indian boys and girls.

Although I have been but two years in this particular work, I have a great deal of interest in it and in the people themselves. Your letter contained suggestions of possible changes in the days to come in regards to the educational policy now in force.

I am taking the opportunity, therefore, to express to you some of the ideas I have formed in the short time in the work. These are very likely not at all new, and no doubt have been expressed before, but I submit them for what they may be worth—as criticisms—constructive at least.

It is to be understood that what is said here is in relation to the conditions existing in this village and others of a similar type. This is a fishing village—always has been and always will be; the boys and men are engaged solely in making a living by means of fishing and trapping. There cannot be any other means of earning a living by the people here. The terrain does not permit it; logging is finished in the immediate vicinity and since the ground is boggy and muskeg, the possibility of farming is entirely out of the question.
I heartily agree with the suggestion of some type of vocational instruction, but you can see that from the above existing conditions a choice is hardly available.

In day schools such as the one here where there are some thirty-three pupils, ranging from six years to seventeen, and in grades from one to eight, the task seems even a more difficult one. It would be a physical impossibility to expect one teacher, no matter how capable, to teach, in addition to scholastic studies, such training as mechanics, carpentry, etc., to say nothing of cooking and household science among the girls in the school.

The fact that there are Residential Schools in various parts of the country does not minimize the difficulty. Just to send some or all of the pupils to a school such as that for some kind of vocational training after a few terms in their village day school would not fairly solve the problem.

There is, however, to me at least, a manner in which the difficulty might be solved, or at least smoothened into a solution.

There has always been advocated at some time or other that there should be some type of follow-up system of school graduates, especially those of a residential school where the graduates are supposed, as a result of their training to be more fitted to take a place in the world.

It is however, a well known fact that there is not much of a place for him or her in the white man's world—at least not until our white social system opens up a place for them. Therefore the logical conclusion to arrive at would be that there should be a place for them among their own people. This however presents the question that it is not fair to expect the Indian to return to his people and work among them for nothing.

I am of course still bearing in mind that all this is
bearing on the education of the Indian child who is attending the day school in his or her own village.

Therefore would it not be an idea worth considering to have suitably trained young men and women chosen from the particular village to which they belong return there to take up the work of training the boys and girls in the day schools along the lines most suited to the employment at present of the majority of people in the villages?

As I have already stated, the work as a result of geographical surroundings in this village is limited to trapping and fishing. The latter brings to mind the thought of training in carpentry, boat-building, mechanics, and navigation for the boys. I added navigation to the list since only a few months ago a regulation was enforced whereby no man may act as skipper of a fish packer without owning a certificate obtained by examination—and this entails instruction. This regulation affects a number of Indians, one at least in this village.

The problem arises as to fair remuneration for such a native instructor. That point, however, does not enter here save to state that too large a remuneration would have as disastrous an effect as an unfair one. Surely a fair estimate could be arrived at.

I have been stressing training for boys—certainly the idea could be evolved along suitable lines for girls.

I am not advocating that such instruction replace the present, but I do submit that one-third of the school time could be given over to this training, with the entire structure supervised as to time, regularity, etc., by the white teacher in charge of the day school.

Such a plan would be feasible all over whether the employ-
many of the people was fishing, farming, lumbering or mining. It would mean a drastic change in curriculum, but I heartily agree with you that the curriculum could stand it.

No doubt the idea arises that such a plan would take years before it could be carried out. I do not think so. I sincerely believe that it could be put into force in a very short time. In almost every village some young man or woman with sufficient knowledge now could be the pioneers. I do know that in this village, carpentry and boat-building could be started any time proper equipment was furnished and the necessary arrangements were made.

The above is written only after some considerable thought on the matter and from actual observations made while engaged in the work. All is submitted in the spirit of co-operation and with all assurances of good will,

yours very sincerely,

J.A. Findlay
Teacher, Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

I fully agree with the opinion expressed in the fourth paragraph of your letter. I have been teaching in the day schools on Lake Winnipeg for eighteen years now. I have seen boys come back from various schools with diplomas obtained in various subjects but I have yet to see these same lads have a chance to utilize their advanced education. A pupil who has shown exceptional talent should not be allowed to come back to a reserve where his or her only means of obtaining a living is by fishing or trapping.

I believe that for schools situated in northern parts or rather isolated spots a programme of studies consisting of reading writing and useful arithmetic, with some knowledge of his country (Canada) is sufficient.

I trust, Mr. Hoey, that I have not been too outspoken and feel sure that you will notice that the above remarks only apply to schools with the same surroundings as ours. I have always thought the world of my little Indian kiddies and anything which will lead to their benefit is the only object I have in mind.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I was very pleased to receive your letter of January 25th, 1937 and to note that you wish teachers to feel free to communicate with you.

I have only been in Indian work for five years, but here are many suggestions that I have longed to make with regard to changes in the educational programme.

As regards manual training and vocational instruction, I heartily agree with you. It is only about one child out of every hundred who goes beyond the eighth grade in the Day School. There are many things that could be taken off the course of study and the time given to some training more beneficial. In the above school the boys are in the majority and older than the girls. I would like to teach the boys gardening while the girls knit, hook rugs, do raffia work. On this particular Reserve there is no farming but all attempt gardening to the extent of planting & harvesting potatoes only.

All the children are fond of
reading, but there are many selections in their Readers that they cannot possibly understand. We have a pre-primer for Indians and I should very much like to see a whole new set of Readers put out for them.

This not being a farming country, the Indians depend entirely upon hunting and trapping for a livelihood. At the beginning of March, they move to the trapping grounds with their families and do not return until the end of May. The boys learn to trap and the girls help with the skinning and cooking. I agree with this, for the Boarding School Boy cannot trap when he returns to the Reserve. However, it is also impossible for them to make up three months work during the month of June. As a remedy for this, I would suggest that the School be closed for the long holiday during the 'Rat Season' and kept open throughout the Summer, except for a short period at the end of July and the beginning of August when it is far too hot for School. Of course, this would not be so pleasant for the Teachers, but we except a few disadvantages when we enter the work.
Re your "Follow-up System", I am afraid that you will meet several obstacles. The Boarding School children often go hundreds of miles away when they leave School. The children from this School usually stay on the Reserve for a while and then go to points on the Hudson Bay Railway where it is impossible to keep track of them as there is no agent, minister or teacher. So far, I have been unable to think of any way in which this work can be accomplished.

Another thing that I would like to see, is work provided for orphans leaving Boarding Schools instead of sending them back to the Reserves.

May I wish you success in all your undertakings.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I was indeed grateful for your kind and most encouraging letter. I was deeply interested in your remarks about vocational instruction. Undoubtedly, it is the only way we can be of any definite service to the Indian race.

It is especially necessary for the girls who marry at an early age, untrained and depending entirely on a local store for clothing, stockings etc purchased at an exorbitant price.

Knowing how drab and colorless their homes would be, I have been working out a plan with the school girls and boys along the lines mentioned in your letter.

We began last year with the yarn sent up by the Government. For the past few years the yarn had been given to the children to take home. Whether or not it had been used for the children I could not ascertain. One thing was certain...
The school girls could not knit. There were very few needles but that obstacle was soon overcome. One energetic father cut wire into correct lengths and laboriously filed until needles of the right size were produced. Soon other fathers did the same and the chief made larger wooden needles for the beginners.

We worked at recess, dinner hour and on Friday afternoons. Girls from seven to ten years made scarves. Girls from ten to fifteen made mittens. Mittens were also made for the boys. This gave additional practice.

After Christmas I bought flannelette and each girl cut, basted and sewed a pair of bloomers. This was followed by white cotton which was made into handkerchiefs hemstitched and embroidered.

They were so eager and learned so quickly that a more extensive program was planned for this year. We started again with the yarn supplied by the Government. Girls from seven to ten years knit mittens or sweaters. Girls from ten to fourteen years knit short socks. They became very popular on the Reserve and odd women who could knit appeared with socks.
like the school girls.

I had purchased enough pretty print for a dress for every girl. They had a choice of color and pattern. Every girl made the entire dress herself with my supervision only. On this Reserve, the fashion has been a front opening on the dresses lapped over about three inches and fastened with a pin. The school dresses were all made with a high neck line and a neat opening on the back. This style has been copied too and all dresses made since Christmas have the back opening instead of the front.

Many small pieces were left over. The three oldest girls became interested in hope chests (Meatli's milk boxes painted) and then for future use. First, we decided on quilts. The pieces left over from the dresses were used for this purpose. Flour bags supplied the backs and we are now waiting for the cotton bats.

In the meantime, the girls have bleached, hemmed and embroidered flour bags which have made very pretty table cloths. Flour bags are also being used for one pair of pillow cases, two pairs stencilled back curtains and dish towels.
The boys lack material but they are not forgotten. There is a coping saw, hammer and other tools for them. We use the wood from the Arctic biscuit boxes. So far we have only made door stops, rabbit carts and other small toys. These are sandpapered and painted.

The oldest boy is making small furniture. He measures accurately and is taught to do it just as carefully as if he had enough wood for large furniture. They learn to use the English names for the tools.

Recently in our English class one little fellow said "I can saw. I can hammer" — and after a moment's thought — "I can axe." Nothing the matter with the little carpenter — just our English language at fault.

I would greatly appreciate some suggestions for the boys work — useful articles for an Indian home.

Yours truly,

In reviewing the work of the Residential School for the past year, the impression persists that, on the West Coast, the existence of Indian Residential Schools can only be justified to the Canadian public by the extent to which these schools can be made the means of equipping the boys for obtaining a better means of livelihood in the industries peculiar to their Reserve location, and the girls with a domestic training which will find expression in dissatisfaction with, and determination to better, the present deplorable housing and living conditions on their home Reserves.

No comparison can be drawn between the functions of the Indian Schools and the white schools. In the latter, the children, for the most part, come from well-earned-for homes, accustomed to a healthy home atmosphere and home comfort, if not luxury. The home example constantly before them inculcates habits of industry, initiative and individual responsibility, and knowledge, if not always the practical observance, of the principles of Christian citizenship.

All this is lacking in the environment of the Indian child before he comes to the school. Moreover, the non-moral conditions of life in an Indian community with which every Indian child is familiar and from which he has never been protected, lays upon the Indian school the responsibility of inculcating in the Indian child a moral standard which is the antithesis of all his home experiences.

This condition is pressed home when one is acquainted with the case of a little Indian chap of seven, who, after coming to school, betrayed knowledge of sexual matters far beyond his years and said he had learned these things at home. As is only possible, when one considers the source of his knowledge, his reaction to the knowledge was anything but good. When the parents were reprimanded with their reply was: "It doesn't do him any harm. He has to learn these things sometime".

The Residential School system is the only system that can bring powerful and lasting influence to bear on the subversive tendencies and habits of the Indian people. Indian education in the residential schools, under what must essentially be a missionary-minded staff, must embrace every phase of uplift. The social and moral problem is not the only one. The economic problem is of equal importance.

Where the natural sources of industry of the Indian, fishing and trapping, excepting only those engaged in agricultural pursuits in territories adapted thereto, is rapidly, and with impunity, being encroached upon by better equipped and organised white people and Japanese, and where in these industries the Indian is being exploited and discriminated against, as there is ample evidence to prove, the function of giving the Indian vocational training to enable him to compete with less handicap in the struggle for existence is one that the residential school, adequately equipped for this purpose, can fulfill. A present investment of Government moneys at this critical stage of Indian economic history for the better equipment of residential schools to provide specialized Indian vocational training would yield very definite returns to the Dominion.

All Indian Residential Schools have these peculiar problems to solve in an individual way. We, at Ahousaht, are primarily interested in the fishing industry. The West
Coast Indian, in common with all Canadian Indians, unfitted by nature for competition and progressive organisation in industry, is rapidly losing out to the Japanese fishermen, and an industry which, in former years, yielded to the Indian an adequate living is now dwindling until few are able to provide themselves with new equipment to replace the worn-out. Under these circumstances the Indians can look forward to nothing else than a complete submersion under the powerful forces arrayed against them. We are in process of organising at the school the means to withstand the economic submersion of the West Coast Indian, and with the assistance of Government, we hope to equip the Indian boys with the means of livelihood and the knowledge that will permit them to enter into fairer competition.

We have been fortunate in obtaining substantial Government appropriations during the past year for the erection of buildings and for building improvement which will assist the school in being of better service to the Indian community through the training of the young generation, but much more is needed to bring the school to competent functioning capacity.

We have had a year of splendid discipline in the school and one cannot speak too highly of the devotion of the staff to almost continuous duty. The freer intermingling of the sexes in social contact has tended greatly towards the elimination of the unhealthy mental attitude to which Indian children by their home experiences are rendered prone, and which timid and fearful restrictions cannot do anything but emphasise.

The class-room work received a good report from the School Inspector, but the experience of former years tends to indicate that the academic work should not be unduly emphasised. The several graduates from this school to High School have made no good use of their opportunities and it is evident that the greatest lasting good can be derived by local training commensurate with the opportunities afforded school graduates in their home environment and on their own Reserves. On the recommendation of the Inspector the higher grades are now on a half-day classroom and half-day vocational training basis.

That the pupils appreciate the home atmosphere of the school is indicated by the reluctance of the older boys and girls to leave school. One of the older boys, whose age of nearly 18 made it impossible for him to be kept on the school roll any longer, came to the Principal before he was discharged and begged him to tell his father "in a polite way" that he could not be discharged. One boy, after his age necessitated his discharge, came voluntarily to the school and worked for his board for the succeeding six months until he found occupation fishing. Some of the older girls already express their regret at the time for their compulsory discharge draws near. Residential school work would show increased value, especially in the all-important sphere of vocational training; were the age of discharge raised from sixteen, as at present, to eighteen. One can only view with impatience the prospects before school graduates, and look forward with longing to the time when the boys can graduate from the school to useful industrial work and the girls to comfortable and healthy homes.

The C.I.T. and Tunis Groups and the Easter Bible-study camp outings, together with regular school talks on the intimacy and daily necessity of Divine Association, have broadened the spiritual outlook of the pupils.
The problem of recruiting pupils is one that is causing us much concern, as it is causing concern to other Protestant residential schools. It would be greatly desirable were the Government to lay down specific and indiscriminate regulations governing applications for admission of Indian pupils to the schools operated by the different Churches catering to Indian education. Under the present somewhat ambiguous conditions it would definitely appear that an Indian with Roman Catholic affiliations or antecedents has no privilege of assuming Protestant allegiance and having his children educated in a Protestant school, however much he may desire to do so.

MISSION WORK.

The experiences of any Indian missionary constitute a succession of "kicks and halpences", of ups and downs. One cannot undertake this work with a myopic view and remain sane. Only when one remembers that Christianity has had hardly more than a half century to loosen the death-grip of paganism, can one view with toleration, if hardly with satisfaction, the decided progress Indians have made during their short experience of Christian influence, surrounded, as they are, by a modern civilization affording them anything but a good example of the efficacy of Christianity.

One can only briefly recount experiences setting forth both sides of the eternal fight between the forces of pagan darkness and Christian light. Can one credit the circumstances confronting an Indian Agent in an unexpected visit to a Reserve on the East Coast in this enlightened Dominion of ours and in this twentieth century? He arrived to find the people congregated in one house where a man was lying sick. Two women were at the feet of the bunk holding the sick man's feet, a length of the long rope-like seaweed found on the coast was knotted loosely around the neck of the sick man and two men at the head of the bed were preparing to pull taut the rope and strangle the supposedly flinching life out of the body. An examination by the Agent disclosed simply a severe bowel congestion and medicine had the sick man sitting up and well on the way to recovery in a few hours. It must be said that the reserve to which these people belonged had never come under Protestant mission influence.

A brighter view is revealed in an Indian home at Ahousaht Village. Here an Indian girl, formerly discharged from the school with incurable T.B., with no other prospect for her than to die in the midst of uncomfortable Reserve surroundings and leave her infection as a legacy to her Indian relatives and friends, lay dying in her humble home. But her lingering hours are brightened and her path made clear by the singing of favourite hymns by her school-going friends and by the prayer and ministration of the missionary, which banished all fear of a pagan unknown and carried her on her way to the meeting with her Heavenly Father with a child's simple confidence.

In the darkness again we tell of the destruction of three full-grown and bearing apple trees which grew in the yard of the little house in which the girl died. Pagan superstition prompted the father to cut down the trees, which had nominally belonged to the dead girl, and burn all her small possessions when she had passed on and had no further use for them.

Continuing in darkness, the infant child of this girl, born to an atmosphere of disease, lingering hopelessly for some months in the care of the aged grandparents. In one
corner of the shack lies the father of the baby and the husband of the dead girl suffering from a revolting skin disease covering the whole body; a disease which hospital examination failed to diagnose. The baby died and the grandparents, their pagan superstition overriding the protests of the sick father, hurried the little body away immediately after death to burial without the knowledge of the Mission.

The marriage of this young couple was a tragedy. The young husband had been one of the healthiest and most athletic of school graduates, the young wife far advanced in T.B. Why was the marriage permitted? What else could be done in a case where the union had already been consummated by co-habitation and where our antiquated social laws provide no legal control over such cases? It was a choice of two evils, a choice which every Indian missionary is continually called upon to make. The traditional tribal influence of the elder generation, still steeped in pagan custom, which not only permits but encourages disregard of the Christian and legal marriage relationship, is an evil that is being fought with all the precept at the command of the residential school, and the fight is being slowly but surely won.

Emerging into light again, we mention a summons to the missionary at six o'clock in the morning to go to the village where an Indian child had died during the night. The absence of mourners and of the little rough box at the home caused no perplexity as West Coast Indian custom requires the removal of a body from the home immediately after death. On reaching the little Mission Church on the hillside the coffin was found laid on the steps outside the door and the mourners waiting for Christian service.

Is Indian Mission work worth while? Immeasurably so. Cavilling cynics, from the shallowness of their perception, continue to reiterate that "the only good Indian is a dead one", and that the Indian problem can best be solved by a negative policy ensuring the obliteration of the race. Could the great need of these simple children of God, appalled and confused as they are by the sudden imposition on their primitive paganism of a devastating civilization the inconsistencies of which are perplexing even to the humanity that has built it up over a millennium of time, be brought home to the great Christian body that compose's our Church and our Dominion, there would not be lacking forceful influences, efficiency and means to obliterate, not the Indian race, but the conditions that now lay that race "at our gate, full of sore".

An outstanding event during our past missionary year was the visit of Rev. Arthur Barner, D.D. The Spiritual native prompting, and the devotional consciousness aroused in our little Indian world by his visit cannot fail to have lasting good influence. We are looking forward to Dr. Barner's next visit.

West Coast Indian Vocational Training.

The Ahousaht Indian school is situated on the Island of Flores off the West Coast of Vancouver Island, about half way up the coast. It is a unit of the West Coast Indian Agency, with office at Port Alberni. This agency includes a number of small reserves located in fishing villages along the west coast, the total population numbering about 1700, all engaged in fishing, with the possible exception of some few around Port Alberni, who are, or could be, engaged in lumbering, employed by the large mills.

The fishing activity as it applies to Indians is largely the catch of salmon and cod. Gasoline-propelled boats are used and the fish are caught at various seasons of the year by spoon trolling and by seine netting. The approximate value of new equipment for a fishing boat employing two or three men, such as is adaptable to Indian fishing, and such as is used by the Japanese, is $2000.00. This includes the value of the boat. Fishing activity can be engaged in practically the whole year, with the exception of part of November and December.

The fish are sold off the fishing boats to purchasing scows anchored in certain harbours and movable from place to place. The fish are then collected from the scows into packing boats, that convey them to the canneries or to Canadian or United States ports for sale.

To indicate the competition that is operating against Indian interests, a brief survey of conditions is given.

It can be said, I think, without possibility of dispute, that, although the Japanese have been excluded by Government provision from certain coastal waters, a conservative estimate would be that 75% of the capitalisation of, and labour in, the fishing industry on the West Coast from Ucluelet to Kyuquot is controlled by Japanese. The Japanese fishing industry is controlled by a very efficient Co-operative organisation, to which all Japanese fishermen belong, presumably under what is known as the Imperial Trading Company, the local organisation having headquarters at Tofino, under the name of the Tofino and Clayoquot Co-operative Association. This organisation owns their own scows and packers, modern in every respect. The pooled profits of the organisation is put back into improved equipment and advanced to the fishermen members to finance new boats and equipment. The Japanese fishing boats are therefore up-to-date in equipment and all diesel motosed. The Indian fishermen, with their indifferent boats and equipment are compelled to sell their fish to the Japanese packers, for which they are paid the market price. This obviously reacts to the increased power and financial strength of the Japanese organisation, as the packing and sale profits must go through Japanese co-operative channels. The only result can be the steady deterioration of the industry as an asset to Indian livelihood, as the returns are too meagre to permit of purchasing of new equipment or the

While some of the Japanese purchasing depots are under white management, there can be no question that the operations are directly under Japanese control.

The situation from Kyuquot north on the West Coast is substantially the same, except that here the control rests in a Finnish Co-operative society, operating under the same conditions as already described.

One possible solution of the Indian problem represented by these conditions would be to set aside certain coastal waters for the exclusive use of Indian fishermen. However, here we would have the extension of special privilege, which is seldom of lasting good to industry, and it would do little to benefit the Indian except to possibly ensure him his usual hand-to-mouth subsistence.

The other, and a progressively constructive solution is to build up the Indian industry so that it can stand on its own feet and operate under favourable conditions with its competitors. To do this an Indian co-operative would have to be formed. It is generally known that this cannot be developed with the control resting with the Indians themselves. They are simply not as yet capable of organisation or co-operation self-controlled. A packer would have to be provided for the conveyance of fish and several seasonal scow depots provided at various points. However, the advantage of securing the additional profits of such an innovation to the Indian co-operative would undoubtedly become a self-supporting economic asset, as has been amply proven by the operations of the competitive organisations. One such packer could take care of all the Indian catch. This would have to be done under Indian Department supervision, but the initial expense entailed would be amply warranted in the setting of the Indians on a permanent and satisfactory economic basis, tending towards secured independence, as opposed to the present definite downward trend of Indian fishing industry leading inevitably to Government support and the further decadence of the Indian race.

The function of the West Coast Residential school has its share in this proposal. Let me emphasise that the sole possible occupation of all the West Coast Indians is fishing. No School devoting much of its training and activity to agriculture or stock raising seedbeds can be of any benefit to West Coast pupils in establishing them in their natural industry on an equal footing with competitors.

What is needed at Ahousaht, as a centre for the training of West Coast Indians, is the establishing of an adequate and competent training school (in combination with necessary academic studies) with efficient and organised teaching under special instructors in boat building and care and repair, and in the
Indian Residential School
Ahousaht, B.C.

practical care and understanding of small-boat marine engines.

Pupils, as they leave school should have available to them boats constructed by the school and equipped to provide means of industry for two or more pupils to each boat.

Under the co-operative plan suggested, where the supervision of the Department would be in evidence, these pupils would continue to be supervised in their industry and could, under normal conditions, repay by yearly instalments, the cost of the boat and the equipment. In this way, once the scheme was in satisfactory operation, it would be self-supporting.

To put the scheme into operation, more facilities would have to be provided at the school in the matter of buildings and staff. There is no doubt that a new school will have to be built in the next few years if this school is to continue in operation. When this is decided it would be advantageous to rebuild with the above object of specialized vocational instruction in view.

The present income of the Indians from fishing, with the disadvantages under which they work, is insufficient to either provide new equipment or to repair the old. It is obvious that, if such conditions continue, it will not be long before the Indians will have no equipment whatever for fishing, and the industry, except insofar as work would be provided seasonally at the canneries, would cease to be a means of support. The idleness of the young men of the Ahousaht Village that is now evidenced is sufficient proof that the means to engage in an industry that is quite open to them are not to hand.

Of particular importance to the success of this scheme of practical economic rehabilitation is the fact that any such scheme must have not only the backing but the actual supervision of the Government.

I have only time to briefly outline the conditions and the means of betterment at present. The objection to it, of course, is that it is going to cost money. The answer to that is that the expense is an economic investment for the future saving of a much greater expenditure. Had the Indians engaged in fishing and trapping in northern areas been accorded some measure of protection and had their means of trade been supervised by the Government, we would not now be facing the situation of loss of support from the natural resources which have hitherto contributed to the support of these Indians, with no other means of support possible in the country which is their natural habitat.
