Dear Mr. Hoey,

The delay in answering your letter of Feb 20th is accounted for by the fact that we only receive mail here once in 10 days. I had, however, been writing a letter to you, consequent to receipt of your circular letter of January 15th, during such time as I could spare from the many duties around an institution such as this.

May I introduce myself to you? You may remember me submitting a report on T.B. conditions among the Indians when you were in the Manitoba cabinet, and when I was United Church missionary at Poplar River on Lake Winnipeg, a report in which the late Dr. David Stewart was very much interested and about which he corresponded with me, and which you kindly acknowledged, and intimated that it might be used in an effort to have the Federal Government form some policy of control. I have for years been deeply interested in Indian economic conditions and was able to institute the innovation of having the Federal Government send supplies to the Poplar River Reserve to be paid for by the Indians out of their treaty money. This was carried on for some four years while I was there and spread to other Reserves in that locality, effecting a saving on actual computation of over $200 to the Indians, not taking into effect the better prices obtainable for their furs on account of being less dependent on trading credit. I hope this system is still operative.

By way of further introduction I may say that there is still a turf fire waiting for me in my old home in Co. Tyrone, although I was born in Fermanagh, a fact which you may, perhaps, better appreciate.

I appreciate very much your letter of January 15th. I am certainly of the opinion, which I have pressed upon the Department for a number of years, that it is only in training the Indian population to better means and habits of industry, and (just as important) in adequately and authoritatively supervising their industrial efforts and their markets, that we can avoid the greater part of them becoming, in the not distant future, an economic encumbrance to the Government. The situation here on the Coast is not as yet so acute as in Manitoba. There the fishing industry on Lake Winnipeg was at one time a lucrative source of livelihood to the Indian people. When the whole industry was turned over to white fishermen, mainly Icelandic, the Indians had to turn their attention to trapping. It is very evident that trapping also, with the encroachment and superior equipment of white trappers and the spread of mining development, will soon cease to be a source of livelihood to the Indian, and nothing else is left to him in that country.

It is only too evident that the resources of fishing and trapping in available territories is being exhibited to eventual

Ahousaht, B.C.

Mr. R.A. Hoey, (2)

extinction, and, recognizing this, it may sometime be the function of the Residential schools to train the Indians to new and unaccustomed sources of livelihood. Agriculture is at once suggested but this would mean transferring the Indians to other territories, for invariably the territories occupied by fishing and trapping Indians is altogether unsuited for agriculture.

Under these conditions, therefore, it would appear that what is desirable for the present is to train the Indians to better withstand highly organized competition in those industries peculiar to their location and from which they have made a desultory living for generations.

It is rather remarkable that the annual report which I made to the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church, who control this school, in January last, should touch upon the matter to which you have given expression in your circular letter. I thought I would send this report on to you.

The boat, however, is certainly too expensive and not of the type suitable to Indian fishing. Possibly the work of some of the older boys on this boat could be included in vocational instruction. For the building of this boat a workshop was erected, a frame building, 24 feet by 48 feet, very suitable for the building of boats. A dormitory for the smaller boys is located above this workshop. In this workshop the older boys made a number of cedar chests, from material supplied by the Department, which were

evidently sold. Totem poles and small eagles or "Thunder birds" were also made, mostly, I gather, without instruction. The other buildings have not all been painted yet, although I have the paint on hand to do much of it.

This could be conveniently done. Some effort was made to cultivate the land years ago but abandoned apparently from lack of interest. It is an unusual condition on the west coast to have such an area of land suitable for agriculture and it is difficult to understand why more advantage was not taken of it. I have had the soil tested by the Department Agriculturalist and his report will show that it is good. The school has shipped in all its garden produce, fruit, eggs and milk to the amount of about $1500.00 a year, and there is no doubt that this could all be produced on our own land. Since I have been here I have done some effective drainage and have removed large stumps immediately behind the school. Last year I planted some 300 small fruits and 120 plants of rhubarb and their growth is amazing. There is much work to be done, but I do not wish to undertake too much at once, and the building programme is just at present keeping us occupied. Mr. A.W. Neill, the Federal Member, visited us last year and he recommended a small tractor for development of the farm and garden. There is no doubt that this development would be a financial aid to the school. The B.C. market price of potatoes wholesale, for instance, is now $2.80 per cwt.

Mr. Hoey, (4)

However, the matter of development of the land could not be said to come under the heading of such vocational instruction as is adaptable to our Indians. It is true that the project would undoubtedly urge the people to do some gardening in their Village, where there is some small area suitable for this purpose. The force of example, one of the most potent forces in Indian education, would tend to this result.

I do not know whether you are acquainted with the Reserve lay out on the West Coast. The Indians are congregated in fishing villages and do not occupy any large tracts of land. These villages are their "reserves". The rocky and mountainous nature of the country debars them from agriculture or stock raising to any extent. However, there are some apple trees in the Ahousaht village, planted years ago and sadly neglected, but still bearing.

Since coming here we have during the past year built a $3000.00 residence for the principal and his family, appropriation for this being made by the Department. The previous accommodation was one small room in the school building. I would have preferred this money to have been spent in other ways in better equipping the school for its function, but the matter was in hand before my appointment. I employed some of the boys on the building and they showed, some of them, good adaptability, and gained good experience. We are at present engaged in building a new laundry with a recreation room for the boys above, and this is being constructed by the school boys under the direction of the vocational instructor. I was able to get an appropriation of $480.00 per year from the Department for the engagement of a vocational instructor last October. The school has augmented this salary to $600.00. I succeeded in getting a man from Northern Manitoba whom I knew, who is an expert mechanic, also an airplane pilot and an excellent all-round man. He came here for a change of climate, but it is obvious that I cannot expect to keep such a man at this salary for very long. He has already had offers from the mining camps at a much greater salary. However, he has been of great assistance to me in property improvement.

I had him in mind in furthering the plan which I will later outline to you in developing the vocational instruction at this school so that it will definitely result in the increased industrial independence of the Indian people, but he has been fully occupied up to now and will be for some time in improvements in the school property, clearing land for building, building of fire escapes, care and repair of engines etc., In all this he has had the senior boys assisting and being instructed, but as yet there is no definite programme of vocational instruction, with graded and progressive classes, such as I consider there should be.

Frankly, our present facilities do not provide means for my idea of vocational instruction. The many odd jobs around such an institution as this and the present necessity for much patching of buildings, repairs, and new buildings can fully occupy the time of the senior boys and does provide them with a sort of general experience. Probably this sort of thing has been accepted as "vocational instruction" hitherto, but obviously it is far
Indian Residential School
Ahousaht, B.C.

Mr. Hoey (5)

from an ideal which would have for its objective the turning out of our boys fitted by training to engage in any competition in the occupation from which they are not only going to earn their future living, but in which we might expect them to excel to such an extent that they will definitely improve the whole economic condition of themselves and their community.

We have in our village now about a dozen young men just hanging around. Day after day they wander over here to the school. I give them such odd jobs as I can afford, such as supplying wood, but they impress me as being nothing but an economic liability to the community and the country. They are not to be blamed. They have no boats to fish with and, with the exception of the cannery season during the summer, when they find employment at the canneries, there is nothing for them to do. The inclinations to mischief, such as homebrew and immorality, under such conditions is obvious. If these boys had boats and fishing equipment, with the enthusiasm which specialised training in this occupation would engender, there need be no idleness for them.

I arrange sports for them when the weather is favourable and one of the ideas of the recreation room which we are building and to which it is my hope to add a gymnasium at some time, is to keep these village boys from deteriorating into useless parasites of society. Some of these boys have had a few years in high school. The Ahousaht school has been noted for the number of pupils prepared for high school during the past few years. To my mind, this was an utterly mistaken policy. There is only one chance in a thousand of Indian boys or girls being able to compete or to find outside employment against a white boy or girl of similar attainment. The only result of higher education has been to give the Indian pupils a glimpse of something to which they cannot possibly attain. The usual thing is that they have gained more appreciation of the frivolities and indiscretions of outside civilization and have adopted them. They almost invariably come back to the only conditions open to them on their home reserve and discouragement and possibly thwarted ambition (in some few cases) have made them more reactionary than their old people.

This letter has become too long. I know that you are deeply interested in the Indian problem, and this is my excuse. I will, in another letter, suggest constructive methods which, in my opinion, apply to residential school functions in this particular area.

Yours very sincerely,

Mr R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,

Dear Sir:

Upon my return from Ottawa, where I had the pleasure of meeting you, I found your letter (150-60) of January 15th on my desk. Before I had the time to reply, influenza hit us and hit us hard: eight of the staff, 51 out of 54 boys and about 30 girls were in bed. A dozen ran temperatures of between 103 and 104° and caused us a little anxiety. The rest were not seriously ill and I was able to assure the Indian Agent that we could handle the situation ourselves and did not need the Doctor. The latter was kind enough to pay us a visit, although he had his hands full with other cases, and he was pleased with what we had done. All are now up and well. Some have a cough but the Doctor told us to expect this and he added that this cough might last into the summer.

Your letter, I think, sets your seal of approval on what we have been doing for years: we have tried to prepare the pupils for their future life. With this end in view we take the children up to the end of Grade VIII but, though it was suggested but not imposed by the Inspector, we do not take them further. They have class (after 30 minutes religious instruction which I give myself and try to make it interesting and practical) from 9.15 until about 11.30, with a short intermission, on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and, for art, drawing, painting, on Saturday mornings. They have about an hour and a half of study Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday afternoon. We used to have only an hour of study until the teachers asked for the additional half hour on account of the time lost during class hours, for the treatment of trachoma. Would you please let me know if we are giving too much time to class and to study?—I should say that singing practice is
held two or three times a week during class hours.

The girls will be married or will, for a time, be servant girls on neighbouring ranches. They wash the dishes, sweep, scrub, dust, etc.; do all the laundry by hand; iron, clean and press clothes; sew, darn, knit, crochet, mend; do a little gardening, picking vegetables, pickling, preserving (this last clause refers chiefly to the girls who are about to be discharged and who spend their last holidays here); every week, three girls are taken out of the classroom and, under the supervision of a Sister, do the cooking for the School; three more are taken out of the classroom every week and, under the supervision of a Sister, do all the baking. They have to keep well up in class to be allowed to cook or bake and they consider being deprived of their turn in the kitchen or bakery as one of the severest punishments they can be given. They like the work and do it well. The first cook or baker is a girl from 15-17 years of age; the second, from 13-15, and the third is from 11-13.

A member of the Indian Department, hearing that all the washing was done by hand, kindly suggested that, if we asked, we might be given machinery. I am against machinery: it is poor training for the future and the girls, who have had machinery in School, find going back to the old tub at home rather hard. I have noticed that the vast majority of the women trained here regularly wash once a week at home.

The boys will have their own small ranches, will work as ranch hands or cowboys and some will be, at times, loggers. We train them for that.

Those who show any aptitude get training in carpentry and blacksmithing. (An ex-pupil, who has a daughter here, is blacksmith for the largest ranch in the country; another, who has three children here, is carpenter and mechanic at another large ranch). The older boys do some ploughing, harrowing, hay-raking, etc.; they help brand, castrate, etc., and get a certain knowledge, as do the middle-sized boys, in irrigating. The younger boys look after the garden, the pigs, the chickens and geese. As they will have a good deal of
St. Joseph's Mission
Cariboo Indian School Station P.G.E.
British Columbia

it to do later, the older boys, with two or more men, fell trees in the winter and "buck" them. The men haul and deck the logs and the boys saw them into blocks. These the older boys and men split.

Some will later have to have a knowledge of simple gasoline engines and machinery used with them (for hay-baling, wood-sawing, alfalfa-cutting, grain-crushing, etc.) and, so, the older boys do this work (or, rather, help in doing it) here. They also do the milking and separating; the girls make the butter. The middle-sized boys help cure ham and bacon; they also do a little cobbling.

This will give you a fair idea of the practical training we try to give. Here are a few things written or said which will show either that some are pleased with the results or are awful fibbers.

Mr Wynn-Johnson, rancher, 3000 cattle: "Allow me to introduce the Principal of the Cariboo Indian School,-the place where they train the boys and girls to work conscientiously and efficiently".

Mr Harris, farm foreman for Mr J.: "The boys we have from your School are good milkers; they are the first on the job in the morning,-we don't have to call them".

Amelia Louis, ex-pupil: "I am working for Mrs Ross. She says that I wash, iron and mend well and that she wishes her daughter could do the same".

The Indian Agent: "That is certainly wonderful bread. Could I take a loaf home?"

My intention in giving these quotations is not to blow my own horn but to suggest that we have been following the ideas you suggested.

Do we give enough or too much time to this vocational training? I would like a frank reply.

Every afternoon, Sundays and holidays excepted, the boys work from 1 p.m. until 3 to 3.30; the girls work from 1.30 to 3.30. Milking takes another 30 to 45 minutes and washing dishes takes longer. Housework and bed-making takes about 20 minutes. Monday morning, the girls wash and the boys do their work. These hours are followed very regularly; at times
they have to be changed.

The children are told frequently to report if they feel tired. They are fat and are able to play after their work and so they do not seem to be overworked.

I would like a reply to this question. We begin our holidays at the end of July so that the pupils can be at home to help with haying which is late in the district. Those who are discharged to be discharged are kept here, as a rule, during the holidays preceding their discharge, which takes place Sept. 15th (and are paid for this time in clothes), so as to get special training. They are given what I would call "half-freedom" so as to make the transition from School discipline to home-freedom less abrupt. The boys, during this time, work with and eat with the men and are under the authority of the Foreman. This shows them what conditions will be when they leave School and work for Whitemen (most of whom prefer Indians for haying and for ranch-hands). Now, some of these boys and girls have asked me to let them out of the classroom in May instead of at the beginning of the holidays and to let them get more training in cooking, baking, sewing, etc., or in ranch work, blacksmithing, etc. I have tried it out during the last two years and the results have been good. Those to be discharged have been given the option of going to class or to working. Most have chosen the latter. May I continue this practice? Unofficially, certain members of the Indian Dept. have expressed themselves in favor of giving those to be discharged this extra vocational training.

Another question: I have tried to make the training in carpentry practical; the boys built our chapel, carpenter shop, sewing room; they have made doors, windows, chairs, tables, kitchen cabinets, wagon boxes, sleighs, hay racks, hay slips, a miniature model house, feeding troughs and racks and have repaired floors, doors, etc., put in panes of glass, etc. Is not this the way to prepare them for the future or should I, as suggested (not so high up) of the Dept. suggested, have them make totem poles and showy but useless cabinet work? I take pity on you and close.
Ottawa, March 24, 1937.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter I humbly wish to acknowledge the interest you have taken in the teachers of our Indian schools. Never, in my teaching experience upon the Six Nations Reserve, until the present time, have I felt the liberty of conferring and discussing our problems with officials of the Indian Department. We, as teachers, are prone to attribute this feeling to lack of interest which, in my opinion, is so characteristic of the Indian Race. However, I feel that our relations will be cordial and you will deal sympathetically with our problems.

Indian children, I find through means (though limited) that I carry on in my own school, show an aptitude for acquiring knowledge through manual work, rather than through book learning.

Recently, the Women's Institute have obtained a vocal teacher. Opportunity was given for a limited number of pupils from each school to attend these lessons, and from the whole group a smaller group will be selected to represent the Reserve at a musical festival to be held in Brantford. Progress is favorable and I believe that our children's efforts will compare with those who have been receiving vocal instruction for years.

Similarly, much I feel could be accomplished by your suggestions of manual training and household science.

If some project dealing with poultry, could be started in our public schools, we could not imagine with what interest boys and girls would attend its classes. Then the school would be in touch with the community and it would be a practical course of lessons of which they would recognize the need. As a case of study we might; In Arithmetic, find the cost of eggs, feed, chicks, aggregates, and averages, fractions, etc.
In Geography: Egg producing countries, Canada's poultry exports transportation, storage.

In Art: Sketches of brooders, brooder houses, making posters.

In Language: Business letters, wording posters.

In short an inexhaustible amount of information might be obtained and boys and girls might apply it to a good advantage in their own homes.

For information re. the "Follow-up System," my records show that during five years of experience, eight pupils have graduated. Two are completing a secondary school course, three have left the Reserve and are now residing in the United States, the others are working at home. Usually, entrance graduation marks the completion of the Indian child's education, as my records might apply to the whole Reserve.

I have made a study of the different types of monthly report card and I would like your permission to forward a sample.

Let me again thank you for your encouragement and I hope that this information is what was so kindly requested of me.

Dear Mr. Hoy:

Your letter dated Jan. 25, '37 gave me the greatest of pleasures. I certainly welcome your interest and preferred assistance.

Perhaps, you know that I am a novice in this work; this is my first attempt at teaching an Indian School. After a few years I may become wiser. I shall at least become accustomed to some things that now puzzle me.

Concerning your many suggestions, I agree in general with all you say, but there are some vital problems that we must face before we can change conditions.

I doubt whether the public mind begins to realize the magnitude of our task. Being a student and also intensely interested in children's problems, I have discovered a few facts concerning my work.

Does the public mind realize the many handicaps of an Indian child? They have to learn a foreign language when they come to
school. It's almost like sending a child to school to learn French or German. They have one language in school and another at home, at play and at all their social functions.

We have this problem, fathers and mothers (young married couples) who attended school for years—they read and must translate into their own native language ideas and figures before they have any meaning for them.

My greatest problem is to get the children to form "mental images" from our English language without thinking it first all over in their native tongue.

Unlike a white child they have no idea of things until you teach them. Every object has two names—an Indian name and an English name. You can see the difficulty—a not too bright child has to carry such a load of mental imagery.

Personally I think one third of the school curriculum should be given to teaching them to understand the meaning of English words. We could profitably cut out many subjects taught a white child and give the time to making him understand what he reads and speaks when he uses English words.
A second problem in our arithmetic. I notice the textbooks emphasize problems: The Indian child can't grasp such simple abstract words as subtraction, multiplication and division—why burden him with a complicated abstract idea—the plainer the work the better. I find an example on the blackboard—a concrete illustration often gets into their minds much quicker than a very simple problem which he cannot yet intelligently read. Perhaps we need an Indian Child's Textbook.

Further we need to link up our teaching of arithmetic to actual life. We have to let them see the value of a dollar. When he realizes that education is his only protection against exploitation, he wants to learn. I find the Indian is afraid of being made a victim of in business. Its pathetic some of the things they ask me and their fears are real to them.

Perhaps my greatest problem is the school attendance. Children come regularly for a few days or weeks, and then the family moves away to a logging camp for months. A man thinks a day or two from school doesn't
matter, so he takes his child on a trapping expedition, or to get firewood.

The result is I have about 30 children in my school and about as many different grades. You can't teach even half a dozen any one problem at a time because they are all at different parts of the same subject. You will realize what it means in an arithmetic period to have all your scholars doing different exercises.

A few are very regular and these make good progress, others are as old as 13 years and still struggling in Grade I; can neither read, reason, or figure, because they come about once in three weeks on the average, and then are ashamed of their own standing in the school.

Another very great need, so one I am working on, a school library. It's pathetic to create a hunger for books and reading and then have nothing to feed them with. We have about six people taking a newspaper, no regular subscribers to an magazine. I have bought, borrowed and begged and yet there is a cry give us a book for Black. I have heard of children begging for bread, these children are simply hungry for good story books, something they can read. They have no other pleasures here.

Must close now (sincerely) Bishop Black.
Dear Sir:

Replying to your communication relative to the welfare & training of our Indian pupils, it has long been my contention that the system of academic training as it is now, will never bring about the results we look for, until we can supplement it with something of a more vocational character, which will be of direct use to the child in after-school days.

The Indian needs, more than anything else, to be trained to do—to make—to finish what he begins. We must ever be ready to encourage initiative, spurring on the "desire" as well as the "how" to do.

My aim has always been to keep alive the creative spirit, born in every child; Continually fostering his ever-ready impulse to make something for himself.

As I see it at the present day, the curriculum in our white schools has tended to destroy initiative rather than foster it; the creative spirit has become slowly submerged, overwhelmed by cramming. Our own children enter school full of ideas to do & to make but eventually find themselves with "no time for anything but study."
With the little material at our disposal here, I have tried to teach my pupils to do things for themselves, be it in garden or in yard, around or in school, or in the Kitchen; mending, sewing, knitting etc., things they will not learn at home, but which are essentials of later life.

Each reserve has its own problems, I am sure. Here we have always the apathy of some of the parents, with lack of interest in, encouragement for the child's ideas; thus it follows that our greatest handicap is irregular attendance—a bugbear which I have tried by every available means to overcome.

In every case except sickness (I refer to Scabies & Impetigo, our worst foes,) the parents are solely to blame. They wander off, visiting at places too far distant from school for pupils to come; they go off berry-picking, hunting etc., taking the entire family with them, for weeks at a time.

Inadequate footwear during spring & fall also bears largely on irregular attendance.

I feel very strongly that these parents should realize their compulsion to let their children attend school regularly; there are no valid reasons except those stated, for non-attendance. These children are all keen to come every day.

Referring to a "Follow-up System."
Thereby supplying information stating what becomes of our pupils on leaving school, it would seem that, on reserve where farm instructors reside, all such information would be available from him at any time, as complete records of each pupil are on file there.

I am glad to know that we may communicate with you at any time; this gives us encouragement for the future.

Thanking you

Yours truly,

(Mrs) E.M. Siddons

Dear Sir,

In response to your request for suggestions regarding Indian welfare and training, we would like to offer one or two of our ideas.

The adjustment of the Indian public school curriculum to allow for systematic training in handcraft and manual work under school supervision would be a great improvement. Special provision should be made for the few outstanding pupils capable of going on to higher studies. These would be trained to be leaders of their people. The uplifting influence of these young people in training cannot be overestimated. Their periodic visits to the reserve at holiday time exert an influence which nothing else can.

Little Pine is a small, backward reserve, but it has been possible to send on four pupils of this Day School. Adam Cuthand will finish his training for the ministry next Spring (1938) and the three others are in grades ten, eleven and twelve in high school.

Beadwork is one handcraft which could be taught to the girls. It is sometimes thought that only the old women can do this native work, but it has been disproved as far as this reserve is concerned. A short time ago only one woman was known to make a pretty beaded mat suitable for a teapot stand or table decoration. In the last year and a half we have had mats made by twenty different women on the reserve. Within a year about forty mats have been sold through the school alone, and every mat had a different design and color scheme. This industry has been awakened by the Saskatoon
Arts and Crafts Society which supplies the beads, specifies certain standards and pays for the making. The Society finds a ready market for all the mats it can procure. Some designs are prettier than others, and some work is superior to the rest, but if the girls in school were trained to do perfect work, and choose the best materials, when they left school they would be ready to get the highest prices for their products. Indian designs and Indian color schemes should be preserved, but stress laid on suitable articles for the white man's market. This type of teaching would also be appreciated by the parents, and help to bridge the great gulf between school and home, awakening greater interest in the school in the ignorant minds of some of the people.

The Society has slightly raised the price for these mats and this has been a help to the people during a very hard year. Almost every parent of school children has made a mat and this has proved a good point of contact with the home, where academic studies are not appreciated. About fifty dollars have been earned on the reserve by beadwork. This is not a large amount but it is a good beginning in the right direction, that of teaching the people to make a living by their own work.

The clipping from the "Saskatoon Star" attached to our Quarterly Report for this term, refers to this reserve.

Yours truly,

A. L. Cunningham.

Dear Sir,

As I think you will be interested in the work I am doing in the classroom here, in the development of texts and a study course suited to the needs of our Bush Indians, I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I have circulated in order to get assistance in the development of an Arithmetic text.

Before taking over the classroom work I dealt with the Indian boys in farm and general work and noted many of their weaknesses in methods and language. Since coming into the classroom I have sought means of combating these.

For help in this work I have gone to missionaries, traders and educated Indians who have been engaged in Indian work for many years. Thus we have been able to bring to the problems many years of combined experience.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I do thank you for your kind circular letter which you sent proud to us in January.

I have now been over twenty-five years in our Anglican Indian schools. At first in boarding schools at Lac la Ronge for 7-8 years from 1911 to end of the war. Then in Southern Alberta at the Old Victoria Home at Brocket. And then to the Centre Regina day school, Wadena Man. Now at this day school for the past nearly ten years. So you can see I am keenly interested in all that concerns Indian education, both in Day and Residential Schools, & how it can best be related to the everyday life on the Reserve here as the missionary as well as my school teacher. I have to
look at the work from varied angles, to help them along. We have a sort of Mother Meeting in the Church Basement every Thursday afternoon, to which I encourage the ladies & that makes them have a little friendly rivalry as to how they bring their duties all up to date & clean! They are told take in a friendly cup of tea & a bit of something to go with it, & then take a little reading or chat & a prayer. While the bigger ladies come into the schoolroom for the afternoon.

Then from Christmas to Easter, when the need is greatest, into nothing much to do & all play to do it—& I tell the men to come on a Thursday evening to the Church Basement, where checker & dominoes await them. They have keen games, till it takes in a cup of tea & coffee all around. Then we have a Bible Class between 10 & 11 p.m. Sometimes I have
as many as 30 at it. - and their Brotherhood meets around in their own homes on Sunday evenings, for a religious gathering. (I am not sure if they have meetings at Sunday school or Thursday evening.) I don't seem to have much time for visiting, with Day School. But I have an old Indian Lady Reader whose been here doing it for more than 30 years, so he mostly goes to do that part.

The Day School here is held in the front room of the Mission House. At present we have six, so there are no rooms at Boarding School + what I have are just beginning them as soon as they can fairly intelligently wander thro' the three Rs. - but they go mostly to our School at Akimiski.

Now here is my problem - it is the upkeep of this schoolroom to come out of my pocket? It is badly needed doing up. Needs something like wood or linoleum to put along the walls neatly as they sit in their desks. - the rest of the walls & ceiling I fixed up myself.
Since I came (ten years next Sept.) it did not occur to me to seek the D. Dear Mr. Hoey—

Thank you for your letter March 11th.

Dear Sir,

Some time ago I received your very fine circular letter ("180-60") regarding the work of the Indian Day Schools.

About 100% leave their school here at sixteen years of age to do manual work, get married and "exist" here. My husband (who is the missionary) and I organized three years ago, when we came here, handicraft classes for the boys and girls. We felt they needed to be instructed in the use of handwork as well.

We were financially helped to get started by the "Dept." in tools for the boys and some cloth and yarn for the girls.

Mr. Powers holds regular classes for the boys and teaches them how to make useful things for their homes, how to care for the tools, uses of them, etc.,
I have taught the girls how to sew and knit. They have knit themselves sweaters, stockings, sweaters, gloves and mitts. They sewed at first simple things, then later, articles of clothing. They have improved so well that some of them can cut out their own patterns for blouses, hats, pockets, etc., and then make up the articles very nicely by hand or machine. The boys and girls together made fine quilts recently. (At odd times I have taught the boys to patch their own clothes they happen to have on.) Some of them can sew equally as well as the girls in anything simple.

Our biggest problem was getting materials. The normal training class was not very successful in obtaining free materials from the lumber companies around here. That had been a serious drawback. However, the girls have been more than happy in obtaining very fine materials which was sample cloth from friends who own or work in the various companies in Toronto. I wrote them what we
were doing and we liberally responded with odd pieces of cottons, flannels, various velvets, Mr. Jackson (manager of the wool firm of Palmer and Baldwin, who is a friend of ours) very kindly sent us twenty-two bales of wool in December, for the class. With liberal people here and there the sewing and knitting class has been provided for.

We have tried particularly hard to get some pupils to pass entrance and go to high school. Owing to the unfortunate fact that they will only spare English while at school, they have difficulty in expressing themselves as "white" people enough to pass the Grade VII white people's Grade Ontario's tests. It seems unfortunate that some special attention should not be given to their exams done in English in June at Bena.

Trusting these few facts may enlighten you a bit on the outside (of the regular mathematical day school) work.

I am,

Very respectfully yours,

(Signed) Lucille B. Sommer.

Re Domestic Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

In outlining suggestions re vocational training and general Indian occupational betterment on the West Coast in my letter to you of March 15th, I confined my remarks to the boys and men. Of equal importance is the training of the girls. In the West Coast Indians we have a people of superior intelligence to any of the western Indians I have yet come in contact with. Nearly every Indian under forty to fifty years of age is a graduate of some residential school. Living conditions on the reserves, however, reflect comparatively little indication of training extending over such a period of time.

Disease conditions, with T.B. and venereal disease predominant, are deplorable, due mainly to the housing conditions and the reluctance of Indians to advance more to the white standards of housekeeping. Many of the homes are large barns of dwellings where whole families, including the in-laws, live together, dominated more or less, as is the Indian custom, by the older generation. It is to these conditions that we have to send our girl graduates back, with little chance of putting into effect the teaching acquired in the schools.

It is the opinion of some medical authorities that the residential school is the medium by which health conditions among the Indians on the Reserves can be improved. While we can keep the children healthy at the school, and, by care, diet and treatment, build up those that come to us under physical disability, it has been amply demonstrated that such care is to a large extent neutralized as a permanent benefit when children have to return to living conditions on the Reserve.

The solution, to my mind, is in the training of the girls that are to make the future homes, set by an aggressive and authoritative programme of reserve betterment starting in the schools and being followed up in the villages.

Building material is cheap on the Coast. The large cedars, of which there is an almost inexhaustible supply, at least until the commercial fir is no longer available, is used for all building purposes, with the exception of flooring. The cedar is hand split into shakes; or large shingles, which provides the outside covering for walls and roof. Some of the small lumber mills used to saw logs brought to the mill for one-half of the lumber content, but this is no longer usual. However, there is no reason why graduates of the schools, on marriage, should not have a comfortable cottage building ready for occupancy, thus gradually doing away with the large community house or the alternative small overcrowded shack, with the disease conditions and the unhealthy immoral conditions which these propagate. Furthermore, with a home of their own to go to, graduates would have opportunity to
Indian Residential School
Ahousaht, B.C.

Mr. Hoey (2)

continue the habits formed at the school and be removed from the subversive domination of the elders. I have tried to interest the graduates of this school, now in the village, some of them married, in this matter of separate home building, but, while they all admit that it would be very desirable, we cannot bring sufficient pressure to bear upon them to arouse them to this activity. Nor is the training of the girls in the school in domestic work of the type to so inculcate better domestic habits in them while they are in school that they would insist on improvement in the village or at their marriage.

Our equipment is perhaps unusually poor at this school, but in general our conditions here apply to all schools. The older girls make the meals for the children, each one with alternating duties, and also work in the laundry, where the washing is done by machinery, and, washing on three mornings in the week, we have all we can do even with machine equipment to get the washing done. The ironing and sewing is, indeed, practical training which they can take with them on graduation, but, for the most part, the training is of necessity part of the school routine, and no time or facility is available for practical general housekeeping and the care of a home in which they could take individual pride, which they could take with them as a standard to maintain after leaving school.

I have had in mind since taking up this work the building of a three or four room cottage, the lumber being obtained by cutting logs and having them sawn at a mill; all the work and the building being done by the boys under conditions such as could be undertaken without outside assistance in the village. The cottage could be furnished mainly by home constructed furniture and decorated and arranged by the girls. A member of the staff could occupy one of the bedrooms, and two or three girls, alternating monthly, occupy the cottage, make their own meals, wash with wash-tub and board, and be given a budget to keep house with. If the habit could be instilled into them sufficiently by personal pride in a home such as they could have in the village, I doubt very much whether they would be satisfied to go back to the present condition of community life, with meals, for instance, of straight fish or seal meat picked up by the fingers from a dish or perhaps a cedar mat spread on the floor.

I have within the last few days had a problem with a girl, now sixteen, whose father wants her to leave school. The father is elderly and is on relief. Her brother is a graduate of this school but has perforce gone back to Indian conditions of living in the village. The father has no home of his own and lives wherever he can, sometimes in one of the smokehouses in the village. He furthermore lives with an old woman, more for company, I presume, than anything else. Emma is a bright, attractive girl. We have had her helping at the residence and doing some of the cooking occasionally. Her manners at our table are no different from our own. If she were to leave school now to the conditions to which she would have to go, in twelve months time there would be little indication in her habits that she had ever known the "white" people's mode of life.
Indian Residential School
Ahousaht, B.C.

Mr. Hoey (3)

Capt. Barry, the Department Inspector, when he was here recently in the matter of the report on educational matters about which you wrote me, was ready to recommend that Emma be kept at the school until she was eighteen, but I am of the opinion that she can be better occupied in the domestic care and betterment of her father and brother, under proper conditions. I therefore saw the father and brother, and told them that, if they would acquire a suitable home, which I would inspect, and equip it in a satisfactory way so as to be comfortable for both themselves and Emma and permit her to continue housekeeping as she has been taught here, then I would consider asking for her discharge at the end of this term. This they promised to do, and the brother is quite capable of doing it when the incentive is strong enough. This is not an isolated problem, but applies to at least half the girls now attending school, although this is an outstanding case.

In the matter of the report which was required re educational matters on the West Coast, may I say that I have given my opinion of conditions and needs with an unbiased mind, eliminating altogether personal considerations. May I suggest then, should a central residential school be built on the Coast, that consideration be given to the training of both the boys and girls with a view to the gradual betterment of Reserve living conditions as well as the industrial future of the Indians. A domestic training unit for the girls, practical and suitable to Reserve conditions, would, I think, do more to control disease and immoral conditions than any policy which the Government could undertake without enormous expense, and would be more permanent than any possible policy.

To assist reserve housing betterment, a small sawmill at the school, inexpensively erected and operated, and available to the Indians of the Coast for sawing material for house and boat construction, would provide vocational training, would provide such boat material for the building suggested in my previous letter, and would make available to the graduates material for home construction along designated lines on leaving school or on marriage. It would be a desirable complement to the proposed providing of school constructed boats for the equipment of the boys in the fishing industry.

I have had much discussion on the Coast with Whites and Indians regarding the practicability of the proposed West Coast Indian Co-operative organisation. It seems to be a generally accepted fact that some such organisation is the only means of securing the industry to the Indians as a permanent means of support. May I suggest that the matter merits investigation? There is no sound reason why the Indian industry might not be later developed to include canning plants on the co-operative basis also, as many of the girls and women are employed in such plants during the summer.

I am of the opinion that, on the West Coast, we have the material to hand, in the intelligence and industry of the Indian people, with the fishing industry responsive to organised development, as the Japanese have shown it to be, to make a marked advance in Indian administration, leading to independence and eventual citizenship. Sincerely Yours,

Attention Mr R.A.Hoey,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters to Indian Agents and to School Principals re the "follow-up" recommendations for Ex-pupils.

As you know, a similar plan as suggested was started on this Reserve many years ago; large Band Funds, of course, assisted in the experiment. The Millionaire's son is never a good example and we may put the young Blackfoot in that class. However, may we be permitted to make a comment or two.

Very few (if any) boys, white or brown, will settle down to work at 17 or 18 without close supervision. The average Indian boy must see his new world on horseback or by car, for at least two years; it is not only a waste of money but possibly derogatory to his future to give him a farm or equipment for which he is entirely irresponsible and from which he may get a quick return of considerable size. Very few parents of Boarding School children have the slightest idea of parental responsibility. This is not his fault but rather the curse of the whole educational system. As a result, you cannot put dependence on the average parent to constructively help to build a responsible character out of the boys or girls from an institution. No Agent, Farming Instructor, Stockman or other Supervisor can get far with a boy who is a free agent. The lad is at the age when he thinks he knows everything!!

So long as there are Boarding Schools, I believe we must either let the ex-pupils get oriented into their new world by the saddle horse along the wild oat route or else follow up the Boarding school with instructive farm-work or apprenticeship in some line to which he may seem fitted, where he is paid and granted more liberties than at school. All this would be under supervision of both sexes and though I cannot elaborate on it here, the cost should not be prohibitive, possibly economy in the long run. We will watch with interest the results of your experiment.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

I note what you say concerning the vocational training of the children. Here the chief occupation is fishing. The boys start to accompany their fathers in this work while still very young so that by the time they are fourteen or fifteen years of age they know a great deal about fishing and are

Fish net making would be a very useful training in this district for many of the women are able to earn good money by making and mending fish nets. In acknowledging receipt of your letter dated May 15th 1937 in reference to a follow-up system for pupils graduating from Indian residential schools, I might say that I consider this one of the best suggestions I have had in some time. I consider the same plan should be used for pupils graduating from local Highschool, Technical schools, or Collegiate institute. I have felt that there was missing link, after pupils graduating from schools of high learning, and were allowed to drift back to the Reserves, and become re-established among their own people and in a year or two lose all desire to better themselves, very often the older Indian encourages them to again take up the Indian mode of life. Often the Indian pupil is capable after graduating, of competing with other races if he once get a start. They are backward or have an inferiority complex and many of them won't push for the first start.

You do say if the follow-up plan is intended for those pupils who graduate from Highschools, or for those who pass there entrance, it will do doubt help in both cases.

On the Walpole Reserve we have a girl who attends Normal this year, and I expect she will pass. She passed the fifth form at highschool last year. I would like this girl to be placed in a teachers position or some other good position without a gap between her the time of her graduating and and secure a position, she is a conscientious worker, but would probably carry on better if she could get a start soon after her graduating. We also have a young man here that completed the regular course at the Sarnia Collegiate a year ago. He is now working as a labourer, I have been trying to have in place ins a better position.
Of course I do mean that all Indian pupils who graduate should be taken away from the farm, but there are always some that are not inclined to farm, and living as the Walpole Island Indians do right on the U.S. border and close to Detroit Mich., where wages are quite high, and much of the time work quite plentifully, it is hard to keep the young people on the farm. This applies to some extent to the white as well as the Indian people, but the Indian is quite apt to forget the farm if he can see a daily or weekly pay check coming in. It is estimated that over 150 of our Indian people from Walpole Island are working on the U.S. side now, the majority crossing daily to work.

Reverend Sir,

The Indian Act provides that the compulsory age for the attendance of Indian children at residential schools is between seven and sixteen years; although, with our permission, children may be kept in a residential school until they reach the age of eighteen years.

The Department has made no definite ruling regarding the exact number of years a pupil should remain in a residential school. The age for admission and discharge was set with the understanding in mind that, within that term of years, the average pupil would be able to cover the course of studies at any Indian residential school.

This year and in future years, the forms for the follow-up system should be forwarded to the Indian Agent concerned for those pupils who have been in your school for a reasonable length of time and have satisfactorily completed the work which has been assigned to them.

It is not necessary to forward forms for pupils who have been discharged owing to illness or who were only in school for a year or two.

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Angin, O.M.I.,

Dear Mr. Lett:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, in which you ask for additional information, in respect to the subject matter of paragraph 2 of the circular sent out from the Department May 15th, last.

I may state, by way of comment, that this attempt to organize an effective "follow-up" system is largely experimental, and it was our intention that the circular letter should be merely suggestive. It is exceedingly difficult to submit, at this stage, definite or arbitrary proposals. I am rather inclined to think the changes will have to be made from time to time, in an attempt to improve and perfect the system.

What I have in mind at the moment is a report from the Principal to the Indian Agent on every pupil who has received instruction at his school, with the exception of sick children who may be sent home from time to time or pupils who may be transferred from one residential school to another.

You will note that, on the report to the Agent, you are asked to state the number of years the pupil has been in attendance at school. You can readily appreciate, therefore, that the Department will be in a position to obtain from these reports the exact period a pupil may have spent at a residential school and that this information will come to us from the Principal in charge of the institution and will be reliable and authoritative in all cases.

Dear Sir,

I very much appreciate your letter dated January 25th, but which did not reach me till March. Please excuse the delay but before writing I wished to discuss the matter with people here and to give it some thought. I will be very glad to give all the assistance and cooperation in my power and any suggestions you wish to give will be carried out as well as circumstances will permit.

Your ideas with regard to a "Follow-up System" are in accordance with my own although any instruction in vocational training would be extremely difficult as the children are often absent. Fishing and logging are the chief activities here. Although there is some of the best agricultural land in this valley the Indians show little inclination to farm. When either of the two farmers in the valley desire hired help they are obliged to get it from Vancouver. This seems a pity as many of the younger men have been to the Residential School at Alert Bay where they learned some farming.

I will give you a resumé of our activities and perhaps you will be good enough to offer criticism and advice.

First of all we both give every encouragement to the Indians. For example, a few of the older boys and girls have expressed a wish to continue their studies next year. Should they do so I have agreed to allow them to come for instruction after school and to study in the house during the day. I trust this is in order. My school would be too unwieldy otherwise.

We have three branches of the Woman's Auxiliary Branch of the Church. The older women do knitting, make garments, fancywork and make quilts. We teach the Girls' Branch fancywork, plain sewing and knitting while the Juniors learn plain sewing. As yet we have nothing like that for the young boys.

Twice a week I have classes in reading and writing for the adult men and women. They are enthusiastic but unfortunately their nomadic habits do not make for much progress. One afternoon all the little pre-school age children come to school. This is to teach them some English so that when they do come to school it will be easier for them and for me. The parents are greatly interested.

When I came here three years ago many of the young men had musical instruments (saxophones, trombones and the like), but knew nothing at all of music. I told them that I could and would teach them the rudiments of music and how to follow an instruction book. They have worked hard and can now play all the latest dance tunes. There are now two piano accordions, three saxophones, a cornet, two trombones, a drum, a banjo and guitars.
I also teach individual lessons on the organ and the children
and taught the rudiments of music with the object of having a school
band with toy instruments. We have part singing after the Tuesday

On Friday afternoons I teach the schoolchildren games and folk-

is already being done and so that you can, if you will, offer

I want nothing more than to see this matter done. I want nothing more than to see this matter done. I want nothing more than to see this matter done. I want nothing more than to see this matter done.

Dear Mr. Lockhart:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant and to thank you very heartily for the information contained therein. I may say, by way of comment, that the "follow-up" system organized by the Department is largely experimental in character. We had very little on record here to guide us. It was felt that an attempt should be made to obtain authoritative information in respect to the progress made by the pupils during the years immediately following their departure from school. I am not at all sure that we shall be able to obtain the services of a director for this work at any time in the immediate future. In the meantime, we are seeking the cooperation of our Indian agents or farm instructors and the missionaries on the reserves. The reports reaching me indicate that my proposals have been favourably received and that a sincere attempt is being put forth by the field officials to make the system a success.

I was interested in your reference to the programme you have in mind, designed to improve the appearance of your school grounds. I regret to state that the funds at our disposal for such work are very limited. We have in Canada at the moment a number of residential schools so old that they are no longer habitable. It is felt that the repair of these buildings has a first claim upon the funds available. Dear Sir:

I did not wish to answer your letter without ample time for consideration; hence the delay which I hope you forgive.

There are two reserves, Cold Lake and Nechako, with which I am well acquainted. For many reasons, not only have they not progressed during the last 10 years, but, have on every standpoint, gone backward.

As things are today, there is no future at all for the young man whether raised at home or in boarding school. Neither owns anything worth mentioning. He resides with his parents who have nearly nothing to give him, or with old couples who are already dependants themselves.
There is no more hunting nor trapping on their land, while outside they come into competition with young white settlers who being raised closer to nature than the average Indian boy of today, are better hunters and trappers, better equipped with guns, snares and traps. We must not be surprised if the Indian in that field is successful, no more.

The depression has taught him that work is hard to obtain outside. He knows that the farmer prefers a man of experience, and of his own color to an Indian. It is, therefore, with reluctance that he leaves his reserve and applies for work.

I am leaving many questions untouched in this letter, and many of the suggestions I propose, are based on endless questions asked with priests and farm instructors, men who have known them for 25 to 35 years, who understand their character and can explain their mistakes. They all come to the following
conclusions.

(i) Until we have eradicated his atavism and the influence which the old plays upon the young, we must not expect too much from him.

(ii) We must be prepared to see him earn his living and improve his standard of living, not from what he will do outside, but on his land.

(iii) We must not expect everyone to become a successful farmer. We must have patience here.

(iv) The manual training we shall teach him will have to be very practical. Some line, which if he becomes skillful in, will be remunerative.

(v) The day school must be made more up-to-date, (b) become the most comfortable house of the reserve, (c) a place where the child likes to go and where the older ones, whom I know, crave for something to read, could sit and pass their evening mostly during the winter months and where the teacher could easily be on hand to lead them.

Motion pictures could complement the studies of
Social science, Hygiene, General science etc., one good picture, showing how germs propagate, would do more towards cleanliness than years of advice from teachers, nurses and doctors.

The pupils should receive one good meal a day not only during the winter months, but through the whole school year. A reasonable amount of clothing should also be provided.

So that the mothers, girls and infants should not be left to their own devices, I would suggest that the teacher's wife receive a fair remuneration for cooking and teaching the girls and mothers some sewing, knitting and housekeeping.

The teacher should be provided with ample material for teaching the different grades and as much as possible follow the course of studies of the province in which the school is situated.

The spirit of cooperation must be cultivated, and it should be the duty of
the Farm Instructor as well as teacher to promote, at all cost, that spirit.

I have often seen the most salutary plans fail to nothing and the cause was the lack of unity among the Indians themselves.

There shall always be a certain % of parasites. They simply will not work. How to deal with them is a serious proposition. They are generally in the way of progress. Nomads...of ten sick or weak. They can be silenced by a ration.

Hoping these few suggestions may be of some use to you.

I remain sincerely yours

Char. T. Hubert

Gurneyville Alberta.

Honorable Sir:

I must apologize for being so late in answering your letter of the 29th of June with its annexed Circular regarding the desirability of creating a "follow-up" system for the children who leave the Residential schools. I have been in continuous travel since the Spring, and I just happen to find it among some other papers in my travelling case.

I have read the Circular, and I find, with Dr. P.W. Head, that it would be very difficult to put it to practice in the North West territories, where the conditions are so very peculiar and where Reserves are not regulated by ordinary rules which prevail outside of the Territories.

Since you are inviting suggestions, I am giving you what I feel would be the best for the country:

Our main effort should be to have a serious control of the sanitary conditions. Unless we do something in that direction, we will have to deal with only more or less sickly individuals. This is far from being an impossibility. The Indian Agents could be required to make an annual visit in the different camps, and then see that every building is kept in good order, especially for what regards cleanliness and sanitation. There is no doubt but that many of the houses of the Indians should be destroyed or burnt, because of the many germs of various diseases which have contaminated previous owners. This, of course, will necessitate the building of new homes; but I do not see that any enormous expenses would be involved. Practically in every case it would be quite enough to provide some lumber for the flooring and the roofing. The ex-pupils, with the aid of their parents, will certainly be able to erect a log-building which for this country is by far the best, unless one is prepared to undergo a large expenditure.

I would also suggest that the pupils who leave the residential schools be then provided by the Department with some traps...
a rifle, some ammunition, and some nets to start his new life. In his annual visit, the Indian Agent would then see what has been done, and if necessary give the appropriate advice for the actual conditions to be maintained or improved in the near future. A friendly advice from the Agent may go a long way towards developing in the young people some kind of ambition in accord with their way of living; trapping, fishing, and hunting.

In my mind, this seems to be the better way to exercise a gentle control, which may be necessary; but this should be regular, and devoid of any bothering or enslaving proceedings.

I firmly hope that something can be done for the ex-pupils; and that it will prove efficient, if it is done in a liberal and I might say a fatherly spirit.

Very respectfully yours,

Dear Sir:

I have been reading over your letter to me sent from Ottawa on January 15, 1937, and am taking this opportunity of giving you some idea of what I have endeavoured to do on the Reserve and in school.

During my first year here I saw the need of some form of social Club for the Indians, but as I was unable to use the school, I had no suitable place where the people could meet. During the Exhibition of Indian work in Prince Albert during July, I approached the Inspector of Agencies, Dr. Robertson, on the matter. He kindly offered suggestions and gave me permission to use the school. In October I organized a Social Club and during the winter had a very good attendance. As it was new to the Indians here I did not expect too much for the first year. Our meetings were held on an average once in two weeks. I confined most of our talks to Health Studies and how Home Life could be improved. These talks were given in English and Cree. Games and Cards were enjoyed after the business session and a light lunch served at the conclusion of each meeting. Although many of the older Indians speak mostly Cree, I found some of the younger ones wanted reading material. I was able to assist in a small way with a few magazines and papers but thought for another year a small library could be established and wondered whether the Department would donate a few suitable books to make a start along this line.

I see the real necessity of a young people's club whereby some of the older school pupils could take part. I feel the young people prefer English only and now that I take the Sunday morning services in English I have a very good attendance.

A small beginning has been made regarding manual work. Many of my girls are quite young and only a few of the boys are really old enough to do much woodwork. The boys made small beds while the girls made the bed clothes and did little knitting. Articles such as hayracks have been made and only odd pieces of wood were used. I feel with some equipment more can be done. With this end in view for my next requisition I am applying for some tools. I am endeavouring to carry out a farm project next term whereby a model farm will be made and the work correlated with the other subjects.

Since I have been in charge of the school there has been no school garden. There is a suitable piece of ground
next to my own piece which would be ideal. Sufficient vegetables could be grown and as the basement in the residence is large enough no root house would be necessary. I understand the Department would supply the necessary seed for a school garden and I am applying for same through the local Indian Agent. Dear sir:

It is some time since I received your letter regarding the education of Indians. Since then I have been compiling an answer in the form of suggestions, criticisms, etc., which I hope may be of some use in mapping out a programme for Indian education. I herewith present them to you with only one thought in mind—that our educational system may be improved.

Program of studies:

Our instructions from the Department read: "The curriculum to be followed in each school is that prescribed by the Dep't. of Education for the province in which the school is located."

Next—"The Dep't. Indians Affairs prescribes certain text-books. For those subjects for which the Dep't does not prescribe text-book, provincial text-books should be used."

There are two things wrong with these instructions to a teacher:

1. A great deal of the material given in the curriculum of this province which, though very excellent for white children, is unsuitable for use in Indian schools.

2. Many of the text-books prescribed by the federal dep't. are meant for schools in other provinces and are very excellent—but do not fully cover the work as prescribed for each province.

This places the teacher at a decided disadvantage, first, because much of the course of studies is unsuitable for Indian children; and second, because text-books allowed do not cover all of the work prescribed by the dep't.

For the general betterment of education in all Indian schools, I believe:

1. That there should be appointed in each province an inspector for Indian schools—preferably a teacher who has had several years experience in an Indian school.

2. That this inspector, with the help of the teachers of that province, arrange a course of studies for the use of the teachers.
3. That there be made available to the teachers of each province a uniform set of text-books to follow as closely as possible the new course of studies.

Here are some of the reasons I (together with other teachers) have for suggesting such changes. As I stated above much of the material given in the curriculum is unsuitable for Indian children. I mean by this that in order to satisfy the public school inspectors we must teach, or attempt to teach, what is outlined in the curriculum, even though we know that it is unnecessary and a waste of time. Let me give a concrete example of this.

During my first two years in an Indian school I spent a great deal of time trying to teach the children to sing by note. They were unable to understand what it was all about and beyond the preliminaries I found that it was an impossible task. During this time the public school inspector visited the school several times and was quite indignant because I was having no success. The same was true of advanced art.

I do not mean to strike out at the public school inspectors but it seems to me that there is something definitely wrong when an inspector admits that he knows very little about Indians and their capacity for learning. One inspector told me that he knew a certain teacher was not efficient but he was good enough for Indian children.

Teachers are in the position where they might easily slip into a "rut." There is nothing definite in the way of what should be taught for the best results or what should be eliminated from the "course." This puts the teacher on his or her own initiative and often the choice of subject matter is not wise.

I sincerely hope that this reply will not convey the idea I think our present system is at fault. My only desire is that the living standard of the Indian people of Canada may be raised, be looked upon as a real asset to the country. Our schools can make a real beginning in this direction. I trust that these suggestions may be of some use in your task.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Sup't Welfare & Training,
Dept Mines and Resources (I.A.B.)
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. McDonald:

I desire to thank you very heartily for your letter of the 31st ultimo and for the information contained therein.

I can assure you that the suggestions sent forward by you will be given careful consideration. May I point out, in the meantime, however, that the appointment of an inspector to undertake the supervision of the Indian day and residential schools in Saskatchewan is scarcely practicable. The distances in that province are, as you know, so great that an inspector would be called upon to spend most of his time on the road. In addition to this, his work would overlap that of the Provincial Inspectors. The tax payers of Canada today are very vigorously opposed to duplication of effort.

It is exceedingly difficult to evolve a programme of studies suitable for the Bands of Indians throughout the Dominion or even the province of Saskatchewan. The life lived by the Bands of Indians in the south, engaged in agriculture, is entirely different from the life of the hunting and trapping Indians of the north or the life lived by certain Bands or Indians who gain their livelihood almost wholly from fishing. I am anxious, therefore, that each Indian school should be to measure at least, autonomous, and that our teachers should rely less on text books than in the past. You are aware, of course, that in Great Britain, subjects alone are assigned and no text books whatever authorized. The pupil in attendance at school can select any text book on any subject that may appeal to him.

In my circular letter of a year ago, I pointed out that at least one third of the school period should be devoted to manual training; woodwork for boys and crochet work, knitting, sewing, etc., for girls. I am convinced that the teacher following this programme will experience no difficulty with the provincial inspectors. As a matter of fact, there is a very wide-spread demand today throughout Canada for the establishment of such a programme in the public schools.

May I again thank you for your letter and may I express the hope that I shall hear from you again.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hogg,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Kenora Residential School in connection with the follow up system of pupils graduating from Indian Residential Schools.

The Principal's letter refers to regulation No. 1 contained in our circular letter of May 15, 1937. Apparently the Principal has not carefully considered our reasons for providing this regulation. Our thought was to establish full co-operation between the Principal of the Residential Schools and our officers in the field with a view to aiding the pupil upon discharge from a Residential School. To do this effectively the Indian Agent must know the names of the children to be discharged from the Residential School some months before the date of their actual discharge. Otherwise he would be unable to make any provision for them.

The Principals know the pupils in the school who are approaching 16 years of age. They also know, or can ascertain, whether home conditions are suitable for discharge of the pupils at that age or whether application should be made to the Department for permission to keep the children at a Residential School for a further period.

Giving the list of those who will probably be discharged within the next year to the Indian Agent does not necessarily mean that the children must be discharged at that time as circumstances might alter the case. It is also realized that the Principal cannot always foresee other circumstances that might warrant discharge of a
