ROUGH DRAFT OF SUGGESTED CIRCULAR LETTER

To Whom Addressed:
Inspectors,
Indian Agents,
Principals of Indian Residential Schools,
Teachers of Indian Day Schools.

The Department wishes to bring to the attention of all Inspectors, as well as Principals and Teachers the necessity for making the education given to Indian children such that practical use can be made of it on graduation.

The following remarks are intended to cover the work of the Elementary School, that is up to the close of Grade 6. The number of Indian pupils taking the Junior and Senior High School courses is not large, and it has been found that, with the exception of special cases, little is gained by the average Indian boy or girl from such High School training.

Throughout Canada more and more attention is being given to that type of education which will fit the pupil best for adult life. It is the wish of the Department that in Indian schools much greater attention be given to the subject of Vocational Training than has been the case in the past. Such Vocational work will include a variety of subjects of which we need only mention here, Domestic Science, Manual Training, Automechanics, Boat Building, School Gardening, and Art and Craft Work. While all these subjects could not be taught in every school, attention should be given to that type of Vocational Training which will best fit our young graduates for life on the Indian reserves.

Domestic Science:

It is necessary in the large residential schools to have much of the routine work done with the help of machinery involving the use of steam and electrical energy. Girls should however be taught simple methods of hand laundering, the cooking and serving of family meals as distinct from the general preparation of the school meals, the making of bread, and the preservation of fruits and vegetables for winter use. The reasons for following certain approved procedures should be clearly taught.

In large schools the girls are taught to sew, mend, patch, darn, knit, crochet, and embroider, etc., but far too little of this has been done in the day schools. In future a definite period should be set aside in the afternoon on several days each week in the day schools for instruction in the above subjects.

In some day schools the girls prepare a simple hot meal for the school lunch at Noon. This is quite easy to arrange for when the teacher's residence is attached to the school, but even in other cases some attempt should be made to teach the day school girls the preparation and proper serving of a simple meal, even if this only consist of cocoa or soup and bread or biscuit.

The cultivation of small school gardens by girls and boys is also a worth while project. In some day schools the fruits and vegetables gathered in the school garden are preserved by the girls in glass sealers, and used at school lunches during the winter.
Manual Training:

In several of the residential schools too much time is devoted to the making of detailed scale drawings of articles to be constructed in the Manual Training Shop. Older Indian boys who happen to be in the lower Grades through failure to make satisfactory progress in strictly academic subjects are quite unable to make detailed scale drawings. They are quite good in handwork and well able to carry out large projects in Manual Training; but of course fail to construct any worth while scale drawings. The making of such drawings is a great mistake, and as they are quite unnecessary such a practice holds back worth while Manual Training. Very simple rough dimension sketches are all that need be attempted, and from these the articles may easily be constructed.

The use of machinery in the Manual Training Shop should be strictly limited, and it is better that none should be used. Manual Training Instructors should realize that their first duty is to train the boys in the use of simple tools which the Indians are likely to have at their disposal on the Reserves.

The construction of highly polished furniture is not the aim of Manual Training in Indian schools. Articles such as ladders, field gates, wheelbarrows, chicken coops, bee hives, simple tables and chairs, etc., should be constructed. Time should also be given to the carrying out of repair work around the school, the construction of display boards, book shelves, work tables, and other articles needed in the class room. The ability to meet a lock or glaze a window is of far greater value than the knowledge of inlaying, and the use of native woods is preferable to that of more expensive imported hard woods.

Music:

In addition to the usual class singing taught in Provincial schools the Indian children should be taught some simple hymns, and the national songs. Indians have a well developed sense of rhythm, and simple rhythmic bands might well be organized in the day schools as well as in the residential schools where they are already a success. Instruments should be for the most part home made.

Where a good gramophone is available it is possible to train the Indian children in Music Appreciation.

Arts and Crafts:

Definite periods are to be given to the teaching of Arts and Crafts in all Indian schools. This subject takes the place of Manual Arts and Handwork in Provincial Programmes. The craft work should be closely correlated with art work. Craft work should be decorated with Indian motifs, and should be of the type suitable to the age of the pupil. Materials used should be those to which Indians in the locality are accustomed. Weaving Mats, Sewing Cards, Raffia, and even Plasticine, are quite out of place in an Indian school.
Arts and Crafts Continued:

Much of the old Indian art is dying out with the old people. It is the wish of the Department that Indian children be instructed in the skills of their parents so that the better types of Indian craft work may be preserved.

It has been found, particularly in the West that Indian girls consider it a retrograde step to make baskets. They wish to be as like the modern city girls as possible. The cause of this dislike of Indian craft work is the very pronounced inferiority complex from which Indian children suffer. Great care should be taken by teachers in their teaching and control of Indians to avoid anything which might increase such an inferiority complex.

Health:

It is essential that a definite period be set aside daily for instruction in Health.

Simple talks and demonstrations should be given, so that children will know how to guard themselves and others against infection.

Cleanliness is essential in and about the school, and children should be taught good personal habits. Teachers of Primary Grades should be particularly careful to see that the usual Health Rules such as those set out by the Junior Red Cross organization are observed. Where pupils come to school without handkerchiefs, simple paper handkerchiefs should be provided as required by the children.

The Health requirements in some Provincial Programmes of Study are too elaborate for the successful instruction of Indian children. Such courses will of necessity need to be modified to suit local conditions. Health subjects can be taught with success to the children in a number of Grades at the same time. Organized games and Physical Instruction should not be neglected.

Elementary Science:

This subject formerly known as Nature may be correlated with Geography and with Health. Simple experiments should be done by the teacher in the classroom. Notes may be taken by the older children, but it is highly doubtful if the pupils should be provided with a text in this subject. Certain Work Books may be used with success.

Academic Subjects:

Instruction in the strictly academic subjects of the courses drawn up by the various Provincial Departments of Education, should in general occupy the morning periods only in Indian day schools, and not in excess of half of each day's work in the residential schools.

Just as good progress can be made by the children when only a small part of each day is devoted to the strictly academic subjects, and it must be remembered that the duty of the school is to give the pupils that all round training of which they stand in need. It is not in the best interests of the Indian children that they be simply instructed in the academic subjects and their progress in these subjects make the condition of promotion to a higher Grade. In general regular promotions should be made yearly. Children who have attended regularly should on no account be denied promotion. Those who appear very slow in the academic work quite often do just as well in a higher Grade as they would in the lower Grade if forced to repeat the year.
In general it is possible to follow the Provincial courses in such subjects as Arithmetic, Reading, Language, Writing, and Spelling.

No period should be longer than twenty minutes, and probably fifteen minutes is quite long enough for the Indian child in one of the Primary or Junior Grades.

The actual teaching lesson involving the use of the Blackboard by the teacher is of the utmost importance in an Indian school, but success depends also on the proper use of the various work books in Reading, Nature Science, and English Language.

Indian children have considerable difficulty in covering the Provincial courses in the Social Science subjects of History and Geography.

It is doubtful if the Indian can benefit much from a study of conditions in other countries during periods in the distant past. The subject of Geography must of course be taken up in dealing with History, but in addition there should be definite lessons in Geography and pupil activity in the way of enterprises and projects apart from the History lesson.

In general the Geography of Grades 3 and 4 should consist of a World Journey taken by the combined Grades. The actual teaching should be mainly by the Story Method. The teacher should make full use of such texts as THE BOOK OF BOYS AND GIRLS ROUND THE WORLD supplemented by extracts from THE BOOK OF NEW CANADIANS. Large poster maps should be drawn to show the course of the class journey. Built-up Panel Posters and other posters should be constructed and these should cover life in each country visited, and be made while the country is being studied. Such Geography as the above should be taught in short periods of about ten minutes and must be taken each day to ensure success. It is quite possible to group all Grades from 3 to 6 inclusive for such a World Journey. Grades 5 and 6 require instructional in Regional Geography in addition to the above World Journey. Grade 5 should cover North and South America with special reference to the Province in which the school is located, and British North America with the other British possessions in the New World. Grade 6 should cover the remainder of the World Geography with special reference to the British Commonwealth of Nations.

Texts may be used to some extent in Grades 5 and 6, but the teaching of Geography to Grades 3 and 4 should be entirely oral.

The teaching of History, like that of Geography must be strictly from the social point of view. Lists of Kings and Queens Wars and Treaty Obligations are of little use to the Indian children. A very brief outline of European and particularly British History is all that is required to lead up to the more important study of Canadian History.

If not taught in detail the study of the rise of the British from the time of the Roman conquest to the age of exploration is a well worth while enterprise or Project. The parallel between the history of the Romans in Britain and the French and English in Canada should be developed. Reference should be made to the rise of the Anglo Saxons, Danes, and Normans, who each in turn changed the course of History. The Crusades and rise of Turkish power should receive attention as owing to the interruption of the trade routes exploration was the more necessary to find a short way to India. The work of Prince Henry of Portugal followed by the discovery of America, leads to the early discoveries by French and English along the eastern Canadian seaboard and thus the History of Canada is introduced. This latter may well be considered through the work of the Missionaries and the expansion of the fur trade over westward. The particular history of the Province in which the school is located should not be neglected.
Methods:

It is essential that the most approved modern methods of teaching be used in the Indian schools. Lessons in all subjects must be motivated. When Indian children are not anxious to learn the fault probably lies with the teacher in that the methods used are not suitable.

To gain the wholehearted support of the Indian parents teachers must visit the homes on the Reserves. Problem cases should be discussed with parents. Teachers who know the home conditions of pupils will often understand better the limitations of their pupils.

Many teachers appear never to have heard of Educational Psychology, though this subject is taught in all Normal Schools. It is particularly necessary that teachers in Indian schools have a good grasp of the essentials of Psychology as that subject applies to the learning process.

Blackboard work is most important, and teachers should make a free use of coloured chalks in their own work on the Board. It has been found that far too great reliance has been placed on text books. The more successful teachers make use of texts for material, but they are by no means confined to the contents of such books. The best lessons are the vigorous oral lessons with much Blackboard illustration.

Socialized methods on the whole are out of place in the Indian schools. The lecture method, and the question and answer method, have been found very successful. What is called the Project or Enterprise should be used in certain subjects, particularly in connection with Social Science and Elementary Science.

Success in the teaching of a Rural Ungraded School whether Indian or not depends on the proper grouping of Grades. Grade 7 may nearly always work with Grade 8, while there is little reason to teach Grades 5 and 6 as separate groups in subjects other than possibly Reading and Arithmetic. Some highly successful rural teachers always group Grades 7 and 8 together as well as Grades 4 and 5; Grade 3 may to a less extent sometimes be grouped with Grade 4. Grade 2 must almost always be taught by itself, while Grade 1 needs to be subdivided into two groups in most of the Indian schools. If the children in an ungraded Rural School be taught in the groups suggested above it will be found that almost all the pupils can be promoted one complete Grade yearly, and this yearly promotion is a most important matter in an Indian school.

General:

The suggestions outlined in this circular are made with a view of helping Inspectors and Teachers, particularly those in ungraded Indian day schools, by indicating methods and organisation of work which has been found highly successful.

In addition to the proper marking of the registers daily, morning and afternoon, those children coming late to school should be shown by a pencil dot in the attendance mark.

Properly balanced Time Tables should be on display in each school-room, but it is even more important that each teacher have on her desk a detailed preview of the day's work.

Instructions and work for the pupils should be placed on the Boards before the opening of school in the morning.

The afternoons should in general be devoted to Vocational Training, Manual Training, Art and Craft Work, Music, etc.

Articles such as ladders, field gates, wheelbarrows, chicken coops, bee hives, simple tables and chairs, etc., should be constructed. Time should also be given to the carrying out of repair work around the school, the construction of display boards, book shelves, work tables, and other articles needed in the class room. The ability to paint a lock or glaze a window is of far greater value than the knowledge of inlaying, and the use of native woods is preferable to that of more expensive imported hard woods.

Music:

In addition to the usual class singing taught in Provincial schools the Indian children should be taught some simple hymns, and the national songs. Indians have a well developed sense of rhythm, and simple rhythmic bands might well be organized in the day schools as well as in the residential schools where they are already a success. Instruments should be for the most part home made.

Where a good gramaphone is available it is possible to train the Indian children in Music Appreciation.

Arts and Crafts:

Definite periods are to be given to the teaching of Arts and Crafts in all Indian schools. This subject takes the place of Manual Arts and Handwork in Provincial Programmes. The craft work should be closely correlated with art work. Craft work should be decorated with Indian motifs, and should be of the type suitable to the age of the pupil. Materials used should be those to which Indians in the locality are accustomed. Weaving Mats, Sewing Cards, Raffia, and even Plasticine, are quite out of place in an Indian school.
Much of the old Indian art is dying out with the old people. It is the wish of the Department that Indian children be instructed in the skills of their parents so that the better types of Indian craft work may be preserved. It has been found, particularly in the West that Indian girls consider it a retrograde step to make baskets. They wish to be as like the modern city girls as possible. The cause of this dislike of Indian craft work is the same profound inferiority complex from which Indian children suffer. Great care should be taken by teachers in their teaching and control of Indians to avoid anything which might increase such an inferiority complex.

Health:
It is essential that a definite period be set aside daily for instruction in Health. Simple talks and demonstrations should be given, so that children will know how to guard themselves and others against infection.

Cleanliness is essential in and about the school, and children should be taught good personal habits. Teachers of Primary Grades should be particularly careful to see that the usual Health Rules such as those set out by the Junior Red Cross organization are observed. Where pupils come to school without handkerchiefs, simple paper handkerchiefs should be provided as required by the children.

The Health requirements in some Provincial Programmes of Study are too elaborate for the successful instruction of Indian children. Such courses will of necessity need to be modified to suit local conditions. Health subjects can be taught with success to the children in a number of Grades at the same time. Organized games and Physical Instruction should not be neglected.

Elementary Science:
This subject formerly known as Nature may be correlated with Geography and with Health. Simple experiments should be done by the teacher in the classroom. Notes may be taken by the older children, but it is highly doubtful if the pupils should be provided with a text in this subject. Certain Work Books may be used with success.

Academic Subjects:
Instruction in the strictly academic subjects of the courses drawn up by the various Provincial Departments of Education, should in general occupy the morning periods only in Indian day schools, and not in excess of half of each day's work in the residential schools. Just as good progress can be made by the children when only half of each day is devoted to the strictly academic subjects; and it must be remembered that the duty of the school is to give the pupils that all round training of which they stand in need. It is not in the best interests of the Indian children that they be simply instructed in the academic subjects and their progress in these subjects make the condition of promotion to a higher Grade. In general regular promotions should be made yearly. Children who have attended regularly should on no account be denied promotion. Those who appear very slow in the academic work quite often do just as well in a higher Grade as they would in the lower Grade if forced to repeat the year.
In general it is possible to follow the Provincial courses in such subjects as Arithmetic, Reading, Language, Writing, and Spelling.

No period should be longer than twenty minutes, and probably fifteen minutes is quite long enough for the Indian child in one of the Primary or Junior Grades.

The actual teaching lesson involving the use of the Blackboard by the teacher is of the utmost importance in an Indian school, but success depends also on the proper use of the various work books in Reading, Nature Science, and English Language.

Indian children have considerable difficulty in covering the Provincial courses in the Social Science subjects of History and Geography.

It is doubtful if the Indian can benefit much from a study of conditions in other countries during periods in the distant past. The subject of Geography must of course be taken up in dealing with History, but in addition there should be definite lessons in Geography and pupil activity in the way of enterprises and projects apart from the History lesson.

In general the Geography of Grades 3 and 4 should consist of a World Journey taken by the combined Grades. The actual teaching should be mainly by the Story Method. The teacher should make full use of such texts as THE BOOK OF BOYS AND GIRLS ROUND THE WORLD supplemented by extracts from THE BOOK OF NEW CANADIANS. Large poster maps should be drawn to show the course of the class journey. Built up Panel Posters and other posters should be constructed and these should cover life in each country visited and be made while the country is being studied. Such Geography as the above should be taught in short periods of about ten minutes and must be taken each day to enable the class to keep pace. It is quite possible to group all Grades from 3 to 6 inclusive for such a World Journey. Grades 5 and 6 require Instructional in Regional Geography in addition to the above World Journey. Grade 5 should cover North and South America with special reference to the Province in which the school is located, and British North America with the other British possessions in the New World. Grade 6 should cover the remainder of the World Geography with special reference to the British Commonwealth of Nations.

Texts may be used to some extent in Grades 5 and 6, but the teaching of Geography to Grades 3 and 4 should be entirely oral.

The teaching of History, like that of Geography must be strictly from the social point of view. Lists of Kings and Queens Wars and Treaty Obligations are of little use to the Indian children. A very brief outline of European and particularly British History is all that is required to lead up to the more important study of Canadian History.

If not taught in detail the study of the rise of the British from the time of the Roman conquest to the age of exploration is a well worth while Enterprise or Project. The parallel between the history of the Romans in Britain and the French and English in Canada should be developed. Reference should be made to the rise of the Anglo Saxons, Danes, and Normans, who each in turn changed the course of History. The Crusades and rise of Turkish power should receive attention as owing to the interruption of the trade routes exploration was the more necessary to find a short way to India. The work of Prince Henry of Portugal followed by the discovery of America, leads to the early discoveries by French and English along the eastern Canadian seaboard and thus the History of Canada is introduced. This latter may well be considered through the work of the Missionaries and the expansion of the fur trade over westward. The particular history of the Province in which the school is located should not be neglected.
It is essential that the most approved modern methods of teaching be used in the Indian schools. Lessons in all subjects must be motivated. When Indian children are not anxious to learn the fault probably lies with the teacher in that the methods used are not suitable.

To gain the wholehearted support of the Indian parents teachers must visit the homes on the Reserves. Problem cases should be discussed with parents. Teachers who know the home conditions of pupils will often understand better the limitations of their pupils.

Many teachers appear never to have heard of Educational Psychology though this subject is taught in all Normal Schools. It is particularly necessary that teachers in Indian schools have a good grasp of the essentials of Psychology as that subject applies to the learning process.

Blackboard work is most important, and teachers should make a free use of coloured chalks in their own work on the Boards. It has been found that far too great reliance has been placed on text books. The more successful teachers make use of texts for material, but they are by no means confined to the contents of such books. The best lessons are the vigorous oral lessons with much Blackboard illustration.

Socialized methods on the whole are out of place in the Indian schools. The lecture method, and the question and answer method, have been found very successful. What is called the Project or Enterprise should be used in certain subjects, particularly in connection with Social Science and Elementary Science.

Success in the teaching of a Rural Ungraded School whether Indian or not depends on the proper grouping of Grades. Grade 7 may nearly always work with Grade 8, while there is little reason to teach Grades 4 and 6 as separate groups in subjects other than possibly Reading and Arithmetic. Some highly successful rural teachers always group Grades 7 and 8 together as well as Grades 5 and 6 and Grade 2 to a less extent sometimes be grouped with Grade 4. Grade 2 must almost always be taught by itself, while Grade 1 needs to be subdivided into three groups in most of the Indian schools. If the children in Ungraded Rural Schools be taught in the groups suggested above it will be found that almost all the pupils can be promoted one complete Grade yearly, and this yearly promotion is a most important matter in an Indian school.

General:

The suggestions outlined in this circular are made with a view of helping Inspectors and Teachers, particularly those in ungraded Indian day schools, by indicating methods and organization of work which has been found highly successful.

In addition to the proper marking of the Registers daily, morning and afternoon, those children coming late to school should be shown by a pencil dot in the attendance mark.

Properly balanced Time Tables should be on display in each schoolroom, but it is even more important that each teacher have on her desk a detailed preview of the day's work.

Instructions and work for the pupils should be placed on the Boards before the opening of school in the morning.

The afternoons should in general be devoted to Vocational Training, Manual Training, Art and Craft Work, Music, etc.

I am forwarding herewith for transmission to Ottawa the rough draft requested by Mr. Hoey. Ottawa, May 15th, 1937.

To Principals
of Indian Residential Schools:

It has been decided by the Department to inaugurate a "follow-up" system for pupils graduating from Indian residential schools. We feel certain that we shall receive your enthusiastic cooperation in the promotion of this project.

The following suggestions are submitted for your guidance: You will note that these refer to pupils who have remained in your school for the usual term of years. It is understood that certain pupils are discharged for medical and other reasons before their education is completed. These regulations are not designed for such pupils.

(1) About one year previous to the discharge of any pupil, the Indian Agent concerned should be advised. Full particulars should be given regarding the reserve from which the pupil comes and, if possible, the names of his or her parents. This will enable the Indian Agent to consider what is the best advice to give a pupil on discharge, regarding his future welfare.

(2) One month before a pupil is actually discharged, one of the enclosed forms should be completed for each pupil. These should be forwarded to the Indian Agent from whose agency the pupil comes.

(3) If there is a missionary belonging to your Church on the reserve to which the pupil is going, you should also advise him regarding the name of the pupil.

(4) When pupils are being discharged, they should be advised that the Agent is being requested to report on their future progress and they should be urged to make proper use of the instructions they have received.

Ottawa, May 15th, 1937.

To Indian Agents:

It has been decided by the Department to inaugurate a "follow-up" system for pupils graduating from Indian residential schools.

Enclosed, for your information, is a copy of a letter which is being directed to the Principals of the residential schools, also a copy of the form which will be used for report purposes.

This year, you will receive from the Principal of each residential school, a list of the pupils who will be discharged in June, 1938. This is intended to give you an opportunity of discussing the welfare of the graduates with those interested and deciding on the best plan to suggest to the graduating pupil.

You will, also, receive this year a form from the Principal giving the necessary information regarding each pupil from your agency who is being discharged at the end of the current academic year, namely, June 30th. Immediately on receipt of this form, you should get in touch with the farm instructor or other official on the reserve to which the pupil is proceeding with a view to assisting the pupil during the critical years following departure from residential school. The forms which you receive should be carefully filed in your office and, at the end of the first, second, third and fourth years, you should briefly record on them the progress made by the pupil. At the end of the fifth year, you should report more fully and forward the form to the Department.

You will appreciate that this attempt is largely experimental. Success will depend almost wholly upon the willingness of the Indian Agents and those associated with them in Indian work to cooperate in an endeavour to assist the graduates from our residential schools.

The Department will be glad to receive suggestions from time to time as to the manner in which you consider the methods employed could be improved.

Yours truly,

THE CANADIAN INDIANS—THEIR ORIGIN AND DESTINY

PART I. THEIR ORIGIN

How far the antiquity of man on the American continent reaches back into the preceding ages, it is impossible to say, but Dr. Stephen Leacock in his book "The Dawn of Canadian History" (Chronicles of Canada Series) furnishes some notable evidence to show that he was in North, South and Central America "during the remote changes of the Great Ice Age", and "long before the gorge of Niagara had begun to be furrowed out".

When Europeans came to this continent at the end of the fifteenth century, they found it already inhabited by races of men very different from themselves, and because they thought they had found an underlying race or Eastern Asia on the sides, they called these people "Indians". In the course of time when this geographical misunderstanding was removed, thinking men began to look for an explanation for the seemingly isolated position of this section of the human race, separated as it was from the rest of mankind by boundless oceans.

After a brief reference to some of the earlier and "certainly naive" theories which were propounded on the subject, Dr. Leacock proceeds to deal with the evidence that man had appeared on the earth long before the shaping of the continents as they are today, had taken place. "Both in Europe and America", he says, "the buried traces of primitive man are vast in antiquity, and carry us much further back in time than the final changes of earth and ocean which made the continents as they are; and, when we remember this, it is easy to see how mankind could have passed from Asia or Europe to America". He speaks of the connexion of the land surfaces of the globe as being different in early times from what it is now, and suggests, after mentioning the proximity of Siberia to Alaska, "it may well have been that farther south, where now is the Pacific ocean, there was formerly direct land connexion between Southern Asia and South America. The continuous chain of islands that runs from the New Hebrides across the South Pacific to within two thousand four hundred miles of the coast of Chili is perhaps the remains of a sunken continent. In the most easterly of these, Easter Island, have been found ruined temples and remains of great earth-works on a scale so vast that to believe them the work of a small community of islanders is difficult. The fact that they have some resemblance to the buildings and works of the ancient inhabitants of Chili and Peru has suggested that perhaps South America was once merely a part of a great Pacific continent."

From the time the writer of this article became interested in the origin of the American Indians, and that was in the year 1896 when he took up his work as a missionary among the Longan and Suhin Indians in the Paraguayan Chaco, he has never been satisfied with the simple explanation so widely accepted in Canada, that they come from Mongolian stock. If some connexion can be traced between the Mongols and some of the tribes of Alaska and the British Columbia Coast, no such connexion has been traced between them and the Indians who inhabit the rest of the vast North American continent, or Mexico, or Central and South America.

To quote Dr. Leacock again, he says:—"Of one thing we may be certain. If there was a migration (to America) there must have been long ages of separation between mankind in America and mankind in the Old World; otherwise we should still find some trace of kinship in language which would join the nativos of America to the great radical families of Europe, Asia and Africa. But not the slightest vestige of such kinship has yet been found". While he considers it "a very notable circumstance" that we cannot connect the languages of America with those of any other part of the world, he points out that affinities and relationships may be traced in some fifty-five groups of Indian languages in North America.
between the Arctic and Mexico, and adds that the speech of the natives of North America may easily be connected with that of the natives of Central and South America. "Even," he says, "if we had not the similarities of physical appearance, of tribal customs, and of general manners to argue from, we should be able to say with certainty that the various families of American Indians all belonged to one race."

A few years ago the writer took time while in Cambridge, Mass., to read in the Harry Widener library at Harvard University, some forty volumes of American history, with a view to collecting the ideas of others who had studied the subject of the origin of the American Indians, and he was interested to learn that a goodly number of them expressed their conviction that they came from the Malay Archipelago. They point out that the Rockies and Andes are comparatively young mountains among the mountains of the earth, and advance the theory that the great convulsion of nature which threw them up was responsible for the submersion of the Pacific continent, the remains of which we can now see in the multitude of islands and islets lying off the southeastern part of the Asiatic coast. When that mighty convulsion took place, no one ventured to state, but it was their opinion that the forerunners of the present Indian races of America were here before that time, and were related to the inhabitants of the last continent.

While the question of the origin of the American Indians affords a tempting theme to the speculative antiquarian, those who are not impressed by the Mongolian theory have cast about for another take its place, and some have found it in the decidedly interesting one just mentioned. In support of the Malay origin of this remarkable people, they point out that when the Spaniards under Cortez and Pizarro came to the Americas in the 16th century, they found two great civilizations—one under the Aztecs in Mexico and the other under the Incas in Peru. They ask where these civilizations came from. They point to the older civilizations of the Mayas of Central America, "whose ruined temples are still to be traced in the tangled forests of Yucatan and Guatemala," and inform those who wish to see replicas of those temples that they do so by visiting the Peabody Museum in Cambridge, Mass.; and they wish to know where that superior civilization came from. They point to the fact that the interest of the Mayas in astronomy led them to discover the lunar year of twelve months of thirty days, and wonder if this knowledge came to them by intuition, or was bequeathed to them from a still greater race that had gone before, just as their own culture formed the basis of many successive cultures in both Central and South America. They point to such things as the blow-pipe in use by the Indians in Peru as being almost identical with that used in Borneo, and they rightly ask if this is merely coincidence. They point to the striking resemblance between the totems of the Maoris of New Zealand and those of the Indians of the northwest coast of Canada; to the resemblance between the communal or "long-houses" of interior Borneo and those among the Indians in different parts of the Americas; to the striking similarity between many conventional designs and decorations of the native tribes of the South Sea Islands and the Indians of Puget Sound; they point to the ruined temples on Easter Island already mentioned, and to various other things which are germane to the subject, and ask if these do not furnish pretty clear and reliable indications that the earliest races which occupied the American continents came from the Malay Archipelago.

That mankind occupied these continents at a remote age of antiquity, Dr. Leacock in the book already mentioned, furnished some "notable evidence." Amongst other things he mentions the finding of the imprints of human feet, deeply buried over twenty feet below the surface of the soil in Nicaragua, in Central America, and reasons that such impressions must have been made in soft muddy soil, subsequently covered by some geological convulsion.
which occurred long ago. He refers to the still more striking discovery of rude implements of stone, and ornaments of gold, and bits of broken pottery, along the Ecuador coast in South America, buried in a stratum of sand and loam such as might once have been surface soil, but now resting below an approximately eight foot layer of marine clay.

Turning to North America he refers to the discovery in the drift of the Mississippi and Missouri Valleys of chipped implements of stone and broken fragments of quartz buried or lying beside the bones of elephants and animals unknown in this continent "since the period of the Great Ice". From such evidence he reasons that the Americas were inhabited by human beings at a remote period in the past, much more remote than most people conceive, and if those human beings were the progenitors of the American Indians, those in Canada included, then we are living in the midst of one of the most interesting people in the whole world today.

PART II

TENIA DESTINY

As the second part of this article deals with a much more vital question concerning the Indian peoples of this country than the preceding one, the writer trusts that it may be found correspondingly more interesting. Until he himself became closely associated nearly twenty years ago, with the work of Indian education in Canada, the horizon of his personal knowledge of the Indians domiciled here was almost entirely limited to those he had read about, or contacted in the province of Ontario in which he was born. In his journeys up and down and across the country, however, since 1920, and in the discharge of his administrative duties as Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Church of England in Canada, his knowledge of these people has expanded a good deal, and he has been in touch with tribes or bands whose existence was unknown to him before.

According to the last census as published in the Report of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Dominion Government, the Indians in Canada now number 112,510, which is an increase of over 4,000 over the last previous census, and it should be of interest to your readers to know of their location across the country. The following figures are taken from the Report just mentioned:

In the above list it will be noted that Newfoundland is not included. This is partly because it is not part of the Dominion; and partly because there are no Indians left there. When the early settlers arrived a tribe known as the Beothuks lived there and along the rocky coasts of the strait of Belle Isle, but these have all disappeared. As "they smeared their bodies with red ochre, bright in colour", it is thought that this gave rise to the name "Red Indian" by which the race is generally known to the present day.

Of the three major groups into which the Canadian Indians are divided, those of Algonquin stock are mostly to be found at
various centres all the way from the Eastern Maritimes to the Great Lakes, but there are some scattered settlements farther west.

In Ontario and around Lake Huron are the Huron-Iroquois, and to the north and west of these two groups, and living at various centres in the broad spaces between Hudson Bay and the Rockies and the Arctic Ocean are to be found the numerous tribes which are of Athapascan stock.

The Indians west of the Rockies are quite distinct from those of the Plains, apart from those tribes of Athapascan stock which have penetrated into British Columbia. While it is true that there are many distinct languages among the Indian tribes living along the Pacific coast all the way from California to Alaska, their physical appearance, and characteristics show such a similarity throughout that they are thought to belong to one kindred stock.

In order that your readers may have a clearer understanding of the difficulties which confront the Dominion Government and the different Church Societies who are, and have been for many years, cooperating closely in the work of Indian education, it may be helpful if further details be recorded here regarding the numerous tribes and communities of these people included in the major groups just mentioned.

(1) Beginning with those of Algonquin stock, we find the Micmacs in Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Quebec and Ontario; the Malecites in New Brunswick and Quebec; the Montagnais and Abenakis in Quebec; the Ojibwas, Pottawatomies, and Delaware in Ontario; Ojibwas and Swampy Croes in Manitoba; Ojibwas, Swampy Croes and Plains Croes in Saskatchewan; Blackfoot, Blood, Peigan and Plains Croes in Alberta; Saulteaux and Croes in the Peace River Block in British Columbia.

(2) Of those of Huron-Iroquois stock we find both Hurons and Iroquois in Quebec, and the Mohawks, Onondagas, Senecas, Oneidas, Cayugas, and the Tuscaroras, otherwise known as the Six Nations, in Ontario. There is also a Band of Iroquois in Alberta.

(3) Of those of Athapascan stock we find the Chipewyan in Manitoba, Saskatchewan, and the North West Territories; the Sarcees in Alberta; the Slave, Hare, Loucheux, Sekani, Dogrib, Yellow Knives, Copper Mines and Caribou Eaters in the North West Territories; the Takudah, Slave, Nahani, Tlingit and Stick in the Yukon.

In addition to these the Report of the Indian Affairs Branch of Government for 1936-37, from which the above details have been taken, states that in British Columbia:

"The Indians of the Bella Coola, Cowichan, Kamloops, Lytton, New Westminster, Nicola, Vancouver, and Okanagan Agencies belong to the Salish tribes. The Kootenay tribe is located in the agency of the same name. The Kwakiutl-Wooden tribe is located in the Kwawkweith and West Coast Agencies; the Haidas, in the Queen Charlotte Islands; the Tlingits, in the Stikine; and the Tsimsians in the Skeena Agency. The Indians of the Babine, Stuart Lake, and Williams Lake Agencies belong to the Athapascan race.

The Indians of the Peace River Block are Athapascan, with the exception of a small group of Saulteaux and Croes at Moberly Lake who are Algonquins."

As the Indians of Canada are the wards of the Dominion Government, some conception may be had from their widely separated locations across the country and their different ways of obtaining
a living of the difficulty of the problem of formulating a system of education suitable to all. In all fairness to the Government and to the Church Societies cooperating with it it must be said that this problem has been squarely faced, and not without an encouraging amount of success. In keeping with the terms of the treaties made with the various Bands, no less than 375 schools have been provided for the benefit of their children. Of these 80 are of the Residential class, with an enrollment in 1937 of 2,040 pupils; 275 are of the Day School class with an enrollment of 9,227; 10 others are known as Improved Day Schools, where a meal is served at midday; and 10 more are Combined White and Indian Day Schools, having an enrollment of 230.

In the earlier days the Government prescribed its own curriculum of studies, but of more recent years a decision was reached whereby the courses prescribed by the Departments of Education in the Provinces or Territories in which the various schools were located, should be adopted, and all such schools inspected, where the Government did not have its own Inspector, by the Provincial Public School Inspector. These arrangements are being followed at the present day, and, in the opinion of the writer, they are working sufficiently well to justify their maintenance.

It would, of course, be a comparatively simple matter to formulate a uniform system of education for these people throughout the Dominion, provided their locations, their living conditions, and their own philosophies were not so varied as they happen to be. In almost every group or settlement will be found at least three distinct lines of thought.

(1) Those who feel that it is a good thing to be a ward of Government, and look with disfavour on any move which might threaten that old established order. To them it is a secure and comfortable feeling to know that a great and kindly White Father will forever take care of them. As psychiatrists tell us that many people must have this sense of security in one form or another, this section of the Indian peoples appears to have that sense developed to a very marked degree.

(2) Then there are other Indians who prefer to grow up. They feel that wardship is a deeply humiliating experience, and keenly desire to escape from it at any cost. Some have even gone so far as to ask to be "turned loose", declaring they would rather lose everything and starve than face a condition of dependency forever.

(3) Differing from these two classes is a third, comprising those who know nothing except wardship, and have no apparent desire to know anything else. They appear never to have heard of cooperation, and wouldn't give it a moment's thought if they had. The people of this class spend their days in brooding over old wrongs and nursing old wounds which refuse to heal. This is generally the attitude of mind of those who are oldest in years, those who are wilfully ignorant of the new forces of life all about them, and refuse to consider the possibilities which such forces have to bring a new vigour and growth into the life of their race.

These three different philosophies or lines of Indian thought are mentioned in order that the magnitude of the problem of working out the best possible system of education for those numerous and valiant people may not be underestimated. With startling rapidity they have been irresistibly pressed into the current of civilization, and any system of education devised for them, if it is to succeed, must enable them to adjust themselves to the new conditions in which they now find themselves. Today they stand on the threshold of a new life from which there is no turning back. Their traditional life of bygone days will never
return, and whether they or their descendants desire it or not, they are destined to become a part of the new social order which has been built up around them. They cannot continue forever, nor even for many years longer, to live a segregated life, and must either be merged into the White life of this country, cease to exist, and if it be taken for granted, as the writer of this article does, that they are destined to share the responsibilities as well as the privileges of full and unrestricted citizenship, then the educational systems devised on their behalf must be shaped and controlled with this objective always clearly in view.

So far as the Indian himself is concerned, he has already seen with his own eyes that many of the Whiteman's ways are superior to his own. He has seen, for instance, that the Whiteman's methods and education have given him control over many of the forces of nature, and over many of the circumstances of life. Even many of the older generation of Indians are now no longer impressed by those who, whether Whiteman or Redman, who disparage the Whiteman's standards and who fail to continue to Indianize the Indian by extolling the indigenous culture which existed before the Whiteman came. Having seen the benefits and advantages of the Whiteman's education, they are demanding it for themselves and for their children, and they are demanding it as their right.

Those who hold to the view that the Indians must, as at present, remain in wardship, and grow up as a segregated community by themselves, do not appear to the writer to show a proper respect for these people, nor does their view tend to develop any feeling of self-respect within the people themselves. While wardship may be necessary for a considerable time, varying in different localities according to prevailing conditions, such wardship should always be looked upon as temporary, and every encouragement given to the wards themselves to work with the Government and the Churches for their complete civil liberty and their economic independence.

It is assumed that Canadian citizenship will not be granted either hurriedly or indiscriminately as it was to the Indians in the United States by Act of Congress in 1824, but will be based on a standard of competency. The process has already begun, with considerable numbers being enfranchised in recent years, and although progress may for some time be slow, the manifestation of a spirit of patience, good-will, and mutual understanding on the part of all concerned will result in the achievement of ultimate success.

In taking cognizance of some of the endeavours already made in that direction, mention has been made of four different types of schools which have been established, and during the summer of 1938 the Church Societies engaged in Indian educational work gave careful consideration, at the request of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs (the Hon. T.E. Grégar) to the question as to whether these schools are sufficient to bridge the gap between the tribal homes of Indian childhood and the demands of the new way of life, or whether they should be modified and supplemented, or entirely superseded. As the result of the careful attention given to the subject, the Church Societies were unanimous in their opinion that the four classes of schools now in operation were making a valuable and worthwhile contribution to Indian education. In the districts where the Indian homes are stable and reasonably compact, the Day School type is particularly suitable for the younger children, as it helps to preserve the home life which is just as sacred to the Indians as it is to any other people, and it does not deprive the parents of the responsibilities of oversight and maintenance which rightly belong to them. Indian children, especially those of tender years, are very dear to the hearts of their parents, and the Government of this country has recognized this fact through the establishment and maintenance of such a large
number of schools of the Day School class. During these earlier years while the children are constantly under the supervision of their parents, except when in attendance at the Day Schools, they are able to learn the history of their own tribe, and how to conduct themselves as members of that tribe. They can also learn the songs and legends of their tribe, the ethics of tribal citizenship, the duty and technique of self-control, and many other useful things which a child should know. As they grow older, however, say when they reach their teens, steps should be taken to teach them to evaluate their position as a unit in the overwhelmingly large and complex world around them; to teach them how best to develop their own personal assets in relation to that world's needs, and to liberate all the finer assets of their racial heritage for the benefit of those they contact from day to day.

And it is at this stage of their development that the writer feels convinced the schools of the Residential class are indispensable. He freely concedes that the Indian Day Schools are well adapted to the education of the younger children under prevailing conditions, but they lack the capability of engendering the initiative, ambition, resourcefulness, and power of productivity which the older boys and girls must have if they are ever to take their rightful place as independent and self-supporting members of the community. In support of his conviction that the Residential Schools are indispensable, not only as homes for orphan and neglected Indian children, for children from destitute and immoral homes, for children who are physically below par but capable of being invigorated, as well as for children from settlements where no Day Schools exist, he may state that he finds better academic results than being secured in the Residential than in the Day School. The Report of the Indian Affairs Branch of Government for 1937 embodies the following information in this connection: Out of total enrollments which are approximately equal at the 80 Residential Schools and the 275 Day Schools, 212 pupils attained Grade VIII standing in the former, while only 146 reached the same Grade in the latter; that while 87 attained Grade IX in the Residential Schools, only 15 got so far in the Day Schools. Such figures, and more of the same kind, which could be quoted, appear to indicate the advisability of having all pupils transferred from the Day Schools to those of the Residential class when they attain either a certain standard or a certain age.

For the Indians in the remoter parts of Canada almost all of whom are nomads, the only kind of School that will prove beneficial is the Residential. The necessity resting on the parents of securing a living by hunting and fishing, makes the Day School impossible except for a few months at a time. As the School building and equipment could not follow them, and as they would be certain to take their children with them, the building, equipment and teacher would all be idle during the greater part of the year.

And the superior benefits which the Residential Schools confer on the Indian children are not confined to the intellect only, for they extend to their physical and spiritual welfare as well. The sanitary conditions under which they live in those institutions, the regularity with which they receive wholesome meals, the suitable clothing with which they are supplied, the nursing and medical care always available for them, and the careful supervision of all their activities under experienced and competent supervisors, all help to build up their physique, while their daily contact with the devout Christian men and women who make up the staff, go a long way towards shaping hundreds of them from year to year into the best type of Canadian citizen. The discipline, the ordered life and the general cultural benefits of the Residential School system can scarcely be exaggerated, while the associations which these schools make possible, frequently for children from widely separated locations, help to broaden their outlook and to form new friendships, as scarcely anything else could.
We are told in the Holy Scriptures that a tree is known by its fruit, and the Indian Residential Schools may safely be submitted to the judgment of public opinion according to this standard. Space is not available to mention even a fraction of the graduate boys and girls who have lived up faithfully to the high traditions of the Residential Schools they attended, and those who have since married and have children of their own express the keenest desire that their children should be enrolled as pupils at the same institutions. Nor is space available to mention the graduates who have qualified as teachers, nurses, ministers of the Gospel, or who are filling positions of trust and responsibility, not only under the Indian Affairs Branch of Government, but in other departments of the country's civic and commercial life.

During the Great War over 4,000 served overseas with the Canadian Expeditionary Force, and some of them won their commissions on the field of battle. Those who remained at home contributed over $40,000,000 to the Red Cross, Belgian Relief and other funds, and as the writer is convinced that they would again prove their loyalty to Canada and the Empire under a similar emergency, he does not consider any expenditure too great to assist them in triumphing over their present disabilities, and rising to the highest height possible for redeemed humanity.

At an important Conference of the Indian Rights Association of the United States, held in Atlantic City last year, the delegates did not hesitate to assert that the Indian must be saved by a process of Christian assimilation to American life, and not by a carefully guarded and subsidized segregation. "Anything which emphasizes", they said, "and makes for separation and race discrimination, militates against the very essence of the Christian religion".

And it is the opinion of the writer of this article that we should aim at the same destiny for our Canadian Indians. That there is inherent value in some of their old cultures and in some of their primitive religious beliefs is undoubtedly true, but to attempt, as some are doing, to encourage them to believe that their old way of life is adequate to meet their needs in these modern times, is neither honest nor hopeful. Rather let us take the sound advice of that great and wise man of the past, the Hon. Alexander Morris, P.C., for some time Lieutenant-Governor of Manitoba, the North-West Territories, and Kee-wa-tin, who in March 1880, closed his report on the Treaties which had been made with the Indians, with those words:

"And now I close. Let us have Christianity and civilization to leaven the mass of heathenism and paganism among the Indian tribes; let us have a wise and paternal Government faithfully carrying out the provisions of our treaties, and doing its utmost to help and elevate the Indian population, who have been cast upon our care, and we will have peace, progress, and concord among them in the North-West; and instead of the Indians walking away, as one of them in older Canada tersely put it, "as snow before the sun," we will see our Indian population, loyal subjects of the Crown, happy, prosperous and self-sustaining, and Canada will be enabled to feel, that in a truly patriotic spirit, our country has done its duty by the red men of the North-West, and thereby to herself. So may it be".

Winnipeg, Man. January 9, 1939.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of the 5th inst. has come to hand, and with it excerpts from Inspectors' Reports which you had received during the month of December, 1938.

As you state in your letter that a number of principals and teachers in charge of Indian schools had not replied to your circular of January 15, 1937, No. 150-60, I am writing to all our principals today directing their attention to this circular and requesting them to forward to you direct any helpful suggestions they may feel able to make regarding manual training and a follow-up system.

I am also taking the liberty of sending to the principals of our Society's Indian & Eskimo Residential Schools a copy of the excerpts from Inspectors' Reports which you so kindly sent, in the hope that the information embodied therein may, as it should, be of suggestive value to them.

You will know from correspondence and from our annual List of Requirements that our Society has, for some years past, been stressing the need of some better provision for manual training at the Schools under its control, and as this was specifically mentioned in the list of "Suggestions for Improving the Prevailing System of Indian Education" presented to the Superintendent General by the Joint Church Delegation on Nov. 21st last, I am unable at present...
to add anything to what was therein stated.

I am glad to learn from the closing part of your letter that you have found Inspectors' Reports in recent months so satisfactory and encouraging and trust I may not be misunderstood if I say as I honestly feel I can say, that a very large share of the improvements effected is due to the capable and systematic direction and leadership you yourself have given in these matters.

With a view to correcting misinformation which is sedulously being sown by ill-informed or irresponsible persons I have responded to a request from the Toronto Star Weekly to prepare an article on the Canadian Indians, and I am enclosing herewith a copy of the article which is going forward today to that paper. Whether it will be published or not remains to be seen, but I, for one, have the satisfaction of feeling that the Government and Church Societies which have taken a very practical interest in every branch of Indian welfare in this country need not be ashamed of their record.

Yours very truly,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 27 having reference to Harvey Ashkewe discharged from a residential school in June. All these children belong to the northern Bands. I can only visit these Reserves occasionally and my visits are necessarily of short duration. Even when I do visit the Reserves I see comparatively few of the Indians except at Treaty and then I have so much work to do that it is impossible for me to get acquainted with the Indians individually. The Indians of the North live mostly in small family groups and we rarely see them at other times. It is therefore impossible for me to report on ex-pupils who live on those Reserves or belong to the remote Bands. When they return to their homes on the Northern reserves they generally resume the usual Indian mode of life. There is nothing else for them to do. The boys make their living by hunting and trapping and the girls assist in cooking, making camp or keeping house, helping to skin animals, etc. I have heard nothing detrimental against any of the pupils mentioned. Mr. Mallinson

Hazelton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Mallinson:

I have your letter of 3rd inst. relative to Mathew Wesley No. 170. I may say that this boy was discharged from school last summer by the Department. Being an orphan he apparently had no definite home to which to go, except that of Mrs. Esther Holland who wrote me regarding him. Mathew has always been a quiet reliable boy around school, so in discussing his future I suggested that he stay at the school for another year and help me with the farm and other work, for which I would pay him a fair wage. He agreed to this and has been with me all winter, doing chores and odd jobs. For the most part he has been quite happy and contented, except that he has at times suffered with a sore foot. I had an X-ray taken and have lately had him in to see the Doctor. In the last examination the Doctor recommended that he be sent to the hospital for treatment and this afternoon I shall take him in. I may say that in the fall he was examined with the other pupils for T.B. and came through clear, so with the exception of this foot he is in good health. When he returns from hospital I shall send him home, as he is now old enough to care for himself.

I regret that I have not kept you informed regarding Mathew, but trust that the foregoing information is satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

*J.F. Woodsworth*
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended April 30, 1941.

TRAINING.

Letters reaching the Department indicate that a large number of young able-bodied Indians, particularly in the Maritime Provinces, have not yet succeeded in securing employment, despite the fact that there appears to be an acute shortage of skilled labour throughout the country. It is just possible that in the immediate future steps will be taken to requisition the services of women for assignments in industrial plants engaged on war contracts, while at the same time thousands of comparatively strong able-bodied young men will experience difficulty in securing employment, for the simple reason that they have not developed the skills necessary to serve usefully in a highly mechanized social and industrial set-up. In my judgment, educationists cannot escape responsibility for this condition. Despite the fact that Germany and certain other European countries had in operation toward the end of the last century a well-balanced system of technical and vocational instruction, educational systems in the English-speaking world were so dominated by the classicalists that it has only been in recent years that a feeble attempt has been made to promote vocational instruction and then only in a very half-hearted sense. It has been my misfortune during the last 30 or 40 years to meet a number of so-called outstanding educationists who looked upon any educational enterprise outside the so-called classical course as an enterprise designed only for subnormal or semi-intelligent human beings. We shall be fortunate indeed if we escape the consequences of a mistaken educational policy pursued over a period of years, which simply ignored the growing mechanization of human society, the gradual displacement of man power by steam, electric energy and the internal combustion engine.

It is significant that the masses themselves rather than our leaders have become conscious of certain weak spots in our educational scheme of things - hence the desire on the part of many to attend youth training
centres, enroll in Short Courses, purchase for use as hobbies short courses in electricity, motor mechanics, radio engineering, etc. The Canadian Legion have at this date an enrolment of 20,000 men of the Active Service Forces in correspondence courses, the large majority of which are of a vocational or technical character.

Inspector Barry, in his report on the new consolidated Indian day school (Ste. Catherine's) Cowichan Agency, B. C., states:

"Mr. Patrick J. Corcoran is making a very great success of his work as manual training instructor at this school. In addition to teaching the boys the elementary work in manual training and constructing a number of articles for use in the school, he takes charge of the boys' games and athletic activities.

The manual training shop was in a perfectly neat and clean condition, as was in fact everything around the school. The tools supplied are in good condition and properly cared for by the instructor.

"The girls' vocational work has been good. Considerable progress has been made in sewing and work with native wools. The girls have made a number of dresses. In my opinion this school is proving a great success. Its general standing can now be classified as excellent."

Reverend E. J. Staley, Principal of the Morley Indian Residential School (U.C.) in a letter to the Department dated April 17, 1941, states:

"You will recall that you were good enough two years ago to start us off in the fur farming business at the school and while as yet it is perhaps premature to begin to get enthusiastic about it, I can say that while it is no gold-mine, it is a paying proposition. This year for the first time we shall be able to carry into account no capital expenditure for supplies or equipment and so I shall be able to furnish you with a much better idea of the situation this fall.

"Just a few rough figures. Last year we pelleted 75 mink. The grading on these showed a wide range in quality; the prices received were all the way from $8.00 to $15.00. Moreover, we had a profit on the sale of $615. This year we have at the present time 50 breeding stock; all this, with the exception of some more miles we purchased this spring, from the original investment of 6 mink of two years ago.

"The Indian boys have taken to the work in a very fine way and I believe now that at least a dozen boys could find employment if they so desired among the large fur ranches in the vicinity of Calgary.

With -
"With average fur prices in the next few years the venture is a good one that we have every intention of giving a full and complete trial."

Mr. D. J. Scoates, B.A., United Church Missionary at Oxford House, Manitoba, has been organizing from year to year a worthwhile exhibition of manual training projects and handicraft at his school. In a letter dated February 21, 1941, sent by Mr. Scoates to the Indian Agent at Norway House, the teacher states:

"Each passing year the exhibition is better than the one before, not only in the added number of exhibits but in the quality of the work done by the children. Further - and this is the primary object of this manual training course - new children are being introduced to this branch of education. This year there were 127 exhibits. Many of these exhibits were the same as last year but for seniors the work was better accomplished and for new pupils it represented their first attempts. The exhibits included dresses, aprons, handkerchiefs, pot-holders, mats, bedspreads, quilts, sweaters, socks, scarves, mittens, gloves, woollen parka hoods, chairs, tables, towel racks, potato mashers, wooden teapots with hooks for pot-holders, wooden toys, candle sticks, door stops, paper mache dishes, calendars, tin articles, bread, cakes, pies, doughnuts, cookies and canned fruit.

"It is impossible to give you a full description of the exhibition. To fully appreciate the work entailed and the enthusiasm of the children, it would be necessary for you to visit the school on that very special day.

"This year there was a good representation of the parents, and that they appreciate the value of what is being taught will be seen in the following facts: some of the adult women have come to my wife and asked her to show them how to make quilts. Last summer more women wanted Mrs. Scoates to help them to can fruits than we had bottles to supply them.

"A new feature introduced this year is that of working with tin. I think I told you that I had bought Mrs. Scoates a blow-torch. The boys are learning to use this and also the art of soldering. They each had one tin article exhibited.

"I might add in closing that the health of the children at school has been splendid, some children losing only 3 days so far this year on account of colds."

Sister Sainte Jeanne, senior teacher at the Pointe Bleue 2-room Indian day school, Quebec Province,
in a letter dated March 25, 1941, states:

"We are pleased toward the end of the year to inform you of the activities of our class in home economics.

"You will notice from the program enclosed that the works performed are proportionate to the age of the pupils in each course. This year, in order to bring the retarded pupils up to date, all of them began at the first year and worked up to their respective courses which entailed for them a considerable amount of work.

"As supplementary work, the girls, in addition to the regular courses, also learned to manufacture Indian moccasins, which accomplishment will be useful to them in later life.

"You may, by this, realize that the money you grant for this work is usefully employed. It is our hope that next year you will grant us from $15 to $20.

"It is also imperative that we should have a sewing machine."

Reverend A. H. Fleury, O.M.I.,
Principal of the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, Mission, B.C., in a recent letter, states:

"It may interest you to learn that we have started a spinning and weaving class at the school. The boys, too, are competing this year in the provincial calf club and poultry contests. Last year they won several prizes. Our Band is entered again in the provincial musical festival and I hope they do as well as they did in other years. I am enclosing a snap of them, recently taken."

WELFARE.

In my report of last month I intimated that relief and welfare expenditures for the period April 1, 1940, to February 28, 1941, were approximately $136,823.25 less than the expenditure for the corresponding period of the preceding year. We have not at this date received from the Treasury Officials a statement covering the entire fiscal year. The officers in the Welfare Division, however, inform me that when all accounts for the year are paid a substantial balance will remain. This is the first year since I entered the Department that we have been able to meet our accounts in full at the end of a fiscal year."
year and emerge with a balance.

It should be borne in mind, however, that a number of commodities supplied by the Department to Indians and used in the repair and reconstruction of schools, Indian homes and other buildings show a tendency to increase in price. Building materials are no longer exempt from sales tax, and this fact must necessarily mean a substantial increase in the cost of materials required for the upkeep and repair of buildings. Tea and sugar have also increased in price, and the burser of a group of residential schools in northern Alberta, Reverend Father Lejote, intimated during a recent visit to the Department that he had paid $750 of a processing tax on the flour recently purchased for his residential schools. Our residential schools use large quantities of gasoline for the operation of engines, lighting plants, etc., and no doubt, the recently announced Dominion tax on gasoline will contribute substantially to the cost of operation of these institutions. It will thus be seen that, despite the efforts we may make to keep our educational and welfare costs down to the lowest possible figures, these costs, for reasons that I have enumerated and for other reasons, are likely to increase somewhat during the year upon which we have now entered.

Reports continue to reach the Department with respect to welfare projects undertaken and accomplished by groups of Indian women. These groups of women were organized first in the province of Saskatchewan, by the late Dr. Robertson, and similar organizations have multiplied rapidly in the other provinces during the last couple of years. Inspector Hamilton has forwarded a report dated April 15, 1941, received by him from Miss A. Eaton, teacher at the north end Peguis Indian Day School. Miss Eaton, in her report, states:

"I still deem it best to carry on with my former procedure, viz.: having the women meet me in school the last Friday afternoon of every month, and the other Friday afternoons I spend visiting. Through force of circumstances during this period (October to April) we only held 2 regular meetings at the school - the last Friday in October and the last Friday in March. At the meeting in October, the first part of the afternoon we were in the school cottage, where I demonstrated how to cook meat and make soup in order to get the most nourishment possible; the rest of the afternoon we spent in the school building doing Red Cross knitting. On the afternoon of the last Friday in March we discussed garden work and I gave out tomato seeds for them to plant in the house, so that they might have early plants and later ripe tomatoes in their gardens. I also sent seeds with the school children to the mothers who could not attend.

"The keenness shown and the progress made in spinning during this period is most gratifying. An issue of raw wool was made to every school child. If a family has no member who can spin,
they have to pay for this service by giving a quantity of yarn. The Indians make these bargains between themselves; I never interfere. Several families who had to pay last year have set about in grim earnest to learn to do their own spinning and have done it.

"There was another incident which, I think, shows this work is well worth carrying on. Mrs. Colin Pahkoo came last week to borrow the preserving kettle. They had snared a lot of rabbits and she wanted to bottle and preserve the meat."

Indian Agent Daunt, New Westminster, B. C., in a letter dated April 19, 1941, states:

"I beg to forward you herewith the following reports in connection with the Sardis, Chilliwack and Soowahlie Native Women's Organizations. These societies are doing a great deal of good on the reserves and the old and helpless receive, through these groups, assistance which they otherwise would not get. The interest which these Societies have awakened among the Indian women in sewing and house-work cannot fail to have a good influence upon Indian life. I think it would be a good idea if the Department wrote a letter to each secretary, expressing their appreciation of the activities of these organizations, which could be read by the secretaries to their assembled members".

The letters suggested by Indian Agent Daunt were sent out to the secretaries of these organizations on April 23.

Indian Agent Spence, Moravian Agency, Ontario, in his April report, states:

"The agricultural short courses recently held under the direction of Mr. E. Moses proved instructive to those in attendance. There is at this time quite a number of our young men away from the reserve, but 10 or 15 adults and 6 senior school boys made up the attendance. On Monday March 10 Mr. Moses spoke on dairy cattle. On Tuesday Mr. F. J. Hudson, of the Dominion Department of Agriculture, spoke on the growing of and the diseases of potatoes. On March 12 Mr. E. A. H. Banks of Guelph discussed horticulture, and on March 13 Mr. F. Simmons, of the Extension Division, Toronto, discussed re-forestation.

"Mrs. Monture and Mrs. McDiarmid conducted classes in cooking and sewing, which were exceptionally well attended by the women of the reserve and by..."
the senior girls of the school.
