Memorandum

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended May 31, 1941.

WELFARE

The last figures received from the Treasury Branch indicate that relief and welfare expenditures for the fiscal year 1940-41 will amount to approximately $265,000.44, compared with an expenditure of $384,770.46 for the fiscal year 1939-40. These figures show a decrease in expenditures of approximately $119,769.11. This is the most substantial reduction that has taken place in these expenditures at any time in recent years.

This reduction can be attributed to better employment conditions in the Dominions, particularly in Eastern Canada. It is noted that relief expenditures at Caughnawaga, Quebec, are approximately 10% of the amount of last year. This reduction can be attributed in part also to constant revision of the relief lists. In Quebec and Ontario these revisions have been worked out by the Indian agents in cooperation with the inspectors, and it is significant that each revision has resulted in substantial savings. The charges made for certain services have also been very carefully checked during the last year. There was a tendency for a time to charge exorbitant prices for Indian burials. As the result of negotiations carried on for almost a whole year, practically all the undertakers providing this service have now decided to accept a maximum charge for each burial not exceeding $25. For a number of years also a custom existed whereby Indians in certain cases were permitted to ship the bodies of their relatives back to the local cemetery on the reserve for burial. A circular was sent out early in the year, in which it was intimated that in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves permission to return the bodies of Indians for burial would no longer be given, unless the cost was borne wholly by the immediate relatives of the deceased.

You are aware that for a number of years certain Indian mothers in the province of Ontario were eligible for allowances under the Mothers' Allowance Act. When I entered the Department, these allowances were borne by the Dominion and Provincial Governments on a fifty-fifty basis. Later, the province of Ontario assumed full responsibility for the payments, and finally, in response to instructions received from the Minister's office,
the cost was borne in its entirety by the Welfare Division. It was learned that these allowances led to almost insurmountable administrative difficulties. A mother receiving an allowance, in some cases for two or three children, would continue to receive the allowance after the children had been enrolled at a residential school. These abuses seemed to creep in despite the exercise of the utmost care on the part of the officials. It was decided during the year to discontinue the payment of these regular allowances, to have each case thoroughly investigated by the Indian agent and a relief allowance necessary to maintain the family made by this Division. It was expected that this decision would meet with a great deal of opposition, but at this date no complaint with respect to this change in policy has reached the Department.

Mr. Johnston, at my request, prepared during the month a statement of the live stock population of the Prairie Provinces in the year 1932 and a similar statement for the year 1941. I have had a feeling for some time that conditions on Indian reserves in the Prairie Provinces, from the standpoint of agricultural operations, were not wholly satisfactory. The fears I entertained are borne out by the figures now before me. The live stock population for the three provinces, exclusive of horses, for the year 1932 amounted to 1,343 and for the year 1941, 1,011, or a net decrease amounting to 332, whereas it might have been reasonably expected that a normal increase for the period would have resulted in a population of at least 6,000 head of cattle. It is significant that the greatest reductions have taken place, not in the so-called drought-stricken areas, but in the more northerly sections of the provinces. In the Carlton agency, for example, there was a live stock population in 1932 of 1,648 and in 1941 a population of 902. In the province of Saskatchewan the reduction amounts to approximately 50 for the period. On the Blood Reserve, on the other hand, the population in 1932 amounted to 1,764 and in 1941, 1,175. The Blackfoot also shows a slight increase. The significance of these figures becomes apparent when the cost of the annual supply of meat for these provinces is noted. Last year the cost of meat purchased for distribution in the provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan from the welfare vote and from band funds amounted to $9,462.70. The figures for Manitoba are not available. These figures do not include purchases of cattle by the Department from Indians; they represent the purchases made by the Department from the large packing houses only. In addition to these purchases, it will be remembered that a year ago we distributed to the Indians of the Prairie Provinces 94 carloads of elk and buffalo meat, received from the Parks Branch.

These figures, coupled with the collapse of the export market for wheat, must of necessity prompt us to make a greater attempt than has ever been made before to encourage subsistence farming amongst the Indians. I have in mind an agricultural program designed to encourage the Indians to keep cows (beef and dairy type), pigs and poultry. The average Indian, however, is not at this stage prepared to undertake the task that must be undertaken.
to feed and care for live stock successfully. Reports reaching the Department from time to time indicate that certain bands have been able or abandoning their herds of cattle during the winter months, with the result that the care of these has to be assumed by the Indian agent and the farming instructor. Subsistence farming, in my judgment, will mean constant supervision by the farming instructor, the Indian agent and the inspector. Unless we can be assured of this, any attempt to increase the live stock population in the Prairie Provinces is likely to end in disappointment. We should face the fact that, agriculturally, we are drifting in the Prairie Provinces and that this drifting tendency has been going on for several years and cannot be attributed wholly to existing economic conditions. The fact that a number of our Indian agents have reached an age when they are no longer as active as they once were contributes to the difficulties standing in the way of a reasonable solution of this problem. I find it difficult to persuade myself that a change in policy in respect to the operation of Indian agency farms is likely to affect conditions in any substantial sense. It is significant that where capable Indian agents are in charge conditions are reasonably satisfactory; where we have less inactive agents, however, conditions appear to be deteriorating steadily.

An attempt has been made, as you know, during the last two or three years to encourage reforestation on a number of eastern reserves. It is gratifying to report that a number of Indian agents are cooperating very effectively with the Department in the extension of this work. Indian Agent Moore, in a report dated May 12, 1941, states:

"Over 15,000 trees were obtained and planted this spring to continue the policy of reforesting at the Caradoc agency. We used our truck to secure these trees from the provincial nursery station and delivered them direct to the Indian farms. About 4,000 of these young trees were planted on the Soldier Settlement property of the late Charles Beatty. This farm is now operated under agency supervision."

Indian Agent Spence, in his report on the Moravian agency, dated May 7, states:

"I would estimate that close to 3,000 trees were set out by the Indians from the nursery plot. They were all used for windbreaks and hedges around Indian homes. It seems they cannot at this time see the use of setting them out for reforesting purposes, but perhaps they will realize this in the course of time."

Reports continue to reach the Department from month to month in respect to the work undertaken and accomplished by native women's organizations in the West. Indian Agent Daunt, in his last report, states (May 1, 1941):

"The three native women's welfare organizations in the Chilliwack area have functioned well and have undoubtedly improved home conditions..."
on the reserves. If these organizations continue as they have begun, they will be of the greatest assistance in awakening a spirit of domestic competition between Indian households, the result of which will be vastly improved living conditions and this, too, by the Indians' own efforts.

TRAINING

Early in April it was decided to have Mr. A. J. Doucet visit the residential schools of Alberta, with the object of organizing worthwhile vocational and manual training courses at these institutions. Mr. Doucet's visit represents the first attempt ever made by the Department to organize courses at Indian residential schools, proportionately balanced between academic and vocational studies and based on the actual needs of the Indian population. For reasons that I find it difficult to explain, our schools in Alberta were, and have been for years, pursuing courses of study almost wholly academic in character. Arrangements were made whereby Mr. Doucet was able to meet Inspector Barry at Kootenay during the course of his trip and thus he had an opportunity to discuss with our Inspector of Schools for British Columbia the details of an Indian educational program that might be encouraged by the Department and adapted to the needs of the period in which we are living. Mr. Doucet at this date has visited a number of the schools in the southern sections of the province and will continue his work in Alberta until the end of the present academic year. Reports received from the Indian agents indicate that his work has been eminently satisfactory. Indian Agent Goderhan, in his report dated May 5, on the Blackfoot Agency, states:

"The highlight of this month was the arrival of Mr. Doucet, and I think I can go further and say that it is the first real practical move to get some real results for the large expenditure made in the education of Indian children. The program of work which Mr. Doucet has indicated might be followed is excellent and I am sure will receive the endorsement of every Indian agent and principal who is at all interested in this work. The program gets our complete support and the idea of turning our boarding schools into technical institutions for Indians is one that appeals to us and, I believe, will appeal to the Indian parents also. It is hoped that the necessary financial aid to make readjustments will be forthcoming. The writer visited both institutions on this reserve and discussed the program generally with the principals and Mr. Doucet; he was a welcome guest at both schools. Health and general conditions at the schools were normally good".

Inspector Gordon Young, in his report on the
Mount Elgin Residential School (U.C.) dated March 27-28, 1941, states:

"At this institution, in addition to the academic training, which is my special field for inspection, much valuable vocational instruction is given.

(a) The girls are trained in sewing, cooking, serving meals and general housekeeping. These activities were all inspected. The work is very practical in character, being that required in the management of the institution. All girls appear to have a share in this management. Dormitories, sewing room, kitchen, dining room and dairy are in good condition.

(b) Several older girls who do not attend the academic classes are receiving special training in sewing; very good work was on exhibition.

(c) The boys receive their vocational training in the general management of the farm garden, orchard and barns and in the workshop. In the shop, elementary wood and metal work is practised. A valuable project this winter was the repairing of automobile engines. Under the supervision of Mr. Johnston, the boys took an engine apart, cleaned and repaired it and re-assembled it so that it gives satisfactory service.

In previous reports the character training, social instruction, musical and literary activities have been mentioned. These continue to form a valuable part of the work of this school."

About a year ago Bishop Lepellet discussed with the officials the desirability of organizing a vocational course for the senior girls at the Ground Residential School. The Bishop was of the opinion that a number of the girls graduating from the school, usually at the age of 13, were altogether too young and too immature to undertake the responsibilities that life imposes in that northern section of Alberta. The officials here were equally convinced that it would be a mistake to keep girls in school above regular age unless engaged in studies of a vocational character. The result was a compromise whereby the Bishop undertook to provide a vocational course for the senior girls by way of experiment. Indian Agent L'Heureux comments on this work in his report for the month of April. The Agent states:

"The pupils of the domestic school at Ground are doing excellent work. At the time of my visit they had made 63 complete boys' suits and had them packed, ready to be sent to the Jeussart School. Sister Rustache, who is in charge of this work, told me that these suits had been made within a month's time, in addition to other work. These girls also take lessons..."
in cooking, washing, ironing, knitting and all kinds of fancy-work. I was very much interested in the practical cooking lessons given to them. These lessons include meat curing, smoking and canning meat, sausage making, etc. These girls also learn to take care of milk and cream and are given instruction in butter-making. These senior pupils have been picked from Jeausure, Sturgeon Lake, Babasa, Fort Vermillion and Grouard Residential Schools. There are 13 of them."

Bishop Lavalois is now anxious to undertake a somewhat similar experiment with a group of senior boys. I regret to state, however, that the limited funds at our disposal will scarcely permit him to undertake this experiment for the time being at least.

The following is an extract from the annual report for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1941, from J. M. Burns, teacher of the Chehalis Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, B. C. This report has been sent forward to the Department by Indian Agent Daunt. I am of the opinion that it should be included in my report for the simple reason that it presents a point of view that is somewhat unusual and emphasizes certain facts that this teacher has apparently learned from his contacts with the Indians - facts that are apt to be overlooked by officials accustomed to dealing with educational problems in the abstract-

"ques. What community work is done by the teacher apart from regular school work - give details?

"Ans. Fifteen years ago this reserve was one of the toughest and most degraded, down-at-the-heel reserves in British Columbia. Today it is one of the best regulated in the Province. No drinking, morals fairly good, 15 out of 24 houses compare favourably with the houses of whites throughout the Fraser Valley in regard to cleanliness and furniture. The old Indian customs and way of life are finished here. Indian basketry should be discouraged - it has made slaves of their women and children, ruined their health and encouraged laziness in their men-folk. Here the so-called "Art" is fading out rapidly. Basketry work of Indian women who have T.B. should be disinfected as the cedar strands are pulled through the mouth of the basket maker.

"ques. Do the parents show interest in the education of their children?

"Ans. None. They have no appreciation for anything they do not pay for. Indian schools will always be a sort of joke with the average Indian until he pays for their upkeep."
"Ques. Is mid-day meal served?
Ans. No. Indian children are better fed here than white children. It will pay the Indian to remain a parasite while he is hand-fed by the Department. We do not want the 'mid-day meal' racket started here.

"Ques. Is there a regularly appointed janitor and if so, state name?
Ans. No janitor. Here, we dispensed with janitor service at the outbreak of war. The boys do the work."

I have, on more than one occasion, expressed the opinion that relief and welfare expenditures in British Columbia had reached a figure that represented, in my judgment, the lowest figure that one might reasonably expect. The destructive forest fires that have been raging during the month in certain sections of Northern Quebec and Ontario have no doubt resulted in the impairment
of a great many Indian hunting grounds and in the destruction of a certain amount of Indian property. Indian Agent A. de la Boissiere, Pointe Bleue, in a letter dated June 14, states:

"As you are undoubtedly aware, the large forest fires which are now burning in the Lake St. John district have destroyed several Indian camps on their hunting grounds as well as their hunting equipment which they had not time to transport to a safe place. Fortunately, however, I have not received any report so far that anyone has suffered injuries or has disappeared. All the Indians who are desirous of earning money have been hired by the various lumber companies to fight the fires."

In a recent letter received from Indian Agent Daley he states:

"During May a very large majority of the Indian men and women have been employed in Michigan. For your information I would also like to state that for the past nine months the Indians of Walpole Island have received in wages from the Chris-Craft Corporation $18,985.00."

This represents per capita earnings for this band amounting to slightly over $23.00.

Reports reaching this Branch indicate that a sincere attempt has been made by our Indian Agents in the Prairie Provinces to substantially reduce wheat acreage on the reserves. Indian Agent Gooderham, in his report dated June 4, states:

"Practically all farms were seeded in good time to both wheat and oats. A total of approximately 4000 acres was seeded to wheat, a reduction of over 2300 acres over 1940, with a total of 2500 acres of oats seeded, an increase over last year of 1700 acres. Besides this 50 acres of Alfalfa were seeded, with oats as a nurse crop, and, of course, there is quite an acreage of Crested Wheat Grass and Rye which was seeded last fall. On the whole, the land has been better tilled and better worked than for many years."

Indian Agent Booth, in his report dated June 5, refers again to the effective work undertaken and accomplished by the members of the Home-Maker's Club. The Agent states:

"The Home-Maker's Club on the Assiniboine Reserve is making very good progress and all the members have been provided with garden seeds and in cases where the Indians could not plow their own gardens the Farming Instructor arranged to have this work done for them. In every case the members agreed to plant a large garden. The work accomplished in the club room is of great benefit to all concerned and I am more convinced than ever that a real Home-Maker's Club is a great boon to Indian women and these clubs should receive all the encouragement they can get from every source."
The Indian Agent concludes:

"All the seeding operations on the Community Farms are completed and work has now commenced on the summer-fallow. I may say that the work on these farms is first-class and should produce better than the average crop, with a number of the Indians working on these farms at various times and should be able to see for themselves how farming should be carried on and also the results of cultivating and seeding at the proper time. In this way these farms should prove to be a good object lesson to all our Indian farmers."

Indian Agent MacCutecheon of Fredericton, in his report dated June 2, 1941, states:

"As you are probably aware, the month of May is our big fiddlehead month, and this year it has been a huge success. During the past few years I have endeavoured to introduce this delectable green to the large canning industries and most decidedly was rewarded this year. The Macready Pickling Company in Saint John are buying tons of them, also retailers in the Saint John market. The Indians of Oromocto, St. Mary's and Kingsclear are receiving the greater returns. Some families have received cash for the month's picking to the value of from $100.00 to $150.00. The price was good and the supply plentiful.

"Clothing recently received from the Department, and shoes purchased locally, have been distributed."

Indian Agent McPherson, Clamdeboye, in his report dated June 11, states:

"I spent some time on the Brokenhead Reserve seeing that the Indians put in their crops and they are all taking quite an interest in the land that was broken for them. We have put in half the crop in wheat and half in oats. The wheat which they threshed on the reserve last year kept the Indians who had land in crop in flour all winter but they were short of oats for feed. This year, however, they should have plenty of oats for feed and plenty of wheat for flour. The Indians who had land broken a year ago have been asked to finance their own seed requirements this year and pay all other expenses. When the land was broken last year the department supplied the seed but the Indians have been all instructed that they must finance their farming operations after the first year."
TRAINING

You may remember that an unusually large number of Indian day school teachers resigned at the close of the last academic year. It was expected that a somewhat similar condition might develop this year. It is gratifying to report, however, that comparatively few resignations from teachers have reached the Division at this date. It is encouraging to report also that we have experienced little difficulty in securing fully qualified teachers for the vacancies that have occurred.

I have expressed the opinion, on more than one occasion, that a large number of our Indian day schools have reached a standard of accomplishment equal to the best one-roomed public schools throughout the Dominion. I make this statement despite the average Indian pupil's limited knowledge of English and the time of enrolment and attendance statistics which have never been wholly satisfactory. Year after year, however, we note from Inspectors' reports a steadily increasing number of pupils who have succeeded in passing their Entrance examinations.

Inspector W.J. Greening, in his report on the Goulais Bay Indian Day School dated June 3, states:

"Miss Fox has had much experience in Indian schools and understands Indian conditions well. She is doing good work at Goulais Bay. If I were asked to mention a school visited by me in which the results of careful teaching of health and personal cleanliness were most apparent, this would be one of the very first schools that would come to my mind."

The Goulais Bay School has at this date an enrolment of 20 pupils.

Inspector Greening, in his report dated June 6 on the Garden River senior room, states:

"I have asked the local High School Entrance Board to consider granting Entrance standing on recommendation to three or four of the Grade VIII pupils of this school. I feel sure that the work that has been done warrants this consideration."

The teacher of this school, Miss Julia Mary Goody, has a first-class Ontario certificate and has had 16 years' teaching experience, 7 of which have been spent in Indian day schools.

Inspector Greening, in his report on the Buzwah School dated May 27, states:

"This is a splendid little school. The teacher in charge is a little Indian lady, the product..."
of the Indian schools, and a product that the Department might be very proud of indeed. If she were teaching in a white school I should urge most strongly that she be given an increase in salary as a recognition of work well done."

The teacher of this school, Miss Christina Wakegijig, has a first-class, Ontario certificate and has been in charge of Indian day schools for a period of 6 years.

Inspector J.M. Gane, in his report on the Cape Croker No. 1 Indian Day School dated May 30, states:

"The new teacher is undoubtedly capable and conscientious. The pupils co-operate harmoniously and in general are proficient in their studies. It is most encouraging to the Inspector to find that even with an enrolment of 46, and an organization of 9 classes, much better than average progress has been made at this school. This enrolment constitutes a heavy burden for one teacher and one which no one should be expected to carry for a protracted period of time.

"The Grade VIII class of three girls was examined in some detail. Two of the pupils are quite outstanding and will be recommended for High School without writing the Departmental Examination. The third was also recommended as she is certainly not weak but a decision on this point will not be made until after the teacher's final examination this week.

"There is at this school a large Grade VII class which will constitute a good entrance class next year.

"Splendid work in manual training, sewing, knitting and other types of craft work has been carried on.

"The pupils are extremely polite and have a very good sense of humour."

The teacher in charge of this school, Miss Louise Cattle, has an Ontario, permanent, first-class certificate and has had 10 years' teaching experience, 9 of which have been spent in Indian day schools.

Memorandum:

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the welfare and training service for the month ended July 31, 1941.

TRAINING:

Despite the fact that our Indian residential schools are closed during the months of July and August and our Indian day schools during the months of July, August and September, these months are in many respects the busiest months of the year in the Training Division. Supplies are sent out at this period to the 75 residential schools and 28 day schools. These supplies consist of textbooks, supplementary readers, chalk, lead pencils, scribblers, drinking cups, etc., and athletic equipment. Difficulty is always experienced in securing a list of these supplies from certain schools. This is particularly true of schools where there have been changes in the teaching staff. These supplies are purchased through the Stationery Office and usually shipped by freight. Repairs to schools are also undertaken at this season of the year. It is at this time also that we re-engage teachers and a point new teachers for vacancies that have occurred at the end of the academic year. It is perhaps unfortunate, but apparently unavoidable, that this additional work should occur during the holiday season when a number of the members of the regular staff are absent on their annual vacation. With our day schools operating on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis, it is of the utmost importance that textbooks and school supplies should arrive at our schools prior to the opening of the schools on the first of October.

The Ontario Horticultural Association and the Provincial Rural School Improvement Association of Ontario have for a number of years sponsored a contest aimed at the general improvement of rural schools and rural school grounds in the province. This competition, it would appear, is organized on a county basis. This year 14 rural schools in Brant County entered the competition. It is very gratifying to be able to report that the first and second prizes were won by Indian day schools on the Six Nations Reserve. The first prize was won by the No. 5 School and the second, by the No. 9 School on the Six Nations Reserve. The teacher at the former school is Miss Nora Jamieson and at the latter, Miss Julia Jamieson. Major Bundle, in a letter dated -
dated June 26, states:

"As you will see by the attached cutting from the Brantford Expositor, two of our schools - No. 5 and No. 2 - succeeded in winning the first two places in the County School Improvement Competition. I am sure you will be gratified that our own schools can achieve such splendid results in competition with others, and success certainly does bring credit to Indian administration.

"It is a pity that you cannot see both of these schools, for really the teachers and the children have done wonders with the grounds, flower beds, etc. The winning school is really a picture of colour, care and tidiness.

"Many thanks also for your share in our success, as but for your kindly interest when down here last and the provision you made to permit me to obtain paint, shrubs and screenings, much of the improvement carried out so eagerly by the children and the teachers could not have been carried out.

"Miss Nora Jamieson's school will now be in running for the provincial competition."

The following comment on the closing of our Indian day schools in the southwestern agency of New Brunswick recently appeared in the Fredericton Gleaner:

"The closing exercises of the Woodstock Indian Day School were held on Friday morning, June 27th. An interesting programme of songs and lessons was carried out by the pupils. A prize for highest general standing was awarded to Reginald Paul, Grade IV. Prizes for the highest averages were awarded to Eugene Polichies, Grade VI; Albert Paul, Grade V; Donna Paul, Grade II; Peter Polichies, Grade I.

"Each girl was presented with a dress and apron and the boys, with sweaters which were made during the term by the pupils under the direction of Sister Emilliana. A delightful display of weaving materials was on exhibition. Prizes were presented and pupils addressed by Mr. McCutcheon, who congratulated them on the year's work and encouraged them to keep up their good standing and expressed deep satisfaction with the work of the Sisters, not only in the school, but among the girls, and families of the Reserve.

"At the Kingsclear Indian Day School a delightful programme was carried out, which consisted of a review of lessons, patriotic songs and recitations. In attendance was Mrs. A. Pierce Crockett and Mrs. G. I. Currier of Fredericton, who presented..."
two books to the school on behalf of the I.O.D.E., Mrs. Crocket making the presentation. Prizes were presented to the following by Rev. Father Harris, parish priest: Norren Tomah, Ronald Tomah, Miles Tomah and Edythe Polchies.

"The closing of the St. Mary's Indian Day School, near Devon, took the form of a review of the school work and also patriotic songs, which were exceptionally well rendered. The pupils making the highest averages were: Grade I, Shirley Brooks; Grade II, Norma Polchies; Grade IV, Clarence Paul; Grade V, Tina Meuse; Grade VII, Harold Sappier and Billy Brooks. Mrs. MacElligott, the teacher, and the pupils were congratulated on their splendid showing by Mrs. W. F. Blair and Mrs. R. L. MacCutcheon.

"The closing exercises of the Oromocto Indian School were held on Friday morning, June 27th. An interesting programme of songs, recitations and lessons was carried out by the pupils. A prize for highest general standing was awarded to James Atwin, Grade VII. A prize for perfect attendance was won by Mary Ann Atwin. In the absence of the Indian Agent, Mr. R. Lee MacCutcheon, the school was addressed by Miss Mary McElroy, N.H., who expressed her regrets that Mr. MacCutcheon was unable to attend and congratulated the pupils on their year's work and encouraged them to keep up their good standing. Miss McElroy also made fitting remarks to James Atwin's achievement in winning honourable mention in the recent Forestry Contest for the elementary schools of New Brunswick."

Mr. Doucet has been engaged since his return from Alberta in the preparation of a course of study designed to meet the needs of the Indian pupils in attendance at our Indian residential schools in Alberta. This program, which emphasizes more fully than the provincial program the importance of manual training and health exercises, will be adopted by the schools at the opening of the academic year on September first.

WELFARE:

The statement of welfare expenditures supplied monthly by the Treasury Department indicates that there has been a steady reduction in relief expenditures for the period April 1 - June 30 - the net decrease for the period amounting to $118,274.31. I am disposed to think that while a steady reduction in these expenditures has been taking place, the net decrease has been substantially less than this figure. You may remember that at the end of the fiscal year 1939-40 there were unpaid accounts amounting to approximately $70,000, while at the end of the fiscal year 1940-41 practically all our outstanding accounts were paid. This fact modifies to some extent -
extent the figures appearing in the last Treasury statement.

I am attaching hereto, for your information, a graph showing the total Indian income from all sources for the period March, 1915, to March, 1933, inclusive. This graph, which has been carefully prepared by Mr. Fast, is self-explanatory. It will be noted that Indian income during the year 1933 was less than it was at the end of the fiscal year 1915 and approximately one-half the amount of Indian income in the year 1920. It is gratifying to note that there has been a steady increase in this income during the last three or four years.

Mr. Christianson, in his report on the Kinistino Reserve dated July 15, 1941, states:

"I wish to point out that we have had farming instructors on this reserve for a great number of years. To the best of my knowledge, practically no results were attained. Since Mr. Gardner was appointed school teacher and farming instructor a great change has taken place. The work accomplished by these people is really outstanding and Mr. and Mrs. Gardner should be complimented on the results they have attained during the last 3 years. Mrs. Gardner does a lot of work amongst the Indian women, which is certainly a step in the right direction, and, as I have said before, she also helps with the school and outside work. Regarding sickness, Mr. and Mrs. Gardner have saved the Branch a lot of money in doctoring Indians themselves instead of sending for a doctor for every illness. Now a doctor is only called when actually required. If there is any way of giving Mr. Gardner an increase in salary, no man that I know deserves it more than he does. At the present time he is receiving $1,000 a year, and I am sure if something was done to show that the work he and his wife are doing is appreciated by our Branch, it would bring about even better results.

"The homes on this reserve are primitive, being regular Indian shacks with mud floors and mud roofs. However, since Mr. Gardner's arrival a number of these shacks have been floored. The Indians took out a number of logs during the winter, to be sawn into lumber for improving the buildings. During my visit the Indians were all living in tents."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended August 31, 1941.

WELFARE.

An Indian Arts and Craft Exhibit was organized and placed on display at the Canadian National Exhibition under the direction of Miss Kathleen Moodie. This is the third consecutive exhibit that has been organized by the Department and placed on display at Toronto. Miss Moodie, in commenting upon the exhibit of this year, in a letter dated August 28, 1941, states:

"Our 'Hand-coven' Room is really very effective and appears to attract more attention than our 'Soldier' window of last year. Our little Pottery demonstration is also interesting, and I think Ethel Moses is really going to develop a marketable line of pottery. Several wholesale dealers are already asking for prices and quantities available, including Valentine-Black. A number of American buyers are fairly climbing over the walls in their efforts to pin us down to delivering minimum quantities of basketry and carvings. The possibilities for a tremendous business appear to be in sight. We sold $185 worth of goods the first day and over $300 worth yesterday. This, I consider not bad for the two opening days".

Employment conditions throughout the Dominion appear to be such that the average able bodied Indian has experienced little difficulty in securing remunerative employment during the spring and summer months. Mr. H. W. McCracken, Acting Indian Agent, Caradoc Agency, in his report dated August 7, states:

"Employment such as fruit picking, harvesting of grain and other varieties of work off the reserves is very plentiful. We have been experiencing difficulty in obtaining suitable Indian labourers to assist us in our agency welfare operations. This is due to the fact that the wages we pay do not compare favourably with those paid by white employers. We may be forced to increase our wages during the next month. Relief is now reduced to a minimum; only sick and aged people need assistance".

Indian Agent Howe, Stuart Lake Agency, B. C., in his report dated August 6, states:

"A visit was made by me to reserves along the Stuart, Trembleur and Takla waterways, using the agency boat

Takulli -
"Takulli", this being my first visit for the season. These reserves are almost deserted by adult male Indians. Work is plentiful and the Indians are taking advantage of the prevailing high wages. In fact, Indian labour is at a premium. Numerous requests for farm help continue to pour into the agency office; $2.50 per day and board is offered.

Indian Agent Down, of the Sarnia Agency, in a report dated August 7, states:

"There is a great tendency at this time among our Indians to reduce their agricultural efforts, a natural trend, I suppose, when other industries are offering them from 50¢ to $1.50 per hour. Their motto appears to be to make hay while the sun shines. I am endeavouring to educate our people to the inevitable post-war period and to impress upon their minds the after effects of 1914-18 and that it might be well to retain their interest in agriculture. What effect this instruction has, however, on the Indian mind with its philosophy of "live today, let tomorrow take care of itself", one cannot tell. An earnest effort will be made to keep the present acreage under cultivation."

Crop conditions on Indian reserves throughout the Dominion appear to vary from exceptionally good crops on certain reserves in Manitoba, to reasonably good crops in southern Alberta and poor crops in certain sections of Carlton, Duck Lake and Touchwood agencies in Saskatchewan.

Indian Agent Davis, in his report dated August 8, states:

"Crop conditions are very bad, owing to the extreme dry weather. The yield will be very small and is estimated at about 8 bushels per acre for wheat. The Sandy Lake Reserve is, however, an exception. The crop there should yield about 20 bushels. There appears to be an area extending from the Birtle Agency in Manitoba to the Onion Lake Agency in Saskatchewan, approximately 60 miles in depth, which will this year experience its eighth successive crop failure. This area appears to be quite extensive in the Duck Lake agency, where conditions from the standpoint of crop production and opportunities for employment are extremely discouraging."

I have expressed regret on more than one occasion at our failure to encourage worthwhile handicraft projects on reserves other than a few reserves in Ontario and Quebec. Reports reaching the Department from time to time, however, suggest that a number of comparatively small worthwhile projects have developed without departmental assistance at certain agencies in the Maritimes. Mr. E. H. Bertho, in his audit report on the New Brunswick Southwestern Agency, states:

"According to the Agent, some of the Indians are engaged in the making of handicraft articles which in most cases are marketed by themselves. They are not in receipt of assistance by way of advances from the Department. The Agent takes orders at his office for baskets, axe handles, etc., from local people. In such cases the money is collected at the agency and paid over to the Indian producers. During the last year, $301.54 was handled by the Agent and recorded in the cash-book."
TRAINING.

In my report of last month I intimated that Mr. Doucet had been engaged since his return from Alberta in the preparation of a course of study designed to meet the needs of the Indian pupils in attendance at the residential schools in Alberta visited by him. This course of study has now been completed and will reach the Principals prior to the opening of the 1941-42 academic year. This course of study represents an attempt to extend still further manual training at our schools. Mr. Doucet defines Manual Training as "All work done by the hands: woodwork, metal work, farm work, gardening, cattle raising, farm mechanics, leather work, sewing, knitting, housekeeping, laundry work, cooking, etc." Mr. Doucet, in his general report dated April 13, states:

"The girls at the schools visited by me are receiving good training in manual arts. If the teachers in charge had clear objectives and the pupils proper motivation, the benefits of this training would be greatly increased. This was apparent in the knitting activities at the school where Junior Red Cross work was organized."

Referring to the boys, Mr. Doucet states:

"The boys are receiving comparatively little manual training and appear to have the wrong attitude toward this particular branch of study. Many of them appear to detest manual training. This work, throughout the activities of the school, should be dovetailed with classroom studies. It would be very desirable to have boys' supervisors and boys' teachers with ability to train their students in General Shop work, to organize sports and to promote physical training".

Educationists in their comments on the work accomplished by educational institutions on the North American Continent, have frequently expressed regret that few female teachers had been attracted to the teaching profession. Male teachers are indispensable in the senior grades if the pupils in attendance at our schools are to receive an adequate and well balanced education. It is just possible that Mr. Doucet in his report on the schools in Alberta has placed his finger on one of the weak spots in our educational set-up. It would certainly appear that men are necessary to give instruction in what he refers to as Manual Training and to supervise the physical development of the pupils, particularly the boys. There are few branches of educational effort more worth while than well organized and well supervised athletic contests. Such contests, however, without male supervision, are of little value in the development of character. Here we encounter a real problem and a problem for which it will be somewhat difficult to find a solution for the time being at least.

There has been a steady decline in the number of male teachers at Indian day schools since the outbreak of the war. There are comparatively few young, able-bodied teachers in charge of Indian day schools anywhere in the Dominion at this date. It is likely that we shall experience difficulty -
difficulty also in finding fully qualified female teachers to take charge of our schools this year. At this date there are about 15 schools for which teachers have not yet been secured, despite the fact that positions in a number of districts have been offered to married women with professional qualifications.

Reports from the West indicate that in view of the prevalence of Infantile Paralysis a large number of public schools may not re-open on the regular opening date on September 2nd. The desirability of keeping our residential schools closed in the Prairie Provinces for the month of September, at least, has been discussed very fully with the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services. It is Dr. Moore's opinion - and with this opinion I am fully in accord - that Indian pupils would be less exposed to the ravages of this disease if permitted to enrol at residential schools, where they can be kept under strict medical supervision and where medical services are readily available. I am now in receipt of a telegram from Dr. Indsor, in which he states that the Public Health Board of the Province of Alberta has issued an order preventing the re-opening or operation of any school in the province, other than educational institutions where the students in attendance are 17 years of age or over. Dr. Moore is now of the opinion that in view of this order Indian day and residential schools in the province should remain closed and has so notified Dr. Indsor. The Principals of our other schools will be notified in due course.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended September 30, 1941.

I visited Toronto in the week ending September 8 and while in the city Mr. Allan and I visited the Ontario Department of Game and Fisheries and discussed with the Deputy Minister of the Department, Mr. Taylor, ways and means of securing areas suitable for the propagation of beaver and other fur-bearing animals in the Sioux Lookout and James Bay agencies. You will recall to mind that these negotiations formed the basis of a discussion at a conference called by the Minister a few days ago.

I also visited the Canadian National Exhibition and spent the major portion of two afternoons at the Indian Handicraft exhibit, organized and placed on display by Miss Moodie. I was assured during my stay there that the Indian exhibit was again one of the most attractive, if not the most attractive, exhibit on the fair grounds. The attendance during my visits was all that one might desire. I was particularly interested in the number of boys and girls of school age who were in attendance and who appeared to take a keen interest in the Indian dances and in the display of handicraft. I was impressed by the amount of work necessary in the organization and promotion of this exhibit. This year, in addition to Miss Moodie, Mrs. Lockwood, Miss Davis, Mr. Elliott Moses and Mr. W. Atkins, 30 Indians were employed. Miss Moodie informed me that the members of the staff had been called upon to work 15 hours a day for a period of three weeks, Sundays included.

The Canadian National Exhibition Commission provides excellent space for our exhibit in the National Industries building, facing on the courtyard used by the Provincial Department of Lands and Forests for their wild life exhibit. This wild life exhibit provides an ideal setting for the display of Indian handicraft products.

The sales at the exhibit this year amounted to $5,300, between $200 and $300 more than the sales of last -
of last year. Miss Moodie assures me that the number of sales this year was considered greater than a year ago but that many of the people visiting the exhibition this year were of a class who were interested in cheap souvenirs rather than in the better and higher priced lines.

In view of the fact that the demand for handicraft products is at the present time substantially greater than the supply, it is just possible that the advertising and publicity for which the Toronto exhibit has been responsible may be no longer necessary and that the time required for the organization of this display might be spent more profitably in the organization of handicraft projects on Indian reserves.

An encouraging report has reached the Department on the handicraft exhibit organized and placed on display at the Vancouver Exhibition. Indian Agent Ball, in his report dated September 3, 1941, states:

"I have the honour to report that the Canada Pacific exhibition closed September 1. The Indian exhibit was smaller than usual, as the space was limited, but I am pleased to report that it was an unqualified success and was most favourably commented upon. I am advised that approximately two thousand dollars' worth of Indian handicraft products was sold during the 7 days the exhibition was open. This is much more than the sales in previous years, in spite of the smaller display and the atrocious weather most of the week. We were given a better location this year and more people visited our section of the exhibition. One booth was set aside for articles donated by various Indians to be sold for the B.C. Spitfire Fund. Miss Gerry, the travelling nurse, was chiefly responsible for these donations, and if she had been here during the exhibition I think this booth would have been even more successful."

Reports received from Indian agents indicate that little difficulty has been experienced by Indians in securing employment at good wages during the spring and summer months. Indian Agent Highgate, of the Moravian Agency, Highgate, Ont., in his report dated September 3, states:

"All available Indians of this reserve are employed in tobacco harvesting at good wages, the average being $4.00 per day."

Indian Agent McNaughton, St. Regis Agency, in his report of September 2, states:

"Employment during the month seems to be at a fairly high level. As usual our Indians are generally employed on the American side."
The basket shop at Chenaill has shown an increase in the number of workers during the latter part of the month.

Indian Agent Lockhart, Fort Frances Agency, in his report for September, refers to the number of Indians of his agency who have secured employment on provincial lands, cutting and peeling pulpwood. The Agent adds:

"With the scarcity of white labour in the district, there is plenty of this work available."

Although crop failures have been very much in evidence on a number of reserves in the Prairie Provinces, reports to hand suggest that work off the reserves has been plentiful. Indian Agent Booth, of the Qu'Appelle Agency, states:

"All the Indians who are not employed on the reserves are able to find all the harvest work they want at wages around $2.75 per day."

Indian Agent McPherson, in his report of August, refers to an attempt made by him to secure employment for a number of his Indians with the Fish Companies operating on Lake Winnipeg, and states:

"I have arranged with the fish buyers to purchase the entire catch of the Bloodvein Indians. This band of Indians fish on a small commercial scale. A number of Indians from Berens River Reserve have come south for the harvest."

Work also appears plentiful on the Pacific coast. Indian Agent Moore, of the Cowichan Agency, reports:

"Generally speaking, work was plentiful during the month and no unemployment was noticed except in the case of old men who are really past the working age. Many of the Indians did not return from the U.S.A. since they went there picking berries in May last. I understand they got seasonal employment all summer and will stay over for hop-picking. In fact I don't look for them to return before October."

Indian Agent Daunt, New Westminster Agency,
in his last report, states:

"Employment opportunities have been satisfactory during the month. Many logging camps are operating in the district. Harvesting work has been in progress on farms, commercial fishing fairly active and the various hop-fields opened their season on the 25th of August."

TRAINING

We have found it exceedingly difficult to secure the number of fully qualified teachers necessary to operate our Indian day schools throughout the Dominion. However, we have received valuable cooperation from the churches in securing a number of teachers for the more remote schools in the northern districts of the Dominion. We have at this date failed to secure teachers for the following schools: Christian Island R.C.; Metagami; Mud Lake; River Settlement and Lower French River. In addition to these vacancies, we have been compelled to keep in our service a number of teachers whose services appeared to be unsatisfactory throughout the year. The evidence before us at the moment would indicate that it will be simply impossible to secure male teachers for our schools while employment is available in war industries. The only exceptions will be young men who are prepared to link up their teaching duties with missionary effort under the auspices and direction of one of the churches.

It is gratifying to report that despite the decision of the Department to operate Indian day schools on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis, a number of schools opened early in September. The Restigouche (4 room) School opened on September 1, and the Caughnawaga School, on September 15. In addition to these, it is altogether likely that a comparatively large number of our schools opened early in the month and that the reports on the operation of these schools will reach us in due course. The Maria (2 room) School will operate this year under the direction of the Sisters of the Holy Rosary of Rimouski. The Maria Indians are, as you know, one of the most backward groups of Indians in the Dominion. Relief costs at this reserve during the last fiscal year amounted to $86.35 per capita as compared with a provincial per capita cost of $12.78. It is our intention to organize at this school a well balanced vocational and academic course. Two Sisters have been employed by the Department but a third Sister, although not on our payroll, is residing at the school and has assumed responsibility for the teaching of domestic science,—cooking, sewing, fruit preserving, the repair of discarded military clothing, etc. If we succeed in securing the services of a farming instructor it is our intention to organize a worthwhile course—
course in elementary agriculture, gardening, crop rotation, etc., for the boys in attendance at this school.

The Dominion Council of Education held a conference at the Lord Elgin Hotel early in the month. This conference consisted of the deputy ministers of Education for the nine provinces, certain members of their staffs and the professors in charge of the faculties of education at a number of the universities throughout the country. A number of these deputy ministers visited our handicraft shop-room and were deeply interested in arts and crafts from a pedagogical standpoint. Several of them expressed amazement at the work accomplished by the senior teen-age group of girls at Caughnawaga. This work, as you know, consists in the main of weaving projects for the production of scarfs, ties, etc. Dr. G. Fred McNally, Deputy Minister of Education for the province of Alberta, who was president of the Council last year discussed with me ways and means of strengthening our educational set-up in the province of Alberta. The reports on our schools received by him from his inspectors appeared to him to be in many respects unsatisfactory. He was very much encouraged by the discussion he had with Mr. Doucet when Mr. Doucet visited Edmonton a couple of months ago. Dr. McNally is particularly interested in manual training and in vocational and physical courses. He assured me that we would experience no difficulty in securing the services of men equipped to give special courses in physical instruction at our schools, should we desire their services at any time. In a letter received from Dr. McNally since his return to Edmonton, he states:

"Yesterday I had a long talk with Fathers Siemard and Gaudette, of the Indian school at St. Albert. We have arranged to have Mr. Bird, of the Edmonton Department of Physical Education, visit St. Albert this week-end and assist the Fathers in putting their physical training on a satisfactory basis. I, myself, expect to have an opportunity of visiting this school early in the year, after the new program has been in effect for some weeks."

Memorandum

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended October 31, 1941.

WELFARE.

Welfare expenditures for the period April 1 - September 30, 1941, amounted to $828,850.01, compared with expenditures amounting to $490,948.60 for the corresponding period of last year. The Treasury officials inform me that inasmuch as there is usually one month's delay in the payment of accounts, these figures actually represent expenditures for five rather than six months. You will note that the figures indicate a net decrease amounting to $176,258.65.

Relief expenditures show a substantial reduction in all the provinces. The greatest reduction - $54,982.24 - appears to have taken place in the province of Quebec, with the province of Ontario showing a reduction of $32,125.55. On the other hand, relief costs in Manitoba for the period - $64,523.31 remain high. Manitoba, with an Indian population of 14,561, shows unemployment relief costs double the costs for the same period in Alberta, with a population of 12,163.

It would appear that Indians have experienced little difficulty in securing steady employment throughout the summer and during the early fall. This fact in itself is almost wholly responsible for the savings effected. The supply of discarded military clothing available has also been a factor. It is gratifying to be able to report that Indian women, under the direction of our agents, are making the best possible use of the clothing supplied. Samples of clothing made into blankets, garments for children, etc., have been sent forward to the Department. These garments bear evidence of skill that is really very commendable.

Weather conditions in the Prairie Provinces during the harvesting season have been more unfavourable than they have been at any time within the last 15 or 20 years. The heavy rainfall has not only delayed threshing operations but has resulted in lowering the grades and consequently the value of wheat and oats, particularly wheat. Indian Agent Iredale, of the Stony Agency, in his report for September, states:

"The weather during the month of September was very bad. We experienced rain and snow on and off for practically the whole month. This
hampered our normal harvesting operations considerably. The temperature also during the month averaged below normal.

Indian Agent Gooderham, in his report dated October 8, states:

"The precipitation at Gleichen was 1.45 inches, but at other points on the reserve it is believed that there was more moisture. The weather was unsettled throughout the month and the first heavy frost occurred on the 8th. This did not clear the air however and finally on the 23rd and 24th it snowed quite heavily. The heaviest frost was on the 27th when 13 degrees was registered."

Indian Agent Webb, in his report on the Peigan Agency for September, states:

"Throughout the month, cold, wet, windy weather has prevailed. This has been attended with some frost and snow, which have hampered the fall work—harvesting, threshing, etc., and prevented the Indians from earning the money necessary to support themselves."

Acting Indian Agent McMillan, in his report on the Blood Agency, dated October 2, states:

"The weather for this month has been the worst at this time for many years. During the month two light snow storms occurred, and the rest of the month was wet. One severe frost was noticed during the month."

In my report of a month or two ago I referred to an area in northern Manitoba and Saskatchewan where crop failures have been recurring for a number of years. Reports to hand from northern Manitoba and Saskatchewan indicate that the crops of this year are a total failure on a number of reserves. It is somewhat disturbing to note also that the crop failure area is extending south. Indian Agent Booth, of Cut'Appelle, in his report dated October 1, states:

"All harvesting operations are now completed, and on the majority of the farms the results were very disappointing. Only on the Assiniboine Reserve have the crops been good. On the Pasqua and Sioux Reserves a little grain was threshed, but on the Pinpot and Muscorpetung reserves the crops were a total failure. All our summer-fallow work is now completed and a first class job has been done in most cases.

Mr. Holden, Inspector for the Wheat Reduction Board, visited this agency and was well satisfied with the work done. He informed me that..."
our summer-fallow was in most fields as good or a little better worked than the fields he had inspected for our white neighbors.

A number of encouraging reports on the work undertaken and accomplished by the members of native women's clubs continue to reach us from month to month. Indian Agent Daunt, New Westminster Agency, in his report for September, states:

"The Native Women's Clubs at Chilliwack put on a very creditable exhibit of native arts and handicrafts at the Chilliwack Fair, under the guidance of Miss Dynes. It was the cause of much favourable comment, not only at the time but when I visited the area during the following week. A number of prominent citizens expressed their surprise and appreciation of the effort".

Major Randle, in his report on the Six Nations Agency, refers to the work accomplished by the tractors. He states:

"The tractors during the month (September) ploughed 198 acres, tilled 269 acres and sowed 84 acres and by these operations assisted 46 individual farmers. Considerable ground on the reserve has been sown to fall wheat this autumn. As weather conditions, except perhaps some lack of moisture, have been favourable to the farmer, the work is well advanced".

TRAINING:

Early in the month Mr. Doucet visited the R.C. and U.C. Indian Day Schools at Caughnawaga, the U.C. Indian Day Schools at Oka and the Indian day school on the St. Regis Reserve.

Mr. Doucet discussed very fully with the teachers in charge of these schools ways and means of promoting worthwhile vocational courses for boys and girls. Mr. Doucet discussed the courses also with Inspector Wescott, who is responsible for the inspection of the R.C. school at Caughnawaga. Mr. Doucet informs me that a worthwhile start has been made at the schools visited by him. It is my intention to ask him to visit the school at Caughnawaga again prior to the Christmas holidays, with the object of observing and reporting upon the progress made since his initial visit. I have experienced difficulty in securing the services of a competent manual training instructor at Caughnawaga. It has not been possible this year to secure a man with
a professional certificate. The best we could do was to secure the services of a man who has been until now foreman-carpenter for one of the large industrial firms in Montreal. While this arrangement is in many respects unsatisfactory, Mr. Doucet is disposed to think that insofar as woodworking is concerned the instructor will be able to provide a good practical course for the boys.

A few schools in the province of Ontario have failed to secure teachers and have not yet been re-opened. Two teachers, one at St. Regis and one at Caradoc, resigned during the month.

The opening of a number of our residential schools in the province of Alberta, which should have taken place on September 1, has been delayed, in response to instructions issued by the Provincial Health authorities, owing to the prevalence of poliomyelitis. However, recent reports indicated that practically all of our schools were in operation toward the end of the month.

Mr. E. Leppard, the teacher in charge of manual training at the Morley Residential School, in a letter to Mr. Doucet dated October 6, states:

"We have been a month late in getting down to work, due to the provincial government ban as a result of the recent floods. However, formal classes are now organized in manual training, sewing, cooking, beading and buckskin. We plan to devote Monday P.M. and Friday A.M. to formal instruction in these activities. The mental attitude of the children this year is a great improvement over that of any other year in my experience."

An encouraging report on the Ste. Catherine Consolidated School, Cowichan Agency, B.C., dated October 20, has just been received from Inspector Barry. Mr. Barry states:

"Vocational training is particularly good at this school. The girls, under Sister M. Engenia, prepare the midday meal in a most excellent manner. This meal is properly served by the girls, who undertake this task dressed in caps and aprons. These girls look very smart indeed and the meal appeared to me to be as well served, if not better than meals served at most residential schools.

"The girls also were seen at their wool work, where native wool is carded on the new machine just provided and knit into worthwhile articles. Ordinary wool was also being knit into socks, sweaters, etc. Some beadwork was being undertaken, belts being made on frames. These frames, I should add, were made by the boys in the manual training shop. The manual..."
training and gardening work at this school is under the direction of Mr. P. J. Corcoran. A number of simple articles of use in the school have been made since my last visit. The manual training shop was perfectly clean and tools supplied were in good order.

The academic work at the school has also improved and with a large group in Grades 7 and 8 another visit in the spring will be necessary for testing purposes prior to the pupils' graduation.

In conclusion I may say that the Ste. Catherine Consolidated Indian Day School is a credit to the Department and to the Sisters in charge - the Sisters of St. Ann."

Inspector Barry's report indicates that the Ste. Catherine School is one of the most successful schools operated by the Department anywhere in the Dominion. It is interesting to note that a group of the pupils have reached Grade 8 and will no doubt pass their entrance examination this year. You are aware that transportation is provided for the pupils in attendance at this school. Despite this fact, however, the attendance has never been wholly satisfactory at any time since the school was first established. I am at this date in communication with Commissioner MacKay, in the hope that the time at his disposal will enable him to make a special inspection of the school and thus be in a position to recommend ways and means whereby the attendance can be improved.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended November 30, 1941.

WELFARE:

Relief expenditures for the period April 1 - October 31 amounted to $872,082.90, compared with an expenditure of $559,750.41 for the corresponding period of last year. These figures represent a net decrease of $112,336.51. The greatest decrease, $57,999.91 - is reported from the province of Quebec. However, for some reason that is not easily explained, relief costs in the province of Manitoba remain comparatively high. Relief expenditures at certain agencies in this province, such as Clandehoye and Fisher River, remain practically the same as last year. The crop harvested in Manitoba, on the other hand, appears to be on the whole better than the crop harvested in the other two Prairie Provinces. A great deal of difficulty was experienced in the harvesting operations as the result of exceptionally heavy rains. It is possible, now that the harvesting operations have been completed, that the results of these operations will be reflected in relief costs in Manitoba during the months immediately ahead of us.

As the result of a conference held with Mr. Elliott Moses early in the month, a Short Course program has been arranged for the following agencies:

| Agency               | Dates                  |
|----------------------|------------------------|
| Six Nations          | January 5 - January 16, 1942 |
| Tyendinaga           | January 13 - January 30, 1942 |
| Moravian             | February 2 - February 6, 1942 |
| Caradoc              | February 16 - February 27, 1942 |
| Sarnia               | March 5 - March 12, 1942 |
| Walpole Island       | March 18 - March 20, 1942 |
| Saugeen              | March 23 - March 27, 1942 |
| Cape Croker          | April 3 - April 10, 1942 |
