This Division will type the programs and assume responsibility for the publicity necessary to make these courses a success. The lecturers will be provided free by the Agricultural College at Guelph, the University of Toronto and the Extension Service of the Provincial Government.

An encouraging report on what one might term subsistence farming or subsistence gardening has been received from Dr. T. J. Orford; in his report dated October 27, 1941, Dr. Orford states:

"The potatoes grown during the past season have..."
have all been taken up. Every Indian family living here has sufficient to carry through until next year. Forty bags have been sent to Rupert's House and 30 to East Main for next spring's planting at these places. In addition to this, the present root-house is full - about 225 bags of which in the spring about 50 will be sent to Albany and 40 to Ogoki and Pagwa for seeding purposes. It is estimated that we have grown about 1100 bags of potatoes altogether this year. As I intimated when in Ottawa, it is my intention to enlarge the gardens for next year in order to produce other root crops, such as turnips, carrots and parsnips, and to use Moose Factory as a centre of distribution for other points in the Bay area."

Little difficulty has been experienced by Indians in securing employment throughout the summer and fall months, and work is likely to remain plentiful throughout the winter. Mr. E. S. Noble, managing director of the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, in a letter to the Department dated November 17, 1941, states:

"We, as well as other companies in this district, are very short of pulpwood cutters this season. At the present time we ourselves could use six or seven hundred more cutters, while the Abitibi Power & Paper Company, Limited, tell me that they could use over 3000 more men between this and the Port Arthur section".

Mr. Noble adds:

"Our camps are excellent; in fact we think they are the best lumber camps in the country.

"We have work the year round for these pulpwood cutters, although we must admit that for one month in the spring the bush is extremely wet and very few men want to work in it. However, if they do want to work, the work is there for them".

Arrangements have been made whereby twelve men will be sent from the Battleford agency to Kapuskasing by way of experiment. If these men are successful and willing to remain on the job, no doubt other groups will be sent to the Kapuskasing district from time to time, particularly groups of men from certain drought-stricken areas in Saskatchewan.

Indian Agent Todd, in his October report on the Kwawkewlth Agency, states:

"All the Indians of this agency have been profitably employed in the fishing industry this season, being one of the largest on record, with the result that the able-bodied Indians, both men and women, are in a good financial position. To date there have been more than a quarter million cases of fish canned at the three canneries adjacent to Alert Bay, and I am informed by the Fishery Department that..."
before the season is over they anticipate half a million cases will have been packed from this district alone. This is the largest pack in the history of British Columbia.

A striking illustration of the results that follow intensive and scientific cultivation of land in certain sections of British Columbia is provided by Indian Agent Strang. In his report for October Mr. Strang states:

"From approximately 2½ acres of land planted in onions confiscated under trespass, which I employed Indians to cultivate and harvest, there has already been shipped and marketed through the Farm Produce Control Board 26½ tons of No. 2 and 2½ tons No. 3 onions. Returns for this crop have not yet been received, but I expect to receive $40 per ton for the No. 2 and $20 per ton for the No. 3, out of which will be paid, of course, freight and wages for harvesting. This experiment has proved to the Indians that they themselves can grow onions profitably and that the climate in this district is ideal for growing them."

Indian Agent Booth, in his report on the Qu'Appelle Agency for October, states:

"The Indian farmers in this agency have had a poor year as far as crops are concerned, but the Wheat Reduction Bonus proved a boon to them, and I have cheques amounting to $2,751 from the Department of Agriculture for distribution to the 45 farmers who applied for this bonus. This amount has not only relieved the Indian from his current debts, but in most cases I have been able to purchase sufficient supplies to carry him and his family through the winter months."

Mr. Booth adds:

"The Homemakers Clubs on the Assiniboine, Pasqua and Standing Buffalo Reserves are all doing good work, not only for their own members but for any destitute Indians who are unable to help themselves. The supply of Air Force clothing sent to these reserves is being remade into the very best of garments for the children of school age and under. I have seen boys' pants and smocks, girls' dresses and waists made from this clothing, which would be a credit to any organization off the reserve. There should not be any reason for any child going without warm garments for this winter."

The Lands, Parks and Forests Branch intend to slaughter a number of Elk in the Banff area during the winter. This elk meat will be placed at our disposal for distribution to Indians and will be distributed under the personal direction -
direction of Inspector Schmidt.

The following exchange of correspondence between the Department and Mr. C. A. Spinney, Indian Agent, Kentville, N.S., illustrates the difficulty experienced by our officials from time to time in administering Indian relief and welfare, in co-operation with a certain type of Indian agent who appears to lack the intellectual capacity necessary to undertake the ordinary duties and responsibilities of an Indian agency. Departmental letter of November 24, 1941, reads in part as follows:

"This office has approved for Miss Marguerite Ioney $15.00 per month in special relief, together with one (1) dozen eggs per week, and one (1) quart of milk per day. The combined total of the two accounts amounts to $19.00. Your attention is drawn to the fact that this tubercular Indian girl apparently consumed the following during the month of October:

- 4 lbs. of Meat - obtained from G. L. West -
- 10 lbs. Beef - obtained from Alex Duvno -
- 4 lbs. Pork -
- 6 lbs. Codfish -
- 1 doz. Herring -
- 2 cans Salmon -

"I am sure you will agree with me that this girl could not possibly consume this quantity of meat."

Mr. Spinney, in his reply of November 26, submits the following explanation:

"Just what do you mean when you make reference to the amount of money this girl is costing the taxpayer, or that I am not concerned what amount of money this girl is costing the tax-payer? What taxpayers are paying into the funds for the upkeep of the Department of Indian Affairs? I am sure there is no tax-payer paying anything toward the Department of Indian Affairs for the province of Nova Scotia. If so, I would like to know this."

TRAINING:

Accompanied by Mr. Jackson, and by Mr. Buck of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, I visited Caughnawaga on November 28th. The time at our disposal, while somewhat limited, enabled us to visit the schools, all of which were in operation at that time, and to observe a number of the teachers at work in the classrooms. I am convinced that the courses of study provided at Caughnawaga will compare favourably with courses of study provided at any public school anywhere in the Dominion. I was interested to learn from the Sister Superior, the Reverend Sister
Jean de Dieu, that no attempt is made to teach French at any of the schools on the reserve. Mr. Doucet and Inspector Wescott, who visited the schools at the opening of the academic year, expressed the view that it would be much more advantageous to the pupils if they were given a good course in English and permitted to abandon the course in French. Mr. Doucet took this position largely because the Indian pupils dislike French and because they enter school with a very limited knowledge of English - hence his desire to make their course in English as comprehensive and as thorough as possible. We did not have an opportunity to meet Mr. Wescott, the manual training instructor who, under the existing arrangement, conducts classes three days during the week. However, the principal in charge of the school appears to be well satisfied with his work. It was interesting to learn from her that the boys enjoy their course in manual training more than they enjoy any of the other branches of study. Mr. Doucet will visit Caughnawaga again prior to the Christmas holidays and review the work undertaken and accomplished since his last visit.

Reports indicate that the suspension of our building program is likely to result in overcrowded and congested classrooms, both at our Indian day and residential schools, in the immediate future. Inspector MacKenzie, in his report on the Sandy Bay Residential School, dated November 5, 1941, states:

"I understand that there are close to 150 children on this reserve who should be attending school, if accommodation were available. As it is, the 92 now enrolled have to attend in alternate periods. These attend, in groups, classroom activities and then go down stairs for manual and vocational instruction and training while other groups take their places in the classrooms. The teachers are doing good work in planning and making work-books. The language work-books suggested last year are proving very helpful. These Sisters in my judgment are doing a grand job and are eager to co-operate fully in making their teaching useful and effective."

Inspector Eldon F. Simms, in his report dated November 3 on the Portage la Prairie Residential School, states:

"As can readily be seen on looking over the registration figures for these two rooms, it is impossible for these teachers to carry out a proper educational program with such enormous classes. The senior room is not too bad because several of the older pupils attend in relays or half days and work outside otherwise. In the junior grades, however, the overcrowding is such that no teacher could do justice to the class. I suggest, therefore, that another room be opened to take care of the beginners in Grade I. To cover the increased cost it would be necessary to raise the number of pupils for which the school can obtain grants. The Principal assures..."
me that he could accommodate several more pupils. At present the situation is such that he has to turn Indian children away."

The Reverend C. F. Hives has now taken charge of the St. George's School at Lytton, B. C. In a personal letter to me dated November 13, he states:

"I would like to bring the pupilage at this school up to 180 if it could be arranged. There will be no difficulty whatever in getting the children. We have at present 166 and I know the children will be crowding to get in before long. I wish you would keep this in mind and, if at all possible, allow us the 180. The staff, of course, would have to be increased. We have all the farm, dairy and garden produce available for that number, and it would be that much more to meet our financial obligations".

Mr. Hives' reference to the school building is very depressing, in view of the fact that the building was constructed at considerable expense a few years ago. Mr. Hives states that the building itself is a horrible mess compared with Shingwauk. He adds: "Poor old Gurney Orr sure improved his plans when he built Shingwauk and he sure got a wonderful contractor to execute his plans as compared with the horrible workmanship of this place. However, the building is here and I know if we are careful in the manipulation of money we can greatly improve it".

Memorandum:

TO DOCTOR McGUIRE,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended December 31, 1941.

TRAINING:

The Caughnawaga Senior School was totally destroyed by fire on December 18th. This school was of solid brick construction. It was built in the year 1927, at a cost of approximately $50,000.00. It is our intention to make provision whereby the pupils enrolled at the Caughnawaga Senior School can be temporarily accommodated in buildings until the end of the present academic year.

The following schools have been destroyed by fire since I entered the Department in December, 1926—Grouard, Alberni, Carcross, Albany and Ahousaht Residential Schools; the classroom building at the Alberni Residential School; and the Hunter's Point Indian Day School. In addition to these buildings, the staff residence at the Kenora Residential School and the blacksmith shop at the Kootenay Residential School were also destroyed by fire. It is just possible that when times again become normal we may find it advisable to attach to this Branch a building commissioner. I note that public school boards in the larger centres throughout the Dominion have a building commissioner on their staff. This man is definitely responsible for the construction and repair of school buildings and the inspection of such buildings. He is called upon, also, to make an intensive study of the best ways and means of eliminating fire hazards.

Indian day schools in the province of New Brunswick have been inspected until this year by a departmental inspector. The Inspector of these schools, Father Ryan, retired toward the end of the last academic year, and immediately following his retirement an agreement was entered into with the New Brunswick Department of Education whereby our schools are now inspected by the public school inspectors of the province. The first reports of these inspectors reached me a few days ago. These reports are interesting in that they are the reports of men who have not been at any time until now in contact with our Indian educational program or the teachers in charge of our schools.
schools. Inspector Fox, in his report on the Oromocto Indian Day School, dated November 28, states:

"This was my first visit to the Oromocto Indian Day School. I was surprised to find such splendid equipment and pupil's attainments. Everything conceivable has been done at this school to make surroundings comfortable, attractive and conducive to progress. It might be advisable to lower one of the blackboards in order that small children might use it."

Inspector J. E. Debruce, in his report on the Fel River School, dated December 5, states:

"I think very good work is being done at this school. I was favourably impressed by the general appearance of the school as well as by the work accomplished. There is no doubt that this teacher is an efficient one."

Inspector Titus, in a recent report on the St. Mary's School, at Devon, N.B., states:

"I found this school progressing favourably. The girls have been taught knitting and considerable work has been done along this line. The boys have already made coat hangers, tie racks and a book-case."

Inspector Anderson, in his report on the Kingsclear School, dated November 24, states:

"This building is in a good state of repair and kept clean and neat. The girls have been taught knitting and sewing, while the boys have made several very useful articles, such as coat hangers, etc."

Mr. Doucet visited the Maria, Lovette, Restigouche and Caughnawaga Schools early in the month. Mr. Doucet's report to me, dated December 20, 1941, on the work of these schools, is on the whole satisfactory. He had an opportunity, at the time of his visit to Quebec City, to discuss our educational program with the officials of the Provincial Department of Education. There has been a wide-spread feeling in the Province of Quebec for a number of years that the public school program is altogether too abstract and academic in character. The departmental officials are fully aware of this fact and are putting forth a sincere attempt to introduce a program of a more practical and vocational nature. The introduction of this program, however, both in the public and Indian schools of Quebec, will require time and the exercise of a great deal of patience. It should begin with the training of the teachers in the normal schools of the province. It is significant that the officials with whom Mr. Doucet discussed our program were enthusiastically in favour of what we are attempting to do at our schools and promised to co-operate with -
with us in the promotion of this program. There is at the present time a lack of fully qualified men capable of giving instruction in woodwork, auto mechanics, electric welding, etc. It is not at all likely that such men will be available at any time until the conclusion of the war. In the meantime, however, an attempt will be made to introduce vocational studies at our schools in Quebec, using to the best possible advantage the instructors that are able to secure.

The Calgary Albertan, in its issue of November 26, publishes an interesting report on an Indian art exhibition, organized at that time in the city of Calgary. The writer in this report states:

"The children of the Inkomeen Indian School at Oliver have told the story of the Nativity, as conceived by the Indians. They have painted animal heads, the Madonna and Child, and Palm Sunday, but particularly outstanding are the various Indian figures painted on buckskin."

These children have been encouraged to take up these artistic studies by their teacher, Mr. Anthony Walsh. This article continues:

"Though only 18 years old, Gerald Tailfeathers displayed at least eight water colours. This Indian boy specializes in landscapes. His Indian portraits, however, far surpass his scenery collection and bespeak a future for this youthful Redskin.

"In opening the exhibition, Dr. W. G. Carpenter, Director of Technical Education for the Province, commended those responsible for making it possible for Calgarians to see this fine Indian art, which he hoped might bring about a revival of Indian arts and crafts in Alberta."

WELFARE:

It is gratifying to report that despite the approach of the winter season, work suitable for Indians appears to be plentiful throughout the Dominion. In my report of last month I referred to the employment by the Spruce Falls Paper and Paper Company of twelve Indians from the Battleford Agency on their pulpwood limits at Kapuskasing, Ontario. I am now in receipt of a letter from the managing director of this company, in which he intimates that the work of the twelve Indians has been on the whole fairly satisfactory and that he is now anxious to secure at least two hundred additional Indians, preferably from Saskatchewan, and if at all possible, Indians experienced in bush work. We have already communicated with the Indian Agent at Battleford and the General Superintendent of Indian Agencies at Regina, in respect to this matter. It is our hope that we will be able to secure 200 able-bodied Indians for this work.

Indian Agent -
Indian Agent Burk, in his report dated December 4th, states:

"I beg to report that a contract has been signed by Mr. F. E. Johnson, President of the Model Mink Farm at Fort William, with the Fort William Band for 300 tons of herring at $28.50 per ton. This price includes freezing and bagging and is f.o.b. Scuaw Bay."

Indian Agent Down, in his report on the Sarnia Agency, dated December 8th, states:

"Our tractors on the Sarnia Reserve have been busy almost every day. In connection with this, I have been out on the reserves in an endeavour to check the acreage ploughed, also fall wheat plantings. I am able to report an increase in fall wheat plantings but a decrease in fall ploughing for 1947 spring planting. This is perhaps a natural trend when one considers the increasing industrial activities with its offer of higher and steady wages, especially among our Indian population. It is difficult to keep them interested in agriculture in normal times and much more difficult when so many other channels are opening up. This is especially so concerning our people on the Sarnia Reserve with its close proximity to the United States. The recession is also beginning to have its effect on Kettle and Stony Point Reserves. I am making no effort to discourage this condition in favour of Agriculture—first because I know it is of no use; second, because the Indians not by any means a natural agriculturist and can only be kept on the land when all else fails. By this do not mean to infer our agricultural efforts have suddenly disappeared, or that we should curb our efforts, but I do say if we, the Indian agents, farm instructors and field staff generally, can hold what we have, it will be an accomplishment and perhaps lead to a more intensive agricultural program when all this world strife and turmoil is at an end. I have great faith in post war conditions for Agriculture and it will be my endeavour to build toward that end."

Indian Agent Simpson, in his report on the Duck Lake Agency, dated December first, states:

"The cattle owners have been engaged in completing repairs to stables and shelters for their live stock. A few have found employment in the camps and with farmers adjacent to their reserves. A number have been engaged in marketing cordwood, for which there is a good demand and good prices. A number have also been engaged in trapping skunk, valued at from $1.00 to $2.50 each, and weasel at 70¢ to $1.10 each. Indians on the reserves have been snaring rabbits, which are more plentiful than they have been at any time for several years. They are dryin'..."
drying the meat and selling the furs at from five to eight cents each. The value of the fur catch for November is reported at $1,060."

Indian Agent Jones, in his report on the File Hills Agency, dated December 8, states:

"Wool and other such materials have been supplied by the Red Cross, and the Indian women are now knitting socks and making up garments. This month a parcel containing 1,000 cigarettes and food was mailed to each of the 11 boys from this agency now serving overseas. Arrangements have also been made to send smokes, etc., to each of the boys from this agency serving in the Army in Canada."

Indian Agent Waite, in his report on the Portage la Prairie Agency, dated December 1, states:

"The season for commercial fishing opened on the 11th and to date very little fishing has been done. The condition is better on Lake Winnipegosis. Ice formed on the 12th of the month and the Indians are fishing close to the shore. The centre of the lake is still open. Pickerel opened at 7¢ per pound and the catch has been the best for some years."

Exceptionally fine work has been undertaken and accomplished by Indian Agent Young on the Griswold Reserve. In his report dated December 15 the Agent states:

"On the Oak Lake Reserve the community farm debt was totally paid off last spring. This year we invested in a small combine, which easily paid for itself during the harvesting operations this fall. We have recently traded in our old tractor and purchased a new one and still have a substantial bank balance.

"On the Oak River Reserve Community Farm we were able to meet our 1940 and 1941 payments and interest this fall, which amounted to $366. We still have a good bank balance.

"The Indian farmers on these reserves were all able to save their feed for the coming year, to pay their current year's expenses and purchase a good supply of flour for winter use. I feel that the Indian farmers on my two community farms have had a very successful year."

Indian Agent Taylor, in his report on the Williams Lake Agency for November, states:

"Indians have been busy cutting Christmas trees - some families have earned two to three hundred dollars for little more than one month's work. Many are now hunting squirrels and making as high as $20.00 per day, with skins worth $5.00 each. There is a dearth of labour in the district and the Indians reap the benefit. Most of the bands should be in very good shape for the winter, which so far gives every indication of being a mild and open one."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended January 31, 1942.

WELFARE:

Relief costs for the period April 1 to December 31, 1941, amounted to $469,171.58, compared with an expenditure of $653,729.80 for the corresponding period of last year. These figures represent a net decrease amounting to $184,158.77. The most substantial reduction - $61,165.03 - has taken place in the province of Manitoba where able-bodied Indians are experiencing little difficulty in securing employment, even in the winter months. Relief costs for this period in the province of Ontario amounted to $57,444.82. Of this amount approximately $25,000.00 has been expended in the Sioux Lookout and James Bay agencies. These agencies have a population (last census) of 8,380 as against an Indian population of 30,145 in the whole of the province. It will thus be seen that approximately fifty per cent of our relief expenditures in Ontario are incurred in the two northern agencies. However, relief costs even in these two agencies, are substantially lower than they are in the northern agencies of Manitoba.

I have noted that relief costs in the James Bay Agency, with a population of 4,014, for the period April 1 to December 31, this year amounted to $18,527.15, while relief costs in the Clandebone Agency for the same period, with a population of 2,463 Indians, amounted to $16,226.17.

Inspector Hamilton, however, appears to be of the opinion that relief costs in Manitoba represent the minimum expenditures that we can expect if the old and incapacitated Indians in his province are to escape hardship and suffering. In a letter dated January 19, 1942, in which he comments on economic and relief conditions throughout the province, he states:

"In my opinion the relief allowed is altogether inadequate and does not begin to supply the bare necessities. The general public would, I believe, brand it as disgraceful".

I am personally of the opinion that the refusal of the Indians in northern Manitoba to go in more extensively for subsistence gardening and the construction of root-houses explains -
explains to a large extent the high costs of relief in the province.

An interesting comment on departmental relief allowances and the effect of these allowances on the character of the Indian population comes from the Yukon. The Missionary in charge of the St. Barnabas Mission at Moosehide who, it would appear, is himself an Indian, in the last issue of "Northern Lights", a magazine published in the interests of the Diocese of the Yukon, states:

"Many of our menfolk work on an equal footing with whites during the summer and they are beginning to realize that if they are to receive respect and equality from fellow citizens they have to put their own house in order. A new spirit of co-operation, however, is abroad and we are trying to live without relief, that most shattering climax ever devised by a white man for a native. As Moosehide natives have been allowed relief since gold rush days, it is going to be some time before it becomes a custom of the past. Prayers supported by hard work are bound to bring success".

Illegitimacy on Indian reserves remains one of our most acute and most disturbing problems. This problem has been very forcefully brought to our attention during the month. Indian Agent McMullen, Colchester Agency, N. S., reported five cases in a single letter. The Trusts Division report that 120 Indians, all of whom had been refused admission to the Band because of illegitimacy, were recently admitted to membership, when Mr. McCrimmon visited the reserve and discussed their claims with the members of the Sarnia Indian Council. The plight of the illegitimate children on an Indian reserve is in a very real sense pitiful and tragic. Frequently abandoned by their mothers and disowned by the members of the band, they receive care for a time in our residential schools - only to be discharged at the age of 16, literally without a friend in the world. It is just possible that during the days that lie ahead of us an attempt will have to be made to secure maintenance orders from the putative fathers of these children. The fact that maintenance orders are now secured in a number of provinces from such fathers has reduced illegitimacy among the white population very substantially in recent years. A rather encouraging report of an attempt made to safeguard the morality of the girl graduates of a residential school comes from the Principal of the St. Phillips Indian Residential School, near Kamsack, Pelly Agency, Saskatchewan. The Principal, Rev. Father A. Paradis, in his report, states:

"The Department is interested in having ex-pupils live up to the moral education received at residential schools. May I remark that in spite of our efforts too many of our boys and...
most promising girls, after being discharged, soon lose their honor and sense of moral behavior, through immoral influences on the reserves, irresponsible parents, or non-enforcement of existing laws and regulations. When mothers and fathers, young men and women, are left to live unlawfully or to change wife or husband, permanently unmolested, what can you expect of any young girl let loose unprotected? In quest of means to encourage the parents to protect their daughters, and reward our deserving girls, I have in the past year set up special wedding celebrations for ex-pupils who have remained faithful to their good moral standing. They are married in the school chapel, and the ceremony is followed by a banquet. There are from 30 to 35 guests, among whom are the Indian Agent, the Chiefs and their wives, the parents and relatives. The bride is presented with dishes, kitchen utensils, a trunk, etc., as household equipment - this to the amount of $50. We had two of these special weddings this past year. As this is part of the assistance that ex-pupils should receive from the Department, could our school or all schools be given an allowance for such purposes?"

In my report of last month I referred to the number of Indians (172 in all) from the province of Saskatchewan who had secured work on the pulpwood limits at Kapuskasing, Ontario. In this connection Indian Agent Ostrander, in his report dated January 20, states:

"There are now 78 Indians of this agency working in Manitoba and Ontario in pulpwood and lumber camps, none getting less than $50.00 a month and board. A considerable proportion of their earnings is sent home to their families, with the result that conditions are greatly improved on the reserves of the south part of the agency. The outlook now for the winter on these reserves is not nearly as bad as anticipated early in the season. Reports from the points where the Indians are working are to the effect that their work has been on the whole satisfactory to the employers there and there is a probability that work of this kind will become more important as a source of livelihood for Indians for the duration of the war at least. Most of my time for three weeks has been devoted towards assisting and encouraging the Indians to get to these distant points, but I feel that my efforts have not been in vain. The income from this work has been between $6,000 and $7,000 a month to otherwise starving Indians."

In view of existing economic conditions in the Prairie Provinces, it is perhaps too much to expect encouraging -
encouraging reports from those charged with the responsibility of operating our community farms. However, the reports from these farms on the whole are reasonably satisfactory, with the exception of two or three farms in the drought-stricken area of Saskatchewan. Interest payments to the Revolving Fund will be made this year in full. Indian Agent Young, in his report on the community farms of the Griswold Agency, dated September 16, 1941, states:

"On the Oak Lake Reserve the community farm debt was totally paid off last spring. We invested in a small combine, which easily paid for itself during the harvesting operations. We recently traded in our old tractor and purchased a new one and still have a substantial bank balance. On the Oak River Reserve Community Farm we were able to meet our 1940 and 1941 payments of principal and interest in full this fall. This payment amounted to $366. We still have a good bank balance.

"The Indian farmers were all able to save their feed for the coming year, pay their current year's expenses and purchase a good supply of flour for the winter. I feel that the Indian farmers on my two community farms have indeed had a very successful year."

TRAINING:

A number of our Indian day schools in the East have undertaken, with enthusiasm, the task of repairing and remodelling a large quantity of discarded military clothing, sent forward to the agencies during the last two or three months. Samples of this clothing, returned to the Department as exhibits, reflect great credit, not only on the pupils, but on the teachers responsible for their instruction. It would appear that a certain amount of this clothing is taken over by the teachers in charge of the schools and assigned as a vocational project to groups of pupils, particularly senior girls. The skill and ability of these pupils to unravel yarn from discarded socks and reknit it into socks and sweaters has been truly remarkable.

Mr. Doucet is at present engaged in the organization and promotion of vocational courses at Tyendinaga, Six Nations, Ramo and Rice and Mud Lake Agencies. At the time of his visit to a number of these reserves, Mr. Doucet will also attend the Short Courses that are usually in session at this season of the year. He will report later on what he considers to be the value of these courses and on ways and means whereby in his judgment they can be improved. I should add that the attendance at these courses last year was in no sense satisfactory - hence
our desire to do everything possible to make these Short Courses more attractive.

The Vancouver Province, in its issue of December 18, 1941, contains an article entitled "Dormant Talent Encouraged". This article reads in part as follows:

"The Society for Furtherance of B.C. Indian Arts and Crafts contributes to the Christmas season two unique publications, illustrated entirely by Indian children of the province. These little volumes, entertaining and originals, are inspired additions to western art and literature.

"Meet Mr. Coyote" is illustrated by boys of the Thompson tribe at the Indian school of St. George at Lytton. This first series of legends of the tribe, gathered by the boys' teacher, Noel Stewart, has a genuine regional note. Both pictures and story have more than a suggestion of that rich flavor or naive contact with the animal people which made 'Uncle Remus' a classic of the Southern States.

"A handsome reprint of 'The Tale of the Nativity', illustrated by the Indian boy-artist Sis-hu-lk, is undoubtedly destined for considerable public favor as something distinctly of the province. Already a first edition has been exhausted, purchased not only here but far beyond our borders.

"The Tale of the Nativity", as told to their teacher, Anthony Walsh, by the Indian children of Inikameep and described in pictures by the boy-artist whose work has been admired in the Art Gallery and even in London, has a simple delightful form which is almost mediaeval in quality and structure.

"Both drawings and narrative describe the event as if the Nativity had taken place in remote times in the Okanagan Valley. The unexpected variations, bringing the story right home to our doors so to speak, produce an effect of singular and poignant charm."

Indian Agent Christie, in his report on the Bella Coola Agency for December, states:

"The usual Christmas concerts were held by the Indian school children. A small charge was made at the Bella Coola School, realizing $30.00, which was turned over to the Red Cross. Another program that this school put on entirely by the older girls realized $50.00. This was devoted to the same worthy purpose".

Indian Agent Gooderham, in his report on the Blackfoot Agency, dated January 5, 1942, states:

"Both -
Both residential schools were visited during the month. The writer was particularly impressed by the number of stock at the Old Sun (Anglican) School. There were 55 head of cattle, of which 16 cows are milking. There were three sows with three large litters of young pigs, besides 25 feeders and one boar. Two hundred and one hens were laying an average of five dozen eggs daily. At the Crossfoot (R.C.) School a good start has been made in the organization of a vocational course and the building used for this purpose has been fitted with benches. It is sufficiently large to handle all those who are taking this course.

More or less as an experiment and also because children have been retained in school almost continuously since the summer holidays, the pupils of both schools got a week's holidays at Christmas. Rations were issued to their parents and it was the first time I ever noted that the parent or guardian realized that he had a responsibility to look after his own. The enthusiasm of getting the children out, however, was not so great when they realized that they would have to feed them and keep them warm and in good health during the period that the Indian normally runs here and there all over the country. The pupils are now back in school and I believe they are mostly in good health. I have noted one thing: that there was less travel to the city and fewer Indians drunk and in trouble than in former years. Possibly this is due to the fact that they had to remain at home and look after their families. At any rate it was good training for the parents.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended February 28, 1942.

TRAINING.

The officials of the Training Division have been reminded from time to time of the waywardness of the graduates of our Indian residential schools and the tendency, on the part of a large number of these pupils, to revert rapidly to a mode of life that reflects little, if any, credit on the institutions in which they have been trained. In my report of last month I intimated that the problem of illegitimacy had become one of the most disturbing problems confronting us on a number of our reserves. It would be a great mistake, however, to conclude that all the graduates of our schools become delinquent or wayward. This month, an unusually large number of reports have reached us from residential school graduates and day school pupils who have really made good.

The "Grouard Echoes", a magazine published by the Grouard Residential School, contains in its last issue a photo of Dom. Povargue, a graduate of the Grouard Indian Residential School, who joined the Air Force shortly after the outbreak of the war and who is now stationed at the R.A.F. Station, Dyce, near Aberdeen, Scotland. It would appear that this boy has recently married an old country girl and is rendering outstanding service in the Air Force. In his letter to the Grouard School he intimates that he spent the Christmas holiday season with his wife's people at Newcastle. He expresses satisfaction that so many Indians from the Grouard district have joined the Army. In the same magazine, there appears a letter from Harry Thomas, O.M.I. This young Indian graduated from the Grouard Residential School a few years ago and later took up a course of theological training at the Lebret Oblate College. In a letter to Sister Jean, of Grouard, this young Priest writes:

"How did you like Churchill's address to the Senate and Congress? He simply arouses me. I often told you when I was young that he was my MAN, and my liking for him has not decreased".

The "Pine Tree Chief", a magazine published by a group of young Indians of the Six Nations Reserve, in its issue dated February 13, refers to the first
Indian girl that has joined the Canadian Women's Auxiliary Air Forces. This girl, Dorothy Montour, is a graduate of the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie and a graduate of the Brantford Collegiate Institute. Another graduate of the Shingwauk Home, Nellie R. Oke, of the Oka Reserve, is now employed at the Cocuasteza Hospital. This girl, an orphan, graduated from the Civic Hospital, London, Ontario, a couple of years ago and spent one year as nurse at the Anglican residential school, Carcross, Yukon Territory.

Here is a letter received a few days ago from the Anglican Theological College, University Hill, Vancouver. This letter is from an Indian student and reads as follows:

"Perhaps it is well to introduce myself first. My name is Frank Calder and I come from the native village of Greenville, of the Nass River Agency, under Agent Gillett.

"I am at the present time taking my third year in Theology at the Anglican Theological College, along with my Arts course at the university. It is of this latter course I wish to speak to you. For the last four years I have been pretty much on my own so far as my education has been concerned. Until now I have done fairly well with my fees, but for this Easter term I find that I am short about $40. If the Department can make a loan of this amount I would certainly be thankful. I shall repay this amount before the end of August, as I do not want this to be a one-sided affair. I had hoped that I would never have to seek financial support from the Department, but now I feel I must, as the payment of my university fees is now overdue. In closing I want you to know that I appreciate the work and kindness the Department has given me in the past."

The Reverend A. E. Minchin, recently appointed principal of the Shingwauk Home School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., in a letter dated February 13, states:

"Stella McDougall, a graduate of this school and a graduate of the Sault Ste. Marie Technical School, has secured a position in the Civil Service at Ottawa. Stella was 17 years old in January and has been informed that her monthly salary to begin will amount to $86.00."

These letters - all of them brought to our attention within the month - suggest that a number of Indian school graduates do succeed in life and that a large number might perhaps follow in their footsteps if we had at our disposal the machinery necessary to give more guidance and direction to our school graduates during that critical period immediately following their discharge from our educational institutions.

Inspector Schmidt, in a report on the St. Paul's (C. E.) Indian Residential School, Blood Agency, states:

"I am pleased to report that a start has been made at this school in the promotion of manual training."
A small outside building has been converted into a work-shop, benches arranged and a start made at woodworking, under the supervision of Mr. A. Doodle. As time goes on and the work becomes organized, this building will have to be enlarged or a new one arranged for. However, now that a start has been made at this work, let us hope that it will be kept up and extended.

Inspector Stehelin, in his report on the Grouard Residential School, dated December 1, 1941, states:

"The introduction of the Youth Training Movement has been of great assistance to the pupils of this school. I have found a great change, especially in the attitude of the boys. It appears that now they have found something in which they can excel. This institution is particularly fortunate in having the services of a man like Father Forcade (physical instructor). A special trip was made by me to Grouard to attend a Youth Training display at this school.

Upon the occasion of my inspection some time was spent in the Home Economics and Home Nursing class, organized by the senior girls. The quality of the work being done by this class is very fine. On display were uniforms for the youth training groups, sewing of all kinds, fabrics and dress materials, hooked rugs, tailored articles, etc. The girls are indeed very proud of their work, and justly so. Through this Home Economics Class it might be possible to organize some local home industry. The leather work and bead industry in the district is not very profitable.

Indian residential schools, to be a success, must bear relationship to the three C's - Correlation, Cooperation and Coordination. Mathematics provide an easy way of beginning correlation. Everything in the school costs how much? Where do these things come from? How are they obtained or manufactured, etc.? Cooperation should enter into work and play. Each pupil should have a certain house detail to do. Coordination will be the direct result of correlation and cooperation."

Inspector Schmidt, in his report on the St. Mary's (R. C.) Residential School, Blood Agency, dated February 10, states:

"Good work has been done by the manual training class. It has been found that the work-shop, a separate building from the main school, is cold in winter and rather difficult to heat - for which reason work in this room is not being carried on during cold weather. The principal has prepared plans for enlarging this building, which will double the available floor space. The new building will be properly finished, lined inside and insulated and a proper floor laid. When completed, it will comprise a number of ordinary carpenter's work benches, a forge, anvil, vice and bench, and will have double doors to allow a truck, tractor or other smaller-
sized farm machinery to be brought inside for repairing or overhauling at any time of the year. The shop is now equipped with an electric welding unit. The tools in use are well cared for and kept in separate lockers. There is a fair supply of materials—boards, planks, etc.—on hand. This is neatly piled in different sizes. Good work is being done in this shop.

"A new wind-break—a-foot board fence—was built around the winter stock feed plot this summer by the older boys.

WELFARE:

Indian Agent Smith, of the Birtle Agency, in sending forward the annual report on the Homemakers' Club organized by Miss M. E. Buckley, R.N., on the Rolling River Reserve, writes as follows:

"They do more needlework and also knitting on this reserve than they do on any of the other reserves in this agency. The wool and flannelette supplied by the Department is all made up by the women into clothing, socks and mitts for the old people, and the ones who do the work receive so much material for their own use.

"On the Rolling River Reserve they nearly all had good gardens last year, more and better gardens than they ever had before since I have known that reserve, and I think the Women's Club should get some credit for these results. When Miss Buckley went to the reserve only two or three of the women could knit and now all the young women can knit."

Indian Agent Moore, in his report on the Tyendinaga Reserve, dated February 3, refers to the agricultural Short Course recently conducted on the reserve under the direction of Mr. Elliott Moses. The Agent states:

"During the period January 12 to 30 agricultural, cooking and sewing short courses were held on the reserve and an exceptionally good class of 21 girls and young matrons attended the ladies' classes. Their sewing and cooking work was very proficient and all in attendance received considerable benefit from the classes. Due to the lack of young men most of whom are in service or working away from the reserve, the men's classes were not too well attended. However, they were present in sufficient numbers to make the class well worth while and some interesting and beneficial discussions took place at the lectures.

Major MacKay, in a letter to the Department dated February 13, refers to an interesting experiment in agricultural extension work undertaken by Indian Agent Christie at the Bella Coola Agency. The Commissioner in his letter states:

"I beg to advise that Mr. Indian Agent Christie organized a Boys' and Girls' Potato Club on the Bella Coola—
Coola Reserve, which has been an outstanding success, and one of the most commendable pieces of work undertaken by any Indian agent in this province during the past year. This Club is organized under the provisions of the provincial Department of Agriculture and the Canadian Council of Boys' and Girls' Clubs at Ottawa.

"Mr. Christie has submitted the list of prize winners in the club to the Department of Agriculture, and they are paying half of the $21.00 prize list, leaving a balance of $10.50, which Mr. Christie suggests should be paid by our Department. I have no hesitation in recommending that this expenditure should be authorized. I can personally vouch that the work of this club was highly satisfactory."

Indian Agent Ball, of the Vancouver Agency, in a letter dated February 11, writes:

"The women on the Squamish Reserve have now a strong organization. Without any financial assistance from the Department, these women have undertaken all kinds of welfare work on the reserve, besides raising funds for other needs. Recently they received two great bales of worn out army socks, and they have already utilized every bit of wool in them to make clothing. This is only one of many similar activities. Rugs are made from material collected among themselves and white friends. These women also visit the aged and sick Indians, doing housekeeping for them and some home nursing."

Agricultural operations on the Six Nations Reserve continue to make satisfactory progress. Major Randle appears to have succeeded in operating his tractors to the fullest extent possible. He appears to have succeeded, also, in persuading the Indians to utilize their own horse power in cooperation with the tractors in working out a very extensive and well-balanced agricultural program on the reserve. Large areas of land, that had become infested with weeds, have been broken up within the last two or three years and are now proving a source of revenue to their owners. Major Randle, in his report dated January 28, states:

"Weather conditions enabled our tractors to continue ploughing for a few days in December, during which time they ploughed 37 acres at eleven different farms. Then the frost came and since then all land operations have ceased.

"Our records show that during the farm season - April to mid-December - our tractors accomplished the following work on behalf of the farmers of the Six Nations and Mississauga Reserves:

| Ploughed | 1,329½ acres |
|----------|--------------|
| Tilled   | 1,359½ "     |
| Sowed    | 131 "        |
| Harvested (cut with binders) | 497 " |

"In carrying out these land operations during the season, our tractors made trips to 284 farms.

"Generally..."
Generally speaking, for the Indian farmer it was a good season. Returns from the acreage cropped were good, while prices generally were considerably higher than in 1940. As a result, most of them met their maturing obligations comfortably, with a decent margin left over in grain, fodder and feed for their winter use.

As in past seasons, both Councils, with departmental approval, purchased considerable coarse grain and grass seed from their own farmers, which seed when cleaned ensures a supply of seed for distribution among those farmers requiring it in the spring.
