Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended March 31, 1942.

TRAINING.

It is encouraging to learn from a number of sources that groups of young Indians, particularly teenage Indian girls, are displaying a keen interest in organized movements such as the Girl Guides Association. Mrs. H.F.H. Hertzberg, Commissioner of Girl Guides for Ontario, called at this office toward the end of February. Mrs. Hertzberg, in her interview, indicated that one of her field officials had expressed the opinion that she had at the Birch Island Indian School, Manitoulin Island Agency, one of the best girl guide groups, if not actually the best, in the province of Ontario. Immediately following Mrs. Hertzberg's visit, I communicated with the teacher of this school, Miss Eva L. Fortin. Miss Fortin, in her reply dated March 14, states:

"I have been working with this group of girl guides ever since I began teaching here 6 years ago. I am quite satisfied with the results of the Guide movement in this village. The girls have entered several contests and always with good results. I feel sure the school work has been promoted a great deal by the work of the Guides.

"As soon as the little girls of the village attain the age of reason, I invite them to come to Brownie meetings. These meetings are conducted by one of my Guides who I have trained to assume the responsibility of organizing the younger set to become Guides. This helps the little ones very much when they reach school age. When these Brownies have learned the Guide laws and grasp their significance I enroll them in the Guide Company. From then on we follow very closely the rules and regulations of the Girl Guide organization."

"The Victorian", a weekly newspaper published at Perth, New Brunswick, in its issue of March 19, 1942, published an article relating to a movie show organized by the Girl Guide group of the Tobique Indian Day School. This article reads:

"Over three hundred children came from Perth and Andover and outside districts, Kilburn, Tilley, Carlingford, Tobique Narrows and Lower Perth, on Tuesday to attend a movie, 'Baby Sandy', and five shorts, which were shown at the Capitol Theatre in Andover by the Maliseet Girl Guides of Indian Point, for the benefit of the Andover-Perth Red Cross Society. The children in the local..."
local schools were given the afternoon off to see the picture. The sum of $44 was realized from the show.

"The Maliseet Girl Guides used their own movie machine, which they bought and paid for with money raised in their weaving and knitting club, and it is a splendid machine. They also used their own films and ushered at the theatre, with the help of the Andover and Perth Girl Guides. The management and staff of the Capitol Theatre were in attendance and gave freely of their help and time.

"The Maliseet Girl Guides, under the direction of the Sisters of Charity, have been doing much valuable work for the Red Cross. Last year, besides donating $25, they knitted many babies' garments for the layettes which were sent overseas."

Indian Agent Phillips, Queen Charlotte Agency, B.C., in a letter dated March 6, refers to the Junior Red Cross that has been organized at the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools. The Agent in his letter states:

"Last year, the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools were organized as branches of the Junior Red Cross, under the name of the 'Haida Juniors'. Meetings are held periodically and at these news letters are read and discussed and the purposes and responsibilities of the membership stressed. Health rules are discussed and kept as closely as possible. The girls knit and make squares for woollen blankets. The boys in the meantime are making scrapbooks for a hospital. These pupils have been and still are collecting the following commodities: rubber, aluminum, glass, silver, paper, tinfoil, rags, newspapers, magazines, and tooth paste and shaving cream tubes.

Through the aims of the Junior Red Cross we hope not only to help Canada's war effort but to raise the tone of the schools and to arouse in the children a desire to serve the community and their own homes whenever an opportunity arises to do so. The children are already planning to hold a program of school sports around Easter time and to sell ice cream at the sports grounds on May 24th. The proceeds from these undertakings will be sent to the Junior Red Cross Funds."

I am personally of the opinion that organizations such as these should be encouraged and greatly extended. They provide the Indian youth with valuable lessons in the art of self-government. They encourage him, too, to assume responsibility for the accomplishment of tasks that he can carry out better and more economically for himself than any other agency designed to help him.

The Public School Inspectors in their reports are constantly reminding us of the difficulties experienced by Indian day and residential school teachers in providing instruction to Indian pupils who enter school without a working knowledge of the English language. Inspector Ferris, in his last report on the Ahtahkskoops Day School,
Carlton Agency, Sask., states:

"The most marked progress has been made during the past year in the pupils' command of conversational language. A good working vocabulary of words and expressions in common use has been developed. The pupils have been trained to answer questions in complete sentences.

"In the field of arithmetic, the pupils show speed and accuracy in the number facts. The drill in this activity is so organized that the weaker members of the group get extra practice. The higher grades showed skill in the formal processes as well as a fair measure of ability in the solution of problems.

"In reading, particular attention was given to the achievement of the Grade One group. This group is made up largely of pupils who entered school after the summer vacation. They had mastered at the time of my visit a vocabulary of from 60 to 100 words. The practice is followed of building up such a vocabulary before the Primer is placed in their hands. This is a sound practice. An improvement was noted too in the reading of the senior grades, more particularly with regard to fluency and expression. Mr. Bigge, who is a fully qualified teacher, holding a first class permanent certificate, conducts his school on sound psychological and pedagogical lines, adapting his methods to meet the peculiar needs of a school of this type. Mr. Bigge has continued and extended the manual work begun by his predecessor, Mr. Goodman."

The Ontario Department of Education, working in close cooperation with the Toronto Public and Separate School Boards, have been outstandingly successful during the last 10 or 15 years in the organization of classes for subnormal children, usually referred to as auxiliary classes. This work is under the immediate direction of two psychiatrists, Dr. Amos and Dr. Stothers. A representative of the Ontario Department of Education, who visited this Branch during the month, informed me that 80% of the girls who have passed through these classes during the last five years are now gainfully employed. This percentage does not include a number of the girls who have married during this period. The work undertaken and accomplished at these classes has received very favourable comment in American and English educational journals.

You will be interested to learn that an I. O. survey of a number of our residential schools in Ontario has been undertaken recently, under the immediate direction of Dr. Amos. A representative of the Department has already visited the following schools: Spanish, Mohawk, Shingwauk, Chapleau, Cecilia Jeffrey, Kenora and Fort Frances. A full report on this survey will be submitted to the Department immediately following the Easter holidays. In addition to this report, the first of its kind submitted to the Department, it is my intention to have Mr. Doucet visit Toronto with the object of attending the teachers' conference usually held during the Easter holiday period, to visit the auxiliary classes and to discuss with the psychiatrist attached to the Ontario Department of Education ways and means whereby our courses of study might be adjusted and brought into stricter conformity with the mental standing of the pupils in attendance at the schools where surveys have been completed."
I am particularly anxious that Mr. Doucet should discuss with the officials responsible for the survey the suggestion already made to me that teachers in Indian day and residential schools should receive special training for the work in which they are engaged. It would appear that when the auxiliary classes are first organized, teachers with the ordinary academic and professional standing were employed. It was soon learned however, from experience, that these teachers were incapable of providing worthwhile courses of study, with the result that the teachers now in charge of these classes are teachers who have spent at least one year in special normal school classes. The Ontario officials are of the opinion that if we cannot provide such training for our teachers in the immediate future, we might seriously consider the advisability of providing a special summer school course for a selected number of our teachers my way of experiment.

WELFARE

Recent reports from Saskatchewan indicate that of the 249 men sent to Kapuskasing for work at the Spruce Falls Paper and Paper Company, approximately 84 have either returned to Saskatchewan or are at this date on the way back to the province. It would appear that none of these 64 men worked for a full month and consequently were unable to pay for their transportation costs back to the reserves. The transportation costs of 80 were authorized by Mr. Christianson, who did not feel like accepting the responsibility for allowing 20 men to remain idle in the Kapuskasing district, in view of the severe climatic conditions prevailing at that time. The other 44 appealed to both Mr. Christianson and to this Branch for the funds necessary to pay their fares and to buy the provisions required to maintain them while en route. This request has been refused. I did not feel that we were under any obligation whatever to pay transportation costs for able-bodied Indians who refused to remain at work until the end of April. Had they remained on the job until April 30, the company was prepared to pay their return fares to Saskatchewan. I must say that despite the refusal of this group of men to continue at work and the refusal of others who may have left the job since our last report was received, the experiment on the whole has been worth while. Conditions in the Battleford Agency, the agency in which most of these men were recruited, were such that had they not been sent to Kapuskasing a great many of them would have been compelled to apply for relief rations. It is quite possible, also, that a number of them have really made good and will experience little difficulty in securing work in pulpwood operations next fall.

Indian Agent Simpson, in his report dated March 2, states:

"A number of Indians have been employed in hauling firewood to market for sale. Thirty-one are still employed in the pulpwood camps in Ontario, one having returned home as the result of illness. About 20 are at present..."
present employed in the and lumber camps adjacent to their reserves. The fur catch reported this month was only $300.00. On the whole, however, the Indians have enjoyed a much better standard of living so far this winter than they have up to this date in any of the preceding six winters that I have been here. There has been no appeals from them for assistance in the way of food and clothing. There has been less sickness during the winter months."

It is somewhat disturbing to receive reports from time to time of a certain amount of lawlessness on a number of our reserves. This condition has been created, no doubt, through lack of proper police supervision, particularly R. C. M. P. patrols. I have never been able to convince myself that the ordinary Indian constable is of much value on a reserve from the standpoint of proper law enforcement or in persuading the Indian parents to send their children regularly to school. The Principal of the Anglican School on the Blood Reserve, who visited this Branch about a year ago, was greatly agitated at the time about what he termed the lawlessness and insolence of the Blood Indians. A few days ago a somewhat similar complaint was received from the Principal in charge of the Anglican School on the Blackfoot Reserve. It is regrettable that these complaints are usually embodied in confidential letters or in confidential statements that cannot be quoted. Unless the men registering these complaints from time to time are prepared to courageously support them in court, if necessary, it will be somewhat difficult to correct the condition. I note that Indian Agent Goocherham, in his report dated March 5, 1942, states:

"A nasty undercurrent, which might appear to be subversive, has been noted among the Blackfeet. I really do not think they are disloyal; I think they are just spoiled; it is a case of too much money and little or no responsibility. Some policy must be devised to make these people more self-reliant. Possibly they are no worse than any other thousand people who had been given what they receive. It makes one wonder if the much vaunted scheme of living even the ample food, shelter and clothing would not be ruined. After all, civilization shows that people only survive when they have to struggle and fight for their existence. This brings up another point - Blackfoot Indians on active service apparently do not realize their responsibility and have by every means imaginable tried to get their discharge. In fact, they are even flouting the Military Authorities at this time by being A. W. O. L. from their unit. Surely these Indians must be made to understand that in such serious times they will not be allowed to get away with this sort of thing."

I have referred to the encouraging tendency on the part of younger Indians to join worthwhile organizations. It is encouraging, too, to be able to report that the older Indians, particularly the older women, are

continuing -
continuing to do good work in the Homemakers' Clubs. Indian Agent Booth, in his report dated March 8, states:

"The Homemakers' Clubs are doing very useful work and continue their meetings regularly. Some of the work is really good. I think that some of the Indian women have shown more pride in their homes since these clubs were inaugurated; bed sheets, pillow cases and quilts are now in evidence in many homes; curtains are appearing on the windows and the Indian women have been raising house plants successfully. Generally speaking, the homes have greatly improved.

The following visitors called at the office during the month:

Rev. J O. Plourde, O.M.I., Winnipeg, Manitoba;
Rev. George Dorsey, Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church, Toronto;
Captain Cummins, Manitoulin Island;
Mr. Askew, Valentine Black Co.;
Miss De Leporte, Department of Education, Toronto.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training."
Ottawa, May 1, 1942.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McGUIE:

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended April 30, 1942.

WELFARE:

A circular letter and garden chart was sent out to Inspectors and Indian Agents early in the month. The letter is designed to stimulate interest among Indians in the cultivation and care of subsistence gardens. A copy of this letter, sent to representatives of the Roman Catholic, Presbyterian and United Churches, has resulted in requests for additional copies of the chart. We have been assured by the churches that the missionaries working under their direction on Indian reserves will do everything possible to cooperate with us in the organization of garden projects and in the promotion of a worthwhile agricultural program this year.

An extensive gardening program will be undertaken on the Eskasoni Reserve, Nova Scotia, by Mr. Alex. Macdonald, who has been transferred from the Pocomaugh School to Eskasoni for this purpose. A somewhat similar program is already under way at Shubenacadie, under the nominal direction of the Reverend Father Wesley and under the supervision of the farming instructor in charge of the farm at the Shubenacadie Residential School. It will thus be seen that both these programs will be well under way prior to the appointment of an Indian agent and clerk at each reserve. This program in Nova Scotia, if climatic conditions are at all favourable, should result in substantial reductions in our relief costs throughout the winter months.

A number of encouraging reports on the Short Courses conducted under the direction of Mr. Elliott Moses recently reached the Department. Indian Agent J. T. Daley, in his report on the Walpole Island Agency, dated March 31, states:

"Possibly the most outstanding thing on the reserve this month was the Short Course held in the council hall. The men's study course was in charge of Elliott Moses and the women's and girls' classes under the supervision of Mrs. Donald and Miss Elsie Cameron. Personally, I do not believe that too much stress can be laid on these courses. It is my opinion that a great deal of encouragement and inspiration has been furnished Indian farmers on this reserve by these studies. Our Indians are certainly interested when they walk a distance of 4 miles in stormy weather to take part in the discussions.

Indian Agent Featherstone, Rama Agency, in his report dated April 2, states:

"During..."
During the week March 23-27 Mr. Moses, assisted by Miss Cameron and Mrs. Monture, conducted a Short Course on this reserve. This was the first time that a Short Course of this kind had been conducted at Rama. Twenty attended the women's classes and everyone was quite pleased with the results. Most of the Indian men being away working, their meetings were not so well attended but resulted, I hope, in some stimulation to the gardening efforts.

An interesting experiment in what one might term immediate post-school instruction has been undertaken on the Woodstock Reserve by Sister Emilia. In her quarterly report dated March 31, 1948, she states:

"I am pleased to report that these classes have been very successful, both boys and girls taking a keen interest in all their work. They have taken special pride in the domestic science kitchen, especially since we have the kitchen painted and repaired last spring. In the sewing class the girls have recently each completed a dress, apron and towel. They have also made curtains for the sewing room hall and function rooms. We hold cooking classes regularly once a week and the classes meet by those in attendance are often served with milk as refreshments. We have also helped a number of the married women to make quilts with odds and ends left over from different pieces of material. A number of nice quilts have already been made on the reserve by the women."

Indian Agent McPherson, in his report on the Clandeboye Agency, Manitoba, dated April 1, refers to the herd of goats at Berens River and the benefit of this herd to the members of the band. Mr. McPherson states:

"We have approximately 20 head of goats on the Berens River Reserve. These goats have all wintered well and have been of great benefit to the band. Some of the Indians on the Fort Alexander Reserve are also going in for raising goats and sheep. One family on this reserve have for a number of years spun their own wool and were able to supply themselves with socks, sweaters, etc., made from wool procured from their own sheep."

The first reference to an Indian potlatch that has been brought to my attention since I entered the Department has been sent forward by Indian Agent Todd, Kwakwaka'wakw Agency, B.C. The Agent, in his report for March, states:

"Most of the Indians of this agency have been profitably employed during the past month. Some have been engaged in clam digging while others have been working at various occupations such as logging and unskilled labour at the new Air Port now under construction at Fort Rupert.

Throughout the year practically all the Indians of this agency have been engaged in the fishing industry and I should like to report that 1941 was the best year financially, for the Indians since I have been agent. Some of them have used their surplus money in improving their homes, while others purchased boats and fishing gear."
regret very much to report, however, that with this surplus cash some of the Indians have returned to their old Indian custom, carrying it on to a greater extent than for many years past. It has been reported to me that some Indians were giving potlatches this winter and giving away large sums of money as well as goods. I have personally discussed this matter with some of the leaders and suggested to them that they should put their money into Victory Bonds and thus help the war effort and give up this custom. This practice seems to be so deeply rooted here that it comes first over everything."

A number of Indians on the Tyendinaga Reserve entered into contracts about a year ago for the production of vegetables for certain canning factories. It would appear that the contractual obligations entered into at that time have been carried out in a manner satisfactory to both parties. Indian Agent Moore, in his report dated April 1, states:

"A large number of contracts are being taken by reserve residents, to plant canning crops of peas, tomatoes and corn. There has been considerable competition among local canners in obtaining these contracts from Indians. A large quantity of literature has been secured by this office from the Ontario Forestry Branch and distributed among the Indians. It is our hope that this will encourage the people to acquire and plant young trees. A number of applications for trees have already gone forward."

TRAINING:

Mr. Doucet is at present engaged in the organization of vocational courses at residential schools in Saskatchewan. These courses are somewhat similar to the courses organized at the residential schools of Alberta about a year ago. In addition to the organization of these courses, Mr. Doucet has been asked to undertake an educational survey of a number of Indian reserves, with the object of determining whether or not Indian day schools or improved Indian day schools would, if established, supply the educational needs of these Indians. He will also, while in the West, visit one or two residential schools and one or two improved Indian day schools in North and South Dakota.

A report on the destruction of the classroom building at the File Hills Residential School reached us early in the month, and a second report from the Superintendent of Indian Agencies at Regina indicates that this building may have been deliberately destroyed by two or three Indian pupils. These pupils have already been arrested and will come up for trial in due course.

An interesting and encouraging report, dated April 8, has been received from Miss Bessie French, Principal of the Port Simpson (United Church) Indian Residential School. Miss French states:

"Your letter which arrived with the report form made me want to sit down and tell you all about us. I sometimes think that the only information the Department officials..."
officials ever get about Indian schools is a tale of discouragement, want and woe. I think, however, that there are bright spots in most of our Indian work. We certainly have our share of encouragement here.

With reference to organizations for ex-pupils, Port Simpson is organized to cover every age group within the church. With the exception of a young men's group, all are effective organizations. We have a group for all unmarried graduates of this school and older girls of the village of about their age and with similar interests. This same group forms my Sunday School class. We meet twice a month, once for study and worship and once for music and handicraft work. The members of the group seem to enjoy these gatherings and I believe they have an influence for good.

With reference to the girls who have graduated since 1939, 4 are nicely married. Three of these live on the Nass River at Kincolith. These girls always visit us here when they come to Port Simpson. I hear from them often and they seem to be a part of the church life on the reserve. One graduate sings in the choir and helps with Sunday School work.

The five unmarried girls are also doing very nicely. One works for the local doctor, one works here in our school laundry, one is employed at the cannery in Prince Rupert, and two are at home, living with their parents. All are clean, respectable looking girls. They attend church regularly and Sunday school, sing in the church choir, attend my midweek meetings and take an active part in all the activities of the village.

One very encouraging feature of our work is the spirit of the girls this year. I believe for the most part that they are here to learn and are trying hard. The parents and guardians have shown their appreciation by donations of fish to the school and have provided practically all their girls' clothing. This is a big help to us and good for them as well as the girls. I wish it were possible to tax each parent or guardian who has a child in this school, if only a little, to encourage a spirit of giving rather than getting."

Inspector W. MacMillan, in his report on the Chapleau (C. E.) Residential School, states:

"The work of this school is progressing very favourably under the direction of Canon Vale, the Principal. The two members of the staff are outstanding teachers. The results obtained by the pupils in the written tests compare favourably with the best results obtained recently in the public school tests of the Inspectorate. The boys and girls are neat and clean in appearance and seem to be well cared for. A fine spirit of cooperation is evident in each of the rooms. The work is well organized and discipline is excellent."

You will remember that Mr. D. S. Pitts, who had been for a number of years assistant principal at the

Mohawk-
Mohawk Institute, became principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey (Presbyterian) Residential School about a year ago. Mr. Pitts is a fully qualified teacher and is not a clergyman.

Inspector R. S. McBurney, in his report on this school, dated March 23, states:

"Mrs. Douglas (Second Class Permanent, Saskatchewan) is an experienced teacher and has been at this school for a number of years. Her results in writing and in "r" are remarkably good. The pupils are quite proficient in spelling and reading and have considerable information gleaned from social studies. They are quite good at memorizing. The classroom register is carefully kept. Grade 2 has school all day and the other grades have school half time and work half time. The Principal, Mr. D. S. Pitts, has the cooperation of his staff and has a school that is doing remarkably good work. It was to me an education and a real pleasure to visit this school."

The Inspector continues:

"Mr. Rusaw (Second Class, Ontario) is an excellent teacher and is doing exceptionally good work. He is an enthusiast in manual training and as a result the pupils of the school are making many interesting things. His basketry is good. I was quite interested in the rustic chairs and beds that he is having the pupils make. He is also an enthusiast in horticulture and throughout the building are several potted plants in bloom. The presentation of his lesson material is excellent. He is putting forth a great effort to have some individual response and is succeeding. The classroom is clean and bright."

The following visitors called at the office during the month:

Mr. J. S. Watt, Hudson's Bay Company, Rupert's House, Que.;
Mr. Justice Robson, Winnipeg, Man.;
Honourable W. R. Clubb, Winnipeg, Man.;
Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., Winnipeg, Man.;
Rt. Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I., Bishop of Gravelbourg, Sask.;
Rt. Rev. H. Belleau, O.M.I., Vicar Apostolic of James Bay;
Inspector of Agencies, C. P. Schmidt, Calgary, Alberta;
Mr. Askew, Valentine Black Co.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, June 1, 1942.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended May 31, 1942.

WELFARE:

It will be necessary to exercise considerable care when comparing relief and welfare expenditures for the present year with somewhat similar expenditures for the fiscal year 1941-42.

The cost of certain farming operations, the purchase of machinery, gasoline, etc., on a number of reserves, which were until about seven months ago paid from fund funds, are now paid from the regular welfare appropriation. The Medical Services have until now purchased the clothing necessary for inmates of hospitals and mental institutions. Dr. Moore has on more than one occasion discussed with me the advisability of having the cost of this clothing borne by the welfare rather than the medical division. He is of the opinion - and I am disposed to agree with him - that this is a legitimate charge on the welfare appropriation. The most serious encroachment on our welfare appropriation, however, will result from certain services, the cost of which has been until now charged to the cost of general administration. It would appear that farming instructors in the Prairie Provinces are used as teamsters by the agents to deliver supplies such as flour, bacon, lard, discarded military clothing, etc., to destitute Indians instead of such supplies from time to time. In view of the fact that the horses and wagons at agency headquarters have not been distributed to Indians, it will be necessary to hire teams when such teams are available to undertake this work. Just what the actual cost for the year will be is somewhat difficult to determine at this date. Vouchers that have already reached the Department would indicate, however, that the costs are likely to be substantial.

Indian Agent Waddy, in a letter dated May 5, 1942, states:

"Regarding your letter, 48-121, of May 2, last, asking for more details on voucher No. 18, for trucking supplies, this is as good a time as any to get this business explained, as you will have a lot more similar items and they have nothing whatever to do with the serious times we are experiencing. The fact is, we have taken teams away..."
from farming instructors and told them that the remaining team should be used for administration only. Therefore they cannot haul freight as they did in past years. No Indian on the destitute list is equipped to haul freight from the station, or he would not be on the list of mine, and no other Indian will haul government freight free. Your best system, in my judgment, is to make your purchases for delivery at the reserve. Most flour mills have trucks and would bid on these terms; then you would not see the freight bills and would not worry about them. Of course, the freight would be charged just the same but under cover. There will be more freight bills from time to time, in fact I have some here right now, but you may be assured I am keeping them down to the minimum."

In other words, it would appear that in the past farming instructors were not in reality farming instructors at all but teamsters and general labourers at agency headquarters, and that the task of delivering supplies from the point of delivery on the railway to agency headquarters and from agency headquarters to Indian homes on the reserve kept them fairly busy employed throughout the year; not only were they called upon to haul flour, bacon, etc., for destitute Indians, but they were called upon as well to haul and deliver wood and in many cases water. In my judgment it will be necessary, therefore, at the close of the present fiscal year, to carefully estimate the cost of such deliveries under the new policy and determine at that time whether or not it would be more profitable to maintain teams and engage labourers for this work.

The demand for Indian girls for domestic work in homes and at hospitals appears at the present time to exceed the demand. We have had requests this month from a large number of women in Ottawa who are anxious to secure Indian girls for domestic employment. We have also had urgent requests from the Ottawa General Hospital and the Tyndale Inn. We have succeeded at this date in securing employment for about eight girls. The reports on the work of these girls, so far, have been reasonably satisfactory.

Indian Agent Waite, in his report on the Portage la Prairie Agency, dated April 30, states:

"One thousand nine hundred and ninety-six pounds of alfalfa seed was sold to the A. E. McKenzie Company for seed and netted $436.26. This sum has been credited to the Lake Manitoba Farm Account. Messrs. Lang Brothers bought 600 sacks of potatoes from the Long Plain Home Farm at 55 cents a bag, netting $320.00. In addition to this, sufficient potatoes have been kept to furnish all the Indians of the Long Plain Reserve with first class seed."

Inspector Hamilton, in commenting upon this report, in a letter dated May 4, states:

"The sale of alfalfa seed, amounting to $436.26, is a real achievement and a line of farming very desirable at the present time. You will note also that..."
$320.00 was obtained for 600 sacks of potatoes. The price of $5.00 is low, but even at that the returns more than paid for the work, and our land is clean and in good shape as the result of the crop."

Miss A. Eaton appears to be doing exceptionally good work, not only at the North Peguis School, where her classroom work appears to be very satisfactory, but also on the reserve. A report for the period of January to Easter, sent forward by Inspector Hamilton, reads as follows:

"It is with great pleasure I begin this report, first noting what has been done in spinning; as in this craft real progress has been made. Three women have bought spinning wheels of their own, and two other women are getting them in the near future.

"Mrs. John Manningway, as well as getting her husband to buy her a wheel, has also got him to buy a sheep. They are exceedingly proud of these possessions, and I am very pleased as the getting of them was done entirely off their own bat. I hope they are fortunate in their venture as I am sure others will follow. Two of my families now have started in with sheep.

"The spinning wheel in school was put to good service being used practically every evening the last two weeks in January and the whole of February. Some women who cannot spin are beginning to do something about it themselves.

"All the school children this winter have had good warm stockings and mitts made from wool spun and knitted on the Reserve.

"In home economics I have kept in mind the matter of cooking for economy and nutrition, trying to wean them from the extensive use of the frying pan and to go in more for soups and stews.

"Gardening time is at hand and I have every hope that the women will rise to the occasion. They are becoming more conscious of the health value of vegetables, and I know many of them are intending to put in larger gardens.

"Mid-March we started a gardening project in school, putting in tomato seeds; our object being to get early plants and so try to get ripe tomatoes on the vines."

In his report for the month of April, Acting Indian Agent McMillan refers to the proposal to employ Japanese in the harvesting of sugar beets and the effect that this employment is likely to have on the Indian population. Mr. McMillan states:

"May I have the privilege of drawing to the attention of the Department the fact that I am going to
lose a considerable amount of outside work for my unemployed Indians, owing to the fact that an effort is being made by the Beet Growers' Association to place about 500 Japanese families now being moved into this district. This number of Japs will practically take over all the beet contracts. This has always been a place where the Indians have been able to make enough to purchase their winter clothing and also bring back money to the reserve in the Fall. I am bringing this point forward at the present time for the reason that if the work in the beet fields is lost I will have heavier destitute expenditures next winter."

TRAINING.

Reports reaching the Department indicate that an unusually large number of Indian day school teachers will resign from their positions at the end of the present academic year. It is altogether likely that we shall experience the utmost difficulty in securing the number of teachers necessary to conduct our schools during the academic year 1942-43. Representatives of the United Church, with whom we have discussed this matter, intimate that they, too, are experiencing difficulty in securing qualified teachers for the residential schools. They inform us, also, that it is almost impossible to secure domestic help and farm hands for these institutions.

Inspector Gordon Young, in his report on the Mount Elgin residential School, Muncie, Ontario, dated April 29 and 30, states:

"In previous reports the vocational work at this school has been mentioned. Only changes or variations from the regular routine will be enumerated in this report.

"The girls are doing considerable knitting, in addition to the regular work in sewing, cooking and household management.

"The dining room and kitchen have been brightened up with a new coat of paint. These rooms have a much more cheerful appearance now. The dormitories and sewing room are in good condition. Three new sewing machines have recently been added.

"Weaving has been discontinued for the duration of the war. This has led to the loss of one teacher.

"Since Mr. Johnson, the vocational instructor, left, Mr. Strapp, the Principal, has had to take the major portion of the shop and general hand work. Under his efficient leadership, the boys have overhauled all the farm machinery, constructed a cold storage bin, painted the dining room and kitchen and have made many repairs to the woodwork about the buildings. This work has given the..."
boys practical training in woodwork and in cement mixing.

Mr. Richardson - the farming instructor, and the boys look after the lawns, shrubs and flower beds.

In the matter of cultural training, considerable progress is made out of regular school hours by the organization of group games, under the leadership of different members of the staff. Instruction in music is under the direction of Miss Sibbald and Miss Morris and choir work is under the direction of Miss Smith.

This institution gives these young people a very desirable type of education. While economic pressure has led to a reduction of the staff, the remaining members have assumed the responsibility of carrying on and appear to be giving good service, even though they are carrying heavy loads.

Some of the suggestions respecting individual needs of pupils and provision for promotion and advancement have been adopted. It is not easy, however, to apply these suggestions in view of the large classes.

I have noticed in the Indian day schools on this reserve several new primary reading books, particularly the basic readers sold by J. J. Gage and Company. These are particularly good for children having difficulty in learning to read English. A supply of them would be valuable in your primary room at the residential school."

I might add that the Mount Elgin Institute is one of the oldest Indian residential schools and is operated by the United Church of Canada. It is the only residential school operated by the United Church in the province of Ontario. It is exceedingly difficult, in view of the age of the buildings, to keep it in a state of repair, but the present Principal, the Reverend O. B. Strang, who is himself a very skilled mechanic, has succeeded to an extent that is worthy of commendation.

The Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School, Lloydminster, Sask., has been for a number of years fortunate in having in charge of its classrooms two teachers both of whom were university graduates - Miss Helen V. Parsons, B.A., and Miss Margaret R. Armitage, B.A. The last report received from Inspector A. R. Brown, however, suggests that these teachers are no longer in charge. Instead, the teachers employed are Miss Eleanor P. Fiddler - no professional standing - and Miss Jessie R. Phoenix, who it would appear, had a first class Saskatchewan Interim, which has now lapsed. The report of the Inspector on the work of these two new teachers is interesting and significant. In his report on Miss Fiddler, the Inspector states:

An impossible situation is created by placing 45 Indian children in charge of an inexperienced, untrained teacher. Miss Fiddler does exceptionally well, considering her deficiencies and the enrolment. Grade I consists of a high percentage of pupils who do not understand English. Twenty
such pupils would be a maximum for a teacher skilled in teaching non-English pupils."

The Inspector adds:

"Miss Phoenix, while willing, is out of date in her methods. She follows rigid academic procedures. She has not developed a complete program as laid down in the Saskatchewan curriculum. I doubt whether she can make a successful adaptation to better methods and the requirements of Indian work."

The instruction given at Indian residential schools has never been, in the judgment of many, wholly satisfactory, and reports such as these are very disturbing. To place an untrained teacher in charge of a large group of Indian pupils, few of whom have even an elementary knowledge of the English language, is in my judgment a sheer waste of public funds. Just what can be done to remedy the condition, however, is a matter in respect to which I am not in a position at the moment to express an opinion. The acute shortage of teachers no existing; the over-crowding of classrooms and the work at our residential schools, generally, will be fully discussed with representatives of the Churches, immediately following the conference at the office of the Deputy Minister on June 3. It is just possible, also, that Mr. Doucet, immediately following his extensive visit to the schools in Saskatchewan, will bring back a number of helpful suggestions.

The following visitors called at the office during the month:

Rev. B. Reinville, O.M.I., Principal, Wabasca Residential School, Wabasca, Alberta;

Rev. J. P. Mulvihill, O.M.I., Principal, Christie Residential School, Kakawis, B.C.;

Right Rev. M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I., Bishop of Keewatin, The Pas, Manitoba;

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCILL:

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended June 30, 1942.

TRAINING

I have referred on more than one occasion to the interest taken in our Indian schools in the province of Alberta by the Provincial Department of Education and particularly by Dr. G. Fred McNally, the Deputy Minister. Dr. McNally has discussed with me during his periodical visits to Ottawa the work being done whereby in his judgment the courses of study at Indian day schools could be improved. He always aims at visiting two or three of our schools during the course of an academic year. It is interesting to note that he and G. H. Ross, Esq., Director of Health and Recreation of the province of Alberta, visited the schools in the Grouard area a few weeks ago. Dr. McNally, in his letter to Sister Jean, immediately following his visit to Grouard, states as follows:

"I should like you to know how much Mr. Ross and I appreciated the opportunity we had last week of seeing something of the work of the St. Bernard Mission. Not to make my letter too long, I shall confine my comments to two or three matters.

"First, we were greatly impressed with the neatness and home-likeness of the classrooms of the school. Indeed, I cannot remember when I have seen rooms so spick and span. Coupled with this was the evident happiness of the children. I had formed that opinion of the Mission children from reading the "Echoes" but was hardly prepared to find the feeling so general.

"Then we were so pleased with the Health and Recreation program. The degree of excellence reached by both girls and boys would have done credit to classes which had been in training much longer than those at the Mission. Nor must I forget the splendid baths. These, I am sure, account in large measure for the healthy, happy appearance of all the children. On our way home Mr. Ross commented more than once on the high standard of results which you have attained.

"And, lastly, I must mention again what I said when speaking to the children. The Mission provides a first-rate opportunity for an all-round education. In addition to the regular school subjects the girls get training in the domestic arts under conditions which..."
approach nearly to those to be found in the homes which we hope they are going to have. A similar training on the farm for the boys will make the opportunity complete. I can think of hundreds of boys and girls in Alberta for whom I could wish just such a well-balanced education.

"Our visit was all too short but left us with a definite desire to repeat it."

You may remember that Sisters were employed for the first time at the beginning of the present academic year at the Christian Island N. C. Indian Day School. Inspector J. M. Bennett, in his report on this school, dated May 6, 1942, states:

"Under the direction of Sister Black and taught by Sister Daley, work in economics has been well done. Samples of the work in sewing, knitting, stitching, etc., reflect interesting and valuable work. Aprons, mitts, scarfs, etc., have been made. Some instruction in cooking was also given to the older girls. This phase of school work is most valuable to these people. The pupils are also engaged in the remodelling of discarded military clothing.

"The children sing well, with admirable expression. They showed their capabilities on a range of pieces for me. Two of the older girls have been instructed in playing the piano.

"I heard all the pupils read; saw their workbooks and writing; gave some lessons in spelling and arithmetic; inspected their art work; and conversed with them to learn their ability in English, since they do not talk much English outside the school. They are progressing quite well in all these studies.

"Sister Black has given directions to adults in First Aid work. Social work for the sick is also being undertaken."

The following article, by Mildred Valley Thornton, appeared in the Vancouver Sun of June 2, 1942:

"Interesting news to art lovers in this province comes from the Royal Drawing Society in London, England, announcing the results of their war-time competition.

"In this competition, which is open to all parts of the Empire, no less than three awards went to children of the Inukseep Reserve in the Okanagan, which has often been in the public eye owing to the success of the Indian artist Sis-uh-lk and of the drama presentations of its children, some of which were broadcast last fall over CBR.

"In the drawing competition, Johnny Stalkia won a bronze star for 'The Animal Dance', painted on a..."
buckskin; Edith Kruger won a silver star for her illustration of a scene from the Indian Nativity play, and a bronze star also went to Bertha Baptiste, and sister of Sis-uh-lk, for her beadwork design of a deer and fawn.

Ten of the most interesting entries from the exhibition were taken to Buckingham Palace for the Queen to see and two of these were the work of Inkamcap children, Johnny Stalkin and Edith Kruger.

The success of Anthony Walsh, teacher of this reserve, in bringing to fruition the talent of these children, has been nothing less than phenomenal, proving beyond doubt that many of the Indian children have talent and inherent ability equivalent to that which brought fame to their forbears as one of the most original and artistic native races in the world.

"The inspired and sympathetic guidance of devoted teachers and opportunities equal to our own is all that is needed to give it expression."

In a circular letter dated May 18, 1937, residential school principals and Indian agents were asked to establish a "follow-up" system during the ensuing five year period and were supplied with printed forms for this purpose.

You will be interested to learn that the first of these returns have reached us from Indian Agent Daunt, New Westminster Agency, B. C. The returns give the history of seven pupils, four of whom attended the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, and three, the Conualeetza Residential School. The reports on the whole are somewhat encouraging. They cover the progress of the pupil year by year and give details of the work in which he is engaged. The following examples indicate to some extent the progress made by the pupils:

Adolph Felix, No. 382, was discharged at the age of 16 and left school with a good knowledge of gardening and manual training. The first three years he remained at home helping his parents at farming and wood-cutting. At the end of the fourth year he married a girl of the Pemberton Reserve. At the end of the fifth year he is described as a good husband and provider, living at Pemberton.

Evangeline Ambrose, No. 0429, was discharged at the age of 17, at which time her parents were both dead. This girl has been living for the last five years with her grandmother and has been successful in both gardening and housekeeping.

Josephine Williams, No. 0361, was discharged from school at the age of 17; left school with a good knowledge of domestic science, home nursing and handicrafts; and had completed Grade VII at Conualeetza. This girl married immediately following her departure from school and has since her marriage lived on the Scooahlie Reserve. She had a baby son at the end of the fourth year.
Edith Williams, No. 0409, was discharged from Coqualeetza at the age of 16. Her health is described as "not very good - had been given special treatment in school preventorium". This girl married Hugh Kelly two years after her discharge from school. During the third year she and her husband built a new home at Kilgard. A baby daughter was born in October, 1933.

Myrtle Kelly, No. 0506, was discharged from school at the age of 18. She took a special course in Home Economics. She had completed Grade XII, which is equivalent to first year university. This girl married Robert Sepass immediately following her discharge from school. A baby son was born in 1929. The fourth year she and her husband built a new home on the Skulkayn Reserve. The fifth year her husband was admitted to Coqualeetza Indian hospital with tuberculosis. The mother abandoned the home and returned to Sumas Reserve and is now living with her father and mother.

WELFARE

A statement of expenditures just received from the Treasury Office indicates that relief and welfare costs for the fiscal year 1941-42 amounted to $707,356.83, compared with an expenditure of $889,088.34 for the preceding year. This represents a net reduction of $175,731.51. In connection with these expenditures, it is necessary to point out, however, that $40,00 was spent from last year's appropriation for the purchase of Indian reserve lands at Tsaksoni and Shubenacadie. Welfare expenditures, therefore, for the last year, appear to have reached a figure as low as any figure reached at any time in recent years. It will thus be seen that while expenditures in Quebec remain high, the reduction has been quite substantial. For some reason that is difficult to explain in view of crop conditions, expenditures in
Manitoba remain higher than in either of the other Western Provinces - $83,250.19 compared with $83,118.48 last year, while expenditures in Alberta have come down from $65,545.75 last year to an expenditure of $56,481.18.

The Seventh Precipitation Report, published by the Searle Grain Company, Limited, shows that the total moisture condition for the three prairie provinces weighted and averaged for both stubble and summerfallow land on June 15th was 93% of normal, as compared with 87% at this time a year ago. On crops seeded on stubble land, which have reserves of moisture from last fall and this current season, the condition is now 100% of normal compared with 88% a year ago.

The total moisture condition in Alberta on June 15th was 91% of normal, as compared with 78% a year ago.

For Saskatchewan the total moisture condition is now 86% compared with 83% a year ago.

In Manitoba the total moisture condition is now 128% as compared with 126% a year ago.

It will thus be seen that crop conditions in the Prairie Provinces are on the whole more favourable than they have been at any time in recent years. Acting Indian Agent McMillan, in his report on the Blood Agency dated June 2, 1942, states:

"The prospects for this year are excellent; the wet weather has brought on the grass and it should be one of the best years for hay that we have had for 10 years. Growth has been prolific. A great effort will be made to have a large hay crop taken off and this should assist many Indians to get along during the winter months."

"Most of the Indians are on the land and not many have left for outside work. However, the Indians that are out working are making a very fair wage - averaging from $30 to $40 per month. I have just been advised that there is a request for 7,000 berry pickers in British Columbia, and I am writing the Mission City Board of Trade for further advice and information."

A few weeks ago our Inspectors and Indian Agents were asked to do everything possible to stimulate interest in the salvaging of rubber on their reserves, and the reports to date appear to be very gratifying. Indian Agent Gooderham, in his report for June, states:

"To date, more than six tons of rubber has been brought in and a great deal of this was tires. Here it comes from, we do not know, but it is here - which goes to show what is possible and what waste there is in this free and easy democratic way of living."

A striking illustration of what can be done by Indians to become increasingly self-supporting is supplied
by Indian Agent Gooderham in the same report. He states:

"It will be remembered that an attempt was made last fall to start a Calf Club on the reserve. However, only one girl faithfully fed and cared for her calf throughout the winter. This girl was Julia Three Suns, an ex-patient of the San. Julia's calf was permitted in the sale of calves from such clubs at Calgary on the 28th. It was not the best nor the worst calf at the sale, but it brought her a good solid price of 15¢ per pound—a gross price to her of $97.50. It is hoped that the publicity of this will stimulate interest among school children and that a larger club will be started this fall."

A number of agents appear to have made a sincere attempt to encourage the cultivation of subsistence gardens. Indian Agent Booth, in his report on the Ku'apelle Agency for June, states:

"There is more activity in Indian gardens this year. Farming instructors are paying more attention to this phase of their work. On the whole, I consider that we will have an increase of over 50% in acreage sown to gardens this season. There appears to be a steady demand for Indian girls for work in the country and I have found positions for six girls in the immediate vicinity."

Memorandum

DOCTOR MOLLIN:

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended July 31, 1942.

WELFARE:

The per capita figures by agencies show that the costs in King's County, Nova Scotia, amounting to $77.13 per capita, were the highest agency relief costs in the Dominion. Expenditures in Ontario, amounting to $2.98 per capita, were lower than corresponding costs in British Columbia. As a matter of fact, expenditures in Ontario, with the exception of the Chapleau, Golden Lake, James Bay, Sioux Lookout and Sault Ste. Marie Agencies, are almost negligible.

Encouraging reports have reached the Division during the month in respect to the attempts made at a number of agencies to organize worthwhile gardening projects. Mr. J. A. Finlay, United Church Missionary at Hartley Bay, Keena Agency, B.C., in a letter dated July 24, states:

"A copy of your circular letter of April 7th., 1942, was forwarded to me, and, following your suggestion in it, concerning a report on gardens, I am pleased to furnish information on the subject as it affects this reserve.

"The people here, numbering approximately 140, have on the whole made use of as much ground as is suitable for the growing of vegetables. With two exceptions, every house in the village has..."
its garden, in which potatoes, carrots, turnips, beets, and green
produce such as lettuce and cabbage are grown. In addition, several
large potato patches have been planted. Raspberries and small fruits
such as raspberries, red and black currants and gooseberries are
also being cultivated. The owners of these intend to can them, while
nearly all the families pick and can huckleberries. Despite the
unsuitability of the soil, due to extreme sourness, exceptional
results have been obtained.

Dr. T. J. Oxford, James Bay Agency, who has been
particularly successful in his attempts to encourage Indians to
cultivate vegetable gardens and construct root-houses, in a letter
dated July 3, states:

"With last year's success behind us, we hope to do
even better this season in the production of vegetables and, as you
know, we have branched out into garden crops other than potatoes.
An encouraging note in this respect is the request of the Albany
Indians for more tools to prepare gardens. These have been supplied.
They also request a chance to grow such vegetables as carrots, turnips,
parsnips and green vegetables such as lettuce, onions and radishes.
The Ogoki Indians have also asked for larger supplies of these variet-
ies of vegetables.

"Our storage problem is taken care of mainly by community
root-houses. At Ogoki this is a simple matter of digging into a clay-
loam high bank. There is a 10 foot long entrance to the root-house
with an outer and inner heavy insulated door. These doors are
insulated with dry moss. The walls and roof of the entrance are three
feet below the surface. The roof is solid soil upon which is packed
the earth removed from the root-house, mixed with moss, making a
covering of about 7 feet in depth.

"At Moose Factory our present root-house, with a
capacity of approximately 300 bushels, is constructed somewhat
differently. We require a new and much larger one which will be built
this summer on the same principle."

You may remember that Inspector Hamilton was authorized
early in May to employ Miss M. E. Buckley, who has been engaged for
a number of years as Missionary on the Red River Reserve, to
organize the women on a number of reserves in Manitoba with the object
of having these Indian women organize garden projects and undertake
the repair and remodelling of discarded military clothing. Miss
Buckley spent one week on each of the following reserves: Fairford,
Little Saskatchewan, Lake St. Martin and Long Plains. It is her
intention also, later in the year, to organize the women on the
Birdtail Reserve, in the Little Agency. Miss Buckley's report on her
visit to the Lake St. Martin Reserve is typical of her reports in
general and reads as follows:

"On my arrival here I visited several of the homes with
the nurses and arranged to hold a meeting in the schoolroom the next
day, which was well attended by the women, and an I.W.W.S. Club was
organized, with Mrs. Beechell (the teacher) as President and Mrs.
Geo. Boardy as secretary. Garden seeds were given out and also any clothing to be made over into garments for the women and children.

"The aims of the club were explained and the need for better gardens than ever was emphasized, and the women were shown how to utilize the army clothing to the best advantage.

"Another meeting was held a few days later when the women brought back the garments they had made. The results were very satisfactory and more sewing was given out to them.

"During my stay here I was able to assist the women a little in their gardens and also to visit them in their homes, which were clean and tidy, but I was shocked to find so many (even children) with T.B., and at our meetings in speaking of the better care of children I explained to the ladies that they were responsible for the health of their families and that it was their duty to do all they could to stamp out this terrible sickness that is so prevalent in their midst.

"Mrs. Bechell, the teacher, entered whole-heartedly into the work of helping me organize the club, and I hope she will resume her duties in the fall to carry on the good work she is doing, not only among the school children but with the young people of the reserve."

Indian Agent Davis, in a report on the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School and the reserves in the Lac La Ronge district, states:

"The Indians have advanced greatly in the cultivation of gardens. Most families have sufficient vegetables for their own use and in a number of cases still have sufficient potatoes to carry them over until the new crops have been harvested. Some of the finest gardens I have seen anywhere were seen at Sucker River and Stanley."

The doctors responsible for the nutritional survey in northern Manitoba a few months ago are definitely of the opinion that it is exceedingly difficult to provide Indians with a well balanced diet unless we can secure for them an adequate supply of milk. Dr. Evans informed Dr. Corrigan at the time Dr. Corrigan visited New York that we should do everything possible to encourage Indians, particularly bands in the northern sections of the Dominion, to keep goats. In this connection it is interesting to note that a good start has been made in the establishment of goat herds on a number of reserves. Indian Agent Davis, in his report already referred to, states:

"The Indians at Sucker River were supplied with goats a couple of years ago by the Department. These goats have increased until there are now 19 in the herd. A number of these goats are milking. I feel assured that this venture has been a decided success."

Goat herds have now been established at Spanish, Golden Lake, Beaver River, Island Lake, Norway House and Sucker Creek.
TRAINING.

There is little to report on the activities of the Training Division for the month. I have already intimated in one or two of my recent reports that difficulty will be experienced in securing the number of teachers necessary for the operation of our Indian day schools during the ensuing academic year. At this date there are 40 schools for which teachers have not yet been secured, and it is altogether likely that we shall receive a number of additional resignations during the weeks immediately ahead of us.

A number of teachers visited the Department during the month. It is gratifying to be able to report that a number of our teachers are sufficiently interested in their work and in ways and means whereby our courses of study can be improved to visit the Department from time to time at their own expense. I was very favourably impressed by the Reverend A. C. Huston, Principal of the Round Lake Residential School, and the Reverend A. B. Chalco, Principal of the Sioux Lookout Residential School, both of whom visited the Bureau last week. For 8 years prior to his appointment to the principalship of the Round Lake School about 16 months ago, Mr. Huston was missionary in charge of the reserve at Norway House, northern Manitoba. He had heard of the nutritional work that had been undertaken by the Norway House Agency and was deeply interested in the attention we are making to provide the Indians with a well balanced diet. In discussing diet and nutritional problems with Dr. Moore, he intimated that while in northern Manitoba he had on more than one occasion declared that if he and the Indians exchanged "grub boxes" he would likely be sent to the hospital in the course of a few weeks and that the Indians would likely become a supermen, physically and mentally. Mr. Huston is a young man, a graduate in Arts of Toronto University, and a man who has devoted the whole of his life to missionary work on Indian reserves. He is likely to make a worthwhile contribution to Indian educational effort in the future. He is greatly handicapped at Round Lake owing to the insanitary and dilapidated condition of the buildings. He has in mind for the future a new building with classrooms for day pupils and a limited amount of accommodation for pupils unable, owing to the location of their homes, to attend as day school pupils.

Mr. Chalco, the Principal of the Sioux Lookout School, is also a university graduate in Arts and Theology. This man was missionary in charge of the Moose Lake Indian reserve in the Fox Agency. He recently married a girl who has been in charge of our Pine Falls Indian Hospital for a couple of years. Mrs. Chalco, she accompanied her husband when he visited the Department, is deeply interested in Indian welfare work and is particularly anxious at the moment to organize worthwhile handicraft projects at the school. She is interested also in the establishment of a goat herd at the institution. I have asked Dr. Moore, at the time of his visit to Winnipeg, to discuss with Mr. Hamilton the desirability of securing 6 or 7 goats for this school. Mrs. Chalco is of the opinion that cows supplied to Indian families soon become infected with tuberculosis and prove a menace to the Indian community in the spread of this disease. You will be interested to learn that we offered Mr. Chalco the principalship of the Indian residential school at Lytton. The position, however, did not appeal to him. He is primarily interested in pioneer work and is particularly interested in the betterment of conditions amongst backward bands of Indians.
Mr. Doucet returned from his western trip 2 weeks ago and will leave early in August for Nova Scotia. Mr. Doucet, who met Mr. Doucet at the St. Albert Residential School, was particularly pleased with the course of study outlined by Mr. Doucet and his suggestions to the teachers. Mr. Doucet has visited only two or three of our residential schools in the province of Manitoba. It is interesting to note, however, that his visits stimulated a great deal of interest in vocational instruction. Father Picardo has informed me that the principals and teachers of the residential schools in Manitoba are meeting at St. Boniface on August 18, 19 and 20, to discuss the re-organization of their courses of study in conformity with the outlines sent forward to them by Mr. Doucet. I have suggested to Father Picardo that he should ask Mr. John, Director of Vocational Instruction of the Provincial Department of Education, to address the convention. I have suggested, also, that it might be well to have Inspector Hamilton take part in the discussions.

The following excerpt has been taken from a letter received by the Principal of the Wabasso R.C. Indian Residential School from an ex-pupil:

"It is a great pleasure for me to send you my best greetings and appreciation for my education at Wabasso. I see now that what I have been taught is coming in handy. I only wish I had more education. My commanding Officer is very well pleased with my good behavior, and I am doing my best to show him how fast I can learn. I have not been in the Army very long but I am making progress day by day."

This Indian boy enlisted about a year ago and is now stationed at Winnipeg.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended August 31, 1942.

WELFARE:

The first statement of relief costs for the present fiscal year was received from the Treasury early in the month. This statement covers expenditures for the period April - July, inclusive.

In view of existing conditions and the opportunities existing throughout the country for gainful employment, it was my hope that our welfare costs would show a substantial decrease. I was somewhat surprised, therefore, to note that the statement indicates a net increase of $4,038.42. The greatest increase - $6,785.13 - appears to have taken place in the province of Manitoba and the greatest decrease - $2,353.24, in Ontario.

I have, as you know, communicated on more than one occasion with Inspector Hamilton during the last fiscal year in respect to his relief costs. His explanations, while plausible, have never appeared to me to be wholly satisfactory. I still find it difficult to understand why relief costs for the period now under review - April to July, inclusive - should amount in Manitoba to $49,874.20 while relief costs in Saskatchewan for the same period amount to $34,484.59 and in Alberta, $2,456.56. It should be added, also, that the amount of farm machinery purchased this year in Saskatchewan far exceeds the amount purchased in Manitoba.

Reports to hand indicate that crop conditions in Ontario and in the Prairie Provinces are more favourable at this time than they have been at any time in recent years. Weed infestation, however, appears to be very much in evidence on a number of our reserves, particularly in Saskatchewan. A teacher from that province, who visited the Department a few weeks ago, expressed the opinion that weed infestation had become so bad on a number of reserves in Saskatchewan that it would cost more than the land is actually worth to eradicate the weeds and bring the land under a proper state of cultivation. In this connection I am disposed to think that our community farms with tractor power have been to some extent remedying this condition in recent years.

It is encouraging to report that, in Alberta at least, our live stock population appears to be increasing somewhat steadily. Indian Agent Iredale, of the Stony Agency, in his report for July, states:

"We will be selling the 2 year old steers and some fat cows about the first week in October. We should have..."
have about 125 two-year old steers to sell and perhaps 60 or 70 old cows. We are carrying about 1150 head of cattle over from last winter, and with the natural increase of about 350 to 400 calves, we should sell more cattle this year in order to keep the number down to 1150 or 1200 at the most. "We are now at the peak as regards the number we can with safety take care of. If we come up against a dry or below normal year we might experience difficulty in providing feed. As pointed out by me several times, if the Department would provide more agricultural lands we could go on increasing cattle herds, but, as things are now, we have reached the limit in the number we can feed, both in regard to pasture and winter feed."

The Indian Agent adds:

"With regard to the surplus horses on this reserve, I would like to reduce the number of horses, but the situation is not by any means alarming. I have been continually stressing the importance of getting rid of a number of small ponies, and gradually this is being done. About 150 have been disposed of during the last 12 months."

Inspector Schmidt, at the time of his visit to Ottawa, discussed with us ways and means whereby the Indians might be encouraged to dispose of their surplus horses. He promised at that time that he would undertake a thorough investigation and send forward a report in due course. This report has not reached the Department, but I note in agents' reports from time to time references to the problem created on the reserves by these surplus horses. The Indian Agent for the Peigan Agency, in his last report, states:

"The horse situation on this reserve is quite a problem. Some of the older Indians seem to place the same value on horses as they did 30 and 40 years ago. I have talked with one or two of the owners of some of the large bunches running on the north side of the river and then got all the Indians together for a fireside chat. The result is that they have asked me to get some buyers. It would appear that they are prepared to sell off the greater portion of these animals for what they can get for them. I think if I can get a few sales made and have the money on hand others will fall into line."

Dr. Moore informed me a few weeks ago that the Quaker Oats Company were anxious to secure horses for horse meat for the preparation of a dog biscuit manufactured by them. Dr. Moore has communicated with this company in an attempt to discover if they would be interested in the surplus horses available on a number of our western reserves.

TRAINING:

In my report of last month I referred to the difficulty we were likely to experience in securing the teachers necessary to operate our Indian day schools. Since that report was written we have engaged about a dozen teachers but we have also received three or four resignations. It would appear at this date impossible to secure our full quota of teachers for the re-opening of our schools.
on October 1. It is rather remarkable that we have succeeded in securing the majority of the teachers necessary for schools in the outlying districts while at the same time failing to obtain teachers in the older sections of the Dominion such as the Rama school in the Rama agency and the St. Clair school in the Sarnia agency.

Major Randle, in a letter dated August 17, reminds us that Miss Sylvia Jamieson won first and third prizes in the competition organized and promoted from year to year by the County and Provincial Rural School Improvement Association. Major Randle states:

"Four other of our schools entered the contest and although they did not win a prize it was understood from the Judges that the markings were very close and that all our Indian schools were highly rated."

I regret to report that the piggery at the St. George's Residential School, Lytton, B.C., was with 22 pigs totally destroyed by fire on August 24. Mr. Hives, the Principal, estimates that a new building will cost approximately $1,000. The destruction of schools and school buildings by fire is one of the most discouraging features of the work of the Training Division. Despite the fact that circulars are constantly going out assuring our Indian agents and school principals to take all the precautions necessary to prevent fires, fires continue to occur with unerring regularity. The explanation in this case was that the fire was caused by a spark from the feed cooker located inside the building. The Principal states: "This source of fire hazard should never have existed, but, like a lot of other foolish ideas that have been allowed to exist here, it was not adjusted in time."

A particularly encouraging letter, dated August 4, 1945, has been received from the Principal of the Ermineskin (R.C.) Residential School. In this letter the Reverend Father Rheaume states:

"Last April the Department made a special appeal to encourage Indians to cultivate subsistence gardens. With this appeal in view and realizing that gardening is an important item in our training program, we have done our utmost to make our pupils realize the importance that should be attached to gardens, especially in these difficult times.

"The boys of Grades 3, 4, 5 and 6, following our advice, went so far as to ask their parents to start gardens at their respective homes, promising to take care of them during the summer holidays. We are sending you forward herewith a survey just completed of the gardens of most of the 34 pupils of this school. We wish to emphasize "Most" as some of the parents are still too nomadic to able to give their children an opportunity of cultivating a garden. In general, however, we feel proud of the work that has been done. We feel sure that if a trophy of some kind was awarded every year for the best garden on the reserve this would help..."
enormously to encourage the Indians to take care of their gardens. Quite a number of Indians have lost much of their produce because they have waited too long before commencing the seeding of their gardens. We are led to believe that stampedes and fairs held here and in neighboring towns are disastrous in that they keep the Indians away from their farms for days, sometimes weeks at a time."

I might add that it is our intention, in response to the Principal's request, to provide small prizes to encourage the cultivation of gardens on our reserves in the future.
