Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended September 30, 1942.

TRAINING:

It is gratifying to report that we secured during the month a number of teachers for the vacant positions at Indian day schools. It would appear that of the 280 day schools usually in operation all but 30 will open on October 1. This does not mean that we have succeeded in securing experienced and fully qualified teachers for these schools. A large number of male teachers have enlisted and their places in many instances have been taken by married women, many of whom have not taught for 10, 15 or 20 years. Just how successful these women will be in adapting themselves to the new teaching methods and the courses of study now in force, I am not of course in a position to state. The 9 month rather than the 10 month teaching period has made it exceedingly difficult for us to secure teachers this year. A number of teachers, who have discussed this matter with us personally, have stated frankly that they are not prepared, in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves, to remain idle for three months during the summer season. Many of these teachers are actuated by the highest motives and one can readily understand their feelings.

The large chimney on the recently constructed section of the Sandy Bay Residential School was struck by lightning early in the month and totally destroyed. The destruction of the chimney also resulted in serious impairment to the roof of the school. Steps have already been taken to have this chimney rebuilt at the earliest possible date.

It is encouraging to learn that Mr. A. E. Caldwell, Principal of the United Church Residential School at Norway House, Manitoba, has entered into a written agreement with the Hudson's Bay Company whereby a number of the male graduates of the school will be taken into the service of the company from year to year. The following letter, received by Mr. Caldwell from Mr. J. W. Henley, the officer in charge of personnel of the Hudson's Bay Company, gives a brief summary of this agreement:

"I was glad to hear from Mr. Bonnycastle on his return from a recent trip to Norway House that he had had an opportunity of discussing with you the employment of young Indian lads at our trading posts.

You may -
"You may recall your discussion with the writer here last summer, when I outlined briefly the type of employee we want to get and what we are prepared to offer them.

"I understand from Mr. Bonnycastle that you would like some assurance from us that we can take a certain number of lads each year from your school. I suggest, therefore, for the present, that you count on us taking four each year under the following arrangements:

1. The boys trained by you we would be prepared to take on at not less than 16 years of age and preferably 17 or 18 if you are able to keep them in school this long. I think your suggestion of selecting the likely recruits at 12 to 14 years of age - well in advance of the time they would be employed - is a good one since in this way you may be able to earmark them for special instruction. I believe Mr. Bonnycastle also discussed with you the advisability of giving employment during school holidays to these boys, but that you agreed it would be preferable they return to their families each summer until taken on permanently by the Company.

2. With regard to the type of training these boys should receive while under your supervision:

(a) We should be glad if you could stress particularly good grounding in writing and arithmetic, as, in this way, they will be of greater use at a post, and be able to undertake more responsibility than simply doing chores and odd jobs around the store.

(b) It is also our intention to employ these lads at points which, because of their location or the size of the business, do not warrant the employment of white assistants. In these cases they must live in the same dwelling as the white manager, therefore, I think you should stress the importance of clean personal habits.

(c) Practical instruction in carpentry and mechanics is also valuable, if available in your curriculum.

The above remarks are intended to serve as an outline of the programme for the next twelve months when I consider the arrangements should be reviewed with yourself, Mr. Learmonth and the Saskatchewan District Manager, R. A. Talbot.

"Meanwhile, we are asking Mr. Learmonth to consult with you in the selection of two more boys to commence employment at Norway House and Rossville not later than 15th June. About freeze-up we should be ready to take on another two.

"I am very hopeful that this plan will work to our mutual advantage and that we may continue to take a few boys each year. Any criticisms or suggestions from you on the arrangements outlined here will be most welcome."

Reports reaching the Department from time to time would lead one to believe that our residential schools -
schools are not particularly popular with the Indian population. I was myself greatly impressed by the criticism of these schools which I encountered, in my conversations with Indians, at the time of my visit to the Peffley and Pugh offices. However, a recent report from Indian Agent Pugh, Saddle Lake Agency, should tend to convince one that any attempt on the part of the Department to abandon these schools would meet with a great deal of opposition from the Indian population. Mr. Pugh's report, which is dated July 16, 1942, reads:

"Cuestioned at the council meeting about the schools being taken over by the Government for the use of Japanese, I stated that I had no definite information about the Edmonton school, that in any case education would be provided for the Protestant children, and there was a definite understanding that the Blue Quills R. C. School would not be taken over. Chief Moses stated that he would sooner see the boarding schools retained, in preference to the day schools. Jonas Cardinal stated that he had been to the Blue Quills School, to see if they were closing down, and he had been informed that they were not. He asked that the Indians themselves have a voice in this matter. He wanted the boarding school retained. Councillor Ralph Steinbauer stated that he could scarcely believe his ears. He remembered being at a league of the Cross meeting some three or four years ago and at that meeting the Indians had passed a resolution asking for day schools, and yet today some are hesitating about these day schools. Councillor Jimmy Cardinal stated that a large day school had failed at Cold Lake through lack of attendance. Councillor Jonas Cardinal stated that the children should be able to come home from the boarding schools and help their parents and that it was of great benefit to the parents not to have to feed and clothe their children when attending boarding schools. He doubted very much the ability of the average Indian to feed and clothe his children as well as they were fed and clothed at boarding schools."

I have referred on more than one occasion to the course in physical culture and in gymnastics organized at the Grouard Residential School by Father Forcade. It would appear that this young priest has now made a start on the organization of worthwhile handicraft projects at this school. In a letter dated September 25, he states:

"The more I study these people, the more I see the necessity for us to teach them how to earn their living. To make them feel this, we must create some ambition in them. I am directing my activities towards industries among them. We have begun this in class. One of our activities is leather work and bead work. We show them how to make use of their skill and the value of it in leathercrafts. We are more or less boycotted through lack of material and especially beads. Do you know of some channels through which we could get them? You will hear more about this through our "Echoes".

"We have purchased and are now operating here the Gestetener printing machine for which you have given us an allowance of $50. The Company is forwarding you the invoice."
REPORTS NOW ON FILE ARE SUFFICIENT TO CONVINCE US THAT THE RESPONSE TO OUR APPEAL FOR THE CULTIVATION OF INDIAN GARDENS HAS BEEN MORE ENCOURAGING AND MORE WORTHWHILE THAN ANY APPEAL SENT OUT FROM THE DEPARTMENT AT ANY TIME IN RECENT YEARS. THIS APPEAL, WHICH IS DATED APRIL 7, 1943, WAS SENT OUT TO OUR INDIAN INSPECTORS AND AGENTS, TO THE PRINCIPALS OF RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS AND TO THE REPRESENTATIVES OF ALL THE CHURCHES. NOT ONLY HAS THIS APPEAL RESULTED IN THE CULTIVATION OF VEGETABLE GARDENS, BUT IT APPEARS TO HAVE RESULTED AS WELL IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF A GREAT MANY COMMUNITY ROOT-HOUSES. IT IS DIFFICULT, IF NOT IMPOSSIBLE, TO OVERESTIMATE THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THESE GARDENS, JUDGED FROM THE STANDPOINT OF THE HEALTH AND PHYSICAL WELLBEING OF THE INDIAN POPULATION, PARTICULARLY INDIAN YOUTH.

MR. CHRISTIANSON, IN HIS REPORT ON AN INSPECTION OF THE QU'APPHELLE AGENCY, DATED SEPTEMBER 25, STATES:

"I WAS PLEASED TO NOTE THAT THE INDIANS HAVE MADE A REAL SHOWING WITH GARDENS AND PRACTICALLY EVERY INDIAN IN THE AGENCY HAS A GARDEN. ON THE SIOUX RESERVE I THINK I SAW THE BEST GARDEN I HAVE EVER SEEN IN MY LIFE. THIS BELONGS TO THE MOSES GOODWILL FAMILY AND THERE ARE PROBABLY ENOUGH POTATOES AND OTHER GARDEN TRUCK TO FEED HALF THE RESERVE FROM THIS GARDEN. IT WAS SHIELDED WITH SUNFLOWERS, WHICH MAKE A WONDERFUL PROTECTION, AND THEY REALLY HAD EVERYTHING YOU COULD NAME IN THE WAY OF CORN AND OTHER VEGETABLES. THESE PEOPLE, AT LEAST, WILL HAVE SUFFICIENT TO LAST THEM FOR THE WHOLE SEASON. HOWEVER, THIS WASN'T THE ONLY GOOD GARDEN I SAW. THE FARMING INSTRUCTOR ON THE MUSCOWETUNG RESERVE HAD 26 ROWS OF POTATOES AND THE ROWS WERE PROBABLY ONE HALF MILE LONG. HE HAD THE NAME OF EACH INDIAN WHO IS ON THE RATION LIST AT THE END OF THE ROW AND THE INDIAN CONCERNED HAD TO LOOK AFTER HIS OWN ROW. THREE OR FOUR OF THE ROWS HAD ALREADY BEEN TAKEN UP AND MR. FOX INFORMED ME THAT HE FIGURED THERE WERE ABOUT 40 BUSHELS OF POTATOES TO EACH ROW. THEREFORE 26 ROWS WOULD YIELD OVER 1000 BUSHELS. I ALSO SAW SOME VERY FINE GARDENS ON THE PIAPOT RESERVE, THE BEST, I PRESUME, THEY HAVE EVER HAD THERE, AND I WAS VERY GLAD TO FIND OUT THAT THE CHIEF OF THE BAND HAD WORKED VERY HARD AMONGST HIS INDIANS TO GET THEM TO CULTIVATE GARDENS THIS SUMMER WITH VERY FINE RESULTS."

WHILE THE REPORTS ON GARDENING OPERATIONS ARE ABOUT ALL ONE MIGHT DESIRE, THE REPORTS ON CROP CONDITIONS GENERALLY, PARTICULARLY CROP CONDITIONS IN THE WEST, ARE BY NO MEANS UP TO EXPECTATIONS. IT WOULD APPEAR THAT WEED INFESTATION, COUPLED WITH EXCESSIVE RAINS, HAS TURNED MANY OF THE AREAS INTO LIABILITIES RATHER THAN ASSETS. IN THE QU'APPHELLE AGENCY, CROP FAILURES OR PARTIAL CROP FAILURES HAVE BEEN EXPERIENCED NOW FOR A PERIOD OF 12 YEARS. THIS YEAR'S CROP FOR A TIME LOOKED PROMISING, BUT MR. CHRISTIANSON, IN THE REPORT ALREADY REFERRED TO, STATES:

"The crops in this agency were wonderful, the best I have ever seen there, but what the results will be is more than I know. Last Monday they were practically through cutting the wheat but they still had oats to cut."
With the rain, etc., people are becoming very much discouraged because the stocks are damp, the ground is wet, and the binders are breaking; in fact it seems almost impossible to get the cutting done. Here and there you find the odd field on the outside that has been threshed and it is now apparent that rust has greatly cut down the yield in spite of the fact we have nothing but Thatcher wheat. Even with that it has rusted badly enough to have the number of bushels per acre greatly reduced. I would like those of you who read this letter to just imagine cutting grain that has been floured to the ground. We can do something with it by cutting it one way but twisted grain is a problem that is pretty hard to get over. Therefore our high anticipations of being able to pay a substantial amount of our indebtedness have gone. What the grain will finally yield if we ever get it threshed is impossible for me to say. So far it has rained every day this week and the ground has been frozen quite hard the last two nights.

This report and this year's results - again I am speaking particularly of the west - tend to emphasize more and more the desirability of encouraging subsistence rather than large-scale farming on Indian reserves. I mean by subsistence farming the cultivation of vegetable gardens, hog and cattle raising and the establishment of goat herds - in other words, production for home consumption rather than for sale or for export.

A report from Inspector Schmidt on the Blood agency suggests that weed infestation, even on summer-fallow areas in that agency, has become so acute that the seeding down of large areas of land for pasture purposes and grazing is absolutely imperative. In this connection it is interesting to note that the seriousness of noxious seed infestation on Indian reserves in the Prairie Provinces was brought to the attention of the Minister 10 years ago by Dr. Tory, who was at that time chairman of the National Research Council. Dr. Tory was of the opinion at that time that noxious weeds were not only a menace on Indian reserve lands but a menace to the adjoining lands cultivated by white farmers. I am disposed to think that the menace is immeasurably more acute at this time than it was 10 years ago. The excessive rains of this year have, of course, brought the matter more prominently to our attention. In addition to this, large groups of Indians have abandoned their farming operations to work outside the reserves. Indian Agent Young, Griswold Agency, in his report for September, states:

"The majority of the Indians of this reserve are out harvesting. The wages asked by them for this work is from $5.00 per day up. Even women are scarce on the reserve as they have been out stocking by the acre. The attitude of the Indian seems to be to make all the profit he can out of the apparent shortage of labour which is caused by war conditions."

Indian Agent Simpson, in his report on the Duck Lake Agency for August, states:

"On most of the reserves every able-bodied Indian is being employed by outsiders. The Indians have responded
very well to the request to give all available help assisting in the harvest field. Their wives and older children are also assisting.

Indian Agent Ostrander, Battleford Agency, refers also to the tendency on the part of Indians to abandon their work on the reserves in favour of outside employment. He states:

"The demand for the Indians to go out of the reserves to work in the harvest fields has become so great that we will have trouble getting our crops harvested. Harvest labour means immediate returns in money while, if they stay on their farms for their own harvest, they know that their first sales of grain will not be sufficient to pay the immediate cost of harvest operations, threshing, twine, etc. This makes the offers of work outside the reserves particularly attractive. The Indians are going out - men, women and children. Wages very from $3.00 to $6.00 a day. I estimate that over 200 men and women of this agency are now employed at outside harvest work."

It is pleasing to note that where we have an Indian agent interested in the organization and promotion of worthwhile handicraft projects the Indians of his agency, particularly the older Indians, are still able to secure a certain amount of revenue from this source. Indian Agent Burk, in his last report on the Port Arthur Agency, states:

"The annual Lakehead Exhibition was held from August 8 to 15. This year a typical Indian village was erected in the fair grounds, consisting of 10 birch bark wigwams. At each wigwam Indians were engaged in the construction of various Indian handicraft projects, making birch bark canoes, beadwork, snow shoes, moccasins, quilt work, rabbit skin blankets, etc. One Indian secured an order for 25 birch bark canoes. Large orders were taken for Indian handicraft for delivery about December 15th of this year. Orders were taken also for 36 rabbit skin blankets."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McGUIII

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended October 31, 1942.

TRAINING:

In my report of last month I intimated that we were experiencing difficulty in securing the teachers necessary to operate our Indian day schools. However, it is gratifying to report that during the month we succeeded in securing 18 additional teachers, with the result that all our schools with the exception of 12 are open and in operation at this date.

I have referred in one or two of my recent reports to the improvement and beautification of certain school grounds, particularly on the Six Nations Reserve. I had an opportunity last week of visiting these schools and I feel that I cannot speak too highly of the work accomplished by the teachers, under the direction of Major Hanle. The No. II School on the Six Nations Reserve won third prize in the provincial competition. Another school on this reserve was visited by a school visitant, an Indian in the province of Ontario to cultivate a forestry plot during the last year. When I visited the Extension Branch of the Provincial Department of Agriculture, I was interested to learn from the officials there that they had taken photos of our schools on the Six Nations Reserve and that it was their intention to use these in lantern lectures, with the object of stimulating interest in the improvement of school grounds throughout the province. One official told me that a number of these lectures had already been delivered and that the audiences were amazed at the progress that had been made by the Indian schools.

A somewhat similar program to the one that has been so successful on the Six Nations Reserve has been started at Tyendinaga. Indian Agent Moore in his last monthly report states:

"A competition was held this year for the improvement of the grounds at the four day schools on the reserve and in May, last, an inspection was made of the schools, with the result that they were given the following standing:

First - Eastern; Second - Mission;
Third - Central; Fourth - Western.

In the early spring, trees were procured from the Ontario Forestry Branch and shrubs from a nursery. These trees were planted in accordance with the landscape plans provided by Mr. Charles Buchanan, district agricultural representative. Annual plants and flowers were also supplied and planted by the teachers and pupils of the schools.

*On October -
On October 14 Mr. Buchanan inspected these school grounds and awarded prizes for the schools showing the greatest improvement since his earlier inspection in May. The following prizes were awarded:

First - Central Day School - $5.00
Second - Eastern - $2.00
Third - Western - $2.00

These prizes were the result of local contributions and have been a great incentive in making this competition a success. Mr. Buchanan states that he finds a greater improvement for the year at the reserve schools than he has found in all the schools in the counties of Lennox and Addington, which form part of his district. Garden tools, lawn mowers, etc., have been supplied the reserve schools and next spring we hope to continue this improvement.

It would be a mistake, of course, to conclude from these observations that our Indian day schools throughout the Dominion are in a good state of repair or that Indian day school grounds, generally, are attractive. The programs carried out on these two reserves simply represent a start in a program which we hope to gradually extend on other reserves throughout the provinces. We seem to experience the utmost difficulty in securing a good quality of paint. For example, the new school on the Oneida reserve, at Muncey, Ont., which we built about three years ago, is at present urgently in need of paint. I examined this school very closely and convinced myself that the paint used must have been of a very inferior quality. The siding of the school suggests that it received only one coat. I am personally of the opinion that to use an inferior quality of paint on our schools is a sheer waste of money. On the other hand, I discussed this matter with Major Randle, and he does not appear to experience much difficulty in securing a good quality of paint for his schools at Brantford.

I had an opportunity, during my visit to Brantford and Muncey, to meet practically all the teachers in charge of our schools and to discuss educational problems with them. I was very favourably impressed with the interest these teachers are taking in their work and in the problems peculiar to the districts in which they are serving. A number of illustrations regarding this interest might be submitted. Mr. Joseph Hill, the teacher in charge of the No. 11 School, Six Nations, had a very fine set of vitamin charts on display in his room. These charts, illustrating the value of vegetables and the place that vegetables should occupy in a well balanced diet, were the best I have seen anywhere. I was naturally anxious to learn from him the source from which he had obtained them. He informed me that he had been deeply interested in dietetics for a number of years and had purchased these charts with his own money from the Provincial Department of Education. This teacher had six Grade 9 pupils (first year high school) in his classroom. Although these pupils experience a great deal of difficulty in covering first year high school work in 9 months, he was of the opinion that they were making fairly satisfactory progress.

Mrs. J. Holdsworth, teacher in charge of the Oneida No. 2 School, had a very fine piano in her classroom.
During the course of my conversation with her she intimated that the piano was almost indispensable in providing instruction in music, in conformity with the revised Ontario curriculum. When I enquired how she had secured the piano she informed me that she had organized a number of concerts and by charging an admission fee had secured quite a substantial sum. With this money in her purse she then approached a family who were moving from the district and who had a piano for sale. When the head of this household learned the use to which she was going to put the piano, it was sold to her at a very reasonable price. This teacher had organized Halloween Party for her pupils and although it was almost 5 o'clock when I visited her school, the children were still in the classroom, taking part in the program and apparently very happy.

It is somewhat unfortunate perhaps that the relationship between the Department and these teachers is a somewhat impersonal one. Accomplishments such as these - and I might quote hundreds of others - are seldom, if ever, brought to our attention, with the result that the teachers seldom, if ever, receive expressions of appreciation from our officials. The time of the average Indian agent is altogether too fully occupied for him even to notice such matters. They are part of the ordinary daily routine and in the course of time become somewhat commonplace. I learned that a number of our teachers were sufficiently interested in Indian work to remain in our service although they had received tempting offers from white schools in adjoining districts. These teachers do leave our schools from time to time, thus being influenced usually by the thought of qualifying later for the provincial superannuation payments. The failure of our Branch to make provision for superannuation payments to our teachers appears to be a source of worry to a great many of our teachers who have spent a number of years in our schools. In this connection Inspector Moir, of Saskatchewan, in his report dated October 1, states:

"Your schools suffer severely from constantly changing teachers. There seems to be no way at present by which Indian day or residential school teachers can take advantage of the superannuation plan in the province."

WELFARE:

Encouraging reports continue to reach us from Dr. Orford, in respect to his gardening program in the James Bay Agency. In his report dated October 14, Dr. Orford states:

"Last spring 50 bushels of certified seed potatoes were purchased. Four and a half acres of welfare gardens were planted with this seed and 10 bushels of a locally grown red seed which I had noticed last year to give a high yield of large firm potatoes.

"Potatoes remaining from last year's crop were distributed for gardens to individual Indians - approximately 100 bushels - and to the group creating a new settlement on the Moose Reserve.

"Men were employed all summer to tend the gardens and they managed fairly well in keeping them cultivated.

"In August -
"In August we began to use new potatoes from the welfare garden - the Indians all being encouraged to use this garden and keep their own for later use. It is therefore rather difficult to accurately estimate the crop, but after all the Indians had been using these potatoes for a month we dug up and stored in the new root-house 386 bags, all large and firm and without any skin blemish.

"It is also difficult to estimate the crop from the individual gardens of the Indians who planted them, but those I did check on had an average yield of 6 bags for every one planted, so I would judge that a conservative estimate would be 600 bags. Of these about 200 bags are stored in our old root-house here on the island and the rest have been taken by the Indians to their hunting grounds. The 200 bags stored here are for use next spring and summer for food.

"In addition to this, the newly created community garden of approximately one acre belonging to the group on the Moose Reserve produced 149 bags of potatoes.

"An acre was also plated this spring in other garden crops - turnips, parsnips, onions, carrots, radish, lettuce, green beans and soy beans. The soy bean was not a success, as reported in another letter. I had hoped to have some of the produce from this acre for the widows during the winter. However, I am more than pleased that all I have left is a few turnips and parsnips. The enthusiasm with which the Indians ate up the garden simply goes to prove that they appreciated its development for them. They particularly enjoyed the radishes, lettuce and green onions and I had an opportunity a short while ago to taste a stew prepared by Indian women, the vegetable portion of which - potatoes, carrots, turnips, onions and beans - was picked from the locally grown gardens. It was delicious and I can only hope that we can continue to encourage them in the use of such food. What a difference it should make in their general outlook and health to get away from their old customary summer diet around here of pan-fried bannock, day in and day out.

"Some of our land will require rotation in crop next year, but we have 5½ acres of newly broken ground which was lying idle this summer. However, I think we could use more ground and approval is requested to employ Indians to mark out and clear about 2 acres on the island, adjacent to our present new plot. We could probably have it ready for plowing by the fall of 1943."

In response to a request received from Inspector Hamilton, Miss Edythe Smith-Windsor, the teacher in charge of the United Church Indian Day School at Fisher River, Man., was engaged during the month of September in the organization of women's clubs, in the Grindstone and Clandeboye agencies. Mr. Hamilton, in his report on this work, says:

"I consider Miss Smith-Windsor has done some excellent work, and already the women of the Fort Alexander Reserve have requested more discarded army clothing. The first shipment of this clothing has all been used and the..."
new garments placed on display by the Sisters at the residential school. I inspected some of these articles and convinced myself that the work was well done."

Miss Smith, in her report on the Griswold agency, states:

"Meetings were held in the basement of the Anglican Church on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. In all, fifteen women attended the meetings. This being the harvest season, all the women were not free to attend.

"Sample garments that had been made by the Fairfield Club were on display. The women were able to understand the purpose of the organization better after seeing some of the work done by another group.

"Eight women took work to do. They ripped up garments to be remodelled and stated the purpose for which each was intended. One woman suggested that a child's overall suit could be made from the pockets of two pairs of army pants. Another suggested using the good parts of sock feet for an afghan. Some socks were given out to be re-footed - using unravelled sock wool for the new feet.

"When I approached Miss Stapleton, the day school teacher regarding carrying on as convenor of the club, she felt she already had too many responsibilities to 'take on' the Club. She suggested, however, that Miss Weller and Miss Wilkins who are at the Anglican Mission with her might enjoy the club work. They were quite willing to carry on.

"I appreciate the assistance rendered by Mr. and Mrs. Young at the agency in getting word to the women about the meetings, and by Miss Stapleton for the use of the church basement for our meetings."

For a number of reasons that seem somewhat difficult to explain, few Indians appear to be interested in the keeping of poultry. The average Indian has not yet convinced himself that eggs or vegetables are either appetizing or necessary to his health. To convince him that both eggs and vegetables should have a prominent place in a well balanced diet, it will be necessary to undertake a worthwhile adult educational program. A lantern and slides might be used very effectively in this program. In the meantime, it is gratifying to learn, from a report received by Inspector Schmidt, that a number of Indians in the Edmonton agency have made a start in the poultry industry. In his report dated October 14, 1942, Inspector Schmidt states:

"A large number of the Indians on Alexander's Reserve have chickens, turkeys and geese. A number of these Indians also have hogs and are making a good deal of money from the sale of pork. On Enoch's Reserve the majority of the Indians have chickens and turkeys and a smaller number have hogs. Most of these Indians milk cows and make butter for their own use and for sale to other Indians."

With an acute shortage of labour existing in the country and with work readily available, one might naturally
expect a substantial reduction from month to month in our relief and welfare expenditures. As a matter of fact, however, there are expenditures such as those referred to by Indian Agent Lasenby, which we are apt to overlook—expenditures which appear to be necessary and which tend to keep relief costs at a comparatively high figure. Mr. Lasenby, in his report dated September 20th, states:

"In explanation of the fact that some relief was given to families of Indians who had enlisted, I beg to say that the enlisted Indians left Norway House for Winnipeg without leaving any provisions for their families, and these families came to me for food as they could not get any provisions on credit at the local stores and I knew it would be at least a month or more before these families would begin to receive any assigned pay or dependent's allowance. I therefore gave these families a little that I considered would last them for a month until their pay began to arrive. Since that time, however, several of these families have been back for more food, not having received their pay as yet, but instead of giving further relief I have given them orders against their treaty payments on the understanding that when they receive their cheques they will repay these amounts. The same explanation applies with regard to the families of the Indians who went out to the prairies for the harvest.

"........... It is quite unnecessary to remind me that these are very serious times and every effort should be made to reduce the cost of relief. I am fully aware of all this and endeavour at all times to practise the strictest economy, not only in the way of relief but in every other way."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended November 30, 1942.

WELFARE:

The statement of welfare expenditures for the period April 1 to October 31 shows a slight increase - $637.48 - over expenditures for the corresponding period of last year. This figure indicates that relief and welfare expenditures have become somewhat static and are not likely to show substantial reductions at any time in the immediate future. However, we can hope for certain reductions in Nova Scotia when the policy of centralization is completed in that province.

I still find it difficult to understand why welfare expenditures remain so high in Manitoba - $68,572.44 for the period under review as against $68,246.05 for last year - showing an increase of $626.39. This amount continues to be high when compared with an expenditure of $45,678.61 in Saskatchewan and $37,440.27 in Alberta. I am not suggesting that there are in Manitoba physically fit Indians in receipt of relief or that the old and physically incapacitated Indians are receiving too much. I do suggest, however, that for some reason difficult to explain, subsistence gardens in the province of Manitoba have not been cultivated to the extent that these gardens have been cultivated in the other provinces. The Manitoba agencies have also been backward, particularly the northern agencies, in the construction of root-houses.

However, two women were employed by Inspector Hamilton during the summer months, with the object of stimulating interest in gardening and in the remodelling of discarded military clothing. It is perhaps too early to expect that the work of these women would be reflected in relief costs.

Mr. Morris, of this Division, has taken a personal and active interest in the Golden Lake band of Indians during the summer months and has found it possible to visit this reserve six times during the summer and fall season. A worthwhile welfare program has been carried out on this reserve, under the supervision of Mr. Morris, and a root-house 25' x 16' (inside measurements) has been constructed. This root-house is at the present time almost filled with vegetables, secured from the Kingston penitentiary. A goat herd of 17 females and two males has been purchased. A barn for the housing of these goats has been secured and repaired and a field suitable for pasture has been fenced. Mr. Morris has succeeded also in organizing the women of this reserve for the remodelling of discarded
military clothing. These women meet at the home of the President, Mrs. Lavallee, monthly. Mr. Morris has already attended two of their meetings. In addition to the remodelling of clothing, the members of this club are taking a keen interest in gardening and in the care of live stock, the improvement of their homes and conditions generally on the reserve. Mr. Morris has succeeded, also, in having the Indians of this reserve prepare 25 acres of land, and this area is ready for cultivation next year.

Rev. J. P. Mackey, Principal of the Residential School at Shubenacadie, N.S., has co-operated very effectively with the Indian agent at that point in the organization of a worthwhile agricultural program on the new reserve. In response to a suggestion made by me, Father Mackey placed his farm machinery at the disposal of the agent for use on the reserve early in the spring. This was done on the understanding that we would pay for its use. I am now in receipt of a letter from Father Mackey, attaching a statement showing the machinery used and the hours of labour spent by his farming instructor on Indian lands. The letter accompanying this statement from Father Mackey reads:

"Enclosed please find a list of the days and hours of work at the Doyle farm on the Indian reserve. This work was undertaken in response to your letters of April 21 and April 29, 1945.

"You will notice that we began work on May 2 and finished on July 18. Due to many causes, we did not obtain the results we had expected. ..... However, we believe that you have a report of the amount of potatoes, carrots, turnips and cabbage harvested, and the crop will more than pay for the amount expended.

"We are not asking any compensation whatever for what we have done, as we consider that the school should be willing to do something for the general welfare of the Indians".

It is very seldom indeed that we receive a letter from anyone or from any source, indicating that a contribution to the welfare of the Indians is being made without cost to the Department.

A number of very discouraging reports have been received on threshing operations in the Prairie Provinces. It would appear that weather conditions at a number of agencies, coupled with an acute shortage of labour, prevented the completion of threshing operations, with the result that large quantities of grain - wheat, oats - will remain in the stocks throughout the winter months. Indian Agent Ostrander, in his report dated November 8, states:

"Threshing has been stopped on all the reserves for some time; in fact it never started on the Poundmaker Reserve and little more than started on the Sweet Grass and Little Pine Reserves. The Red Pheasant and Thunderchild Reserves were about half finished. Winter has set in and there is little hope of the grain being fit to thresh for the rest of the winter. The stocks are wet..."
inside. Snow and ice has been driven into them by a blizzard which swept the district on the 27th of October. There only remains now the possibility that we can protect the grain from cattle and horses, in the hope that some of it will be worth threshing when spring comes around. It was simply impossible to get threshing machines at the proper time. Another difficulty was the financing of the cost of threshing, with heavy crops and a small quota for immediate delivery, many farmers could not pay it once. Trying to pay the threshing crew and meeting fuel costs was a great worry to many threshing machine owners, who after weeks of fighting bad weather conditions and difficult financing eventually pulled in their threshing machines, even before the weather forced them to do so."

It so happens that a number of the reserves referred to by Indian Agent Ostrander are indebted to the revolving fund for advances made to their community farms. In view of this report, however, collections this year are not likely to be very satisfactory.

In my report to you on my visit to the Caradoc Reserve, I referred to the organization of a project aimed at the production of willow on the reserve. It is encouraging to note, from a letter received from Indian Agent Down, dated November 20, that this project is now under way. The Indian Agent in his letter states:

"You will, I am sure, since your recent visit and discussions re the planting of willow be interested to learn of the progress made to date. Not much time was lost in reaching a final decision in respect to suitable land and I immediately requested Mr. Ryckman to prepare the land selected for planting.

"On Friday November 13 I received a call from Brantford to the effect that a quantity of willow sets were ready. I immediately made arrangements for the trip and on arrival was agreeably surprised to learn that 50,000 sets had been prepared for planting. I at once realized that we had a job ahead of us and the weather did not look too promising; however, I instructed Mr. Ryckman to hire 7 or 8 men and together he and I supervised the planting. This work was entered into and accomplished with a good spirit of cooperation, and I am happy to advise you that 50,000 sets have been planted. If nature will be kind and favour us with a few more days of planting weather, I shall be able to report the completion of this work.

TRAINING

A teachers' convention - the first of its kind held since I entered the Department 6 years ago - was organized at St. Boniface, Manitoba, on November 24, 25 and 26. This convention was made up of residential school principals and residential school teachers in charge of schools operated by the Government in cooperation with the Oblate Order. Principals and teachers were present from the following schools: McIntosh, Fort Frances, Fort Alexander, Sandy Bay, Muscowequan, St. Phillips, Cowessess, Qu'Appelle, Onion Lake, Dusk Lake, Thunderchild, Crowfoot, Blue Quills, Ermineskins, Blood, Sacred Heart, St. Albert, Guy, Beauval, Cross Lake and Grouard. In addition to the
principals and teachers from the aforementioned schools, the convention was attended also by Bishop Phelan; the Reverend Father Southier, Oblate Provincial for Alberta; the Reverend Father Lavigne, Oblate Provincial for Manitoba; the Reverend L. Beuglet, O.M.I., representing the Bishop of Grouard; the Reverend Father Tessier, representing Bishop Guy; and the Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., who was mainly responsible for the organization of this convention, was also present. This branch was represented by Mr. Doucet and Mr. Phelan. Mr. J. R. Johns, Director of Vocational Education in the province of Manitoba, also addressed the convention and took part in the discussions. Mr. Phelan and Mr. Doucet have returned with very encouraging reports of the proceedings. Mr. Doucet is of the opinion that this was one of the best, if not the best, convention of its kind he ever attended. I was particularly pleased that Mr. Johns was able to appear before these teachers. Mr. Johns is, in my judgment, the most outstanding authority on vocational instruction in the Dominion. A few years ago he refused an offer from the New Zealand Government to organize the entire school system of New Zealand on a vocational basis.

Inspector Muller, in his report dated November 25 on the Peguis South, Centre and North Indian Day Schools and the senior and junior rooms at the Fisher River School, states:

"I enclose herewith reports of Indian schools which I have been asked to inspect. I am very glad to say that the teachers at these schools are not only qualified and experienced but are carrying on their work efficiently. They all show a personal interest in the welfare of their pupils and are putting forth their best efforts.

"The pupils are receiving practical instruction in health as well as in other subjects of the curriculum. I found the children quite neat in appearance and much better clothed than usual. Their health, too, seems to be much improved and there is a good attitude on their part toward their teachers and their work.

"Each of these schools has received recently about a dozen library books, attractive in appearance, and of an easy reading level. In my opinion these books are most suitable for the children and I have asked the teachers to endeavour to have all these books read during the course of the year. I feel that the reading of such books by the pupils in the low grades will contribute much towards improving the quality of reading generally found in Indian schools and will help to create a taste for reading. It would be interesting to follow the effect the reading of these books will have on the pupils."

It is gratifying to be able to report that a large number of our teachers appear to be taking a keen interest in the health program of the Department. A number of these teachers assisted last spring in the organization of garden projects on their reserves, and Inspector Waind, in his report on the St. Philips Residential School, states:

"The exhibits of this school at fairs during the past summer included health posters, Christmas cards, valentines and handwriting exercises. This school won prizes in the work shown including sewing as well as the above work."

A few months ago I learned that Dr. Barclay, Superintendent of the Coqualeetza Hospital, was employing
a number of Indian girls as maids at the hospital. In a letter dated September 2 I asked Dr. Barclay to report from time to time on the number of these girls who in his judgment had made good. His first report, dated November 10, states:

"The above-mentioned maid, (Eleanor Moon) is leaving shortly because of the illness of an aunt with whom, I believe, she has made her home. This girl came from Alert Bay, in Mr. Todd's agency, and attended the Alert Bay Day School and St. Michael's Residential School. She completed Grade 6 in the latter institution. She came to us on the recommendation of the Principal of St. Michael's, Mr. Anfield.

"Eleanor's behavior here has been exemplary. She seems to have good common sense, has proven very satisfactory with hospital routine and latterly has been in charge of the preventive children as night attendant. We are sorry to lose her but hope she may be in a position to return to our staff later on. From time to time the names of other deserving girls will be drawn to the attention of the Department."

I have referred from time to time to the domestic science classes at the Maliseet Reserve, in the New Brunswick Northern Agency. Indian Agent Whalen, in a letter dated November 10, refers to a visit made by him with two of his teachers to the Maliseet School. The Agent states:

"On October 31st I took Sister Dolores and Sister Balliana, teacher and field worker on the Woodstock Reserve, to visit the school and domestic science room at the Maliseet Reserve, near Perth.

"The teachers discussed problems and ideas with regard to their school work, the domestic science work and everything in general which would be of assistance to them in their line of work.

"Both departments of this school were visited in the morning and again in the afternoon, also the domestic science department in the basement of the school building. The domestic science work was wonderful. When the Sister told us the amount of money they took in for their manufactured goods I began to long for such rooms for the Indian schools of my agency.

"The visit was very satisfactory and much was accomplished. I believe if there were more such school discussions between the teachers of the different Indian schools, such discussions would prove very helpful to both teachers and pupils."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended December 31, 1942.

It is difficult to resist the temptation that comes to one at the end of the calendar year to undertake and submit in this report a cursory review of the tasks undertaken and accomplished during the year that has now reached its close.

WELFARE:

It can be stated that the Indians enjoyed greater earning power and on the whole a higher standard of living during the year 1942 than they have enjoyed at any time in recent years. Throughout the entire year employment was plentiful and wages high. The fur catch was above average and here, too, prices were satisfactory. The elimination of Japanese competition in the fishing industry on the Pacific Coast enabled an unusually large number of Indians to secure gainful employment in salmon and herring fishing. The distribution of huge quantities of discarded military clothing - greatcoats, tunics, windbreakers and boots - and the use made of this clothing by groups of Indian women has enabled the Indian to become decently and comfortably dressed for the first time in many years.

There have been, of course, a great many discouragements throughout the year. Discouragements, disappointment and an almost constant sense of frustration appear to be inseparable from Indian administration. Perhaps the greatest discouragement of the year was the result secured from our farming operations throughout the Dominion, particularly our farming operations in the three Prairie Provinces. With the exception of the Six Nations Reserve at Brantford and the Blackfoot and Blood Reserves in Alberta, I am disposed to think that there has been a substantial decline in our farming operations. Of course, I have not before me at the moment the statistics for the year, but a number of reports received toward the end of the year from our agents in the West indicate that a great many Indians were induced by the prevailing high wages to abandon their farms, with somewhat serious results. For example, the amount of grain threshed in the Battleford Agency was almost negligible. Large quantities of wheat and oats in this agency are now buried under three or four feet of snow and, prior to the snowfall, were drenched with fall rains. Indian
Agent Ostrander intimates that an attempt will be made to protect this grain from the encroachment of cattle, field mice, etc. This delay in threshing operations has resulted in a number of requests from agencies for seed grain. A request for seed grain in the Battleford Agency was sent forward by Mr. Christianson a few days ago. He intimates that none of the wheat and oats will be threshed in time for next year's seeding operations and that it is doubtful if this grain would be satisfactory for seed if it were threshed, and so the Indian again turns to a benevolent government to assist him in his agricultural operations.

As a department we are the largest single land owners in Canada and should be the largest land operators, and yet, despite this fact, we are purchasing seed grain from year to year for Indian farmers and purchasing beef at this time as high as 16¢ a pound for cattle supplies. There seems to be a peculiar lack of policy and direction in our farming operations in the Prairie Provinces, and I am not at all convinced that a change of policy can be effected under the present leadership. Agricultural and field staff seem to be either discouraged or in a rut, or perhaps both. Under the leadership of Dr. Robertson, they emerged from this rut for a year or so in Saskatchewan and, while on the surface, organized a number of worthwhile women's clubs and community farms. Indications at the moment, however, are that the progress then apparent is no longer noticeable. The tendency to lean on the Government appears to be very pronounced, with the result that relief expenditures in the province of Manitoba are almost as high at this date as they were during the depression. The Indian problem in Canada and particularly in Western Canada will demand strong, capable leadership. It appears somewhat astounding that in the area in Canada where the Indians own and control the greatest resources, progress appears to be most difficult. The progress made, however, by the Indians of British Columbia during the last few years affords a striking example of what can be accomplished by capable leadership.

Viewing conditions in the Dominion as a whole, however, it can be said that a number of projects have been organized during the course of the year which are likely to contribute to the health and general welfare of the Indians. The most notable of these, in my judgment, is the establishment of a number of goat herds on certain reserves. Purebred goat herds have now been established at Spanish and Golden Lake, Ontario Island Lake, Norway House and Berens River, Manitoba, and Sucker Creek Carlton Agency, Saskatchewan. In addition to this, a number of requests for the establishment of herds have been received from Indians on Lac La Rivièrè, Dr. Orford and a number of Indians at the Cariboo Agency. The keeping of small herds of goats on the part of the Indian is, in my judgment, the least expensive method of providing him with a well balanced diet. The Indians of Berens River, Manitoba, who have been encouraged to keep small herds of goats, by the United Church Missionary at that point, have now learned that these animals provide them with an abundant supply of milk and that the goats can easily be transported by canoe to their hunting and trapping grounds.

The construction of root-houses has also been a notable feature of our year's work. Large community root-houses were constructed at Eskasoni, Shubenacadie, Lennox Island and Golden Lake Reserves during the year.

It is also encouraging to report that groups
of Indian women have been organized for the remodelling of discarded military clothing during the year in Manitoba. It was necessary to exercise a great deal of pressure and secure the services of the Presbyterian missionary from the Battle agency before this work could be undertaken. Reports recently received however indicate that these organizations are now in full swing. If these groups of women can be encouraged to cultivate small subsistence gardens, preserve fruits and vegetables, in addition to the remodelling of military clothing, these activities should be reflected in the relief costs for the province.

TRAINING

A sincere and earnest attempt has been made throughout the year to save our educational institutions from serious impairment. This has not been an easy task. At the outbreak of the war we had in charge of a number of our day schools a fairly large group of fully qualified male teachers. With the exception of a few male teachers suffering from physical disabilities and a number of missionaries who have been exempted from military service, there have been no male teachers now in charge of Indian day schools. This shortage of qualified teachers has remained acute throughout the year, and has resulted in the employment of married women, many of whom have not been teaching at any time in recent years. This failure on our part to secure fully qualified teachers must of necessity be reflected in the progress and general efficiency of our schools.

The decision to pay our per capita grants to Indian residential schools on a basis of $2.24 has resulted in a substantial reduction in our school enrolment. It is worthy of note that in the year 1937-38 we had enrolled at residential schools 9,523 pupils and at Indian day schools, 9,510 pupils; and yet, despite the fact that our school population has a natural increase of approximately 300 pupils per annum, our enrolment for the last school year amounted in the case of residential schools to 9,249 and at Indian day schools to 8,441. It will thus be seen that our educational policy, for the time being at least, appears to be having such an adverse effect. The payment of per capita grant on a $2.24 basis, our refusal to pay for supernumerary pupils at residential schools, our failure to secure the number of teachers necessary to operate all our Indian day schools and the absence from reserves of a large number of Indian families have all contributed to this decline in our school enrolment. It is significant to note that our educational costs per pupil in 1936-37 amounted to $39.54 but have increased with the decline in enrolment until they appear to be at this date approximately $109.92 per pupil.

The tendency of the Indian day school teacher to change frequently, coupled with irregular attendance at day schools, is perhaps one of the most discouraging features of our educational program. It was disclosed in a pedagogical survey, undertaken a few years ago in the United States, that the average pupil enrolled at an elementary school will make more progress in three years under the same teacher than he will in four years under four distinct and separate teachers. Practically all the provinces in the Dominion have now a superannuation fund for teachers. The creation of these superannuation funds has arrested the tendency so evident a
few years ago on the part of teachers to move from one province to another and has contributed substantially to security of tenure and continuity of teaching service in public schools. The same that are likely to experience a great deal of difficulty in securing fully qualified teachers for our schools in the future unless such teachers are classified as permanent Civil Servants and thus enabled to qualify for superannuation allowances.

One of the outstanding accomplishments of the year, in my judgment, was an Intelligence Quotient survey of certain Indian day and residential schools, undertaken by Dr. C. E. Stothers, psychiatrist in charge of the Toronto Auxiliary Classes. The report of this survey, a somewhat voluminous document with complete tabular statements, was submitted to the Department on November 30, 1942. A great deal of this work, which was undertaken and completed without cost to this Branch, was accomplished by Miss L. Helen De Laporte, assistant to Dr. Stothers. A survey of the following day schools was undertaken:

Tyendinaga Central
Eastern
Mission
Western

Mud Lake
Kettle Point

and the following residential schools:

Shingwauk
Kenora (R.C.)
Fort Frances (R.C.)
Spanish (R.C.)
Mount Elgin (United Church)
Mohawk Institute (C.E.)

This report is likely to prove invaluable to the officials of this Division in working out an educational program designed to meet the peculiar needs of our Indian population.

In the language of the layman it would appear that the average Indian pupil is at least two years behind the average white pupil at any time during his sojourn at school. This discrepancy is due to a number of causes - lack of cultural advantages in his home, environmental disadvantages and linguistic handicaps.

Dr. Stothers is definitely of the opinion that it will be necessary to provide a special course of training for Indian day and residential school teachers before we can expect satisfactory results from our schools. The following is a summary of the recommendations submitted in the report for our consideration:

Supervision -

More supervision by the school inspector is necessary.

If a group meeting or convention of the inspectors concerned were called, there would be a better understanding of the problems involved in Indian education.

Teaching Staff

A special -
Teaching Staff

A special course of training is strongly recommended for Indian day and residential school teachers. This course could be given at various centres across the continent or in Ottawa. It is suggested that a special grant on salary be given to both teacher and school to encourage the teacher to take this special course. If the teacher received special training, many of the difficulties which arise could, in our judgment, be overcome.

Equipment

It is strongly recommended that large additions be made to all school libraries as soon as possible. Each classroom should have reading texts and social study readers both above and below the grade level of the classroom for children more advanced and retarded in reading. Any of the new progressive series of readers with controlled vocabularies would be suitable.

It is recommended that manual training equipment be installed in all schools to promote greater development of hand work as a hobby and the teaching of finer steps in woodwork which may not occur in practical work outside. The equipment of a household science unit room would enable a household science teacher to correlate the various activities of a household for teaching purposes.

Courses of Study

It is recommended that instead of one course of study being followed by all schools the course of study be modified to meet the needs of the various communities. The effect of this will be to make some of the schools "Opportunity Schools" with the bright children as "Specials".

Art and Craftwork

Art work should follow a course of study with emphasis on the portrayal of familiar scenes and experiences. The child should learn the beauty of his own environment and his relationship thereto. Craftwork should be given throughout the entire period of the child's school life and not merely as a by-product of art. It should be an important subject. Craftwork, besides its development of the aesthetic sense, should develop muscular dexterity. It can be an excellent media for improving handwriting neatness and precision and in this way influence both spelling and arithmetic. Nothing restores confidence to the slow learning child who has met defeat as much as the creation of a piece of craftwork.

In view of the fact that such a large percentage of these children, i.e., 61%, need more than a straight academic course of study, the practical work at an Indian school becomes of paramount importance. In the majority of the residential schools this was essential work in the upkeep of the school itself, cooking the meals, dusting, sweeping, washing dishes, mending stockings and clothing, making uniforms, dresses and overalls. This work was usually under the supervision of the sewing teacher, cook or Supt. The necessities of the school, however, were the controlling factors. There were courses made out within the limitations possible and in some schools a good basic training was received. Each department seemed to be somewhat separate, the school, the sewing, the cooking etc. With closer guidance from someone with authority and training, the departments could be dovetailed and greatly increased in
effectiveness. Embroidery was taught at St. Mary's (Kenora) and St. Margaret's (Fort Frances). Craftwork in the form of weaving was being taught at Munsey (Mount Elgin) and beaded moccasins at St. Mary's (Kenora). The workmanship and stitchery were well done.

The practical work in our judgment is being well done, in view of existing limitations of accommodation, money for upkeep, time and other handicaps. Children, however, are young but once, and it did seem pathetic to us to see the little children darnimg huge grey socks instead of making a gay doll's dress.

We are at present engaged in an intensive study of this report, with the object of extracting from it all that might with profit be incorporated in our courses of study. The suggestion that Indian day and residential school teachers should be given a special course of training is one that merits a great deal of study. In view of the fact, however, that Indian day school teachers remain less than three years on an average at our schools, it would seem to me that before a special course of study is organized and provided, ways and means should be found to encourage continuity of teaching service at our schools.

Rev. George Dorey, D.D., United Church Mission Board, Toronto.
Right Rev. G. J. Breynat, O.M.I.
Most Rev. P. S. Moraud, O.M.I.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, January 31, 1945.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended January 31, 1945.

WELFARE:

I have referred on more than one occasion to the work undertaken and accomplished by Indian Women's Clubs in the Prairie Provinces and in British Columbia. Indian women's organizations have been particularly successful in the province of Saskatchewan. The members of these clubs are now engaged in the remodelling of military clothing, the canning and preserving of fruits and vegetables, the encouragement of better attendance at Indian day schools and in tasks of a patriotic character. It is no exaggeration to state that the existence of these organizations is one of the most encouraging features of our Indian welfare program. In view of this fact, it is gratifying to be able to report that a start has been made in the organization of these clubs in the province of Ontario. Indian Agent Down, in a letter dated January 11, states:

"I do not know how far you have progressed at other agencies in connection with the formation of Homemakers' Clubs, but I thought perhaps you would be interested to learn of the developments, progress and method of approach in forming such clubs at this agency. ......."

"Perhaps I was fortunate in being able to retain a projector that had been used by Dr. Moore in presenting a lantern lecture outlining the nutritional value of vitamins in the daily diet; also his presence at my initial meeting. Prestige is always added by the presence of an official from Ottawa. I was also well supplied with a varied collection of very serviceable remodelled clothing, which was on display and used very effectively for demonstration purposes. .......

The result has been that we have now five groups but only two available sewing machines. This has caused some disappointment and confusion. However, we assigned the machines with promise that the three other groups would be supplied as efforts warranted. At this date four groups have been supplied with material and are functioning very creditably and satisfactorily. Already, children are beginning to appear on the reserve in remade sweater coats and new suits. Shirts are being repaired and being made over for men and boys. Blankets are being ripped and made serviceable. The women are suggesting an interchange of patterns for all types of winter and summer clothing. These women set their own meeting days and work out their own ideas of remodelling clothing and already the response has been far beyond expectations."

Mr. Down, in a report dated January 9, also refers to this year's farming operations at his agency.
He states:

"This is a service that has perhaps caused more unpleasantness and disunity at the agency within the last five years than any other service. Just why this should be so and wherein lies the fault, I do not know, and if I did, it is past history in any case. Certainly, every effort has been and will be made to correct many wrongs. In this effort, I have and expect to retain the full cooperation of Mr. Hyckman. It is perhaps sufficient to state that the program was started off on the wrong foot.

"During my regime of 10 months it has been my responsibility to take part in a complete crop season and it is on this 10 months that I wish to report. Crops went in good shape and although we did at times have a little too much rain, the growing season was good.

"Bushels threshed:

Rye - 1135; Wheat - 918; Oats - 2128;
Mixed grain - 1257, making a total of 5435 bushels.

In addition, we harvested 450 bags of potatoes.

"This, I understand, is the largest crop by at least 2,000 bushels that has ever been harvested under the local welfare program. Very good, but I am not satisfied. I do not like the scheme under its present system of operation. We are concentrating too much on agency farming for the benefit of the agency rather than the instructional values of general farming for the individual. Unfortunately, I see no immediate prospect of changing the system until a central instructional farm is introduced, whereby we can instruct. No man, no matter how good he is, can instruct in general farming merely by growing grain."

In a reference to relief costs at his agency in this report, Mr. Down states:

"It is sometimes said that there should be no relief administered these days of mechanical warfare with its attendant industrial and agricultural expansion. To a degree, this is correct, but we still have our aged, unemployables and sick individuals, and it is to these that relief is being extended. A genuine effort has been made within the last year to weed out the dead wood, the parasite who thinks the world and every person in it owes him a living. In this, I think I can claim some success. Your records should provide the answer."

An article in the February 1 issue of Maclean's magazine illustrates very strikingly the innate inertia of the North American Indian. This brief article, on page 40, reads:

"American soldiers at Fort Nelson, B.C., 250 miles northwest of Edmonton, are beginning to get the notion that certain of the Indians at that outpost are the laziest lugs north of the equator. They regard trapping as sport, make big money at it, but are allergic to all other forms of labor. 'They are what might be called the idle rich,' Morris Brown, U.S. Army, reports to his former colleagues..."
of Metropolitan Life. 'One big Indian buck came up to our tents and offered any two soldiers sixty cents an hour to cut wood for him.'

Brown doesn't say what happened, but if the Yanks didn't teach the wealthy buck the ancient game of poker, and send him back to his wigwam sans feathers, they aren't the guys we thought they were."

The statement of welfare expenditures for the period April 1 to December 31 has just been issued. This statement shows a total expenditure for the period amounting to $457,078.46, compared with $469,171.08 for the corresponding period of last year. These figures represent a net decrease of $12,092.62. It is noted, however, that with policy of centralization in force in Nova Scotia, relief costs in that province for the period increased by $10,124.51. These figures are on the whole, in my judgment, reasonably satisfactory. Relief is now extended only to the aged, sick and physically incapacitated. The distribution of discarded military clothing has enabled us to effect substantial savings in a number of agencies. The only way whereby relief or welfare costs could be still further reduced would be by the multiplication of subsistence gardens and the cultivation of community gardens, from which old and physically unfit Indians could be provided with vegetables. An earnest attempt will be made this year to greatly extend our gardening program.

TRAINING:

A conference, arranged by representatives of the Churches with the Minister, which took place on January 9, enabled us to meet again representatives of all the Churches responsible for the operation of our Indian residential schools.

These representatives, without exception, emphasized the difficulty they are experiencing in securing the wool and woollen fabrics necessary to clothe the children enrolled at our schools. They are experiencing difficulty also in securing farm hands, dishers and domestic help. The representatives of the non-Catholic Churches contend that at no time in recent years have they experienced the same difficulty in securing fully qualified teachers for classroom work. They claim that at this date they are paying substantially higher salaries to both farm labourers and teachers than they were at the outset of the war. It is not at all likely that these conditions will change to any appreciable extent until the end of the war.

A few days ago I reported to you that the Fort George Anglican Residential School had been completely destroyed by fire. Residential schools have been destroyed at the rate of at least one per annum since I entered the Department. The destruction of this school reminds us again that only fully fireproof buildings should be erected for the institutional care and education of Indians. We have
been particularly fortunate in recent years in that, despite the number of buildings destroyed, not a single life has been lost.

About a year ago we received some very flattering reports on the work of Anthony Walsh, teacher at the Inkanseep Indian Day School, Okanagan Agency, B.C. Mr. Walsh appeared to be outstandingly successful in the training of his pupils in amateur dramatics and buckskin drawings. He also, in cooperation with the pupils, published a booklet entitled "The Tale of the Nativity" or the story of the Nativity, gleaned from Indian legends. Mr. Walsh has recently resigned from his school with the object of joining the Armed Forces. We can only express the hope that his services will be available at the close of the war.

Encouraging reports continue to reach us from the Grouard Indian Residential School, Grouard, Alberta. Inspector Stehelin, in his report dated December 2, 1942, states:

"In the school 'Adaptation to the immediate home surroundings of the Indian child' is the pass-word. This is especially true in the senior room, where Sister John is carrying on exceptionally fine work. Her quarterly review, the 'Grouard Echoes' is rapidly growing.

An enterprise is begun on 'Lets Go Indian'. Skilled Indian women come to teach the pupils how to make leather goods. For the boys, experienced Indians come and give demonstrations in birch bark work and other Indian skills. The C.Y.O. is progressing very favourably under the expert guidance of Father Porade. The pupils, boys and girls, are enthusiastic over these activities. The general results have been the development of an Esprit de Corps in the school, and an improvement in the general health and carriage of the pupils. The result of giving responsibility to pupils has been wonderful. The introduction of the Steam Bath has produced results beyond expectation. Skin diseases and vermin disappear as by magic. The teachers report that during the past year the entire school has been free from colds, grippe and contagious disease.

"The home economics class was visited. The ten girls enrolled are doing very fine work in sewing, rug-making, knitting and weaving. The building equipped as a home centre is very attractive and it provides a valuable opportunity for these girls to familiarize themselves with simple but yet important social graces.

"The wood-working class was visited. There is accommodation for 8 to 12 pupils. The raising of bees has been suggested by myself as an activity topic in the school. All teachers are very enthusiastic and it is planned to develop an enterprise on Bees, in which mathematics, science, art, social studies and language will be taught. It is planned that during the school years the Indian boys will learn about bees, make their own hive and equipment and on leaving school each boy will have one working hive and the necessary knowledge to carry on."

We have succeeded during the last year in securing positions for a number of girl graduates of the
Mount Elgin, Chapleau and Spanish Residential Schools. There appears to be an acute shortage of domestic help in a number of the larger centres throughout the Dominion and this shortage is very much in evidence in Ottawa. These girl graduates have been placed in a number of better class homes and are rendering satisfactory service. A number of these girls have also been placed at the Ottawa General Hospital. At the present time these girls are brought in from the residential schools and placed in the General Hospital by way of trial. Later, when they express a desire to go into domestic work, positions are found for them. Of the 12 or more girls already brought in, only one has abandoned her work. This girl, a graduate of the Mount Elgin Institute, returned a few months ago to her father, who is a resident of the Caughnawaga Reserve.
