Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended February 28, 1943.

TRAINING:

A year ago we reached an understanding with Lt. Colonel W. G. B. Dailley, Chairman of the Army Salvage & Disposal Board, whereby quantities of discarded military socks were shipped to a number of our Indian residential schools and a few of our larger day schools for processing. These discarded socks are shipped from the nearest Ordnance Depot and the processed yarn is returned to this depot. The response on the part of our school principals has been more than encouraging. The Principal of the Maria Day School, in a letter dated January 17, states:

"We have sent 500 skeins of yarn to the Military Officer in Quebec, as requested by yourself. Considering that the girls of the junior class are not 20 in number, you will admit that they have been very active.

"Out of the unraveled soldiers' socks there are remnants that are unusable unless woven for blankets. Nothing is thrown away. Everything, even the smallest clippings of material, have been saved."

The Principal of the Chapleau Residential School, in a letter dated February 22, states:

"I thought you might be interested to know that we have shipped from this school to date 700 cards of wool, reclaimed from old socks and wound after twisting two threads together."

Rev. Father Mackey, in his letter of February 16, referring to this work at the Shubenacadie School, states:

"I beg to inform you that we have made some progress with the wool from the army socks. When this work was begun, an army officer from the Salvage Depot came and looked over the work. He said it would be satisfactory for darning purposes. At that time we sent samples to Colonel Dailley at Ottawa. While waiting for a reply from him we went ahead and had 7,000 cards or skeins ready. Then the report from Ottawa came and said that it was not satisfactory—that two strands should be made into one. However, since the arrival of the spinning wheel we have sent two lots of 1,000 cards each to Halifax, one early in January and one early this month. We hope to send about the same amount every month from now on. We do not know, of course, how this compares with what the other residential schools are doing. We find that the bottle neck is putting the yarn..."
through the spinning wheel. The wheel can be going practically all day long. A number of girls will put all the yarn thus processed on cards in a very short time. If this salvage work is to be carried on effectively until the war is won, two more spinning wheels will be needed. This work has cut into our Red Cross work and I suppose it is just as important."

Father O'Grady, Principal of the Kamloops Residential School, who visited the Department two days ago, informed us that regular shipments of this reprocessed wool were being sent from his school to the Ordnance Depot in British Columbia.

It is interesting to note that while it was necessary to purchase a number of spinning wheels for this work, a few of the schools have succeeded in reconstructing old discarded sewing machines for this purpose.

You may remember that Sisters took charge of the Big River R. C. Day school at the opening of the present school year, October 1, 1942. This school had been from the date of its establishment in charge of a lay teacher, James A. Bonneau. Inspector Ferris, in his first report on this school since the Sisters took charge, dated November 27, states:

"The main feature of lessons observed was that every phase of instruction was made to serve the purpose of a lesson in oral language. In the lower grades especially, games and action songs were made to serve this purpose. In the more academic features of teaching the proportion of correct answers was higher and the responses more prompt than has been observed from any previous visit to this school. Now, it may be said that pupils furnish some evidence of achievement.

"There is no question that the present arrangement providing for a division of labour and responsibility has many advantageous features. The duties devolving upon the teacher of an Indian day school are too numerous and varied to be undertaken by one person unassisted. Under the able management of the Sisters in charge here, the pupils are not only provided with a wholesome noon lunch each day but they are learning, as well, many useful things in the field of domestic economy. The general tone of the classroom as well as the improved appearance of the children provides abundant evidence of the efficiency of the present management."

I might add that Sister Cecilia, who is in charge of this school, has a Saskatchewan First Class Professional Certificate and has had 11½ years' teaching experience.

A particularly good report has been received on the work accomplished in the senior room of the Onion Lake Residential School (R. C.). Inspector Bowes, in his report dated October 21, 1942, states:

"This classroom is a credit to the institution; the tone of the whole school is excellent. The classes are bright and intelligent. The written work is good and mathematics well above average. Reading is fluent and
expressive. Spelling is well taught and the results very good. The pupils take a delight in telling stories. Language and pronunciation are excellent for the time spent by these children in school. Sister Celine du Carmel is a very efficient teacher and organizer. In fact remarkable results are being secured at this school."

I have referred so frequently to the somewhat dilapidated condition of a number of our residential schools, particularly the older buildings, that I hesitate to discuss the matter again. Reports constantly reaching the Department, however, indicate that substantial repairs are needed at a number of our schools and that equipment in the case of many schools is in a worn out condition. I refer to the matter now, in the hope that when surplus equipment is available, immediately following the close of the war, the needs of our residential schools will not be overlooked. Indian Agent Gooderham, who is usually very conservative in estimating the needs of the schools in his agency, in his report on the Crowfoot (R.C.) School dated February 9, states:

"A good inspection was made of the Crowfoot School. The children were well and happy. The class work was well handled with three teachers in charge. The midday meal, too, was exceptionally good. The staff, however, work under certain difficulties. The laundry at this institution is very poor and there is no ironer. The washing machines and extractor are 30 years old and next to impossible to operate. It is hoped that this school can be supplied with an ironer and an extractor, even if the machines purchased are second hand. A new hog-house is urgently needed. During the cold weather litters of young pigs were lost, despite the endeavours made by the staff to save them."

WELFARE:

Last year, a circular dated April 7, 1842, was sent out with the hope of encouraging gardening on Indian reserves. The response to this appeal was on the whole reasonably satisfactory. Copies of this circular were sent to representatives of the churches. These representatives communicated with the missionaries on the reserves, with the result that we had the active cooperation of these missionaries in the organization and promotion of gardening projects. An earnest appeal was made by the churches to the Indians to take an interest in their gardens during the growing season.

This year, a somewhat similar letter was prepared and sent forward to all our field officers. We enclosed with this circular a vitamin chart, in the hope that it would stimulate interest in the production of vegetables from a health standpoint. The response to this circular, although sent forward only a few days ago, has been very encouraging. Indian Agent Lariviere has already requested 100 additional copies of the chart. Inspector Hamilton, in a letter dated February 22, states:-
"Please forward one dozen copies of the chart 'Vitamins' which accompanied your letter from Dr. McGill dated February 15. We would like to have some of these on hand to distribute amongst the Indian women's war service clubs in Manitoba."

Dr. Chas A. MacLean, New Richmond, Que., in acknowledgment of the circular letter and chart, states:

"I wish to thank you for the vitamin chart I recently received from you. It is the most concrete and practical chart of this sort of information I have ever seen.

"The nutritional condition of the Indians of Maria, P.C., is now at a higher level than at any time since I have had anything to do with them. In a great measure this can be explained by the fact that most of the families have men in the Armed Forces on account of whom the families receive an allowance. This provides more than enough money for the expenses of living. The wisdom with which some of this money is spent is faulty, but on the whole their buying power is greater and they have more food to eat. ....... The soil on the reserve seems to be a poor sort and such as it is, is impoverished. There would be sufficient pasture for the summer months for some cows but they could not raise enough winter feed for them."

A very wide distribution of this letter and chart has been made. It has already been sent out to inspectors, Indian agents, medical health officers, farming instructors, nurses, and to the principals of Indian day and residential schools. Copies have been sent also to representatives of the churches for their information. The only unfavourable reaction to this letter and chart has come from Mr. Christianson. Mr. Christianson, with a great many years of service in the Department, seems to resent very bitterly any advice or direction from this Branch. His letter of protest, dated February 20, reads in part as follows:

"As far as I know at the present time, there are no able-bodied Indians on the ration list in Saskatchewan. The old people who are on the ration list are being cut down to the bone as it is, without having someone use the same old threat over and over again, that is that they will not be able to provide any sustenance for the Indians. These old people are not in a position or able to raise pork or poultry. Why do these officials keep harping on the same threat? I feel that when our Indian agents receive a statement of this nature they are placed in a rather peculiar position. After all, they see the conditions of the Indians and know that they are only getting a very meagre allowance. At the same time they are anxious to satisfy our Branch and they really do not know what to do."

The promotion of a gardening or any other worthwhile program among Indians at any time is an exceedingly difficult and exacting task, even with the active and loyal cooperation of the field staff. When this cooperation is lacking, the task simply becomes an impossible one. The agricultural resources of the Indians in Saskatchewan are greater than the resources of the Indians in any other province, and yet the progress we appear to be making in
recent years is far from satisfactory.

The following excerpts, taken from two letters recently received, I pass on without comment. Mr. Christianson, in a letter dated January 30, states:

"A few days ago Mr. T. B. Prince, Acting Agent at Carlton Agency, called me on the telephone and advised me he had received a letter from the Chief and Council of the James Roberts Band in Treaty No. 10, asking that the goats they were to receive this spring be cancelled because the Sucker River Indians informed them that the goats had not been of much help to them. Mr. Prince also stated he had received a letter from Mr. Moses Ratt, Councillor at Sucker River, objecting to keeping the goats they have there. I informed Mr. Prince that if these Indians did not want them there was no use sending them there. I also instructed him to see that the goats they have there were looked after, and you will note by Mr. Prince's letter that he has written to Moses Ratt, asking him to look after the animals personally and do his utmost to save the ones remaining."

The other excerpt is taken from a letter addressed to you from the teacher of the Spanish River Anglican Day School, Massey, Ont. The teacher in this letter states:

"Apropos the circular received today from the Indian Agent, which says 'the use of dairy products should be stressed; the Department will assist in establishing herds of goats' (circular #1254) may I respectfully state my case.

"Realizing that the people, especially the children in this locality, are milk-starved, I had done what little I could to remedy the lack. Out of my own funds I began serving a portion of hot milky cocoa to the children in school during the lunch hour, shortly after my arrival here in January, 1941. When I could possibly afford to, I have given cans of milk to those who badly needed it. Of course, out of my salary as teacher I could not afford to do very much of this sort of thing.

"Then, last October, I acquired four female goats. Three are Loggenbergs and one a Saanen. I acquired these goats with two objects in view. First, I wanted to augment the diet of the school children and their families by distributing milk to them. Secondly, I planned to give the young kids as they came along as prizes for improvements in living conditions.

"As soon as the goats were brought here I had the interest of the people. On my plan becoming known, one man began to build an addition to his house in the form of a kitchen. Another put a new floor in his house. Another is planning to build a new house.

"My wife and I have modestly re-furnished the school apartment at our own expense and have shown the people here what can be done with a moderate outlay. We want them to copy us and doubtless they will."
Though this is an Anglican school and many of the Indians are Roman Catholics, no religious distinctions are drawn or will be.

My wife and I remain on the reserve during the summer. We are thus enabled to tend the goats ourselves all the year round and do our own gardening. In the former task the school children are very willing helpers, as they are very fond of the goats. In the second venture our gardening is of interest and an encouragement to the people.

Unfortunately, in my efforts with the goats I have hit two snags. First: the billy goat that I had lined up for breeding purposes was strangled only a few days before I was to borrow him. I have not been able, though I have made numerous enquiries, to locate another. This is unfortunate as two of the goats should be bred before the end of March of this year. The other two should be bred next November or December, thus giving a constant milk flow. Second: One of the Indians, on promise of a kid to raise at home, helped me erect a log shelter for the goats. This proved to be too small and far too cold. I therefore, am having to board the goats out during the severe weather, at my own expense.

For advice on raising goats I wrote to the Departments of Agriculture, both Provincial and Federal. Along with pamphlets, Mr. L. E. O'Neill wrote from Toronto:

"I hope that your experiment with goats at your school will prove successful. Undoubtedly, your idea of having a better milk supply for the people particularly the children is a good one." From Ottawa, Mr. James A. Telfer sent pamphlets and in a letter said, "I wish to congratulate you on your initiative in regard to the establishment of a supply of wholesome and nutritious milk for the use of Indian children...... I trust that you will be very successful in your undertaking and that splendid results with regard to the feeding of the children may accrue."

It would indeed be a pity if the two snags mentioned above were to bring to naught previous efforts. I was therefore overjoyed to read the above quoted paragraph from your circular No. 1234.

Would the Department of Indian Affairs assist in procuring a billygoat for breeding purposes and the materials necessary to build a barn as described on page 12 of publication No. 634, Farmers' Bulletin No. 67 - Goat Husbandry in Canada? If the materials for building the barn are provided I would build the barn myself. I personally built a kitchen on to the school building, which is quite livable and comfortable. With a billygoat available I could build up a herd for the benefit of the people amongst whom I work.

Thanking you for any assistance you may render to enable me to continue to serve the Indians of this reserve, may I remain, respectfully yours - Charles G. Kehler."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McGUIRE,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended March 31, 1943.

WELFARE:

The response on the part of our Indian agents and representatives of the Churches to the circular letter on gardening, dated February 15, 1943, has been more than encouraging. Requests for additional copies of the Vitamin Chart, which accompanied the letter, have been received from Indian Agent Lariviere, Inspector Hamilton, Major D. M. MacKay and the Hudson's Bay Company.

Archbishop Sinnott, in his letter of acknowledgment, states:

"The ideas expressed in this letter are excellent. If we could only induce the Indians to cultivate subsistence gardens and grow vegetables, it would be a distinct advance. As you suggest, I shall ask the missionaries in my jurisdiction to talk on this subject some time during the early spring season".

I have referred on one or two occasions to the welfare program organized at Golden Lake by Mr. Morris. A notable feature of this program was the purchase of a goat herd. The progress of this herd has been fairly satisfactory, although three goats were lost this spring. The Agent, in a letter dated March 17, states:

"In my report submitted March 1, 1943, I stated that 13 goats had kidded and that we have now 18 kids. I am sorry to state that since that time we have lost three kids, due to diarrhoea. Seven of the kids took this disease. We immediately isolated them from the rest of the goats, reduced their feed and gave them medicine as per instructions in publication No. 634 (Goat Husbandry in Canada). Four of the goats got better but three died. We have them in with the rest of the kids now and they appear alright.

"We now have six female and nine male kids, two old billygoats, one young billy and sixteen female goats. I have inspected this herd frequently during the winter and spring. The Indians are milking them and are using the milk. The goats milked well after freshening but are not milking so well now. However, I believe that as soon as they get on the grass their production will come back again."

Reports reaching this Branch from time to time indicate that the Oak River and Oak Lake Community Farms have -
have been exceptionally successful. This success cannot be attributed wholly to the fertility of the soil or to favourable climatic conditions. I am disposed to think that the success is due to a large extent to careful management on the part of the Indian agent. Both these farms have now met their obligations to the Revolving Fund in full and both have at this date a substantial surplus. This surplus will enable them to continue this year's operations without assistance from the Department. The Indian Agent, in his report dated February 25, states:

"Our Oak River and Oak Lake Community Farms have been very successful during the past few years, particularly this past season. This year we grew 25,310 bushels of grain and 500 bushels of potatoes. We have been able to dispose of most of our barley, which graded malting, realizing 60 cents per bushel, net. We have also disposed of half our wheat and at present we are feeding crushed wheat and oats to 45 head of community farm cattle, two department bulls, 6 horses, and 50 head of Indian cattle which would otherwise starve if we didn't take them in and feed them. This gets rid of considerable grain.

"We plan to summer-fallow more land this year and grow more coarse grains and flax.

"I am not in favor of raising pigs here. My labourer runs the tractor part time and operates the threshing machine all fall. It would be necessary to hire Indian labour to feed and care for the pigs and as Indian labour is in such demand I doubt if we could depend on hiring one capable of this work. In fact, I am not sure that I will be able to engage Indian labour to operate the tractors on our community farms. Personally I feel that I have all that I can handle under the present set-up here. I also feel that we are doing our bit towards the war effort by feeding our 45 head of community farm cattle and fifty head of Indian cattle."

It is particularly gratifying to note that they are feeding 45 head of community farm cattle and 50 head of Indian cattle at these farms.

Relief expenditures for the period April 1, 1942, to February 28, 1943, amount to $544,170.94 compared with $565,872.99 for the corresponding period of last year. These figures indicate a net decrease of $19,702.05. Reductions during this period have taken place in all the provinces with the exception of Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Manitoba. The increases in Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island can be easily explained by the purchase of machinery, lumber for housing construction, etc. It is somewhat difficult, however, to explain fully the increase in Manitoba. Relief costs in Manitoba for the period under review amount to $79,211.37, compared with an expenditure of $59,083.37 in the province of British Columbia, where the Indian population is almost double that of the population in Manitoba. An itemized statement of welfare expenditures in Manitoba indicates that the higher expenditures take place amongst hunting and trapping Indians. There has been, for example, an increase of almost $5,000 in the Norway House Agency and over $1,000 in The Pas Agency.
TRAINING:

A great deal of enthusiasm is being displayed by the pupils of a number of our Indian residential schools in the processing of yarn for the Armed Forces. The following excerpt is taken from a recent issue of the Edmonton bulletin:

"Indian children of the Ermineskin Residential School at Hobbema are doing their part to help in Canada's war effort.

"In army camps throughout the province, soldiers are darning their socks with wool prepared by the Indian children from condemned socks which were discarded by the troops and returned to the salvage depot of the Royal Canadian Ordnance Corps at Calgary.

"When the 'condemned' socks - that is socks no longer fit for use by the troops - are received at the salvage depot from various units, they are packed and shipped to the Indian school at Hobbema of which Father P. Pheaume, O.M.I., is principal.

"The young Indians wash and disinfect the socks, then unravel the uppers and card the wool in skeins for darning purposes.

"The skeins of wool are then returned to Ordnance and distributed to the various Army units.

"The plan of having the students at Indian schools perform this worthwhile work is being carried on across the Dominion".

A number of reports received recently from public school inspectors and from one or two of our own inspectors deal with conditions that are far from satisfactory at a number of our Indian residential schools. With a substantial increase in the cost of living in recent years, coupled with the difficulty experienced by the church authorities in securing certain supplies such as woollen garments, etc., it is perhaps too much to expect satisfactory reports from these institutions. Conditions at one or two of the schools have a tendency to contribute to truancy. Inspector Coleman, who made a special inspection of the Alberni School, to determine the cause of truancy, in his report dated March 4, states:

"When I visited the school I attended at the noon meal in the children's dining room and observed that the food was served up on the tables 15 minutes before the entrance of the children. It consisted of boiled fish, potatoes, a piece of cake and water to drink for beverage. This did not appear to be a very interesting meal, as it did not appear to contain the necessary elements for maintaining the health of the children, although it might have some fattening value; I asked to see the menu for the week in order to ascertain the food balance for the day. I was informed by the Principal that he did not have one, the planning being left to the woman in charge of the kitchen. It was evident that the Principal was not conversant with the meals served, as would be expected. I would point out..."
that, under existing circumstances, great care has to be taken with such diets, due to shortage of certain foods, and that the absence of planning is liable to lead to serious results, so far as the health of the children is concerned."

Major MacKay, in sending forward Inspector McArthur's report on the St. George's School, Lytton, B.C., states:

"Lack of properly qualified teachers is no doubt the fundamental cause of the low standard in the academic work at St. George's. It will be noted that Inspector McArthur found the teaching in three of the four divisions unsatisfactory and in one of the four divisions, wholly worthless. This, to say the least, is a disturbing state of affairs, but when one examines the qualifications of the present teaching staff, it is what might well be expected. It is evident that there has been a gradual deterioration in the academic work at St. George's since the resignation of Mr. Norman Stewart, which occurred shortly after Mr. Hives took over. It will be recalled that Inspector Barry reported quite favourably on this school in September, 1941. The four teachers on the staff at that time were fully qualified and all but one had considerable teaching experience.

"The question of salary has probably contributed to the difficulty of getting certificated teachers but in my opinion not to the extent suggested by Mr. McArthur. There has been, and continues to be, a scarcity of teachers, but apart from this and the question of salary, I am afraid that there continues to be a tendency on the part of some of our principals to feel that qualified teachers are not essential for work in Indian schools."

Inspector McArthur himself, in commenting upon the work of the teachers at this school, states:

"I found it impossible to rate three of the teachers on some of the points listed, largely because they are not teachers at all in the ordinary sense of the word. For instance, they do not know what preparation entails, despite the fact that they are conscientious. At the present time this condition is not by any means confined to Indian schools."

A disturbing report on the prevalence of tuberculosis amongst the Indian pupils enrolled at the Morley (United Church) Residential School has been sent forward by Inspector Schmidt. In this report Dr. Baker, of the Central Alberta Sanatorium, states:

"Nine pupils have become positive reactors to the tuberculin test since November, 1941."

Dr. Baker in his report continues:

"I wish to point out that these children were not only X-rayed but given a physical examination by a member of our staff on March 9. There seems to have been a most unfortunate serious outbreak of tuberculosis in connection with this school and hospital, and I think your..."
Department should take steps to have another survey made before long.

This is a matter that comes directly under the supervision of the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services. I feel it my duty and responsibility, however, to state that in my humble judgment there is a vital and direct relationship between such outbreaks and the grants made by this Department for the upkeep and maintenance of our residential schools. I am convinced that with the limited funds at our disposal we should again seriously consider the abandonment of a number of our insanitary dilapidated residential schools. This would enable us without increasing our appropriation to increase the grants to a number of schools that appear to be unable to function effectively under the existing financial arrangements.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCILL

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended April 30, 1943.

WELFARE:

In response to an invitation received from Mr. Arnell, I attended a conference of Indian agents organized by him and held at the King Edward Hotel, Toronto, on April 2 and 3.

This was in my judgment one of the best conferences of its kind that I have attended at any time. The speeches delivered were brief and informative, the discussions relevant and well directed and the proceedings during the entire two day period of more than ordinary inspirational value. I am convinced that serious consideration should be given to the desirability of holding such conferences annually or semi-annually. Two of the speeches delivered appeared to me to be outstanding. One was delivered by Mr. Rush, of the Ontario Department of Agriculture Extension Branch. Mr. Rush is a vegetable grower on a large scale and he devotes a limited part of his time to the delivery of lectures for the Department of Agriculture. He has been engaged in the production of vegetables for half a century or more and informed us that last winter he shipped out 80,000 head of cabbage without losing a single head. Mr. Rush discussed up-to-date methods of soil cultivation, the selection of vegetable seeds, planting seed eradication, spraying as a means of insect control, the dehydration of vegetables, the construction of root-houses, the storage of vegetables generally, the effect of war on vegetable imports and in fact almost everything related to practical gardening. The discussion of Mr. Rush's address extended far into the night. The second address was delivered by Dr. Moore. It is exceedingly difficult to sum up in a sentence or two the impression created on the minds of the agents by Dr. Moore's illustrated lecture. Despite the fact that a great many of the terms used by Dr. Moore were technical, the lecture as a whole was followed very closely. The fact that the subject matter of the lecture and particularly the relationship between production of vegetables and health was discussed in the rooms by the Indian agents until the early hours of the morning is a striking tribute to the lecture itself and to its effectiveness in stimulating interest in the matters discussed. The delivery of this lecture at Toronto and at points in the West, Dr. Moore has already resulted in a number of requests for departmental assistance. These requests consist of additional demands for vegetable seeds, requests
for pigs, milch cows, poultry, goats and farm equipment. Should these requests continue—and I am disposed to think they will—it is altogether likely that this conference, if I may refer to it as such, may result in an additional expenditure of welfare funds that may exceed $100,000 for the present fiscal year. This money, however, will be well spent if it contributes to the health and physical wellbeing of the Indian population and should ultimately have the effect of substantially reducing hospital costs.

Another interesting result of the conference at Toronto is supplied in the number of requests for Dutch willow slips. Mr. Down of Munsey delivered a brief address at the conference on the cultivation of willow at his agency. His remarks seem to supply the answer to a number of questions that have recently been reaching the Department in respect to an adequate supply of raw material for basket making at reserves such as St. Regis, Pierreville, Maria, and Prince Edward Island. These willows not only make a substantial basket, and one which is likely to be much more durable than the Black ash baskets, but are admirably suitable for the construction of wicker furniture. You will be interested to learn that arrangements have already been made for willow plots at St. Regis and the other reserves where Indians are engaged in basket-making already referred to.

Indian Agent Down, in commenting upon the agents' conference, in a letter dated April 10, states:

"I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the opportunity given of meeting with the senior departmental officials and officials of the field staff in a round-table conference. I left the conference with a spirit of complete satisfaction and the knowledge that our problems are not insurmountable. Much credit is due to the departmental officials for the close, friendly co-operation. A great measure of credit is due also to Inspector Arnsil for his untiring efforts to make the conference the success it was."

Letters, indicating a wide-spread interest in our gardening program of this year, continue to reach this Division. The minutes of the meeting of the Enoch Band (Edmonton Agency) held March 8, read in part as follows:

"Agent Laight then spoke on Indian gardens. He told Council that it was the wish of the Department that every Indian on the reserve should have a garden. He explained that by growing enough vegetables the Indians would have a large part of their food. He also explained that it would not be enough just to grow vegetables for summer use but that every Indian should be expected to grow enough for both summer and winter use. Agent Laight informed Council that there was now a good root-house at this agency, where the Indians could store their vegetables for winter use, and that he expected to see the root-house filled with potatoes and vegetables this fall. The Chief and Councillors agreed to give Farming Instructor Boorse all the assistance they could in having good gardens cultivated on the reserve this year."

An illustration of initiative on the part of an agent, coupled with real co-operation between him and
the officials of the Provincial Department of Natural Resources, is supplied in a report from Indian Agent Pugh, Saddle Lake, dated March 31. In this report the agent states:

"I was successful in obtaining a crate of fish eggs from the Alberta Provincial Fish Hatchery at Canyon Creek, through the good offices of Fish Inspector M. Heron, of Lac la Biche, Alberta. In company with Farming Instructor Carrie, we put these into Saddle Lake, approximately 2 million whitefish eggs - on March 18. The co-operation of the Indians was excellent and they seemed to appreciate this action".

We have been constantly emphasizing in our correspondence of late the desirability of having Indians who are now employed at high wages spend at least part of their earnings on the improvement and reconstruction of their homes. The response, while not as satisfactory as one might expect, in a few agencies at least, is rather encouraging. Indian Agent Ashbridge, of the West Coast Agency, in his last report, states:

"New houses have been built on Sheeshatht, Opitsat, Hesquiat, Mooshaht, Chlet and Ucluelet Reserves. All these houses are of more modern design than the ones formerly built by Indians on the Coast and all have been built without departmental assistance".

Letters received from hunting and trapping Indians are usually somewhat discouraging. Relief costs remain high in these regions. In view of this fact, the news contained in a personal letter received a few days ago from Mr. J.A.C. Watt, Rupert's House, by Mr. R. Conn, is exceptionally gratifying. Mr. Watt states:

"The beavers are rolling in and more mink than we have ever had here. Indians have very little in the way of debts and over $4,000 in credit balances. Rats are a better price than last year and if they get some they should be well away. The Indians have contributed almost $200.00 to Red Cross work this year. The relief account is confined to old widows."

TRAINING

For the second year in succession, a special grant, amounting to $10.00 per pupil, was sent out early in the month to our residential schools. Audit reports recently received indicate that in a large number of cases this grant was urgently needed. Mr. W. R. Butchart in his audit statement on the Alberni Residential School (U.C.) dated March 29, 1942, states:

"The total revenue for the 24 months was $75,270.40, and includes per capita grants received from the Department through the Board of Home Missions, Toronto, amounting to $67,903.50. The grants for manual training for the period totalled $2,087.32, and other grants from Ottawa amounted to $287.56. Farm revenue from the sale..."
of live stock amounted to $1,118.11, while sale of candy and sundry refunds totalled $1,276.51.

"The expenditures amounted to $76,436.79 and are $3,766.39 in excess of the revenue for the period. As a whole, the expenditures compare very favourably with other schools of comparable size in the province. The salaries are about equal to those at St. George's School, Lytton, the only other large Protestant school in British Columbia. Power and fuel costs at $6,686.78 are somewhat higher than at other schools. Transportation costs for pupils at $4,556.42 are also high, and will probably continue as more pupils are drawn from such distant and scattered small areas. Included under 'Miscellaneous' are bank charges of $126.80, interest on overdraft.

"The Principal has had much difficulty in attempting to keep his expenditures within the income. The church authorities have guaranteed an overdraft of $2,000.00 but the Bank has asked that this guarantee be increased to $4,000.00. Besides the deficit of $4,354.95, the liabilities at the end of February included merchants' accounts of about $1,500.00 (including February accounts of about $1,000.) and the February salaries of about $1,100.00."

You may remember that immediately following the resignation of Inspector Barry we entered into an agreement with the Provincial Department of Education in British Columbia, whereby our schools are being inspected, this year, by the public school inspectors. The reports of these inspectors on the Indian schools visited to date have been somewhat critical. Their criticisms have been directed particularly against the employment of teachers lacking professional qualifications. The report of Inspector H. H. MacKenzie, dated March 31, on the St. Mary's Mission Residential School, and the report of A. F. Matthews on the Kamloops Residential School appear to be the most satisfactory yet received. The Inspector in his report on the St. Mary's School states:

"The classrooms at this school are large, well lighted and comfortable.

"Children spend half of each day in classroom work in the academic subject-fields taught, and the remainder of the school day is occupied by the boys in technical work or out-of-door activities, and by the girls in home economic activities, including sewing, cooking, laundry, etc. The boys have the benefit of a manual training instructor for three half days weekly.

"These Indian children display unmistakable evidence of being exceptionally well cared for. They are well fed and well and suitably clothed - the girls being taught to make practically all their own clothing. Dormitories and dining rooms are commodious, bright, sanitary and well kept.

"The work of teaching in all classrooms would be facilitated by furnishing a supply of supplementary reading and source material for the different grades enrolled."
"There is a very fine tone displayed throughout the school. Pupils are genuinely happy and seem to appreciate the kindly care and attention accorded them. The staff of teachers display unfailing interest in and enthusiasm for their work and are rendering a very fine teaching service.

"To Reverend Father Superior Fleury, principal of the school, however, whose optimism, energy, broad-mindedness and kindly and charming personality pervade the whole atmosphere of this institution, must go the credit for the truly sound and practical training given to these Indian children."

Inspector A. F. Matthews, in his report on the Kamloops Residential School, dated March 30, 1945, states:

"A good deal of attention is given to the matter of the vocational training of the pupils. The school day is divided into two main periods. In the case of the boys, one of these periods is spent in practical work on the farm, and the other in classroom instruction. When the new manual arts building is completed, the vocational training will be extended. At present there is not much integration, if any, of this work with the actual instruction in the classes. It appears to me that the classroom instruction in certain subjects, and particularly in Science, should be correlated in a large measure with the agricultural and mechanical art work carried on by the pupils.

"The girls appear to be getting a good practical training in domestic science and kindred subjects. Training in the domestic arts, such as cooking, fruit preserving, needlework, spinning, etc., is stressed. The pupils make their own uniforms and dresses and appear to be proficient in knitting, mending and fancy needlework. They are well supplied with equipment for carrying on these various activities and this material is well utilized.

"The school in general appears to be well conducted. Its condition reflects much credit on the business management and organizing ability of Father O'Conry. As principal of the school he keeps in close touch with all its various activities and is active and progressive in his work of administration and in his efforts towards providing a worthwhile training for the pupils. All records covering the school life of each pupil and the general business administration of the school plant are kept on file in the principal's office.

"The auditorium is a large building with a well equipped stage and a large central floor for games and general recreational purposes. It is equipped, also, with a moving picture machine. During my visit to the school the pupils staged an evening entertainment consisting of instrumental selections from the school band, vocal numbers by the girls and an exhibition of physical exercises by the boys. The colourful and becoming uniforms worn by the girls and boys were made by the pupils. The various items on the program were well rendered and..."
thoroughly enjoyed by the audience as well as by the performers themselves. The program presented by the pupils reflects much credit on the teaching and organizing ability of the teachers who trained them for this performance."

The following excerpt has been taken from the quarterly return sent in by Mr. Joseph M. Barre, teacher of the Pemberton Indian Day School, B. C.:

"School activities organized in the past have been continued with renewed vigor. The Junior Red Cross is active and sponsors the salvage drive. Radish, pumpkin and other seeds were harvested from the school garden. The visual course in Tuberculosis Education has been successfully covered in this quarter.

"A film slide of Indian basket weaving and commentary was made by this teacher for the Extension Department of the University of B. C."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended May 31, 1943.

WELFARE:

Despite the fact that a number of weeks have passed since the visit of the Nova Scotia agents to Ottawa and the meetings of agents in Toronto, the Prairie Provinces and British Columbia, references to these meetings appear in agency reports and in general correspondence, almost daily. Indian Agent Rice, in his last monthly report on the Shubenacadie Agency, states:

"To have been to Ottawa for a week, in close contact with the officers of the Branch, was a much appreciated revelation. Names that were once identified only by signatures and titles have now become personalities with their own backgrounds. With these impressions comes a more vivid realization and understanding of the tremendous amount of work which these officials continually accomplish in their respective fields. Our labours here, on these individual reserves, are dwarfed by comparison. With the proper perspective comes a keen appreciation and a whole-hearted respect for the men with whom we work. To have been to Ottawa meeting our officers and to have been welcomed so cordially and treated so royally while there will always be greatly appreciated. I want to sincerely thank each and every one who in any way contributed to the success and enjoyment of the conference."

Indian Agent Howe - Stuart Lake Agency - in his last report states:

"During my visit to Vancouver to interview Stephen Poole (accused of the murder of his wife) I was extremely fortunate to attend a very interesting and enlightening lecture on Nutrition, delivered by Dr. P. E. Moore, Acting Superintendent of Medical Services. May I respectfully suggest that at some future date similar lectures, accompanied by slides, be shown in this agency, where the Indians can attend, and particularly at the Lejac Indian Residential School."

Agents in their monthly reports indicate that this spring has been the most backward experienced by them at any time in recent years. Indian Agent Gooderham, in his report dated May 12, on the Blackfoot Agency, states:

"Very little spring work has been done on the farms. Some cultivating was started, but the weed crop
was so slow that this was held up. Seed grain has been distributed, cleaned and treated, and machinery has been put in pretty good shape to rush in the crop. It is now the 15th of May and there is not 10% of the crop seeded. This is the latest season in our experience and it is hoped that nothing will hold up the spring work longer and that there will be a good rapid growing season.

The backwardness of the spring is likely to result in a substantial increased oat and barley acreage and a corresponding reduction in the wheat acreage. In view of the existing wheat surplus, however, this may result in better balanced agricultural operations and lead to greater dependence on mixed farming and stock raising.

The response on the part of agents and school principals to our circular letter on gardening continues to be encouraging. Indian Agent Ostrander, in his report on the Battleford Agency, dated May 5, states:

"The special effort put forward towards gardening, hog-raising, the production of milk, eggs and poultry is already bearing fruit. Many Indians have been able to buy a few chickens and have already made arrangements to increase their gardening efforts for the year. With authority from the Department, 30 breeding sows have been purchased and there were also a few sows purchased by Indians with their own funds. I think that in all there will be about 50 litters of young pigs this spring, which should make a substantial difference to the pork production of the country as well as a considerable revenue to the Indians. There is a large quantity of feed grain available on the reserves where these sows are located and little doubt exists that the effort will prove successful."

Indian Agent Daunt, in his report on the New Westminster Agency, dated May 1, states:

"On April 20 we attended a very interesting lecture on Nutrition by Dr. P. E. Moore, Acting Superintendent of Medical Services. The Reverend Principal of St. Mary's Indian Residential School and two Sisters were also present from this agency. As the lecture was to be repeated at the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital, Sardis, we instructed the members of the local Indian women's club to attend."

The work undertaken and accomplished from time to time by the Society for the Furtherance of B. C. Indian Arts and Crafts continues to receive widespread publicity in the province. The Victoria Times of May 2, in an article entitled "Indian Art Exhibit" states:

"At 3:30 p.m. Monday, May 17, in the Provincial Museum, Mrs. Walter C. Michol will open the exhibition of the work of B. C. Indian children, which has been arranged by Dr. C. Carl, with the assistance of A. E. Pickford. The exhibition is being sponsored by the Society for the Furtherance of B. C. Indian Arts and Crafts, which was founded by Miss Alice Ravenhill and of which Major L. Bullock-Webster is now president. This society was responsible for bringing to the notice of the general public the paintings of Francis Baptiste of the Inkameep Reserve and..."
entertained the Indian children brought here by the community drama branch of the Provincial Department of Education for the opening of Thunderbird Park."

Dr. J. Melling, of the Athabasca Agency, in his last report, refers to the decision of the Department to supply Vitamin B flour to Indian agencies. Dr. Melling states:

"I am pleased to see that Vitamin B fortified flour is to be ordered for Indian use. I have seen what would appear to be signs and symptoms of thiamin deficiency in both Eskimo and Indians during the past four years. It would be interesting to run a series of blood levels for this substance in our local Indian population. It would be interesting also to compare the population of one of our primitive bands - solely meat eaters - with one of our more advanced bands whose diet is generally more varied and which is particularly high in flour and potato carbohydrates... I have noted particularly with the Eskimo that those individuals that took their food in the characteristic fashion - uncooked - were a healthier lot from the point of view of the B complex deficiencies.

The introduction of fortified flour would seem to be very commendable, providing a blanket order were issued to all traders dealing in this commodity. I recall that while I was at Chesterfield Inlet the Hudson's Bay Company, in co-operation with the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch, introduced a variety of whole wheat flour. The opposition trader at that point was stocked with the standard white flour. The stores of the latter trader were soon consumed as against a marked drop in the flour sales of the Hudson's Bay Company. Eventually the natives resorted to using pieces of silk or satin to sift the flour element from the Company flour so that the resulting bannock would be white. It is not easy to introduce new ideas to our native population especially if those ideas involve some alteration in the dietary habits."

TRAINING.

You may remember that Miss E. Smith-Windsor, teacher at the Fisher River Indian Day School, was employed for a month of the holiday period of last year in the organization of homemakers clubs on a number of reserves in Manitoba, and permission has already been granted Inspector Hamilton to employ her for a similar period in organization work this year. It is gratifying to note that this teacher has been outstandingly successful in the organization of women's clubs on her own reserve. Inspector Hamilton, in a letter dated May 21, states:

"Miss Smith-Windsor, teacher on the Fisher River Reserve, reports the result of a Red Cross drive at that point. The W. A. and Women's Clubs held a joint sale of goods which netted a total sum of $260.00. This was certainly a worthwhile effort and the women of the different organizations are deserving of hearty congratulations. Perhaps you might see fit to write Miss Smith-Windsor, Koostatak, Man., a letter of appreciation."

A letter expressing appreciation has already been sent forward to this teacher.
It would appear that steady progress is being made in the organization and extension of vocational courses in the province of Alberta. You may remember that Mr. Doucet visited the schools of this province about two years ago. Indian Agent Iredale, in a report on the Morley (U.C.) Residential School dated May 14, states:

"I would like to mention that excellent progress has been made at the school in the manual training classes. The older boys are showing wonderful response in the making of various articles (household things) such as medicine cabinets, etc., but what struck me most were the kitchen cabinets, of which there were seven, all completed, with the exception of three which still need the small handles and the glass in the doors.

"They are all the same size and style, measuring 42 inches by 24 inches by 68 inches high in the lower part. There are two cupboards and two drawers and above the table top there is another cupboard with glass doors opening in the middle, with hooks for hanging cups and small basins inside near the back to set plates on their edges. These cabinets are very well made and are attractively painted in various colours. I would estimate them to be worth at least $25.00 each.

"The boys are very proud of their work and they will be allowed to take them home at the end of the school year. In my opinion this line of training should be encouraged. I would suggest that further materials should be furnished for next year's manual training, but I think they should get their supplies during the summer vacation, in order that they can commence immediately in the new school year and also in time to allow the lumber to become properly dried out (most of the lumber purchased now-a-days is very green).

"I cannot say that the progress in the classroom is anything wonderful. The majority of the children are just mediocre, but there seem to be a few bright pupils.

"The sewing classes are doing very good work, repairing clothes and making over old clothes into various useful garments. This is very good training. There is also a beadwork class one afternoon each week, when the girls are shown how to make leather goods, gloves, mitts, moccasins and the like, with bead trimmings. Some of the work is very good, both in design and workmanship."

A number of schools have been particularly successful in reclaiming wool from discarded military socks. The Sisters in charge of the Pierreville Indian Day School are in receipt of the following letter from Major L. A. LaCroix:

"Reverend Sisters: - This will acknowledge with thanks receipt of 14 pairs of socks together with 540 cards of darning wool made from condemned socks.

"This office would particularly like to emphasize the high standard of work performed by your pupils in making new socks from condemned socks. Several pairs..."
of these socks are being forwarded to the Army Salvage and Disposal Board for their information.

Yours truly - L. A. LeCroix, Major,
D. O. O., MD. No. 5.*

Mrs. Winifred E. Faison, teacher of the Boothroyd Indian Day School, Lytton Agency, British Columbia, in a letter dated March 31, states:

"The pupils of this school are all members of the B.C. Junior Red Cross and complete their health charts each morning. They have sent parcels of knitted goods to the Red Cross for bombed out children overseas and have also sent donations to the Prisoner of War fund.

With reference to a circular recently sent out by the Department on Nature Study, I would like to state that my pupils, like myself, are great nature lovers. We keep a daily record of everything we observe - the arrival of birds and their migration, arrival of insects, flowers of every season, etc. We make good use of 'Canadian Nature' and 'Forest and Outdoor' magazines."

Two fully qualified teachers are regularly employed at the Coqualeetza Hospital. The salaries of these teachers are paid from the Indian Education Appropriation. In the employment of these teachers we are following a practice that has become general at the larger sanatoria throughout the country. Mr. H. H. MacKenzie, public school inspector, in his first report on the work of these teachers, dated April 1, states:

"All children are inmates of the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital and receive their instruction in their hospital cots, either in the preventorium or in the regular wards of the hospital. Thus there can be no classroom activities in the usual sense of that term. In the preventorium, pupils receive instruction two hours daily for five days per week. In hospital wards A and B (younger children) daily instruction continues for approximately one hour; in ward C, one hour on alternate days and in wards D and E, for one and one-half hours daily.

A really noble experiment is being attempted here, and I am persuaded that a very fine service is being rendered to these invalid Indian children. As must be obvious, the work is beset with many real difficulties but admirable patience, genuine sympathy and understanding and indefatigable energy in, and enthusiasm for, their work on the part of both teachers engaged in this service are assurances of sound and successful work being accomplished."

Miss Bertha Blue, teacher at the Songhees Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, B.C., in a report to the Indian Agent dated May 9, states that a Homemakers' Club has been organized recently on the reserve. She writes as follows:

"At present some of the members are knitting for our Armed Forces while others are sewing articles for the needy in Russia. Another item stressed at some of the first meetings was the necessity of planting gardens. The
majority of the members have already done so. For our next meeting we have been fortunate in procuring a guest speaker. The subject of her lecture will be 'Proper Nutrition and Good Health'. This, I feel sure, will prove not only interesting but enlightening to our members."

Indian Agent R. H. Moore, Duncan, B.C., in commenting upon the work of this teacher, states:

"I might say in this regard that Miss Blue has already shown her ability as an organizer among the women of the reserve in many ways. There is quite an active Junior Red Cross Unit at this school."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended June 30, 1943.

WELFARE:

I am now in receipt of the final financial statement showing welfare and relief expenditures, by provinces, for the fiscal year 1942-43. This statement indicates a net decrease in expenditures amounting to $59,379.25 when compared with expenditures for the preceding fiscal year. Decreases appear to have taken place in all the provinces with the exception of Prince Edward Island, which shows a net increase amounting to $443.08, and British Columbia, with an increase of $1,619.76.

A particularly gratifying feature of this statement is the net decrease in relief expenditures in the province of Nova Scotia and in New Brunswick. The decrease in Nova Scotia amounts to $15,020.25. This net reduction in expenditure has taken place despite unusual expenditures made for the purchase of trucks, sawmills and a limited acreage of land at the Shubenacadie and Eskasoni Reserves. The salary of Mr. Robb, Construction Foreman, and the wages of a group of men engaged in the construction of Indian homes has also been charged to the Welfare Appropriation.

Relief expenditures remain high in the northern Agencies - Seven Islands, Abitibi, James Bay, Sioux Lookout, Clandecope, Torrey House, The Pas, Battleford, Athabasca, and Lesser Slave Lake. The smallest decrease - $386.37 - appears to have taken place in the province of Manitoba, and the greatest, apart from Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, already referred to - $19,282.22 - in the province of Saskatchewan.

The reduction in expenditures appears on the whole reasonably satisfactory. Certain lands were purchased from the welfare appropriation during the last fiscal year in Nova Scotia and Bear Island, Ontario. These expenditures would ordinarily be charged to the Reserves and Trusts Division and are scarcely a legitimate charge on welfare funds. However, no provision has been made in recent years for the purchase of lands in the Reserves and Trusts appropriation.

The following excerpt, taken from the annual report of the Secretary of the Interior of the United States, is interesting, in view of the decision of this Department, in 1941, to purchase additional lands and centralise the Indian population of Nova Scotia on the Shubenacadie and Eskasoni Reserves:

"Essentially the Indians are a rural people and services in their behalf have had to be aimed at their economic rehabilitation, largely through various forms of agriculture, forestry, livestock and other uses of natural resources. Studies conducted during the past four years..."
of graduates of Indian schools show unmistakably that the majority of Indian young people, upon completion of their schooling, either remained at home permanently or returned there within a short time after graduation. Even the young people who had been trained in vocational and industrial pursuits as a rule did not pursue their trades, but found their way back to their home communities. The depression and the continuing unemployment in skilled trades and other forms of wage work made it extremely difficult for young Indians to secure employment in cities. Hence, it became the policy of the Indian Service to make available to Indians every possible opportunity to secure a livelihood through the use of reservation resources.

"This policy found expression in a program characterized by land acquisition and consolidation; extension of credit facilities; conservation of soil and moisture; education of Indian youth in the intelligent use and conservation of their resources, and by other activities designed to conserve, enlarge and properly to use the natural resources of the Indians.

"These efforts toward economic adjustment of the Indians on the land and the conservation of their resources are now being supplemented with programs to aid the Indians in taking their part in the defense program."

I have referred on more than one occasion in these reports to the urgent need of repairs at certain Indian day and residential schools. In recent weeks I have had an opportunity to review reports dealing with the condition of agency offices, the houses of Indian agents and agency buildings in general. These reports have convinced me that the funds available for the repair and upkeep of these buildings during the last 10 or 15 years have been wholly inadequate, to keep the buildings in good condition. Mr. Christianson, in a lengthy report on the Touchwood Agency, dated June 10, 1943, under the heading "Government Buildings", states:

"As you are aware, no exterior painting has been done at this agency for years. The sidings on the buildings are becoming loose and need repainting. The furnaces are giving out and a great deal of expenditure will have to be made to put the buildings in shape. The furnace at the agency office is burnt out; the furnace at the agency house is burnt out and the furnace at the farming instructor's house and fishing lake is burnt out. Therefore, you will see it will take a lot of money to put things in shape. On the outside the buildings appear to be alright but they are in poor shape when examined from close range."

It has occurred to me that an officer might be employed by this Branch and charged with the responsibility of making the best possible use of the surplus materials and equipment that are likely to be available from time to time at military camps. I find it difficult to persuade myself that Indian agents and field officers, generally, can render satisfactory service while they remain dissatisfied to the extent that a number of them appear to be dissatisfied with housing conditions on our reserves.

A sincere attempt has been made during the last two or three years to increase the number of live stock,-
cows, goats, pigs, etc., on our reserves in the Prairie Provinces. The response on the part of agents has been somewhat dilatory, but with the disappearance of drought conditions, recent reports have become more encouraging. Indian Agent Ostrander, in his report dated June 6, 1943, on the Battleford Agency, states:

"Cattle have wintered with minimum losses. The calves are coming along satisfactorily. Nine well-bred Hereford heifers were bought for the Founder's Reserve at the request of the Indians. Goats are being purchased where needed and are being requested for milking purposes. However, only four have been bought so far and goats are hard to get. Seven more will be purchased just as soon as they can be found. In an effort to increase hog production, 20 sows, in pig, have been purchased with departmental authority. Another 25 have been purchased by Indians with their own resources. A few of these have farrowed and the average litter is slightly over eight, which, with fair luck and good attention, should give us around 400 hogs for market early in the winter. The Indians appear to have become quite interested in the hog industry and it should develop, unless it receives an unexpected setback by disease or accident."

The reafforestation program, started in Ontario four years ago, has been retarded somewhat by the acute labour shortage existing on reserves. It is encouraging to note, however, that the Indian agents concerned remain interested in these projects and encourage their extension wherever possible. Indian Agent McNaughton, St. Regis Agency, in his last report, dated June 4, states:

"Two acres of land were leased in the Chenail for the purpose of planting willows and 16,000 sets were put in at this agency. In addition to this, 1,000 pine were planted, some for agency purposes and the rest distributed amongst Indians. A number were planted at three of our schools, the latter being done to improve the site as well as to provide a windbreak. A small number of fruit trees were also distributed."

TRAINING.

Excerpts from two letters received by Canon S. Middleton, Principal, St. Paul's (C.E.) Residential School, Blood Reserve, Alberta, have been published in a recent issue of the Lethbridge Herald. These letters indicate that these boys are continuing with their studies and seeking to improve their educational standing while serving with the Armed Forces. In part, this ex-pupil, now in England, writes:

"I am taking a course at an English School and the instructors really know what they are doing. Most of them saw service in the Battle of France. It is quite odd to be amongst English fellows. They are very reserved but we get along fine. There is a sharp contrast between them and the Canadians. The Canadians are usually loud-voiced and more confident than the English. Yesterday I went for a walk in a part of England I used to read about in ancient history, never dreaming that some day I would be sitting in that spot. The Salisbury Plains look like the prairies. At Petawawa 40 of us were in the same class; now there are only 4 of us taking advanced survey work,—a very small percentage, considering that the Petawawa..."
class had the highest average of any class to take the course. If you are not mathematically inclined, however, you simply cannot keep up the pace. I would like to form an all-Indian regiment, but I am afraid it is an idle thought."

The other ex-pupil, Stephen Wadsworth, writes:

"I am getting along very satisfactorily in school. I am up in the filing and fitting department and will spend one month there before moving on into the woodwork department. I am getting quite proficient with a file and other tools."

Speaking of his family at home, he says:

"I am here so that they and their children may go on living in a world that is really worth living in. I have often heard the phrase 'A country worth living in is worth fighting for', and I quite agree with it. I am happy and proud to be able to say that the graduates of good old St. Paul's have contributed so much toward the realization of a final Allied victory."

Recent audit reports received from the Treasury office indicate a rather disturbing increase in the cost of operating residential schools. These increased costs would appear to be due to a reduction in the average attendance at a number of our schools and the increased salaries paid to teachers, coupled with the higher wages paid to farm help. Mr. E. H. Berthe, in his last report on the Mount Elgin Institute, dated May 26, 1943, states:

"The cost per pupil per year shows an increase of $34.19 over the previous year. This increase is due to the reduction in the average attendance from 141.15 in 1941-42 to 127.78 in 1942-43.

Mr. Berthe adds: - "Although there were no extraordinary purchases at this school during the year, the financial condition is worse than one year ago. According to the Principal, he cannot see any improvement in sight, as the general cost of operation appears to be steadily increasing".

Mr. W. R. Butchart, in his report on the Sacred Heart (R.C.) Residential School, Peigan Agency, dated May 7, 1942, states:

"The cost of operation per day was up by $4.38. The cost of operation per pupil per year was quite high at $24.30 - an increase of $28.56. This increase may be traced to the increased farm costs. The cost of clothing at $7.41 is very low and is down by $8.56. The cost of food at $31.57 per pupil per year is up $1.56."

The per capita grant allowed at this school is $165.00.

The Auditor, Mr. Butchart, in his report on the Blood (R.C.) Residential School, dated May 28, states:

"The cost of operation per day is up by $12.21 and the cost of operation of $205.28 per pupil per year shows an increase over the preceding year of $22.76. The cost of clothing at $18.95 is $5.70 higher and the cost of food at $28.21 is $3.24 higher. The children appear..."
to be well dressed. The low food costs are due to the fact that all meat, vegetables, milk, butter and eggs are produced on the farm."

The per capita grant allowed at this school is $165.00.

You may remember that, immediately following the retirement of Inspector Barry, provision was made for the inspection of our Indian day and residential schools in British Columbia by public school inspectors, under the direction of the Provincial Department of Education. Reports of these inspectors have been reaching the Department from time to time during the last 6 or 7 months. While a few of the reports submitted by these inspectors have been somewhat critical of certain teachers who lack professional standing and of others too old to adopt new teaching methods, the reports on the whole have been satisfactory and somewhat encouraging.

Inspector T. F. Robson, in his report on the Lejac (R.C.) Residential School, Stuart Lake Agency, states:

"The program of vocational work provided at this school is comprehensive and varied. Provision is made for differences in age, sex, physique and talent. Training tasks are rotated so that children obtain variety of experience in home activities, the school farm, gardens and workshops.

"Boys were observed actively employed in the care and feeding of farm stock, wood and metal work, shoe repairing, gardening, slaughtering and preparation of animals for food consumption, and various aspects of repair work and maintenance.

"A hot-house has recently been constructed by the boys for the acceleration of plant production. Improvised power tools, initiated by the instructor of vocational training - a graduate of the school - are a feature of the wood-work establishment. The butchers' and cobblers' shops are giving valuable training. Some of these buildings are too small and the scope of the work is thereby restricted.

"Girls are well trained in homemaking activities and develop responsibility in house-work - care, preparation and service of food, dormitory service, laundry, bake-shop and dairy practice. They take an active part in butter and cheese making and in the cleaning and grading of eggs. Training in needlework is exceptionally good; much of the pupils' clothing is made and maintained by the girls; the art needlework is excellent and the knitting, noteworthy. Spinning is practised and the provision of hand-looms would be a worthwhile addition to this phase of pupil training.

"With respect to general conditions, I may state this institution is effectively supervised and economically and efficiently administered. Offices, stores and warehouses were inspected and found to be in good order. Careful planning and direction is reflected in an orderly work routine.

"The farm is a notable feature. Power machines and horses are both used in soil cultivation. A dairy herd of Holsteins, a beef herd of Shorthorns, Sheep, Swine, and poultry bear evidence of good husbandry and provide
valuable training. Numerous field crops are grown.

"The children are particularly well dressed, clean and tidy and appear to be happy and healthy. The staff take a keen personal interest in their welfare and, in my opinion, these children are most fortunate in their environment. The uniform dress of both boys and girls is both attractive and economical. Clothing of a practical character is worn for outdoor activities.

"Constant upkeep by repairs and paintwork, apart from sound economy, enhances the attraction of this institution".

In view of the fact that a certain proportion of our time is spent in dealing with delinquent Indian girls and wayward Indian boys, it is gratifying to be able to report the case of an Indian girl who is making a real success of her work, Miss Christine Wakegiijig, teacher at the Burwash Indian Day School, Manitoulin Island Agency. Miss Wakegiijig has been in charge of this school for the last 5 years. She has a first class Ontario certificate and has completed Part I of a special elementary course in Home Economics. She is a graduate of the Spanish R.C. Residential School and of the North Bay Normal School. Inspector W. J. Greening, in his report dated May 8, states:

"The privilege of visiting this school is a genuine treat to an inspector. There is no other school in this whole inspectorate in which more efficient work is being done. As I remarked last year, this is a splendid little school with an equally splendid little teacher, an Indian maiden of whom the Department may be justly proud. I have met few teachers her superior and all too few her equal".

Two years ago the Christian Island R.C. Day School was taken over by Sister Agnes Black, S.O.S., Sault Ste. Marie. Sister Black, who has visited the Department since taking charge of this school on two occasions, appears to be doing particularly good work at her school. She is a teacher with a Quebec Superior Certificate and has had 14 years' teaching experience. Inspector Bennett, in his report dated May 28, states:

"I examined all pupils in reading, spelling, arithmetic, writing and language. I found their progress and proficiency quite good. In fact, this teacher has produced real results. The pupils are interested in community singing and sang five school songs for me. Two pupils played the piano. Real results in sewing and knitting are in evidence. I viewed quite a few articles made by these pupils—towels, mitts, parkas, pillow slips, knitting bags, neatly done, and other sewing.

"The health of the children is the concern of the teacher as well. Individual cups and tooth brushes are neat and clean at the rear of the school, provision being made for cleanliness of hands and face. The equipment of this school is in good order. The classroom is most attractive and neatly 'dressed' with children's work and suitable pictures for language purposes. When one compares the appearance of this room with other similar schoolrooms, one is impressed with this school".
