Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended July 31, 1943.

WELFARE:

Miss Edythe Smith-Windsor, who has been outstandingly successful in the organization of women's clubs in the Fisher River Agency, Manitoba, and who is regularly employed as an Indian day school teacher on the Fisher River Reserve, was employed during the month of July by Inspector Hamilton on the organization of women in the other agencies of the province. In her report to Inspector Hamilton on the work accomplished in The Pas Agency, Miss Smith-Windsor states:

"Mr. Lovell had arranged for suitable homes at Big Eddy and The Pas, where our meetings were held. A woman interpreter and leader had been chosen at each place. Sewing machines were also available at these homes. Announcements of my gatherings Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at Big Eddy and Thursday and Friday at The Pas had been made at the churches on the preceding Sunday. Mr. Lovell's hearty cooperation, in fact, went a long way towards making my meetings a success.

"Attendance at Big Eddy was very good and a tremendous amount of work was done by the women there. Thirty women and older girls attended the meetings and 82 articles were completed.

"The Indian women were told the purpose of the women's clubs and shown some garments that had been made by the Fisher River club. Most of the women stayed to do their work at George McMillivary's home. They ripped out the garments, cut and sewed them right there. A few who had small children at home took work with them and returned for more as each garment was completed.

"At The Pas meeting fewer women attended because many of the women are working in the potato fields at present. Those who did attend were the younger women. Their interest will draw others, I am sure. Twelve women, however, attended and five articles were finished in the two days spent with them."

A number of encouraging reports on the condition of Victory Gardens have reached the Branch during the month. Indian Agent Rice, of Shubenacadie, in his last report, states:

"Although we were late getting the crops in, I believe the yield should be a good one. The great amount of moisture and a few really hot days made the growth almost..."
mushroom-like over night. All told we put in about five acres of potatoes, one of turnips and one of smaller vegetables—chiefly carrots, parsnips, beets, beans and peas. It was necessary to send a tractor around to help some of the families on the reserve, as the local farmers were too busy struggling with the weather to bother much with the Indians. This privilege was kept to a minimum, however, and enjoyed chiefly by the old folks. In addition to this community effort, practically all of the Indians, both old and young, have very good and fairly large family gardens. Due to the widespread shortage of commercial fertilizer, most of the Indians were caught flat-footed. Fortunately, I knew a farmer who had purchased more than he needed and the Indians were able to buy almost a ton. For our community garden I bought 15 truckloads of stable manure. This, with a sprinkling of the more refined variety, should give the garden the little extra boost that is needed.

"On the 7th instant we moved a family into the last of the six houses constructed last autumn. All the occupants of the new buildings have large gardens. One house in particular was built right in the middle of a large growth of alders. After working hours and during idle days this Indian has cleared, stumped, ploughed and seeded a plot which is already large enough to supply him with his winter vegetables."

Indian Agent F. H. Moore, in his report on the Cowichan Agency, dated July 1, states:

"The crops and gardens in this agency are looking exceptionally good. Vegetable gardens on the various reserves are more numerous and better cared for than I have ever seen them before. This helps to prove my theory about the Indians and vegetable gardens, which is that necessity and inability to buy what they need will make them grow more."

Indian Agent Down, Muncey, Ont., sent forward with a letter, dated July 27, a number of snapshots showing the progress that has been made in the cultivation of a community potato patch. Commenting upon these snapshots, the Agent states:

"I enclose snaps of the cutting and preparing of seed potatoes for our 1943 twenty-three acre planting. This was quite an undertaking, with the scarcity of seed and without proper machinery. Although weather conditions were bad, we preserved and today we are the proud possessors of what promises to be a profitable venture, not so much from a financial standpoint but from the standpoint of supplying our Indian people with one of their staple foods."

"I am also enclosing snaps of a make-over storage building which is being constructed to facilitate the storage of discarded military clothing. When this building is finished it will give us approximately 1000 square feet of floor storage space at an approximate cost of $600.00."

On July 9, accompanied by Mr. Morris, I visited the Golden Lake Indian Reserve. This was the first opportunity I had of visiting this reserve in several years. If I remember correctly, my last visit was early in July, 1937. At that time the entire population of this reserve were in
receipt of relief or departmental assistance of some kind.

You are aware that Mr. Morris has taken a personal interest in this reserve during the last two years, with the result that there has been an astonishing improvement in general conditions. The Indians, who at the time of my last visit were cynical and very critical of the Department, appeared to have developed a co-operative spirit and are displaying an anxiousness to work with the Agent that is really amazing. I saw a community patch of potatoes on this reserve, of approximately three acres, that appeared to me to be the best patch of potatoes I had seen anywhere in the district. This patch of potatoes, by the way, had been sprayed the preceding day by the members of the women's clubs.

Fifty-five young pigs have been distributed amongst Indian families on this reserve, on the understanding that in each case the Indian will raise one pig for the Branch and one for himself. In the fall, the pigs owned by the Branch will be slaughtered and salted down and thus made available for the old and physically incapacitated men and women, who are ordinarily in receipt of relief allowances. A Yorkshire boar has also been purchased from the Experimental Farm, for $10.00. This animal is now at the reserve and will in a short time be ready for breeding purposes.

During my inspection of the reserve I visited the home of an Indian Angus Vincent. This man had a brood sow that farrowed on July 9, the day of my visit; it had a litter of 11 pigs. Although Vincent is a man in his middle seventies, he informed me that this was the first time that he had ever owned a brood sow and the first time that he had ever attempted to raise pigs.

The goat herd at this reserve is in excellent condition. There are approximately 30 goats in the herd. At the time of my visit, arrangements were being made by the Agent to send one billy and five nannies to Dr. Orford, Moose Factory. One billy and three nannies had already been sent to Manawan, in the Abitibi Agency. A purebred Saanen billy, 11 months old, had just been received by the agent from the Spanish Residential School.

Practically all the families visited had small gardens in a good state of cultivation. The following trees, sent in by Mr. Morris, had been planted: 100 rhubarb; 100 gooseberries; 12 plum; 60 currant; 120 apple; 1000 strawberry plants; 82 raspberry canes. Nine hundred and seventy-five (975) Barred Rock chickens had also been shipped in to the reserve - 500 on May 21 and 475 on June 25. One hundred of these pullets, in due course, will also be sent to Dr. Orford.

Real progress has been made, under the direction of Mr. Morris and Indian Agent Ruddy, at this agency. In fact, I feel that I cannot speak too highly of the work already undertaken and accomplished. The response of the Indians has been most gratifying. Moral conditions on the reserve have improved to such an extent during the last two years that I found it at times difficult to convince myself that this was the same reserve that I had visited five years ago. These results are due almost wholly to the personal interest taken by Mr. Morris in this group of Indians and to the splendid work accomplished by the members of the women's clubs, under
the leadership of Mrs. Lavallee.

I came away with the impression that, despite the progress made, these Indians will require a great deal of careful supervision for a number of years. Our experience at this agency, however, would indicate that even the most backward groups of Indians can be made comparatively self-supporting with little cost to the Department, provided we have on the reserve itself the leadership necessary to give intelligent direction to a worthwhile rehabilitation program.

TRAINING

An unusually large number of Indian day school teachers resigned at the close of the academic year - June 30, and it is just possible that an additional number will resign from our service prior to the opening of the schools on September 1. At this date there are 32 schools for which we have not yet succeeded in securing teachers. The higher salaries that are being paid this year in public schools, coupled with the large number of teachers who have joined the Armed Forces, are largely responsible for this condition. It is not at all likely that teachers will become more plentiful at any time during the years immediately ahead of us. It is a matter of regret that we have to call upon a large number of teachers, particularly women, who lack professional training, to take charge of our schools. The employment of these teachers is likely to act as a retarding influence in the progress ordinarily made by Indian pupils.

You may remember that immediately following the destruction of the Carcross Residential School by fire, on April 17, 1939, two private homes were rented by this Branch for residential school purposes. This arrangement was never wholly satisfactory and the buildings themselves were condemned as insanitary and unfit for occupation about 8 months ago by the Indian Health Officer for the district. Bishop Geddes, who visited the Department a few months ago, was of the opinion that the pupils enrolled at Carcross might very well be transferred to the old R.C.M.P. building at Dawson, provided that this building could be secured for educational purposes. It would appear, however, from recent correspondence, that the obstacles standing in the way of operating the building at Dawson as a residential school have proved insurmountable. Dr. H. A. Alderwood, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, in a letter dated July 27, states:

"Our Commission has explored every possibility of effecting the transfer of our residential school work from Carcross to Dawson. We have been in continual correspondence with Bishop Geddes and the Principal of the School, but the many difficulties and uncertainties surrounding the question seem to make the transfer impossible. The matter was thoroughly reviewed at the July meeting of our Commission, and in view of the lateness of the date now reached it was felt that a definite decision must be arrived at. The following resolution was eventually adopted: - 'That in the face of the impossibility of carrying on a school effectively at Carcross under existing conditions and in view of the many uncertainties connected with the suggested..."
removal to Dawson, we are regretfully compelled to recommend that the school be closed temporarily. Pending the construction of a new building at Carcross or some other point, we urge the establishment of a day school to provide for some of the children concerned."

Dr. Alderwood continues: "We deeply regret that we are forced to recommend the cessation of the work of the Chootla School even for a time, as its reputation in the Yukon for valuable service over a long period of years is something we treasure. We are also convinced of the need of such an institution and it is our hope that arrangements may be made for a number of the children to be provided for at one or more day schools."

It is our intention, this year, to make a wider distribution of the biscuits specially prepared for use at Indian day schools. The distribution this year will include practically all the Indian day schools in northern Manitoba, northern Saskatchewan and northern Ontario. It is our hope that, in addition to the value of these biscuits from a nutritional standpoint, their distribution will tend to encourage more regular attendance at our schools. Lack of attendance at Indian day schools still remains one of the most perplexing problems in the Training Division.

Memorandum:

Doctor McGill,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended August 31, 1943.

TRAINING

Arrangements have been completed whereby an educational survey will be undertaken of the agencies and reserves from which pupils have been recruited for enrollment at the Mount Elgin Residential School in recent years.

I visited Toronto on Saturday, August 28, and discussed with the joint Secretaries of the Home Mission Board of the United Church - Dr. Cochrane and Doctor Dorsey - the details of this survey. These officials of the United Church agreed to have a representative of the Church, the Reverend R. E. Joblin, of Nuncy, accompany Inspector Arneil and Mr. Gordon Young when these men visit the agencies.

On Monday, August 30, I visited the Ontario Department of Education and interviewed Mr. V. K. Greer, Chief Inspector of Public and Separate Schools with the object of securing from him the name of an educationist who might undertake this survey. Mr. Greer, with whom I had been in correspondence, had given this matter a great deal of careful consideration and expressed the opinion that Inspector Gordon Young, of Strathroy, Ont., was the only man of whom he could think, with the qualifications necessary to undertake such a task. Mr. Young has taught public schools and high schools in the southwestern district of Ontario over a period of years and has been a public and high school inspector since 1930. He is Chairman of the Victory Loan Campaign Committee for the London district and is President of the Boys' and Girls' School Fairs Association for Western Ontario. In response to Mr. Greer's suggestion that I personally interview Mr. Young, I visited London on the afternoon of the 30th ultimo. I met Mr. Young at the London Hotel. At the outset he hesitated to undertake this survey, in view of the additional duties for which he had become responsible in connection with the Victory Loan campaign. He was, however, seized with the importance of the task we had in mind and seemed to have somewhat deep-seated convictions in respect to Indian education. He has on another occasion inspected the Mount Elgin Institute and Indian day schools on the Caradoc and adjoining reserves. He finally agreed to undertake the work and intimated that he would begin the survey at Caradoc on Tuesday, September 14. I am personally of the opinion that the information obtained during the course of this survey and the recommendations made by Mr. Young should prove invaluable to us in working out a worthwhile educational policy, not only at the Caradoc agency, but at a number of agencies in Western Ontario.

Mr. Greer informed me during the course of our interview that he has been approached from time to time by
teachers employed at Indian day and residential schools, all of whom were anxious to get his advice and assistance in securing recognition from the Department for superannuation allowances. Mr. Greer pointed out that practically all the public and separate school teachers of the Dominion now qualify for superannuation at a certain age or at any time during their teaching career, if suffering from physical disability. He personally found it difficult to convince himself that we could secure and retain in our service fully qualified and conscientious teachers unless some provision was made in the future for retiring allowances. He expressed the opinion that in the province of Ontario it might be possible to work out an arrangement whereby the Dominion would contribute to the Ontario Government Superannuation Fund, on the understanding that teachers employed in Indian day and residential schools would contribute a similar amount. This, in my judgment, is a matter that should be given careful consideration and a decision with respect to it reached, just as soon as times become normal.

A great deal of difficulty has been experienced in securing the number of teachers necessary to open our Indian day schools on September 1. Dr. Dorey informed me that despite the efforts put forth by the superintendents of missions in the provinces and by himself, personally, there were still a number of schools for which he had not succeeded in securing teachers, and, in addition to this, a number of the teachers recommended by him lacked full academic and professional standing. At this date there are 25 day schools for which teachers have not yet been secured. It is particularly regrettable that we have failed to secure teachers for schools such as the Rama two-room school. Our failure to open and operate a school such as this, with a large enrolment, is likely to contribute to waywardness and delinquency on the reserve.

The Indian agents at Shubenacadie and Eskasoni were notified early in the month that it would not be possible to proceed with the construction of schools at their agencies during the present fiscal year. Both Mr. Rice and Mr. Maclean, in letters now received, have expressed the opinion that our failure to proceed with this building program will not seriously retard the centralization program. Both agents believe that extensions can be made to the existing day schools at very little cost and that in any event there are a great many elderly Indians in receipt of relief who can be moved into the houses that are being constructed on the reserves.

WELFARE:

Economic conditions throughout the country are such that able-bodied Indians are experiencing little difficulty in securing employment. A large number of Canadian Indians have found employment in American war industries. The wages paid in these industries are substantially higher than the wages received by Indians at any time in their history. Teen-age boys and girls in a number of cases are receiving wages at the rate of
$200 per month and one Indian, a resident of the St. Regis reserve, who is a foreman in a munitions plant, earned a little over $8,000 during the last year.

Relief expenditures are at the present time confined to the purchase of supplies necessary for aged and physically incapacitated Indians. There are a number of factors, however, that tend to contribute to our relief and welfare costs. Illegitimacy and general waywardness appear to be steadily on the increase. Reports indicate that comparatively few Indians are taking advantage of the wages received to improve their home buildings and home surroundings. Indeed, in a great many cases, these Indians have temporarily abandoned their homes or shacks on the reserves and taken up residence in the cities, towns and villages. The financial statement of welfare expenditures from April 1 to July 31 - a four month period - indicates a decrease of $21,624.53. The greatest decreases have taken place in the provinces of Manitoba and Quebec. In Manitoba the decrease amounts to $15,767.61 and in Quebec to $11,056.92. This, I should point out, is the first substantial reduction in relief expenditures that has taken place at any time in Manitoba during the last 10 year period. It would appear that a large number of the Indians in that province have secured employment with farmers and in cordwood and lumbering operations.

In response to a request received from the Department of Labour, a circular letter was sent out early in the month to all Indian agents. In this circular letter, Indian agents were asked to state approximately how many Indians from each of the reserves might be available for pulpwood, cordwood or lumbering operations for the period October 1 to April 30. These agents were asked to send their replies direct to the Department of Labour. A number of them, however, ignoring instructions, sent their returns to this Branch. These returns indicate that there will be comparatively few Indians for work of this character during the coming winter.

I embraced the opportunity extended to me at the time of my trip to Toronto to visit the goat farm operated by Mr. Cole at Markham, Ont. Mr. Cole, from whom we purchased a male goat a few months ago, has operated this farm for a period of 30 years. He specializes in the Saanen dairy type of goats and has won hundreds of prizes at exhibitions in Canada and the United States. A few months ago he sold a one-year-old pedigreed Saanen male goat to a resident of London, Ont., for the sum of $100.00. Mr. Cole, with whom I had a lengthy discussion, expressed the opinion that the demand for goats during the last six month period has been greater than it has been at any time in the last 30 or 40 years. I was interested to learn from him that he imported his first goats from the State of California and imported them with the object of securing a milk supply for his wife, who was then an invalid. The fact that his wife had gone on a diet of goat's milk, in response to instructions received from her physician, and the fact that she recovered
rapidly convinced Mr. Cole that goat's milk possesses unusual curative elements. He feels that it is his mission in life to encourage the farmers and the town dwellers of Ontario to go in more extensively for goat herds. I was gratified to learn from Mr. Cole that good grade milking goats can still be purchased at prices ranging from $15.00 to $25.00.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended September 30, 1943.

TRAINING.

The members of the committee responsible for the educational survey on a number of our reserves in southwestern Ontario began their work with a study of conditions on the Caradoc reserve, on Tuesday, September 14. Mr. Neil, member of the committee who returned to Ottawa yesterday, informs me that the following reserves have been visited: Cape Croker, Saugeen, Kettle Point, Sarnia, Walpole Island, Caradoc, Six Nations and New Credit. Inspector Gordon Young, chairman of the committee, has suggested that two additional days be spent at the Caradoc agency, prior to the preparation of the final report. It is expected that this report will reach the Department in the course of a few weeks.

You may remember that a couple of years ago a number of letters appeared in the Press of British Columbia, in which criticism was directed against the educational policy of the Department in the province of British Columbia and particularly the educational program provided at a number of our schools in the Cowichan agency. I regret to state that during the last six or seven months a number of somewhat similar letters have appeared in the Family Herald and Weekly Star. I find it somewhat difficult to understand the motives by which the writers of these letters are actuated. Copies of the papers containing these letters appear to be distributed to a number of Indians throughout the Dominion. For example, Mrs. Monture sent forward a few days ago a newspaper clipping containing an article by Mrs. H. Haylen-Ward, R.R. No. 4, Victoria, B.C., which states that with the exception of a few mission schools, maintained by the church, no provision has been made for the education of the Indians of British Columbia. Mrs. Monture seemed quite disturbed over the subject matter of this letter. It is just possible that provision should be made by the Department for the amount of publicity necessary to keep the general public informed regarding the work undertaken and accomplished from time to time by the Government on behalf of our Indian population.

In view of the foregoing, this excerpt, taken from a letter recently received from Indian Agent Moore, of the Cowichan Agency, is somewhat interesting. The agent states:

"With reference to the present setup at the Tsartlip Indian day school, I may say that under date of

the third -
the third instant I made quite a lengthy report to the Indian Commissioner, directing his attention to the improved conditions at this school and the splendid spirit which now exists over what we found previously, in fact, ever since I came to the agency. The Sister in charge, Sister Maureen Regan, has done an excellent job in the short time she has been there, and the attendance, even at this early date, has been much higher than at any time during the past year. I feel extremely confident that the future of the school is most promising. Since I came here I have never found the children so clean, attentive, well managed and happy as they were at the time of my visit. Altogether, I believe that insofar as this school is concerned, the Department made a wise move to engage the Sister, particularly one so well qualified as Sister Maureen Regan is. This particular school, pupils and teachers alike, have been a headache to me for years, but I really feel now that we will make progress."

A three-room Indian day school was established at Restigouche in the fiscal year 1926-27. This building, however, proved to be wholly inadequate to provide the classroom accommodation for the steadily increasing Indian pupil population at that agency. The decision reached early this year to construct a full basement under the existing building was, in my judgment, a wise one. This work, which was undertaken under the supervision of Mr. Doucet, is now completed. We have now, in addition to the three original classrooms, four spacious classrooms in the basement, admirably adapted for vocational instruction. The total cost of this addition is not likely to exceed $7,000.00 - approximately $1,750 per classroom. The principal of the school and the Indian agent, in a joint letter dated September 27, referred to the reconstruction of the school and stated:

"The wonderful improvement made at the Restigouche Indian Day School is now in evidence. It is a delight to the members of the teaching staff to express to the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch their sincere gratitude for the beautiful work accomplished. Please accept our heartfelt thanks for having sent into our midst Mr. Doucet to direct and control this laborious undertaking. Sincere congratulations are due Mr. Doucet for the cleverness with which he overcame all the difficulties inseparable from such a task. Our school has been not only enlarged but made more comfortable. You have every reason to be proud of it and I might add that this school has been admired by all who have seen it. Roomy and well equipped classrooms are now at our disposal for vocational instruction. Each one of us will do our utmost to prove to you that you have not co-operated with us in vain."

I have referred so frequently to the substantial repairs that appear to be necessary at a number of our Indian day and residential schools, that it is a real pleasure to me to be able to refer to a school the actual condition of which leaves little to be desired. Mr. Christianson, in his report on the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School, dated September 16, states:

"The exterior of this building was painted in 1938 and is in excellent shape; in fact, everything around the institution appears to be in first class condition and in the very best of order. The provincial boiler inspector
had just completed his inspection. The only remark he made was that there were signs of pitting in the tubes of the boiler. I went over the laundry machinery, the lighting plant, the batteries, etc., and found everything in a fair shape. The plumbing is also in good order. The barns are also in fair shape, having been painted last fall by the members of the staff. This school owns 100 head of cattle and were milking 18 cows at the time of my visit. They have also 12 horses, 125 pigs and 235 chickens.

"I noticed that the school had two fine gardens, which are a splendid example to set before the Indians of the reserve. These gardens appear to be as well kept as any one could find on an experimental farm. The lawns and hedges in front of the school were beautiful."

In my last report I referred to the number of schools - approximately 25 - for which teachers had not been secured. Since that date, six additional teachers have been appointed to day schools, and a letter just received from the Secretary of the Home Mission Board of the United Church suggests that there is a good possibility of getting a fully qualified teacher, with B. Ed degree, to take charge of the Rama two-room day school, at Longford Mills, Ont. In view of the acute shortage of teachers throughout the Dominion, particularly in the western provinces, I consider we have been very fortunate this year in securing the teachers necessary to operate our Indian day schools. In this connection a great deal of our success is due to the splendid co-operation of the churches. A number of missionaries with full normal school training have volunteered for service in our schools. It is very doubtful if these men would be available were it not for the close co-operation that has been maintained between the Department and the Churches in the operation of our schools. Bishop Geddes, who visited the Department a few days ago, informed me that a young man, a graduate of Cambridge University, and his wife had offered their services for the operation of an Indian day school in the Yukon.

WELFARE.

The following report of the launching of the destroyer "Micmac" appeared in the Halifax Herald of September 20th:

"Five full-blooded feather-festive Indian chiefs almost 'stole the show' from their namesake, H.M.C.S. Micmac, Canada's largest home-built ship of war, at her launching at Halifax shipyards, Saturday.

"Stoically, they posed separately and with rear-admirals and other high officers of the armed forces, as if such things happened to them every day.

"When the Press received a baptism of champagne, which a wind blew in their direction, the workers who had a half hour to watch their masterpiece go down the ways, the guard of honour composed of Nelson Sea Cadets and all officials burst into laughter. But not the Chiefs; they did not even bat an eye."
"Not until they saw the towering sharp-nosed glistening bow of the Micmac slide smoothly away from them after Mrs. Macdonald had snipped the launching ribbon, did the tribal chiefs give forth even an 'ugh'."

"Then, they did themselves proud—they chanted for all they were worth the prayer to Saint Anne, their patron saint, into the microphones. So impressive were they that newsreel men asked them for encores. They graciously obliged."

It would appear that a number of Indian bands in the Prairie Provinces are making a substantial contribution to the meat supply of the nation. Acting Indian Agent McMillan, in his last report on the Blood agency, states:

"Our annual sale of Indian cattle was held on the 30th of the month, when approximately 518 head of cattle were sold. These included 93 dry and 325 steers with a few canner cows. Prices were very good indeed, No. 1 steers bringing $11.85; No. 2 steers $10.85; heifers under 1050 lbs. bringing $11.85 and over 1050 lbs., $10.50. Cows sold at $9.25 with no No. 2 cows offered, and canner cows brought $6.25. It was noted that the prices received that day compared favourably with the market price at Winnipeg at that time. The amount of cash received was approximately $60,000 for the cattle sold."

Indian Agent Kerley, in his report on the Crooked Lake Indian agency, dated September 4, also refers to cattle sales recently held at his agency. The agent states:

"Cattle sales were held on all reserves during the month, with an average price of $80.00 per head received. The top steer brought $125. The cattle are all in very good condition."

Indian agents continue to refer to the success of their Victory Garden campaign. Indian Agent Bryant, in his reported dated September 6, states:

"There are some very creditable gardens on all the reserves of this agency and nearly all the Indians have at least a patch of potatoes. During the month gardens were judged and prizes awarded on all four reserves. We had an expert gardener from Kamsack to judge the garden plots on Cote and Keesekoose. This gardener remarked that several of the Indian gardens would compare favourably with the white gardens in the neighborhood."

The following is an excerpt from the Victoria Daily Colonist of August 3, 1943:

"Indians in many of the settlements on the west coast of Vancouver Island are extremely interested in A.R.P. work and are making a fine showing also in the Pacific Coast Militia Rangers, it was learned by Attorney General Maitland and Commissioner T.W.S. Parsons of the B.C. Police, who Saturday completed a tour of Vancouver Island.

"The Indians, Commissioner Parsons stated, act..."
in the A R P organizations as fire-fighters and wardens and in this work have become closely associated with the Police."

"The following is a quotation from a letter received from Air Vice Marshall of the Western Air Command, in connection with the daring rescue by a West Coast Indian of a pilot whose parachute held him suspended in a tree 75 feet from the ground:

"This action on the Indian's part is considered to be a very courageous and commendable feat and, needless to say, is thoroughly appreciated by the Royal Canadian Air Force and the pilot concerned."

Indian Agent Asbridge, in a reference to A R P organization work, states:

"Drills and instruction in connection with A R P work are being carried out at all Indian day and residential schools. Gas masks have been issued to the residential school at Alberni and to reserves in the vicinity of air ports and encampments."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended October 31, 1945.

WELFARE

Mr. Morris, accompanied by Inspector Thibault, visited the Oka and St. Regis agencies during the week ending October 16, with the object of organizing Homemakers' Clubs on these reserves. With an abundance of discarded military clothing available, it is in our judgment of the utmost importance that the women on our reserves should be organized for the purpose of making the best possible use of this clothing by remodelling and by undertaking necessary repairs. It has been our experience also that where homemakers' clubs have been established the women usually take an active interest in the promotion of gardening and in the improvement of home conditions, generally, on the reserves.

Mr. Thibault, in his report on the meetings held at Oka and St. Regis, states:

"Nineteen women were present when the meeting opened at the Oka Village School. The teacher of the school, Miss Diabo, was present, as well as John Angus, the teacher in charge of the Country School at Oka, who acted as interpreter. Ten men were also present, some having accompanied their wives. The meeting was very quiet, no questions being asked. John Angus repeated in the Indian language the explanations given by Mr. Morris. The women agreed to meet again on October 15, to elect their officers and to notify the Indian agent of their choice."

Mr. Thibault adds: "Knowing this particular group to be to some extent prejudiced against the Department and not always willing to co-operate, it is our hope that our work will be of some benefit to them. No such proposal having been previously offered to them, they were anxious to talk the matter over between themselves before accepting or rejecting it. I am pleased to say, however, that their response exceeded my expectations. The teacher, Miss Diabo, herself an Indian, promised full co-operation.

"There were 15 present at the meeting held at the Oka Country School. The ladies agreed to meet a few days later to elect their president and secretary. The result will be given to the Indian agent upon his next visit and then forwarded to the Department. The teacher,"
John Angus willingly acted as interpreter during the meeting and promised his full cooperation.

"Our first meeting at the St. Regis agency was held on Thursday, October 14, at 2 P.M. The women were somewhat slow in coming. However, we were able to make up a list of 27 names, including Miss Terrance, the teacher, as well as Miss Foisy, who is teaching at the Chenail School. All were interested in the exhibits of clothing and of the enlarged photographs exhibited by us. They appeared to listen with interest to the explanations given by Mr. Morris. These women elected their president and secretary and an organizing committee of six.

"Our second meeting was held at the St. Regis Village School on Friday the 15th at 10 o'clock A.M. There was a satisfactory attendance at this meeting, despite the fact that many Indian women are at present employed in the United States, helping to harvest vegetable crops. These women leave every morning, by truck, and are returned home the same way. The presence of the two teaching Sisters at this meeting added to the interest. The Sisters appeared to be quite friendly with all the women present and they assured us of their full cooperation in promoting the new organization.

"Our third meeting was held on the afternoon of the same day at the Cornwall Island West School. This meeting was held at 2:30 P.M. While waiting to open the meeting, the ladies upon their arrival looked over the clothing exhibits and were very much interested in the photographs displayed around the classroom. They listened very attentively to the explanations given by Mr. Morris. The teacher, Mrs. White (an Indian) was kind enough to repeat all that was said in the Indian language for the benefit of a few older women not familiar with English. Mrs. White is a very active person and, I was informed, a good organizer. She will be given a chance to show what she can do now in the setting up of this project on this particular section of the reserve."

Mr. Thibault adds: "May I conclude by expressing my opinion that the St. Regis Indians can be expected to go ahead quicker with these organizations than the Oka Indians. The members of the St. Regis Band do not show that suspicion which is apparent when one meets the Oka Indians. However, I will be pleased to see the progress made at Oka. These Indians have fine land and many advantages over other Indian groups in Quebec."

Mr. Morris also visited the Maniwaki reserve on October 27. While I have not yet received a formal report from him, he assured me personally that the response of the Indians of Maniwaki was encouraging and satisfactory in every sense. It is our hope that we shall have an opportunity at an early date to discuss more fully with Mr. Gendron a comprehensive welfare program that might be promoted on the Maniwaki reserve.

A number of encouraging reports continue to reach the Department from month to month with respect
to successful gardening projects, organized on Indian reserves. Indian Agent Buddy, in his last report on the Golden Lake Reserve, states:

"In June we sowed the following vegetables in the two community plots; 35 bags of potatoes (approximately 5 acres), 2 lbs. of turnips and a quantity of corn. This was a community project and groups were organized during the summer months to do the weeding. On September 24, 25 and 27 we dug the potatoes with a digger and had a yield of 250 bags. These potatoes are now stored in the community root-house. We expect to have about 2½ tons of turnips for human consumption and about the same amount for feed for our live stock. We have 12 loads of hay and green feed for our goats. This feed was also grown on the community plots. In addition to these community projects each Indian had a garden at his home and these turned out to be very good. The Department this year allowed $25.00 in prizes for gardens and the improvement in the gardens on the reserve this year was remarkable. Bags of flour rather than cash were given as prizes. The Indians dug approximately 200 bags of potatoes from their individual gardens."

The Indian Agent at the Caradoc Agency, Mr. G. W. Down, secured permission early in the spring to proceed with the cultivation of an area on the reserve suitable for the production of potatoes. Mr. Down refers to the results of this project in a letter to the Department dated October 18. The Agent states:

"After our spring discussions on potato growing, you will, I am sure, be interested in the subsequent results. Although we were handicapped without the services of an efficient sprayer, we have grown and harvested one of the largest crops of potatoes grown from one block in the district - 1500 bags of good quality potatoes. We think this is an accomplishment to be proud of, especially with the adverse weather conditions which we have had to fight. Storage facilities were inadequate, but we overcame that difficulty by pitting 500 bags."

The Agent adds: "We were more than satisfied with our potato venture and I feel, without going into the figures, that I have again been able to prove that the cost of essential machinery for the growing of a crop is very negligible when proper methods are used. However, it must be understood that I cannot undertake another year of potato growing on such a scale without proper efficient machinery at my disposal at all times. The fact that we did not have this machinery is not, of course, the fault of your efforts in securing it. We understand that the Government has already decided to release more agricultural machinery in 1944".

Indian Agent Featherston, of the Rama agency, in his report for September, states:

"The gardens have been judged and prizes awarded. The gardens have been good, some remarkably good. The fourth prize went to Mrs. Annie Benson, mother of Chief Benson, a woman of 75 years. This woman, by her own efforts, grew a large garden with nearly all the..."
common vegetables and plenty of potatoes. There are more vegetables and potatoes on this reserve now than I have ever seen before. This is remarkable, considering that the able-bodied men are mostly employed off the reserve.

School gardens, that is, gardens cultivated on the lands adjoining Indian day schools, are seldom a success. This fact can be attributed to the absence of the average teacher during the months of July and August. However, where we have secured a married man, who is prepared to remain at the school during the summer months, the results are usually somewhat encouraging. Indian Agent Waite, in his report on the Swan Lake (U.C.) Indian Day School, states:

"The school garden at the Swan Lake Indian Day School this year produced the following vegetables:
25 bushels of potatoes, 61 lbs. of white beans, 7 bushels of carrots, 14 bushels of turnips, 2 bushels of onions and 2 bushels of tomatoes."

The Agent adds: "The teacher, Mr. Schellenberg, makes request to have an additional portion of the garden broken so that more vegetables can be produced next year."

Vegetables produced at Indian day schools are usually used in the preparation of noonday lunches. Reports from the Prairie Provinces indicate that considerable difficulty has been experienced by our agents in the operation of community farms. With high wages prevailing in the adjoining districts, Indians cannot be easily persuaded to take up agricultural operations on their own reserves. We do feel, however, that a very vigorous attempt should be made to keep these farms in operation, despite the difficulties we are at present encountering. The operation of these farms is desirable, from the standpoint of production; but in addition to this, we may find it very desirable and very helpful to divide certain areas now under cultivation amongst young Indians returning from overseas service. This excerpt, taken from a report submitted by Indian Agent Ostrander, is well worthy of serious consideration:

"The work of the community farms of this agency has been slowed up this year by the fact that most of the working Indians were away from their reserves earning good wages. This does not suggest to me that the community farming project has been a failure. It is only a reminder to me that at a not far distant date the war will be over and the Indians whose labour is now much in demand will then be still needing a means of livelihood but will be again in competition with thousands of able-bodied white men returning from the services and war factories and in this competition the Indian falls miserably and has to return to his reserve and procure a miserable livelihood for his family by trying to sell wood at very low prices, or in a manner equally discouraging and degrading. I would not only like to see our present community farms continued, but I would like to see them on all the reserves fitted for agriculture, as they have proved successful under not the best of conditions as regards price of grain and occasional poor crops, and..."
have furnished a means for able-bodied Indians to earn thousands of dollars by honest effort, where they would have had to be fed by other means if the community farm had not been operating. Before and during the period of re-establishment resulting from the end of the war, the Department will have to face the question of how the Indians will make their living when all the able-bodied white men are again in competition with them for the available jobs. I have found no more practical way than in the development of the resources which the Indians have on their own reserves, by community farms started through revolving fund loans. I am certainly in favour of the repayment of these loans at the earliest possible date, as the actual repayment has a good moral effect upon the Indians, but the importance of the repayment of the loans should not completely submerge the great benefits which can be derived from the operation of these farms, and a community farm which is being operated in a thriving condition, furnishing work and a living for a large number of Indians, should not be closed out and rented to white men, just because the payments to the revolving fund have slowed up."

TRAINING

Audit and other reports now reaching the Department indicate that principals of residential schools are experiencing difficulty in operating these institutions with the funds available from per capita grants and from other sources. Mr. W. R. Butchart, in his audit report on the Sandy Bay Residential School, dated October 25, states:

"The cost of operation per pupil per year works out at $206.85, an increase of $26.03 over the operating costs of the preceding year. The rate of increase is even larger than this figure would indicate as the average pupilage of 26.8 is up 9.2. The only apparent liabilities, other than August accounts, were arrears in salaries. At the end of August $1,250 was owing to the Oblate Fathers on account of the principal's and assistant principal's salaries. There was also the amount of $440.00 owing to the Sisters, of which $330.00 was paid in September".

The authorized enrolment at this school is 95 and the per capita grant, $165.00.

The auditor, in his report on the Pine Creek Indian Residential School dated October 6, states:

"The cost per pupil per year was $180.01, an increase of $8.36. The attendance shows a decrease of 4.9%.

This school has an authorized enrolment of 120 and the per capita allowance is at the rate of $165.

The Norway House (United Church) Residential School has at this date an authorized pupilage of 105 and a per capita grant allowance of $175. The auditor in his report on this school dated October 7 states:

"The revenue at this school for the period amounted to $22,883.09 and includes the per capita grant of $14,711.81 and a special 1942 grant of $968.50.

The United Church allows a grant of $4,000 per
year to this school, which was received in full. The expenditures totalled $25,780.99. The cost of operation per pupil per year works out at $264.95, an increase of $13.17. The cost of food was $73.25 per pupil per year, an increase of $18.75.

"The goats supplied this school have not as yet proved a source of revenue, as most of the kids have been males".

Reverend J. Camirand, S.M.M., Principal of the Kuper Island School, Vancouver Island, in a letter to the Chief of the Training Division dated October 21, refers to the problems confronting him at his school and states:

"I must admit that the bonus received in the past two years has helped considerably to tide over these conditions, but I must also say that previous to receiving that help much of our personal salaries was used from month to month to make purchases and that to date we still owe $500 of back salaries to members of our staff".

This, I may say, is the only residential school operated by the members of this particular Order.

An interesting and somewhat encouraging report on the Thunderchild (R.C.) Residential School has been received from Mr. Christianson. He states:

"This is one of the old church schools and a very bad fire trap, just the same as the old school at Hobbsma. Everything around this institution, however, was in first class shape and well kept, just as in all Catholic schools. Since arriving there, Father Angin informs me he has lined the school inside with V-joint and tar paper because the plaster was all falling down, etc. I also noticed that some new floors have been put in, but I do not know whether this was done by the Department or the school authorities. I then went around the outbuildings and they are all in fair shape.

"There were 92 children in residence at the time of my visit to the school and Father Angin informed me the quota was 120, but I believe there were a few children who had not returned after the holidays. Then, in all probability, he will be able to recruit a few more children because I have three in mind for him from Battleford.

"During the afternoon of my visit to this school I was in the classrooms and the teachers all had the children go through their lessons, etc. I came to the conclusion that the senior teacher there, one of the Reverend Sisters, was the best teacher I had ever come across in an Indian school. I found out when I was talking to her that I had met her previously at Hobbsma some years ago. Therefore, I would say that the teaching in this institution is excellent, which is borne out by the way the children responded in the classroom."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended November 30, 1943.

WELFARE

Our records indicate that there is invariably a substantial increase in relief and welfare costs during the interval between the resignation, death or retirement of the average Indian agent and the appointment of his successor. Not only is there substantial increase in relief costs, but in the western agencies we frequently lose a comparatively large number of our live stock. A striking illustration of the increase that usually takes place is furnished this year in the case of the Carlton agency. Relief and welfare costs at the Carlton agency for the period April 1 to October 31, 1942, amounted to $5,782.53, and this year, with Mr. Prince and later with Mr. Jones in charge, the costs amounted to $9,735.94. It is somewhat difficult to understand this increase, in view of the economic conditions prevailing in this agency. I have in mind the ability of the Indians to secure gainful employment on farms or in cordwood operations. A breakdown of these expenditures has been made. It would seem that the increase has taken place almost wholly in the item classified as "provisions". The expenditure for this item during the period under review, this year, amounted to $6,366.34, compared with an expenditure of $5,492.61 for the corresponding period of last year. It is just possible that the average temporary agent, who is usually a clerk, finds it somewhat difficult to resist the pressure of the Indians for increased relief allowances and, in view of the temporary position he occupies, may not desire to antagonize the Indians of the agency. Consideration might well be given to the desirability of having an agent appointed to an agency at least two months prior to the resignation or retirement of the outgoing agent. I have given this matter a great deal of serious thought and I feel confident that such an arrangement would result in substantial economies to this Department.

The goat herds, referred to from time to time in my monthly reports, are being gradually extended to a number of reserves throughout the Dominion, where the need for milk appears urgent. Indian Agent Down, of the Caradoc Agency, in a letter dated November 15, states:

"It will be of interest to you to learn that all goats purchased during the summer and farmed out to individual Indians have been collected and placed in winter quarters. I have recently added five to the herd, making a total of 10 females and one male. This is somewhat short of the number I was authorized to buy, but the locating and buying of milk goats is not an easy proposition. However, I hope to increase this herd before the spring of 1944. The billy shipped from the Spanish School has done splendidly. He has, since we received him, grown twice his size and we have renamed him 'Spanish River'. Our program for the next year will be an endeavour to place a goat wherever there are young children needing milk. Providing our increase in..."
female goats is average, we should have within a year or two a sizable herd at this agency.

Indian Agent Taylor, of the Kamloops Agency, in his report for October, states:

"The two milch goats recently purchased have already proved their worth. One was given for the use of the family of Eddie Michel of the Adams Lake Band. His small daughter was in hospital for months, a very bad case of malnutrition. I saw her recently and the change in her appearance and health is unbelievable. This family are now fully converted to the merits of goat's milk. The children of T. Casimir have also benefited considerably from the milk of the other goat. There is a T.B. history in this family and we hope to avoid further inroads, with milk as an important part of the family diet."

Indian Agent Taylor also refers to his gardening program at the Kamloops agency. In this connection he states:

"I beg to advise that our request for increased garden acreage has met with very favourable response and the results are gratifying, particularly in view of the fact that a large number of the Indians are engaged in seasonal employment, removed from their reserves, for a large part of the growing season. Our latest check-up reveals some 235 separate gardens, comprising a total of 286 acres. This is an average of 1.22 acres per garden and 5 persons per garden, based on the total population. The gardens have been quite equally divided among the different bands. The produce was varied and the quality good and there was a noted increase in the growing of green stuffs, which would indicate an appreciative understanding of our advice regarding vitamin values. Without exception, the growers have adequate facilities for winter storage of vegetables and from present indications there should be no lack of these foods in any Indian home during the coming winter."

It would appear that a reasonably good start in the cultivation of gardens has been made at Lennox Island. Indian Agent Daly, in his report for November, states:

"From October 1st to 6th was spent at office work and on the 6th I went to Lennox Island to get the potatoes dug and stored. The crop was not a heavy one but was of good quality and should be sufficient to take care of all the Indians' needs during the coming winter. Carrots, beets and parsnips were exceptionally good. Turnips were large but not numerous. Most of the onion crop was used during the late summer and autumn. Peas and beans were only a light crop. Soy beans, however, did well and will be of some value as a protein feed for cattle. There was a large crop of cranberries on Hog Island this year. These berries were of good quality. Many of the Indians made money picking and selling them.

"We are hoping to procure a carload of Black Ash for the Indians of Lennox Island, to be distributed during the latter part of the month."

An interesting and encouraging report has been received from Indian Agent Spence on the successful
agricultural Fair held this year at the Moravian Reserve. The Agent states:

"The members of the Moravian Agricultural Society held their annual fall fair October 11 and 12. We had excellent weather and 2400 paid admissions. The baking, sewing and canned vegetable exhibits were of good quality but none too plentiful. The school had a fine exhibit of manual training articles—woodwork, sewing, knitting, writing and painting. Fourteen head of cattle were exhibited and these were of good quality. John Huff, a Moravian soldier settler, has a herd of extra good Hereford cattle.

"Several Indians have been interviewed with a view of using discarded army clothing for children. Some progress is being made."

A number of striking illustrations of the average Indian's lack of frugality have been reaching the Department in recent months. The latest is supplied in the last report of Indian Agent Lewis, of Hobbema. Mr. Lewis states:

"Most of the Indians returned to the reserves during the month, threshing in the white settlements being completed. They all look good and fat but otherwise the large wage they have been getting is not very apparent. One Indian, who acknowledged that he had been earning $7.00 a day all fall, came into the office and asked for a pair of boots, explaining that the ones he was wearing were broken and that he had no money with which to buy new ones. We will now have to try to get our able-bodied Indians out in the lumber camps for the winter."

Indians of the Prairies Provinces continue to dispose of their cattle at prices which appear to be very satisfactory. Indian Agent Fredale, of Nopley, reports that we sold our steers and cows early this month in the usual manner. About 20 cows were sold earlier in the summer. These animals are included in the following statement:

| Item       | Price     |
|------------|-----------|
| 144 Steers | $13,539.49|
| 64 Cows    | $5,186.21 |
| **Total**  | **$18,725.70** |

Average price per steer: $96.11
Average price per cow: $81.22

Indians are not likely to experience much difficulty in securing gainful employment during the winter months. Indian Agent Lovell, of The Pas, in a report dated November 6, reports that "there is a big demand for Indian help of all kinds. Fishermen, especially, are at a premium and some of the companies are offering our men $125.00 per month and board for fishing. This is the best rate of wages I have ever seen offered for this type of work. There is also a good demand for men to cut wood and work on the various construction crews. There appears to be plenty of work to keep everyone busy during the winter".

TRAINING

Inspector Moir, in his report on the Gordon's (C.E.) Residential School, Punnichy, Sask., refers to the difficulty experienced at this time by residential school
principals in securing fully qualified teachers. Inspector Moir states:

"On the day of my visit to this school two letters were received from two former students, now overseas. In one of these letters 39 was given as the number of boys serving in the present war. This is a commentary on the influence of the school and should be reason in itself for doing everything possible for these children. The staffing of this school remains a problem. One of the reasons seems to be lack of superannuation for teachers who would like to specialize in Indian work. Once these schools have a permanent staff of well trained teachers, good progress will result. Radio, moving pictures, well illustrated magazines - these must become part of the classroom equipment."

I have had an opportunity to discuss educational matters generally and the operation of our residential schools in particular with representatives of the Roman Catholic, Church of England and United Churches, during the last two or three days. These representatives have assured me that the principals of residential schools, with a few rare exceptions, are experiencing the utmost difficulty in financing their schools. This difficulty, I should state, is reflected in audit statements recently received by this Division. Indians appear to be vigorously opposed to the return of senior pupils to these schools. This refusal on the part of Indians can be easily understood and is due, no doubt, in part at least, to the fact that boys of 16 and 17 and girls of the same age are experiencing little difficulty in securing gainful employment. In the Prairie Provinces - so I have been informed - a large number of the senior pupils were kept out of school for harvesting operations.

Another difficulty confronting residential school principals is the securing of fully qualified teachers. I have been making a somewhat close check of reports received from public school inspectors on classroom work at residential schools and the qualifications and academic standing of the teachers in charge of these rooms. I am disposed to think, although I have not at the moment the exact figures, that approximately 65% of the teachers now employed at residential schools lack professional training. This, to me, is a rather serious condition and may be to some extent responsible for the lack of popularity of our residential schools in certain sections of the Dominion. In any event, this is a condition that should be remedied at the earliest possible date.

Representatives of the Churches, while deeply interested in the three year vocational course of study prepared by Mr. Doucet, remind me that they lack the accommodation and facilities to promote such a course of study with any hope of success. They remind me also that it is simply impossible, for the time being at least, to secure male teachers qualified to give such instruction. They have assured me, however, that an attempt will be made by the female teachers to do all that is humanly possible to give this instruction insofar as they are equipped to give it.

The following telegram has just been received from the Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Church of England:

"Regret inform you our Society's school main buildings at Onion Lake completely destroyed by fire this
morning. Staff and pupils safe. Outbuildings intact. Children being sent to homes. Will advise further when full report received from Principal.

The Onion Lake Church of England School is a government-owned institution and had at the date of its destruction by fire an authorized enrolment of 100 pupils. There was an actual attendance of 127. The following schools destroyed by fire in recent years, have not yet been rebuilt: Alberni classroom, File Hills classroom, Caribou senior school, Carcross residential school (C.E.), Fort George residential school (C.E.), Onion Lake (C.E.) residential school and Back Settlement Indian day school, Carcross agency. Unless provision can be made for the rebuilding of these schools at an early date, the problem of finding sanitary and adequate accommodation for our steadily growing Indian school population will become increasingly acute.
