Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended January 31, 1944.

WELFARE:

A campaign of criticism - one might refer to it as a campaign of vilification - has been directed against the administration of Indian affairs with steadily growing intensity during the last three or four year period. The records before me indicate that this campaign began in British Columbia, when articles signed by Mrs. Glynn-Ward (Mrs. Howard) appeared in the daily and weekly papers of that province. These articles became so scurrilous that the R. C. M. P., without direction by this Department, investigated the activities of Mrs. Howard, with the result that a number of the B. C. papers refused to publish her articles on Indian administration. Mrs. Howard then began an attack in the Montreal Herald and Weekly Star and in a number of Old Country publications. It would appear that copies of her letters and articles appearing in the Montreal papers were distributed to certain prominent Indians throughout the Dominion and have been taken quite seriously. More recently, it would appear that this campaign has been taken up in the province of Alberta by one John Laurie, Principal of the Crescent Heights High School, Calgary. Mr. Laurie appears to have written a special article entitled "Any old clothes for the Indians" which appeared in the Calgary Herald on January 7. In addition to this article, Mr. Laurie has appeared before the members of the American University Women's Club in Calgary and delivered an address, a summary of which appeared in the Calgary Albertan of January 11, under the heading "Cites horrible conditions under which Indians live". Mr. Laurie has also appeared before a local group of Canadian university graduates in Calgary and delivered the same address.

Major MacKay and Inspector Schmidt, with whom I have discussed these articles and this unfair publicity have pointed out that it is comparatively easy to attach too much importance to such articles. I have a feeling, however, that misleading information supplied to Indians in this way, with no corresponding attempt on the part of the Department to correct the impression created, has a tendency to shatter the faith of the Indian in our educational institutions, in our Indian agents and generally in the work of the Department. It is significant that during the last two year period we have experienced the utmost difficulty in persuading Indians to send their children to Indian day and residential schools. Is it possible that the faith of the Indian in the schools provided by the Department - never very strong - has been somewhat weakened, if not wholly shattered, by this propaganda? Mrs. Howard, for example, has directed her attacks
particularly to conditions on Indian reserves and Indian schools in the Cowichan agency, and during the last year the attendance at the Ste. Catherine Consolidated School has been so unsatisfactory that we have on more than one occasion seriously considered the desirability of closing this school, the largest and best equipped Indian day school in the Dominion.

I have referred on more than one occasion to the difficulty experienced in securing from Indian agents worthwhile reports on fishing operations in their agencies from year to year. You will be glad to learn that a number of reports have been received during the present season and that these reports are, without exception, satisfactory and encouraging. Indian Agent Swartman, in a letter dated January 8, 1944, states:

"I have recently been in communication with Mr. F. W. Bowman, of Hudson, regarding results of commercial fishing operations conducted by our Indians at Lac Seul and Osnaburgh during the present season. I believe the Department would be interested to have some of the details.

"The principal catch was taken on Licenses held by the Lac Seul Band and Indians of Treaty 9, residents of Lac Seul, and also the Osnaburgh band at Lake St. Joseph. The Lac Seul Indians caught a total of 506,675 lbs., for which they received $49,259.64. The catch this year included jack fish, tulibees and eel-pouts as well as 69,399 lbs. of suckers, which were previously discarded. During the season ten more of the Lac Seul Indians fitted themselves out with small gas boats, which now makes a total of 30 gas-powered boats owned and operated by the members of the Lac Seul Band.

"In addition to the above $12,000.00 was paid to the Osnaburgh Indian fishermen. No exact record of the Indians' catch at Lake St. Joseph is obtainable at present, as their fish were shipped out along with those operating on other licenses. This sum, however, was divided amongst about 15 or 20 families, fishing regularly during the summer months".

Mr. A. J. Goodman, in a report on fishing operations at the Fisher River Agency, submits figures indicating that 17 Indians, fishing on Lake Winnipeg, had a fish catch amounting to 64,905 pounds, for which they secured $5,604.55.

Mr. Goodman has also submitted a report on fishing operations in The Pas Agency. In this report he states:

"There was some fish put up and frozen during the late fall at this agency but none cured to keep for any length of time. To do this curing, Mr. Lovell suggests that a full-time man would have to be employed to instruct and demonstrate and encourage the Indians for a long time. This emergency stock of fish should be put up and cured in early spring and late fall only when the weather is at least very cool. If the fish at these seasons is properly cured, salted, smoked and dried, it would keep for an indefinite length of time. I am reasonably certain that if we can get the Indians started at curing fish and meat for themselves, it will not only save money for the Government, but to a great extent..."
raise the standard of living and health of the Indians themselves. Wherever I happen to be during the early spring and late fall, I will demonstrate to Indians and half-breed settlers how best to cure fish and meat and at the same time demonstrate to them how to treat nets in and out of use, mending them and storing them properly between seasons.

We are frequently critical of certain groups of Indians for their refusal to assume the duties and responsibilities ordinarily associated with right living and democratic citizenship. In this connection a somewhat encouraging report has been received from Indian Agent Anfield, of Bella Coola. In this report Mr. Anfield states:

"It is thought that the Department would be interested in seeing how well these Indians handle their band projects. The secretary and treasurer are both graduates of the Alert Bay Residential School, and it was a pleasure to check their accounts and find everything so well kept.

"These Bella Coola people have a grand community hall, which they are constantly improving and in which they take tremendous pride. They elected new officers at the annual meeting and the most interesting feature of the evening was the keen election fight among some of the youngest men to be at the top of the poll as janitors. This tribe start the young men of 16 or 19 as janitors, on the understanding that they will work their way up through the other offices such as floor manager, stockkeeper, ticket collector, secretary, treasurer and hall president—a real example of democratic living. In recording the votes, I was impressed by the fact that in every instance the older men would cast their own ballot for some other than their own son or younger brother—a rather fine gesture."

It is encouraging to be able to report that despite the large number of Indians employed by white farmers during the last two crop years, enlistments and the number of Indians who have secured employment in war industries, there has been a substantial increase in the acreage under cultivation on our reserves and a substantial increase, as well, in the actual amount of grain, vegetables and live stock produced. Last spring and early summer, a number of brood sows were purchased and distributed to a number of agencies in Saskatchewan, on the understanding that Indians receiving these sows would contribute an amount of pork or bacon equivalent to the value of the sow received, for ration purposes. The first report on this experiment, dated December 29, 1943, has been received from Mr. Christianson. This report reads as follows:

"I have asked for a statement in this regard from every agency that was supplied with hogs, and am now in receipt of one from the Crooked Lake Agency, setting forth the following information:

White Bear Reserve—5 sows were supplied at a cost of $185.00; 4 sows farrowed and 27 young pigs raised.

Okanagan Reserve—3 sows were supplied at a cost of $90.00; 2 sows farrowed and 12 young pigs raised.

Kahkewistahaw Res.—1 sow was supplied at a cost of $30.00; and 8 young pigs raised.

Cowessess—
Cowessess Reserve - 2 sows were supplied at a cost of $60.00; both farrowed and 12 young pigs raised.

Sakimay Reserve - 2 sows were supplied at a cost of $60.00; neither farrowed, consequently no young pigs were raised.

"Pork returned for ration purposes amounted to 1935 lbs. The total number of young pigs raised in the agency amounted to 59. The sows that did not farrow this year have been bred again and there will be 900 lbs. of bacon to be delivered next year from those who had no increase this year. From the 13 sows purchased 9 farrowed and raised 59 pigs. Therefore, for a beginning in this agency, we did not do badly".

It will thus be seen that the project has been reasonably successful in the Crooked Lake Agency and is likely to result in a substantial reduction in the amount of ration bacon for this agency.

TRAINING:

I have, on more than one occasion, expressed the view that teachers in charge of Indian day schools should be classified as welfare and training officers and should be employed, not for a 10 month, but for a 12 month period, less the 15 days regular holiday period granted members of the Civil Service. It is interesting to note, in this regard, that Inspector Tomlinson, one of the most experienced public school inspectors in the province of Saskatchewan, in his report dated November 26, 1943, supports this proposal. The Inspector states:

"The good effect of the earlier opening (September 1) is quite evident. When times get back to normal, it would seem desirable to consider the teacher's job as a twelve-month one, with the usual Civil Service vacation. The many opportunities for service on the reserve, by the teacher, are always in evidence".

I can only add, by way of comment, that it is particularly regrettable, in view of the production campaign we are seeking to promote this spring, that we shall not have the assistance and leadership of our teachers during the two important months of the crop year.

The following excerpt has been taken from the "Indian Missionary Record", published in Saskatchewan:

"Since the outbreak of the war, we have recorded the number of 55 men and women, ex-pupils of the Duck Lake (R.C.) School, who have volunteered in His Majesty's Services - 47 men and 8 women. It was realized that 9 out of the 47 men were rejected on account of their health by the Military Medical Board. Thirty of the boys are now overseas, serving in various countries, and one girl, Pte. Mary Greyeyes, who served with the C W A C for the past two years five months. Letters are received from these ex-pupils regularly, in which they state that their general health is good."

Evidence, in respect to the difficulty experienced by residential school principals in securing qualified teachers and in financing these institutions, is steadily
accumulating. The St. George's (C.E.) School, at Lytton, B.C., has at this date an enrolment of 180 pupils and receives a per capita allowance of $460. In addition to the per capita grant, it receives approximately $5,000.00 annually, as a special grant from the New England Company, London, England. There are 14 residential schools in the province of British Columbia, and only two others, in addition to Lytton, receive a per capita grant as high as $180. The Lytton School is in charge of the Reverend C. F. Hives, who has had 30 years' experience in the administration of residential schools, at Lac la Ronge, Sask., Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., and Lytton, B.C. In a letter dated December 26, 1945, Mr. Hives, in an outburst of discouragement, writes:

"We have just disposed of Christmas Day, with 70 pupils in bed with the Flu. No nurses available, in spite of all our efforts to secure one. We have no laundress, and last week I had to personally take charge of the laundry work, with two girls to help. At present we have one cleaner. Our man went down with the Flu and since his recovery left for Vancouver, where his wife is very seriously ill. I have had to be up at 4 and 5 o'clock in the morning to look after the heating of the building, which at present resembles a hospital. We have no farm manager and I have had more outside supervision work to undertake. I do not like to sound so much like a one-man orchestra. How long one can stand the strain, I don't know, but conditions cannot get much worse. The chances are they may improve.

"In reply to your anxious letter of the 21st instant, I beg to report that owing to illness, pressure of work and shortage of staff, I was late in making out my October financial statement. It is the first time I have ever been late, and anyone who has the faintest idea of what I and others have been going through since the commencement of the term, in the matter of epidemics of measles, whooping cough and Flu, will recognize some justification for the delay.

"You state in your letter that the Department are showing some concern over the financial situation of our school. I admit it is not at the present time a paying concern; but at least we are not in debt, if one takes into consideration our current surplus. When I took over the administration of this school, there was not only no current surplus - there was a large indebtedness.

"In regard to the salaries being in arrears, I have never been later than the third or fourth day after the end of each month. I used to pay salaries before the end of the month, but so many of the staff held their cheques over that I had to carry them as cheques outstanding. I have had considerable difficulty in securing staff workers, who are generally of an unreliable type. They come and stay for a week or so and leave as soon as they hear of higher wages elsewhere. I have had to raise all salaries twice during the present year, and still they are low, compared with the general rate of salaries in the province, and we are short-staffed.

"I feel sure the Department realize that the present financial assistance we receive is quite inadequate to meet the needs of present day demands. The only way I
know of to make that financial assistance suffice is to cut down on the food and clothing received by the pupils and put more boys to work instead of hiring extra labour; but we should not do these things. At least I would rather leave than do them. Fifty cents per day, which we receive as our per capita allowance, seems altogether too small, compared with two dollars per day, allowed at the hospitals; and yet most of these children require a great deal of care and certainly more nourishing food than they now receive.

The chaplain himself, in his statement some time ago, along with the information regarding the diet these children should be receiving, are all very fine and, I have no doubt, required a great deal of time and expense to produce; but we cannot carry them out simply because our per capita grant allowance is not sufficient to enable us to do so. Our school is not unique in this respect. If a survey were made of all the schools, I have no doubt one would find that very few schools come anywhere near to what the pupils should be having in the way of nourishment. Several times, staff members have come here from other schools and I have enquired of them about the way Indian children have been fed at schools where they were employed. The diet we supply is, if anything, a little better than at the majority of our schools, because we have the advantage of tomato juice and fruit; but I would certainly like to see our regular meals improved.

"I assure you, sir, it is not my intention to be disrespectful, and as the Department are inclined to be critical of our financial situation and worried about matters, it is just as well if they hear my views on the subject. I have been in this work for 30 years and know pretty well what I am talking about. A careful survey should be made of all the schools, if possible, by people who have a thorough and practical knowledge of what is best for the welfare of residential schools".

In view of the difficulty we have experienced, and are still experiencing, in securing teachers and janitors at Indian day schools, and particularly men for janitor service in British Columbia, we are, as officials, perhaps somewhat fortunate that the Churches and not the Department are called upon to operate our residential schools in this crisis. One case was the resignation of Mr. MacKenzie, whose principalship has retired as the result of ill health during the last two years. Three outstanding principals have retired during the present academic year: Reverend M. de Bretagne, Principal of the Cu'Appelle School at Lebret, Sask.; Reverend R. C. Scott, Principal of the Alberni School, B.C.; and Reverend J. P. Mackey, Principal of the Shubenacadie School.

Everything considered, the outlook for our residential schools is in no sense encouraging.

On the other hand, Indian day schools, despite the difficulty we have experienced in securing fully qualified teachers, appear to be doing reasonably good work. The following excerpt is taken from the Vancouver Sun, January 3, 1944:

"St. Catherine's School at Duncan, Christie Indian School at Kakawis (west coast of Vancouver Island) and the Inkaneep School at Oliver (Okanagan Valley) have each received awards for entries submitted through the Society for the Furtherance of B. C. Indian Arts and Crafts and displayed..."
at the Canadian Handicrafts Guild annual exhibition held this fall in Montreal and Quebec. First prize for applied work was awarded to Inkameep School for excellent paintings on buckskin, some of which had already received awards in the Royal Drawing Society's exhibitions in London, England.

First prize for design and second for applied work went to Christie Indian School for examples of native designs and fine beadwork. A special prize was awarded St. Catherine's Consolidated Indian School for unusual examples of woodwork. Individual prizes were won by Madeline Charlie of St. Catherine's School for a beautifully knit sweater and by Mrs. Johnny Jackson of Kakawis for a finely woven basket.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended February 28, 1944.

WELFARE:

I have referred on more than one occasion in my recent reports to the attempts made by this Division, during the last two-year period, to encourage hog production on a number of reserves. In this connection the reports received during the last two or three weeks from Saskatchewan indicate that the experiment undertaken at a number of agencies in the production of hogs has been reasonably successful. Mr. Christianson, in a letter dated February 22, 1944, reporting on the raising of hogs at the Qu'Appelle Agency, states:

"Regarding the sows that were furnished Qu'Appelle Agency last Spring, as you know Mr. Booth is without a clerk and looking after two agencies, but I have at last been able to get a statement on the hogs that were supplied to his agency last spring.

16 sows were supplied last Spring, as follows:

Assiniboine Reserve - 6 from which there were 37 young pigs raised;

Pasqua Reserve - 4 from which there were 29 young pigs raised;

Muscowpetung Reserve - 2 from which there were 15 young pigs raised;

Standing Buffalo - 4 from which there were 27 young pigs raised;

"To sum up, there were 16 sows supplied to the Agency from which 106 young pigs were raised. 4,303 lbs. of pork are being delivered to the Agency and there are still 429 lbs. of pork to be delivered.

"THIS IS IMPORTANT. The 1,008 lbs. of bacon in the estimates for Pasqua need not be shipped. The same applies to the 1,008 lbs. for Muscowpetung and the 1,050 lbs. for Carry the Kettle. The Agent claims he has enough to carry on at the present time for these three reserves, but the bacon for Piapot and Standing Buffalo is to be shipped as requested in the estimates. When more bacon is required for the three reserves which are not getting any in the first shipment, you will be advised. We want to make as
big a saving as we possibly can. Personally I think that this venture at Qu'Appelle Agency has been very satisfactory because the Indians themselves have sold a lot of pork and they have sold some young sows to other Indians. Some of them have also kept another sow for breeding purposes from the young pigs that were raised.

"In talking to Mr. Booth he informs me for the present they have all of the pigs they can handle until the Indians become more hog minded but for the first year I think you will agree with me that the Indians have done mighty well because evidently they sold 160,000 lbs. of pork. There are, also, of course, a few Indians who purchased hogs themselves.

"I hope I have made myself quite clear."

Inspector Hamilton, in his report dated February 1, on the Peguis Reserve (Fisher River Agency) states:

"The cattle returns show 354 head. The cattle seen were in good condition and the Indians claim to have enough feed.

"Pigs are now kept by 10 people, turkeys by 8 and chickens by 45. Those who have no grain purchase it at the agency from the community farm crop. The supply of surplus grain available at this farm has already stimulated a desire on the part of the Indians to keep more poultry."

"One Indian who had three ewes last summer raised 6 lambs. ..... A few years ago we purchased two spinning wheels and paid a teacher to give the Indians lessons in spinning. Today they have five additional wheels, all purchased by individual Indians. Already, they have knitted up all their raw wool and are hoping to have more next year. Our venture on this reserve with sheep has proven helpful and the flocks are increasing slowly. There are others anxious to get a start, and if funds are available in our 1944-45 estimates I would like to purchase 12 head. The cost will amount to approximately $145.00.

"This band of Indians purchased 50 good work horses during the summer months. There are at least 15 Indians driving good teams who never before owned a horse. These horses have greatly added to the earning power of the Indians. They can now haul their own wood instead of paying others to do the work."

The Peguis Reserve has at this date a population of approximately 1039.

Inspector Hamilton in this report also refers to conditions at the Fisher River Reserve. He states:

"The stock returns on this reserve show 280 head of cattle, all in good condition...... Two Indian families have pigs, eight have chickens and one has five ewes. Of those having chickens, three have over fifty.
The others have flocks of from 20 to 40. The Indians on this reserve, however, are practically all fishermen. They reported a good catch for the early part of the season, but the run has now slowed down and many were lifting their nets at the time of my visit. The Indians have requested permission from the Provincial Government to fish in Lake St. George and two other nearby lakes for jackfish. Jackfish are now worth from five to six cents per pound.

Two seasons ago a machine for the baling of straw was purchased at the Caradoc Agency. The baler was purchased in the hope that a market would be found for the surplus hay and straw produced on the reserve. Reports received from the agent to date indicate that this purchase was amply justified. In a report dated February 4 Mr. Down states:

"Another phase of agriculture during the month of January has been the pressing and baling of straw and hay. I have been able to keep four or five Indians working and more than 100 tons of straw and several tons of hay have been already baled. When one considers that a little over two years ago most of the straw grown on the reserve went up in smoke, I think that our initial expenditure for the baler has been justified. Certainly, the lessons taught suggest sound agricultural practice and not without profit.

"Our willow plantation during the month received some attention by way of cleaning out rows and the spreading of barnyard fertilizer. The young canes look strong and healthy, although I would prefer to see a blanket of snow covering the roots, especially during the months of February and March."

It is particularly gratifying to report an actual increase of cattle at the Battleford Agency. Indian Agent Ostrander, in his last report, states:

"There is a slight increase of cattle on all reserves, with a resulting fairly good increase for the whole agency. There is also a considerable increase in work horses on most of the reserves. A fairly large number of Indians have good work horses at the present time. All live stock have had a good winter as the weather has been very favourable. There will be many breeding sows carried over for breeding this year, and the whole project of hog raising, which was started last year, has been reasonably successful. This project has been the subject of a special report."

TRAINING

The utmost difficulty has been experienced throughout the year in securing the number of teachers necessary to keep our Indian day schools open and in
operation. Despite the fact that we have employed a number of elderly teachers, lacking both professional and academic standing, we have at this date 12 schools for which we have not yet obtained teachers. We did succeed, however, during the course of the month in securing a fully qualified teacher for the St. Clair School, Sarnia Agency. This school will re-open on March 1. We were fortunate in securing a teacher at this particular time, especially in view of the fact that a number of Indian parents were urgently requesting us to make provision for the transportation of their children to the public schools in Sarnia. If this provision had been made, it would have been necessary also to pay substantial tuition fees to the Sarnia School Board.

One of the teachers in charge of an Indian day school at the Caradoc Agency submitted her resignation during the month. It is significant and somewhat difficult to understand why we have experienced so much trouble in securing teachers at this agency during the last two or three year periods. The reason is, as you know, comparatively close to the city of London and is in no sense isolated. Residences, however, are attached to the schools and teachers are expected to live in these houses. The majority of teachers appear reluctant to live and work steadily amongst Indians when other schools are available.

I have already referred to Inspector Hamilton's report on the Fisher River Agency. In a reference to the Indian day school, Mr. Hamilton states:

"In this school we have Miss Smith Windsor in charge of the senior room with 33 enrolled, and Miss MacCall in the junior room with 43 pupils. The attendance has been fair but there is room for improvement. A number of Indians have been camped with their families near the lake where they are fishing and consequently the children were unable to attend school. Most of these people, however, have now moved back, so that the attendance should improve.

"The pupils are well along in their respective grades and the work seen was well done and neatly set down. I am certain the children are making good progress. The pupils were all well dressed, many with dresses, skirts, coats and windbreakers made from army clothing. These were all neatly remodelled, and the average person would never know the material was from old army clothes. The sewing club, under the direction of Miss Smith-Windsor, has done excellent work."

Inspector Bowes, in his report on the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School, dated November 25, 1945, states:

"Primary Room - Beginners are making satisfactory progress. This is a typical primary room and is well equipped with primary material. The pupils are divided into three groups. The Grade One class has been in school a year and progress is satisfactory. These pupils were making progress equal to that of a foreign child with one year in this grade. In all divisions, discipline was good."
The pupils were polite and industrious. Number work was far beyond the work required in the usual Grade One class. Sister Louise Margaret, who has a certificate from the Nicolet Training College, is a valuable addition to the staff of this school.

"Intermediate Class - General progress in this class is very satisfactory. Spelling was above average. Language was good. Reading was clear, distinct and each word carefully pronounced. Singing, excellent. Pupils were orderly. Sister St. Hippolyte, who is also a graduate of the Nicolet Training College, continues to do efficient work in this room."

Senior Room - Sister Celine du Carmel, a graduate of Nicolet, acts as principal of the school as far as the academic work is concerned. She is very capable and the Indian pupils in her room were making excellent progress. Reading and language work were well advanced. Pronunciation was above expectation. Mathematics was good in all grades. The general tone of the classroom was excellent."

The Onion Lake School has an authorized enrolment of 100 pupils.

Inspector Campbell Innes, in his report on the Thunderchild Indian Residential School (Battleford Agency) of December 13, 1943, states:

"Kindergarten - Sister Loretta - This teacher has a fund of excellent ideas which effectively rouse her pupils to put forth their best efforts. Steady progress is made in improving the language. These children are learning the language through socialized activities. The classroom plays are most helpful. This kindergarten classroom should furnish a splendid foundation in the basic habits. Physical education - Socialized games are well developed and carried out in an orderly manner. Art is quite well correlated and has a large place in the program.

"Primary Room - Sister Colette - This teacher appears anxious to improve her classes. She is ready to explain and to drill. The drill may be more challenging with an understanding of her pupils. The instruction should be natural and influential. The lessons may be developed a little more to secure more understanding and observation. Oral reading is quite good in word recognition and in articulation. A variety of songs are sung. There is good tone. Health exercises are given to interpret rules. Work books are generally neat. Pupils are covering the course in arithmetic. They are drilling for accuracy.

"Intermediate - Sister Saint Cyr - First Class certificate. This teacher appears quite capable of preparation of material to meet the needs of her pupils. I found them quite courteous, interested and fairly responsive. A good effort is made to cover the course. This teacher is responsible for the subjects of arithmetic, spelling, reading and physical education.

Senior Room - Sister Marie de Galilee - Here is a very interesting and pleasant classroom in which
the pupils are trained to live and think together in order to accomplish a definite purpose. All subjects have received equal attention. Every effort is made to understand the needs of the pupils and to train them to work with initiative, originality and self-reliance. I was pleased to note that language is stressed at all times - reading, reciting, debating. I was also pleased to note that the activity work is so effectively used to encourage the real meaning of the subjects. The new program for Indian schools now includes cooking, leather work, knitting, housekeeping, gardening, sewing, wood work, poultry, metal work and dairying. The pupils have a number of lessons in each. They have an opportunity to earn certificates and badges covering three years' work. I was pleased to see at this school a good open-air rink, toboggan slides and swings. The pupils have the use of a radio."

The Fishing Lake Indian Day School (C.E.) has been in charge of the Reverend Alex. J. Lawes since 1922. Mr. Lawes' wife is also an experienced teacher. Inspector R. E. Sparkes, in his last report on this school, states:

"The improvement noted in my last report has been continued. It seems to me that Mr. Lawes should be encouraged to attend another refresher course during the next year or two. It would provide him with the assistance he so badly needs.

"Simple and interesting songs are rendered with all the children taking part. Good use is made of the blackboard for making essential assignments for seat work.

"Reading - By the use of simple readers it should be possible to secure greater fluency and expression in rendering the selections. The pupils appear to have some idea of the meaning of the pieces studied, but the response is poor. The children seem restrained as though afraid to speak out plainly. Phonics, however, continue to be successfully drilled. Penmanship is very good. These children write quite legibly. Construction work is partly under the control and guidance of Mrs. Lawes, who is an experienced teacher. The type of work presented was excellent, but a greater degree of self-determination should be provided."

Reverend F. O'Grady, Principal of the Kamloops (R.C.) Residential School, in a letter to the Indian agent dated February 19, 1944, refers to the vocational courses undertaken by the pupils at the school. The Principal states:

"While the technical training of the boys consists chiefly in the proper use of hand tools, the older boys are very anxious to learn the operation of power tools, the knowledge of which will be very useful to them after school. This year the boys, under the direction of the manual trainer, have undertaken the project of making 20 spinning wheels, which will be given to the senior girls..."
graduating in June. The girls have become very proficient in the carding and spinning of wool and it is felt that if they are given spinning wheels to take home with them they will make good use of such equipment and will thus benefit by the training they received at school."

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended March 31, 1944.

WELFARE:

It is difficult to resist the temptation that besets one in the preparation of this, the last monthly report for the fiscal year 1943-44, to compare conditions on Indian reserves as we have come to know them throughout the year with conditions prevailing on these reserves prior to the outbreak of the war. It can be said that Indians have enjoyed a greater measure of prosperity throughout the year than they have experienced perhaps at any preceding period in their history. Indians have found little, if any, difficulty in securing work at satisfactory wages; in fact, the demand for Indian labour far exceeds the supply. The prevailing prices of farm products, the high prices being paid for furs, the extension of fishing operations by Indians on the Pacific Coast and the rabbit cycle, which this year appears to be at its peak, have all contributed to the prosperity of the Indian.

There are still a few districts, however, where relief costs at this date are practically as high as they were during the depth of the depression, in 1936. These districts consist in the main of northern agencies, such as Abitibi, James Bay, Sioux Lookout, Norway House and Lesser Slave Lake. It would appear that the Indians at these agencies have not the skill, training or temperament to take advantage of employment conditions. They are usually referred to as hunting and trapping Indians and are likely to remain so for a great many years. Relief costs in such areas are not likely to be reduced until provision is made by the adoption of long-term policies for the replenishment of wild life, upon which these Indians have depended until now for a livelihood. It is somewhat difficult to escape the feeling that the administrators are devoting altogether too much time to the Indians who are living in the southern sections of the country and who, for the time being at least, are capable of looking after themselves, and not enough to the hunting and trapping Indians, who undoubtedly have a greater and more legitimate claim on the assistance we are in a position to render. For example, it seems difficult to justify free education, free medical care and hospitalization for Indians such as the group at Caughnawaga when one learns that large numbers of these Indians are earning $20.00 a day or more in war industries.

The prosperity to which I have referred in my opening sentences does not appear to be fully reflected
in our relief and welfare costs. Relief and welfare expenditures for the period April 1, 1943, to February 28, 1944, amounted to $547,741.36, compared to an expenditure of $544,170.94 for the corresponding period of last year. This represents an increase of $3,570.42. I attribute our failure to still further reduce relief expenditures to a number of factors the significance of which is apt to be forgotten. We made, last year and this year, substantial expenditures from welfare funds in the purchase of land. The purchase of this land represents capital outlay and should in my judgment be charged to the Reserves and Trusts Division. Again, we have taken over the operation of community farms that were financed until 18 months ago from trust funds. In addition to these expenditures, the program of tuberculosis control, promoted in recent years by the Medical Division, has resulted in additional expenditures from the Welfare Vote. Patients discharged from sanatoria throughout the country require, for a year or two after discharge, food supplies such as milk, eggs, fruit, etc., that do not ordinarily appear on our relief schedules. These are granted in each case on the recommendation of the local medical officer. To withhold such supplies from Indians during their period of convalescence would undoubtedly retard their recovery and thus result in their return for hospital treatment. Finally, we have, during the last two year period, spent more money on the purchase of livestock, particularly purebred bulls, in the West, and herds of goats in the East. We have spent substantial sums, as well, in the purchase of pigs in Saskatchewan, in the construction of brooder houses and the purchase of poultry in Ontario and Quebec. It is gratifying to note that despite the large number of Indians who have found work in the United States and an equally large number who have found work in our own war industries, production on Indian reserves throughout the country was substantially increased during the year. Reports recently received from Indian agents, missionaries and teachers indicate that field officials, with few exceptions, are responding with enthusiasm to the plea made in our circular letter on production, sent out with the accompanying chart on February 15.

Indians continue to take a keen interest in the work of the Red Cross Society. Inspector Hamilton, in a letter dated February 25, sent forward an excerpt from a communication received by him from the teacher at the Little Saskatchewan Indian Day School. In this excerpt the teacher states:

"I thought you would be interested to know what some of our Indians are doing in regard to the war effort. Our Women's Organization has sponsored several little sales, Saturday evenings, with the result that we have donated $10.00 and $15.55 to the Red Cross, $18.00 to the starving Indian (Hindu) Fund and today I am sending $100.00 to the Red Cross, the net proceeds of a social evening held on the reserve".

The following summary is taken from the Regina Leader Post of February 7, 1944:

"Indians of the Pelly Agency, near Kamsack, raised $279.00 during 1943 for philanthropic purposes. Of
the $279.00 raised, $84.00 went to the Red Cross, $15.00 to the Greek War Relief, $15.00 to the Milk for Britain Fund, $35.00 for Soldiers' Christmas boxes and $110.00 was raised to send cigarettes to men of the reserves who are in the Armed Forces. Fifty knitted articles and 36 articles of clothing were made by the Homemaker's Club for overseas parcels. Another phase of the Indian war effort is seen in the $900.00 worth of Victory Bonds purchased on the reserve during 1943."

You may remember that a few months ago Mr. Arneil and Mr. Morris organized two or three Homemakers' Clubs on the Iyendina Reserve. The Anglican Missionary on the reserve, the Reverend Herbert Pringle, in a letter dated March 21, states:

"The Homemakers' Clubs are already a great success on the reserve and the members look forward to the meetings and take great delight in remaking garments. I have been in several homes where the clothes from the clubs have been received and the parents are most grateful. Every Friday during Lent we go to the Eastern School for a special service for the children at 6 P.M. The Homemakers' Club meets at 6 o'clock each Friday and the members will stay for this service. When I suggested a Homemakers' Sunday service in the Church with Corporate Communion for the members and a special sermon relating to homemaking, the members took up the idea with enthusiasm and have chosen the first Sunday in July as their day."

Indian Agent Down, in his monthly report dated March 3, states:

"You are aware, of course, that we have five Homemakers' Clubs organized at this agency. All have been visited during the month and the continued interest and appreciation of the material supplied by the Department is very pleasing. The useful purpose to which it is being put must be seen to be appreciated. One class alone has made and distributed more than 50 bed quilts, another 20, and so on, and all these quilts are made from small cuttings. In other words, the leaders of these clubs are making use of every piece of material. Other types of clothing of every description are made for children of all ages. Teachers report that they never saw the children so well dressed. This is certainly a credit to the expert needlecraft of the women. During the month many finished articles were brought to the office for inspection and at times the office resembled a clothes store, but I am always interested and the women are always proud to show their work. There is another interesting point that must not be overlooked and that is that these classes are teaching young girls to sew and remodel every type of discarded garment. In many instances young women have made complete dresses with very little help or instruction from their parents. As I watch these women work and note their interest in producing something for themselves, I cannot help but visualize the
possibilities behind these organizations. With proper guidance and a good selection of leaders, their efforts can be guided into many channels of usefulness and education.

I have referred on one or two occasions to the attempts we were making to encourage the raising of hogs on a number of reserves in Saskatchewan. This experiment to date has been all that one might expect. Indian Agent Simpson, in his report dated March 1, states:

"John P. Sanderson & Son, Gilbert, shipped 17 hogs to the market recently and realized $500.00 from the sale thereof. These Indians expect to have 8 more ready for market within a fortnight. Two other members of this reserve expect to have 16 or 19 hogs fit for market about the same time."

TRAINING:

Early in the month Mr. Doucet inspected the Indian day schools on the St. Regis, Caughnawaga, Pierreville, Restigouche and Maria Reserves. Mr. Doucet is, as you know, primarily interested in the encouragement of vocational studies at our schools. During the course of this inspection trip, however, he made scientific tests on reading and other related subjects. Mr. Doucet is definitely of the opinion that the courses of study provided are more suitable for girls than for boys and that girls on the whole appear to make greater progress in classroom work. This is a condition that can only be corrected by the employment of more male teachers and it is not at all likely that such teachers will be available until the end of the war. Mr. Doucet will undertake the inspection of schools on a number of reserves in Eastern and Northern Ontario immediately following the Easter vacation. It is his intention, also, to attend the Provincial Conference of Teachers, held in Toronto during the week ending April 15.

An unusually encouraging report was received from Inspector W. J. Greening immediately following his inspection of the Kenora (N.C.) Residential School on March 5, 1944. The Inspector stated:

"This school has inaugurated this year a new system whereby the very young pupils are enrolled in a special class and given an opportunity to secure practice in oral English. I think this is an improvement as last year the junior teacher had too much to do.

"It is noted that two new teachers have come to this school this year from Crooked Lake. As both of these teachers have professional certificates from the province of Quebec, all three teachers on the staff have full professional standing - something of a record for schools in my district west of the Great Lakes.

"I do not think that I have ever before been so pleased with the work being done at this school,"
especially so in the senior class. A great deal of attention to written English must have been given to her classes by the Sister teacher, Sister St. Janvier. I was able to demonstrate for the benefit of this teacher some ideas in the correcting of mistakes in written English, something that I am not too sure previous teachers in this grade would have been able to appreciate.

The following news summary has been taken from the Calgary Albertan, February 15, 1944:

"Loyalty was again intensified when St. Paul's Residential Indian School (C.E.) (Blood Reserve) won the January prize in the savings stamp drive open to all schools in the Cardston district and fostered by the Cardston Rotary Club. Far in excess of the allotment, somewhere near 600¢, was the amount sent to St. Paul's School. This followed a similar prize won by the St. Mary's (R.C.) School in the month of December. The two Indian schools have been the main winners throughout the district. One of the Indian Chiefs at the celebration, on Friday, said: 'Red Indians; red blood; win the war and Indian help a lot'. The rest of the district salute the two Indian schools for their splendid achievement.

The school cadets, under the leadership of Lieut. Charles Middleton, gave a demonstration of their gun handling. In the school music room, after the flag was dropped by the bomber which circled the school and dipped its wings, a program was rendered under the direction of Ven. Archdeacon Middleton. Eighteen Rotarians sat on the platform with Chief Cross Child and Chief Percy Crighton, Chief Cross Child in a speech interpreted by Chief Freighton, said he welcomed everyone and hoped that the Indians' efforts will help win victory soon. The Rotary president, Sterling O. Low, officially presented the flag to Canon Middleton. Gordon S. Brewerton, one of the Rotarians having charge of the Indian School Campaign, gave a message of appreciation and congratulation. Father Charron, of St. Mary's School, gave a short address. The Indian Agent, Mr. McMillan, thanked both schools for their achievements."

The resignation of Miss A. McGinty, teacher in charge of the Shubenacadie Indian Day School, was received during the month. It is not at all likely that a teacher for this school can be secured at this comparatively late date in the academic year. The closing of this school is likely to create a certain amount of dissatisfaction amongst Indian parents who moved to the reserve on the understanding that educational facilities would be available for their children. We can only express the hope that immediate steps will be taken toward the construction of the new day school on this reserve and that the building will be ready for occupancy at the beginning of the next academic year.

Father J. W. Brown, who was appointed principal of the Shubenacadie Residential School immediately following the resignation of Father Mackey toward the end of the last calendar year, visited the Department early in the month. Father Brown assured us that he would be glad to provide
accommodation for at least two teachers at the residential school, should it be found possible to proceed with the construction of the building during the summer months.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended April 30, 1944.

WELFARE:

Brief reports from Mr. Morris, who has already visited the Peigan, Blood, Blackfoot, Sarcee and Stony Agencies, indicate that spring operations on these reserves have been delayed as the result of unfavourable weather conditions. Mr. Morris was particularly impressed with the herds of livestock on the southern reserves. It would appear from his reports that there has been an abundance of feed throughout the winter, with the result that the cattle are in splendid shape.

It is just possible that in my reports to you during the last two or three years I have not dealt as fully as I might have dealt with live stock production at our Indian agencies, particularly live stock production in the Prairie Provinces. The fact that I have not done so was, in part at least, due to our emphasis on the organization of goat herds in the East and the purchase of pigs for distribution, particularly in Saskatchewan, and such matters as the organization of Homemakers' Clubs, etc. May I state, however, in this report, that there is no phase of our welfare work to which I have given as much attention during the last eight years as I have given to the promotion of the live stock industry on our Indian reserves. The large acreage on a number of reserves, particularly in the West, lends itself to the expansion of this industry without involving us in much capital outlay. I have already referred in a special report to the organization of a special herd at the Blood Agency. A somewhat smaller herd was organized at the same time at the Peigan Agency and is doing reasonably well. Mr. Christianson, in a letter dated April 11, refers to the revenue derived throughout the year from the sale of live stock in Saskatchewan. In this report Mr. Christianson states:

"As for live stock sales, the revenue from cattle was $76,200.00 for the year, compared with an amount of $70,000.00 for the preceding year. Including cattle beefed, the total value of cattle disposed of by the Indians was $84,150.00, which was a substantial increase. The cattle sales averaged $62.50 per head. The cattle population on the reserves during the year has increased considerably. For instance, the Black Lake Agency reports an increase of around 80 head within the year and the Touchwood Agency, 110 head. Financial assistance was given, either from government appropriation..."
or band funds, in the purchase of pigs, with the understanding that the Indians getting this assistance were to turn in pork from pigs raised, value for value. The reports have been very satisfactory and many Indians participated in the venture. The Duck Lake Agency, in their live stock statement of March 31, report that 25 hogs were butchered and 275 sold. The Carlton Agency have raised over 500 hogs, and although I have not the exact figures from the other agencies, I know this project has been a success."

It is interesting to know that the value of cattle alone disposed of during the year in Saskatchewan was equal to $6.47 a head of the Indian population.

The interest taken in our circular letter, emphasizing greater production, dated February 15, has been very encouraging. Archbishop Sinnott, in a letter dated February 28, states:

"I have written to all the Indian missionaries under my jurisdiction to back and support by every means in their power the campaign on Indian reserves. The idea is such an excellent one that we must all get behind it. I hope that next year it will meet with still more satisfactory results."

Dr. H. A. Alderwood, Secretary of the Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C., in a letter dated February 26, states:

"I have to thank you for your letter of February 15th and have taken note of what you write. I have also studied with interest the chart sent out by the Department to all field officers. I may say that in my visits to our schools I have been very pleased with the efforts being made to increase production and assist in meeting the expenses of the school in this way. ...... You may rely upon me to get this matter before our agents and to stress the aspect of attention in the matter of self-support."

A few weeks ago Mrs. Irene V. Gougeon, assistant supervisor of the conservation program directed by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, interviewed us with the object of securing samples of military and R.C.M.P. clothing remodelled by the members of our Homemakers' Clubs. Mrs. Gougeon expressed the opinion at that time that a display of this clothing would go a long way to stimulate white women to undertake somewhat similar tasks. In a letter dated April 18, 1944, Mrs. Gougeon states:

"You will be interested to know that I have taken your display to several places in Ontario and Quebec and have found that the women were most enthusiastic and interested in the work you are doing. It is indeed surprising to find that so many have never heard of the work being done to organize Indian women. I expect to have finished with the garments toward the end of May and will return them to you. I found them very helpful in rounding out my demonstrations."

In this connection I was interested in a report which appeared in the evening edition of the Ottawa Citizen about two weeks ago. In this report the writer stated:

"More than 100 interested women attended the Remake Revue in St. Mathias Hall, Fairmont Avenue, on Friday evening, which was under the auspices of St. Agnes Guild.

"This was part of a nation-wide program, sponsored by the Consumer Branch of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board, under the direction of Mrs. Irene Gougeon, assistant supervisor of clothing conservation for Canada. The keen..."
interest displayed by the women attending was ample proof that these remake centres are filling a long-felt need on the part of young mothers for advice and help in making over used and partly worn garments for growing children as well as adults. A special display from the Department of Indian Affairs attracted a great deal of attention. These garments were made from discarded uniforms and included several hand-made quilts.

It is regrettable that despite the influence of our schools and the conscientious service rendered by missionaries, reports received from time to time indicate that conditions on certain reserves are profoundly discouraging to anyone interested in the cause of Indian betterment. Dr. J. P. Harvey, of Fort Norman, N.W.T., in a recent letter, states:

"I have long been aware of conditions at Good Hope and have several times in the past mentioned these conditions in my reports. Between snuff and chewing tobacco, there has been nearly a ton used there for each of the past few years. The use is universal. I can name some of the people who customarily empty two cans of snuff per day. The children begin smoking and chewing at extremely early ages. I have seen them barely able to walk, toddling along with a cigarette in their mouth - not cigarettes picked up on the trail but given them by their parents. I cannot help but attribute some of the extremely high mortality among the children to this cause. At various times the possibility of invoking Chapter 129 C.C.C. or a health ordinance has been discussed with the local policeman, but the opinion is that it would have to include the entire band and is hence deemed difficult.

"I miss no opportunity when in Good Hope to stress the evils of chewing tobacco on pregnant women or nursing mothers and on the young, but there is absolutely no response. I am quite satisfied that if we are to try to stop it, this will have to be done by Order in Council, prohibiting the sale of these commodities completely. The use of chewing tobacco is prevalent along the river, slightly less being used further north. The use of snuff is centred pretty well at Good Hope, but the use of both is increasing at all posts.

"Had I my own way, I would prohibit the traders from handling snuff, chewing tobacco and also factory-made cigarettes. I would also notify wholesale houses who fill Indian orders in the territories that the sale of these commodities is prohibited to Indians."

Mrs. Dewdney, wife of the missionary at Fort McPherson, N.W.T., in a letter dated March 1, states:

"We have no police here and the police at Red River pay actually very little attention to this place. We have what constitutes a very serious health menace and I would like some advice. When the people are away from the fort, there are main centres where they gather. The first one is for fishing at the mouth of the Peel River, about 25 miles down from here. There are dozens of tents and a number of small houses in a very small area on top of the river bank. In summer it is a village in..."
itself, but a village with no regulation at all. Hundreds of dogs are tethered down the bank and around the tents and houses. Dog excrement lies all over the place and on any trail you may take into the bush the place is utterly filthy. I have asked and asked the Red River police to do something, but nothing is ever done. The mouth of the Peel is the chief breeding ground for tapeworm. The dogs are the hosts and I believe that sooner or later almost everybody living there gets it."

For the first time since I entered the Department, 74 years ago, I received this month a letter of appropriation from an Indian. I was so surprised and startled by the receipt of this letter that I decided to incorporate it in my monthly report. I may explain that a few months ago Mr. Arnell and Mr. Morris succeeded in organizing a number of Homemakers' Clubs on the Tyendinaga Reserve. At the time of their visit, they learned that Mrs. Margaret Brant had lost her son as the result of military action overseas. Mr. Morris extended his sympathy on behalf of the Branch and brought back with him a photo of the deceased soldier. This picture was a small and indistinct snapshot, and we decided to have it enlarged, as a token of our appreciation to Mrs. Brant for her leadership on the reserve, and Mrs. Brant received the enlarged picture in due course. In a letter dated April 8, 1944, she states:

"First, I would like to thank you very much for the picture you so kindly sent us of our son Lloyd. We are all so pleased to have it, and as time goes on it will be all the more valued. Our family appreciate your thoughtfulness and kindness in sending it to us.

"I am leaving my monthly report of the Homemakers' Clubs with Mr. Moore, to be sent to you. I am pleased the Clubs are doing so well. All the members work harmoniously together and we greatly enjoy our weekly meetings. The members will continue to meet weekly until the busy season starts. Kind regards and many thanks for all your help."

TRAINING:

Three residential school principals and two Indian day school teachers resigned during the month. I have already dealt somewhat briefly with the resignations of the residential school principals in memoranda to you during the last two week period. The resignation of the teacher in charge of the Rama Indian Day School was particularly unfortunate in that she had in her class three pupils proceeding toward their Entrance Examinations in June. In view of this fact, we decided to amalgamate the two classes at the United Church Indian Day School on the Caughnawaga Reserve and transfer the senior teacher of that school, Miss Daly, to Rama. Miss Daly has reported for duty at the Rama agency.

So many discouraging and depressing reports have been received recently from the principals of residential
schools, that it is a real pleasure to be able to submit excerpts from a report that appears to be satisfactory in every sense. The Public School Inspector, Mr. A. F. Matthews, in his report on the Kamloops Residential School dated April 10, states:

"As stated in my previous report, the main building of the Kamloops Indian School provides adequate accommodation for the staff and the 256 pupils enrolled at the school. The building is clean, comfortably heated, well lighted, and well ventilated. The classrooms are large, bright and airy and contain adequate seating accommodation for all the pupils.

"The instruction carried on in the girls' classes is particularly effective. The teaching Sisters in charge of these classes have had professional training and successful experience in their work. Their pupils are alert and responsive and are making good progress. The training given in manual arts and in industrial activities, generally, is well conducted and practical in its application. The teachers in the boys' division are without professional training or previous experience in this work. Father O'Grady is finding it extremely difficult to obtain experienced, qualified teachers and is obliged to accept whatever he can obtain in the way of instructors.

"The various classrooms are fairly well supplied with equipment. However, science equipment is lacking for experimental and demonstration work in the upper grades of the school. Additional supplementary reading material, suited to the various grade levels, would be very helpful.

"The school grounds are large and well adapted for playing fields and are well equipped for recreational purposes. Under Father O'Grady's direction, improvements to the grounds are continuing. The farm in connection with the school appears to be well managed and conducted with business efficiency. This farm is well stocked with herds of beef and dairy cattle, horses, pigs, hens, etc., and is the main source of the food supply for the school. The produce of the orchard and small fruits and vegetables are canned in large quantities for use at the school.

"As reported last year, vocational training is receiving a large measure of attention at this school. In the case of the boys, one-half the school day is spent on vocational work and the other half in the classroom. The new manual training building, built by the boys, is well equipped for technical work and is a decided asset to the school equipment. The boys are now being trained under a competent vocational instructor in wood and machine work with definite objectives, such as the making of spinning wheels and other equipment for the school. Training of a practical nature is given also in shoemaking and repairing, dairy work, care of dairy animals, cattle and farm work generally. The girls are getting a good practical training in domestic arts and kindred subjects. They make their own uniforms and dresses and are proficient in knitting, fancy needlework, sewing and spinning. A very practical side of their training is the practice given them in cooking, fruit preserving and ordinary household duties. The dining rooms are clean and well cared for. There appears
to be a plentiful supply of good, wholesome food. The tables are clean and artistically arranged.

The utmost difficulty has been experienced this year in securing certain equipment at a number of our schools. The teacher of the Caughnawaga R.C. Day School, in a letter dated April 14, states:

"This is a personal plea. As you are aware, the meter on our oil furnace at the teachers' residence burned out on March 19. Since that time we have been using wood to heat up the house, but with poor results. Yesterday and today have been miserable days, the temperature in the residence being between 54 and 58. Mr. Bush, the caretaker, is doing all he can, but we cannot ask him to be on the job 24 hours a day. Therefore, a Sister fills up the furnace every hour or so. Couldn't you possibly do something to help us out? We can assure you that we would appreciate heat, since all this year has been a year of suffering from lack of heat, either at the school or at the residence. I feel that the Sisters' health is suffering from this. Nearly all of them have had severe colds and sore throats and one at this date is suffering from double pneumonia. Please come to our rescue."

The records indicate that a requisition for a No. 36-72 AE Gurney steel steam heating boiler was sent forward to the Purchasing Division on January 17, 1944. Attached to this requisition was a quotation from the Gurney Foundry Company to Mr. Brisebois. It is my understanding that the Gurney Foundry Company, Limited, in a letter dated December 29, 1942, intimated that they were prepared to supply a boiler suitable for this school approximately one month after the receipt of the order.

You may remember that immediately following the opening of the Coqualeetsa Hospital the desirability of providing part-time instruction for the younger patients receiving treatment at the institution was carefully and sympathetically reviewed. It was finally decided to employ two fully qualified teachers at this hospital. We are now in receipt of the first inspector's report on the educational work provided for these patients. Public School Inspector H. MacKenzie, in his report dated April 1, 1944, states:

"A very great experiment in educational effort is being successfully carried on at the Coqualeetsa Indian Hospital. Children who are hospital cases and not permitted to leave their cots are being taught to make normal progress in the fundamental school subjects. Ordinary classroom procedure is of course precluded. Very thorough work is being done by Mrs. Robertson in Reading, Language Development, Arithmetic, Spelling and Writing and, so far as source material makes possible, in the Social Studies. Mrs. Robertson's teaching is characterized by very genuine kindness and sympathy as well as energy and enthusiasm. Miss Flynn, the junior teacher, displays a good knowledge of modern techniques of teaching and is moreover kindly, sympathetic, of buoyant manner and thoroughly energetic in the conduct of her work. . . . .

"To broaden the subject fields in teaching and to ensure greater progress and efficiency, I would recommend the following:

1. Movable framed blackboard. Where cots are
placed along more than one wall, it is impossible for the children in the cots to see a fixed blackboard.

2. (a) A much greater supply and variety of readers and textbooks;

(b) A reasonable supply of textbooks on Health, Elementary Science, History and Geography;

(c) Materials for manual and graphic arts;

(d) Radio, so that these children may benefit from the Provincial Department of Education broadcasts in Music, Social Studies, Health and Science;

(e) A gramophone with suitable records especially leading to music appreciation;

3. Visual Aids. A motion picture machine, 16 mm projection film or one of the many smaller less expensive types is of vast assistance in classroom teaching. To these Indian children the visual appeal makes the strongest impression, and visual aids by means of one of the many types of machines would be exceptionally helpful in this splendid work you are carrying on at the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital.*
