Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended May 31, 1944.

WELFARE:

Unusual expenditures, for which no provision has been made in the estimates, may, unless the utmost care is exercised, result in a substantial deficit at the end of the present fiscal year. I have in mind the purchase of the woodlot, a few weeks ago, at Oka, at a cost of $14,000; the erection of a school at the new Calstock Reserve, Ontario, at a cost of $6,500; and an addition to the Kettle Point School, Ontario. This addition is urgently needed to provide for the pupils formerly enrolled at the day school on the Stony Point Reserve, now leased to the military authorities. In addition to these expenditures, we have now under consideration the desirability of purchasing a reserve for the Brunswick Band of Indians in northern Ontario. However, no funds have been provided for this purchase and I am very doubtful if the amount can be provided from the welfare vote. Teachers' salaries will likely show an increase during the academic year ahead of us. As a matter of fact, we have now before us recommendations from two inspectors in Ontario, suggesting that we fix a minimum for our Indian day school teachers of $1,200.00 next year. Whether or not we fix such a minimum, I am convinced that unless salary increases comparable to the salaries now being paid in the public schools are paid by this Branch, it will be exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to secure the number of teachers necessary to keep our schools in operation. A number of our teachers have already intimated that it is their intention to resign at the end of the present school year.

I am bringing these matters to your attention early in the year, as I am naturally anxious to avoid any misunderstanding with respect to Welfare and Training expenditures toward the close of the present fiscal year. In the meantime, the greatest care will be exercised in working out our welfare program. As a matter of fact, we have already reduced our expenditures on the purchase of live stock, goats, pigs, etc., and the purchase of farm machinery, which is exceedingly difficult to secure. As against this, however, Mr. McCrimmon has recently taken into treaty six or seven hundred Indians at Rocky Mountain House, Alberta, and has already wired for the machinery necessary to start the members of this band in farming operations. It is just possible that the additional expenditure required to provide for the needs of this band during the present fiscal year will amount to
approximately $8,000.00.

A disturbing report on the loss of 64 head of cattle at the Alexander's Reserve, Edmonton Agency, has recently been received from Inspector Schmidt. The Inspector, in his report dated May 23, states:

"Farming Instructor Conway was sick in hospital at Edmonton and off duty entirely for 25 days during the months of December and January last. He is still not well and says he cannot now ride horse-back for any length of time. When this man was admitted to hospital I asked Indian Agent Laight to give Alexander's Reserve especial attention and asked him to make a very careful count of the live stock and to carefully check all departmental property."

It would be interesting to trace, if we could, the relationship between the farming instructor's absence from the reserve and the loss of the cattle. In addition to the inspector's reference to Mr. Conway's illness, there are other features of his report which are far from satisfactory. The Inspector states:

"Mr. Conway says that he thinks all the cattle are branded 'I.D.' The last round-up was made on October 15, 1942, but very few Indians - two or three only - were there to help with this work, and apparently all the cattle were not rounded up at that time. A proper round-up and check of the cattle has not been made during the past winter, 1943-44."

Anyone familiar at all with the live stock industry in the Prairie Provinces and particularly in Alberta, realizes fully the importance of branding. When we are careless in this regard we are simply inviting disaster. The brand is the only means we have of identifying either departmentally-owned or Indian-owned cattle. Inspector Schmidt's reference to the fact that the census of cattle made in recent years may have been somewhat faulty is not wholly convincing. The evidence now before us certainly indicates that there has been gross neglect in the administration of affairs on this reserve, and the loss of 64 head of cattle, at an approximate value of $8,400.00, is certainly a serious blow at a time when we are putting forth a supreme effort to increase live stock on our western reserves. I have a feeling that the absence of the farming instructor from the reserve was in no small way responsible for the disappearance of the cattle. I suggest that serious consideration be given to the advisability of extending to our inspectors in the Prairie Provinces the right to make temporary appointments or to employ temporary help without reference to Ottawa, when farming instructors are absent from their reserves as the result of illness. The old contention that long distance farming invariably leads to bankruptcy is likely to be borne out in the case of our farming operations in Western Canada. You may remember that a few years ago we lost 160 head of cattle at Hobbema as the result of our delay in the appointment of the Indian agent now in charge at the agency.

You may remember the difficulty experienced by this Division a few years ago in securing from undertakers throughout Canada a reasonable rate for Indian burials. In this connection it is encouraging to learn, from a
report recently received from Indian Agent Bonnah that
the Indians of St. Regis, under his direction, have organ-
ized for the burial of Indians on reserves on a co-
operative basis. The Agent in his report states:

"We have in active operation two Casket Lodges,
viz.: Chenaill Casket Lodge and Cornwall Island Casket
Lodge. A trustworthy and aggressive member of the Band
accepts the responsibility of raising the cash and looking
after the general business of the Lodge. At Cornwall
Island, Mr. Peter Thompson is the business manager; while
in the Chenaill, Mr. Richard Sunday conducts the business
for the Chenaill District, St. Regis Village, St. Regis
Island and other islands in Lake St. Frances in the
Province of Quebec.

"Both Lodges are non-profit cooperative enter-
prises, managed, owned and operated entirely by the Indians.

"Voluntary membership is accepted by both Lodges
and at the death of a member of the Lodge, the living
members contribute, what we might term, a death per capita
assessment. In the case of the Chenaill Lodge, the death
assessment is fifty cents (.50) for each active member.
On Cornwall Island (Ontario) where the membership is small,
the per capita is slightly higher; seldom exceeding seventy-
five cents (.75). The only time a levy is made is at the
death of a member.

"In cases where a member has lapsed in his per
capita assessment for a period of from one to five years,
and if death intervenes, his relatives have the privilege
of paying up back assessments, thus putting the deceased
in good standing as a participating member of the Lodge.

"A casket to the value of forty-five dollars
($45.00) is supplied for each deceased member. In the case
where a relative of the deceased desires a more decorative
casket, he or she is at liberty to purchase the same through
any undertaker, and, in this event, a cash amount of $45.00
is contributed by the Lodge. The overcharge is paid by the
deceased's relatives and is not the responsibility of the
Lodge.

"It must not be construed from the above that
our Lodges purchase the finished casket through any outside
firm. In fact, it is very seldom that one of our Indians
would even consider a "hand-me-down" casket for one of their
deceased. As a result by far the greater majority of
caskets are made right on the reserve by Indian labour. It
is the Lodge Manager's duty to see that sufficient dry
lumber, outside, covering, satin lining and hardware are
on hand at all times for the completion of at least eight
high quality caskets. Such materials are purchased whole-
sale through reliable firms and, in accordance with true co-
operative principles governing service organization, are
paid for in cash when delivery is made.

"It is my hope that in the near future both our
Lodges can be united and an intensive membership campaign
put over to obtain new members. Upon completion of this
campaign an accurate survey will be made and if found
necessary a request will be forwarded for a small advance
to enable us to enroll these destitute cases, within
certain age groups, in lieu of departmental contribution
towards complete funeral costs for destitute Indian burials."
Mr. Christianson refers in his report on the Assiniboine Reserve, Qu'Appelle Agency, dated May 2, to a speech delivered by Dan Kennedy, a member of the Assiniboine Band. This speech was delivered at the time of Mr. Christianson's visit and is described by him as the highlight of the meeting. This Indian, Dan Kennedy, pointed out that his family, which consists of himself, his son and several sons-in-law, produced last year 12,000 bushels of grain. He claimed that he was not quite satisfied with this and that the members of his family should really have produced more. He reminded the Indians that a lot of them were out stocking and working at harvesting and threshing for the white man whereas the white man should be working for them. He declared that the Indians had a gold mine on their reserve right at their feet, for which they paid no taxes, and in addition, received education and medical care. This should enable the Indian, he declared, to produce cheaper than the white man, and he was convinced they could do it if they would only buck up.

Mr. Christianson adds: "Naturally, some of the Indians did not like this lecture, but everything Dan Kennedy said was true. These Indians have a very fine reserve if they would only buckle in and take advantage of their heritage."

**TRAINING:**

Mr. Phelan visited the Sarnia and Six Nations Agencies during the week ending Saturday May 27. While at Sarnia he undertook a survey of the educational facilities at Kettle Point and in his report recommends that a one-room addition be built to the Kettle Point School. Mr. Phelan intimates that this work can be undertaken during the vacation period by Indian labour at an approximate cost of $8,500.00. It is our intention to proceed with this work.

While at Six Nations, Mr. Phelan discussed very fully with the recently appointed public school inspector, Mr. Webster, our educational program on the Six Nations Reserve. The Inspector expresses the view that it would be a mistake to provide high school instruction at our schools with the exception of Grade 9, that might be provided for a limited number of pupils. It is the Inspector's opinion that Indian pupils who pass Grade 8 should be encouraged and assisted to take up high school courses at the public, high and vocational schools in the adjoining white communities. A large proportion of the Six Nations pupils, in his judgment, should be attending high school at Brantford or the Brantford Vocational School. In the estimates of this year we have an additional $5,000 with which we hope to assist a larger number of the more promising pupils at Brantford and at a limited number of our other reserves. Mr. Phelan, in his report, states:

"Inspector Arneil, Superintendent Randle and myself arrived on the Six Nations Reserve at 9:30 on the morning of May 24. The children from the different schools on the reserve, together with the teachers, were already there and a lengthy program of competitive sports..."
was started immediately. This program was under the direction of Mr. Joseph Hill, one of our teachers.

"The competitions were held on the fair grounds and we remained there until 5:30 in the evening.

"There was very keen competition in all the events on the program, and during the whole course of the day I heard no complaints from any of the competitors regarding any decision that was made.

"The holding of this sports day was inaugurated some years ago by Superintendent Randle and very great interest is apparently taken in it by all the Indians. Late in the afternoon there were approximately 2,000 people on the grounds. Refreshments were served in the Agricultural Hall at noon by the members of the Six Nations Council and their wives."

Early in the month Dr. Moore and I interviewed Mrs. Allan Stevenson, National Director, Nutritional Services, Canadian Red Cross Society, and discussed with her somewhat fully ways and means whereby the Red Cross Society might assist in a nutritional survey at a number of our residential schools. It was finally agreed that Mrs. Stevenson would suggest to the members of her committee at their annual meeting on Tuesday June 6 that the Red Cross in co-operation with the Department become responsible for a nutritional survey at six representative Indian residential schools, with the object of determining the adequacy of the diet now supplied, from a nutritional standpoint. It was agreed also that she would suggest to her committee that a survey be undertaken at an Indian day school with the object of determining the best ways and means of providing a noonday lunch without encroaching unduly on the time of the teaching pupils. We adjourned the discussion on the understanding that Mrs. Stevenson would report back to us in due course. In this connection it is somewhat encouraging to note, in Mr. Christianson's last report on the Assiniboine Day School, a reference to the health and general appearance of the children in attendance. Mr. Christianson states:

"The children all looked well and appeared to be well dressed. I was informed by the teacher, Miss F. Hodgson, that the vitamin biscuits that are being furnished now by the Department are real good. A mid-day meal is given at this school. The teacher told me several of the children who were below weight when they came in the fall had gained during the winter time."

You may remember that about a month or six weeks ago a very critical report on conditions at the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School was received at the office of the Minister. The matter was very thoroughly investigated by Inspector Hamilton, who expressed the view that the charges were groundless and that good work was being done at the institution. I am now in receipt of a report from the Public School Inspector, Mr. R. S. Burney, on this school. This report is on the whole satisfactory, indeed one might say, rather encouraging. In reporting on the senior room, the inspector states:

"Mrs. Douglas this year is teaching Grades 5, 6, 7 and 8. Mrs. Douglas is doing good work. She is greatly interested in her work and is quite enthusiastic that two
of her pupils will be writing the Entrance examinations this year. Her pupils have been working at Health Posters, which are being done very neatly and carefully. The writing and art work is remarkably good. In my opinion it is the influence of Mrs. Douglas that produces such wonderful results in Art throughout this school.

"The pupils are making good progress in their studies. They speak and read well for Indian children and do well in Arithmetic. The pupils are clean, healthy and neatly dressed. There is every indication that they are being well looked after in this school. The classroom is clean and bright and the classroom material is put to good use. This year there are no men on the teaching staff. The manual training equipment is not being used because there is no teacher qualified to provide instruction in this work."

I have referred to the Caradoc Reserve, Munsey, Ontario, on more than one occasion, as the problem reserve of the Dominion. In making this comment I had uppermost in my mind welfare matters such as relief, housing, sanitation, drainage, noxious weeds, etc. I am convinced that we are rapidly reaching a time when this reserve will also become recognized as the problem reserve of the Dominion from an educational standpoint. It is unnecessary to refer to the condition of the residential school, ordinarily known as the Mount Elgin Institute. This school remains one of our most acute fire hazards. It has long since outlived its usefulness. We have, however, a number of well built, fully modern day schools on the reserve. Inspector Gordon Young, in his last report on these, dated May 25, states:

"Unfortunately, the schools on this reserve have had a very discouraging experience. Mrs. Schuyler and your agent disagreed so entirely that Mrs. Schuyler retired in the fall. Mrs. Gillespie succeeded her but has also retired, leaving the River Settlement School without a teacher.

"Mrs. Batesman was in charge of the Bear Creek School during the fall. I called several times on this teacher as I visited public schools in the district and got the impression that she was doing good work. Family reasons, however, forced her retirement at Christmas and Mrs. Gould, the present teacher, was not secured as her successor for several months.

"These difficulties have been greatly aggravated by a scarcity of qualified teachers. Just now the salaries paid to Indian day school teachers are so much lower than those paid to teachers of public schools that I believe conditions on this reserve will be worse in September. I therefore recommend that salaries of Indian teachers be raised to a minimum of $1,200.00 per year at once. This should certainly be done in the case of Mr. Richardson and Miss Sibbald. In addition to this, the agent and the inspector should be directed to get together at once on this educational problem. Neither one alone can cope with the problem as it is at present, nor can the two of us do much if salaries are not increased."

An interesting item on a graduate of the Chapleau (Anglican) Residential School appeared in the Chapleau Post of April 29. This article reads:

"John Jeffries, a graduate of the St. John's Indian Residential School and Chapleau High School,"
spent last week end in town, visiting his people and the Indian school. He is on his way West to take up work for the summer as a Student Missionary. He has been invited to return to the work he started last summer and will soon be on his way to Loon Lake, Saskatchewan.

"He has completed his third year at Wycliffe College and passed in all his subjects this spring. Shortly before leaving college he was presented with a very nice Cassock and Surplice as the student chosen by his college as the one most helpful in the general student life of the College, especially in the spiritual side of college life. John Jeffries will be honoured as the boy chosen as one of two Indian boys in Canada to represent the Indians of Canada at the Coronation of King George VI.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL.

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended June 30, 1944.

An event of the month was the convention of so-called Indian Chiefs, held at Ottawa during the week ending June 10. This is the second attempt made within the last two year period by Jules Sioui, of Lorette, and Andrew Paull, of Vancouver, to organize an Indian convention at the Capital. Indian delegates to the convention of this year informed me that the attendance was greater than the attendance at any preceding convention.

One could put up a convincing argument, I feel, for the organization of Indians. Indians, like other racial and minority groups, in this age of organized effort, may require an organization for defense and for legitimate aggression. I have a feeling, however, indeed I might say a conviction, that the Indian organization, the officers of which were recently elected at Ottawa, can do little, if anything, in the interests of Indian advancement but can cause the Department endless trouble and annoyance. Indeed it can be said that we are already witnessing or experiencing certain repercussions from the last convention. A request comes for the payment of a tuition grant refused by the Department but now recommended by Jules Sioui. A letter reaches the Minister from the Port Arthur Agency, asking for fulfillment of his recent promises. Mr. Down, of the Caradoc Agency, visits the Department and expresses surprise that the Indians were granted official recognition, in view of the circular letter sent out to agents, repudiating the convention and the leaders who were attempting to organize it.

I have learned from experience that it is not easy in a democracy to withhold recognition from certain groups, particularly certain racial groups. It would appear, however, that even a semblance of recognition tends to shatter the prestige and authority of our Indian agents. The Superintendent of United Church Missions in British Columbia, Mr. Bunt, who visited the Department a couple of months ago, informed me that the Native Brotherhood in that province had passed almost out of existence until the report appeared in the Press that Andrew Paull had been received by the Acting Minister at Ottawa. Immediately following this announcement, there was a regular stampede, so he informed me, on the part of the Indians to join the Association. Incidentally, he received a telegram from the Coast, while here, informing him that Andrew Paull had been
suspended from the organization, allegedly for the misappropriation of funds, and asking him to permit the Reverend Andrew Kelly (an Indian) to take over the secretoryship. Would it not be possible to come to an agreement whereby Indians would not be received by the Government unless accompanied by Indian agents or Indian inspectors? If this is considered impossible or inadvisable, I am definitely of the opinion that letters, denouncing these conventions and repudiating the leaders, should not be sent out.

Why are the Indians anxious to visit Ottawa? The answer to this question will largely depend on the Indian to whom the question is put. John Ioctocosis, of the Battleford Agency, a young and fairly intelligent Indian, who visited this Division, came to Ottawa, so he assured me, because Indian agents had lost all power and authority. The Indian agent, so he said, has not as much power or authority as the average Indian. I informed him that if Indian agents had lost all power and authority, the Indian had the right to appeal to the provincial inspector. "But the provincial inspector," he replied, "has no power; just talk." No Indian agent or inspector had exercised power or authority in Saskatchewan since the days of Commissioner Graham.

Chief Eagle Chief Mosquito, of the Battleford Agency, an elderly Indian, who could not speak English or at least who did not speak English, in his interview with me, was very much interested in a bronze Indian head that he observed on my desk. This Indian head has a hollow centre, designed for pen nibs. Gazing on this Indian head, he burst into uproarious laughter. When I enquired what he was laughing at, he replied, through the interpreter: "Now I have discovered a perfect model of what the Department thinks of an Indian - just head - no brains!" and while he said this he put his index finger into the cavity of the model. Then he was quite somber for a moment and again burst into laughter. When I enquired again for an explanation of the laughter, he replied: "I am a very old man. I have only a few years to live. I should spend these years in search of a model that will illustrate what the Indian thinks of the Department. I know now what the Department thinks of the Indian".

Whatever the Government of Canada has accomplished for the Indians - and they appear to have accomplished a great deal - we appear to have failed to retain their confidence and esteem, if indeed the Government has ever enjoyed these. Suspicion of the Department on the part of the Indians was very much in evidence during the course of the interview. In this connection I recall to mind a statement made by Colonel Carnichael of the Pensions Board. He had visited a large number of Indian reserves in Canada, with the object of interviewing Indians in receipt of pensions. He was amazed, so he informed me, at the bitter, hostile attitude of the Indians to what he referred to as officialdom. Is it not possible that the first step in a worthwhile Indian welfare program might well be the creation of a measure of confidence in the consciousness of the Indian in what the Department is doing and attempting to do, particularly a measure of confidence in the authority and sincerity of the Indian agent?
I found the requests of these Indians somewhat interesting. Tootoosis, who appeared to speak for the group, asked for the immediate establishment of what he referred to as non-religious Indian day schools. He was not opposed, so he said, to religion but it should not be forced down the throats of the Indians. He asked also for the establishment of a community hall in which Indian women could meet for the remodelling of clothing and for the discussion of timely topics. They had a Homemakers' Club on his reserve, that did good work. "When we go to church," he stated, "we walk along the road together; then we divide, each group going to his own particular church, but when the members of the Homemakers' Club go to a meeting, they all go to the same place and work together." It was his opinion that it would be a great pity if religion divided the Indians in the same way that it appears to have divided white men. "But I am not opposed to religion," he concluded, laughingly, "although it does not seem to have done the white man much good." I was anxious to learn from him where he got these progressive ideas. I had in mind ideas relating to the establishment of a community centre, the discussion of timely topics etc. He admitted that he had got a number of them from white farmers for whom he had worked. White farmers, he claimed, had been educating themselves and would soon take over the government of the provinces and ultimately the government of the whole country. My interview with this group left an impression on my mind that these Indians are thinking and should be provided at all times with intelligent, sane, progressive leadership.

A number of interesting reports have recently been received from Mr. Morris, who is, as you know, engaged in an inspection of Indian agencies in the Prairie Provinces. In his report on the Grouard (R.C.) Residential School, dated May 14, Mr. Morris states:

"The children at this school are in good health and well clothed. Steam baths are installed and are very effective. Twelve senior girls, under the supervision of one of the Sisters, are living in a house apart from the other living quarters, where they are taught domestic science and housekeeping in a practical way—cooking, cleaning, sewing, and in fact everything that is done in the average home. This is good work and training such as this should prove very beneficial to the girls after they leave school. Father Forcade's handicraft workshop is a rather substantial building of log construction. The women, many of whom are Indians, are becoming experts. The finished slippers, gloves, bags, etc., compare with the best manufactured anywhere. The Grouard Co-operative store occupies one end of the building and is doing a good business. This store is badly needed in this outlying, isolated district and will undoubtedly develop in time and become a real financial success."

Somewhat discouraging reports have been received during the month on the condition of certain day and residential schools.

Commissioner MacKay, in sending forward the public school inspector's report on the Cariboo Residential
School (R.C.) states:

"It would appear that unless the Oblate Order, under whose auspices this school is operated, is in a position and is willing to provide a standard of accommodation in keeping with present day requirements, consideration should be given to the closing of this school and to the provision that might be made for the construction of Indian day schools to serve the needs of the Indian population."

Inspector McArthur, in his report on this school, states:

"As I reported last year, the buildings are old and are not well suited to present day needs. The classrooms are small and have insufficient and poorly placed window space. Electric lights partly compensate for inadequate natural lighting. During the year the old chapel was converted into a gymnasium and assembly hall. Although the room is rather small, it makes possible some physical education and provides space for assemblies during the winter months."

Inspector Hamilton, in his report on an inspection of the Pas Agency, dated June 15, states:

"Pine Bluff - Inspector recommends the construction of a new school and teacher's residence. The present buildings are built of logs and are in poor condition.

"Big Eddy - The teacher's residence at this school is badly constructed and small. After the war a new house should be built. The school itself is in poor condition.

"Shoal Lake - This school is of log construction and should be replaced after the war. The teacher's residence is in good condition.

"Red Earth - A new school should be erected here after the war. The teacher's house is in fair condition but requires repairs.

"Grand Rapids - This school is of log construction and small and is in poor condition. This building should be replaced just as soon as funds are available.

"Chemawawin - This school is past repair and should be replaced at the earliest possible date. The teacher's residence should be painted inside and out. The foundation requires repair."

Mr. Morris, in his report dated May 27 on the Ermineskin (R.C.) Residential School, Hobbema Agency, states:

"This is a very old school building, entirely unsuitable and in my opinion a dangerous fire hazard. If a fire were to break out in the middle of the night, with the temperature below zero, there is no doubt but that there would be a serious loss of life amongst the Sisters and the children. The place was spotlessly clean, however, and the remodelled..."
clothing and articles of handicraft were as good as anything yet seen on my trip".

Miss Bessie French, Principal of the Crosby Girls' School (United Church), Port Simpson, B.C., in a letter dated June 6, states:

"We are quite proud of ourselves this morning, for the mail has brought us word that we have been awarded the Oakesonton Challenge Cup for the highest standard of dramatic work achieved during the year. Of course, we are all delighted."

The following news excerpt is taken from the Vancouver Sun of May 29:

"Winners of the various prizes in the Victory Contest for 1944, sponsored by the Latham Foundation, have recently been announced. It is the godparent to many worthwhile enterprises for cultural progress and annually offers large sums of money and scholarships for art work of high merit. This year the Foundation launched its 16th poster contest for the Promotion of Humane Education.

"The animal poster contest is twofold in its purpose. It aims to encourage artistic proficiency and to inculcate in children everywhere the love and proper regard for animals and wild life. This group which is open to Grades 1 to 6 drew a great many entries from all over Canada and the United States. Four of the winners in this class were Canadians and two out of the four were Indian children living in British Columbia. Both winners are girls. Annie George is a pupil at the Indian day school at Penticton, and Helena Tiffin brings honour to the Christie Indian Residential School, on the west coast of Vancouver Island."

Criticism is offered from time to time for our failure to encourage the brighter and more promising Indian pupils to take up high school and vocational studies. I attribute this criticism to the fact that the number of Indian pupils engaged in high school studies does not appear in the statistical tables published from year to year in our annual reports. Reports received from a number of residential school principals indicate that a fair proportion of the pupils proceed with high school studies in adjoining high schools and collegiate institutes. Canon Kinchin, in his report on the Shingwauk Residential School, states:

"Ten of our senior pupils have been attending either the collegiate institute or the technical school, where they have done good work. Two of them stand first in their respective classes. Twelve of this year's Grade VIII students are being recommended for Entrance and most of these are hoping to go down town to school next year."

Katherine Middleton, in a recent article published in the Vancouver Province, refers to the attempts being made by the Department to establish goat herds at a number of northern reserves in British Columbia. Miss Middleton in this article states:

"Here is an interesting good-nutrition note, which is somewhat off the beaten path and has to do with goats and Indians on reserves.

It is -
"It is this way: Fresh goat's milk is strikingly similar in food value to cow's milk. Therefore, it offers a great deal in good nutrition. For this reason the goat is of particular value in remote spots where it is impossible to have a dairy cow but where the smaller and hardier goat will thrive. And so, out in British Columbia, the Indians on reserves are being encouraged to keep a goat, that is, two goats each to four families with children. This is being done through the Indian Department at Vanderhoof, B.C., and the first lot of goats have already been purchased. Some of the goats may find themselves as far as 100 miles north of this point, on the new Alaska highway.

"It seems that the Indians move back and forth for the fishing season and live in districts where it would not be possible to keep a cow. Not so with the goats, however, for there is usually lots of brush around the reserve as well as good greens for their food. And further, the Indian Department is arranging to take back half the increase in the goat population and these will be placed with more Indian families. This interesting story came to me through 'Country Life', a B.C. publication which briefly noted the news on this from 'The Blast' of Victoria, B.C. As one could expect, the latter publication has to do with the business of raising goats."

Indian Agent W.P.B. Pugh, of Saddle Lake, Alberta, refers in his last report, dated June 2, to the recent visit of Mr. Morris to that agency. Mr. Pugh, in commenting on this visit, states:

"A very enjoyable and instructive visit was received from Mr. J. E. Morris. Mr. Morris was here from May 18 to May 26. To have an official visit the agency and to go over the ground with the agent is as good as a refresher course. While we had bad weather which threw some of our plans out of gear, I think Mr. Morris saw a very good cross section of the agency. I thoroughly enjoyed his visit and help and information I received from him and I can also say this for the rest of the staff. I can only express the hope that he may be able to visit this agency again and that other officials will also come. I hope also that I can make a success of some of the projects he is anxious to start, and I think I can see some action in the making already."

An urgent call was received a few days ago from the Extension Service of the Alberta Department of Agriculture, for a group of Indians in a number of our northern agencies of that province whose help appears to be urgently needed to harvest this year's crop. We have asked Inspector Schmidt to discuss this matter personally with the Head of the Extension Service. It would appear, from reports reaching this office that crop prospects in Alberta at this date are the best that they have been at any time in recent years.

An encouraging illustration of real co-operation between an Indian agent and an Indian day school teacher comes to us from the South Western Agency, New Brunswick. The Indian Agent, Mr. E. J. Whalen, in a letter dated June 15, states:

"The Kingsclear Reserve has a large supply of wild apple trees which could be made into a very profitable..."
orchard, if the Indians could be persuaded to take an interest in these trees and graft and look after them, Miss Conners, the school teacher, and I got the children interested in grafting. During the season they put on 60 grafts. There are nearly all growing and I believe in a few years we will have the coming generation interested in grafting and looking after fruit trees. So far, however, the school children are the only ones interested, but if the graft survives the winter, I think the older people will become interested in this kind of work. We got the actions from the Dominion Experimental Farm and I was obliged to buy the materials and make our own grafting wax, as none of this was available in the area. I got the bees wax from the New Brunswick Beekeepers' Association, Inc., the tallow from the John Palmer Shoe Factory and the resin from the Neil Hardware store. I have enough wax to do another year."

An interesting item of information in this connection has also been received from Indian Agent R. L. Bonnah, of St. Regis. In his report dated June 2, he states:

Three thousand strawberry plants were received and distributed amongst a few Indians. Ninety-four apple and cherry trees were received and placed with certain Indians who desire to eventually go into fruit farming. Three hundred and five apple and cherry trees were received and distributed amongst the various Women's Clubs. Four thousand five hundred forest tree nursery stock were received and placed amongst Indians to assist them in future years. I have made arrangements with the Quebec Forestry Branch to send an expert here to survey the ground in anticipation of an extensive reforestation program on the Quebec side of the river. I hope I will have the time to devote to this matter, but at the time of writing it is very doubtful."

Mr. Bonnah, in this report, refers also to an experiment in poultry-raising. "Towards the close of the month," he states, "all of the second batch of chickens were distributed through the Women's Clubs. It was interesting to note that many of the skeptics took advantage of the opportunity to obtain the allotted number of chickens before they finally disappeared. Of the 1300 purchased the total loss was 94. In general, the Women's Clubs appear to be functioning well and with a minimum of dissension".

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended July 31, 1944.

WELFARE:

A few days ago I received from the Treasury a statement of welfare expenditures for the period April 1 to June 30, 1944. This statement, you will note, shows an increase of $15,671.86 over the welfare expenditures for the corresponding period of last year. Increases have taken place in all the provinces with the exception of New Brunswick, Saskatchewan and the Yukon.

It would appear that we have reached a stage when welfare expenditures cannot be further reduced. In other words, we appear to have a group of aged, physically incapacitated Indians, unable to provide for themselves, and the number of these is not likely to show a reduction but rather a substantial increase during the years immediately ahead of us. It is significant that this increase has taken place despite the fact that very few expenditures have been made during the period for the purchase of agricultural implements or for agricultural operations. The fact that a charge is now made for discarded military clothing represents an increase of $5,482.04. It is unnecessary to remind you also that an increasingly large number of Indians are being discharged from sanatoria. These discharged Indians, many of whom have received one, two and three years' treatment, require additional care and are usually supplied, on the recommendation of the doctor, with additional rations, such as milk, eggs, fruit, etc. The number of such cases is also likely to increase steadily in the immediate future.

It is difficult to escape the feeling that we are witnessing at this time a steadily awakening interest in our Indian population and in the administration of Indian affairs. The number of requests received by this Division during the months of this year for Branch reports far exceeds the number of similar requests received at any time since I entered the Department, now almost 8 years ago. In addition to this, interviews with Members of Parliament and phone calls from Members of Parliament, seeking information, have been steadily multiplying. The convention of so-called Indian Chiefs at Ottawa a few weeks ago was immediately followed by the organization of an Indian Rights Association in the province of Alberta, and we are likely to hear a great deal from this organization in the days that lie ahead of us. It is significant that the secretary of the association is Mr. John Laurie, a high school principal, of Calgary. Mr.
Laurie has already delivered a number of addresses on behalf of the Indians of Alberta. These addresses have received a great deal of publicity. It would appear that certain parties in Calgary have been circulating prominent citizens throughout the province on behalf of the Stony Indians. These Indians, under the chairmanship of Mr. Percy Gardner, of Pekisko, have engaged a firm of lawyers - Milligan and Millican, of Calgary, with the object of securing additional lands for the Stony Indians. In this connection you may remember that Mr. Christie also included, in the 1937-38 estimates an item for the purchase of additional lands for these Indians, but the item was later deleted, in the interests of economy. The correspondence on this matter would indicate that the outstanding need of the Stony Indians is land that will enable them to grow the vegetables necessary for their sustenance. The present lands - at least this is the contention - are subject to late frosts in the spring and early frosts in the fall, with the result that the production of vegetables is a very hazardous and uncertain undertaking.

The following excerpt has recently been taken from the "Wampum", a quarterly review of Mission work on the Indian reserves of Ontario:

"The Department of Indian Affairs can no longer hope to satisfy the Canadian people with the publication, annually, of brief tables of statistics. Such a report cannot possibly tell the story of what is being done. For their own defense at least they should make a publication which will give a fairer picture of the whole matter and invite discussion on these matters. Those in public positions no doubt become accustomed to criticism. The growing demand, however, for a study of our Indian work is a healthy sign of a new interest on the part of Canadians. If this demand is honestly met there will be a better day for us all."

Two conferences with representatives of the Penitentiaries Branch were held during the month. Penitentiaries throughout the Dominion are now prepared to supply this Branch with school desks, blankets, scribblers, chairs, and brooms. In addition to the repair of boots and the dyeing of discarded military clothing, they are also prepared to supply us with young Holstein bulls in the province of Ontario.

We have been experimenting during the last two or three year period, with a reasonable measure of success, in the purchase of baby chicks for distribution to reserves where Homemakers' Clubs have been organised. Indian Agent A. D. Moore, of Tyendinaga, in his report for July, states:

"Six hundred Barred Rock chicks were procured the first week of June and two breeder houses have been in operation, with fair prospects, and the losses to date in these birds have not been great. The Homemakers' Clubs held one meeting during June to report on their activities and to receive supplies of clothing."

An official letter, the subject matter of which is somewhat discouraging, was recently received from J. C. Kelley, of the War Assets Corporation. In this letter Mr. Kelley states:

"Mr. T. F. Murphy, Supt., Equipment and Supply Branch, Post Office Department, Ottawa. - Dear Sir: Reference is made to your memorandum of the 10th instant relative to the disposal of second hand wearing apparel to
the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources.

Although this particular transaction will be cleared in the usual manner, it may be mentioned that subsequent surpluses must be listed with the Crown Assets Allocation Committee for directions and sale at the established rate to the Indian Affairs Branch. You are, therefore, requested to clarify the matter with the Chairman of the Crown Assets Allocation Committee and if continuing authority is granted, these items will then be available to the Indian Affairs Branch at a mutually agreed price.

"A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch for their information in the matter."

It would appear that the Indian Affairs Department and later the Indian Affairs Branch have been receiving, from the Post Office Department and from the R.C.M.P., discarded clothing without cost. The time at my disposal has not enabled me to search the records, but I have been informed that this clothing has been transferred without cost, year after year since Confederation. In future, however, a charge will be imposed. The imposition of this charge is to me somewhat disturbing at a time when our Indian agents appear to be overworked and a time when a number of agents are without competent clerical assistance. I may point out that this charge does not fit into our administrative setup for a number of reasons. The cost of relief and welfare is kept by agencies, with the result that blanket shipments of this clothing can no longer be sent forward to our inspectors, or if sent forward to our inspectors, an itemized account of the quantity allotted to each agency will have to be kept. In addition to this, the agent will be expected to sign the regular voucher, which is equivalent to an affidavit, stating that the clothing has been delivered at a particular reserve in good condition and that the charges are fair and reasonable. Few agents are prepared to sign such vouchers, unless they have actually inspected the clothing, with the result that this new policy is likely to entail a great deal of additional labour.

This is not all, however. In recent years a certain amount of this clothing was transferred to Indian residential schools, on the understanding that the senior girls would be given instruction in remodelling certain garments and in the production of clothing for the younger pupils. It will not be possible in the future to transfer this clothing to the schools unless a charge is made. Unfortunately, there are times when this clothing arrives in a mutilated and almost worthless condition. Should it arrive in this condition at a school, the Principal is likely to refuse delivery and will, in all probability, send it back to the centre from which it was shipped. As a matter of fact, Mr. Hives, Principal of the St. George's School at Lytton, who visited this office a few days ago, informed me that he was sending back a shipment of discarded clothing because on inspection it appeared to him to be so mutilated that it was practically worthless. This matter has been discussed very fully and in detail with Mr. Reaume and Mr. Vincent. Mr. Reaume has promised me that he would discuss the matter with the officials of the War Assets Allocation Committee in Montreal. I can only express the hope that
officialdom will display a semblance of sanity and revert to the original policy insofar as Post Office and R.C.M.P. clothing is concerned.

Mr. Morris has completed his inspection of the agencies in Alberta and Saskatchewan and left for Norway House, Manitoba, on July 24. Mr. N. J. McLeod, Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Sask., in a letter dated June 29, states:

"I wish to thank the Department officials at Ottawa for the opportunity of meeting and discussing the problems of Indian welfare with a representative direct from Ottawa. I can assure you his advice and guidance will be a great help to me in furthering Indian welfare."

Mr. McLeod is, as you know, one of our recently appointed agents and no doubt welcomed the opportunity afforded him to discuss administrative matters at his agency with Mr. Morris. In this connection I must express regret that the manual prepared for the guidance of agents has not yet been published. It is significant that we usually receive from an agent, immediately following his appointment, five or six times as many letters as are ordinarily received from an experienced agent. These letters invariably contain requests for information that might well be supplied in a manual. I have in mind the holiday periods at Indian day schools, the actual holidays allowed, Indian eligibility for relief, statement of relief rations, the responsibility for Indian burials, the repair of buildings and a number of such matters. In the absence of a dependable manual, misunderstandings are likely to arise. Mr. Fraser, for example, the recently appointed Indian agent for New Brunswick Northeastern Division, communicated with a member of Parliament for the district, protesting against the inadequacy of our relief rations and intimating that rations had been drastically reduced in 1946. As a matter of actual fact, no reduction took place in the ration list at that time. This list was, as you know, revised and substantially increased in May, 1946.

TRAINING:

I have referred on more than one occasion in my recent reports to the provision made by Provincial Governments and Public School Boards for substantial increases in teachers' salaries. I am now in receipt of a letter from the Department of Education of Nova Scotia, stating that the following provision has been made for additional payments to teachers in the province of Nova Scotia:

INSTRUCTIONS CONCERNING SALARY INCREASES AUTHORIZED BY THE COUNCIL OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION

Minute of the Council of Public Instruction of May 23, 1946.

No. 1. The request for increased grants recently presented to the government by the Nova Scotia Teachers' Union has been given long and careful consideration by the Council of Public Instruction, as a result of which it has been decided to make
increases for all classes of teachers according to the following schedule, beginning with the school year 1944-45:

1. Teachers holding permanent or interim licenses of First Class or higher, and permanent licenses of Second or Third Class:
   a. After 20 years of teaching service . . . . $300.
   b. After 10 and up to the end of 20 years of teaching service . . . . . . . . . . 250.
   c. After 5 and up to the end of 10 years of teaching service . . . . . . . . . . 200.
   d. After 1 and up to the end of 5 years of teaching service . . . . . . . . . . 150.
   e. In the first year of service . . . . . . 100.

2. Graduates of the Normal College Summer School holding Temporary Second Class licenses, after the first year of service . . . . . . . . 100.

3. Teachers holding permissive licenses, regardless of experience, and graduates of the Normal College Summer School holding Temporary Second Class licenses in the first year of service . . . . . . . . 50.

This salary schedule, which represents a substantial increase in the salaries paid in Nova Scotia until now, and other such salary schedules throughout the Dominion are likely to prove somewhat awkward and embarrassing if applied to Indian day school teachers. I have in mind the fact that increases such as these will enable the teacher to earn a salary considerably higher than the salaries paid to a number of our Indian agents. It is just possible that the time is rapidly approaching when a uniform salary schedule for Indian school teachers throughout the Dominion will become a necessity and when Indian day school teachers will become permanent Civil Servants.

Reports received at the end of the academic year suggest that an unusually large number of pupils in attendance at Indian day and residential schools this year passed their Entrance examinations. The Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie, states that 12 pupils completed their Entrance work at the end of the year and that of these 10 are likely to proceed with high school and vocational studies during the coming year.

Mr. F. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, St. Regis, in a letter dated July 26, states:

"I am pleased to advise you that reports are now in concerning students of the Cornwall Island Schools who have successfully passed the Ontario Entrance examinations. At the West End School, under the direction of Mrs. Emily White, five pupils passed this examination. It is interesting to note that Inspector Mr. Thomas saw fit to recommend two of Mrs. White's pupils, the other three being successful on the written test. Considering the over-crowded conditions at this school and the handicaps under..."
which this teacher has had to work; I believe her success is well worthy of mention. This particular school, I note, has had an average attendance of approximately 45 pupils throughout the year.

We are experiencing the difficulty usually experienced at this season of the year in securing the number of teachers necessary for the operation of our Indian day schools. We have at this date 30 schools for which teachers have not been secured. Of this number, however, five remained without teachers during the last academic year, so that actually we require at this date 25 teachers to operate the same number of schools as were operated last year. We are in constant communication with the church authorities and it is our hope that a number of appointments will be made during the next two or three weeks.

Mr. Domett undertook an inspection of the Restigouche and Bersimis Schools during the early part of the month. You may remember that a great deal of difficulty was experienced by the Department in securing the fuel (coal) necessary to heat the Bersimis School, with the result that this school has been operated on a four-months basis during the last three years. This period of operation never proved wholly satisfactory, and a number of complaints reached the Department with respect to the waywardness and delinquency of children of school age. Mr. Domett, at the time of his visit, worked out an agreement whereby the school will operate for the period March 1 to November 30. This appears to be a fairly satisfactory solution to what had become a rather embarrassing and perplexing problem.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended September 30, 1944.

TRAINING & WELFARE

Mr. Phelan visited the Shubenacadie and Eskasoni Reserves during the two week period ending September 16. Mr. Phelan, while there, made arrangements with the Mother Superior of the Sisters of Charity for the employment of Sisters at the Shubenacadie Indian Day School. Mr. Phelan also interviewed Archbishop McNally at Halifax and Bishop Morrison at Antigonish. As the result of his interview with Bishop Morrison, it is altogether likely that a young Priest with special training in pedagogy and in the organization of co-operative societies will take charge of the reserve at Eskasoni.

Mr. Phelan, in his report on the Shubenacadie Residential School, states:

"I inspected this school very carefully on September 7 and found everything running smoothly.

"I must point out, however, that the Principal, Reverend Father J. W. Brown, is 64 years of age and, while he is quite vigorous, at the same time it is evident that the smooth operation is depending, to a large extent, upon the Reverend Sisters. During the course of an interview with Most Reverend J. T. McNally, Archbishop of Halifax, on September 5, I pointed out to him that, while we realize the difficulty of securing young men at the present time, owing to the number of Priests from this diocese in the Armed Forces, at the same time the Department hopes that conditions will make it possible for a young man to be secured in the near future.

"The pottery programme is proceeding very satisfactorily and a number of articles are being sold to people who call at the school. The Principal of the Province of Nova Scotia Technical College, at which pottery is taught, visits Shubenacadie frequently and is extremely interested in the work that is being done at our school. Due to the fact that several of the pupils who make pottery will eventually reside on the Shubenacadie Reserve, it is quite likely that this industry could be further encouraged on the reserve when the Sisters take charge of the day school. It is understood that one of the teachers who will go to the Shubenacadie Day School eventually will be able to continue the pottery training.

"You will recall that there was some correspondence regarding the purchase of additional land for the school and at the time the request was made to us we expressed the opinion that no additional land should be..."
secured at the present time. I discussed this matter with the former Principal, Reverend J. P. Mackey, whom I met in Halifax on September 8, and he stated that there was approximately ten acres of land adjacent to the school which it would be desirable to purchase at some time, but that, as the school has done very well with the amount of land they have, he did not see any particular reason for making the purchase at the present time, other than it might stop someone else from securing it. In discussing the matter further with Father Brown, it appears that he has lately purchased five acres of this ten-acre plot. Evidently, following our refusal to purchase land, he purchased the five acres from his own funds. He paid $100 an acre for it, or a total of $500. He stated that if the Department wished to secure this from him at any time he was quite willing to transfer title to us for the amount just stated.

"There is a continuation school in the village of Shubenacadie, which is situated about a mile from the school, where instruction is given as far as Grade II. Pupils who take Grade II in the Nova Scotia schools can then proceed to Normal School for a year's training and obtain a teacher's certificate. A few years ago one of the pupils of the Shubenacadie School, James Prosper, resided at the Shubenacadie Residential School and took Grade II at the village school. He is now in the Air Force.

"It is interesting to know that 55 former pupils of the Shubenacadie Residential School are now in the Canadian Army. Of these three have been killed. One, Jimmy Prosper mentioned above, is in the Air Force and two ex-pupils are in the United States Navy.

"Both the main building and the outbuildings are in good condition, with the exception of the trouble that they have been having with the wall. Mr. Sparks, of the Surveys & Engineering Branch, who has been at Shubenacadie in connection with the erection of the new day school, made a careful inspection of the wall and roof and it is his opinion that the coping at the top of the walls should be fixed. He claims that if this is done the leaking of water into the building will be prevented. He had representatives of two firms inspect the roof with him and their quotations have not yet been received, but he estimated the expenditure would probably amount to $2000.00."

In discussing conditions on the reserve, particularly the housing program, Mr. Phelan states:

"I spent September 8 and 9 with the Indian Agent on this reserve. At the present time there are approximately 300 Indians residing on the reserve. Forty houses have been completed and of these eight were built during the current year. Five more cellars were being dug and this means that five more houses will be complete before the winter. A recent census of the reserve indicated that there are 107 children under the age of sixteen. Of course, all of these are not of school age at the present time. A visit to the day school which we are operating on the reserve until the new building is finished showed the names of 46 pupils on the register. As a result the old day school is extremely crowded and, pending the completion..."
of the new building, it may be necessary to have the younger children come for half a day and the older children for the other half.

"The erection of the new building is proceeding rather slowly. At the time of my visit on September 9 the foundation had been completed and it was hoped that the work would progress more quickly so that the walls would be erected and the roof on before the cold weather started. At the time I visited the reserve the well digger had not yet struck suitable water, although I phoned Mr. Buck today and was informed that suitable water had been secured at a depth of 327 feet.

"At the present time we are still operating schools on the Afton Reserve, Indian Cove Reserve and Millbrook Reserve. The Afton Reserve is just outside the town of Antigonish and Indian Agent Rice states that very few of the Indians residing here wish to move to the new reserve, as they can obtain work in Antigonish. The Indian Cove School is situated near Pictou Landing and the Millbrook School is located a short distance from Truro. In both cases the Indians are very reluctant to move to the new reserve for the same reason as I stated in regard to the Afton Reserve. I recommend that the Principal's residence and the teachers' residence be erected next year. As soon as the school is finished the other buildings will be required and they should be provided at the earliest possible date.

"On September 5 in Halifax I interviewed the Mother Superior of the Sisters of Charity. This is the same Order as we have in the Shubenacadie Residential School. They are willing to provide whatever number of qualified teachers we require. However, they have made all their appointments for the current academic year and, in view of the delay in erecting the building, it will not be possible for them to provide any Sisters until the academic year 1945-46. I pointed out that in addition to teaching the school it would be expected that the Sisters would take an active interest in Homemakers' Clubs on the reserve. The Mother Superior promised that they would do this and to assist us in this regard they would arrange to send one Sister who has had considerable experience in social service work. As you know, the salaries of teachers have been considerably increased in the white schools in Nova Scotia this year. It was agreed with the Mother Superior that the following salary rate would be suitable: $1200 a year for the Principal and $1000 a year for each assistant.

"This Order not only provides qualified teachers for schools, but also has a number of Sisters who are qualified nurses. One of their activities is the operation of a big hospital in Halifax. In the event of a nursing station being established on the new Shubenacadie Reserve, I feel very definitely that one of the Sisters should be employed. This would mean that both the teaching services and the nursing services would be in charge of the same Order and would no doubt give us beneficial results.

"At the present time, as you are aware, considerable employment is being given to the Indians in the erection of the new houses. I also noted that several had cultivated gardens during the past summer. A separate
report is being submitted regarding the lumber which is at present surplus to requirements.

Both the Indian Agent and the Clerk seem to be fully conversant with their duties and apparently are working hard to get everything into good shape.

I have referred in my recent reports to the difficulty experienced in securing the number of fully qualified teachers necessary to operate our Indian day schools. In this connection it is gratifying to be able to state that despite the acute shortage of teachers existing throughout the Dominion, all our schools, with the exception of 20, are now in operation. A large number of the teachers now employed by the Department have been secured by the Churches. I am personally of the opinion that without the assistance of the Churches this year, a large number of our schools would have remained closed.

An unusually large number of residential school principals have resigned during the last two year period. These resignations, I note, have been due, in the majority of cases, to ill health. The change in the principalship of a residential school is a somewhat serious matter from the standpoint of effective departmental administration. An illustration of this is furnished by the experience we have recently had at the Norway House Residential School, operated by the United Church of Canada. The Principal of this school until the end of the last academic year was Mr. A. E. Caldwell. Mr. Caldwell has now been transferred to the Pacific Coast and is at present in charge of the Alberni Residential School. During his stay at Norway House, however, Mr. Caldwell was deeply interested in the organization of a goat herd. This interest was no doubt due, in part at least, to the health or nutritional surveys conducted in the Norway House district by Dr. Moore, Dr. Nisdall and Dr. Kruse. When the new principal, Mr. Jones, took over early in July, however, he immediately decided to sell or destroy the goat herd. Fortunately, Mr. Morris arrived at Norway House two weeks later and made arrangements whereby the goat herd at the school was purchased by the Department and placed under the supervision of Mr. Jackson, the recently appointed clerk at the agency. Mr. Morris, in his report, states:

"I arranged with the Principal of the School, Mr. Jones, to purchase the goat herd - 16 females at $14.00 each and 8 males at $10.00 each. This herd has been shamefully neglected; only three nannies were being milked and the milk was being fed to pigs, despite the fact that goats' milk is selling at $1.00 a quart in Montreal. Agent Lasenby was informed that he was to take over the herd and put it under the supervision of Mr. Jackson. The milk, for the time being, will be used at the hospital and milking nannies in future will be given out to Indian families with young children, who are unable to secure milk from local sources."

Reports recently reaching the Department indicate that a number of residential school principals are experiencing the utmost difficulty in recruiting the number of pupils for which per capita grants are allowed by the Department. Less than fifty per cent of the pupilage has been enrolled at the following schools: Mount Elgin Institute, Chapleau, Moose Factory and Albany.

The refusal on the part of Indians to return
their children to school is due, no doubt, in the main, to existing economic conditions. Teen-age Indian boys and girls have been able to earn high wages at harvesting operations in the west and in the tobacco fields and fruit districts of Ontario, and the Indian parent looked upon any suggestion that the boys should return promptly to school as a suggestion that would result in an economic loss. The Churches have already protested somewhat vigorously against this condition and have already intimated that some re-adjustment will have to take place this year in the payment of our per capita grants if the Churches are to escape substantial deficits at the end of the year. I am personally of the opinion that a number of speeches delivered against residential schools during the last year or so are having a very adverse effect on the attendance of Indian pupils at these institutions. In fact, certain phrases from the speeches delivered have been quoted to me by Indians and by Indian parents. These pronouncements, they seem to think, justify them in refusing to send their children to these schools. It would appear that we are rapidly approaching a time when a definite decision will have to be reached with respect to residential schools throughout the Dominion. If they are not serving the purpose for which they were established, then in my judgment they should be either closed or remodelled or the program now in force modified to meet the more urgent needs of the Indian population.

For example, Mr. Doucet has spent a couple of years in working out a vocational program designed particularly for residential schools, and yet very few of our schools have either the classroom buildings or the equipment necessary to introduce this program.

A particularly encouraging report on the work at the St. Regis Indian Day Schools was received from Indian Agent Bonnah. It would appear that the R.C.M.P. Constable and Mr. Bonnah have been devoting a great deal of time to the organization of a worthwhile program of athletics on the reserve. Mr. Bonnah, in his letter dated September 21, states—

"It is more than gratifying to the writer and the local constable to feel that your office has put such weight behind our endeavour. As a result of our combined effort, the attendance at the Village School, so far, this week has increased by approximately 70%. The attendance at this school has never been what it should be, but, to make matters worse, the children, boys especially, had the habit of coming in late. Unless there is a very good reason to detain them now, they are on the dot when the bell rings. Otherwise they will be prevented from taking part in our sports program. Competitive sports are being arranged between the various schools. The idea behind this move was so that our children would get to know each other and perhaps by doing so would profit from the example of some of our better students. Strange as it may seem to your office, it is nevertheless a fact that many children from one school do not even know any of the children from another".
