Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Welfare and Training Service for the month ended October 31, 1944.

In my report of last month I referred to Mr. Phelan's visit to the Shubenacadie and Eskasoni Reserves in Nova Scotia. I submitted at that time a summary of the report made to me by Mr. Phelan, immediately following his visit.

In this report I am submitting a summary of certain recommendations made by Mr. Phelan, following his visit to the Eskasoni Reserve. His report on this reserve reads as follows:

"I spent September 11, 12 and 13 on this reserve. At the present time there are approximately 60 families on the reserve. The Indian Agent stated that there are approximately 75 additional families who may move to this reserve. The Agent considers that it is very doubtful if the Indians from the Sydney Reserve will move to Eskasoni. Practically all of these have reasonably good homes on the Sydney Reserve, which is located on the outskirts of the town of Sydney. In any event, they have permanent positions and practically all of them are able to provide for themselves. Some of them could be considered in prosperous circumstances. He mentioned particularly Ben Christian, who is a practical plumber and has his own business in Sydney. The Agent expressed the opinion that if these Sydney Indians did not move to Eskasoni they should be enfranchised.

"During the course of our conversation the Indian Agent stated that the Indians who have not yet removed to Eskasoni are expressing the opinion that if they remain where they are at present the Department will continue to provide the usual services. With this in their minds many of them are not anxious to move. The Indian Agent feels that unless we discontinue school services and medical services on these reserves it will be difficult, if not impossible, to have many of these Indians move to Eskasoni.

"At the present time the majority of the Indians living on the Eskasoni Reserve are being employed either in the sawmill or building the new houses. The Agent feels that immediate steps should be taken to plan some industry on the reserve at which the Indians could be employed. One plan the Agent has is to encourage native industries. In this connection he pointed out that as part of their post-war..."
programme the Provincial Government of Nova Scotia intends to feature the possibilities of the Bras D'Or Lakes for summer homes. As a consequence they hope to attract not only Canadians but Americans to this section of the province. If this plan goes through, the Agent thought that there would be a splendid market for Indian goods.

Up to the present 20 houses have been completed, 14 houses partly completed, 4 barns completed, 2 outbuildings completed, 2 temporary buildings completed and 5 excavations for new houses are now ready. The attached rough sketch, prepared by the clerk at the Eskasoni Agency, gives an idea of where these buildings are located. The sawmill is operating and recently a machine for making shingles has been installed. In order to have the sawmill equipment complete the Agent requests that a planer and matcher be supplied. The only equipment of this kind available in Cape Breton could be secured for approximately $1,000, which the Agent considers is good value. There would be some slight additional expenditure for new belts, pulleys, etc. In answer to a query the Agent stated that the new houses being erected on the reserve cost approximately $1,000, which he considers is the minimum at which houses of this type could be erected at this particular place. It was evident that several Indians had cultivated gardens during the past summer, but there was no farming on an extensive scale. As you know, the reserve does not lend itself to this. There are several head of cattle on the reserve and a few horses.

SCHOOL - The present school is located on the old section of the Eskasoni Reserve. It is simply a one-room building without basement. The majority of the desks are very antiquated and must have been supplied many years ago. I recommend that 24 medium sized chair desks be supplied. These can be used in the new school when it is erected. At the present time there is an enrolment of 48 pupils of whom 25 have to come approximately three miles and the Agent has arranged for driving them. The proposed site for the new school, Principal's residence and teachers' residence is adjacent to the church and to the present school. If the new school is erected on this site the driving of the children will have to be continued. I asked the Agent if it would not be possible to obtain a more central site, but he expressed the opinion that this was not feasible. However, it would appear that while the residence should be near the church for the convenience of the Sisters who will be in charge of the school, there is not the same necessity for having the school located at the same point. At the same time there is the question of supplying water and other services, and I presume the new site was selected with this in mind. I feel that this is a matter which should receive very careful consideration before we proceed with the erection of the new buildings. Whatever decision is made, I feel very definitely that immediate action should be taken. The policy of centralization is being retarded and might be ultimately ruined by the delay in the erection of the buildings required to provide an adequate educational programme. The Indian Agent considers, and I agree, that a definite date should be set for closing the outside schools. However, until the new school is provided, I cannot see how we can take definite action in this particular regard.

"At the -
"At the present time we are conducting the day school on the Sydney Reserve, which I have mentioned previously. The school on the Sydney Reserve is in reasonably good condition and in the event of our closing it, the Agent thought that arrangements could be made to have it taken over by the Catholic Church authorities, who are considering the erection of a new church in that district. Similarly, on the outskirts of the town of Sydney, we are also conducting schools on the Middle River and Woodsmag Reserve. Both of these buildings are very old and are of no value. The Salmon River School was built within the last few years and is a good building. The Agent considers that the neighbouring white section would be interested in obtaining it.

"I have already submitted a memorandum to you with reference to the appointment of Father Ross as Principal. This matter has already received attention. When in Antigonish I interviewed the Mother Superior of the Sisters of St. Martha. Tentative arrangements to secure the services of these teachers were previously made by Inspector Arnell. The Mother Superior seemed very anxious to co-operate with us and stated that if we advised her by April 1, 1945, regarding the number of Sisters we need, she would be able to supply them for the academic year 1945-46. It was agreed that the salary for the Principal would be $1,200 and for each assistant $1,000 per year. These are the same salaries as suggested for the Sisters at Shubenacadie. In this case, also, pointed out that the Sisters would be expected to take an active interest in Shubenacadie Clubs on the reserve. The Mother Superior promised that they would do this and provide a Sister who had experience in social service work. This Order also has Sisters who are qualified nurses. In the event of a nursing station being established on the Eskasoni Reserve, I feel that one of the Sisters should be employed. This would mean that both the teaching services and the nursing services would be in charge of the same Order. You will remember that I made the same recommendation in regard to the Shubenacadie Reserve.

"I had a very nice interview with Reverend A. R. MacDonald, Parish Priest of Christmas Island. Father MacDonald was formerly Agent for the Eskasoni Reserve and is familiar with conditions there during the past 25 years. He is extremely interested in our centralization programme and is giving both the Agent and clerk every possible assistance. Father MacDonald feels that the programme is proceeding satisfactorily, but, like many others, expressed the hope that we would provide the school at the earliest possible date. He was glad to know that Bishop Morrison had suggested Father Ross, whom Father MacDonald has known for many years."

May I direct your attention particularly to Mr. Phelan's reference to the school site. It was, to me, somewhat disturbing to learn that, should we proceed with construction on the site selected by Mr. Arnell and by Mr. Buck, it would be necessary to provide transportation for a number of Indian pupils whose homes would be three miles or more from the school. I decided to have Mr. Doucet,
and a field man selected by the Department of Education for Nova Scotia undertook an educational survey of the reserve, with the object of selecting the best site or sites for the establishment of our Indian day schools. Mr. Doucet has now returned to Ottawa. He is of the opinion, and the representative of the Nova Scotia Department of Education agrees with him, that we should proceed with the construction of a four-room school on the present site. Both these officials are of the opinion that it will be necessary, in the not distant future, to construct an additional two-room or four-room school to meet the educational needs of the Indian population that will finally be established on this reserve. Mr. Doucet's report and findings, however, will not interfere in any way with our present building program. This matter has already been discussed very fully with Mr. Busk, and it has been decided to proceed with the construction of the school, together with the Principal's residence, residence for the Sisters and the other agency buildings, at the earliest possible date. I am attaching hereto the sketch map referred to by Mr. Phelan in his report, for your information.

A somewhat discouraging report on conditions at the Mohawk Institute was received by Long Distance Telephone from Colonel Randle a few days ago. It would appear that as the result of carelessness the boiler at the school, which cost $5,500.00 including installation costs, was left without water and was injured to such an extent that it is no longer capable of functioning. I decided to send Mr. Phelan to Brantford to make a thorough enquiry into this accident. Mr. Phelan's report, which is dated October 30, 1944, reads in part as follows:

"Colonel Randle's letter of October 19 outlined what had happened. In interviewing the Principal, Reverend Mr. Snell, it was found that acting on the instructions of the man who is in charge of the furnace, one of the boys lowered the water in the boiler. Instead, however, of simply lowering the water, he left the tap open and went on to perform other duties and no one checked the matter. About 9:30 in the evening the building became cold and the stoker was started without anyone ascertaining if there was water in the boiler. As the pipes did not heat, the Principal again visited the boiler room and found the boiler ruined, due to the fact that there was no water in it and that the stoker had been running for over an hour.

"From my conversation with the Principal, it appears that the so-called engineer, the boys' master and even the Principal operate the stoker whenever they feel more heat is required. I pointed out to the Principal that this was very careless habit and issued instructions that in future the boiler should be operated by one or two persons and that when anyone was taking charge of the boiler he should take over from the one who had been handling it for the previous period. The Principal stated that he had engaged another man, whom he considered qualified. We discussed this man's qualifications and it is possible that he will be an improvement on the man who has been..."
employed. However, I believe that it is advisable to instruct Colonel Randle to interview this man and make certain that he is capable.

"Following my visit to Brantford, I interviewed Mr. Briggs, the Chief Inspector of the Boiler Inspection Branch of the Department of Labour in Toronto. While the low pressure boiler we operate at Mohawk does not actually require a person holding a certificate, at the same time it would be preferable to have such a person, due to the fact that the hot water boiler is a high pressure one. In conversation with Mr. Briggs, he suggested that in the best interests of all parties concerned it would be preferable to secure a person holding at least fourth class papers. If the person engaged does not hold such papers, arrangements might be made to have him examined by the Board of Examiners of the Boiler Inspection Branch in Toronto."

Accidents such as this appear to occur from time to time at residential schools, despite our best efforts to prevent them. Just how much they are due to dual control of these institutions, I am not in a position to state. I do feel, however, that I am not unfair when I state that the average clergyman is scarcely qualified to supervise the mechanical equipment supplied by the Government for the average residential school, nor is he equipped to pass judgment on the qualifications of the men who apply for positions such as the position of firemen and engineers, from time to time. Ordinarily, an accident such as this at Brantford would call for the dismissal of the principal. It so happens, however, that we had made arrangements whereby the present Principal, Mr. Snell, would retire at the end of the present academic year and that the school would be taken over and operated, not by the Church nor in co-operation with the Church, but by the Department, at that time. This is still my intention. In view of this decision, I am disposed to think that we should ask Colonel Randle to take a more active interest in the administration of the school and in the qualifications of the members of the staff until a new principal is appointed.

A few weeks ago Dr. Moore and I interviewed Mrs. Allan Stevenson, National Director of the Red Cross Nutritional Services, with the object of having the Red Cross undertake a nutritional survey at a number of our Indian residential schools. Mrs. Stevenson and an associate undertook their first survey at the Chapleau (C.E.) Residential School early in October. Although Mrs. Stevenson's report has not yet reached us, she deemed it advisable to visit Ottawa a few days ago, to discuss with the officials here the work of her survey, which covered a period of ten days. A summary of Mrs. Stevenson's report will reach you in due course. In the meantime, it can be stated very definitely that conditions at the school are in no sense satisfactory. Mrs. Stevenson assured us that she went to the school, not expecting equipment comparable to the
equipment in the average hospital. She was, however, not prepared for the lack of cleanliness in evidence everywhere in the school. She discovered that no arrangements whatever had been made to provide the pupils in attendance with foods containing Vitamin C - tomatoes, oranges, grapefruit, etc. She discovered that the method of cooking potatoes hours before they were actually consumed destroyed any Vitamin C that potatoes, when well cooked, usually contain. She discussed conditions at the school with the local medical health officer; with the Indian Agent, Mr. Matters; and with the dentist who was engaged in professional work at the school at the time of her visit. The dentist informed her that it had been his experience that Indian pupils entering the school with their teeth in good condition, for some reason or another that he could not explain, became victims of tooth disease in a comparatively short period of time. Mrs. Stevenson attributed this to lack of vitamin C in the diet and to the breakdown or collapse of the gum tissues. Mrs. Stevenson was particularly shocked at the provision, or lack of provision, made for the care and distribution of the milk supply at the school. The Principal, she said, seemed to feel that because they had an accredited herd, pasteurization or even cleanliness were no longer necessary. The result was that she and her assistant developed, during the first two or three days of the survey, a stomach infection, although both steadfastly refused to consume milk after the second day at the school.

The Chapleau School, operated by the Church of England, has always been looked upon as one of our reasonably efficient institutions. In fairness, it should be said, however, that the church authorities have been experiencing the utmost difficulty in securing the staff necessary to keep their school open and in operation during the last two or three year period, and yet there are certain features of the work at the school, discovered by Mrs. Stevenson, that are profoundly discouraging. For example, we have prepared, during the last three or four years, Vitamin Charts. These charts, together with circular letters, have been sent out from time to time to our Indian agents, our farming instructors, our residential school principals, and to our day school teachers. Mrs. Stevenson, prior to her visit to Chapleau, was supplied with copies of these charts. She told me quite emphatically that there was not a vestige of evidence anywhere at Chapleau to indicate that these charts had ever been read by the Principal or by the members of the staff. Mrs. Stevenson is personally of the opinion that the sending out of such charts is largely a waste of money and that if dietary practice at our schools is to be corrected, it will have to be corrected by personal contacts and by definite instruction. She expressed the opinion that the Red Cross might be willing to undertake a survey of an additional number of schools and might be prepared to provide dieticians to undertake Short Courses on Nutrition at each school, provided a satisfactory arrangement could be reached with this Department.

Early in the month, Mr. Phelan attended a conference of Indian day school teachers at the Oneida No. 1 School, Muncey, Ontario. Mr. Phelan, in his report, states:

"On October 15 I attended the ninth consecutive annual convention of the teachers in charge of the..."
following Indian schools: Bear Creek, Back Settlement, River Settlement, Oneida No. 1, Oneida No. 2, Oneida No. 3, Moraviantown, St. Clair, Kettle Point, Walpole Island No. 1 and Walpole Island No. 2 Day Schools and Mount Elgin Residential School. The convention was held at the Oneida No. 1 School. In addition to the teachers mentioned, there were present Public School Inspectors Smith, Young and Pearson.

"A very interesting and constructive programme for the teachers had been prepared and each of the inspectors took a prominent part in the discussions, giving valuable advice to the teachers with reference to the proper handling of the various subjects of the curriculum. The President of the group this year is Mrs. Ross, the Principal of the Walpole Island No. 1 School. I answered several questions regarding the Department's policy and the method of supplying books, etc. At the request of the inspectors it was decided to supply copies of the new curriculum readers published by W. J. Gare and Company to all the schools which had delegates at this particular convention. The inspectors expressed the opinion that this series was one of the best in existence at the present time and was especially suitable for Indian schools.

"It will be interesting to you to know that all our schools in this particular section have co-operated in response to the request to gather milkweed tops for war purposes. A very large amount of this is being sent to the distributing point.

"At the conclusion of the meeting the President expressed the appreciation of the gathering that one of the Departmental officials had attended."

Ottawa, December 6, 1944.

Memorandum:

Mr. DOUXET,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended November 30, 1944.

At the request of the Indian Agent, Mr. Doucet spent November 16, 17 and 18 on the St. Regis Reserve, inspecting the different schools.

From a report that Mr. Doucet has submitted, it is evident that the services of Miss Mary Terrance, teacher of the Chemail School, are not satisfactory and it will probably be necessary to make a change of teacher at this school.

Due to the encouragement of Indian Agent Bonnah, a Boy Scout group has been organized. In regard to this Mr. Doucet writes:

"I was very much impressed with the enthusiasm displayed by the boys and girls in this group and I think this movement deserves every encouragement. For a club room they are using the building formerly used as a residence by the agent. On Halloween a party was organized by the personnel of the agency, with the result that no extra police supervision was necessary and no damage of any kind was done on the reserve."

In a report on his inspection of the Swan Lake School, in the Portage la Prairie Agency, on November 10, the Public School Inspector points out that the teachers had cultivated, during the past summer, a garden for the school and also individual gardens for the students. As a result he has in store from the school garden 15 bushels of potatoes, 140 lbs. of white beans, 250 lbs. of turnips, 40 lbs. of onions and a large box of carrots. These vegetables will be used during the winter to serve a midday lunch to the pupils.

Arrangements were recently completed for transferring a buck kid goat from the Norway House Agency to the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. The Principal of the latter school, in a letter dated November 6, states that the pupils are very much interested in raising goats.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
MEMORANDUM:

- MR. ROY -

The following is a brief report on the work of the Welfare Division for the month of November.

The relief statement for the first seven months of the year to October show there is an increase totalling $87,450.21 over the same period last year. While this is a large increase it is not considered serious. Most of it can be accounted for as follows:

(1) Additional quantities of foods were purchased for delivery to ration houses on the various reserves in the Prairie Provinces and N.S.T., to meet the increase in destitute Indians on a parity with the quantities set out on the normal ration list.

(2) Extra fishing nets purchased for Northern Indians cost approximately $8,000 more than the previous year.

(3) A very active building program is being presented to house Indian families being settled on the Eskimo and Subsistence Reserves in N.S.-amounting to approximately $50,000 to-date.

I visited the Women's Clubs at Tyendinaga, Golden Lake and Maria Reserves where arrangements were completed for the women members to undertake the making of various articles of clothing, such as, pyjamas, nightgowns, dressing gowns, shirts, etc. This clothing is to be used for distribution from time to time to Indians receiving medical treatment in hospitals. The same will also be available to be issued to Indians when discharged from hospital. A considerable saving should result from this undertaking. The arrangement is that the women will buy the material, the women will supply the labour and the Board will pay for the labour, not in cash but in household needs, such as, dishes, kitchen utensils, paint, and similar articles of furniture, etc. This project as well as providing clothing at less cost to hospital patients will give instruction and proficient Indian women an opportunity to improve Indian homes and general living conditions. This experiment, if successful in the East, will be introduced later to other areas in Canada.

It was thought the women might have difficulty in making men's trousers so arrangements have been made to purchase 1,000 pairs, new, assorted sizes, from the Air Force. The cloth for the making of shirts and women's blouses is being obtained from the Department of Munitions and Supply.
The purchase of the right type of engines to operate the saw mill at Indian Lake in the Bow River Agency has taken up considerable time. The senior officials of the other Divisions were consulted to discover if they were undertaking any projects that might require the use of a heavy Canadian Tractor. As a result of these discussions however, information of Bow River has been written to for additional information, which when received, should make it possible to arrive at a satisfactory decision.

Mr. J. A. McLaughlin of the Justice Department visited the office and with Mr. Arnold present we discussed the various services that might be available to our Branch at the various Institutions across Canada. Mr. McLaughlin has since summarized the discussion, and set out in detail, the services that are available, and it is thought, this Branch will benefit a great deal by taking advantage of his suggestions.

During the summer we took advantage of the opportunity of obtaining three pure bred Holstein bull calves from the Kingston Institution. These are excellent animals and will, undoubtedly, make a big improvement in the Indian milking cattle. We also availed ourselves of the opportunity of accepting sufficient vegetables - turnips, carrots, beets and potatoes, which were grown at the Institution at Collingwood and St. Vincent, as well as the care of the seeds of distinctive Indians at Golden Lake and St. Regis. These two reserves suffered from lack of moisture during the growing season and the vegetable crop was almost a complete failure.

Indian Agent, Dr. T. J. Griford, advises:

"The last of the 500 ten gallon hogs were given out this Fall to Indian hunters. Most of those issued previously were still in good shape but the fish and game supply was so abundant that there was no difficulty in using all the hogs we had. Some were shipped to Factory River and East Main, where there is also a good fish run each Fall.

"It would be good policy to distribute more of these wooden hogs to scattered Bay Route and on reoccupation for them if funds are available for their purchase.

"This is a very interesting experiment - started two years ago and we are very happy to note that 200 - 10 gallon hogs or salt cured fish and game have been provided for winter food. It is considered that this experiment should be developed in other Agencies in the North as the freighting of cured meat and other foods in the isolated areas is very costly.

Arrangements were completed during November with officers of the Justice Branch to slaughter 300 Elk at Jasper Park - $750 at Banff Park and $8 at Factory - the meat to be slowly frozen and stored in packing houses and then distributed as rations to needy Indians. Inspector Schmidt has had considerable difficulty in obtaining cold storage space. He eventually was successful in obtaining space in the Burns and Company packing plant at Calgary, providing the meat is inspected by a qualified Veterinary Surgeon.
Dr. H. Barker, Veterinary Director General, Department of Agriculture, was interviewed by Dr. H. F. Lewis of the Burns Bros., Inspector Arnold and myself, and arrangements have been made whereby a Dominion Government Inspector will be available at the time of the slaughter to inspect the meat and see that it meets with the requirements of the Department of Agriculture for storage in the Burns plant.

Mr. W. B. Greenwood, Assistant Associate Director, National Selective Service, interviewed Inspector Arnold and myself, with respect to obtaining Indian labour for pulpwood operations. He stated that there was a serious labour shortage in the pulp industry in the area extending from Sarnia to Port Arthur. The Indian Agents in the area affected are being written to requesting that attention be drawn to this particular labour shortage with instructions to do everything possible to obtain Indian help. It was pointed out to Mr. Greenwood that there was little likelihood of obtaining a great number of volunteers, as practically every able-bodied Indian in this area is at present employed.

J. E. Harris,
WELLS DIVISION.
Memorandum-

Mr. Hoey -

The following is a brief report on the work of the Welfare Division for the month of December.

The statement from the Treasury Office for the first eight months ending November 30th shows that relief costs are up $96,999.95 as compared with the same period last year. The greatest increases are in Nova Scotia - $19,514.33, Quebec - $23,211.89, Manitoba - $19,428.38, and Alberta - $14,045.12.

The Nova Scotia increase is the result of the building programme in connection with centralization schemes in that province.

The Quebec increase is mainly Abitibi - approximately $5,000, Caughnawaga - $3,500, Maniwaki - $2,500 and Restigouche - $3,000. These increases at these agencies will be investigated.

The Norway House Agency in Manitoba shows the greatest increase totalling $14,305.82. Note, a quantity of pork had to be condemned. The cost of replacing it amounted to $1,400. Approximately $1,700 was required to purchase additional groceries for destitute Indians. A goat herd was purchased and a barn built to house them; hay and oats were bought at Winnipeg for winter feed; three sewing machines as well as a quantity of sewing material was supplied to the Cross Lake Homemakers' Clubs; an addition to the warehouse was built to properly store greater quantities of food, particularly bacon.

The increase in Alberta totals approximately $14,000. Lesser Slave Lake - approximate increase $4,800; Rocky Mountain House (a new agency) - $1,420 - purchase of harness, farm machinery, etc. The purchase of clothing in Alberta shows an increase of approximately $6,000 under the heading of general. Quantities of military clothing were made available at Calgary. This clothing was purchased and distributed to the various agencies.

Reports from the various Homemakers' Clubs show that they have all been very active. Great quantities of children's wearing apparel have been made up from discarded military clothing. The women are very interested in their work. The following is a letter which I received from Mrs. Mary Sinclair, President, of one of the three Homemakers' Clubs organized at Cross Lake at the time of my visit:

"We, the homemakers of Cross Lake wish to express our gratitude to you for the nice sewing machine you sent us. Also we have been very glad of the good counsel you gave us last summer."
of how we might help our husbands in many ways. Yes, Mr. Morris, you are helping us a lot, and we thank you very much.

At this time I would like to tell you that the homemakers' clubs are going along fine, except that the building in which the sewing was to take place wasn't ready. So we Presidents made arrangements about this. We planned that our sewing time should be on Thursdays every week in the Presidents' homes for the time being till the house is built.

The soldiers' clothes you sent us were divided into three bundles, one for each club. The women ripped the clothes and made fine clothes out of them such as snow-suits, dresses, coats, etc.

The women seem to be very interested in their sewing like myself. My children are wearing clothes I made out of soldiers' clothes. Indeed, it is a great help for our husbands as there is no work around here and no fur at all this year, and hardly any price for fur. People live mostly on fishing by selling them to the Hudson's Bay Co. and the schools; so that means it will be hard this winter for us all.

My husband is Charlie Sinclair, Councillor. We have seven children, three of whom are at the school and four at home. I had a little baby girl last September. Her name is Jean Margaret. She will be three months old on the ninth of December.

Mr. Morris, one thing I wish to ask you which the homemakers' club does not understand. Will the government always help us by sending things like this; or will we have to help ourselves?

All the members in my group seem to remember you as they always mention your name at every sewing day while they are doing their sewing.

Well, sir, I must conclude this letter now. As I conclude, I wish to express my best wishes to you for the coming New Year. May it bring all its richest blessings into your home. I am wishing you a very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

Good bye, Mr. Morris.

(Mrs.) Mary Sinclair,
President,
Homemakers' Club #2

We very seldom receive letters of thanks, but during the past year one other letter of appreciation was received from Mrs. Grant, who is convenor of the Homemakers' Clubs at Tyendinaga. We are particularly glad to know that the women are taking an active interest in improving their homes and living conditions on the reserves.

The reports and the results of farming and grazing in the Prairie Provinces show that on the whole the past summer has been an outstanding year. Great quantities of grains of all kinds have been harvested.
The cattle herds are showing increases and are commencing the winter in excellent health with plenty of hay and fodder available. The following is an excerpt from Indian Agent Young's report, dated December 15th:

Conditions are very good. The Indian farmers are doing well, due to good crops and good prices for their grain. A number of them have purchased machinery, horses, and have also repaired their houses.

Besides doing this the Indian farmers have paid $1216.88 off their old seed grain debt since June, 1944. This seed grain debt was for seed received prior to 1937.

This office is particularly pleased with Mr. Young's action in collecting $1216.88, being payments on old seed grain debts. Mr. Young's ability to collect debts for seed grain prior to 1937 is to be commended as they have already been placed in the uncollectable column. Such debts are seldom collected. Mr. Young reports that a total of 58,228 bushels of grain were harvested in his agency this year - community farms 21,418, Indian farms 36,810. When the grain belonging to the two community farms is sold there undoubtedly will be a balance to their credit of approximately $20,000. The balance at present is $16,474.34.

Mrs. M. E. Watnier, special investigator of the Children's Aid Society, visited the office. Mrs. Watnier has been very helpful in dealing with several cases of young Indian girls who gave birth to illegitimate children.

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, January 31, 1945.

Memorandum—

- Mr. Roy -

The following is a brief report on the work of the Welfare Division for the month of January.

The major portion of the month was taken up with the placing of our usual contract requisitions for groceries, ammunition, fishing supplies, etc.

Mr. W.F.B. Pugh, of the Saddle Lake Agency, spent some time in the Welfare Division during his visit to headquarters, and on leaving expressed himself as having a much clearer understanding of the Department's welfare policy, generally, and stated that as a result of his visit and having met headquarters staff he would resume his duties at the Saddle Lake Agency feeling his problems were understood here, and that he is more than a cog-in-a-wheel in which no one is particularly interested.

Mr. E. Lortiviore, of the Athabasca Agency, spent some time with Mr. Harris and the undersigned during his recent visit to Ottawa, and a $500.00 increase this year over last year's relief costs was discussed at some length. He pointed out that this increase is accounted for in improved health and living conditions amongst the Athabasca Indians and is reflected in reduced medical costs. Considering the Indian population of the Athabasca Agency the per capita increase in relief costs is not large. Mr. Lortiviore appears to have the question of Indian welfare well in hand in his agency.

The centralization scheme in Nova Scotia, which is responsible for increased relief costs in that Province, is progressing favorably and in his latest monthly report Mr. H. G. Ross, of Antigonish, advises that this year's quota of twenty new houses has been completed. I quote hereunder from the report referred to—

"At the close of October we were engaged in operating the shingle mill and building Indian houses. With very little variation these two projects were carried through until our quota was reached. The shingle mill worked more or less steadily until December 20th and supplied all our shingles for 20 houses and we have over 25 ft on hand surplus to this year's requirements. The shingles were made at an approximate cost of $2.00 per thousand and represent a total output of 300 ft for the year.

At the end of December 16 houses were completed and two more all done but the finishing touches. Since the last report we brought three families from Truro and placed them in new homes on this reserve, and are making plans to bring three more immediately after the new year."
Discarded military clothing is still being purchased from the Department of National Defense - although in reduced quantities as compared with earlier in the year due to stores now being built up in many of the agencies. Some requisitions for clothing still continue to come in, however, and reports indicate that this clothing continues to be used to good advantage by the Indians receiving same. I again quote from Mr. R. G. Ross's recent report on the Subsistence agency:

"There is not a family on this and many other reserves who does not have this material in great quantity and make from it admirable clothing for the children. Recently we received here a number of sheepskin linings (the outer canvas coat was removed) and in very few days little Indian children blossomed out with new suits and parka hoods made from sheepskin and looking for all the world like pictures seen of little Eskimo children. The difficulty or impossibility of securing camera films prevent us from sending pictures to your office showing the multitude of uses made of this clothing."

The experiment referred to in Mr. Harris' report for November, regarding the making of pyjamas, nightgowns, dressing-gowns, etc., has been somewhat delayed due to difficulties in obtaining material, but most of this has now been received and some very creditable samples of women's skirts made from R.C.A.F. (R.B.) material by the homemaker's Club at Neepawa have been forwarded to this office by Mrs. J. B. Gordon, Indian Agent.

Considerable time was spent during January in an endeavor to arrange the purchase of a D-4 Caterpillar Tractor for the operation of the sawmill at Norway House. As you are aware, arrangements were made to ship the old Norway House mill and engine to Island Lake, via Hudson - Hudson Bay Railway - Illford - and winter tractor freight to Island Lake, leaving Norway House Monday, January 29th, by train. Our application has been submitted to the Director of Administration of Farm Construction Machinery and Municipal Service Equipment, of the Hartline Prices and Trade Board, but to date has not been approved. This must be given continued attention - even if it is necessary for some one from this office to personally interview Mr. L. R. Charlton, Director of the above mentioned Branch of the Hartline Prices and Trade Board, at Toronto. The logs are now being cut for next season's operations and cannot be left to rot for want of power to operate the mill. It is imperative to receive one of the tractors released in the next quota in order to take advantage of summer navigation on Lake Winnipeg.

Mr. J. A. McLoughlin, Acting Inspector of Penitentiaries, called at this office during the month and left blueprints of a folding chair and garden hand scuffle for the manufacture for this Branch at $2.75 for the former and $3.10 for the latter, P.O.R. Stoney Mountain Penitentiary, based on the present cost of material. Inspector McLoughlin, and Warden Campbell of the Stoney Mountain Penitentiary, interviewed our Inspector Hamilton in Winnipeg after having discussed this subject with officials of the Indian Affairs Branch here, and the items mentioned were suggested by Inspector Hamilton. The garden hand scuffle is designed from one Mr. Hamilton constructed for his own use and found very satisfactory for gardening operations. The advisability of purchasing a number of these scuffles for welfare purposes is now under consideration.
In closing I might state that nothing particularly out of the ordinary occurred during the month of January. Our regular quota of Indian visitors included two unmarried natives, a discharged soldier, and a number of one of the Homemakers' Clubs - all in need of guidance or assistance.

C. Roberts,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, February 26, 1945.

Memorandum—

- Mr. Roy -

The following is a report on the work of the Welfare Division for the month of February.

During the month the Division was busy clearing up outstanding purchase orders and accountable advances in preparation for the end of the fiscal year.

Agent Lariviere (Matane, Quebec) reports a poor fur hunt. This situation has been further complicated by an epidemic of scarlet fever at Chibougamau. The agent took immediate effective measures to deal with the situation, but the cost of these and the additional relief indicated will further increase relief costs in his agency where expenditures are already very high.

Mr. Indian Agent Haislip reporting on the Fortage in Prairie Agency, for the month of January, states that the general health of his Indians is good. Trapping has been only fair with prices for fur slightly lower than last year. The majority of his Indians are away from the reserves getting employed at fair prices. Fishing is steady - fair to good, with prices slightly improved over last month.

The Indian Agent of the Fox Agency, reporting on an inspection of the northern portion of his agency states:

"In every case I found conditions exceedingly bad. The fur catch has been very poor, in fact, a failure. In addition, the Province did not allow any beaver to be trapped this year, and this is the only animal the Indians have been able to trap in recent years.

I had to buy relief at all places — so will have to purchase more supplies for the undersigned band to prevent starvation — Will you please send authority by telegram to spend $100.00 for clothes for relief of this (Belcourt House) Band."

In a later letter the agent stated that the band remaining food was Split Lake, not Belcourt House. Necessary expenditures have been authorised.

Inspector Hamilton, reporting on conditions in the Sioux Lookout Agency states that - on the whole the catch of fur has been varied as from fair to good. In the last category we find the Trout Lake Band, where good trappers have had incomes of from $800.00 to $1,500.00. Five Indians of this band chartered a plane at Christmas time to visit their children at the Sioux Lookout Residential School.
School. The cost of this charter was $515.00. The general health of this agency is reported good. Mr. Swartman, the Indian Agent, reports that the total value of fish caught under commercial licenses in this agency, during 1944, amounted to $77,363.99. In the more remote parts of the agency approximately one-half of the value of the catch was consumed in air transportation charges.

The Indian Agent at Batshawan, Quebec, has reported that his Indians have had a very poor harvest this winter. So poor, in fact, that merchants who outfitted Indian families last fall have declined to grant further credit to these Indians. The branch was faced with the necessity of furnishing limited outfits, or authorizing relief allowances. The limited outfits were authorized.

In the spring of 1944 ten Indians from the Albany and Attawapiskat Bands were given employment by the Boardmore Leather Company of Acton, Ontario. Later on in the year, this number was increased to fifteen. A report has now been received from Dr. T. J. Orford, the local Indian Agent, stating that the Indians have given very satisfactory service. In fact, the Company has stated that some of the Indians are becoming experts and are being placed on piece-work where they can earn more pay. Thirteen of these Indians are paying for Victory Bonds on the installment purchase plan, while they make down payments amounting to over $300.00. One of these Indians had the misfortune to lose his hand in an accident. He was given hospital attention by the Compensation Board, while the Company kept him on the payroll. He has been fitted with an artificial hand and is now working at the installation centre. It is anticipated he will be able to work again soon and will receive a pension of $25.00 per month for life. Dr. Orford states - "In my opinion these Indians have substantially contributed to the war effort with their labour and purchase of bonds. There appears to be complete satisfaction between them and their employers with no thought on the part of the firm towards exploiting them".

One of our New Brunswick agents has requested authority to purchase seed potato requirements now. He points out that due to the increase of export orders for New Brunswick seed it will be difficult, if not impossible, to obtain requirements at a later date. He states that one order alone for seed, to the value of $300,000.00, has been received from the Government of France.

The following is an excerpt from a report received from Miss H. Foster, Indian Affairs Bureau, at Briftpille, Alberta, on the activities of the Samsonkwa Club at Briftpille:

"Smoker Creek: The Indians on this reserve are more settled than the Indians on the Briftpille reserve. Many of the men work on the railroad and the families live within easy reach of one another. There are a number of clean houses and several rather intelligent young women. To date six meetings have been held. The members discussed the building of a hall under the conditions suggested by you on your visit here last spring. In the meantime a log building (two-story) formerly the residence of Jean Baptiste Willier of Smoker Creek, is being used as a club hall. The women furnished the building and cleaned it thoroughly. It was decorated for a Christmas party held Dec. 24/44 for the community and their families. The decorations were made entirely by the Indian women of foil and crepe paper; stuffed toys and rag dolls were made by the younger girls. There was an exchange of gifts and "Santa Claus" was present..."
to entertain the children. A few samples of beading and some work in birch bark were on display. An invitation to attend the party was sent to the Indian Agent.

Plans for regular meetings in the new year in the form of sewing bees were made. Miss Blanche Damerau has kindly consented to help with sewing and later with cooking lessons, both fields in which she excels.

From the Health District papers, we choose a simple story for each meeting. This is told first in English and then in Cree. Scrap books are being kept—one on sewing hints, cooking tips, and a third on general interest topics.

The women on the Sucker Creek reserve are enthusiastic and interested in the club. Although progress will be slow, over a period of time we may reach our objective.*

Our housing programme in the Nova Scotia agencies continues. The Indians of the Shubenacadie Indian Reserve are busy with logging operations to provide the material to construct some forty new houses during 1945.

During the month Captain G. Armstrong returned to work in the Welfare Division after an absence on leave of ½ years in the Canadian Active Army.

G. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, March 12, 1945.

Memorandum -

- Acting Director -

The following is a report on the work of the Welfare Division for the month of March.

During the month the Division has been very busy dealing with requests for seed, fencing, machinery, etc. The tempo of this work has been speeded up due to the early spring.

The Branch has received the following reports of conditions amongst the Indians from such widely scattered places as Fort Reliance, Saguenay Bay and Fort Churchill, on the west coast of Hudson's Bay. The Hudson's Bay Company doctor, at Fort Reliance, reports -

"Life at Reliance is still rolling along in the usual manner, not getting much excitement. Indians are having a fair few years, so far, which helps to keep things moving."

The Churchill Detachment of the R.C.M.P., reporting on winter patrol to Rock Lake, Manitoba, advises as follows -

"In regard to Indians I found them in fairly good condition. They have had a good few weeks this season and have plenty of outdoor meat and grease. It is reported that coloured farms are now being found in districts which previously have been occupied by the white man. Several supplies have been brought to the writer by the Indians. This kind which was until recently absolutely unknown in this area now seems to have entered the district in numbers."

At this time of the year the Branch receives many requests for seed, fertilizers, chickens, young pigs, fruit trees, etc., from the various agencies throughout the Dominion. In connection with our program for bettering the living conditions of our Indians many of these articles are supplied free of charge. Of course, we have to distinguish between a genuine desire for improvement and the desire to get something for nothing simply because it is being given away. Certain of our agencies such as Traditions, Canada, and Golden Lake, have used such assistance to good advantage while others like Saguenay went something for nothing, not even being prepared to say thank you for it. The following is an excerpt from the Saguenay agent's report on a distribution of young chickens last year -

"I may say that I concur with you (Mrs. Robertson - Indian) and would suggest that no chickens be given out this year as it should be borne in mind that the Indians of this reserve who are interested in raising poultry have for many years bought their own chickens and can always, with a few exceptions, find means to meet their own requirements.

I regret the lack of interest taken by our Indians in this project..."
project but I honestly cannot recommend an expenditure of money which in my opinion is not warranted by present economic circumstances nor by the actual attitude of the Indians.

Since receiving the above report an Indian delegation from Goughnour visited the Branch advising us that they were prepared to accept a distribution of young pigs in lieu of chickens this year. Needless to say such distribution has not been authorized.

In direct contrast to the above I would like to quote from a report received from G. W. Horn, our Indian Agent at Haney, Ontario, dealing with his 1944 agricultural programme -

"I have in mind a story that might be told of three men who came to me early in the year requesting assistance in cash crop farming. All three are middle aged men with families and all, I was advised, with bad records. In fact I was told not to trust any one of them. I therefore talked to each one explaining my proposition and what he would be expected to do in return. With more or less verbal agreement I covered harvest, assisted in land preparation, supplied seed and followed through the growing season with occasional advice. Weather conditions appreciably reduced their crops but not their enthusiasm. Each one more than lived up to his part of the bargain; but my point was not so much the bargain as it was to re-establish three men, and by their own unsolicited expressions of thanks, I think I am able to claim success in that all three are on the way to establishment and looking forward to 1945 and better crops."

Major D. H. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, forwards us the following report on the success of the Nootka Indians of the West Coast Agency in attempting to better their economic conditions. It appears that these Indians have built a fleet valued in estimated cost to be the second of its kind on the coast to enable themselves by independent fishing and marketing, to improve their financial status. The cost of this fishing and marketing fleet was $32,000.00 plus $477.00 for a lighting plant. The fleet was located in Friendly Cove, and the Indians having no funds to build an approach and provide an anchor, asked departmental assistance. This was provided at a cost of $484.64.

During the month officials of the Division attended a number of conferences on Family Allowances. A set of instructions for Registering Officials has been drawn up and has been approved by both the Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources and of National Health and Welfare. To date forms required to register eligible Indian families have not arrived at this office, but are expected in the course of the next few days.

G. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, May 1, 1945.

Honours—

Acting Director—

The following is a report on the work of the Welfare Division during the month of April.

The Division has been very busy during the month clearing the balance of 1944-45 vouchers for payments, dealing with Family Allowance problems and registrations, requisitioning advances for the new year, and erecting the necessary accommodations from the 1945-46 Vote. We are pleased to report that there has been no carry over of unpaid accounts from the past fiscal year.

The last fiscal year has been a year of progress in so far as our Indians are concerned. Reports received from Indian Agencies all across the Dominion indicate that the financial status of our Indians has been improved materially due to the unseasoned demand for casual labour with resultant high wages. Returns from fur are not as great as in the previous year but have been smaller and prices lower. Income from this source is estimated to be from 75% to 75% of that received last year.

Increase in Indian income from all sources has entailed increased work on the part of our agency. The following excerpt from a report received from the Indian Agent at Bella Coola can be duplicated in many of our agencies across the Dominion—

Nearly 1000 Income Tax Returns are now in process of preparation and the pending registration of Indians for Family Allowances will keep the administrative end of the agency on the jump for some time. This office is also the business centre of the Bella Coola Indian Lumber mill which handles millions of dollars in timber as well as all the buying, selling of logs, and other problems incident to an annual logging operation of from one to two million feet of pulp, spruce, and cedar.

On many Indian Reserves throughout the Dominion enthusiastic Homemakers' Clubs have been established. These Clubs are furnishing the Indian women a new incentive to maintain better living conditions in their homes. In Eastern Ontario and Quebec the Homemakers' Clubs are making clothing for use in our hospitals. Spinning and weaving pyjamas; Golden Lake dressing gowns; St. Basil windbreakers; Hudson's Bay Company women's shirts. Small fruits, dry-cured chilis, garden seeds, etc., have been supplied free of charge to the Indian families in many parts of the Dominion.
During the month the Indian Agent at St. Regis informed us that he had formed a Girl Guide Company of twenty Indian girls. He was authorized by the Branch to obtain Guide uniforms for these girls and to keep these uniforms as a Company store unless the Indian girls purchased their uniforms from him. In such cases the agent has been authorized to purchase as many additional uniforms as have been sold.

The Indian Agent at Fort Frances reported the formation of a Cadet Corps of twenty-eight boys at the residential school. These boys are being trained by Sgt. Willard Price of Fort Frances. The Agent has also reported the formation of a "Teen age Gentlemen's Club" at the residential school for boys and girls under the supervision of the Knights of Columbus. The agent stresses upon the necessity of constructing a community building and club-room on the reserve for the use of these young Indians.

From time to time the Branch has to deal with the problems of delinquency among Indian girls and women. The attached report from Miss Ruth Atkinson, Welfare Worker, of Prince Rupert, British Columbia, outlines conditions better than we can describe them. There appears to be a common sense solution to the problem. Give the Indian Agent the powers of a magistrate that he may be able to adjudicate in paternity cases and deal with offenders in instances such as mentioned in this report.

[Signature]

G. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, January 2, 1945.

Memorandum:

MR. ROE,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended December 31, 1944.

As the result of an invitation received some weeks before, Mr. Doucet was authorized to visit the St. Regis Indian Reserve in New York State, adjoining our St. Regis Reserve, for the purpose of addressing a gathering of American Indian school teachers which was being held at Hogansburg. In connection with this visit, the following letter has been received from Mr. R. P. Daly, Supervising Principal of the St. Regis (American) Indian School:

"It was an inspiring pleasure to have you visit our school and speak to our parent-teacher association, December 5th. Everyone - children, parents, and teachers - spoke about your manner of kindness and tolerance. Your visit was just the 'tonic' that we needed to inspire us to greater co-operation in the solution of the problems that confront us.

"Canada has now given me two delightful experiences this year - my visit to your country and one of your reservations, and your recent visit to St. Regis. The good-will that I encountered both times makes me hopeful that our two countries may in time convince the world that international cooperation and confidence may be achieved in time of peace as well as in time of war.

"You have an open invitation to visit us often at your convenience."

It is also interesting to know that the American School has offered the use of their gymnasium several times a week, free of charge, if desired, by pupils attending our St. Regis Schools.

On October 27 the Deputy Minister was forwarded a report submitted by Dr. A. B. Simas, following his inspection of the Ekhorn Residential School. Since that time the authorities of the M. S. C. C. have appointed a new principal, in the person of Mr. R. E. Hilts, who was formerly assistant principal at the St. George's Indian Residential School. In a letter dated December 31, 1944, from the Reverend Dr. H. A. Alderwood, he states that he had just returned from an inspection of the Ekhorn School and the following statements were made in his letter:

"We have been delighted with the manner in which Mr. Hilts has tackled the problem. He seems to..."
have been able to create a new spirit of loyalty and enthusiasm among the staff, and we are confident that the spirit of the school has been changed.

"Several staff changes have taken place and we are confident that the new workers secured will do much to raise the tone of the school. The new Farm Instructor has already made changes which have greatly increased the supply of milk and we have confidence that in the coming year he will be able to develop the garden along new lines.

"In the matter of food, Mr. Hiltz has declared that in the main supplies were adequate but he has made a number of changes aimed at improving variety and attractiveness. We have approved of his suggestion that bread should be secured from a bakery at Virden and are well satisfied that this is of high quality. The children are receiving less bread, more milk, more fruit and in general we feel confident that little fault could now be found with the food. The Principal has also introduced a better system in the serving of the meals so that the food is warm and appetising when received.

"In the matter of clothing Mr. Hiltz found that a number of items were short and this again was a result of bad management, as the Women's Auxiliary of our Missionary Society freely supplies adequate clothing when it is ordered by the school. Our records show that about $4,200.00 was spent in 1948 and this ought to have been adequate supplies. In the matter of bedding there was a real shortage in some linens and Mr. Hiltz has sent in very urgent requisitions which are now being filled. I understand that the Department has been securing new mattresses and we have on order a large quantity of blankets from the Army surplus supplies.

"The Principal has had all the lockers removed from the dormitories and these are being placed in the play-rooms. This will serve to increase the air space and we have instructed the Principal to keep his attendance down to 130 so that there may be no complaint of overcrowding.

"The Principal has thrown himself enthusiastically into the task of reviving organisations that had been allowed to lapse. Both the Scout troop and Guide Company are now functioning and a choir is being trained to give a candlelight service at Christmas time in the village church."

We have recently received copy of a letter written by the Director of the Canadian Red Cross Society to the teacher of the Chatlain Bay School, St. Regis Agency. This letter reads in part as follows:-

"Ever so many grateful thanks to you and your juniors for the wonderful box of work which we received this week. We are more than thrilled to get these big jumper dresses with blouses so well made, the other dresses both big and small, and all the dear little rompers, to say nothing of the beautifully made nighties and hospital bed jackets so daintily edged and trimmed. I am afraid we sent you a lot of difficult sewing and it was more than good of you to get it all finished. I am keeping a sample for an exhibit, and all the rest together with the sweet blue baby knitted jackets and booties will be sent overseas to help in
the clothing of children, boys and girls, in countries which have been under the Germans for so long."

School Inspector Wilson, reporting on his inspection of the Morley Indian Residential School on November 2, 1944, commented on the work that is being done, as follows:

"Main attention was given to language and reading in the teaching observed at this time. Mrs. Lepard secured quite good results in seat assignments and a reasonable amount of oral response in her teaching and questioning periods. It is quite evident that, under the guidance being given here, the pupils are gaining mastery of simple fundamentals and co-operate with interest and enjoyment.

However, the enrolment of this room and of the junior room also does not permit the more intimate personal contacts of teacher with individuals which are deemed essential for maximum results. This objective is attained in part with the senior girls and boys who attend school half days only. They devote part-time to farm or household duties.

Mr. Lepard, with the assistance of an Indian boy of about 18 years, instructs and supervises the senior boys in farm duties and workshop. Mrs. Lepard takes charge of the senior girls in household work. In this she has the assistance of two Indian girls, who appear to be giving needed help. One of them is gifted in music and she directs an orchestra. Each year as I visit the school I hear her group of eight or ten play a few selections on instruments which they have gathered together from various sources, and it is a delight to observe what has been accomplished."

Memorandum:

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended January 31, 1945.

The first telegram received in the New Year conveyed information regarding the destruction by fire of the main building at the Wabasee Church of England Residential School. This is a church-owned building, erected many years ago. The incident was reported to the Minister's office in a memorandum dated January 8, 1945.

The month has been reasonably busy, including the checking of the December quarter returns from the residential schools. Quarterly returns from the different day schools have also been received during the month.

From Inspector Hamilton's preliminary reports, regarding the work of the recently appointed Principal of the Elkhorn School, it is felt that we can expect better conditions to exist at this school in the future.

In his report for the month of January, 1945, on conditions in the Blackfoot Agency, Indian Agent Gooderham wrote as follows:

"School concerts were attended; Indian children are natural actors and actresses and these concerts are very interesting. The Crowfoot School pupils were exceptionally good and a special concert was put on for invited whites and was attended by prominent people as far away as Calgary. It must be mentioned here that the Sister Superior found good market for native handicraft in 1944. She got the mothers of pupils to do the work. She supplied most of the material and paid them well. Fifteen to twenty women earned from $10.00 to $20.00 per week for at least 10 months in a year. They did this in their spare time. The organization was splendid and the work good. All credit is due this Sister."

Since the commencement of the current academic year, we have authorized several grants to enable Indian pupils to take advantage of higher education. In the majority of instances the reports received are extremely encouraging. In a letter from the teacher of the Cape Croker Indian Day School, she writes regarding two former pupils of her school as follows:

"You will be pleased to know that our friend Basil Johnston of Regiopolis College came first in his report at the Christmas exams.

"Ines Johnston, Stratford, is doing very well."
too and Sister believes she can finish commercial course in June if she keeps on as she has been doing."

During the month 425 letters were sent out from this Division. In future months it is hoped to supply additional information of a somewhat similar nature.

Memorandum:

MR. ROY,

I am submitting herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended February 28, 1946.

Last fall we supplied a loan for the St. Cyprian (C.E.) Indian Residential School (Pelican Indian Agency). Since that time the school has gone ahead with the project and results are more than encouraging. They secured the services of Mr. David Boyle, Principal of the Coleman School District No. 1416, to teach the children this craft. Mr. Boyle has had considerable experience and is doing first class work.

A report from the Principal of the Fort Alexander (R.C.) Indian Residential School (Clansboyes Agency) indicates that the Cadet Corps which was formed there last year is extremely active and the training they are receiving is proving valuable for the boys belonging to the Corps.

Early in February we were advised by the Trusts and Guarantees Company, Limited, Calgary, that the late H. B. Penrose had made a bequest of $500.00 to the Stony Indians attending the Morley School the sum of $500.00 to provide Christmas presents and entertainment for them for the next five years after my decease." A cheque for the above amount has been received and has been deposited in the Trust Account of the Stony Indians. The Principal of the Morley Residential School has been so informed and instructed to apply the November first of 1945, 1946, 1947, 1948 and 1949 for $100.00, in order to enable him to carry out the terms of the bequest at Christmas time in each of the years mentioned.

On behalf of the Holy Angels' Residential School management, Fort Chipewyan, Inspector Schmidt forwarded several articles of clothing as samples of the work being done by the pupils in the use of discarded military clothing. It is quite evident that valuable use of discarded clothing can be made at many of our residential schools.

Sister Lebreux, one of the teachers at the Berens River R.C. Day School (Clansboyes Agency) has organized the Berens River Indian Women's War Service Club with a membership of 45 Indian women. These are divided into five different groups. The statement forwarded to
us indicates that a considerable amount of clothing has been remade from discarded military supplies.

With one exception, the Wabasee C.B. School, the December quarter (1944) returns have been received from all the residential schools and the per capita grant due has been paid.

Last Fall the Government Stationery Office requested that the requisitions from the residential schools for books and other classroom material for the academic year 1945-46 be forwarded to the Stationery Office as early as possible in 1945. Consequently all residential schools were requested to forward their requisitions early in January. The majority of these have been received and are going forward to the Government Stationery Office.

A recent report from Mr. G. W. Down, Indian Agent, Cariboo Agency, reads as follows:

"The response of our Indian children to the War effort must not be overlooked. All schools have their own junior organizations and all have contributed regularly to War Savings Certificates. A recent check with the teachers reveals that a total of $345.18 in War Savings Stamps was purchased in 1944 and many children have fully paid certificates in their possession.

"The Milkwood Food collection during the Fall of 1944 received attention and 200 bags were collected for which $40.00 was received and distributed to the various schools according to the number of bags obtained."

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY.

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended March 31, 1945.

Indian Agent Orford had arranged a plane trip around Hudson's Bay for the month of March. We took advantage of this situation to have Mr. Doucet accompany him. Mr. Doucet left Ottawa on March 5 and was absent for three weeks. During that period he had an opportunity of visiting the two residential schools at Fort George, Que., the residential school and a day school at Albany, the residential school and the day school at Moosonee and the day school at Rupert's house. At each of the points mentioned he had the opportunity of staying sufficiently long to enable him to review the work that is being done and to make practical suggestions to the principals and teachers regarding improvement of the classroom work.

A report received from the public school inspector on the Fort-a-la-Corne South Indian Day School, Duck Lake Agency, province of Sask., reads in part as follows:

"Mr. and Mrs. Ahenakew are to be complimented on their real interest in the welfare of the students. Mr. Ahenakew is supplying some instruction in manual training, while Mrs. Ahenakew instructs the girls in sewing, knitting and embroidering. This type of instruction is going to be of real practical value to the students."

Mr. Ahenakew is an Indian whom we assisted some years ago in taking a high school and teacher's training course.

The Inspector's report has been received on the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. The following excerpts from that report are interesting:

"Written work was superior to that of many public schools. In particular I might mention letters which were written by all the pupils at my request.

"I found that writing was above the average and reading equal to that of pupils of foreign extraction in attendance at white schools."

The work done in the primary classroom of any school is extremely important, as it lays a firm foundation for the future development of the pupil.
The following excerpt from a report of the school inspector on the Thunderchild Residential School is consequently very encouraging:

"This is a progressive classroom for beginners in the study of English. The children live in a natural atmosphere and there is a harmony of ideas, action, colour, sound, etc., which encourages growth. The teacher tries to understand her pupils and they respond eagerly to her appeal. I am sure correct social and study habits are encouraged."

The Inspector also notes with pleasure the success that this school obtained in securing prizes for hand work at the Regina and Prince Albert Fairs.

A few months ago we had several complaints regarding the Brandon Indian Residential School. The matter was discussed with the Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church, and the Reverend Mr. O. B. Strapp, formerly Principal of the Mount Elgin Residential School in Ontario, was transferred to Brandon as Principal. Subsequent to his taking charge of the school we arranged with Mr. Hamilton to make monthly inspections with a view to keeping a close check on this important school. In a letter dated March 10, Mr. Hamilton reports that conditions have improved at the school and that a much better feeling exists between the staff and the pupils.

The Indian Residential School conducted under the auspices of the M.S.C.C. at Fort George, Que., was destroyed by fire on January 26, 1943. The Anglican Church authorities have recently completed a new building at this point. It is 100 ft. 6 in. by 65 ft. The main floor has a 10 ft. ceiling and the second floor an 8 ft. ceiling. Building operations were commenced in the early summer of 1943 and the building was not finally completed until October, 1944. We allow per capita grant for 50 pupils.
