Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended April 30, 1945.

In a telegram dated April 9, Indian Agent Todd advised this Branch that the pump-house at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School had been destroyed by fire on April 8. Fortunately, all the equipment was saved, and arrangements were made to rebuild the pump-house at a cost of less than $200.00. The material was supplied by the Department and the work was done without cost to us, by the senior boys, under the direction of the manual training instructor.

The following extract is taken from the report of the provincial school inspector regarding his inspection, on March 22 and 23, 1945, of the Kamloops School, which is our largest Indian Residential School:

"There has been a marked improvement in the quality of the teaching in Divisions I and II, boys' classes, since my visit to the school in 1944. The teachers of these divisions are experienced teachers, who hold first class certificates in the province of Saskatchewan. The Sisters in charge of Divisions I and II, girls' classes, are also carrying on effective work. All four teachers are strongly interested in their work, keen and alert in their attitude towards modern teaching procedures, and eager to raise the standing of the classes under their charge. A more detailed account of the work carried on by these teachers will be found in the enclosed reports on the work of each.

"The school grounds are large and well adapted for recreational purposes. Father O'Grady is strongly interested in the development and beautification of the grounds about the buildings and is continuing to direct improvements in accordance with his original plans.

"The main school building, auditorium and gymnasium, manual training building, workshops, barns, etc., are well cared for and in good condition. The school plant is being further increased by the erection of a small sawmill, which, when completed, will give the male pupils an opportunity to gain valuable experience in this phase of manual training.

"Vocational training continues to receive a large measure of attention in this school, and facilities
for carrying on this work are being gradually extended. One half of each school day is given over to instruction in farm work and technical training, under competent instructors. The main objective of this instruction is to give a practical training in the duties essential to the carrying on of a well conducted farm, and in practical manual skills.

"The school is well organized and capably administered by Rev. Father O'Grady, the Principal. He is strongly interested in the well-being of the pupils under his charge, and is progressive, and receptive to new ideas in his attitude towards modern education. He has strengthened the teaching staff in a marked degree this year, particularly in the boys' divisions of the school, and has extended the facilities for training in manual and vocational training.

"The combined gymnasium and auditorium building is extensively used for recreational and physical training activities. At an evening entertainment given in this building during one evening of my visit to the school, the pupils staged an exhibition of physical exercises, vocal and instrumental music, etc. This programme was excellently presented and reflected much credit on the instructors who trained them in these various activities."

In a letter dated April 13, 1945, Indian Agent Daunt reported as follows in connection with the visit of Major Ian Eisenhardt, Federal Director of National Physical Fitness, to the St. Mary's Mission Residential School (New Westminster Indian Agency):

"I beg to report, for your information, that on April 11th, the St. Mary's Indian Residential School was visited by Major Ian Eisenhardt, Federal Director of National Physical Fitness. He was accompanied by Captain G. C. Darby, University of Saskatchewan, Mr. Ray Youmans, University of Manitoba, and Mr. Gerry Matheson, of the British Columbia Fitness Programme. I met these gentlemen at the school.

"The school teams put on a display which was declared by Major Eisenhardt to be the best he had seen in his tour of the country. He was also greatly impressed by the singing of both boys and girls.

"Major Eisenhardt stated it was his intention to call upon the Department, when he returns to Ottawa, around April 23rd, and seemed to be anxious to make arrangements, if possible, for a team from the school to give displays across Canada, during the coming summer. He will doubtless go fully into his re-actions when he visits you.

"A very fine luncheon was served to the party by the pupils of the school.

"There is no doubt that the performance put up by the pupils was a great credit to themselves, the school and the Department."

Indian Agent -
Indian Agent Matters (Chapleau Agency) advises that, at the Spring Convocation of Wycliffe College, John Jeffries, a member of the Mississaboe Cree Band, graduated and will eventually become a clergyman of the Church of England. Jeffries was formerly a pupil of the Chapleau Residential School.

Fire of unknown origin broke out in the boiler-room at the Ermineskin Residential School (Hobbema Indian Agency) just after midnight on April 16. Shortly after the outbreak of the fire, it was discovered and prompt action was taken to extinguish it. As a result of the work of the staff, assisted by the City of Wetaskiwin Fire Department, the fire was brought under control within an hour and a half. This is a church-owned school and the management carried insurance, which will cover the damage to the building. Commenting on the fire, Indian Agent Lewis writes:

"I give credit, for this fire not assuming greater proportions, to the fire drill, which is regularly practised in this school, where everyone has a job to do in case of fire, and knows how to do it, and the assistance cheerfully given by the Wetaskiwin Fire Department, to whom I would ask that the Department forward its thanks officially.

"I also wish to report that the school was evacuated in five minutes, each pupil parading in front of the school with a blanket. When it was found that there was no immediate danger, the older pupils got clothing and bedding from the dormitory and the girls and smaller boys were billeted in the Church for the night. The older boys were allowed back into the dormitory of the new wing after the fire was out."

On the recommendation of Mr. Stelfox, it was decided to approve the operation of a day school at Rocky Mountain House during the coming summer, and P.C. 2259 was obtained authorizing its establishment. Mr. Stelfox was so informed, but he now advises that in his opinion it is impossible to operate a school this year. However, he intends to make another attempt later in the year.

At the Coqualeetza Hospital we employ two teachers to give instruction to the children who are receiving treatment. The work done by the teachers has been most commendable and has elicited favourable comment from the inspector. It is interesting to know that two of the boys have recently won prizes in the Kiwanis Hobby Show for Boys. Both were first prizes - one for wood carving and the other for leather craft. This Hobby Show was held during the first week of April.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended May 31, 1945:

In a report recently received from Mr. D. S. Pitts, Principal of the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian Residential School, Kenora Agency, he advises that the Boys' Band from that school made a splendid showing at the Manitoba Musical Festival, which is stated to be one of the largest in the British Empire. The Band won two competitions and was second in the third, with marks of 86, 85 and 85.

Under the direction of Dr. W. S. Barclay, Medical Superintendent of the Coqualeetza Hospital, the second annual Tuberculosis Poster Contest was carried out among the Indian schools in British Columbia. Eleven of the 13 residential schools competed and sent a total of 37 entries. The material was sent to approximately 44 of the day schools in the province, but it is disappointing to note that only 5 of these competed. The Department allowed an amount of $25.00 for prizes and the grand prize was won by Sally Prince, aged 15 - Grade 8 - from the Lejac Indian Residential School. It is intended to hold another contest this Fall.

In reporting on his inspection of the St. Mary's Mission Residential School, Mission City, British Columbia, on May 2 and 3, the public school inspector wrote in part as follows:

"Judging by all reasonable standards, the children are exceptionally well cared for. The treatment accorded them is not coldly professional. They are growing up in an environment of kindness, sympathy and understanding. To this treatment the pupils make a fine response, with genuine loyalty and affection towards their teachers and the Principal.

"In physical education high standards have been attained, the older boys displaying superior skill and training in the most advanced programme of physical education."

A short time after receiving the above report, Major Ian Eisenhardt, National Director of Physical Fitness, Department of National Health and Welfare, visited the Branch and interviewed the Acting Director. Major Eisenhardt wrote as follows:

"I was very..."
"I was very happy to meet you last Wednesday and it was a great relief to me to realize how much importance you attach to physical fitness; at least with you I did not have to do any selling job.

"Regarding our conversation pertaining to physical training among Indians, I would appreciate it very much if you would authorize me officially to take a film on the training in physical education, which is given at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School at Mission City, B.C.

"I would also appreciate your official authorization to take along on a proposed Trans-Canada tour of a British Columbia gymnastic team, a contingent of Indian boys from the above mentioned school.

"Both of the above proposed activities have the full approval of your local officials.

"The matter of considering Indians and Eskimos as the 10th province under the National Physical Fitness Act is one which I would appreciate very much, if you would discuss with your Minister and I, on my side, will take the question up with the Minister of National Health and Welfare, The Honourable Brooke Claxton, and as soon as one of us has any news regarding further developments, we should advise the other."

We are hopeful that the interest of Major Eisenhardt in our Indian children will result in the encouragement of physical training at our Indian schools.

Judging from reports received, it is evident that domestic science is continuing to receive proper attention in the Indian day schools in the province of New Brunswick. The following report from the teacher of the Oromocto School gives a fair idea of the work being done:

"We received 20 yards of flannelette for the school and from this, the girls made their own underwear and underwear for the smaller pupils who are not able to sew. In all, 11 pairs of bloomers and 2 slips were made. From the scraps, quilt pieces were cut by the pupils and taken home to be made into quilts.

"Snow suits were made from Air Force uniforms, both for the smaller children at school and for those at home not of school age. This work was done by the women and supervised in the homes and 10 such suits were made.

"Army gloves were darned in school and given to pupils who needed them. In cases where the gloves were too badly worn to be darned, the hands were cut off and new bands knitted to the wrists. The school children, the women and the teacher supplied the yarn for this project, sometimes using yarn that had been ravelled from sweaters, etc.

"Sixteen suits of discarded Army underwear were cut down and made over to fit the boys. Besides this, the women on the reserve made over some of the underwear into suitable garments for themselves."

- The following
The following interesting newspaper clipping comments on the work being done at the St. Mary's Day School, New Brunswick West Indian Agency:

"One day this week the teachers and pupils of St. Mary's School, Devon, had a most interesting display and sale. During the past three months this school has been under the supervision of two Sisters of Charity, and innovations and improvements have been introduced. The introduction of needlework and home economics has been received with enthusiasm both by the pupils and their parents. Practical instruction is given in all branches of home economics, including knitting, sewing, crocheting, weaving and care of the home."

In reporting on the Lejac Indian Residential School, Stuart Lake Indian Agency, province of British Columbia, the public school inspector writes:

"Administration is conscientious, efficient and constructive. The harmonious relationship among staff members is gratifying and is reflected in the general atmosphere of the institution. The tone is good and the pupils appear to be happy and healthy; compared with children in the Indian day schools I visit, they are fortunate in their environment.

"The unremitting direction, supervision and attention to detail of the Sister Superior are of an unusually high order and are worthy of the highest praise.

"The farm is an instructional and economic asset and, in view of acute labour problems, its operation reflects great credit on both management and staff.

"The health of pupils receives constant attention; recreational activities are well directed and supervised. In view of the long winter season, more space for indoor activities is needed.

"The general operation of the school shows a keen appreciation of native traits and needs and reflects great credit on the principal and staff."

Memorandum—

Acting Director

I wish to submit the following report on the work of the Welfare Division during the month of June.

Correspondence from the various agencies across Canada showed that weather conditions continued bad which means that Indian farmers had great difficulty in getting their crops seeded. Undoubtedly this will affect the income of many farmers, particularly in the Prairie Provinces as the average room to seed will be a great deal less than last year.

The live stock returns for Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, have all been received with the exception of the Sarcee and Pelican Agencies. Mr. McMillan, the agent at Peigan, submitted a count indicating that it was a book count. This was considered to be unsatisfactory and was returned to Inspector Schmidt for investigation and report. The total count for Manitoba was 2869, a decrease of 100 over the previous year. The count for Saskatchewan was 7410, an increase of 993 over the previous year. The Alberta returns will be reported when the count is completed.

Mr. O. Armstrong and myself inspected the Golden Lake Reserve for one day visiting the Indian homes and the school, as well as inspecting the goat herd and pasture. Every home with the exception of three was very clean and tidy. The Indian women have really done a fine job in cleaning up their yards and surroundings. A number of children were distributed to the members of the Homemakers' Club. Milking goats are being allotted to the different families. There are three poor families who, in spite of every effort to assist them, are still living in very dirty, unhealthy shacks. It is the intention of this Division to assist these three families in constructing new homes so that their children can be brought up in sanitary conditions. In my last month's report I advised that the women members of the Homemakers' Club had undertaken to care for Angus Fisher - blind and paralyzed during the night. Since this was for a period of two months, and I wish to report that at the time of our visit the home was splendidly clean; the windows and doors were properly screened and Angus was resting as comfortable as it was possible to make him. In fact, he could not receive better care or attention. The women deserve a great deal of credit for this very fine work as I feel that it made the old man much happier to be with his own people during the few remaining days of his life. Mr. Fisher died two days after our visit and the women have the satisfaction of knowing that they did their best to make him comfortable.

The school and grounds were in excellent condition. The grounds were nicely mowed and flower beds were set out. The school children themselves were very clean and well dressed. The school-teacher, Miss McNulty, is doing a very fine job. She likes her work...
work and the children co-operate with her. There is only one criticism to make if she is to be criticised, and that is that she keeps the class as late as 6 o'clock which often makes it very late when the youngsters return to their homes. This school is a credit to our branch and compares very favourably with the best country schools for white children in the district.

The goat herd now numbering approximately 90 is in excellent condition. Some of the goats are a little on the thin side but arrangements are being made to extend their pasture. Three animals are being shipped to start another herd in the Athabasca Agency. Arrangements are now being made to place a number of milking nannies in other agencies where milk is very necessary.

A convention was held on June 19th, 20th and 21st, at the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, of delegates from reserves in eastern Canada. There were two delegates from Golden Lake; five from Manitoulin; three from Coughswayage; seven from St. Regis, and three from Caradoc—a total of 20. Practically all the members as well as the officers of the four clubs at Tyendinaga attended. The purpose of this meeting was for the women to become acquainted, discuss their problems, and learn as much as they could from the efforts of the other clubs. The meeting was held in the Council Hall. Dr. P. E. Moore, Mr. Armstrong and myself, attended the convention. Chief Clifford Maracle welcomed the out-of-town delegates and guests on behalf of the Tyendinaga Band.

Mrs. Minnie Brant, convenor of the Tyendinaga Homemakers' Clubs, read an address of welcome to the out-of-town delegates which reflected great credit on herself. She hoped that the delegates would make themselves completely at home and that they would enjoy their visit while at Tyendinaga. Dr. Moore, commenting afterwards, stated that she would grace any meeting. During the two days of my visit she was very busy among the delegates seeing that they were looked after properly and arranging teas and luncheons. In other words, she supervised the convention so that everything ran off smoothly.

Mr. Armstrong gave a short talk on the benefits of Family Allowances. He pointed out to the women that as leaders in their various reserves they should do everything humanly possible to assist in bettering the living conditions of their children. He gave them figures on the amount of money that could be distributed in each of their reserves if all the children between the ages of one and fifteen were registered. According to the last census, the total amount from Family Allowances at Caradoc will be—$36,300.00; Golden Lake $5,100.00; Coughswayage $72,300.00; Manitoulin $15,120.00; St. Regis $31,740.00 and Tyendinaga $10,840.00. Mr. Armstrong emphasized that if the money is properly spent there should be a real improvement in the health and living conditions of all families.

Dr. Moore gave an illustrated lecture on diseases of the eyes, mouth, skin, etc. His lecture naturally would be very technical, but in simple language he told the women how many of these diseases could be avoided and cured by proper eating. That is, cooking the foods properly and preparing balanced diets for their families. He showed these women how it will be possible to purchase such foods as milk, greens, etc., with the money available from Family Allowances. I am of the opinion that the women benefited a great deal by his talk.

Dr. H. A. Boyce, physician for the Tyendinaga Reserve, gave a health talk and stressed the eating of proper foods, particularly milk for children.

Mr. T. L. Bonnabit.
Mr. T. L. Bemah's talk on why we should organize our Indian children went over in a big way. He has recently organized a Boy Scout Company as well as a Girl Guide Company at his agency. One of the representatives from St. Regis was Margaret Thomas, a fourteen-year-old patrol leader. She looked very lovely in her Girl Guide uniform. She gave a display of the uses made of the rope, which is part of her uniform, as well as giving a brief talk on the significance of the different badges, etc.

Mr. Bemah was very much in demand at rest periods by the delegates of the other clubs, who were anxious to learn all about his organizations so that similar ones could be introduced at their reserves.

Miss N. Stoddart, school-teacher at the eastern Indians school, gave a talk on education. She stressed the necessity of children attending school regularly and requested that the women of the Homemakers' Clubs use their influence to encourage all mothers to see that their children attended school regularly and on time.

Mrs. Morris Mareale (Indian), school-teacher at the central school, also gave a short talk on the attendance of school children stating that she had been a student under Miss Stoddart and that she found her advice and encouragement very beneficial and that she always looked up to Miss Stoddart as her inspiration. Mrs. Mareale entertained the delegates by playing several piano selections.

Mrs. J. Levalley, of Golden Lake, gave a brief talk on the benefits derived on her reserve since the organization of the Homemakers' Club at Golden Lake. She stated that the Indians at Golden Lake had made more progress since the Homemakers' Club was formed four years ago than in the previous 25 years.

Mrs. Lewis McComber, President of the Coughswaga Homemakers' Club, stated that she was firmly convinced that if the women will continue the work of their organization and cooperate with the Indian Affairs Branch that great good can be accomplished on the reserves. She was loud in her praise of the assistance and encouragement they had received and stated that the Medical Division had already accomplished a great deal of good for them by providing medical services and hospitalization. Mrs. McComber has only one complaint to make and she asked that attention be given to the placing of key teachers in charge of the schools at Coughswaga at an early date. She stated that she knew there was a serious shortage of teachers but hoped that when this condition improved the Branch would give serious consideration to her suggestion.

Reverend H. Pringle, the Anglican Minister located on the reserve, gave a very interesting talk. He selected as his subject "Homemakers' Clubs" and then gave a brief explanation of each word emphasizing its meaning, describing what a house consisted of, showing the difference of makers of homes and breakers of homes, and the importance of clubbing together to accomplish the maximum of good for all. Mr. Pringle pointed out the fact that the several speakers had stressed the importance of the proper care and feeding of children, as well as how living conditions generally could be improved. He was of the opinion that these talks would be very beneficial and would assist the Indians in complying with the Family Allowances Act.
The delegates from each of the Homemakers' Clubs, represented, placed on display articles of remodelled clothing made by their members. This clothing displayed excellent workmanship and were all useful articles of wearing apparel. The more you see of the work that these women do the more you realize that they are experts with their hands. Prizes were given for the best samples. The judges were two women prominent in Red Cross work at Deseronto. Indian Agent A. D. Moore reports on the convention as follows:

During the first two days of the gathering Departmental officials were present and are quite familiar with the proceedings that took place on those days. At 10:00 A.M. on June 21st, the Club members assembled at the home of the Reverend H. Pringle and spent one half hour viewing the display of hand paintings of Mr. Pringle at the Rectory. At 12:30 a party of forty proceeded to the R.C.A.F. Mohawk Airport where, by the kindness of the Commanding Officer, Group Captain Seacole, they were provided with guides, and for two hours, visited the main points of interest at the Airport. At 1:00 P.M., they assembled at the Council Hall for luncheon.

While the delegates were at luncheon, I secured the services of Mrs. McCullough and Mrs. Dalanly, prominent Red Cross workers of Deseronto, and had them judge the articles that were on display. In view of the fact that these articles were made from many varieties of materials, and, as each Reserve had a magnificent display, it was decided that the judges would pick the best made articles from the whole display which were set aside as samples of the best workmanship, and, in doing so, some articles were taken from the exhibits of each and every Reserve. Mrs. McCullough addressed the gathering and explained the reasons for the choices made by the judges, and so that there would be no hard feelings among the delegates, we awarded each visiting delegation a prize of $5.00 from the $25.00 authorized, which pleased them very much. As Tyendinaga has four Clubs and each had a large display, I, in consultation with Mrs. Brent and the judges, thought they were worthy of consideration as the basis and gave them a prize of $2.50 for each club, or a total of $10.00, making total prize awards of $35.00. As the programme called for the awarding of prizes, I paid them in cash which pleased the delegates very much, and, if you consider the amount paid excessive or not authorized, you can deduct the same from the enclosed voucher.

After the awarding of prizes the meeting was thrown open and, with my permission, the delegates exchanged a number of articles among themselves so that they could take home and display the work that was being done on other Reserves. After the mutual exchange of ideas for the betterment of the clubs, the meeting closed and the delegates packed their exhibits and were conveyed to their trains; some proceeding Thursday evening, while others remained over until Friday morning.

Mrs. Brent informs me that she hopes to have sufficient Club funds...
" Funds to pay all local accounts for transportation, board and lodgings, but if they run short, it may be necessary to ask the Department to pay a small amount, and this will be known definitely when all accounts are in and the local clubs meet.

In my opinion the gathering was a marked success and the delegates should carry back to their Reserves many new ideas and suggestions for the benefit of their peoples. The Tyendinaga Clubs are to be congratulated on the manner in which they organized and carried through their duties as hostesses and who were so instrumental in the success of the gathering, and I would suggest that a letter be sent by the Department to Mrs. Brent, her officers and members, to congratulate them for the services they rendered."

Indian Agent Moore acted as Chairman for the convention. He was very constructive in his suggestions and guidance, and conducted the meeting in a most efficient manner.

The delegates were taken on a tour of the reserve visiting homes, the schools and the churches, and a special visit was made to the Mohawk R.C.A.F. Airport. Attached hereto is a programme which you will note made a very busy three days. It is my personal opinion that this meeting will prove very beneficial and the various delegates will go back to their reserves and report what they have learned to the members of their clubs. Undoubtedly if the women on these reserves will work together, and with the benefits to be derived from Family Allowances, they should accomplish a great deal of good both for themselves and their families. It is hoped that these meetings will become an annual affair. The delegation from St. Regis requested that the meeting next year be held on their reserve.

As you know Tyendinaga is noted for the large acreage put into growing crops for the canners such as beans, peas, tomatoes, etc. Last fall this reserve did a great deal of fall ploughing and the Indians hoped to increase their acreage this year. However, the late wet spring made this impossible. A great number of acres will not be planted at all. One Indian who had planted thirteen acres of tomatoes lost the whole crop two nights later by frost. He was unable to replant all of the crop, but he was successful in obtaining additional tomato plants to replace eight acres.

Indian Agent Lariviere reports as follows on Phillip Palson, Turgan Lake, Quebec, who is to receive a number of goats this year from the Golden Lake herd:

" Above advised he secured a ploy. As on hay it was possible for him to pay for it cash on delivery. He demanded that I express his thanks to you for having protected him in case it would have been impossible for him to pay cash. He further demanded that I thank you for having furnished him with seeds. He stated that you may rest assured that he will look after the goats to the best of his ability, not only for his own benefit but to support movement to improve Indians, etc.

Taking advantage of this letter - the Palson girl at school in Amos - I am informed, has done very well and desires to return.

These Palsons are no doubt exceptions and I believe through them much can be done to improve other Indians in their area. They have just ambitions and do things in an intelligent manner without ups and downs, like we usually find among the so-called intelligent Indians."

Mr. Lariviere...
Mr. Lariviere, in his report on the goats at Wawenapit in which he refers to the Indians as the 'Happy Potato Band' because of the number of bushels of potatoes they harvested last year, states:

This Band as found could be called, to better express their views, etc., 'Happy Potato Band'. The other very interesting part respects the goats. In spite of hard luck (the billy and the oldest and best nanny died during winter) they are getting from 4 goats, two young ones and two about 3 years old, 2 gallons of milk daily. Our trouble this year was "I HAVE NO MILK" can get some. See Gill "the boss" of the goat set up, he arranged things, in an Indian like manner and he certainly has created a STRONG DESIRE FOR MILK (even an aged Indian stated if he had THAT KIND OF MILK HE WOULD FEEL FINE). In his set up he takes care that his daughter does most of the work. His goats are getting to be very good milking them, too. The value of milk to them based on EVAPORATED MILK FROM STORE is about $6.00 per day. At the present time our boss said "I THINK I WILL FLA IT TO GET 3 GALLONS MORE". The reason why, he said, he was watching them very close because he found out some days they give more and he WANTS MORE.

With regard to the Wawenapit Band, Indian Agent Lariviere further reports that he arranged for twelve able-bodied men to be engaged as fire-rangers by the Province. Fifteen men were sent to Clova to work on special jobs for the Canadian International Paper Company. In each case he arranged that part of their wages was mailed to the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company at Wawenapit to provide food and other necessities for their families. Further he had the doctor inoculate them for typhoid. He made a request to the Canadian International Paper Company that their foreman be requested to instruct the brighter Indians in the art of filling saws so that they would be more competent in pulpwood operations.

Regarding the prosecution of Indians who commit acts of immorality particularly against the juveniles, the following is an excerpt from Inspector Osmundson's letter to the Superintendent of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police at Regina. Note, this letter was written at the request of the Welfare Division:

Confirming conversation in your office on the 9th instant and in view of the fact that many cases have gone unpunished when Indians have been charged under Section 301-2 of the Criminal Code, it is considered in order, and in fact advisable, that your Detachment men should lay charges under the Juvenile Delinquents Act in the future unless there is almost a certainty of conviction under Section 301-2 of the Criminal Code.

It has been found that in the very few cases where a conviction was secured on a charge of Carnal Knowledge the Penalty imposed was very light as Magistrates do not seem to consider that offences of this nature committed by Indians, upon Indians, are as serious as such offence committed by white people, upon white people. For this reason it is thought...
thought that a conviction under the Juvenile Delinquents Act will serve the purpose. The defense usually put up when an Indian is charged under Section 301-2 of the Criminal Code is that the girl in question was not of previous chart character. Such a statement by the accused when charged under the Juvenile Delinquents Act will be no defense and implicate others, thereby resulting in their being charged the same.

Indian Agent Mr. Sampson in his quarterly report states:

"Children of Unmarried Parents Act, No. 56,

Two cases under this Act were brought into court and both putative fathers were ordered to pay maintenance costs of the illegitimate children. Another case is under investigation now. The fathers in all cases are Indians."

Mr. Sampson advises re trapping and hunting:

"The winter's returns have been moderate and all trappers have had slightly increased revenue this season as lynx is becoming plentiful again and is currently bringing a good price. Wolves continue in great numbers and besides seriously depleting and driving moose from the country are attacking beaver and foxes. With the ban on poisoning these predators few are caught; trapping them requires patience, scrupulous care, and cleanliness which the Indian fails to give."

It is the intention of the Welfare Division to encourage Inspectors and Agents at every opportunity to prosecute and imprison Indians who are living in an immoral manner.

Father J. E. Beaumet, O.M.I., of Val d'or, Quebec, visited the office. He was loud in his praise of the work being accomplished by Indian Agent Lariviere. He was curious to know what control, if any, would be exercised over the purchases made by Indians with Family Allowance cheques. When informed that certain foods would be supplied under the supervision of the Indian Agent he expressed pleasure, and he felt that if the proper foods were supplied it would be very beneficial in improving the health of children and families.

J. E. Morris,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, July 3, 1945.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended June 30, 1945:

During the past month there has been considerable correspondence with respect to repairs and equipment required at the various schools throughout Canada for the coming academic year.

Requisitions for school material have been completed and forwarded to the Government Stationery Office.

Approximately 560 letters have been sent out from the Division and 485 vouchers were passed for payment.

Mr. Doucet was absent for approximately three weeks, during which time he inspected the following Residential Schools: Spanish, Shingwauk Home, Fort William, Sioux Lookout, McIntosh and Fort Frances. He also inspected the Day Schools on the Garden River Reserve. The following are extracts from his report:

SPANISH RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

"The pupils have been divided into two groups, the juniors and the seniors. This division takes place in the refectory and in the dormitories. The result has been very gratifying to the pupils and the management. The senior boys have their clubroom near the dormitory. This clubroom is under the management of the pupils themselves. They need not retire at the same time as the juniors but may do so at their own discretion. Their good behaviour entitles them to this privilege. This is a definite step in the training of responsibility.

"A great improvement is noticeable in the spirit of these pupils. This, I believe, is due in part to the divisions mentioned above and to the introduction of other activities such as organized games, skating parties, etc., in which both boys and girls participate. This is normal in the life of young people and with the proper supervision is bound to have a good result. In general, in all the schools there appears to be a better spirit among the children. This is attributed mostly to the application of the principles encouraged by the general convention at Winnipeg."

SHINGWAUK

"The Girl Guides do good work. There is a happy spirit among the girls. They attend meetings with other girls in the city. They are left to manage these meetings..."
themselves and participate in the work. This organization will leave its mark on the character of these children. It is unfortunate that the boys are not so well favoured. This is due, of course, to the lack of trained male help. It is hoped that this flaw in our schools may soon be remedied.

"A number of pupils attend the Sault Ste. Marie High School and are a credit to the school and to themselves. The Reverend Principal takes great pride in the achievements of his pupils and is doing a good job under difficult circumstances. Tests taken at this school will appear also at the end of this report."

"SIoux LOOKOUT

"The cadets are doing very commendable work. They take a great deal of pride in their appearance and carry on very efficiently. They deserve a great deal of credit. In order to train for their work they walk once a week five miles to get to Sioux Lookout, march drill, and practise there for a number of hours and then return to their school. They were preparing for a general inspection in Sioux Lookout and I had the pleasure of meeting the executives and the various training officers. These people expressed their satisfaction with the work done by the Sioux Lookout Indian Cadets."

"RECOMMENDATIONS:

"Two main points have struck me on this inspection trip:

1. The eagerness of the teachers in seeking information and endeavouring to improve their methods.

2. The handicap under which teachers who have not been able to get any professional training are working.

"It has also struck me that in the schools that I have visited for the second time there is a great improvement in the spirit of the children. There is more happiness, more satisfaction,- In other words, greater family spirit. It is rather encouraging to notice that some of the suggestions that have been carried out seem to be bringing results.

"Some method will have to be found to give teachers who wish to work in Indian schools a special training that will fit them to teach Indian children. As mentioned in my previous reports, the teacher is the keystone for the complete structure of Indian education. This, I wish to add, to my mind, is of primary importance."
Public School Inspector McBurney, in reporting on his inspection of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario, wrote as follows:

"This is the first time it has been my privilege to visit Miss Atwater. She comes to this school with many years' successful experience at Gordon Indian School. There is every indication that she is doing very commendable work. Her pupils are making good progress in their studies. They show good interest in their work and their books are neatly kept. Peter Hill, in Grade VIII, is an Entrance candidate this year.

"The classroom is clean and bright and the classroom material is put to good use. The Register is carefully kept.

"At the time of my visit it was a privilege to meet Mr. Doucet, Inspector from the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa. I heard him speak the evening of May 16th to the members of the Sioux Lookout Public School Home and School Club. He gave a very interesting talk on present-day trends in education.

"It was also a pleasure to renew acquaintances with the principal of the school, Rev. A. B. Cheales, and with Mrs. Cheales. During this war period Mr. Cheales has had an added burden because of the scarcity of fully-qualified teachers for his school."

Inspector Warkentin, in reporting on his inspection of the Fort Alexander Residential School, Clandeboye Agency, Manitoba, made the following interesting comments:

"The progress made by the pupils in Miss Tetrault's room is excellent and truly exceptional. This is particularly evident in the beginners' class, who have had only one year's instruction. While most of them, if not all of them, are older than white children would be for the same grade, I find that these children have made better progress in reading than many classes of beginners in the other schools of my division. When I remember that the Indian children are learning to read what is to them a foreign language and that the teacher is instructing in a language which is not her mother tongue, I find the skill acquired by these children truly remarkable."
I attach, for your information, a Year Book issued by the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. As you know, this school is located at Lebret, Saskatchewan, and has an authorized enrolment of 250. This booklet is a very interesting review of the work of the school for the academic year 1944-45 and it will, no doubt, be noted with interest that over 100 of the ex-pupils of this school were in the Armed Forces.

The water for the Alberni Residential School, situated in the West Coast Agency, Vancouver Island, British Columbia, is secured from the town of Alberni. For some months past the management has been complaining regarding the charges for the water. Indian Commissioner MacKay was instructed to arrange with officials of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Vancouver, to investigate the matter. This was done recently and it was found that the water system was leaking at the rate of 10,000 gallons per day, maximum pressure. This leak has been repaired, at no expense.

The attached snapshot gives an idea of the articles produced by the Woodworking Class at the Old Sun Indian Residential School, operated under the auspices of the Church of England, at Gleichen, Alberta.
Inspector McBurney's report, following his inspection of the Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School on June 4, reads in part as follows:

"Mrs. Douglas continues to do good work, as in previous years. Her pupils are making good progress in their studies. They speak and read well for Indian children. The writing and art work, as in previous years, is excellent.

"In my opinion Mrs. Douglas has an excellent influence on the pupils and on the school. She has now been teaching twelve years in this school.

"The Boys' Band at this school has over a number of years won distinction. Most of the boys in the Band are in this classroom.

MR. HOST,

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended July 31, 1945:

On July 31 there were 32 Indian day schools for which we had not yet secured a teacher for the academic year 1945-46. At 19 of this number the teacher has always been nominated by one of the Churches. In each of these cases the Church concerned has assured us that a teacher will be secured before September 1. To secure teachers for the remaining 13, we have been in communication with the Indian Agent and the local Inspector and others interested and we are still hopeful that at the majority of them, at least, we will be able to secure a teacher before the new academic year commences.

During the first part of the month Mr. Doucet visited the Restigouche Reserve and made arrangements for necessary improvements to the school. On the return trip he visited Bérelinie, where we are now operating the school from March 1 to November 15. There was an excellent attendance of pupils at the time he was present and the classroom work appeared to be progressing satisfactorily. On July 28 he left for Winnipeg, to conduct a Teachers' Conference at St. Boniface Manitoba, during the last week of the month.

A report from the Principal of the Elkhorn Residential School supplied detailed information regarding the graduation exercises and a notable performance of "The Moon Goddess" which was presented at the City of Brandon by an all-Indian cast, the members of which had been trained by the Principal. Both the Brandon Daily Sun and the Elkhorn Mercury gave special prominence to this performance.

Inspector George Young, reporting on his inspection of the Back Settlement Day School, Caradoc Agency, Province of Ontario, wrote:

"The class work of this school leads the rest of the reserve. I found all pupils very happy and apparently making rapid progress, in spite of irregular attendance. The progress in every subject is almost equal to our best white schools. The youngsters all read well, write neatly, explain subjects with ability, answer promptly, calculate with a good degree of skill and speed. Their records indicate that they are covering a large portion of the regular Ontario Course of Study.

"A limited amount of hand work has been accomplished. Mrs. Thompson has given you splendid service and has developed a commendable spirit in the purchase of War Savings Stamps. Their conduct is most commendable."
Inspector G. W. Bartlett, reporting on his inspection of the Fairford Indian Day School, Portage la Prairie and Manitowapah Agency, Manitoba, commented on the school as follows:

"I am glad to learn that all requests for supplies and equipment made last year have been met. The children present were ahead in Arithmetic of those in similar grades in white schools but much slower in getting work done. I got very good results in Silent Reading, but their Oral Reading leaves much to be desired."

During the month 620 letters were sent out from this Division and 650 vouchers were passed for payment.

The following visitors called at the office during the month:

Lt.-Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Supt., Brantford, Ont.
Rev. F. O'Grady, Principal, Kamloops Indian Residential School, Kamloops, B.C.
Rev. T. J. Dwyer, S.J., Indian Missionary, North Shore, Lake Huron.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, September 6, 1945.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended August 31, 1945.

In my report for the month of July I stated that on July 31 there were 32 Indian day schools for which we had not yet secured a teacher for the academic year 1945-46. On August 31 there were 22 schools for which a teacher had not yet been secured. Of this number, 11 were schools at which the Church concerned is allowed to nominate the teacher, and in all of these cases the church authorities feel that a teacher will yet be secured.

From July 31 to August 3, inclusive, Mr. Doucet conducted a summer course at St. Boniface. This was attended by 82 teachers from Indian residential schools in Manitoba. On August 6, 7, 8 and 9 he conducted a similar course at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask., which was attended by 40 teachers of Indian residential schools. Reports from those interested indicate that great interest was shown by all present and everyone appeared satisfied with the manner in which these courses were conducted.

Following these conferences, Mr. Doucet proceeded to The Pas, where he examined the buildings of The Pas Air Force, with a view to determining if they would be suitable for a residential school, requested by the Missionary Society of the Church of England. Mr. Doucet's conclusions were that the buildings available at this point would not be suitable as a residential school.

Inspector Hamilton, reporting on his visit during the month of July to Cross Lake Reserve, writes as follows in connection with the Cross Lake Indian Residential School:

"This was my first visit to the new school and I was greatly impressed with the very excellent building.

"The dormitories were spotless, well aired and very bright. The beds were quite close together, but with all the windows I am sure the children have plenty of fresh air. The bedding was clean and there was abundant.

"The classrooms were very bright and the walls nicely decorated. The desks, although in use for some years, were almost without a scratch. I am certain, from the books seen, that the Sisters do very excellent work in the classroom.

"I examined the work done in the sewing-room..."
and must admit that the girls do splendid sewing. They make dresses, knit all kinds of garments and do very excellent patch-work and darning.

The kitchen and dining rooms were in excellent order and the girls receive a good training in cooking and baking. The children seen were in good health and I am sure are well cared for and well fed.

The school has a large garden, which this year was planted late and of course was not up when I was there. The Rev. Father keeps some very fine Holstein cows, a flock of hens and some pigs. The school is under excellent management and the children appeared very happy. The operating of such an excellent school in this remote area is a great credit to the Church and Government. The Rev. Father Trudeau is interested in his work and is assisted by an excellent staff of Sisters."

With your approval, I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve during the month, in order to choose accommodation for another classroom, rendered necessary by the return to the reserve of several Indian families who have been residing in the United States. A store on the main street of the village was secured and this should prove suitable for the current academic year. I also went to Brantford, where Colonel Randle and myself interviewed Rev. Mr. J. Zimmerman, who is now Principal of the Mohawk Institute. Detailed reports regarding these visits have already been submitted to you.

Requests for materials and supplies of various kinds, correspondence with regard to appointment of teachers and other communications related to the re-opening of the schools for the academic year 1945-46 have necessitated a great deal of correspondence during the month, and all members of the staff have been extremely busy. Seven hundred and sixty (760) letters were sent out from this Division during the month and $25 vouchers were passed for payment.

The following visitors called at the office during the month:

Rev. J. Camirand, Principal, Kuper Island Indian Residential School, B.C.

Rev. L. Lauzon, Indian Missionary, Cowichan Agency, B.C.

Rev. Father Lalonde, S.J., Indian Missionary, Caughnawaga,

Rev. Sister Mary George, Principal, Indian Day School (P.C.) Caughnawaga, Que.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Memorandum—

Director—

The following is a report on the work of the Welfare Division during the month of August.

Early in the month the Division shipped clothing made by our Indian Homemakers' Clubs at Tyendinaga, Golden Lake, St. Regis, Maniwaki and Restigouche, to the Unappelle Indian Hospital and the new Airport Hospital at The Pas. The Purchasing Agent in reporting that he was unable to obtain children's flannel gowns required for the latter hospital suggested that this clothing might be manufactured by Homemakers' Clubs. Arrangements are being made to have them supplied by the Tyendinaga Branch. In acknowledging receipt of the shipment mentioned above Dr. Simson, Medical Superintendent of the Unappelle Hospital, wrote as follows:

"The shipment of clothing arrived here in good condition and we appreciate receiving it very much. As the quality of material in pyjamas and nightgowns is such superior to what may be purchased anywhere today, and our stock is nil, we would appreciate a further shipment of them should they become available."

Dr. R. F. Iule, Medical Superintendent, of The Pas Agency, reporting on his treaty trip—conditions generally and York Factory in particular—states:

"I think that gardens could also be classified as natural resources which have not been used to the extent which they might be. This applies to a greater or less extent to all reserves. However, it is my considered opinion that there will be no progress in this direction until the Indians are given a firm and sympathetic supervision."

While on the subject of gardening I have to quote an excerpt from Mr. Inspector Hamilton's report on a visit to the Mathias Colomb Reserve at Pukatagan in The Pas Agency on July 10, 1945:

"There were a few nice garden plots. I found potatoes just coming through the ground and those were the first I had seen up in any Indian garden. I was told by several (Indians) that many have small plots of potatoes close to their winter dwellings."
Speaking of new sources of income, in the same report, the Inspector states that some members of this Band are starting to engage in fishing in addition to the usual hunting and trapping. One Indian said that he and his son made $200.00 fishing in ten days. They fish at Grenville Lake and Ramell Lake.

Each year the Division provides a certain sum of money to pay prizes for garden competitions. This year gardens have been disappointing as a whole because of the cold, wet spring. Despite this handicap some basins have done remarkably well. Agent Whalen, of Fredericton, N.B., reporting on the competition in his agency, encloses a letter from the judge of the competition, Mr. R. A. Smith, Horticultural Service, of the Provincial Department of Agriculture, Fredericton. This enclosure deals with the Kingsclear Reserve Competition and, in part, reads as follows:

"Your department and the Indians themselves are to be congratulated on the excellence of various gardens, which are a credit, considering the unfavourable season and the poor results obtained. The project, I feel, is a step in the right direction as it helps the Indians to support themselves at a time when certain foods are in short supply. Generally speaking some of these gardens compare very favourably with the best found anywhere this season."

From time to time the Division receives reports from various sources indicating that the Indians as a whole throughout the Dominion are experiencing a period of prosperity. Many of these reports would indicate that the Indians are engaging in co-operative enterprises thus taking advantage of their natural resources which in former days would have been more or less exploited by whites. As a case in point I might mention the Bella Coola Indian Agency. This Agency has considerable timber resources which in former years would probably have been sold on a stumpage basis to white operators who would have engaged white men to do the work of cutting the timber. The Indians of Bella Coola have organized an association called the Bella Coola Lumbermen who are cutting the timber on the reserve and selling it direct to the manufacturers thus eliminating the middle man's profits. An Auditor's report on a recent inspection of this Agency shows that in the 1944-45 operations the income of this group was $22,461.79. Disbursements, which include among other items, a new tractor, bulldozer, $230.00 purchase of war bonds, Red Cross $101.00, party for the troops $25.00, wages $8,717.14, amount to $22,122.54, leaving a cash balance of $338.85 to their credit after a loan from the department of $5,000.00 has been repaid. In addition to the above credit this association now has assets of some $12,500.00, and a credit surplus of $6,886.38 timber cut but not delivered. Considerable credit for the success of this venture must be given to the local Indian Agent who manages the books of the association, and keeps them straight in so far as their financial transactions are concerned.
In a report from the Bella Coola Agency, dated July 24, the agent states as follows:

"Plans are now being considered to have the Bella Coola Indians loggers take over a timber license of three million feet of spruce on Kwatna Inlet as a fall operation when fishing closes down. At Bella Bella the Indians had a satisfactory herring run with a gross of $56,000.00 to the bands. This operation was followed by a fairly good halibut season and the commissioners advise that $25,000.00 cash was paid to the Bella Bella Indians for halibut and fresh fish this spring."

The Auditor's report on the Kwakwaka'wakw Indian Agency states that the 1944-45 revenue from all sources amounted to $78,401.06. He notes an item - refund of income tax deductions to Indian fishermen $22,641.77.

Inspector Hamilton reporting on a visit to York Factory and Shuswap districts states as follows:

"The Indians, especially at York, were well dressed. They had good clothes and all were clean in appearance. The babies were very clean and outfitted with nice clothes and plenty of bright warm blankets. These same remarks apply to the Shuswap group and those located at Gillam. Certainly there were no signs of recent hardship or poverty. The relief issued to the York Factory Indians for the winter amounted to less than $100.00 and Mr. Island, the Indians' Agent Manager, said there was no hardship. He also stated that the Indians had paid practically all their debts.

There is work now for all the Indians freighting for the Hudson's Bay Company. They earn about $4.00 per day and board. It takes a week to make a return trip to Shuswap for which the Indians receive $25.00 and food. They will have steady work until they leave (for their trapping grounds) in September."

Dr. J. P. Harvey, Indian Agent, at Fort Norman,

N.W.T., reports:

"Contrary to my expectations the prices of spring fur held up and the catch was good. This was general throughout the area. Consequently, the people at present have fairly large quantities of money among them and also as a consequence, the gambling is again flourishing at new higher levels. Talking seems to have little effect and it seems that to cut it down will require definite regulations with penalties."
Throughout the Dominion the French receive communications showing that the Indians of Canada appreciate the fact that they receive family allowances in the same manner as their white neighbours. Agent Featherston, of the Ross Indian Agency, at Longford Mills, Ontario, remarking on this states:

"They are now impatiently waiting for the initial payment and think that the whole thing is a successful idea. What the agent thinks is another story."

The Indians of Northern Manitoba are increasingly obtaining employment in the fishing industry. Prices are high when disposed of to the consumer, but owing to the cost of transportation from northern areas the return to the Indians is not as great as one would be led to expect. However, this industry is assuring an income to the Indians at a period when they used to be very hard up. Inspector Hamilton, reporting on his recent inspection of the Norway House Agency, states that the Indians of God's Lake are receiving $.45 per lb. for white fish and $.65 per lb. for trout plus a .25 bonus in each case. They contracted to supply up to 600,000 lbs. of fish. This limit was not reached, but some idea of the amount that was supplied is reflected in a credit of approximately $1,000.00 bonus money which has been left with the trader as a fund to be used in obtaining winter outfits to go hunting and trapping. The trader, Mr. Campbell, advises that he has work which will give the Indians from $2,500.00 to $3,000.00 and they can start this work any day.

Mr. Inspector Thibault reporting on a recent inspection tour of the Lower St. Lawrence states that the Indian Agent at Mingan reported that hunting was fairly good and prices paid to the Indians for their fur were very good. This success in hunting is reflected in lowered relief costs. The agent states that relief is now being given to only the old and sick Indians.

Mr. John E. Pugh, our Indian Agent at Blood, reports calling for tenders on the sale of 455 steers and 150 head of dry cows and heifers. Bids are to be received up to 4 P.M. on September 4 next.

Mr. C. F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies in Alberta, reports that it was necessary to destroy one of the departmental herd bulls at Morley, Alberta. This bull was sold for slaughter, as due to some disease he was of no further use for breeding purposes.

The Division has received a report from the ReGellePe stating that an Indian of the White Bear Indian Reserve had been sentenced to three months in the Regina goal for an offence of contributing to juvenile delinquency under the Juvenile Delinquents Act. It might be pointed out that this Division is attempting to obtain a conviction in every case where there are offences against
young Indian girls. We find that the magistrates are inclined to a misguided leniency in their sentences because they seem to be of the opinion that because the crime is committed by Indians against Indians it is not as serious as it would be if the parties were whites. In my opinion, the only way to prevent such offenses is to amend the Indian Act to give the Indian agent power to deal with them.

[Signature]

G. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.
Memorandum—

Director—

The following is a report on the activities of the Welfare Division during the month of September.

Reports received from Indian Agents across the Dominion show our Homemakers' Clubs to be very active:

Deseronto Club—This club has arranged to make up 50 children's flannel gowns for the Airport Hospital at The Pas, Manitoba. The Purchasing Agent was unable to obtain this clothing from usual trade sources so the Indian women kindly offered to assist us by making the gowns.

Restigouche Club—This club consists of some 15 members under the guidance of the Reverend Principal of the Indian Day School. They have arranged to make 300 pairs of pyjamas and 500 dressing-gowns during the coming winter for the use of our Indian hospitals. The Branch is to provide the materials and will pay .75¢ each for the garments. Payment is to be in kind, that is, useful household equipment; and or clothing.

Golden Lake—This club under the capable leadership of Mrs. J. Levalley held a picnic to collect funds for the building of a new church on the reserve. Over $1,400.00 was collected. This winter, in addition to the usual activities, they are going to carry on with their programme of making dressing-gowns for use in Indian hospitals.

During the month organisation of clubs continued in the Birtle and Portage la Prairie Agencies. Miss E. Smith Windsor was engaged as an organiser during the month of August. During that period she visited the following clubs—Belting River Reserve, Keesekookomin, Bird Tail Sioux, Long Plain Reserve and Swan Lake Reserve. Miss Windsor reports that the clubs are active and are doing excellent work in the re-modelling of military clothing for their own and their less fortunate neighbours' use. The Swan Lake Club put on a special display at the Swan Lake Fair and received fifteen first prizes and five seconds for their work. One is amazed at the ingenuity of the women in re-modelling discarded army clothing. Miss Windsor notes quilts from khaki shorts, windbreakers from khaki drill and a "trim little dress" from a khaki shirt.

A new club has been organised at the Oka Country School. This club has a membership of sixteen and the President is a Mrs. Oke. This is the first sign that a band hitherto classed as
uncooperative may be experiencing a change of heart. Anyway it is a step in the right direction and the club will receive every encouragement from the Branch.

Attached hereto is a copy of a most interesting report on the summer camp held for the Girl Guide Company of the St. Regis Band. This was an experiment on the part of Mr. T. L. Bomah, our local Indian Agent, and I would say that the results show that it is definitely worth while.

Last month we submitted a report on commercial fishing on God's Lake Reserve of the Norway House Indian Agency. We have now been advised that the Marketing Prices and Trade Board have ordered the white contractor (as to increase the price paid to Indians for fish by $2 to $3 per lb., as this contract was for an amount of $50,000 lbs., the adjustment will assure the Indians of considerable extra income. This action was a result of representations made by Mr. Cowan, Assistant Deputy Minister of Mines and Natural Resources for the Province of Manitoba.

During the month the Branch finally succeeded in having a wooden shack situated on No. 2 Highway, Tyendinaga Reserve, dismantled. This shack was an eye-sore among the well kept farms and farm buildings fronting on the main road.

A Royal Canadian Mounted Police report recently received shows that Alfred Clarke, a treaty Indian from the God's Lake Band, was sentenced to six months in Norway House Common Gaol because of a charge of non-support laid against him by his wife. This sentence was suspended on the accused answering that he would support his wife and children in the amount of $25.00 per month. We have had considerable trouble with Indians who, on living off a reserve, fail to contribute to the support of their wives. The action on part of the Magistrate at Norway House should certainly cut down complaints of this nature in that area at least.

During the month many Indian delegates to the Convention in Ottawa visited the Division. Numerous welfare matters were discussed to the mutual advantage of the Division and the Indians concerned. Welfare matters in general were discussed with Mr. T. L. Bomah, Indian Agent at St. Regis. He has submitted a proposed set of bylaws for the St. Regis Band. These bylaws were passed unanimously by the Band Council, and it is hoped that once they have become law many hang-ups to the agent's programme for bettering conditions in the agency will be eliminated.

C. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.
Ottawa, October 4, 1945.

Memorandum:

M. ALLAN.

I submit herewith a report of the activities of the Training Division for the month ended September 30, 1945.

In my last monthly report I stated that on August 31 there were 28 Indian day schools for which a teacher had not been secured for the academic year 1945-46. During the past month we have succeeded in re-opening 7 of these and consequently on September 30, 1945, there were 15 Indian day schools without teachers, divided as follows: Ontario 5; Manitoba 2; Saskatchewan 1; and British Columbia 7. It is interesting to note that an article in the Winnipeg Free Press dated August 29, 1945, stated that at the re-opening of the white schools in Manitoba on September 1 there were 125 rural schools without a teacher.

Early reports from various parts of the Dominion indicate that we may expect very large attendances at all our day schools. This is probably due to a great extent to the payment of family allowances. As soon as the September quarter returns are received, it is intended to review each of them carefully and make certain that children enrolled are attending regularly.

As family allowances are not paid to parents whose children are enrolled in residential schools, it was felt some months ago that there might be considerable difficulty in obtaining full enrolment at the residential schools this year. However, with the exception of a few schools, recent reports indicate that practically all our residential schools will have their full enrolment, and in many cases they have received applications for more pupils than there is accommodation available.

Consequent upon the opening of the schools for another academic year the correspondence during the month has been extremely heavy. Eight hundred and fifty (850) letters were sent out from this Division during the month and 550 vouchers were passed for payment.

Memorandum:

- Director -

The following is a report on the activities of the Welfare Division during the month of October.

The volume of the work in this Division increased considerably during the month as many of our Indian Agents, having completed their field work, are bringing their office work up to date. Reports received from across the Dominion show that crops on the whole have been rather disappointing. The western agencies had a very late spring followed by a hot summer and a very wet autumn. In many agencies harvesting has not been completed by the end of October. Our Indian Agent at Pelly reports that they had a splendid crop on their Community Farms. He mentions one field of oats, 57 acres, which threshed out more than 90 bushels to the acre. Indian gardens have been poor and the Branch will be faced with the necessity of supplying considerable quantities of seed potatoes next spring. We have had numerous complaints from agencies across the Dominion of a shortage of land and shortening in the trading posts from which our Indians receive their winter supplies. Indians use large quantities of fats and usually purchase their winter supply when they leave for their hunting grounds. This year we have had many representations from merchants who are unable to obtain necessary supplies to outfit the Indians. In many instances Indians have proceeded to their hunting grounds without their minimum requirements of fats.

Dr. T. J. Orford, Indian Agent of the James Bay Agency, reporting on a visit made to the Fort George Band, stresses the economic and physical difference between the Indians who tramp on the coast and those who trap inland:

"The inlanders, about 255 in number, are noticeably better clothed and healthier appearing than the coastal hunters. In comparing fur incomes the reason becomes apparent - they constitute only one third of the band in numbers yet they trade more than two thirds of the total band fur hunt. The inlanders have good hunting and trapping grounds with sufficient fish, rabbits and birds to supply a fairly good diet basis and enough income from furs to keep well clothed and fairly well outfitted. The coastal people have poor game conditions and only one or two good fishing areas - and a low fur income. One noticeable feature of moving these people to hospital or to work is to see the rapid weight increase that begins immediately. Every youngster gains at least five pounds and I have seen as much as fifteen pounds increase in children around twelve years of age with three square meals a day."
The agent points out that the Welfare Division will in the future find it necessary to greatly increase expenditure on these Indians until "our Beaver Sanctuary comes into production". In comparison with these Indians the agent notes as follows:

"Moving down to Rupert's House and Nemaska we step into another world. The Hudson's Bay Company Sanctuary has been gradually increasing the beaver quota and this year the Department's Nottaway Sanctuary opens up. At Nemaska every head of family must have a beaver quota and a single man or woman requiring beaver for support has a quota. There is therefore no welfare issue of food or clothing required at present. Those who are crippled or too old to trap the fur for themselves are given the beaver by some other member of the family."

Speaking of the Indians housing accommodation at Nemaska the agent states:

"It is a very agreeable change from the usual type of James Bay Camp - this should be an easy band to control (tuberculosis) once we are able to undertake a full X-ray survey and hospitalise all those showing signs of the disease."

The agent points out that the Indians of Rupert's House having money to spare are asking for lumber to build houses, tent floors and walls, and make wooden sidewalks.

The agent further points out that Mrs. J.S.C. Watt, the widow of a Hudson's Bay Manager who first began beaver conservation is living at Rupert's House. She is operating a bakery which is apparently going to be very successful. The Indians, under her leadership, are constructing a community hall 106 feet long by 28 feet wide with cement foundation and pillars. The Indians are supplying the labour at $1.00 a day and have donated nearly $5,000.00 to defray the cost of construction in addition to promising more from this year's beaver hunt. The agent states "in my opinion it gives us as an Indian Department a very red face". The agent also mentions considerable unrest or agitation by certain members of the Moose Band. Apparently these people are followers of Jules Sicot.

Each year Dr. Orford carries out a gardening project at Moosonee. This year he reports that despite the cold spring and an early frost they will have sufficient seed potatoes for next year. Dr. Orford found that he was unable to grow beans in his garden so he requested the Branch to obtain a culture from the Dominion Experimental Farm. The result was most satisfactory. Three rows of beans were sown - two with the culture, and one without. The untreated seed did not germinate while the agent had a very heavy crop from the treated seed.

In connection with our garden competitions throughout the Dominion I would like to call your attention to the one held on the Moravian Indian Reserve. The first prize awarded for the best garden was a sixty-six piece dinner set, and the second prize awarded was a 9 x 15 rug. Agents throughout the Dominion have been encouraged to give prizes for garden competitions in kind instead of paying cash as Indians who receive cash spend it immediately while prizes in kind are proudly treasured by the recipient.
From reports received from agencies across the Dominion it appears that the Indians are enjoying full and profitable employment. In the Stuart Lake Agency the Farming Instructor states that on all reserves visited the Indians were employed in the logging industry, ties, pitprops and saw logs. There is plenty of work for all that are able and willing to work.

During the month a conference of agents, and Farming Instructors, of the Province of Saskatchewan, was held in Regina, to meet Colonel H. M. Jones, the Branch Supervisor of Family Allowances. In addition to Allowances many other problems were discussed and the following recommendations were submitted to the Branch:

1. An increase in the Farming Instructors' salaries
2. Further hospitalization facilities
3. B.C.G. vaccination of all Indian babies
4. Annual conferences with a senior representative of the Ottawa office present
5. The payment of day school teachers' salaries for the full twelve months of the year.

In addition, the conference recommended that Farming Instructors be supplied with an efficient means of transportation. At present the Farming Instructors either use their own cars, or horse and buggy. The Instructors have to cover considerable ground each day so the horse transport is not considered efficient enough, and a recommendation has been made that a light half-ton pick up truck be supplied to each Farming Instructor.

The Division is in receipt of a report from the Yukon advising us of an epidemic of influenza at Old Crow, Yukon Territory, during July and August. No medical service was available so the wife of Corporal E. A. Kirk, R.C.M.P., officer in charge of the detachment there, assumed control. She contracted influenza but had to take over again after a few days because the other white people at the Post became ill. This Division wishes to express its deep appreciation of the excellent service rendered by Corporal Kirk and Mrs. Kirk in this emergency.

During the month numerous sales of livestock were held throughout the Dominion. Prices were very good indeed and the income to the Indians concerned was very substantial.

| Hobbsma Agency | $1,030.28 |
| Blood          | $1,005.47 |
| Paigan         | $3,000.00 |

Last spring the Branch established a purebred herd in the Paigan Agency. The agent reports that "the herd has improved considerably in condition during the summer months. The calves born, five heifers and four bulls, are a fair bunch. Two of the bull calves are much better than the others and may develop into sires."
Reports received from every province across the Dominion indicate that Family Allowances are being used to good advantage by Indians in supplying them with that "necessary extra" which means the difference between living and existing. Indian children returning to our schools are better fed and better dressed than ever before.

The following report from Inspector Ostender would indicate the necessity of providing trained personnel to direct the activities of our Homemakers' Clubs. His recommendation to pay Farming Instructors' wives for their services in this connection is being given serious consideration—

"The new Homemakers' Clubs have been formed in this province and the only ones operating satisfactorily at the present time are the White Bear, Assiniboine, Thunderchild, and Meadow Lake Clubs. The success of a Homemaker's Club depends almost entirely upon the representative of the Department who is operating it. We have no Indian women with administrative ability and initiative sufficient to organise and keep a Homemaker's Club in operation. We have therefore had to depend almost entirely upon unpaid representatives of the Department. In most cases these are the wives of the Farming Instructors. When a man is being paid a lower salary than many of the men he knows with equal or less ability and working shorter hours it is hardly to be expected that his wife will have much energy and enthusiasm to assist him in his work with no further remuneration. Some ladies will do this but there are not many of them. The question of Homemakers' Clubs is intertwined with education and the administration of Family Allowances to the extent that it would appear that the best solution for the future is the appointment of a married day school teacher who will also find teaching in social service work and who can be paid a small additional salary for this work. Appointments of teachers in our day schools, like the appointment of our Farming Instructors, are not very attractive to the right class of people at the present time. On nearly every occasion when I have had an interview with a prospective Farming Instructor and told him what was expected of him and the salary which he would get he lost interest. I am informed by the Church authorities who have been given the task of finding day school teachers that they are faced with practically the same replies."

Agent Swartman of the Sioux Lookout Agency has reported that the Indians of Lee Soul, Osmaburgh, Trout Lake, Fort Hope, and Martin Falls Bands, have had a good early summer fish catch. He also notes that much of the profit of this industry goes to the transportation companies. The Trout Lake Band, at Hijicon, has a good estate of sturgeon and caviar in May, but had to pay the Canadian Pacific Airlines .20¢ per pound to have their produce transported to the market (railway). The Fort Hope and Martin Falls Bands engaged in commercial fishing for Austin Airways who paid them .15¢ per pound this summer at the fishing grounds as against .10¢ per pound in 1944.
