The following is a report on the activities of the Welfare Division during the month of November.

During the month the Division was extremely busy completing preparation of Welfare and Agency Estimates for the fiscal year 1946-47. This is the first time that the Welfare Division has had to prepare Agency Estimates, and the task was complicated to some extent by the absence of last year's work sheets.

Mr. Morris returned from an inspection trip of the Maritime Provinces around the middle of November. Since his return one stenographer has been engaged full time typing his reports. As the other stenographer was working on the typing of Estimates considerable trouble was experienced in handling current correspondence. Mr. Roberts helped solve the problem by doing his own typing. The writer could not overcome his difficulties that way as the "hunt and poke" method he uses is very slow to say the least.

At long last the bylaws of the St. Regis Band have been revised in such a manner as to receive the approval of the Band Departmental Solicitor. The Band officials have been toiling over these bylaws during spare minutes for a period of over two months. It certainly is a relief to see them on their way to the Indian Agent, for approval of the Band before placing them with the Privy Council for authorization.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province of Manitoba, has forwarded a report (copy of which is attached) on fishing operations in the Lake Winnipeg district during the 1945 season. He shows an income of $79,338.13 from this industry. The Branch is at present canvassing the possibility of recovery of oil from fish offal to provide the fats so badly needed by our northern Indians. In this connection I would like to express the thanks of the Division to the Fisheries Research Board of Canada for information placed at our disposal.

Now that the Estimates are to the fore I think this would be a very opportune time to call the attention of the powers that be to housing conditions that exist among our Indians. Recently a report was received from our Field Nurse, Miss Ruth Bohman, whose territory covers the Saddle Lake and Lesser Slave Lake agencies. The particular reserve mentioned - Beaver Lake - is in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

"In October 10 I made a visit to the Beaver Lake Reserve. The condition of the Indians up there is appalling. Most of the houses were at this time undergoing repair for the winter. Most of the..."
homes on that reserve are very poorly built and have insufficient windows—most of them having only one which measures about 24" x 24". I also checked the water supply and found one well that was more than a mere hole in the ground. Most of the drinking water comes from either stagnant sloughs or else dug outs in the marsh lands. The water was biologically tested at the Provincial Lab and the reports filed at this office, and several specimens were reported positive "unfit for human consumption".

There are 9 school age children that are not at school (and there were a number of families not at home) some of these children, ages ranging from 7 to 15, who have never been to school.

There is a special case I would like to draw to your attention Doctor. Flora Gladue, who is suffering from an acute eye condition—10 years of age. I was unable to examine the child because of parental objections. I tried to reason with the family but of no avail. The child is partially blind and I advised the parents to take the child to Lee in Biche to see the Doctor there. To date the parents have made no effort to get medical attention. Is there anything that can be done in these cases where the parents refuse to have a child treated. They are paying a heavy price. I am sure the child will lose her sight. The children on this reserve are suffering badly from malnutrition and Tuberculosis. All in all the health picture at Beaver Lake is a sad one.

Several trips were made to Goodfish Reserve and here the conditions are considerably better. Here too the houses were undergoing repair. A number of children here were suffering from Dysentery. A number of Indians are using the water from the Whitefish Creek and I sent specimens to the Lab. The report came back "positive".

Provision has been made in the 1946-47 Estimates to carry out a program of building and repairing Indian houses. It is hoped that when this program is completed conditions such as those mentioned by the nurse will not exist anywhere in the Dominion of Canada.

For a number of years the Branch operated the Community Farm on the Oak Lake Indian Reserve, in the Griswold Agency, Province of Manitoba. During this period of operation a considerable credit was built up in trust funds at Ottawa from proceeds of crops sold. Last spring the Community Farm was divided among twelve Indian farmers who were supplied with implements, horses, and harness, to operate this land. At that time the Branch was a little dubious of the success of this venture but the agent's report shows that the Indians have used the land and equipment to very good advantage. The agent states as follows:

"The results of this year's farming by these Oak Lake Indians proves that they really can do very good work, and I feel that this was a venture worth while. With the yields received and the good price of grain, these Indians all have a good income. You will note that one of the smallest farmers, Mr. Daniel, with 21 acres seeded, got 377 bushels of wheat and 150 bushels of oats. This gives him an income of $7777.00. Another Indian, Mr. Chukas, with 42 acres of wheat and 31 acres of oats has an income of $1777.00. Let us hope that this proves to these farmers that work well done at the proper time really pays, and that they will continue to work and produce crops like they have done this year."
During the month the Branch was advised by the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch, that they proposed to slaughter surplus elk at Banff and Jasper National Parks this fall, as follows:

1) 400 Elk, Banff National Park
2) 250 Elk, Jasper National Park

The meat of these animals, with the exception of a small quantity required by the Alternative Service Work Camps, was donated for the use of our Indians. Our Inspector of Indian Agencies, for the Province of Alberta, was advised in the matter and he made all the necessary arrangements for the slaughter and handling of the meat.

FEAST OF ALL SAINTS

On the feast of All Saints, we went around wishing each other a happy feast — for it is said that we are all "Saints in the making." So many people came to Mass and Holy Communion that day; we are always glad when so many come for we know it must be very pleasing to God, and then too, it gives us a chance to see our friends and relatives who cannot come here very often. In the afternoon, Sisters Ray, etc., and Jean Picard came with the singers for a truck ride. Dan Quinn had his driving and he took us as far as the station at Maida. Just as we reached there, we saw the St. Bruno car going by. They didn't stop, but we waved waved our hands for they were in a hurry. We found out afterwards that they were taking a patient to the hospital at High Prairie. When we came back, some boys were talking about dinner. George Fraser said, "Don't talk about dinner, or I'll eat all of you up!" I guess his ride had made him very hungry. We enjoyed our ride very much although it was quite cold, and we were glad that we were singers, for the other boys and girls did not have the same privilege as we had.

Next day was All Souls' Day. The people came in great crowds, because they wanted to go down to the graveyard with the Fathers and Sisters to pray for the dead. We prayed all the way down, and when we got there, we sang the "Liberation" and recited many prayers. There are three Bishops buried here, also three priests, two Brothers and four Sisters of Providence. This little cemetery is in the center near the big cross, and is locked off from the rest. All around are the graves of the people who are taking their last sleep, waiting for the Lord to blow his trumpet on the last day.

Urban Collin——Sr. VII.

VISITORS

On Nov. 5th, our Indian aunt, Mr. L'Héroux, visited our school. We were glad to see him. He said he could try to come and visit us often this year. We hope he doesn't change his mind for he is always a welcome visitor to our school. When he left, Jimmy Thomas asked him if we could have a holiday. Mr. L'Héroux and Fr. Fulher laughed—but we got the holiday alright! Come again!! — Gerard Thibeault—Sr. VI.
HAPPY FEAST!

Fr. Lajoie had his feast on Nov. 13th. He said Mass at 6:30 AM in the Convent chapel. We sang hymns during the Mass and prayed for him. After breakfast, Fr. Falher and Floo' and Sr. Superior came to the halls with Fr. Lajoie. He spoke to us about hunting and he told us that he would like to spend a longer time with us. Before he left, he gave us a treat of candy. Then we gave three loud cheers that filled the church. He is Vicar General because he is taking Bishop Guy's place. Would we have had a holiday if it hadn't been Saturday?--- Roy Smith -- Gr.V.

ELECTIONS

The elections for the Children of Mary officers was held on Nov. 16th. We had been waiting anxiously for this event for a long time, so that night we all gathered in the Girls' Refectory to hold our meeting. Rev. Fr. Falher, Sr. Superior Sr. Jean Placidus, and the two Sisters in charge of the girls at the time, Sr. M. Thea and Sr. Guy of the Senior were all present. It was an easy election, for almost everyone seemed to have the same intentions, and soon, we saw that our new President was Helen Miller, the Vice-President, the same as last year: Rosalie Webb. When Mary Collins was elected as Secretary, she had all the votes except three. The three newly elected officers thanked us for the honor we had given them, promised to do their best, and then shook hands and received the congratulations of Fr. Falher and the Sisters. When Fr. Falher announced to us that Rev. Fr. Kindervater would be our new Director, we clapped and cheered with joy, for we knew that our conferences would be interesting.

That same day, our class went to the Club meeting of Lister Benigna's pupils. It was most interesting and all well done. We thanked Sister and the Junior Club for having given us such an interesting half hour, and we told them we hope they will entertain us soon again.

Mabel Gladu --- Gr. VI.
ST. THERESE'S CLUB MEETING

On Nov. 16th, we had our club meeting. We invited Sr. Jean Placideus and her pupils in our schoolroom. Alexis Cardinal jiggled while Sister Jean played the organ. Therese Aussent recited a poem "Jesus Tender Shepherd" as a night prayer. Then Elsie Phillips sang a song called "I'm a Grey Little Eskimo". After her song, Roger Quirion told a good joke. These are some of the things we did. We like to have the meetings and hope they will enjoy the next one too, because Sister Jean Placideus said that she enjoyed it very much. We are trying to live up to our aims.

Therese Aussent --Gr. V...... Jim Andrew --Gr. IV.

A SILVER JUBILEE

On Nov. 19th it was Sr. Mary Thea's silver jubilee. It was twenty-five years that she was a sister. But she was not all that time in Croward. She stayed in some other missions as a school teacher. Many of the older pupils had her for a teacher when they were in the lower grades. We prayed for her and wished her a happy feast. On her Silver Jubilee, Fr. Falhor granted us a half-holiday. We enjoyed sliding in the afternoon. George Fraser --Gr. V...... Alfred Thibault --Gr. IV.

A TOFFY FILL

We looked forward to the feast of St. Catherine, for it is a Canadian custom to make toffy on that day. We are like all children; we love sweets of any kind, and with dear old Sister Duguay as Toffy Chief, we are sure to get a big share. So the toffy began to boil two days before, so that the girls could get it all pulled in time. We were always trying to find an excuse to go to the kitchen so we could smell it even if we were not lucky enough to get a piece from the friendly cooks. We had a sweet, sticky evening, and a happy one because we ate toffy to our hearts' content.
That same day, our teacher took us to see the Boys' new house. It was lovely although it was not yet finished. I was so busy looking at the big steam furnace that I did not notice that I was behind the others, and just as I came out from the furnace room, a man standing on the elevator at the third floor threw down a board which almost hit me on the head. For the first time in my life, I was swift and got out of the way just on time. This is the third year that we go visiting the new house on the feast of St. Catherine. Two years ago, Sister took us to see the new barn. Last year, Sr. Superior was doing the first washing in the new laundry, so Sr. Jean took us to see it, so we could see the big electric washers at work. Will there be something to visit next year, we wonder?

Nellie Ghostkeeper, one of our old pupils who has been at the Mission for many years finally decided to get married, and on the feast of St. Catherine, she and Louis Cordinal were married by Rev. Fr. Proulx in the Fathers' chapel. The newly married couple had the wedding supper at the Fathers' Refectory, after which they came to see the Sisters and the girls. We wished them good luck and gave them some stuffy. So it was a very interesting day for us, and I hope I will be here in the Mission to celebrate the next St. Catherine's day.

Maggie Budskin---Gr.VI.

RETREAT FOR THE CHILDREN

From Dec. 5th to the 8th, we had our retreat in the chapel. Rev. Fr. Floc'h preached it and he explained things well, because everybody could understand what he said. There were four instructions every day, two in English and two in Cree. He pointed out to us how to try to become better and to be very good Catholics. Since we had our retreat, we will try to be very good and be pious little children. We had Benediction in the Chapel every night. We surely enjoyed our retreat very much this year.

Victorine Bellrose. --- Gr. V.

While Fr. Floc'h was here preaching the retreat, Fr. Falher went to Sturgeon Lake to preach to the Children there. When he came back he brought Fr. Roué.
RECEPTION FOR THE CHILDREN OF MARY

On the feast of the Immaculate Conception, eight of us girls were received as Children of Mary. We were all dressed in white for the ceremony which was very beautiful. Before Benediction, Fr. Kindervater, our director, spoke to us very briefly on the joy of being a Child of our Heavenly Mother, saying that when we begin to approach what our mother does for us, as she begins to grow up.

Father then blessed our candles and gave them to us, and while he was blessing our badges, Helen Miller, our president, and Rosalie Webster, our Vice-President, lighted them for us. After our beautiful new badges were given to us, we recited our Act of Consecration. Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament came next, after which we went to the hall and received the congratulations of our director, and Sr. John Placidus, our directress.

When we went to supper, we were so surprised and happy to see a special table prepared for us, the nuns members, and our officers. Sister Josephine had arranged the table with beautiful bouquets of flowers. We had a very nice supper, and a very gay time. To thank Sr. Josephine Augustin for all she did for us, also Sr. Superior for the beautiful pictures which pleased us so much. That night the C. of Mary had a reunion in our classroom, where Fr. Kindervater showed us such lovely pictures with his electric machine. It was all about the life of St. Ann and the Blessed Virgin Mary. As he showed us the pictures, Father told so many interesting stories that the time just flew by, and all of a sudden, it was 8:30.

We sang songs; some of the girls did some special dances, and then to finish up the evening right, Fr. Kindervater sang a song in German. The other girls had been in bed quite a while when we tiptoed in....so happy over that beautiful day. It is my first year in the Mission and all these things are so new to me, but I am...
so proud to be a Child of Mary at last, and will do my best to do all that we have been advised to do by those who are in charge. Dorothy Phillips — Gr. VIII.

MORE ANGELS IN THE HOUSE!!!!

On Sunday, Dec. 12th, nine little girls were received into the Guardian Angel Society. After Fr. Fisher had blessed the bridges and given a nice little instruction, we said our Act of Consecration. That evening we chose our officers. They were Margaret Ander, Florence Noskeyl and Viola Willier.

That same afternoon three children were baptized. They are Annie, Smith and Peter Kassapomatto. They came from White Fish Lake, but have been staying here since school started. They are happy now because they were anxious to be baptized.

Elsie Phillips — Gr. LV.

ARRIVALS

Rev. Fr. Lajoie has just returned from a business trip to Ottawa. He went there with Bishop Guy. We are sure he had a pleasant time, and we hope he had good success in what he planned to do on that trip.

Sister McReilly, who went away from here in September because she was very ill, gave us a big surprise by coming here on Dec. 10th. She had been in Vancouver B.C., where she had to have an operation, but to everybody's surprise, she got better almost right away, so she decided to give the Sisters here a surprise, by coming back. We were all so glad to see her back; we had prayed for her every day while she was gone. I suppose she will soon be taking care of the sick people again because she is a good nurse.

Ernest Giroux — Gr. VIII.
A RED LETTER DAY

When it was decided that the boys' house was to be blessed on Dec. 14th, Rev. Fr. Lejole asked Bishop Guy if he would please come for that great day. The Bishop was in the midst of his Xmas rush, but because he wanted to make us very happy, he consented to come. When we heard that he was coming, we children began to count the hours. Before Mass on Tuesday morning, no one could keep quiet. When Sister started playing the march in the chapel our hearts began to thump. They thumped harder as we saw our dear Bishop Guy coming in with a smile on his face. I guess if it hadn't been in the chapel, we would all have eloped and married — but we couldn't so during Mass we sang with all our hearts to thank God for this great joy. After Mass we waited for him in the dining room. When he came out of the chapel we greeted him so joyously. He told us he was happy to come here, and he showed it too. You might say we were lucky but we would have enjoyed it more if he could have stayed with us longer.

Helen Miller — Gr. VII.

At eleven o'clock, we had such joy on seeing Bishop Guy coming in to bless the boys' building. We were so happy because he kept his promise in coming to see us soon. The children first sang a welcome song to show that even if Bishop Guy doesn't live here he will always be welcome in his former home. The song was followed by an address read by Frank Giroux. Then His Excellency gave us a very nice and interesting talk. How glad we were when he said that in a few weeks' time Mr. Christ would be coming to help Fr. Lejole. How everyone clapped! We know that the Bishop remembers us because he came here from many miles to bless the house of the boys, and he travelled many more hours than the hours he stayed here in Grouard. We surely hope that he will come to visit us soon again and that he will stay longer. May God bless him always!

Ruth Jordan — Gr. VIII.

That evening the carpenters put on a program for the special benefit of the Bishop. Wasn't it funny to see the working men dressed as girls? One I enjoyed was a play called "The Troubles of Cowen", acted by Mr. Paulet and Noel Fortin. Mr. Paulet was
phoning to someone asking for a man to fix the shutter and the other understood "shut up". When he first started to phone he would repeat "Hello, are you there?" so many times that it made us laugh just to hear it. The other would get off the subject, and Mr. Prulet would say "Oh Pshaw!" and again repeat "Hello, are you there?" There were six numbers on the program and all were very interesting. The program was under the direction of Mr. Barulieu, the main boss.

I think the best actors were Mr. Portelance and his son, Rudolph. They made us laugh so much that the tears were just rolling down our cheeks. In a play called "Scientific Dentistry", Mr. Portelance pulled out a tooth from Mr. Audier. That was the funniest play I had ever seen, because he used a butcher knife, big pliers and a rope to take the tooth out, and when the tooth finally came out, the dentist and the patient both fell down on the floor from the shock. Mr. Barulieu sang a beautiful song called, "Pray, Love and Sing". Everyone enjoyed the program very, very much.

Mabel Noskoyi --- Gr. VIII.

If you want to see the boys' magnificent new building follow me and I will show it to you. Let us go inside up the steps by the front door that we see in the picture. Now those three windows to the west end the one to the east is the boys' Recreation Hall. The other two windows to the east is the refectory. The floor is made entirely of cement; the walls are plastered.

Now let us go upstairs. The stairs are not made yet so the men make a ladder-stairs. It is rather shaky, be careful or you'll tumble down and break your neck maybe! The second story contains all of the dormitory. At the western end is the Infirmary, locker, and Sister Mary's room. At the other end are Sr. Henriette Eugenie's room and bath rooms.

Now to the basement - first let us go to the Engine Room. There is a wonderful big furnace here which heats the whole house with steam. Near the furnace is a tank which holds 500 gallons of hot water. I guess the boys will have clean hands, and clean dishes after this! There are bathrooms, a baggage room and a tank room.
The rest of the basement is the laundry. The machines haven't arrived yet so we are waiting for them. There are no hot air grates; instead we have radiators in the rooms.

When His Excellency, Mgr. Joseph Gay blessed the building, the priests who accompanied him were Fathers Lejoie, Falher, Floch, Kindervater and Proulx.

Brother Nicol and Mr. A. Beaulieu also accompanied them. They said some special prayers for the house blessing. It is the only house that is entirely fire-proof from Edmonton up to the North Pole, so you see we have reason to be proud!

GRATITUDE AND WISHES

It has been very flattering and pleasing for us to have received such kind encouragement in our work; "The Grouard Echoes" has many generous friends whom we wish to thank most sincerely today for their kindness. We wish to thank very specially, our inspector, Mr. Gilles, for his encouraging letter which we highly appreciated — also that of our Indian Agent, Mr. L'Houroux. May we offer our sincerest thanks also to all those generous friends who so kindly sent us financial aid? We were deeply touched by so much kindness and we are most grateful.

Once again the beautiful season of Christmas is here — and once again, we offer to our friends, all the loving wishes that we have in our hearts for them. To our many readers, far and near, we extend our sincerest wishes for a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year, praying that the Divine Babe may hear our prayers on your behalf and grant you your hearts' desires.

Merry Christmas! ———— Happy New Year!

God bless you!

The Editors.

"PER CRUCEM AD LUCEM"

They are gone, those beautiful days so filled with happiness and blessings! We gaze slowly and sadly around us... all speaks to us of him who was our father, our friend, our advocate for seven happy years. We recall the Mission as it was before his arrival. We admire now—our beautiful new school, the renovated convent, the enlarged play yards, the spacious barns and sheds, the comfortable homes for our employees, and last of all, the wonderful new building for the boys—a lasting monument to his loving solicitude—and we realize fully all that our dear Bishop has done for us. The realization fills our hearts with gratitude but overwhelms us also with poignant regret for our loss. To escape from the loneliness that surges over us, we mount slowly to the classroom. But here again, we're met with reminders of his affectionate interest: the piano, the music cabinet, the beautiful pictures on the wall, the typewriter, our printing machine, and countless other treasures speak to us of our loss. Gazing up into his pictured face smiling down so kindly at us from the piano, we say:

"O kindest of fathers! it is hard, bitterly hard to give you up! You have been a kind, good father to all your flock, but to us, your Ground children, you have been more than a friend, more than a father; you have been an inspiration. God bless you for your loving kindness, your interest in all that concerned us! God bless you for having given us so beautiful an example of Christlike charity! You are gone, dear Father, and we are missing you, but in your new field of action, God bless you, we pray. And through the years, when memory brings the picture of your kindly face before us, we shall murmur softly, "Dear Bishop Guy, God bless you!"

"There is never a life without sadness, There is never a heart free from pain;
If one seeks in this world for true solace, He seeks for it ever in vain.
So, when to your poor heart comes sorrow, The deepest, perhaps, you have known.
'Tis the touch of God's sickle at harvest, Since He reaps in the fields He has sown."
VACATION.

We were glad to hear that Bishop Breynat was coming to visit us one day. Suddenly we heard something like an airplane and began to look around for it. Then we went down to the lake to see Bishop Breynat who was there. That evening, the Fathers and sisters and everybody went to see the plane. The pilot took some for a short ride; for some it was their first experience. When Mgr. Chrest and Mr. Mass went up, the pilot made loops and circles. When they came down again, the riders looked very white and sickly! They left the next morning at nine o'clock; it was beautiful to see the rising of the airplane. We hope to see them again.

Roy Smith -- Grade V.

We find many kinds of wild berries in the woods. There were more raspberries than any other kind of berries this year. There were quite a few choke cherries and cranberries too. It rained too much in August and the raspberries would fall off. There were too bad to go berry picking too. Last year there were many a little but there were not many this year.

Corr. Dossierkiss -- Harold Austen, Gr. V.

On Sunday, July 25th, we went for the pilgrimage of St. Anne at St. Bruno Mission. We got up very early so we could arrive there for the ten o'clock Mass. After our dinner, we visited the peoples' tents, and enjoyed it very much. Around two o'clock we had the procession. They sang some hymns while Bishop Guy carried the Blessed Sacrament. He told the people that this was the last pilgrimage yet because there were so many for the High Mass and other ceremonies. Afterwards we went to town with Sister Francis Desireé and played around for a while, then went back to Groulx. We enjoyed the day very much.

Malbo Cardinal -- Grade V.

Merry Ann Cardinal was married to John Smith on August 25th. She wore a long white satin dress. Everything she had on was white, even her slippers. The witnesses were Agathe Cardinal with Henry Tomkins, Nellie Ghostkeeper with Harry Thomas, and Nancy Thomas with Leo Dufrane. Father Bemerge said the Mass and gave a nice little talk. They had a nice breakfast at the Fathers' house afterwards.
SCHOOL DAYS! SCHOOL DAYS!

"Yes, we came all the way in the Mission truck, but we stopped at St. Bruno's for dinner. I was so surprised and sorry to hear that Sister Bernadette Clare is teaching there this year instead of in Grouard. Who is replacing her here? Sister Guy of the Savior? Are Mrs. Louis du Bois Pastuer and Henriette Eugenie the only two new Sisters this year? I'm sorry that Sister Françoise Désirée and Sr. George Wilfred are gone; we will miss them both, won't we? But I'm so glad that Sr. Mary Thecla and Sr. Jean Placidus are back from their visit to the United States. How hard I prayed for them while they were far away, so that they would come back here again.

What's the new Father's name? What? Father Kindervater? Isn't he jolly? I saw him talking to Father Beaucage, and when I heard Fr. Kindervater laugh I had to laugh too, though I didn't know what they were laughing about! My! What a beautiful house the boys are going to have! Is it true the Mission trucks are hauling day and night? And they say there are thirty men working there—many of them experts from Saskatchewan or Southern Alberta. Pardon me? O, yes, indeed! I'm glad to be back at school! Especially since I am to be in the Senior class this year and to be Sr. Jean's pupil! How anxious I am for morning so I can start in. I will always consider tomorrow a red-letter day!

Jean Bellrose—Grade VI.

When Sister Jean Placidus came home to Grouard after three long months away from us, she brought back many nice things for the classroom. We were so glad to hear that her brother had given her a nice Brunswick portable with many records. Sister also brought her mother's radio for the school. Now in our class, we have three nice musical instruments. The Jesuit Fathers in Icikin gave Sr. M. Thecla fifty nice rolls for our piano. So you can imagine what a musical year we will have! Some of Sister Jean's friends also gave her many nice pictures and books which we enjoy looking at? Don't you wish you were in our classroom? I'm sure you do!

Mabel Noakewi—Grade VIII. Simone Dufrane—Sr. VE
The old pupils who are continuing their studies went back to their different schools. Nancy Thomas, Mary Jane Sinclair and Nora Mohr went back to St. Augustine's at Peace River, but Florence Cunningham went to the Normal at Calgary.

Paul Hurubise who was at the Junior College with Harry Thomas is now going to the Jesuit College with the Fowrgus boys. Harry Thomas of course is back at the Junior too. He wrote and said that Greek is no big job! Two of our last year's pupils are keeping on their studies: Jonny Gordon is going to school at High Prairie and Raymond L'Hirondelle is going to High School at Peace River. Good luck to you, dear old schoolmates!

JIMMY THOMAS --- Gr. VIII.

MOTHER PROVINCIAL'S VISIT

Mother Provincial came here in the beginning of July to visit. Sister Mary Theola and Sister Jean Pléchais did not see her because they were not here. So when they came back, Sr. Superior went with them to McLennan to see Mother Provincial as she was there then. Then they came back they brought Sister Mireille with them; she went to the hospital in August. On Sept. 12th, Mother came with Sr. Gertrude McGillis but left the next day. Sr. Mireille stayed here about fifteen days and then went to Vancouver to have an operation. We are praying so she will be well again.

MRS. RUTZINGER --- Gr. V.

THE NEW BUILDING

The new house that they are making for the boys is beautiful. It is of brick and it is 110 feet long by 40 feet wide. It is three stories high and is entirely fireproof. The floors are made of cement. For the ceilings they have many big irons and iron pillars to hold it up. The walls are made of brick and tiles. They will put some plaster on the walls of the house to make it nicer. The outside of the house is made of bricks and there is a cross made of cement in the front center. On the right hand side of the cross is written A.D. which means "In the
year of the Lord" or "Anno Domini" as they say in Latin. On the left side is marked 1937. We are very proud of that house because it is the only fireproof building in the country. In our next issue, we will describe it and perhaps draw a picture of it for you.

George Califer -- Gr. VIII ... Jeremie Cardinal -- Gr. VII.

During vacation, Mrs. Quirion with her daughter and Yvonne Dion cooked for all the hired men who were working on the new building. A few weeks ago Mrs. Quirion was seriously hurt in an automobile accident and is now in the McLennan hospital. Since then the working men are having their meals at the man's refectory. Mr. and Mrs. Assent and their children are now living in Mrs. Quirion's house which was Mr. Lizée's house before. Mr. and Mrs. Lizée are now in charge of the mission farm.

Lena Twin -- Gr. VI.

MORE CHANGES

About two weeks ago, Rev. Fr. Lejoie, the changed from St. Augustine's Mission so he could come here to replace the Bishop until the new Bishop arrives. We bid Fr. Lejoie a hearty welcome to Ground and we promise to be so pleasant that he will not be too lonesome for his Peace River children.

Fr. Beauchamp our dear Catechism teacher left us to go to be the Superior of Peace River Mission. We were very sorry to see him go because he was so good to us. But Fr. Proulx who was sick in the McLennan hospital came back and is now teaching us Catechism. We like him very much and hope he may be a good teacher like Fr. Beauchamp.

Sister A. Riberdy came here a few weeks ago to replace Sr. Marcelline as Sacristan. Sister has a twin sister whom she left at Kenora, but we are hoping she may come and join her sister here soon.

Annie Thomas -- Gr. VII.

Mrs. Walter - driving through the country saw two regimentmen climbing a telephone pole. "These men," she said haughtily, "must think I never drove a car before."
**POATOE**

One morning while we were in school studying, one of the sisters came and told Sr. Jean Flechidus that we were going to start the potatoes. We were kind of glad because we knew we were going to have fun. When we went to the big field on the other hill we didn't know the boys were trying to beat us. Then we heard that we started counting our sacks. Also, but were beaten by the boys, we had picked 1500 sacks of potatoes. While we were picking, the men were finishing the new root cellar which is all made of cement. We knew the potatoes will not rot so easily now. The following Saturday Sr. Mary Auxiliatrice and the boys went to the farm to pick all the potatoes for Mr. Lizée. They had much fun and enjoyed the truck ride too.

Frank Giroux --- Gr. VI.

**INSPECTOR'S VISIT**

One morning we heard that Mr. Gillis, our new inspector, was coming to our classroom. We were anxious to see him, yet we were rather afraid to go to school. But as soon as we saw him, we decided we liked him because he reminded us so much of Mr. Lizée, the Bishop's chauffeur. Mr. Gillis is tall, has brown eyes and a gentle smile. He stayed in our room all forenoon, and we enjoyed every minute of it. Before he left, we sang several songs for him. If he enjoyed his visit as much as we did, Mr. Gillis must have pleasant memories of Grouard!

Helen Miller --- Gr. VII.

**FAST DAYS**

On September 29th, we had a good holiday because it was Sr. Superior's feast. We enjoyed playing the gramophone in the girls' hall. In the afternoon all the boys and girls had each an apple, some candy and ice-cream which tasted very good. We also had a little program in the girls' hall. It was done only by a few girls. Some sang and others played different little games.

Rosalie Wabicon --- Gr.VI.
On the eve of Fr. Falher's feast, we had an interesting program. How happy we were that Bishop Guy and Mgr. Charost were here to unite their wishes to ours for our pastor's feast. All the Fathers and Sisters came, also the men working at the mission came with their wives.

The program was started by a beautiful festal song then Ernest Giroux read the address. We played Fr. Falher's favorite pieces on our flutes, then Fred Giroux as Uncle Podgor caused a lot of excitement and laughter by his accidents, when trying to hang a picture. We also reported our "Historical Trivologic." The German song, on account of its queer sounding words, nearly took the house down. I'm sure Fr. Bruckert would have been proud to see that we remembered so well the song he taught us last spring.

Dorothy Phillips — Gr. VIII

Mgr. Charost came with the big red truck to get us dry scholars for the concert in honor of Fr. Falher, because we older girls were in the program. As soon as we got to the Mission, Sr. John Precious brought us into the chapel for benediction. All the people then came in the classroom where the concert was taking place. After all was over Sr. Superior brought two big pans full of apples which Fr. Falher gave to all the children. When it was time to go home Mgr. Charost got Bishop's car and he took us home in it. We were all very glad because it is not often we have a chance to ride in the Bishop's car. We'll think of dear Mgr. Charost for his kindness. Fr. Falher said that he enjoyed this program better than any other he had attended for a long time.

Kathleen Morton — Gr. VI

It happened that Mgr. Charost's feast came the next day after Fr. Falher's, so on the sixth of October (his birthday) he said Mass in our chapel. The hymns were lovely, and we tried our very best to sing well for it was his last feast in Grouard.

Margie Budskin — Gr. VI
ELECTIONS

We the pupils of Grade IV and Grade V had our elections on Oct. 1st. We chose Mary Twin for President, Victor Twin for our vice-president and Victoria Ballerose for our Secretary. We wanted to have it on Oct. 1st because it was near the feast of St. Therese of the Child Jesus. Sister explained our motto to us and she also talked about our patroness. Our aims are to be obedient, speak out in class and to give good example. Our motto is "Onward and Upward" and our colors are pink and green, the same as last year.

Charlotte Gladu — Gr. IV.

FAREWELL TO THESE

I had never thought that such sad days could come to the Mission, for I had been here over four years, and I thought that it would always be a happy place in which to live. I realize now what sadness is, because ever since June when we heard that our dear Bishop and his secretary would be leaving us, our hearts have been very sad. Now that they are gone, we are lonesome and wish the dear Lord had not taken them away from us. But I suppose this is our cross which we must carry bravely if we want to reach Heaven some day.

Bishop Guy and Msgr. Cherest had been away for some time because they went to assist at the Churchill Jubilee, and when they came back, we realized that they had just one month left to stay with us. Many people came from all over to see them before they left and to say Goodbye. As October 20th drew nearer and nearer, we became very sad. On October 17th, all the people of Grouard came to the Girls' Hall where a Farewell reunion was held. It was very hard to sing and to talk, but we did our best to make our last little concert nice. Floroma Shaw read a very beautiful and sad address; three times she had to stop, because she was crying. Dorothy Phillips recited a very touching poem, and then two girls sang a song called "We'll Not Forget" which made many people cry. Then Frank Giroux, who always makes everyone laugh when he is in a play, came to speak his lines ... but instead,
he burst out crying, and could not say a word. After the children finished their parts, Fr. Falher got up and told the Bishop how grateful we were for all he had done for us, and expressed his deep regret over the departure of both His Excellency and his devoted secretary. Then Mr. Ausetant read an address in French, Willie Hébert read one in Cree, then Mrs. Maurice spoke in English, saying that our loss is Or. Volbourg's &c. Dan Cunningham expressed the regrets of the Half-Breeds while Mgr. Thomas-Giroux spoke for the old pupils.

When all the speeches were over, Bishop Guy got up to speak. How attentively we listened to the last words of our beloved Bishop. He then presented a beautiful certificate of Bravery from the Government to Sr. Mary Auxiliatrice and another to Harry Fraser for their heroism at the fire last winter, and told us to follow these examples. After that we all went outside to have our pictures taken, as a souvenir of our last reunion. Fr. Sorrent and the St. Bruno Sisters, also Fathers Bouveng and Mdeau from Peace River, were there too.

This morning, Oct. 20th, Mgr. Chrest said his last Mass in Grouard in our chapel at 11 a.m. Then the Bishop said his last six. We sang hymns, though we found it hard to do anything but cry—our hearts were so sad. At 8 o'clock, the Bishop, Mgr. Chrest and the Fathers went to the cemetery for a last prayer beside the quiet graves of the other three Bishops of Grouard, then all assembled for the last prayers and the blessing of our dear Bishop. Outside, the Bishop's car was waiting, and as soon as it started it was followed by the two big trucks filled with the children and Sisters. This was the first time we had gone for a ride on a sad occasion—as Fr. Falher had said, it was like a funeral. We went to the station, and watched the train coming. When we had waved our last Goodbyes and watched the train out of sight our hearts were very heavy for we realized that our kind Bishop was gone for good. Everyone said that our loss was a double one because Mgr. Chrest whom everyone loves, is gone too. We are glad that he will be near the Bishop to help him in all his cares, but we will miss Mgr. Chrest.
very much, because he was always so very kind and helpful to everybody. The Bishop promised us that they would both come back and pay us a visit some day. We hope that promise will come true very soon. Until then we are keeping our promise and are praying very hard, so that God may bless them both and make them happy in their new life.

Mary O'Keefe—Ruth Morden —Gr. VIII.

SOME DAY

Not now, but in the coming years,
When we have reached the Better Land,
We'll know the meaning of our tears,
And all we do not understand.

We'll know why friends we love the best
Are forced to leave us with our woes,
Why strangers come to take their place,
Whose hearts are not as true as theirs.

Hope, then, my soul, the God of old
Is guiding thee with kindly hand.
The plan of life He'll soon unfold,
When we meet in the Better Land.

Re-organization of Our Magazine.

Rev. Father Balter, Sister Superior and the teachers had a meeting and decided that the four classrooms unite to publish a school journal. Each class-room will give short stories or articles and in this way all the pupils will help in the making of the school Journal. The name Blue Quills Moccasin Telegram will be the same as before. We will change the cover for Christmas so we will send them earlier.

Theresa Iaskweyak — Grade VII.

Story of the Blue Quills School

by the Senior Boys' Class.

We have read with much interest the Journals coming from the different Indian schools. We find them most interesting. It is the first time our class has written for a Journal, and we do it with pleasure. We would like to tell you something about our school so that we may be more acquainted. We have the benefit here of a large modern school. We know much work has had to be done in the past before it was possible to have this fine school. We owe much to the Oblates Fathers and the Sisters of Charity, whom we more often call the Grey Nuns. We, the pupils of the Boys' Class have been asked to tell the story of the Blue Quills school, so my friend Adolphus will begin farther on in this Journal.

Joseph MacGilvery — Grade VII.

Visit of Bishop Pallaise.

On November 4th Bishop Pallaise gave us a surprise by visiting us. He was with Father Lemoine, Provincial, and another priest. They arrived just in time for supper and there was great excitement in getting supper ready for them. I know this as I am working in the kitchen this month.

The next morning all the children went to attend the Bishop's Mass. Most of them went to holy Communion as it was the First Friday of the month. Of course we kissed his ring first and then we received the Host.

The Bishop and the two priests went to Frog Lake to bless the two crosses that are to mark the places where the two priests were murdered during the Riel Rebellion. (Father Marchand and Father Lafond.) The priests were killed there but their bodies were brought to St. Albert.

Roseanna Cardinal — Grade VII.

At Frog Lake.

My home is at Legoff. My grandfather's name was Delaney. He was a Farm Instructor at Frog Lake. My mother often spoke to me about my late grandfather who had been killed at Frog Lake about half a century ago. Rev. Father Lafond was going to hear my dying grandfather's confession when suddenly a shell of a gun went through him and Father Lafond fell dead to the ground. I am going to draw a picture of the two crosses that Father Langlois put up at Frog Lake.

Eric Martineau — Grade IV.

Doctor Hill's Visit.

On Wednesday, November 3rd, Dr. Hill, the Indian agent of Onion Lake came to visit our school with Joe John from there. Rev. Father Balter had a long talk with Dr. Hill while Joe John saw his two nieces, Theresa and Jeannette. Dr. Hill went away that same evening.

Jeanne Janvier — Grade VI.
A Narrow Escape

On Thursday afternoon, Nov. 18th, around three o'clock something very exciting happened.

Paul Fluet, a new employee was hauling coal from St. Paul with a team of horses. He drove to where they empty the coal and as they were peeling, one of the horses fell into the hole with his hind legs. His front legs and half of his body were on the top while the horses on him was all broken up. Four other employees came to help but they could not pull him out. Then they quickly ran in and tried to get him down by the inside. They at last succeeded. Then they led him out of the furnace room and then by the furnace. It was rather difficult for the poor horse to go up the stairway in going out again. But you buy imagine how gladly the horse galloped with joy when he was out again after such a hard struggle. Here is the picture I drew of how he looked when he fell in.

Therena Paqweyak — GPM VII.

Conclusion of The Story of Blue Quills School.

I wish to tell you first about the Fathers who at different times have been in charge of our school. While it was on the Sande Lake Reserve there have been besides the ones already mentioned: Father Levesque, Father Lefebvre and Anglin, who all helped us to make good reputations. Then I would like to say something about two of these Fathers whom I am glad to have as Principals while I was a pupil. First I began to like to remember Father Anglin who was here when I was a little boy and our prayers go in his behalf to the Great Master in Heaven. Besides, we would often hear about our good Principal Father Salter. After doing so many years of his life to the School when I was on the Reserve, he has come to us here in the Blue Quills.
To make you understand much in a few words I will say; we pray he may stay with us many years.

Arthur MacFetters - Grade VII.

A Mass for our Dead.

On Nov. 3rd Sister said that it would be fine to have a Mass for the children who died in our School. We started to give the money on Nov. 10th. When we knew that we could not pay the dollar we went to the boys' room and asked them if they would help us to pay the dollar. On Nov. 30th we had $1.05. Each of the four class-rooms had given something. We expected only a low Mass but Father Balter gave us a High Mass instead. The Requiem Mass was on the first of December and all the children sang the parts of the Mass. Here are the children who paid the money.

Fun on the Feast of St. Catherine.

We had lots of fun on St. Catherine's Feast. In the morning nearly all the girls went to Mass except those who had some work in the kitchen and in the dining-room.

At school we had an Arithmetic game the first, the second was Bible History and if we knew we put up our hands. The teacher called one to say it. After we had a peanut. When we went down to dinner we had some taffy. After supper all of the older girls went to help in the kitchen and in the dining-room that we could be finished early. Sister Houle waited for the kitchen girls. The Sisters from St. Theresa Hospital in St. Paul came and the Sisters all went up to the Sisters' parlor. Miss Marie Ange Thibert came to keep us. We played Bingo and the one who won got something. After we finished playing Bingo the girls started to dance. Three best players played mouth-organ. One came to take the place when one got tired. After we took our lunch and the Sisters did too. Then we went to bed.

Alice Nayottatik --- Grade IV.

Mr. Schmidt's Visit.

Mr. Schmidt, the Inspector, came on Friday, Nov. 27th but we did not know he was here. We were very surprised to see him on Saturday morning when we went to Mass. It was so nice to see him receiving Holy Communion. Monday morning Mr. Gullion, the Indian Agent, took him to Lac La Biche in his car. Mr. Schmidt came back on the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, Dec. 8th. We were glad to hear him sing so well and it gave us a good push. After High Mass, Sister Reule said that we sang loud that time. We were sure that we had pleased everybody. Agnes Cardinal said she hoped he would come back to help us sing on Christmas.

Jane Whiskyjack --- Grade V.

Wants to be wise like Solomon.

We have Catechism every day from 1:30 P.M. till 2 o'clock. When Father Balter cannot come our teacher teaches the lesson. We have Bible History. One of the stories I liked best was the way Solomon could find out to which woman the baby belonged. I was glad the mother got back her son. I wish to be wise like Solomon. Our History says he got wisdom because he prayed to the Lord for it. That made me think that I should pray much. Elie Noel - Gr. IV.

Give my best regards to all the pupils I knew, also to the Sisters.

Your very sincerely,
Robert Anderson.

Robert and his father are taking the treatment for Tuberculosis. They were in the General Hospital for about a year before going to the University Hospital.

Our New Skating Rink

We are working on a new skating rink. As soon as it is cold enough we will put on the water. Father Allard got us some new skates and some of the boys have new hockey sticks. We will have pleasure skating and playing hockey this winter.

François Blackman — Grade VI.

Jokes in Our School

One forenoon in the kitchen as a girl was filling her dessert bowl too much — with peaches — the Sister in charge of the cooking said; "Say, Catherine, that bowl is too full." The girl replied; "No Sister, it is because my bowl is too small."

On another occasion a little girl in grade two had to make a sentence with "whiskers" but did not know what it meant so she said; "The whiskers can run", thinking it was some kind of an animal.

Roseanna Cardinal — Grade VII.

Bible History Stories

We are making a booklet for Bible History, and we are pasting pictures in it. We are writing stories in it too, and this is the story I wrote about.

Sodom

The angels are coming with Lot and his two daughters. Lot's wife was turned into a pillar of salt because she turned back. The city was burned because there were too many wicked people. There is now a lake. It is called "Dead Sea". This story teaches us that God punishes the wicked people.

Margaret Cardinal — Grade IV.

News Items

Nancy Janvier was not well since she had the measles in June but she came back to school again on Oct. 9th. She stayed here for almost a month. Then she went to bed on Nov. 7th. When her came she had been taken to the hospital. She went home to Lagoff with her mother. Lately we heard that Nancy was feeling better.

Reverend Sister Superior went to St. Theresa Hospital to get all her teeth out. She went on Nov. 30th. She stayed four days in the hospital and came back on Saturday morning Dec. 4th.

Sister Ida Thibert works in the kitchen and she is a very good cook. On Nov. 29th she went to bed because she had the Grippe. She was taken to the hospital on Dec. 3rd. We all hope that she will soon recover from her sickness and come back again to our school.

Caroline Janvier — Grade VI.
Miss Theresa Paskey, President of the Tekakwitha Club,
Blue Quills Residential School.

November 27th, 1937.

Dear Friends,

I want to thank you in the name of my class for your kind invitation to join the School Paper Club. We enjoyed reading your club magazine and met copy would be most welcome. We have decided to make a little bit of money by selling our club magazine. We will be glad to help you with any questions you may have.

Your little Indian friends,

by Jean Baptiste Laflèche.

The pupils of Holy Family School.

November 27th, 1937.

Dear Sister,

Here I am to thank you for the kind letter such a happy surprise to poor little me in the land of ice and snow! I am very enthusiastic over your school magazine. I think it is a splendid way of broadening pupils' minds and getting them interested in something beyond their own little personal world. Pupils must be led to interpret others and the outside world. We will do that for us. After all, it's a self-centered, direct citizenship; besides being a tremendous opportunity for civilization and cooperation.

An old maid wished to marry a man but could not get him. So one evening she went in the church to pray. She did not see the priest who was there also. Thinking she was alone she knelt before the crib and began to pray out loud with great devotion. "Oh Lord, that I may marry this man! May he be good to me! Make him love me!" How We Expect to Spend Christmas.

We usually go to bed early after supper for we have to get up before twelve.

During the second and third Masses we sing hymns in Cree and English. After Mass we go down to the dining-room to take our lunch of doughnuts and cocoa. Then we go to bed for we are quite tired. In the morning we take our breakfast and besides we have some popcorn or sometimes apples.

During the day we play games and in the evening, that is the time we have the most fun, as we have our Christmas Tree.

All the boys and girls and the Staff are assembled in our room as usual. But Santa Claus comes in the last. He then starts to call each one and asks us to do something for him, such as singing and dancing; then he gives us the toys. We again get some more candies and peanuts.

So I hope we will have some fun again this year as we usually do.

Margaret Mary Large — Grade VI.
